A minor in Animal Sciences\nrequires a minimum of 16 credits of courses with\nthe ANIM SCI prefix. At least 9 of the 16 credits\nmust be upper-division, taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses, and include a\nminimum of 7 credits from the following list:\nANIM SCI 313, 330, 350, and/or 351. In addition,\nstudents may use up to 4 credits of ANIM SCI 399\nor 499. Students must maintain a minimum 2.0\nGPA within ANIM SCI courses to retain the Animal\nScience minor.\nDescription of Courses\nANIMAL SCIENCES\nANIM SCI\n101 Introductory Animal Science 3 (2-3) Types\nand breeds of livestock, terminology, methods,\nmanagement systems, techniques of animal\nand poultry production and consumer impact.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n166 Young Horse Handling 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: ANIM SCI 101. Effective horse\nhandling skills and techniques; safety for\nboth horse and human will be emphasized and\nprioritized throughout the course. S, F grading.\n172 Dairy Cattle Management Laboratory\n1 (0-3) Management practices associated with\na dairy enterprise. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students. S, F grading.\n174 Beef Cow Calf Management Laboratory\n1 (0-3) Management practices associated with\na beef cow calf enterprise for students without\nexperience. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students. S, F grading.\n178 Swine Management Laboratory 1 (0-3)\nManagement practices associated with a swine\nenterprise. Field trip and special clothing\nrequired. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students. S, F grading.\n180 Animal Sciences Orientation 1 Animal\nsciences as a profession; career opportunities,\ncurriculum, advisement, internships,\nexternships, animal centers, special services\ncenters, and course requirements.\n205 [BSCI] Companion Animal Nutrition\n3 Biological concepts with application in\nnutrition of pet animals, including evolution\nand selection of pet species and their nutrient\nrequirements.\n240 Introduction to Domestic Animal\nAnatomy and Physiology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ANIM SCI 101; BIOLOGY 106.\nFundamental knowledge, terminology and\nbasic principles of domestic animal anatomy\nand physiology for future advanced courses.\nThe major organ systems (e.g. muscle, skeletal,\nneural, endocrine, cardiovascular, respiratory,\nand renal) are covered with emphasis on\ncomparative anatomy, integrated function,\nand homeostatic control mechanisms.\n260 Live Animal and Carcass Evaluation 3\n(1-6) Basic principles of live animal and carcass\nevaluation. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n266 Equine Management 2 Foundational\nlearning of best practices in equine\nmanagement.\n267 Equine Science 2 Fundamental Scientific\nprinciples of equine anatomy and physiology\nincluding nutrition, reproduction, and muscle\nbiology.\n274 Beef Feedlot Systems 2 Overview of\nfeeding management, feed milling and\nbatching, animal health, and economics of the\ncommercial cattle feeding business. One 1-day\nfield trip. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n280 Animal Science and Society: Current\nTopics 1 A discussion of the products, science,\nand management of animal agriculture and\nhow they relate to, and impact, society.\n285 Rights and Welfare of Animals 3 Ethical\nconsiderations and welfare of animals used as\ncompanions, for food, and in scientific research.\nRecommended preparation: BIOLOGY 102 or\n106 or concurrent enrollment. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n313 F e e d s a n d F e e d i n g 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 106; MATH 106, 107,\n140, 171, 172, 182, or 202. Utilization, practices,\nrequirements, nutritive characteristics, and\ncalculations of rations for animals. Field trip\nrequired. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n314 P r i n c i p l e s o f N u t r i t i o n 3 Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 107; CHEM 102 or\n106. Digestion, absorption, metabolism, and\nfunction of nutrients. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n315 Captive Exotic Animal Nutrition,\nHusbandry and Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ANIM SCI 205, ANIM SCI\n314, or SOE 431. Nutrition, husbandry,\nand management of captive exotic animals\nemphasizing the requirements of the animal\nenvironment.\n330 Animal Genetics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nBIOLOGY 107; STAT 212. Basic genetic\nconcepts and methods for the genetic\nimprovement of Mendelian and polygenic\ntraits in animals. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n345 Introduction to Animal Growth and\nDevelopment 3 Course Prerequisite:\nBIOLOGY 106; BIOLOGY 107; junior standing.\nAnimal structure, composition, whole body\nand cellular growth, prenatal and postnatal\ngrowth; emphasis on skeletal muscle, bone\nand adipose tissue. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n346 Introduction to Skeletal Muscle\nPhysiology 3 Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY\n106. Structure, function and regulation\nof skeletal muscle; embryonic, neonatal,\npostnatal growth/atrophy; muscle-specific\nproteins. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n350 Physiology of Reproduction 3 Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 106; BIOLOGY\n107; CHEM 102 or 106. Anatomy and\nphysiology of reproductive organs; hormones\nof reproduction; production of gametes;\nartificial insemination; fertilization; prenatal\ndevelopment; fertility and infertility.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n351 Physiology of Reproduction Laboratory\n1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: ANIM SCI 350 or\nconcurrent enrollment. Laboratory and field\ntechniques used in animal reproduction\ninvolving hormones, artificial insemination,\nsemen evaluation and pregnancy. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n360 Meat Science 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nB I O L O G Y 1 0 7 . A n a t o m y, s l a u g h t e r,\nclassification, and processing of meat animal\nspecies. Special clothing and equipment\nrequired. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n378 Advanced Livestock and Meat Selection\nand Evaluation 2 (0-6) May be repeated for\ncredit. Course Prerequisite: ANIM SCI 260.\nPrinciples and practices of livestock and meat\nselection and evaluation. Off-campus and\nweekend participation required.\n380 Careers in Animal Science 1 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nAnimal Sciences; junior standing. Issues and\npreparation for careers in animal sciences areas.\n398 Cooperative Education Externship V 2\n(0-6) to 8 (0-24) May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 8 hours. Cooperative\neducation externship in livestock production\nor related field. S, F grading.\n399 Practicum V 1-8 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 12 hours. Directed\ninternship in livestock production and related\nfields conducted at WSU centers on or off\ncampus. S, F grading.\n405 Ciders and Other Fermented Foods 3 (2-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106 and 107, or\nMBIOS 101, or MBIOS 304 and 305. Chemistry,\nmicrobiology, and technology associated\nwith the production of cider, beer, and other\nfood fermentations. Two half-day field trips\nrequired. (Crosslisted course offered as FS 405,\nANIM SCI 405). Recommended preparation: FS\n304 and 465. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n\n63\nAnimal Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n408 [M] Ruminant Nutrition 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ANIM SCI 313. Anatomy,\nphysiology, and metabolism in ruminant\nanimals.\n440 [M] Physiology of Domestic Animals 3\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106; BIOLOGY\n107. Basic animal functions; relationship\nand difference between domestic animals;\nmeasurement of functional processes.\n451 [M] Endocrine Physiology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 106; BIOLOGY 107;\none of the following: ANIM SCI 440, BIOLOGY\n352, MBIOS 303, or MBIOS 401. Anatomy,\nphysiology, and biochemistry of endocrine\nsystems and hormone action; emphasis on\ncomparative, veterinary, and biomedical\nmodels. Credit not granted for both ANIM SCI\n451 and ANIM SCI 551. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n454 Artificial Insemination and Pregnancy\nDetection 2 (1-3) Course Prerequisite: ANIM\nSCI 351. Techniques in semen handling,\ninsemination and pregnancy detection in\ncattle. Special clothing required. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n460 A d v a n c e d M e a t S c i e n c e 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CHEM 102 or 106; junior\nstanding. Structure and development of\nskeletal muscle, postmortem biological\nchanges, meat quality, meat processing, food\nsafety, and meat industry. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n464 [ C A P S ] [ M ] C o m p a n i o n A n i m a l\nManagement 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nANIM SCI 313; ANIM SCI 330; ANIM SCI 350.\nCare and management of companion animal\nspecies throughout the life cycle, including\nnutrition, reproduction, exercise and behavior.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n468 Applied Physiology of Cultured Fish 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ANIM SCI 313; ANIM\nSCI 330; ANIM SCI 350. Development and\nmanagement of finfish aquaculture systems\nand production strategies. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n472 [CAPS] [M] Dairy Cattle Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ANIM SCI 313; ANIM SCI\n330; ANIM SCI 350; junior standing. Principles\nof breeding, feeding, and management of dairy\ncattle. Field trip required. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n473 [M] Advanced Dairy Management 3\n(1-6) Course Prerequisite: ANIM SCI 472.\nCurrent dairy record keeping and database\nmanagement systems. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n474 [CAPS] [M] Beef Cattle Production 3 (2-\n3) Course Prerequisite: ANIM SCI 313; ANIM\nSCI 330; ANIM SCI 350. Breeding, feeding,\nand management; commercial and purebred\nenterprises; management of beef cattle on\nranges, pastures and in the feedlot. Field trip\nrequired. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n478 [M] Swine Production 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: ANIM SCI 313; ANIM SCI\n330; ANIM SCI 350. Principles of breeding,\nfeeding, management, and marketing of\nswine. Field trips and special clothing required.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n480 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n481 Special Topics in Study Abroad: Animal\nProduction Systems in the World V\n2-6 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Immersive course\nintegrating experiential learning activities in\nanimal production systems into international\nlocations where ANIM SCI Faculty are already\nworking and conducting research.\n485 [M] Applied Animal Behavior 3 (2-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106; BIOLOGY\n107; STAT 212; junior standing. Application\nof scientific principles governing animal\nbehavior to practical aspects of animal\nhousing, breeding, handling, training, and\ncare. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n488 [M] Perspectives in Biotechnology 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MBIOS 301 or ANIM SCI\n330. Theory and application of biotechnology\nin agriculture, industry, and medicine;\nmethodological, environmental, social, and\neconomic concerns. Credit not granted for both\nANIM SCI 488 and ANIM SCI 588. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n495 Research in Animal Sciences V 1-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: Junior standing.\nPlanned and supervised undergraduate\nresearch experience.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n500 Seminar in Animal Sciences 1 May be\nrepeated for credit. Current developments in\nanimal sciences.\n501 Milk, Meat, and Methane: Contemporary\nAnimal Production Issues 3 Provides\nknowledge and understanding of livestock\nissues that affect contemporary livestock\nproduction.\n504 Special Topics V 1-4 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 12 hours.\n507 Advanced Nutrient Metabolism 3\nAdvanced topics in metabolic regulation\nof carbohydrate, fat and amino acid use by\nanimals.\n510 Digestion and Nutrient Utilization in\nAnimals 3 (2-3) Gastrointestinal physiology,\nrate of passage, feed intake regulation,\nmeasures of digestibility, starch, fat and\nnonstarch polysaccharide, and digestion and\nutilization of nutrients.\n513 Mineral and Vitamin Metabolism 4\nAbsorption, excretion, metabolism, dietary\nrequirements and interactions of minerals and\nvitamins in animals and humans. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n520 Preparation of Scientific Literature in\nAnimal Sciences 2 Preparation of grant\nproposals, manuscripts, and literature reviews\non research topics.\n528 Topics in Animal Breeding 2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 4\nhours. Systems of selection and mating for\ngenetic improvement in farm animals.\n545 Statistical Genomics 3 (2-3) Develop\nconcepts and analytical skills for modern\nbreeding by using Genome-Wide Association\nStudy and genomic prediction in framework of\nmixed linear models and Bayesian approaches.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CROP SCI 545,\nANIM SCI 545, BIOLOGY 545, HORT 545, PL\nP 545.) Recommended preparation: BIOLOGY\n474; MBIOS 478. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n551 [M] Endocrine Physiology 3 Anatomy,\nphysiology, and biochemistry of endocrine\nsystems and hormone action; emphasis on\ncomparative, veterinary, and biomedical\nmodels. Credit not granted for both ANIM SCI\n451 and ANIM SCI 551. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n558 Molecular and Cellular Reproduction\n3 (2-2) State of the art concepts of the\nmolecular, cellular, and physiological aspects\nof mammalian reproduction. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as MBIOS 528, ANIM SCI\n558). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n581 Stem Cell Biology, Therapeutics and\nRegenerative Medicine 3 Provides\ninformation on the latest cutting edge research\nin the areas of stem cell biology and tissue\nregeneration; covers stem cell therapeutics,\ngene transfer vectors and methods for\nisolating, characterizing, and generating stem\ncells. (Course offered as PHARMSCI 581, ANIM\nSCI 581).\n582 Seminar in Reproductive Biology 1\nCurrent developments in reproductive biology.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents. S, F grading.\n588 [M] Perspectives in Biotechnology 3\nTheory and application of biotechnology\nin agriculture, industry, and medicine;\nmethodological, environmental, social, and\neconomic concerns. Credit not granted for both\nANIM SCI 488 and ANIM SCI 588. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n598 Advanced Topics in Animal Sciences V\n1-2 May be repeated for credit. Recent research\nin various disciplines of animal sciences.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n\n64\nAnimal Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nAnimal Sciences PhD program. Independent\nresearch and advanced study for students\nworking on their doctoral research, dissertation\nand/or final examination. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nDepartment of\nAnthropology\nanthro.wsu.edu\nCollege Hall 150\n509-335-3441\nProfessor and Department Chair, A. Duff; Professors, E.\nChilton, C. Grier, E. Hagen, B. S. Hewlett, J. M. Mageo,\nC. L. Meehan, R. J. Quinlan; Associate Professors, A.D.\nBlackwell, J. Cassaniti, L. Premo, M. B. Quinlan, E.\nThornton, S. Tushingham, C. Wilkinson; Assistant\nProfessors, J. Blong, R. Horowitz, A. Pisor; Professor,\nCareer Track, M. Mansperger; Associate Professors,\nCareer Track, N. Hess, B. L. Hewlett, M. Sugerman;\nAssistant Professor, Career Track, N. Grow; Professors\nEmeriti, R. E. Ackerman, W. Andrefsky, Jr., J. H. Bodley,\nT. A. Kohler, W. D. Lipe, N. P. McKee.\nThe curriculum includes courses in the four major\nsubfields of anthropology: archaeology, cultural/\nsocial anthropology, linguistic anthropology, and\nbiological anthropology. These courses familiarize\nstudents with current issues in human evolution,\nlinguistics, the prehistoric development of culture,\nand cultural theory. Undergraduate majors are\nrequired to gain a background in all four of these\nmajor subfields. Graduate students may specialize in\narchaeology, cultural anthropology, or evolutionary\nanthropology. The program in archaeology\nemphasizes research and training in the prehistory\nof the Americas, including the Pacific Northwest\nfrom Alaska to northern California, the Columbia\nPlateau, the Pueblo societies of the Southwest,\nMesoamerica, and the Andes. Faculty research\nemploys ceramic and lithic analysis, paleoeconomic\nand paleoenvironmental approaches including\ngeoarchaeology, paleobotany and zooarchaeology,\nas well as stable isotope analysis, archaeometry\nvia gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, and\nmodeling and simulation. The department also\nconducts summer archaeological field schools.\nThe program in cultural anthropology emphasizes\nglobalization, historical ethnography, psychological\nanthropology, medical anthropology, gender\nand culture, biocultural perspectives, and public\nhealth anthropology. Faculty research is based\nin North and Central America, Polynesia, Sub-\nSaharan Africa, and South and Southeast Asia.\nThe program in evolutionary anthropology\nemphasizes evolutionary psychology, behavioral\necology, evolutionary cultural anthropology,\nevolutionary archaeology and paleoanthropology.\nEvolutionary faculty have research interests that\nspan several continents including the Americas,\nEurope and Africa. The department also emphasizes\nresearch and training in Psychological/Medical\nAnthropology and Ethnobiology.\nDepartmental offices and laboratories are\nlocated in College Hall near the center of campus.\nPhysical facilities include special laboratories\nfor biological anthropology, isotope and lithic\nanalysis, paleoecology, geoarchaeology, and\nzooarchaeology, as well as research laboratories\nfor faculty and advanced students. The Museum\nof Anthropology, with permanent and temporary\nexhibits, and ethnographic and archaeological\nresearch collections, is also housed in College Hall.\nThe department offers courses of study leading\nto the degrees of Bachelor of Arts in Anthropology,\nBachelor of Arts in Human Biology, Master of\nArts in Anthropology, and Doctor of Philosophy\n(Anthropology). Positions open to anthropologists\ninclude those in teaching, research, museum work,\nstate and federal agencies, non-governmental\norganizations, private consulting firms, and\ninternational business. In addition, anthropology\nprovides a strong general foundation for a pre-\nprofessional education.\nHuman Biology\nHuman Biology is an explicitly interdisciplinary\ndegree jointly administered by the Department\nof Anthropology and the School of Biological\nSciences. The BA in Human Biology offers students\nan opportunity to explore how human biology\ninfluences and is influenced by the environment,\ncultural and social structures, and economic and\npolitical policies. Human Biology melds approaches\nand content from social and biological sciences to\nprovide students with a synthetic understanding\nof the roles of culture, the dynamics of natural and\nsocial systems, and biological attributes responsible\nfor shaping the human being. Our aim is to prepare\nstudents to be engaged, creative, insightful, and\nskillful in diverse professions that encompass the\narenas of health and environmental sciences,\nsocietal support, and public policy that influence\nthe welfare of humans.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nWe expect that our graduating students will have:\n• Familiarity with the basic principles and findings\nof ethnology, archaeology, biological anthropology,\nand linguistics, the four subfields of American\nanthropology as well as the ways in which these\nfour subfields are interrelated;\n• Awareness of the basic research and analytical\nmethods and underlying theories of the four\nsubfields of anthropology;\n• Ability to read critically and synthesize\ni n f o r m a t i o n p r o d u c e d b y p r o f e s s i o n a l\nanthropologists and published in academic books\nand journals;\n• Ability to write in accessible, standard, academic\nprose narratives that are marked by: a framework\nof clear, general statements; specific, concrete\nevidence that supports these statements; analysis\nand discussion of the material presented; and a\ncoherent summary conclusion, indicating the\nsignificance of the work;\n• Ability to apply the principles, findings, and\nresearch and analytical methods of anthropology\nto new situations and data, including those of\neveryday life.\nSee https://anthro.wsu.edu/undergraduate-\nstudies/program-learning-goals/.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nANTHROPOLOGY\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the anthropology\nmajor upon making their intention known to the\ndepartment. To graduate, a minimum of 34 credits\nin anthropology courses are required. Grades of C-\nor higher are required for all anthropology courses.\nNo required course can be taken pass, fail.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nANTH 203 [DIVR] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1
