coursework.\nMinors\nAnthropology\nA minor in Anthropology requires a minimum of\n18 credits, including three of the following: ANTH\n101, 203, 230, and 260. At least 9 credits must be\n300-400-level work taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses. A minimum grade of C-\nis required in each course contributing to the minor.\nDescription of Courses\nAMERICAN INDIAN STUDIES\nAIS\n320 [DIVR] Native Peoples of North America\n3 A holistic exploration of various indigenous\npeoples and cultures of North America,\nthrough the lens of anthropology. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as ANTH 320, AIS 320).\n327 [DIVR] Contemporary Native Peoples\nof the Americas 3 Contemporary cultures\nof Native American communities emphasizing\nNorth America. (Crosslisted course offered as\nANTH 327, AIS 327).\n331 [SSCI] Archaeology of the Americas 3\nCultures and environments of the Americas\nfrom the arrival of the earliest hunter-gatherers\nto the development of complex civilizations.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ANTH 331, AIS\n331.)\n401 Tribal Nation Building Leadership -\nResearch I 2 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 4 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By permission only. Ontology and\nepistemology; indigenous research methods;\nparticipatory research, collaborative research,\ncritical ethnography.\n402 Tribal Nation Building Leadership -\nResearch II 2 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 4 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By permission only. Indigenous\nresearch methods; participatory research,\ncollaborative research, critical ethnography.\nANTHROPOLOGY\nANTH\n101 [DIVR] Introduction to Anthropology 3\nExplores what it means to be human through\nthe major subfields of anthropology, including\nbiological anthropology (human evolution\nand variation), archaeology, sociocultural\nanthropology, and linguistics.\n130 [SSCI] Great Discoveries in Archaeology\n3 Impact of great archaeological discoveries\nand the work of archaeologists on our sense of\nthe past.\n135 [SSCI] Mythbusting in Archaeology 3\nA critical exploration of pseudo-scientific\nclaims and fantastical interpretations of\narchaeological sites and objects in popular\nmedia.\n201 [HUM] Art and Society 3 Art as an\nexpression of social and cultural systems in\nnon-Western societies.\n203 [DIVR] Global Cultural Diversity\n3 Introduction to the field of cultural\nanthropology; examination of how cultures\nvary and are similar.\n205 [SSCI] Health, Healing, and Medicine\nAcross Cultures 3 Anthropological\nperspective on health, disease, and medical/\ncuring systems; relationships between culture,\nbiology, political-economic environments,\ndisease, and curing examined. Recommended\npreparation: ANTH 101 or 203.\n\n66\nAnthropology\nWashington State University, 2021\n214 Gender and Culture in America 3\nExploration or variation in gender roles,\nrelationships, values, and institutions among\nmen and women in US, ethnic, and other\nsubcultures.\n220 [DIVR] Perspectives on Race 3 Critical\nexamination of racial classification and social\nhierarchy, influences of biology and culture\non human variation, and differences among\ngroups.\n230 A r c h a e o l o g i c a l M e t h o d s a n d\nInterpretation 3 Archaeological fieldwork\nmethods; lab-based analysis of archaeological\nmaterials as applied to reconstructing past\nhuman lifeways.\n232 [SSCI] The Pyramids of Egypt: Why and\nHow? 3 Archaeology of the social, political,\neconomic, and technological developments\nthat are indicated by the pyramids of ancient\nEgypt.\n260 [BSCI] Introduction to Biological\nAnthropology 4 (3-3) Evidence for human\nevolution; evolutionary explanations of\nhuman variation; techniques of biological\nanthropology.\n268 [BSCI] Sex, Evolution, and Human\nNature 3 Human sexuality, male-female\nrelations, cooperation, violence and parent-\nchild relations examined cross-culturally and\nin nonhuman primates utilizing evolutionary\nand biocultural perspectives.\n275 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n280 [BSCI] Skeleton Keys: Introduction to\nForensic Anthropology 3 Examination of\nforensic anthropology techniques to identify\nhuman skeletal remains in a medicolegal\ncontext.\n300 Field Methods V 2-8 Course Prerequisite: By\ninstructor permission. Practice in methods of\narchaeological, ethnological, or linguistic field\nresearch.\n301 [ARTS] Arts and Media in Global\nPerspective 3 Contemporary arts and media\naround the world, and their impact on identity,\nsociety, and culture.\n302 [ S S C I ] C h i l d h o o d a n d C u l t u r e 3\nAnthropological theory and methods applied\nto the study of infant, child, and adolescent\ndevelopment.\n303 T h e A n t h r o p o l o g y o f R e l i g i o u s\nExperience 3 Body, meaning, and power in\nreligion cross culturally.\n304 [SSCI] Cross-Cultural Perspectives\nof Mental Health and Illness 3 Cross-\ncultural mental health and illness; common\nU.S. mental illnesses and treatments in diverse\ncultures around the world; mental illnesses\nspecific to particular cultures. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105; ANTH 101 or 203.\n305 [SSCI] Anthropology of Epidemic\nDisease and Bioterrorism 3 Cross-cultural\nunderstanding of how humans respond to\nepidemics, including high mortality diseases,\ndiseases common in the developing world, and\ndiseases that pose future threats.\n307 [DIVR] Contemporary Cultures and\nPeoples of Africa 3 Introduction to family,\nsocial, political, economic and religious\ninstitutions of African cultures in context of\nAfrican social issues.\n309 [SSCI] Cultural Ecology 3 Major findings of\necological anthropology relating to problems\nof population, resources, and environment\nin small-scale cultures. Recommended\npreparation: Sophomore standing, ANTH 101\nor 203.\n316 [DIVR] Gender in Cross Cultural\nPerspective 3 Cross-cultural examination\nof the status and roles of women and men,\nsexuality and marriage, and folk concepts\nof sexual anatomy in traditional cultures\nin Western science; concepts of nature and\nculture are explored through a variety of\nperspectives. (Crosslisted course offered as\nANTH 316, WOMEN ST 316). Recommended\npreparation: Sophomore standing; ANTH 101,\nPSYCH 105, SOC 101, or WOMEN ST 101 or\n201.\n317 Global Feminisms 3 An interdisciplinary\napproach to examining women’s roles and\nexperiences throughout the world and\ndifferent approaches to feminism/feminisms.\n(Crosslisted course offered as WOMEN ST 332,\nANTH 317).\n320 [DIVR] Native Peoples of North America\n3 A holistic exploration of various indigenous\npeoples and cultures of North America,\nthrough the lens of anthropology. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as ANTH 320, AIS 320).\n327 [DIVR] Contemporary Native Peoples\nof the Americas 3 Contemporary cultures\nof Native American communities emphasizing\nNorth America. (Crosslisted course offered as\nANTH 327, AIS 327).\n330 Origins of Culture and Civilization\n3 Prehistoric roots of culture from the\nbeginnings of humankind to the rise of\nthe first civilizations in Africa and Eurasia.\nRecommended preparation: 3 hours ANTH.\n331 [SSCI] Archaeology of the Americas 3\nCultures and environments of the Americas\nfrom the arrival of the earliest hunter-gatherers\nto the development of complex civilizations.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ANTH 331, AIS\n331.)\n334 Time and Culture in the Northwest 3 The\narchaeologically reconstructed environmental\nand cultural past of the Northwest including\ncontemporary scientific and social approaches\nand issues. Recommended preparation: ANTH\n101.\n336 Old World Civilizations 3 Evolution of\ncomplex society, urbanism, states and empires\nin the eastern hemisphere; survey of European,\nAfrican and Asian civilizations. Recommended\npreparation: ANTH 101, 230, or 330.\n340 [M] Maya, Aztec and Inca Civilizations\n3 Examination of the great prehistoric\ncivilizations of Mesoamerica and South\nAmerica. Recommended preparation: ANTH\n101, 330, or 336.\n350 [DIVR] Speech, Thought, and Culture 3\nThe role of language in social situations and as\na reflection of cultural differences.\n355 [HUM] Historical Linguistics 3 Origins and\nevolution of human language, relationships\nbetween peoples and languages, development\nof contemporary ethnicities, linguistical\nchange, reconstructive methods, and writing\nsystems.\n370 The Archaeology of Climate Change\n3 Exploration of the connections between\nclimate change and people from the Ice Age to\nthe present in order to understand the factors\nthat cause environmental change.\n380 Human Osteology 3 Introduction to the\nfield of osteology including molecular analysis,\npaleopathology, taphonomy and forensic\nanalysis.\n381 [BSCI] Primate Behavioral Ecology 3\nEvolution of primate behavior from ecological\nand phylogenetic perspective emphasizing\nm e t h o d s f o r u n d e r s t a n d i n g p r i m a t e\nadaptations and diversity. Recommended\npreparation: ANTH 101 or BIOLOGY 101, 102\nor 150.\n390 [M] History of Anthropological Thought\n3 Course Prerequisite: ANTH 203; ANTH\n230; ANTH 260. Development of theories\nin anthropology including contributions\nof significant individuals, representative\nclassics and influential current movements.\nRecommended preparation: Junior standing.\n395 Topics in Anthropology V 3-6 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Examination of selected topics in\ncontemporary anthropological theory and\npractice. Recommended preparation: Junior\nstanding.\n399 Archaeological Field School V 2-8 Course\nPrerequisite: By instructor permission. Training\nin methods of archaeological data recovery and\nanalysis.\n402 Cross-cultural Gender and Kinship 3\nPrinciples of kinship in anthropology applied\nto questions of cross-cultural gender definition.\nRecommended preparation: ANTH 101 or SOC\n101.\n404 [CAPS] The Self in Culture 3 Course\nPrerequisite: One course at the 100-level\nand one course at the 200-level in any of the\nfollowing subjects: AMER ST, ANTH, CES,\nCOM, ENGLISH, FINE ART, H D, HISTORY,\nHUMANITY, PHIL, POL S, PSYCH, SOC,\nor WOMEN ST; junior standing. Survey of\nanthropological theories exploring self in\nWestern/non-Western cultures through\ndreams, history, and human development.\n405 Medical Anthropology 3 Relationships\na m o n g d i s e a s e , c u r i n g , c u l t u r e a n d\ne n v i r o n m e n t ; n o n - We s t e r n m e d i c a l\nsystems; political economy of health care.\nRecommended preparation: Junior standing.\n410 History of American Indian Sovereignty\nand Federal Indian Law 3 The history of\nsovereignty and Federal Indian Law against the\nbackdrop of treaties and trust responsibility.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY 410,\nANTH 410, POL S 410).\n\n67\nAnthropology\nWashington State University, 2021\n417 Anthropology and World Problems 3\nData and methods of cultural anthropology\napplied to the solution of contemporary\nhuman problems, emphasizing sustainable\ndevelopment. Recommended preparation: 3\nhours ANTH; junior standing.\n418 H u m a n I s s u e s i n I n t e r n a t i o n a l\nDevelopment 3 Interdisciplinary analysis\nof complex interaction between tradition\nand modernity in Third World societies.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ANTH 418, POL\nS 418, SOC 418).\n430 [ M ] A r c h a e o l o g i c a l T h e o r y a n d\nExplanation 3 Archaeological theory and\nthe role of theories of culture change in\ncrafting explanations for the human past.\nRecommended preparation: ANTH 230; ANTH\n330 or 331.\n450 Ethnolinguistics 3 Anthropological theory\nand methods applied to the study of cognitive\nlinguistics, or the interrelation of language,\nmind, and culture. Credit not granted for\nmore than one of ANTH 450 and ANTH\n550. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n463 Introduction to Anthropological\nDemography and Epidemiology 3 Small-\nscale population dynamics; culture change;\nevent history analysis; evolutionary life history;\nrisk; reproduction; morbidity; and mortality in\nethnographic, historical, and archaeological\npopulations. Credit not granted for both\nANTH 463 and ANTH 563. Recommended\npreparation: ANTH 260. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n464 [ C A P S ] H o r m o n e s a n d H u m a n\nReproduction 3 Course Prerequisite: Senior\nstanding. Hormones, diet, and stress in the\nregulation of human reproduction, behavior,\nand physiology; menstruation, parenting,\nand pregnancy; evolution of reproduction.\nRecommended preparation: ANTH 260,\nBIOLOGY 107, 150, or equivalent.\n465 Human Evolution 3 Human origins in the\nlight of the fossil record and evolutionary\ntheory. Credit not granted for both ANTH 465\nand ANTH 565. Recommended preparation:\nANTH 260. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n466 Evolution of Cooperation 3 Human\ncooperation from an evolutionary perspective,\nas informed by research from anthropology,\nbiology, ecology, economics, and psychology;\ndiscussion-based seminar.\n469 Genes, Culture and Human Diversity\n3 Relationships between genes, language\nand culture are explored as a means to\nunderstanding world history, genetic and\ncultural diversity and unity. Recommended\npreparation: Junior standing.\n473 [CAPS] [M] Evolution and Society 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ANTH 260 or BIOLOGY\n301; junior standing. Survey of how the theory\nof evolution is used to better understand\nourselves, the societies in which live, and\nthe biological world on which we depend.\nRecommended preparation: BIOLOGY 405\nor concurrent enrollment. (Crosslisted course\noffered as BIOLOGY 473, ANTH 473).\n480 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n490 [CAPS] [M] Integrative Themes in\nAnthropology 3 Course Prerequisite: ANTH\n203; ANTH 230; ANTH 260; ANTH 390;\njunior standing. Current research crosscutting\ntraditional subdisciplines of anthropology.\n495 Research Practicum V 1-6 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 10 hours.\nHands-on experience in selection of a research\nproblem, review of literature, developing\nmethodology, data collection, and reporting\nresults.\n498 Anthropology Internship V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n15 hours. Course Prerequisite: By instructor\npermission. Participation as archaeological or\ncultural anthropological intern in public or\nprivate sectors; requires special arrangement\nwith faculty advisor. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n500 Field Methods V 2 (0-6) to 8 (0-24) Course\nPrerequisite: By instructor permission. Training\nin gathering and analyzing field data.\n504 Culture, Ecology, and International\nDevelopment 3 Sociocultural properties\nof ecological systems in developing nations;\ncultural transformation in dynamic systems;\nethnographic description, comparison; mixed\nand collaborative methods.\n507 Advanced Studies in Culture Theory\n3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Evaluation of major\ntheories and methods and their relationship\nto problems in cultural-social analysis.\n510 Fundamentals of Cultural Anthropology\n3 Overview of basic concepts and theory\nin cultural anthropology based on in-\ndepth analysis of selected theoretical and\nethnographic materials.\n513 Lithic Technological Organization 4 (3-3)\nMethods and theory of lithic technology.\n514 Ceramic Analysis 4 (3-3) Basic concepts,\nmethods, and approaches used in the analysis\nof archaeological pottery.\n519 International Development and Human\nResources 3 History of and recent changes\nin international development emphasizing\nanthropological perspectives. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as ANTH 519, POL S 538, SOC\n519).\n521 P s y c h o l o g i c a l A n t h r o p o l o g y 3\nPsychological and anthropological aspects\nof personhood, self, human development,\ngender, sexuality, emotion and cognition in\nvarious cultures.\n522 Culture and Mind 3 Examination of cultural\nvariation in mind and mental processing, and\nhow shared ideas and personal perceptions are\nnecessarily co-constitutive of one another.\n525 Medical Anthropology 3 Examination of\nthe interactions between culture and well-\nbeing, including illness concepts, distributions,\nprevention, and treatments in global\nperspective.\n528 Historical Ethnography 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\nCulture history, ethnography, theoretical, and\ncontemporary problems of selected culture\nareas.\n529 Seminar in Ethnography 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Methodological, stylistic and craft issues\nin the process and product of ethnography.\n530 Theory in Archaeology 3 History of\narchaeological method and theory; analysis of\ncurrent literature.\n535 Cultural Resource Management 3 Role\nof archaeology in historic preservation and\nresource conservation; legal and institutional\nframeworks; research and interpretation in a\nCRM context. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n537 Quantitative Methods in Anthropology\n4 (3-3) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 8 hours. Sampling, exploratory\ndata analysis, inferential statistics, and use of\nstatistical software in anthropological research.\n539 Prehistory of the Southwest 3 Prehistory\nof the American Southwest; emphasis on\nPueblo, Mogollon and Hohokam traditions\nand relationships to historic native groups.\n540 Prehistory of the Northwest Coast\n3 Prehistoric cultures, chronologies, and\ninterrelationships on the northwest coast of\nNorth America.\n543 Prehistory of the Plateau and Basin 3\nArchaeology of the interior Northwest and\nGreat Basin.\n546 Complexity in Small Scale Societies\n3 Seminar focused on classic literature and\ncurrent issues relevant to complexity in small\nscale societies, predominately covering hunter-\ngatherer systems. Recommended preparation:\nANTH 530.\n547 Models and Simulation 3 Models and\nmodel-building as an anthropological\napproach to present and past cultures.\n548 Hunters and Gatherers: Past and Present\n3 Introduction to hunter-gatherer studies in\nanthropology and archaeology exploring uses\nof evolutionary approaches to modeling and\nreconstructing hunter-gatherer behavior in\ncontemporary and prehistoric contexts.\n549 Environment and Culture Change in\nComplex Societies 3 Development of food\nproduction, and evaluation of environment’s\nrole in changing social, economic, and political\nconfigurations in past complex societies.\nRecommended preparation: ANTH 530.\n550 Ethnolinguistics 3 Anthropological theory\nand methods applied to the study of cognitive\nlinguistics, or the interrelation of language,\nmind, and culture. Credit not granted for\nmore than one of ANTH 450 and ANTH\n550. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n\n68\nAnthropology\nWashington State University, 2021\n554 Anthropological Field Methods Seminar\n3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Elicitation, recording\ntechniques and analysis of sociocultural\nand linguistic field data. Recommended\npreparation: ANTH 450 or 550.\n561 C u r r e n t Tr e n d s i n E v o l u t i o n a r y\nAnthropology 3 May be repeated for credit.\nIntensive review of current trends in biological\nanthropology.\n562 Evolutionary Method and Theory in\nAnthropology and Archaeology 3 A\ngraduate-level seminar-based course focusing\non the evolutionary analysis of past and\npresent human behavior.\n563 Introduction to Anthropological\nDemography and Epidemiology 3 Small-\nscale population dynamics; culture change;\nevent history analysis; evolutionary life history;\nrisk; reproduction; morbidity; and mortality in\nethnographic, historical, and archaeological\npopulations. Credit not granted for both\nANTH 463 and ANTH 563. Recommended\npreparation: ANTH 260. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n564 Advances in Evolution and Human\nBehavior 3 Recent trends in the study of\nevolution and human behavior.\n565 Human Evolution 3 Human origins in the\nlight of the fossil record and evolutionary\ntheory. Credit not granted for both ANTH 465\nand ANTH 565. Recommended preparation:\nANTH 260. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n566 Evolutionary Psychology 3 Overview\nof evolutionary psychology; theoretical\nfoundations, insights, and key research\ncontributions and applications from this\ninterdisciplinary field.\n567 Primate Behavioral Ecology 3 Seminar-\nbased course focusing on evolutionary analysis\nof primate behavior, morphology and ecology.\n568 Research Design and Grant Writing 3\nProject development, research design, and\nsuccessful proposal writing.\n569 Evolutionary Cultural Anthropology\n3 Evolutionary nature of culture and its\ninteractions with human biology (genes) and\necology.\n570 Sediments in Geoarchaeology 4 (3-3)\nSediment-forming processes, sedimentological\ntechniques, reconstruction of Quaternary\nenvironments, and sedimentology of site-\nforming processes.\n571 Stable Isotope Analysis in Anthropology\n4 (3-3) Lab and seminar course on stable isotope\napplications, methods, and interpretations\nwithin the field of Anthropology.\n572 Residue Analysis and Experimental\nArchaeology 4 (3-3) The science of\narchaeological residues, identification of\norganic and inorganic compounds, method\nand theory of interpretation, experimental\narchaeology, ethnoarchaeology.\n573 Zooarchaeology 4 (2-6) Identification\nof animal bones from archaeological sites,\nmethodological and theoretical techniques\nfor interpreting faunal remains. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n576 Paleoethnobotany 4 (3-3) Methods of\nanalysis and interpretation of botanical\nremains recovered from archeological sites,\nincluding pollen, phytoliths, starch, wood,\nand macro-botanical remains.\n581 C o m p a r a t i v e B i o l o g y o f S o c i a l\nTraditions 3 Phylogenetic and modeling\nperspectives used to examine the evolution\nof social learning and cultural transmission in\nhumans and other animals. (Crosslisted course\noffered as ANTH 581, BIOLOGY 581).\n591 Special Topics in Anthropology 3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n9 hours. Examination of current areas of\nanthropological theory and research.\n593 P u b l i s h i n g a n d P r o f e s s i o n a l\nCommunication 3 Preparation of original\nresearch reports; survey of types of professional\ncommunication, and of standards and\ntechniques.\n598 Advanced Anthropology Internship V\n1-15 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 15 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nBy instructor permission. Participation as\narchaeological or cultural anthropological\nintern in public or private sectors; requires\nspecial arrangement with faculty advisor. S, F\ngrading.\n599 Archaeological Field School V 2-8 Course\nPrerequisite: By instructor permission. Training\nin methods of archaeological data recovery and\nanalysis.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nAnthropology PhD program. Independent\nresearch and advanced study for students\nworking on their doctoral research, dissertation\nand/or final examination. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nDepartment of Apparel,\nMerchandising, Design, and\nTextiles\namdt.wsu.edu\nJohnson Annex, C 30\n509-335-1233\nDepartment Chair and Professor, T. Chi; Assistant\nProfessors, A. Ghalachyan, H. Liu, X. Lou, J. Son;\nInstructors, S. Hiscock, M. Shaheen; Professors Emeriti,\nL. Bradley, C. Salusso.\nApparel, Merchandising, Design, and Textiles offers\nBachelor of Arts and Master of Science degrees, and\nalso participates in the Individual Interdisciplinary\nDoctoral Program.\nAs the largest and most comprehensive\n4-year apparel and textiles program that offers\na full Apparel Design program and an in-depth\nMerchandising program in Washington, we offer\nstudents all of the tools necessary to succeed in the\nfashion, textiles and apparel industry. We have state\nof the art classroom and laboratory equipment, fully\nequipped apparel design studios, a program and\ncurriculum aligned with industry, and nationally\nand internationally recognized faculty who\nchallenge students to understand all the aspects of\nthe discipline. Students in the AMDT department\ngraduate with a thorough understanding of the\ninterdisciplinary nature of the apparel and textile\nindustry across the supply chain. The curriculum\noptions are designed to teach students to:\n• Recognize the global world that we live in today\nby understanding dynamic and diverse political,\nsocio-cultural, and economic systems and how they\nimpact human behavior and industry processes in\na global economy.\n• Increase knowledge of the industry by applying\nindustry relevant decision making and creative\nprocesses in the selection, production and placement\nof goods and services that meet consumer needs in\nthe textile, apparel & retail complex using industry\nbest practices.\n• Utilize technology by applying knowledge and\nskills regarding current technology to retrieve,\nanalyze and disseminate information, and develop\nsolutions relevant to the textile, apparel, and retail\ncomplex.\n• I m p r o v e v e r b a l , v i s u a l , a n d w r i t t e n\ncommunication skills by demonstrating the ability\nto effectively communicate ideas verbally, visually\nand in writing as team members and/or leaders\nwithin a professional environment.\n• Think analytically and critically by demonstrating\nanalytical and critical thinking skills to recognize\nproblems, collect, analyze, synthesize information,\ndevelop, evaluate and implement solutions.\n• Develop an understanding of sustainable\npractices by understanding environmentally\nsound, economically viable, and socially supportive\nsustainable practices in the textile, apparel and retail\ncomplex.\nStudents majoring in Apparel, Merchandising,\nDesign, and Textiles choose an emphasis in\napparel design or merchandising. Each option\nincludes the program’s core courses, as well as\noption requirements and electives. Students can\nindividualize their expertise by exploring minors\nand supporting work in business administration,\ncommunication, and fine arts.\n\n69\nApparel, Merchandising, Design, and Textiles\nWashington State University, 2021\nAn internship is required of students in both\nemphasis areas. Internships are a valuable way\nto gain experience and contacts in the industry\nand make students more competitive when they\ngraduate. A large number of companies in the\nU.S. and abroad offer internships in the textile and\napparel field. Internship exposures help students\nbetter their understanding of the industry, and\ndetermine what career path is best for them.\nNormally the applicant for graduate study\nshould have an undergraduate major in apparel,\nmerchandising, design, or textiles. However,\ncandidates with a good record in related fields (such\nas business, economics, marketing, psychology,\nsociology, and etc.) may be well prepared for certain\nareas of advanced study. All graduate students must\nshow competency in their area of study (through\nan undergraduate degree or industry experience)\nin order to earn their degree. Please refer to WSU\nGraduate catalog and web site at https://gradschool.\nwsu.edu/.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe goal of Apparel, Merchandising, Design,\nand Textiles is to provide high-quality education\nthat prepares graduates for success in the fashion,\nretails, textiles and apparel industry. State of the\nart classroom equipment, fully equipped apparel\ndesign studios, a program and curriculum aligned\nwith current industry needs, and nationally and\ninternationally recognized faculty, give the students\nin WSU’s AMDT program a learning advantage.\nYou may find all Student Learning outcomes at:\nhttp://amdt.wsu.edu/undergraduate/outcomes\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nAPPAREL DESIGN\n(120 HOURS)\nApparel design focuses on the interaction between\ndesign and merchandising and offers depth in\napparel design.\nStudents are admitted to the apparel design\noption upon making their intention known to the\ndepartment.\nStudents seeking to remain admitted to the\napparel design option are accepted through a\nportfolio review process. Applications are available\nin the Academic Coordinator’s office and must to be\nsubmitted during the spring semester of the second\nyear. Transfer students who have completed two\nyears of college may submit an application during\nthe summer prior to the first semester of attendance\nat WSU for consideration.\nStudents who major in Apparel, Merchandising,\nDesign, and Textiles must have a minimum 2.0\ncumulative GPA and receive a C or better grade in\nall AMDT courses. A course may only be repeated\nonce. Courses required in these programs cannot be\ntaken on a pass, fail basis.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAMDT 105 1\nAMDT 108 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nAMDT 268 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nH D 205 [COMM] 4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nElectives 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAMDT 210 [PSCI] 4\nAMDT 211 3\nAMDT 220 3\nArts [ARTS] 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nAMDT 212 3\nAMDT 221 3\nAMDT 250 3\nAMDT 311 3\nElectives 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAMDT 310 4\nAMDT 314 3\nAMDT 315 [M] 3\nAMDT 318 3\nAMDT 488 1\nSecond Term Hours\nAMDT 308 3\nAMDT 312 3\nAMDT 492 3\nAMDT Electives\n1 \n3\nElectives 3\nThird Term Hours\nAMDT 490 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAMDT 409 3\nAMDT 411 3\nAMDT 417 [DIVR] [M] 3\nAMDT Electives\n1 \n3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nAMDT 412 3\nAMDT 413 [CAPS] 3\nAMDT Electives \n1 \n3\nElectives 3\n_______\n1 \nAMDT Electives (9 credits): Any AMDT course not\nused to fulfill major requirements or as approved\nby advisor.\nMERCHANDISING\n(120 HOURS)\nMerchandising includes courses designed to allow\nstudents to develop competence in the planning,\nbuying, and selling of merchandise in either\nmanufacturing or retail organizations. Curriculum\nincludes a focus on marketing. Students often\npursue one of the minors in Business.\nStudents are admitted to the merchandising\noption upon making their intention known to the\ndepartment.\nStudents who major in Apparel, Merchandising,\nDesign, and Textiles must have a minimum 2.0\ncumulative GPA and receive a C or better grade in all\nAMDT courses and the business industry elective. A\ncourse may only be repeated once. Courses required\nin these programs cannot be taken on a pass, fail\nbasis.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAMDT 105 1\nAMDT 108 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nAMDT 221 3\nH D 205 [COMM] 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAMDT 268 3\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] 3\nElectives 4\nSecond Term Hours\nACCTG 230 3\nAMDT 210 [PSCI] 4\nAMDT 212 3\nAMDT 250 3\nElectives 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAMDT 314 3\nAMDT 318 3\nAMDT 488 1\nElectives\n1 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nAMDT 307 3\nAMDT 308 3\nAMDT Electives\n21 \n3\nBusiness Industry Elective\n3 \n3\nElectives\n1 \n3\nThird Term Hours\nAMDT 490 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAMDT 417 [DIVR] [M] 3\nAMDT 430 3\nAMDT 435 3\nAMDT Electives\n21 \n3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nAMDT 413 [CAPS] 3\nAMDT 450 [M] 3\n\n70\nApparel, Merchandising, Design, and Textiles\nWashington State University, 2021\nAMDT Electives 3\nElectives\n1 \n4\n_______\n1 \nAMDT and general electives should include\nsufficient 300-400-level coursework to meet\nUniversity requirement of 40 upper-division credits.\n2 \nAMDT Electives (9 credits): Any AMDT course not\nused to fulfill major requirements or as approved\nby advisor.\n3 \nBusiness Industry Elective: B LAW 210; ECONS\n321, 326, 352, 430; H D 320 [M]; MGMT 301, 315;\nMIS 250; PHIL 360.\nDescription of Courses\nAPPAREL, MERCHANDISING, DESIGN, AND\nTEXTILES\nAMDT\n105 Introductory College Seminar in\nApparel, Merchandising, Design, and\nTextiles 1 Course Prerequisite: Concurrent\nenrollment in AMDT 108. Concepts of\nshared responsibility in planning and actual\ncompletion of AMDT undergraduate study.\n108 Introduction to Apparel, Merchandising,\nDesign and Textiles 3 An introduction to\napparel, textiles, merchandising and design\nwith an emphasis on an examination of\nindustry structures and careers.\n210 [PSCI] Textiles 4 (3-3) Examination of basic\ntextile components including fibers, yarns,\nstructure, coloration, and finishes relative to\nperformance standards and expectations for\nintended use.\n211 Apparel Assembly 3 (0-6) Problem\nsolving approach to apparel and textile\nproduct assembly with emphasis on product\ndevelopment process.\n212 Apparel Product Development 3 Course\nPrerequisite: AMDT 210. Examination and\nevaluation of ready-to-wear apparel as it\napplies to the retail industry; explores concepts\nand principles of apparel production and\nterminology in the apparel industry.\n220 Historic Costumes and Textiles 3 Global\nsurvey of dress and textiles from prehistory to\nmid-1800s.\n221 Historic Costume II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAMDT 210 or concurrent enrollment. Overview\nof apparel design, designers and social history\nin the 20th century.\n230 Creating Visual Advertising in Fashion 3\nHands-on opportunity to visualize and execute\ncross-sector visual advertising campaigns\nwithin the commercial, editorial, and lifestyle\nworld of fashion in advertising.\n250 Principles of Merchandising 3 Course\nPrerequisite: AMDT 108. Concepts and\nfunctions of merchandising in apparel and\ntextiles industries; cost, pricing, and profit;\nmarketing and retailing strategies.\n268 Communicating Creative Concepts in\nFashion 3 (0-6) Illustration and rendering\nused for fashion and costume design;\ndrawing fashion figures and apparel; studies\nor composition for fashion presentation,\nadvertising, and portfolio.\n307 Consumer Behavior in Fashion 3 Course\nPrerequisite: AMDT 314. Concepts and theories\nfrom social sciences to consumer behavior\nresearch related to fashion and apparel\nmarketing.\n308 Visual Merchandising and Promotion 3\n(2-2) Course Prerequisite: AMDT 250; AMDT\n268. Examination of fashion promotion\ncomponents of visual display and store layout;\napplication of principles and elements of\ndesign and concept development.\n310 Advanced Apparel Assembly 4 (1-6)\nCourse Prerequisite: AMDT 211; admitted to\nthe major in Apparel, Merchandising, Design,\nand Textiles. Advanced assembly techniques\nfor a range of textiles and multi-layer garments;\nemphasis of high-quality execution on final\nproducts.\n311 Apparel Flat Patterning and Design 3\n(0-6) Course Prerequisite: AMDT 211. Flat\npattern techniques for apparel patternmaking;\ndevelopment and creation of original design.\n312 Apparel Draping, Fitting, and Design 3\n(0-6) Course Prerequisite: AMDT 311; admitted\nto the major in Apparel, Merchandising,\nDesign, and Textiles. Exploration of draping\nand flat pattern techniques; fitting techniques\nemphasized; development and creation of\noriginal design.\n314 Fashion Forecasting 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAMDT 210; AMDT 221; AMDT 250; AMDT\n268. Developing forecasting expertise needed\nto work in merchandising environment;\nexamined through influences on acceptance\nand rejection of apparel/textile products;\nanalysis of the forces such as socio-cultural\nindicators, past and present trends that\ninfluence existing trends, and the role of\nfashion forecasting theory and technique\nmethod in determining future trends in\nfashion and related industries.\n315 [M] Textile Product Analysis 3 (2-2)\nCourse Prerequisite: AMDT 210. Analysis of\ntextile product characteristics including fiber,\nstructure, finish, apparel product properties,\ngarment performance, and overall quality\nassessment and assurance.\n318 Merchandise Buying and Planning 3\n(2-2) Course Prerequisite: AMDT 250; MATH\n[QUAN]; admitted to the major in Apparel,\nMerchandising, Design, and Textiles. In-\ndepth study of apparel buying and planning,\napplication of buying and planning principles,\nproblem solving skill development.\n408 [ARTS] Visual Analysis and Aesthetics\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing. In-\ndepth analysis of the visual interaction among\napparel, accessories and the body; identifying\neffective visual communication.\n409 Technical Apparel Design 3 (0-6) Course\nPrerequisite: AMDT 312; AMDT 492; admitted\nto the major in Apparel, Merchandising,\nDesign, and Textiles. Advanced understanding\nof technical applications in apparel production,\ndevelopment, and construction related to\nmodern manufacturing. Credit not granted\nfor both AMDT 409 and 509.\n411 Advanced Apparel Design 3 (0-6) Course\nPrerequisite: AMDT 312; AMDT 492; admitted\nto the major in Apparel, Merchandising,\nDesign, and Textiles; senior standing.\nIntegrated application of apparel design,\npatternmaking principles with assembly\nprocesses to demonstrate capacity to develop\nand create high quality original designs.\n412 Apparel Design Collection 3 (0-6) Course\nPrerequisite: AMDT 411; admitted to the\nmajor in Apparel, Merchandising, Design,\nand Textiles. Problem-solving creation and\npresentation of two and three-dimensional\nhigh quality original apparel and designs.\n413 [CAPS] Global Sourcing 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ADMT 307; ADMT 318; admitted\nto the major in Apparel, Merchandising,\nDesign, and Textiles; junior standing.\nKnowledge, skills, and effective solutions for\ntextile and apparel sourcing in a global context.\n414 Creativity: Development of Consumer\nProducts 3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe major in Apparel, Merchandising, Design,\nand Textiles; junior standing. Processes\nand techniques to stimulate creativity\nfrom a multidisciplinary approach for the\ndevelopment of new consumer products.\n417 [DIVR] [M] Multicultural Perspectives\no n t h e B o d y a n d D r e s s 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Engagement\nin multidisciplinary approaches that explore\nthe social importance of the body, gender and\ndress.\n419 Regional Experience in Apparel/Textiles\nField V 1-3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nany major. Field trips to experience the textile\nand apparel industry from the perspective of\nprofessionals within a wide range of careers.\nAdditional cost associated with class. See\ndepartment for details.\n422 [DIVR] Fat Studies 3 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. Examination of weight based\noppression as a social justice issue with other\nsystems of oppression based on gender, race,\nclass, age, sexual orientation, and ability.\n(Crosslisted course offered as AMDT 422,\nWOMEN ST 422).\n429 National Experience in Apparel/\nTextiles Field V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in Apparel,\nMerchandising, Design, and Textiles. Field trip\nto experience national culture integrated with\nthe field of textiles and apparel in industry\ncenters in the US. Additional cost associated\nwith class. See department for details.\n\n71\nBiological Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n430 Soft Goods Supply Chain Management\n3 Course Prerequisite: AMDT 318; admitted to\nthe major in Apparel, Merchandising, Design,\nand Textiles. Stages and functional areas of soft\ngoods supply chain management.\n435 Retailing in the Apparel and Textile\nIndustries 3 Exploration of apparel and\ntextile multi-channel retailing from a\nmanagerial point of view; use of industry-\nstandard software to work through common\nscenarios; critical examination of current\nindustry issues.\n439 International Experience in Apparel/\nTextiles Field V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to any major. Field trip\nto experience international culture integrated\nwith the field of textiles and apparel in industry\ncenters worldwide. Additional cost associated\nwith class. See department for details.\n440 Organizational Leadership 3 (2-2)\nApplication of organizational leadership\nprinciples using experiential learning models\nfor skill transfer to industry.\n450 [M] Strategy Planning and Decision\nMaking 3 Course Prerequisite: AMDT\n307; AMDT 318; admitted to the major in\nApparel, Merchandising, Design, and Textiles.\nExamination and synthesis of advanced\nmerchandising theory; strategic planning,\ndecision-making and the role of technology\nin the textile and apparel industry.\n460 [M] Costume Museum Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Junior standing. Skills and\ntechniques for handling textiles and apparel\nartifacts in museums.\n488 Internship Preparation 1 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 2 hours.\nOrientation and practical information for\nstudents in preparation for an internship.\n490 Cooperative Education Internship V\n1-6 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 12 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nAMDT 488. Experience with business, industry\nor government unit.\n492 Computer Applications in Apparel,\nTextile, and Design 3 (1-4) Course\nPrerequisite: AMDT 268; admitted to the\nmajor in Apparel, Merchandising, Design, and\nTextiles. Computer-aided design techniques in\nfashion graphics; portfolio development and\npresentation.\n495 Instructional Practicum V 1-4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 4\nhours. Course Prerequisite: By interview only.\n496 Special Event Production V 1 (0-2) to 3\n(0-6) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite: AMDT\n211 or 308; admitted to the major in Apparel,\nMerchandising, Design, and Textiles; by\npermission of instructor. Producing, exhibiting,\nand promoting product lines/special events or\napparel, textiles and illustrations exhibits.\n498 Special Topics V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Current\nissues, trends, and merchandising strategies in\napparel and textiles.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n508 Environmental and Social Issues in the\nApparel Industry 3 Exploration of current\nenvironmental and social issues in the global\napparel industry.\n509 Technical Apparel Design 3 (0-6) Advanced\nunderstanding of technical applications\nin apparel production, development, and\nconstruction related to modern manufacturing.\nCredit not granted for both AMDT 409 and\n509.\n512 Apparel Design Graduate Studio 3\nCourse Prerequisite: AMDT 508. Integration\nof consumer demand target market research\nwith the development, application, and testing\nof prototype products for specific end uses.\n515 Textile Product Development and\nInnovation 3 Apply knowledge of textile\ncomponent and emerging materials/\ntechniques to innovative textile product\ndevelopment. Recommended preparation:\nAMDT 210.\n517 Theory and Methods of Culture, Gender\nand Dress 3 Exploration of appearance issues,\ntheory, and research from the perspective of\nsocial science, feminist theory, postmodern\nand poststructural discourses.\n518 Apparel Merchandising Analysis 3\nAnalysis of marketing and retailing strategies,\ntrends and technological developments in\nrelation to business and consumer aspects\nwithin a global context.\n519 R e s e a r c h M e t h o d s 3 Analysis and\nu n d e r s t a n d i n g o f r e s e a rc h m e t h o d s ,\nexploration of thesis topic as applicable to the\nfields of apparel, merchandising, design and\ntextiles.\n520 Aesthetic Analysis of Fashion Design 3\nIn-depth analysis of apparel fashion design\nprovided through exploration of aesthetic\nand human perception theories within a socio-\nhistoric context.\n550 Social Networking and Omni-channel\nRetailing 3 Analysis of social networking\ntechnology and consumer trends, industry\npractices, and marketing strategies that\ncomprise omni-channel retailing; assessment\nand solution of market challenges; presentation\nof academic research.\n596 Advanced Instructional Practicum 3\nInformation and direction for graduate student\nteaching assistants seeking professional\ndevelopment in classroom teaching. S, F\ngrading.\n598 Topics in Apparel and Textiles V 1-3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n8 hours. Current topics in apparel and textile\ntheory and research.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 702 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nSchool of Biological Sciences\nsbs.wsu.edu\nAbelson 301\n509-335-3553\nProfessor and Director, P. Carter; Professor and Associate\nDirector of Graduate Program, R. Gomulkiewicz;\nProfessor and Associate Director of Undergraduate\nProgram, R.D. Evans; Professor and Associate Director\nof Research, A. Cousins; Professors, K. Beerman, J.\nBishop (Vancouver), S. Bollens (Vancouver), J. Busch, H.\nHellmann, M. Knoblauch, J. Pioviah-Scott (Vancouver),\nS. Porter (Vancouver), C. Portfors (Vancouver), E.\nRoalson, C. Robbins, C. Schultz (Vancouver), H.\nSchwabl, M. Skinner, A. Storfer, M. Tegeder; Associate\nProfessors, J. Brunner, A. Cavagnetto, O. Cornejo, E.\nCrespi, W. Dowd, M. Dybdahl, J. Kelley, A. McCubbin,\nE. Schwartz, P. Verrell, H. Watts; Assistant Professors, T.\nCheeke (Tri-Cities), J. Zambrano; Associate Professors,\nCareer Track, D. Allison, M. Berger (Vancouver), L.\nCarloye, K. McAteer (Tri-Cities) S. Ritchie, E. Sweet (Tri-\nCities); Assistant Professors, Career Track, N. Ankrah,\nE. Johnson, M. Jorgensen, D. Monk; Senior Instructor, D.\nWilmington (Vancouver); Research Faculty, E. Nilsson;\nProfessors Emeriti, R. A. Black, G. Edwards, L. Hufford,\nR. Johnson, M. Ku, J. Larsen, R. Mack, J. Mallatt, D.\nMiller, D. Moffett, S. Moffett, C. Omoto, J. Paznokas,\nP. Schroeder, G. Thorgaard, E. Uribe.\nThe School of Biological Sciences offers training\nin molecular, cellular, organismal, ecological/\nenvironmental and evolutionary biology. The\nSchool offers Bachelor of Science degree programs\nin Biology and Zoology, a Bachelor of Arts in\nHuman Biology, and Master of Science and Doctor\nof Philosophy programs in Biology and Plant\nBiology. The School also offers undergraduate\nminors in Zoology and Biology, and the Certificate\nin Quantitative Biology, provided in collaboration\nwith the Department of Mathematics.\n\n72\nBiological Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nFacilities\nThere are modern facilities for study of molecular\nand genomics, cellular biology, genetics, plant and\nanimal physiology, anatomy and ultrastructure,\nfunctional morphology, ecology, molecular\nsystematics, behavior, ecology, and environmental\nand evolutionary biology. The University’s location\nis conducive to field studies at sites such as the\n800 acre George E. Hudson Biological Preserve at\nSmoot Hill and nearby public lands. Special facilities\ninclude the Franceschi Microscopy and Imaging\nCenter, plant growth facilities, a laboratory for\nbioanalysis and biotechnology with facilities for\ngenotyping, DNA sequencing, and genomics, the\nWSU Stable Isotope Core Facility for stable isotope\nanalyses, and the collections of the Charles R.\nConner Museum of Natural History and the Marion\nOwnbey Herbarium.\nCooperation with many other campus units\nextends research opportunities. Cooperative\narrangements with faculty in units such as Molecular\nBiosciences, Animal Sciences, Environment, and the\nCollege of Veterinary Medicine are readily achieved.\nUndergraduate Programs\nIntroductory biological sciences courses provide\nbackground in the concepts common to life sciences\nand an overview of the diversity of animals, plants,\nand microorganisms. Advanced biological sciences\ncourses probe specific areas in depth. Undergraduate\ncoursework in either biology or zoology prepares\nstudents to pursue career opportunities in ecology\nand environmental biology, laboratory research and\nbiotechnology, human health, animal health and\nwelfare, plant biology, entomology, education, and\na variety of other biological specializations.\nCandidates for the Bachelor of Science in Biology\nor the Bachelor of Science in Zoology must fulfill\nthe University and the College of Arts and Sciences\nrequirements for graduation as described elsewhere\nin this catalog. Requirements for admission to\nthe majors, University degree requirements, and\nthe School and the individual degree option\nrequirements can be found in the individual\nschedules of studies for the degree options.\nWe expect that students graduating with a\nBachelor of Science in Biology or Zoology will\nmeet the following learning outcomes: (1) have a\nmastery of fundamental biological concepts and\nan ability to integrate this conceptual knowledge\nacross different subfields within the discipline; (2)\nuse critical thinking and scientific skills to analyze\nand solve biological problems; (3) effectively\ncommunicate biological problems and solutions to\nthe scientific community and the public at-large in\nwriting and in oral discussion; (4) have the ability\nto formulate logical hypotheses, to test hypotheses\nusing quantitative and other appropriate methods\ninvolving collection and analysis of data, and to\nmake valid inferences from experimental results; (5)\nidentify and access the central body of knowledge\nin biology or zoology through utilization of a wide\nrange of methods for researching the primary\nliterature; (6) use scientific literacy and knowledge\nof biology or zoology to analyze contemporary\nsocial, cultural, and environmental issues to make\ninformed rational decisions.\nBiology\nSeven options are available for the Bachelor of\nScience degree in Biology: general biology, biology\neducation, plant biology, ecology/evolutionary\nbiology, entomology, pre-physical therapy/pre-\noccupational therapy/pre-physician assistant, and\nbasic medical sciences. Each option includes a\ncommon core curriculum plus additional specialized\ncourses. The general biology option provides\nbroad training in the life sciences, particularly for\nstudents seeking to continue in professional or\ngraduate school. The biology education option is\nparticularly suitable for students who would like\nto teach biology at the high school level. The plant\nbiology option is available for students with a\nspecial interest in plants and serves students who\nwould like careers in plant sciences or to pursue\ngraduate studies. The ecology/evolutionary biology\noption provides a concentration on ecological and\nevolutionary biology to address interests in such\nfields as environmental and wildlife biology. The\nentomology option is available for students who\nwish to focus on insect biology. The pre-physical\ntherapy/pre-occupational therapy/pre-physician\nassistant option is designed for students who\nwould like to pursue studies in physical therapy,\noccupational therapy, or physician assistant\nprograms. The basic medical sciences option\nsupports students who aim for a career in the health\nfields, including professional training in medicine,\ndentistry, and pharmacy. This degree has two plans\nof study (Plan A or Plan B). Either will help students\nto meet the requirements for admission to medical,\ndental, or pharmacy schools, or other health science\nprofessional programs. Plan A students have a\nprimary concentration of biological sciences and\na secondary concentration in chemistry. Plan B\nrequires courses from three unrelated areas of\nbiological sciences (biology, molecular bioscience,\nand neuroscience). Students will work with their\nacademic advisor in the School of Biological\nSciences to plan individual courses of study.\nHuman Biology\nHuman Biology is an explicitly interdisciplinary\ndegree jointly administered by the Department\nof Anthropology and the School of Biological\nSciences. The BA in Human Biology offers students\nan opportunity to explore how human biology\ninfluences and is influenced by the environment,\ncultural and social structures, and economic and\npolitical policies. Human Biology melds approaches\nand content from social and biological sciences to\nprovide students with a synthetic understanding\nof the roles of culture, the dynamics of natural and\nsocial systems, and biological attributes responsible\nfor shaping the human being. Our aim is to prepare\nstudents to be engaged, creative, insightful, and\nskillful in diverse professions that encompass the\narenas of health and environmental sciences,\nsocietal support, and public policy that influence\nthe welfare of humans.\nPlease see the Department of Anthropology\nfor degree program requirements, including the\nschedule of studies.\nZoology\nThree options are available for the Bachelor\nof Science degree in Zoology: general zoology,\npre-veterinary/animal care, and pre-medicine/\npre-dentistry. Each of these options includes a\ncore curriculum that provides a strong science\nfoundation plus additional specialized courses\ntaken in the particular program option. The flexible\ncurriculum leading to a zoology degree meets the\nneeds of students with various interests and goals.\nThe general zoology option provides a broad, solid\nfoundation in zoology. It is especially aimed at\nstudents desiring a well-rounded background for\nfurther professional studies or for entry into the work\nforce in areas such as wildlife biology or fisheries.\nThe pre-medicine/pre-dentistry option is offered by\nthe School of Biological Sciences as a course program\ndesigned to provide a solid academic foundation\nthat successfully prepares the student for admission\ninto medical, dental, or pharmacy school. The pre-\nveterinary/animal care option prepares students for\ncareers involving animal care and maintenance in\nresearch institutions, zoos, aquaria, and clinics and\nfor application to colleges of veterinary medicine.\nAccelerated Pre-Vet Option in Zoology\nThe School of Biological Sciences has an academic\ntrack that can allow highly qualified students to\nearn both a Bachelor of Science in Zoology and\na Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree within\na seven-year span. Students can enroll in the\nundergraduate zoology program and complete all\nUCORE requirements, the necessary zoology core\ncourses, and all veterinary medicine prerequisite\ncoursework in a three year period. The required\nprerequisites courses can be found on the WSU CVM\nwebsite: https://dvm.vetmed.wsu.edu/admissions/\nprerequisites. Such students who are accepted into\nthe College of Veterinary Medicine DVM program\nafter completing this 3 year program will then be\nallowed to transfer credit back from their first year\nDVM curriculum to fulfill the requirements that will\nallow them to earn a BS in Zoology.\nInterested students must be advised in the School\nof Biological Sciences. High scholastic achievement,\nalong with demonstrated experience and interest\nin working with animals and within the veterinary\nprofession, will be a few of the main criteria for\ninclusion. Interested students should contact the\nSchool of Biological Sciences no later than the first\nsemester of the sophomore year. Students would\nthen declare zoology with the pre-vet option as a\nmajor in the first semester of the sophomore year.\nThe procedures for application into the DVM\nprogram will be the same as those for all other\napplicants to the program (excluding those\napplicants applying to the Early Acceptance\nUndergraduate Programs through the Honors\nCollege or Department of Animal Sciences).\nStudents in this program are not given preferential\nconsideration for admission into the DVM program.\nParticipants who complete the three-year zoology\nprogram, and are accepted into the DVM program\nduring their junior year, will begin the veterinary\nmedicine curriculum in their fourth year of study.\nThese students would complete only the DVM\ncurriculum from this point on, and credits from the\nfirst year of the DVM program will be used to fulfill\nthe remaining requirements that will allow them to\nearn a BS in Zoology. If the student is not accepted\ninto the DVM program or withdraws from it, he/\nshe may continue to earn the BS in Zoology and\nmay be eligible to apply to the College of Veterinary\nMedicine as a senior or following completion of the\nBS.\nTransfer Students\nScience courses taken at other institutions will\nbe evaluated and credits accepted when possible.\nInquiries should be directed to the Associate\nDirector of Undergraduate Programs.\n\n73\nBiological Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nGraduate Programs\nAt the graduate level, the school awards Master\nof Science and Doctor of Philosophy degrees in\nBiology and Plant Biology. Faculty interests and\nresearch programs are diverse, including genomics,\nmolecular and cellular biology, animal and plant\nphysiology, various aspects of organismal biology\nof plants and animals, systematics, ecology,\nevolutionary biology, and biology education. A\nlist of specific faculty interests can be obtained at\nhttps://sbs.wsu.edu/people/ or by writing to the\nSchool. Communication with faculty members\nprior to applying for the graduate program is\nstrongly encouraged.\nPreparation for Graduate Study in Biology\nand Plant Biology\nStudents with undergraduate majors in such fields\nas animal sciences, biology, botany, cell biology,\nenvironmental sciences, genetics, microbiology,\nnatural resources, plant sciences, wildlife biology,\nand zoology may be prepared for graduate study in\nthe School of Biological Sciences. Graduate Record\nExamination scores from the general aptitude\nsection are required.\nStudents who complete Master of Science and\nDoctor of Philosophy degrees in our program\nfind careers as faculty in colleges and universities,\nconservation biologists and managers of natural\nresources, biologists and technicians for state\nand federal agencies, specialists in informatics,\nand scientists and laboratory technicians in\nbiotechnology and other life sciences industries.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBIOLOGY - BASIC MEDICAL SCIENCES\nPLAN A\n(120 HOURS)\nCandidates for the Bachelor of Science in Biology\nmust fulfill the University and the College of\nArts and Sciences requirements for graduation as\ndescribed in the WSU general catalog. Admission\nto the major requires completion of 24 semester\ncredits and 2.0 GPA.\nHonors students complete honors requirements\nin place of UCORE requirements. The math and\nscience components of those requirements are\nfulfilled as part of the School requirements described\nbelow. Other University requirements include: 120\ntotal credits, of which 40 must be 300-400-level\ncredits; the writing portfolio; and two writing in\nthe major courses (identified by [M] in the course\nlistings). The College of Arts and Sciences requires\ntwo years of high school foreign language or at least\ntwo semesters of college-level foreign language.\nBachelor of Science degree options in Biology and\nZoology require a minimum of 19 semester credits\nof core BIOLOGY courses (BIOLOGY 106, 107, 301,\n370 [M] or 372 [M], and 395 or 403 or 405). An\nadditional 21 semester credits of biological sciences\ncoursework selected in consultation with your\nbiology advisor is required. The 21 semester credits\nmust include 15 upper division credits, six of which\nmust be BIOLOGY courses taken in residence at\nWSU, one additional BIOLOGY writing in the major\ncourse (identified by [M] in the course listings), and\none BIOLOGY Capstone course (identified by the\n[CAPS] in the course listings. An overall GPA of\nat least 2.0 must be maintained in all College and\nSchool requirements. A maximum of 4 credits of\ncoursework that are graded S, F may be used toward\nfulfilling School requirements or program options,\nand no other courses taken S or P can be applied\ntoward fulfilling School requirements or program\noptions. Students must complete an exit survey.\nStudents may not double major or take a minor in\nany combination of Biology, Zoology, or General\nStudies Biological Sciences.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 106 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or 171 [QUAN]\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 301 4\nCHEM 345 4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nForeign Language, if needed, or Electives\n2 \n4\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 348 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or Electives\n2 \n9\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMBIOS 303 or CHEM 370 4 or 3\nPHYSICS 101\n3 \n3\nPHYSICS 111\n3 \n1\nElectives\n2 \n3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nPHIL 365 [HUM] 3\nPHYSICS 102\n3 \n3\nPHYSICS 112\n3 \n1\nElectives\n2 \n6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDegree Program Elective\n4 \n2-4\nDegree Program Elective [M]\n4 \n3\n300-400-level Electives 6\nElectives\n2 \n4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY Capstone [CAPS] 3\nDegree Program Elective [M]\n4 \n3\n300-400-level Electives 6\nElectives\n2 \n4\n_______\n1 \nMATH 106 may be taken the first semester as a\nprerequisite to other MATH courses and as a co-\nrequisite to CHEM 105. MATH 108 may also be\nneeded. In addition to either MATH 140 or 171,\na statistics course is highly recommended, and for\nsome programs, required.\n2 \nAn elective may be substituted for PHYSICS\n101/111 and 102/112 if it is not required for\nentrance to a graduate or professional program.\n3 \nDegree Program Electives: A combination of 39\nscience credits, with 21 credits in 300-400-level\ncourses, is required. 20 credits must be selected from\nthe following list and must include a minimum\nof one each BIOLOGY, MBIOS, and NEUROSCI:\nBIOLOGY 251, 315, 321 [M], 324, 333, 350, 352,\n353, 393 [M], one from 395 or 403, or 405, 418\n[M]; MBIOS 304, 360 [M], 401, 402 [M], 413, 414,\n423, 440, 442, 446; NEUROSCI 301, 403 [M], 404,\nand 430 [M]. Coursework must include sufficient\n300-400-level coursework to meet the University\nrequirement of 40 upper division credits.\n4 \nStudents are encouraged to pursue a minor.\nBIOLOGY - ECOLOGY AND EVOLUTIONARY\nBIOLOGY OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nCandidates for the Bachelor of Science in Biology\nmust fulfill the University and the College of\nArts and Sciences requirements for graduation as\ndescribed in the WSU general catalog. Admission\nto the major requires completion of 24 semester\ncredits and 2.0 GPA.\nHonors students complete honors requirements\nin place of UCORE requirements. The math and\nscience components of those requirements are\nfulfilled as part of the School requirements described\nbelow. Other University requirements include: 120\ntotal credits, of which 40 must be 300-400-level\ncredits; the writing portfolio; and two writing in\nthe major courses (identified by [M] in the course\nlistings). The College of Arts and Sciences requires\ntwo years of high school foreign language or at least\ntwo semesters of college-level foreign language.\nBachelor of Science degree options in Biology and\nZoology require a minimum of 19 semester credits\nof core BIOLOGY courses (BIOLOGY 106, 107, 301,\n370 [M] or 372 [M], and 395 or 403 or 405). An\nadditional 21 semester credits of biological sciences\ncoursework selected in consultation with your\nbiology advisor is required. The 21 semester credits\nmust include 15 upper division credits, six of which\nmust be BIOLOGY courses taken in residence at\nWSU, one additional BIOLOGY writing in the major\ncourse (identified by [M] in the course listings), and\none BIOLOGY Capstone course (identified by the\n[CAPS] in the course listings. An overall GPA of\nat least 2.0 must be maintained in all College and\nSchool requirements. A maximum of 4 credits of\ncoursework that are graded S, F may be used toward\nfulfilling School requirements or program options,\nand no other courses taken S or P can be applied\ntoward fulfilling School requirements or program\noptions. Students must complete an exit survey.\nStudents may not double major or take a minor in\nany combination of Biology, Zoology, or General\nStudies Biological Sciences.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 105 [PSCI]\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 106 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or 171 [QUAN]\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 345 4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nPHYSICS 101 or 201 3\nPHYSICS 111 or 211 1\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 370 [M] or 372 [M] 4\nPHYSICS 102 or 202 3\nPHYSICS 112 or 212 1\nProgram Option Courses or Electives\n2,3 \n4\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nBIOLOGY 301 4\nProgram Option Courses or Electives\n2,3 \n7\nForeign Language, if needed, or Electives\n4 \n3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nProgram Option Courses or Electives\n2,3 \n6 or 7\nSTAT 212, 412, or PSYCH 311 3 or 4\nForeign Language, if needed, or Electives\n4 \n3 or 4\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY Capstone [CAPS] 3\nProgram Option Courses or Electives\n2,3 \n11\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 395, 403, or 405 3\nProgram Option Courses or Electives\n2,3 \n13 or 14\nComplete School of Biological Sciences Exit\nSurvey\n_______\n1 \nMATH 106 may be taken as a pre-/co-requisite to\nCHEM 105 and other MATH courses. MATH 108\nmay also be needed.\n2 \nEcology and Evolution Option requirements\ninclude one course from the Physiology Emphasis\narea (BIOLOGY 350 or BIOLOGY 420); 12 total\ncredits from the Ecology Emphasis (BIOLOGY\n330, 410, 462, 469 [M], 483 [M] [CAPS]) and the\nEvolution/Organismal Emphasis (BIOLOGY 322\n[M], 324, 332 [M], 335 [M], 408 [CAPS], 409, 412,\n418, 423, 428, 432 [M], 438 [M]). At least one course\nmust be from the Ecology Emphasis and one course\nfrom the Evolution/Organismal Emphasis.\n3 \nAll biology majors must complete 21 semester\ncredits of biological coursework including 15 upper-\ndivision credits, 6 of which must be a BIOLOGY\nprefix taken in residence at WSU. Approved courses\ninclude 200-400-level BIOLOGY courses except\nthose used to fulfill core requirements (BIOLOGY\n106. 107, 301, 370 [M] or 372 [M], one from 395,\n403, or 405), and any courses approved by advisor. A\nmaximum of 4 credits of coursework graded S/F may\nbe used toward fulfilling departmental requirements\nor program options and must be approved by\nadvisor. Coursework must include a total of two\nBIOLOGY [M] courses and sufficient 300-400-level\ncoursework to meet the University requirement of\n40 upper division credits.\n4 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n\n75\nBiological Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nBIOLOGY - EDUCATION OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nCandidates for the Bachelor of Science in Biology\nmust fulfill the University and the College of\nArts and Sciences requirements for graduation as\ndescribed in the WSU general catalog. Admission\nto the major requires completion of 24 semester\ncredits and 2.0 GPA.\nHonors students complete honors requirements\nin place of UCORE requirements. The math and\nscience components of those requirements are\nfulfilled as part of the School requirements described\nbelow. Other University requirements include: 120\ntotal credits, of which 40 must be 300-400-level\ncredits; the writing portfolio; and two writing in\nthe major courses (identified by [M] in the course\nlistings). The College of Arts and Sciences requires\ntwo years of high school foreign language or at least\ntwo semesters of college-level foreign language.\nBachelor of Science degree options in Biology and\nZoology require a minimum of 19 semester credits\nof core BIOLOGY courses (BIOLOGY 106, 107, 301,\n370 [M] or 372 [M], and 395 or 403 or 405). An\nadditional 21 semester credits of biological sciences\ncoursework selected in consultation with your\nbiology advisor is required. The 21 semester credits\nmust include 15 upper division credits, six of which\nmust be BIOLOGY courses taken in residence at\nWSU, one additional BIOLOGY writing in the major\ncourse (identified by [M] in the course listings), and\none BIOLOGY Capstone course (identified by the\n[CAPS] in the course listings. An overall GPA of\nat least 2.0 must be maintained in all College and\nSchool requirements. A maximum of 4 credits of\ncoursework that are graded S, F may be used toward\nfulfilling School requirements or program options,\nand no other courses taken S or P can be applied\ntoward fulfilling School requirements or program\noptions. Students must complete an exit survey.\nStudents may not double major or take a minor in\nany combination of Biology, Zoology, or General\nStudies Biological Sciences.\nStudents completing this degree will earn a B.S. in\nBiology. In order to obtain teaching credentials in\nthe State of Washington, students must complete\nadditional requirements. Completion of the Master\nin Teaching (MIT) program at WSU will meet state\ncertification requirements (for details, please see\nhttps://education.wsu.edu/graduate/mit/). A 3.0\nis the minimum GPA for admission to the MIT\nprogram at WSU. Students obtaining Biology\nEducation Option would also be competitive for\nother post-baccalaureate teacher certification\nprograms.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 105 [PSCI]\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 106 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nENGR 120 2\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 301 4\nCHEM 345 4\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nTCH LRN 301 3\nForeign Language, if needed\n2 \n0 - 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 370 or MBIOS 303 3 or 4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or 171 [QUAN]\n1 \n4\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language, if needed, or Electives\n2 \n3 or 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nBIOLOGY 370 [M] or 372 [M] 4\nPHYSICS 101 or 201 3\nPHYSICS 111 or 211 1\nProgram Electives\n3 \n4\nSecond Term Hours\nPHYSICS 102 or 202 3\nPHYSICS 112 or 212 1\nTCH LRN 465 3\nProgram Option Requirements\n4 \n3 or 4\nProgram Electives \n3 \n4\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY/TCH LRN 430 3\nSTAT 212, 412, or PSYCH 311 3 or 4\nTCH LRN 467 [M] 3\nTCH LRN 470 3\nProgram Electives \n3 \n4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY [CAPS] or HONORS 450\n5 \n3\nBIOLOGY 403 or 405 3\nBIOLOGY/TCH LRN 431 3\nProgram Option Requirements \n4 \n3 or 4\nProgram Electives or Electives\n3 \n3\nComplete School of Biological Sciences Exit\nSurvey\n_______\n1 \nMATH 106 may be taken as a pre-/co-requisite to\nCHEM 105 and other MATH courses. An overall GPA of\nat least 2.0 must be maintained in all College and\nSchool requirements.
