Students must complete an exit survey.\nStudents may not double major or take a minor in\nany combination of Biology, Zoology, or General\nStudies Biological Sciences.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 105 [PSCI]\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nSOC 101 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 106 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or 171 [QUAN]\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nANTH 203 [DIVR] or Diversity [DIVR]\n2 \n3\nBIOLOGY 251 or 353 4\nCHEM 345 4\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 301 4\nPHIL 365 [HUM] 3\nPHYSICS 101 or 201 3\nPHYSICS 111 or 211 1\nSTAT 212, 412, or PSYCH 311 3 or 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 315 or 354 4\nBIOLOGY 393 [M], 490 [M], or\nBIOLOGY [M]\n2,3,4 \n2 - 4\nForeign Language, if needed, or Program\nEmphasis Requirements\n5,2,3,4 \n3 or 4\nPHYSICS 102 or 202 3\nPHYSICS 112 or 212 1\nPSYCH 333 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 370 [M] 372 [M] 4\nH D 101 or PSYCH 361\n2,3,4 \n3\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or Electives\n5,6 \n6\n\n78\nBiological Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] 3\nProgram Emphasis Requirements or\nElectives\n2,3,4,6 \n12\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY [CAPS] or HONORS 450\n7 \n3\nBIOLOGY 395, 403, or 405 3\nProgram Emphasis Requirements or\nElectives\n2,3,4,6 \n10\nComplete School of Biological Sciences Exit\nSurvey\n_______\n1 \nMATH 106 may be taken as a pre-/co-requisite to\nCHEM 105 and other MATH courses. MATH 108\nmay also be needed.\n2 \nPre-Occupational Therapy Program emphasis\n(13 credits) includes ANTH 203, BIOLOGY 220,\nBIOLOGY 393 [M], COM 102, H D 101.\n3 \nPre-Physical Therapy Program emphasis (8-9\ncredits) includes BIOLOGY 393 [M] or 490 [M],\nKINES 380 or BIOLOGY 350 or BIOLOGY 352,\nPSYCH 361 or H D 101.\n4 \nPre-Physician Assistant Program emphasis (14-15\ncredits) includes CHEM 370 or MBIOS 303, MBIOS\n304 or 306, MBIOS 305, PSYCH 361 or H D 101.\nStudents in this emphasis will also need to complete\na BIOLOGY [M] course to fulfill the University\nrequirement of 2 [M] courses.\n5 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n6 \nPre-Physical Therapy / Pre-Occupational Therapy\n/ Pre-Physician Assistant Program emphasis courses\nshould be selected in consultation with a biology\nadvisor and include coursework to fulfill the\nUniversity requirement of 40 upper division credits.\nIn addition to core biology courses (BIOLOGY 106,\n107, 301, 370 [M] or 372 [M], one from 395, 403,\nor 405, BIOLOGY [CAPS] or HONORS 450), all\nbiology majors must complete 21 semester credits of\nbiological coursework including 15 upper-division\ncredits, 6 of which must be a BIOLOGY prefix\ntaken in residence at WSU. Approved program\nelectives include CHEM 370, KINES 380, MBIOS\n303, 304, 305, 306, PHIL 365, and 200-400-level\nBIOLOGY courses except those used to fulfill core\nrequirements, and any courses approved by advisor.\nA maximum of 4 credits of coursework graded\nS/F may be used toward fulfilling departmental\nrequirements.\n7 \nStudents in Honors College complete HONORS\n450 in lieu of a BIOLOGY [CAPS] course.\nZOOLOGY - ACCELERATED PRE-\nVETERINARY OPTION\n(125 HOURS)\nThe Accelerated Pre-Veterinary Option track allows\nqualified students to earn both a Bachelor of Science\nin Zoology and Doctor of Veterinary Medicine\nwithin a seven-year span. Interested students must\nbe advised by faculty in the School of Biological\nSciences, and should contact the school no later\nthan the first semester of the sophomore year.\nCandidates for the Bachelor of Science in Zoology\nmust fulfill the University and the College of\nArts and Sciences requirements for graduation as\ndescribed in the WSU general catalog. Students must\ncomplete a minimum of 90 undergraduate credits,\nincluding 30 credits of 300-400 level coursework,\nand be accepted into the Veterinary Medicine\nprogram to complete this degree.\nHonors students complete honors requirements in\nplace of UCORE requirements. The math and science\ncomponents of those requirements are fulfilled as\npart of the School requirements described below.\nOther University requirements include: 120 total\ncredits, of which 40 must be 300-400-level credits;\nthe writing portfolio; and two writing in the major\ncourses (identified by [M] in the course listings).\nThe College of Arts and Sciences requires two years\nof high school foreign language or at least two\nsemesters of college-level foreign language. Bachelor\nof Science degree options in Biology and Zoology\nrequire a minimum of 19 semester credits of core\nBIOLOGY courses (BIOLOGY 106, 107, 301, 370 [M]\nor 372 [M], and 395 or 403 or 405). An additional\n21 semester credits of biological sciences coursework\nselected in consultation with your biology advisor\nis required. The 21 semester credits must include\n15 upper division credits, six of which must be\nBIOLOGY courses taken in residence at WSU, one\nadditional BIOLOGY writing in the major course\n(identified by [M] in the course listings), and one\nBIOLOGY Capstone course (identified by the [CAPS]\nin the course listings). VET MED credits fulfill other\nProgram Option electives requirements. An overall\nGPA of at least 2.0 must be maintained in all College\nand School requirements. A maximum of 4 credits\nof coursework that are graded S, F may be used\ntoward fulfilling School requirements or program\noptions, and no other courses taken S or P can be\napplied toward fulfilling School requirements or\nprogram options. Students must complete an exit\nsurvey. Students may not double major or take a\nminor in any combination of Biology, Zoology, or\nGeneral Studies Biological Sciences.\nFor more information about the Accelerated Pre-\nVet Option program contact the School of Biological\nSciences.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 105 [PSCI]\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 106 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or 171 [QUAN]\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 301 4\nCHEM 345 4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nCHEM 370 or MBIOS 303 3 or 4\nPHYSICS 101 or 201 3\nPHYSICS 111 or 211 1\nSTAT 212, 412, or PSYCH 311 3 or 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY [CAPS] or HONORS 450\n2 \n3\nBIOLOGY 321 [M] or BIOLOGY 322 [M] 4\nPHYSICS 102 or 202 3\nPHYSICS 112 or 212 1\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or Elective\n3 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 370 [M] or 372 [M] 4\nBIOLOGY 395, 403, or 405 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language, if needed, or Elective\n3 \n4\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nVET MED 510 4\nVET MED 511\n4 \n5\nVET MED 513 4\nVET MED 568 2\nVET MED 586 1\nSecond Term Hours\nVET MED 512 4\nVET MED 520\n5 \n5\nVET MED 521 3\nVET MED 534 3\nVET MED 545 3\nVET MED 580 1\nComplete School of Biological Sciences Exit\nSurvey\n_______\n1 \nMATH 106 may be taken as a pre-/co-requisite to\nCHEM 105 and other MATH courses. MATH 108\nmay also be needed.\n2 \nA biochemistry course is required for admittance\nto U.S. veterinary colleges.\n3 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n4 \nZoology, Pre-Veterinary/Animal Care Program\nOption electives should be selected in consultation\nwith a biology advisor and must include 12 credits\nselected from BIOLOGY 352, 360, 393 [M], 412,\n423, 428, 432, 438 [M], 495, CHEM 370 or MBIOS\n303, 304, 305, SOE 431, or as approved by advisor.\nBeyond the core requirements (BIOLOGY 106,\n107, 301, 370 [M] or 372 [M], one from 395, 403,\nor 405, BIOLOGY [CAPS] or HONORS 450) all\nzoology majors must complete 21 semester credits\nof biological coursework including 15 upper-\ndivision credits, 6 of which must be a BIOLOGY\nprefix taken in residence at WSU. Approved courses\ninclude 200-400-level BIOLOGY courses not used\nto fulfill core requirements, and any courses\napproved by advisor. A maximum of 4 credits of\ncoursework graded S/F may be used toward fulfilling\ndepartmental requirements or program options and\nmust be approved by advisor.\n5 \nStudents in Honors College complete HONORS\n450 in lieu of a BIOLOGY [CAPS] course.\nMinors\nBiology\nA minor in biology requires a minimum of\n20 hours in BIOLOGY coursework including\nBIOLOGY 106, 107, 301 and 8 additional hours\nof BIOLOGY courses at the 300-level or above.\nNo more than 2 hours in BIOLOGY 490, 491, 494,\n495, 496, 497 or 499 may be included in the 20\nhours. 9 credit hours must be earned in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. All coursework for\nthe minor must have a minimum cumulative GPA\nof 2.0. Students who major in biology or zoology\ncannot be granted a minor in biology.\nZoology\nA minor in zoology requires a minimum of 20\nhours, including BIOLOGY 106, 107, and one of\n321, 322, or 324; and 8 additional hours from the\nfollowing courses: BIOLOGY 315, 330, 333, 335,\n350, 352, 353, 354, 407, 410, 412, 418, 423, 428,\n432, 438, 456, 475, 476, 486, 490, 491, 495, 496,\n497, 499. No more than 2 hours of BIOLOGY 490,\n491, 495, 496, 497, or 499 may be included in the\n20 hours. Credit hours for the minor must include 9\nhours of 300-400-level courses taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. All coursework\nfor the minor must have a minimum cumulative\nGPA of 2.0.\nCertificates\nCertificate in Quantitative\nBiology\nThe certificate in Quantitative Biology requires 17\ncredits. Students must earn a grade of C or higher in\neach course and no P, F or S, F graded course work\nmay be applied to the certificate.\nRequirements:\n• MATH/BIOLOGY 340\n• 6 credits of mathematics (MATH 172 or higher)\nand/or statistics (300-400-level), of which 3 credits\nmust be taken in residence at Washington State\nUniversity\n\n81\nBiological Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n• 8 credits of 300-400-level BIOLOGY courses\nof which 3 credits must be taken in residence at\nWashington State University\nDescription of Courses\nBIOLOGY\nBIOLOGY\n101 [BSCI] Biology of Humans 3 The biology\nof good health and longevity; evaluation of\nlifestyle choices; consideration of each body\nsystem and the potential for disease and\ndisorder. Credit not granted towards elective\nrequirements for majors in the School of\nBiological Sciences.\n102 [BSCI] General Biology 4 (3-3) Enrollment\nnot allowed if credit for BIOLOGY 105\nalready earned. Understanding current\nand future advances in biology as ‘citizen\nscientists’. Lecture and laboratory; not for\nstudents majoring in the life sciences. Credit\nnot allowed for students who have already\ncompleted BIOLOGY 105. Credit not granted\ntowards elective requirements for majors in the\nSchool of Biological Sciences.\n103 Science and Scientific Thinking 1 (0-3)\nExploring science as a tool for understanding\nnature using case studies, experimentation,\nand data analysis. Topics range from atoms to\necosystems including physiology, inheritance,\nand the carbon cycle. Credit not granted\ntowards elective requirements for majors in the\nSchool of Biological Sciences. Recommended\nfor students with an ALEKS math placement\nscore of less than 45%. (Crosslisted course\noffered as BIOLOGY 103, SCIENCE 103).\n105 General Biology Laboratory 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Enrollment not\nallowed if credit for BIOLOGY 102 already\nearned. Understanding biology as a science and\nits effect on issues within society. Laboratory\nonly. Credit not allowed for students who\nhave already completed BIOLOGY 102. Credit\nnot granted towards elective requirements for\nmajors in the School of Biological Sciences.\n106 [BSCI] Introductory Biology: Organismal\nBiology 4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite: One\nof the following -- a minimum ALEKS math\nplacement score of 40%, MATH 100 with an\nS, MATH 101 with a C or better, MATH 103\nor higher, BIOLOGY 103 with a C or better,\nBIOLOGY 102, BIOLOGY 120, or 3 credits\nof biology with a lab. One semester of a two\nsemester sequence (BIOLOGY 106/107 or\nBIOLOGY 107/106) for science majors and pre-\nprofessional students. Biology of organisms;\nplants, animals, ecology and evolution.\n107 [BSCI] Introductory Biology: Cell\nBiology and Genetics 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Minimum 2 credits 100 level\nCHEM or concurrent enrollment. First or\nsecond semester of a one-year sequence\n(BIOLOGY 106/107 or BIOLOGY 107/106) for\nscience majors and pre-professional students.\nCell biology and genetics of prokaryotes and\neukaryotes.\n110 B i o l o g i c a l P e r s p e c t i v e s o n\nEnvironmental Issues 3 Current case\nstudies of human interaction with the\nenvironment exploring concepts in ecology,\nbiodiversity, global chemical cycles, and\nclimate change. Credit not granted towards\nelective requirements for majors in the School\nof Biological Sciences.\n111 [BSCI] Laboratory Experiments in\nBiology and Genetics 1 (0-3) Scientific\nmethod and its application to a diverse range\nof biology and genetics topics and research\nquestions. Credit not granted towards elective\nrequirements for majors in the School of\nBiological Sciences.\n120 [BSCI] Introductory Botany 4 (3-3)\nIntroduction to plant science, highlighting\ncertain aspects of plant biology and current\nresearch and how these relate to us all in the\nmodern world. Credit not granted towards\nelective requirements for majors in the School\nof Biological Sciences.\n125 Genetics and Society 3 Genetic topics in\nmedia and daily life including human health,\nagriculture, ecology and forensics for the\neducated non-biologist. Credit not granted\ntowards elective requirements for majors in\nthe School of Biological Sciences.\n135 Animal Natural History 3 Identification,\nlife history, habitat relations, ecology, behavior,\nand conservation of animals commonly found\nin the Pacific Northwest. Credit not granted\ntowards elective requirements for majors in the\nSchool of Biological Sciences.\n140 [BSCI] Introduction to Nutritional\nScience 3 Information related to dietary\nsources of nutrients, their functions in the\nbody, physiologic and environmental factors\nthat govern nutrient requirements, and\nguidelines for optimal dietary patterns. Smith Hall 213\n509-335-1578\nDepartment Chair and Regents Professor, J. Tang;\nProfessors, B. K. Ahring, G. V. Barbosa-Cánovas, S.\nChen, M. García-Pérez, P. Ndegwa, R. Peters, S. Sablani,\nC. O. Stöckle, J. Wu, Q. Zhang; Associate Professors,\nM. Karkee, H. Lei, S. Sankaran, B. Yang; Assistant\nProfessors, L. Khot, K. Rajagopalan; Research Assistant\nProfessor, M. R. Salazar-Gutierrez; Affiliate Faculty, E.\nBeers, D. Brown, M. Flury, G. Ganjyal, A. Jayakaran,\nH. Lin, D. McCool, J. S. McEwen, J. McIntyre, P.\nPfromm, B. Rasco, M. Wolcott; Adjunct Faculty, W.\nElliott, G. Hoogenboom, J. Liu, G. Muntean, W. Qian,\nP. Robichaud, M. Tucker, S. Wang, M. Wigmosta, A.\nWright, V. Wu; Faculty Emeritus, R. Cavalieri.\nBIOLOGICAL SYSTEMS ENGINEERING\nBiological and Agricultural Engineering is a\nmultidisciplinary program that provides students\nflexibility to acquire and apply knowledge of\nengineering and science in their programs of\nstudy and research projects. The Department\noffers Ph.D. and M.S. degrees in Biological and\nAgricultural Engineering. Students apply scientific\nand engineering principles to conduct high-\nquality research and to disseminate knowledge\nand technologies in four areas of emphasis: a)\nfood engineering, b) bioenergy and bioproducts\nengineering, c) land, air, water resources and\nenvironmental engineering, and d) agricultural\nautomation engineering.\nApplicants to the graduate program should have\na B.S. or M.S. in engineering or a closely related\ndegree, with a cumulative Grade Point Average\n(GPA) 3.0/4.0 or above. Applications must include:\nofficial transcripts for all college level work, contact\ninformation for three references, statement of intent,\nand resume. International applicants must include\nofficial transcripts and their English translations.\nAlso, English proficiency test scores must be sent\nfrom the testing agency directly to Washington\nState University (University Code#4705).\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nDuring their training in our graduate program,\nwe expect students to grow professionally and\nacquire skills for successful careers. Alumni who are\nsuccessful in their careers will exhibit most, if not\nall of these features.\nAcademia\n• Possess a national and international reputation\nfor excellence in their area\n• Value the significance of quality scholarly work\n• Are creative and innovative\n• Contribute to the knowledge base within their\ndiscipline\n• Attract funding for their research\n• Provide leadership to professional organizations\n• Enable undergraduate and graduate engineering\nstudents to be successful in their careers\nIndustry\n• Effectively manage engineering research and/or\ndevelopment research teams\n• Provide leadership in developing industry\nstandards of practice\n• Are creative and innovative\n• Develop profitable products or revenue saving\nmanufacturing procedures\n• Provide vision for future direction of their\ncompanies and for the industry\nGovernment service\n• Provide expert technical knowledge in decision\nmaking processes\n• Provide leadership within their technical and\nprofessional societies\n• Contribute to the development of public policies\n• Provides global perspective in the use of technical\nknowledge\nDescription of Courses\nBIOLOGICAL SYSTEMS ENGINEERING\nBSYSE\n491 Advanced Topics V 1-4 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 8 hours. Directed\ngroup study of selected advanced topics in\nbiological systems engineering.\n512 Research and Teaching Methods 3 (2-\n3) Graduate research with an emphasis on\nbiological systems engineering and college\ninstruction.\n530 Machine Vision for Biological Systems\n3 Image analysis techniques as applied to\nmachine vision applications integrated into\nautonomous equipment used in specialty\ncrops.\n532 Electrohydraulic Systems Control 3\nFluid power transmission, E/H control, control\nsystems and controller design.\n541 Instrumentation and Measurements 3\n(2-3) Basic engineering concepts involving\ninstrumentation including measurement\nsystems, sensors, data acquisition, signal\nprocessing, and analysis.\n550 S o i l a n d Wa t e r C o n s e r v a t i o n\nEngineering 3 Land, water and air\nconservation emphasizing on soil and water\nengineering concepts, state of science solution\ntechniques, and engineering design.\n551 A d v a n c e d B i o l o g i c a l S y s t e m s\nEngineering Topics V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nDirected group study of selected advanced\ntopics in biological systems engineering.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n552 A d v a n c e d B i o l o g i c a l S y s t e m s\nEngineering Topics V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Directed group study of selected\nadvanced topics in biological systems\nengineering. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n554 Aquatic System Restoration 3 Study of\nnatural, damaged and constructed ecosystems\nwith emphasis on water quality protection\nand restoration of lakes, rivers, streams and\nwetlands. (Crosslisted course offered as CE 585\nand BSYSE 554). Required preparation must\ninclude CHEM 345; MBIOS 101. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n\n86\nBiological Systems Engineering\nWashington State University, 2021\n555 Natural Treatment Systems 3 Principles\nand design procedures of natural systems for\nwastewater treatment for agricultural and non-\nagricultural applications. (Crosslisted course\noffered as CE 555, BSYSE 555). Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n556 Surface Hydrologic Processes and\nModeling 3 (2-3) Fundamental hydrologic\nprocesses, governing equations and solution\nmethods, GIS techniques commonly used in\nhydrology, class project on modeling surface\nhydrology.\n557 Nutrient Cycling and Transport 3\nCycling of carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus\nat global and watershed scales; modeling of\ntransportation and transport in agricultural\nsystems\n558 Groundwater Flow and Contaminant\nTransport 4 (3-3) Physics of flow and\ncontaminant transport in saturated porous\nmedia including governing equations, well\nhydraulics and computer modeling.\n560 Aquatic Chemistry 3 Chemical principles as\napplied to natural environmental system, water\nsupply and pollution and control engineering.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CE 583, BSYSE\n560). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n564 Agricultural Waste and Air Quality\nManagement 3 Detailed analyses of\nagricultural wastes and their potential\nadverse impacts on the environment; current\nmanagement systems; reuse and recycle.\n581 Advanced Physical Properties of Foods\n3 Analysis, modeling, and experimental\nprocedures to measure food physical properties\nfor use in food processing system design.\n582 Food Process Engineering I 3 Design of\nfood processing systems; design and simulation\nof sterilization and pasteurization processes in\nfoods. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n583 Food Process Engineering II 3 Design of\nfood separation unit operations including\nconcentration, dehydration, and membrane\nprocesses.\n584 Thermal and Nonthermal Processing\nof Foods 3 Food preservation methods based\non application of thermal and nonthermal\nprocesses.\n585 Food Packaging 3 Properties of packaging\nmaterials, manufacturing of packages, shelf-life\ntesting and food packaging interaction.\n593 Renewable Energy Technologies 3\nThermochemical biorefinery technologies for\nbiofuels and bioproducts; facility operations,\nanalysis, and design of integrated processes for\nbiofuel and bioproduct production\n594 Design and Analysis of Biomass\nConversion Processes and Systems 3\nAnalysis of bioprocessing and biotreatment\np r o c e s s e s i n c l u d i n g e n e r g e n e t i c s ,\ns t o i c h i o m e t r y, s p e c i e s c o m p e t i t i o n ,\nprocess infiltration, product separation and\noptimization.\n595 Biosystems Engineering for Fuel and\nChemicals 3 Design and optimization of\nbiological systems for industrial functions,\nmodeling and simulation of cell processes,\nbioreactors and system integration.\n596 Biomass Thermo-Chemical Conversion\n3 Biomass chemistry, analytical thermo-\nchemistry, torrefaction, pyrolysis, gasification\nand combustion; characterization and uses of\nthermochemical products. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n597 Biomass Biological Process Engineering\n3 Technical issues in the biological process\nengineering field, commercial application and\nevaluation of new technologies in resource,\nenvironment and economic contexts.\n598 Graduate Seminar 1 May be repeated for\ncredit. Required of all graduate students in\nbiological systems engineering. S, F grading.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee chair\nbefore enrolling for 702 credit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. S, U grading.\nCarson College of Business\nbusiness.wsu.edu\nTodd Hall 570\n509-335-3596\nCARSON COLLEGE OF BUSINESS Dean and Professor,\nL. Hunter; Senior Associate Dean for Faculty and\nResearch and Professor, D. Compeau; Senior Associate\nDean for Academic Affairs and Professor, T. Tripp;\nAssociate Dean for Graduate and Online Programs,\nC. Oliver; Associate Dean for International Programs,\nS. Ahn.\nThe Carson College of Business (CCB) prepares\nstudents for innovative and impactful careers in\nbusiness by effectively applying core business\ncompetencies, encouraging ethical and professional\nbehavior, employing a global perspective, enhancing\nabilities to make data-driven decisions, leading\nteams, and communicating persuasively. The\nCarson College of Business reaches students across\nthe state of Washington (and beyond) by offering its\nprograms at the Everett, Global, Pullman, Tri-Cities,\nand Vancouver campuses.\nThe Carson College of Business is among two\npercent of business schools worldwide to achieve\naccreditation by the Association to Advance\nCollegiate Schools of Business (AACSB), the world’s\npremier business education accrediting body, at the\nbaccalaureate, master’s, and doctoral levels. The\nCarson College of Business’s undergraduate and\ngraduate business programs are consistently ranked\namong the top business programs in the country\nby U.S. News & World Report. For current rankings of\nCarson College programs, visit our website: https://\nbusiness.wsu.edu/about-carson/rankings-facts/.\nFaculty across disciplines produce scholarly and\napplied research at the main campus in Pullman\nas well as campuses in Everett, Vancouver, and\nthe Tri-Cities. In addition to these campus and a\nthriving Global campus, international activities\ninclude partnerships and/or programs in Chile,\nChina, France, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Korea,\nSpain, Switzerland, Tanzania, and Thailand. For\nmore information and news about the college, its\nstudents, and programs, visit business.wsu.edu.\nBachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration\nThe Carson College of Business offers eight\nmajors under this degree: Accounting, Business\nAdministration (Vancouver and Tri-Cities campuses\nonly), Entrepreneurship, Finance, International\nBusiness, Management, Management Information\nSystems, and Marketing.\nBachelor of Arts in Hospitality Business\nManagement\nThe Carson College of Business offers three\nmajors under this degree: Hospitality Business\nManagement, Senior Living Management, and\nWine and Beverage Business Management.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nUpon completion of the Bachelor of Arts in\nBusiness Administration and the Bachelor of Arts\nin Hospitality Business Management, graduates will\nhave the knowledge to be able to:\n• Act ethically and professionally.\n• Make theory-based and data-driven decisions.\n• Identify, assess, and initiate opportunities to\ncreate value.\n• Gain a global business perspective and be\nsensitive to and respectful of cultural differences.\n• Communicate clearly and persuasively, both\norally and in writing.\n• Lead a team and act as an effective team member\n\n87\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\nAdmission to the Major and Minor\nGiven high demand for business courses and\nstrict accreditation requirements, acceptance into\nthe Business Administration (BA) and Hospitality\nBusiness Management (HBM) degree majors is\ncompetitive and course enrollments are limited.\nA student must meet the following minimum\nrequirements to be eligible to apply for a CCB major:\n• Complete the following courses with a grade of C\nor higher: B A 100 Introduction to Business; HBM\n101 Professional Development; B A 102 Exploring\nCareers in Business; MATH 201 Mathematics for\nBusiness & Economics (MATH 202 or ALEKS score\nof 80% or higher is an acceptable substitute. MATH\n106 will be accepted as an alternative to MATH 201\nfor transfer students); ECONS 101 Microeconomics,\nOR ECONS 102 Macroeconomics.\n• Complete the Carson Career Amplifier Program\nYear 1\n• Have a WSU cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and\nnot be on academic probation\n• Complete at least 27 credit hours\nStudents will be placed in rank order based on GPA\nand other performance criteria. The top students\nthen are admitted to the major based on the number\nof spots available that semester.\nTo be eligible for admission to a CCB minor,\na student must meet the following minimum\nrequirements:\n• Be admitted to a major\n• Have a cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and not\nbe on academic probation\nStudents will be placed in rank order based on\ncumulative GPA and other performance criteria.\nThe top students then are admitted based on the\nnumber of spots available that semester.\nStudents must apply to be admitted to the major/\nminor during the term they anticipate completing\nthe above requirements. On the Pullman campus,\nearly application during the first half of the semester\nis encouraged to avoid delays in course enrollment.\nSee https://business.wsu.edu/undergraduate/certify/\nmajors-requirements\nIn order to remain a major in the Carson College\nof Business, students must maintain a minimum\nof 2.50 business GPA. Students who do not meet\nthis requirements are subject to Academic Rule 53.\nCarson College Core Business\nRequirements\nThe following Core Business classes are designed\nto provide business majors with a solid foundation\nin business, strengthen their professional skills, and\nmeet the learning outcomes listed above.\n• B A 100 Intro to Business\n• HBM 101 Professional Development\n• B A 102 Exploring Careers in Business\n• B A 201 Ethics, B A 202 Teams, B A 203\nInnovation; or B A 211 Ethics, Teams, Innovation\n• B A 204 Decision Analysis, B A 205 Spreadsheets,\nB A 206 Data Visualization; or B A 212 Decision\nAnalysis, Spreadsheets, Data Visualization\n• ACCTG 230 Intro to Financial Accounting\n• ACCTG 231 Intro to Managerial Accounting\n• B LAW 210 Law & the Legal Environment of\nBusiness\n• MGTOP 215 Business Statistics\n• MIS 250 Managing Information Technology\n• I BUS 380 International Business\n• MGTOP 340 Operations Management; or HBM\n494 Service Operations Management (HBM/WBBM\nmajors only)\n• FIN 325 Intro to Financial Management\n• MKTG 360 Marketing\nInternational Experience Requirement\n(IER)\nLearning Outcomes\nUpon completing the IER, students should be\nable to:\n• Appreciate differences in the external\nenvironmental factors that affect global business\n• Identify the specific elements of the cultural\nenvironment that affect global business decisions\n• Evaluate the implications of the external\nenvironmental factors on global business decisions\n• Incorporate global economic, political and\ncultural factors when making global business\nrecommendations\nStudents can satisfy the IER requirements by\ncompleting one of the following:\n• Study abroad for 6 or more credit hours. Two\nsmaller study abroad programs may be cumulated\nto meet the entire 6 credit-hour requirement.\nInternational students in the Carson College of\nBusiness (not including WSU Global students) will\nmeet their study abroad requirement through their\nstudy in the United States.\n• Complete a major or minor in a foreign language.\n• Students that demonstrate proficiency in a foreign\nlanguage (e.g., STAMP test) will be deemed to have\nmet the Carson College of Business International\nExperience Requirement. [Honors College students\nthat meet their demonstrated proficiency in a\nforeign language will also be deemed to have met\nthe Carson College of Business IER.]\n• C o m p l e t e a m i n i m u m o f o n e y e a r o f\ninternational experience in any of the following\nareas: military service, Peace Corps, Volunteer work\nwith an organization, missionary work, or other.\nDocumentation must be submitted to the student’s\nacademic advisor for approval.\nComplete two of the following:\n• T h e G l o b a l L e a d e r s h i p C e r t i f i c a t e o r\nother certificate with a major international\ncomponent (e.g. The East Asia Program) as approved\nby the administrative head of the International\nBusiness Institute or Department of Marketing and\nInternational Business.\n• A brief study abroad program of at least 3 credit\nhours.\n• An “international non-business course”.\nApproved courses include: AMDT 413; ANTH 301,\n306, 307, 309, 312, 316, 317, 320, 330, 350, 370, 405,\n417, 418, 450, 469; ARCH 428; ASIA 302, 315, 373,\n374, 477, 479; BIOLOGY 401; CES 301, 325, 372,\n377, 379, 380, 401, 405, 421, 426, 470; COMSOC\n321; CRM J 405; CROP SCI 360; ECONS 427, 428,\n430, 433, 453; ENGLISH 373, 410, 457; FINE ART\n331; FOR LANG 410; H D 350, 403; HISTORY 331,\n373, 374, 436, 464, 466, 473, 477, 479, 491, 492,\n494, 495; HUMANITY 350; PHIL 314, 315; POL S\n314, 424, 427, 435; RUSSIAN 410; SOC 331, 332,\n375, 415; SOE 300, 312, 390, 412; SOIL SCI 360;\nTCH LRN 480, 487; WOMEN ST 316, 332, 340, 406.\n• An approved 300-400-level “international\nbusiness or economics course”. Approved courses\ninclude: ACCTG 420; ECONS 327; FIN 481; I BUS\n415, 416, 435, 453, 470, 482, 496; MIS 441.\n• At least 3 credits in a foreign language. Approved\ncourses include: CHINESE 101, 102, 203; FRENCH\n101, 102, 203; GERMAN 101, 102, 203; ITALIAN\n101, 102; JAPANESE 101, 102, 203; LATIN 101, 102;\nRUSSIAN 101, 102, 203; SPANISH 101, 102, 203.\nSign Language is not an approved foreign language\nto satisfy this requirement. Students who wish to\nrequest alternative foreign language courses to be\nused to satisfy this requirement must work through\ntheir academic advisor to prepare a formal request\nfor approval to the International Business Institute.\n• An international internship approved by the\nDepartment of Marketing and International\nBusiness (maximum of 3 credit hours).\n• An accepted petition to the Department of\nMarketing and International Business to allow the\nuse of extensive international travel experiences\nat the collegiate or corporate level for up to 3\ncredit hours towards the International Experience\nRequirement. Although petitions must be approved\nprior to the international travel, exceptional cases\ncan be reviewed on a case-by-case basis. Normally\nsuch an experience will be at least three months\nin duration.\n• A University course research project with an\ninternational business research focus that is a\nsignificant part of the course learning component,\nand that constitutes 40% or more of the class.\nThe petition for allowing a project work to count\ntowards the International Experience Requirement\nshould be signed off by the course instructor, and\nthe final approval will be made by the Department\nof Marketing and International Business for Pullman\nbased students, and an IBUS Fellow or Area Director\nfor urban campus students. *\n• Participate as finalists in an international or global\ncase competition (e.g., Global Case Competition\nconducted by WSU International Programs). The\ndetermination of whether a case competition can\nbe counted towards the International Experience\nRequirement will be made through a petition to\nthe Department of Marketing and International\nBusiness. Although only final round participants\ncan be considered, exceptional cases that did not\nmake it to the final round can also be considered\non a case-by-case basis by the International\nBusiness Institute or Department of Marketing and\nInternational Business, which will make the final\napproval.\n* Students also need to obtain pre-approval from\ncourse instructor prior to start of project work on\nthe petition form that is available with advisors at\nthe respective campus locations.\nCarson Career Amplifier Program\nThe Carson Career Amplifier Program (CCAP)\nengages students in co-curricular activities and\nprograms that provide students with the opportunity\nto develop professional skills and experiences that\nemployers are seeking. In addition to required\ncoursework, earning a degree in the Carson College\nof Business requires students to complete several\ncategories of co-curricular requirements each year.\nCategories are based on a subset of the National\nAssociation of College and Employers (NACE)\nCareer Readiness Competencies and include:\n• Communication\n• Leadership\n• Professionalism\n• Career Management\nThe CCAP program helps students to develop the\nprofessional skills needed to become business leaders\nof tomorrow. With a focus on professionalism,\nnetworking, and engagement, students will select\n\n88\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\nfrom a menu of online and in-person activities\nthat satisfy each requirement. Each year, CCAP\nrequirements become progressively more involved;\nfrom learning about student success strategies in the\nfreshman year, to participating in an internship or\nstudy abroad as a junior or senior. Details about\nrequirements for satisfying annual milestones can\nbe found on the Carson College website.\nStudents can expect to spend a minimum of\n7-10 co-curricular hours each year, depending on\nhow students choose to satisfy each requirement.\nHowever, as students become involved in leadership\nactivities and high impact learning experiences,\nthe amount of co-curricular hours will increase.\nFor example, over the course of one academic year,\na student attending weekly club meetings could\nspend about 26 hours in club meetings, a summer\ninternship could total 300-400 hours, and a 6-week\nfaculty led study abroad program averages about\n250 hours.\nExamples of activities that could be used to satisfy\ncompetencies:\nCommunication: • Networking events •\nProfessional development seminars on resume/\ncover letter development and interview preparation\n• Mock interviews • Jobs or volunteer work that\ninvolve public speaking;\nL e a d e r s h i p : • I n c r e a s i n g c o m m i t m e n t /\ninvolvement in clubs and organizations resulting in\nthe opportunity to take on leadership roles. Includes\nbusiness clubs, student government, current work,\nGreek & Residence Hall leadership, community\norganizations, roles such as Resident Assistant (RA)\nand Research Assistant. • Structured leadership\nprograms/trainings • Increasing leadership\nresponsibilities within current employment;\nProfessionalism: • Activities that increase student\nunderstanding of professional standards expected\nin higher education (in and outside the classroom)\n• Activities that increase student understanding\nof professional standards expected by employers\n(internships, relevant work experiences, business\nconsulting projects) • Opportunities that allow\nstudents to strengthen and demonstrate their\nprofessionalism and work ethic;\nCareer Management: • Assessing oneself\n(strengths/weaknesses, interests/dislikes, abilities,\nvalues) • Learning about majors, internships,\ncareers/employers, professional development\nopportunities in order to make informed decisions\n• Setting major/career goals based on analyzing\noneself and career opportunities • Identifying areas\nwithin one’s skillset that need to be developed/\nstrengthened • Pursuing activities that strengthen\nareas needing growth & development.\nOptions used to satisfy competency will be\nbased on the availability of events/activities at\neach campus and Global Campus students will\nhave the ability to satisfy requirements through\nevents/activities in their surrounding community\nand current employment site. If an activity/event\nis not on the list, students, advisors, and faculty\nwill have the ability to propose additional events/\nactivities that align with the goals for a competency.\nEach year (based on credit hours) will be tracked as\nmilestones in the myWSU system. Completion of\nthe first year of the CCAP is required for admission\ninto the College. Subsequent years will be tracked\nannually. Completion of the CCAP for all 4 years\nis required for graduation.\nGraduation Requirements\nIn addition to fulfilling the University\nrequirements for graduation listed in the Summary\nof Academic Policies section of the WSU Catalog,\nto graduate with a CCB degree, students must also\nmeet the Carson College of Business requirements\nlisted below, and the major requirements (described\nin the departmental section of this catalog).\nCarson College of Business Requirements:\n• Completion of admission to the major\nrequirements listed above.\n• Completion of requirements listed in the\nSchedule of Studies.\n• Completion of the International Experience\nRequirement (listed above).\n• Completion of the Carson Career Amplifier\nProgram (requirements for each of the 4 years) (see\nabove).\n• Completion of at least two ‘Writing in the Major’\n[M] courses for each major.\n• A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.50 in all CCB\ncourses (counting only WSU business courses taught\nby CCB including HBM courses). Economic Sciences\ncourses or other courses outside the college are not\nincluded (with the exception of ECONS 327 which\nis cross-listed with a CCB course).\n• At least nine 300-400-level business courses must\nbe WSU courses*.\n* A WSU course is a course that does not require\nevaluation for transfer credit.\nAdditional Information and Requirements\nEnrollment in most 300-400-level business\ncourses is restricted to students who have met\nthese requirements and have been admitted to\nthe BA or HBM degree major. Students admitted\nto non-business majors may enroll in restricted\n300-400-level business courses with permission of\nthe department chair as space is available.\nThe chair of the department and/or the senior\nassociate dean of the college must approve in\nwriting any business courses to be satisfied by\ntransfer, correspondence, independent study, or\nother credit. Additional transfer, correspondence,\nand independent study credit (within University\nlimits on these credits) may count toward the\n120 hours required for the degree and/or satisfy\nrequirements other than major courses.\nOnly general elective courses that are not\nUniversity Common Requirements (UCORE), not\ncore/major requirements, and not offered by the\nCCB may be taken pass, fail.\nAn honors senior project is required for Honors\nstudents.\nDouble Majors in Business\nStudents may pursue two business majors (double\nmajor) by completing at least 15 additional credits\n(18 credits for accounting) from courses specifically\nrequired by the second major and distinct from\nthose used to satisfy the first major, including\ntwo Writing in the Major [M] courses per major.\nCourses used to fulfill the primary major cannot\nbe used to fulfill the requirements of the second\nmajor. A double major with Hospitality Business\nManagement and Wine Business Management is\nnot permitted.\nSecond Bachelor’s Degree\nStudents who are pursuing a bachelor’s degree\noutside of the College of Business may obtain\na second degree of Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration or Bachelor of Arts in Hospitality\nBusiness Management by completing the following\nadditional requirements:\n• Complete the admission to the major\nrequirements listed above and apply to be admitted.\n• Complete all college and major requirements,\nincluding two Writing in the Major [M] courses\nper major, and the International Experience\nRequirements listed above.\n• Complete a minimum of 150 credit hours.\nStudents seeking a second degree with a business\nmajor must apply to be admitted to the Carson\nCollege before they can enroll in 300-400-level\nbusiness courses (see Admission to the Major\nand Minor requirements above). Students should\nconsult the Carson Center for Student Success for\nspecific degree requirements.\nTransfer Students\nStudents planning to transfer to Washington State\nUniversity should follow, as closely as possible,\nthe University and College requirements listed\nabove. It should also be noted that courses\ntaken at community colleges are not accepted as\ntransferable equivalents to 300-400-level courses\nat WSU. Transfer students are strongly advised to\nuse the WSU Transfer Clearinghouse website to see\nhow credits will transfer to WSU and to refer to\nthe Carson Center for Student Success website for\nadditional transfer information specific to Business.\nMaster of Business\nAdministration\nhttps://onlinemba.wsu.edu/mba\nCommons Hall 101\n509-335-7617 Pullman Campus\n877-960-2029 Online\nFaculty: S. Bergstedt, J. Bravo, C. Chi, S. Fotopoulos, D.\nGursoy, R. Hernandez, J. Hu, J. Johnson, J. Joireman, M.\nJordan, J. Kallberg, H. Kim, T. Kokta, V. Kolde, R. Liu,\nG. Mader, B. Marlowe, D. Miller, R. Moser, D. Muehling,\nD. Mundell, M. Petersen, A. Prera, M. Reyes, G. Rose,\nJ. Rose, R. Sanchez, S. Silverman, P. Skilton, J. Taylor,\nB. Wong-On-Wing.\nThe MBA program in the Carson College of\nBusiness features nationally prominent faculty with\nadditional layers of faculty support that encourage\nfrequent and personal interaction among faculty\nand students. The MBA program focuses on student\nmastery of knowledge and application in today’s\nbusiness environment. The CCB offers two MBA\nprograms within the MBA degree: the online MBA\n(OMBA) and the online executive MBA (EMBA).\nInformation about application deadlines is\navailable on our website.\nOMBA PROGRAM\nThe OMBA curriculum is divided into three\nsections: Foundation, Core, and Electives.\nOMBA Foundation:\nOMBA candidates begin with a foundation\nin business before taking core coursework. The\n\n89\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\nfoundation coursework includes the courses listed\nbelow. Previous coursework in business may permit\nthe waiving of some or all of these foundation\ncourses based on course equivalency evaluations.\n• ACCTG 550\n• B A 500\n• B A 501\n• B A 502\n• B A 503\n• B A 504\n• ECONS 555\n(Note that for any course with a non-B A prefix,\nits course description is listed under the department\nthat offers the course.) Students who complete the\nfoundation curriculum at WSU with the required\nGPA are eligible to receive a certificate in General\nBusiness Administration. See the certificate\nrequirements for specific information.\nMBA PROGRAM Curriculum (36 Credits)\nA minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0 is required for\nthe MBA degree.\nCore Curriculum (27 credits)\n• ACCTG 533\n• B A 514\n• FIN 526\n• MIS 580\n• MKTG 506\n• MGMT 590\n• MGMT 593\n• B A 579 (4 credits)\n• B A 599 (1 credit)\n• B A 600 (1 credit)\n• Electives (9 credits): Students may choose to take\nan array of electives or to concentrate in a specific\narea. Approved courses include BA 595, 597, FIN\n521, 527, 528, 581, HBM 535, 581, 582, I BUS 580,\n582, 600, MKTG 507, 561, 565, 577. Not all courses\nor concentrations are available at all times.\nEMBA PROGRAM (40 credits)\nA minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0 is required for\nthe Executive MBA degree. Foundation courses are\nnot required for the Executive MBA.\n• ACCTG 533\n• B A 514\n• FIN 526\n• I BUS 580\n• I BUS 600, MGTOP 587, B A 595 or 597\n• MIS 572\n• MIS 580\n• MKTG 506\n• MGMT 588\n• MGMT 590\n• MGMT 593\n• MGTOP 581\n• B A 579 (4 credits)\n• B A 599 (1 credit)\n• B A 600 (1 credit)\nCERTIFICATES\nThe Carson College of Business offers certificates\nfor graduate, professional, and MBA students\nconcentrating in specific areas. Admissions to the\nelective certificates is the same as admission to the\nMBA program. Students must complete a minimum\nof 9 credits (except for the General Business\ncertificate which requires seven courses) and earn\na cumulative 3.0 GPA with no grades below B- in\nthe concentration to earn a certificate. The elective\nseries in the OMBA may be used to earn a certificate.\nCertificate in Finance:\nFIN 521, FIN 527, FIN 528, FIN 581\nCertificate in Hospitality and Tourism:\nHBM 535, HBM 581, HBM 582\nCertificate in International Business:\nFIN 581, I BUS 580, I BUS 582, I BUS 600\nCertificate in Marketing:\nI BUS 582, MKTG 507, MKTG 561, MKTG 565,\nMKTG 577\nCertificate in General Business\nAdministration:\nACCTG 550, B A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ECONS\n555 (Students with previous coursework in statistics\nand/or economics may not be required to complete\nB A 500 and/or ECONS 555.)\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBUSINESS ADMINISTRATION, VANCOUVER\nAND TRI-CITIES CAMPUSES ONLY\n(120 HOURS)\nThe following major is available only to students\non the Vancouver and Tri-Cities campuses. The\nPullman, Everett, and Global campuses do not offer\nthis major.\nGraduation Requirements\nTo graduate with a Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration with a major in Business\nAdministration, students are required to complete\nall admission and graduation requirements listed in\nthe Carson College of Business (CCB) section of the\ncatalog and the coursework included in the sample\n4-year plan listed below.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nB A 100 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] \n1 \n3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] or 105 [WRTG] 3\nMATH \n3\nComplete Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 1\nApply for Admission into the Major\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nACCTG 230 3\nB A 201, 202, and 203, or B A 211 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMIS 250 3\nSocial Science or Humanities Elective\n4 \n3\nConsider studying abroad this summer\n5\nSecond Term Hours\nACCTG 231 3\nB A 204, 205, and 206, or B A 212 3\nB LAW 210 3\nCOM 102 [COMM], H D 205 \n5\nComplete Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 4\n_______\n1 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n2 \nMATH 201 will be waived with an Aleks score of\n80% or higher or the completion of MATH 202\nor equivalent. MATH 106 will be accepted as an\nalternative to MATH 201 for transfer students.\n3 \nAlternative to MATH 202 is MATH 140 or 171.\n4 \nSocial Science or Humanities Electives (6 credits):\nAny courses with the [SSCI] or [HUM] designation,\nor courses in ANTH, ASIA, CES, CRM J, DTC, ECONS,\nENGLISH (excluding ENGLISH 402 or 403), FINE\nART, FOR LANG, HISTORY, HONORS 270, 280, 370,\n380, H D, HUMANITY, PHIL, POL S, PSYCH, SOC,\nand WOMEN ST not used to fulfill other (including\nUCORE) requirements.\n5 \nAll students must complete the International\nExperience Requirement. Options for completing\nthe requirement can be found in the Carson College\nof Business Academic Unit section of the catalog\nunder Business (Pullman, Tri-Cities) or Business\n\n90\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\nAdministration (Vancouver). Students should\nconsult with their advisor to determine the best\noption.\n6 \nMATH/STAT 212 will be accepted as alternative to\nMGTOP 215 for transfer students.\n7 \n300-400-level Business or ECONS elective (11\ncredits). Must include at least 6 credits of 400-level\nbusiness courses. May not include courses from the\nCCB core, the set of required business administration\ncourses, or any 498 Internship or 499 Special Topics\ncourses.\n8 \nSocial Science or Humanities Electives (6 credits)\nAny courses in ANTH, CRM J, DTC, ECONS,\nENGLISH (excluding ENGLISH 402 or 403), FINE\nART, FOR LANG, HISTORY, HONORS 270, 280,\n370, 380, H D, POL S, PSYCH, SOC, and WOMEN\nST not used to fulfill other (including UCORE)\nrequirements.\nMinors\nBusiness Administration\nPlease see the Carson College of Business section\nof this Catalog for additional instructions. To be\nadmitted into the Business Administration minor,\nstudents must meet the following minimum\nrequirements:\n• Complete 27 credits.\n• WSU cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and not on\nacademic probation\nThe minor in business administration requires a\nminimum of 18 credits of coursework, including:\n• B A 100\n• ACCTG 220 or 230\n• MGMT 301 or HBM 381\n• Any two upper-division Carson College of\nBusiness courses (excluding 498 and 499 courses).\n• Any one Carson College of Business course at\nany level.\n• Students must maintain an overall GPA of at least\na 2.50 in the business administration minor courses.\n• A minimum of 9 credits of upper-division\ncoursework must be taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses.\n• Up to 6 credits may be transferred from another\ninstitution.\nTo be admitted into this minor, students must\nmeet with a business advisor and declare their\ninterest. Students must ensure that they meet all\ncourse prerequisites before enrolling in any College\nof Business courses.\nCertificates\nCertificate of Behavioral Business\nResearch\nThe certificate of Behavioral Business Research is\nopen to all Carson College of Business majors. This\nprogram prepares students for new and emerging\nresearch techniques in business behavior research.\nTo complete the certificate, students must complete\n15 credits consisting of three core courses and two\nadditional electives with a GPA of 2.5 or better.\nRequired core courses include MKTG 360, 368,\nand 487. Fulfillment of elective emphasis courses\nrequires completion of MKTG 407 and 467; or 6\ncredits from MIS 374, 400, 420, 426; or as approved\nby advisor.\nProfessional Sales Certificate\n(Vancouver and Pullman\nCampuses Only)\nThe Professional Sales Certificate Program at WSU is\nopen to all majors. This program prepares students\nfor multiple forms of persuasive communication,\ncreating and delivering value to business customers\nand effectively managing sales operations. To\ncomplete the certificate, students must complete\n15 credits consisting of three required courses and\ntwo additional electives with a 2.5 GPA or better.\nRequired core courses include MKTG 360, 379, and\n478. Two additional electives should be drawn from\nMKTG 450, 479, 480, ENTRP 490, HBM 480, and\nMGMT 485.\nDescription of Courses\nBUSINESS ADMINISTRATION\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nB A\n100 Introduction to Business 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 103, 106, 140, 171, 172,\n182, 201, 202, or concurrent enrollment\nallowed, or ALEKS score of 40% or higher.\nOverview of business activities and disciplinary\nfunctions found in modern for-profit\norganizations; introduction to each of Carson\nCollege of Business learning goals.\n102 Exploring Careers in Business 1 Course\nPrerequisite: B A 100; MATH 106, 140, 171,\n172, 182, 201, 202, or concurrent enrollment\nallowed. Conduct research to better understand\nbusiness expectations; use career assessments\nto clarify major and career goals; develop\naction plan; write application for admission\ninto a Carson College of Business major.\n201 Ethics for Business 1 Course Prerequisite:\nB A 100; B A 102; HBM 101; admitted to a\nmajor or minor in Carson College of Business.\nEnrollment not allowed if credit already earned\nfor B A 211. Introduction to business ethics;\noverview of ethics value foundations; focus on\npreparing students to make business decisions\nethically. Credit not granted for both B A 201\nand 211.\n202 Teams 1 Course Prerequisite: B A 100; B A\n102; HBM 101; admitted to a major or minor\nin Carson College of Business. Enrollment not\nallowed if credit already earned for B A 211.\nTeam and group dynamics, including factors\nand behaviors that impede or increase team\nperformance; leadership roles in teams. Credit\nnot granted for both B A 202 and 211.\n203 Innovation 1 Course Prerequisite: B A 100; B\nA 102; HBM 101; admitted to a major or minor\nin Carson College of Business. Enrollment not\nallowed if credit already earned for B A 211.\nProcess of innovation inside organizations;\nfactors and behaviors that promote innovation\ncreation and implementation. Credit not\ngranted for both B A 203 and 211.\n204 Spreadsheets 1 Course Prerequisite:\nSophomore standing. Enrollment not\nallowed if credit already earned for B A 212.\nIntroduction to spreadsheets; basics for using\nspreadsheets for data analysis and to support\ndecision-making. Credit not granted for both\nBA 204 and 212.\n205 Data Visualization 1 Course Prerequisite:\nCourse Prerequisite: B A 204 or concurrent\nenrollment. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for B A 212. Principles and\ntechniques of representing data visually in\ngraphs, charts, and diagrams; communicating\ndata-based results effectively; skeptical\ninterpretation of visually represented findings\nwhen making decisions. Credit not granted for\nboth B A 205 and 212.\n206 Decision Analysis 1 Course Prerequisite: B\nA 204 or concurrent enrollment. Enrollment\nnot allowed if credit already earned for B A\n212. Introduction to techniques for making\ninformed and logical decisions in a business\ncontext. Credit not granted for both B A 206\nand 212.\n211 Ethics, Teams, and Innovation 3 Course\nPrerequisite: B A 100; B A 102; HBM 101;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for B A 201, 202, or 203.\nIntroduction to business ethics; overview of\nethics value foundations; focus on preparing\nstudents to make business decisions ethically;\nteam and group dynamics, including factors\nand behaviors that impede or increase team\nperformance; leadership roles in teams; process\nof innovation inside organizations; factors and\nbehaviors that promote innovation creation\nand implementation. Credit not granted for B\nA 211 if credit is already earned in either B A\n201, 202, or 203.\n212 Spreadsheets, Data Visualization, and\nDecision Analysis 3 Course Prerequisite:\nSophomore standing. Enrollment not allowed\nif credit already earned for B A 204, 205, or 206.\nIntroduction to basics for using spreadsheets for\ndata analysis and to support decision-making;\nprinciples and techniques of representing\ndata visually in graphs, charts, and diagrams;\ncommunicating data-based results effectively;\nskeptical interpretation of visually represented\nfindings when making decisions; techniques\nfor making informed and logical decisions in a\nbusiness context; introduction to spreadsheets.\nCredit not granted for B A 212 if credit is\nalready earned in either B A 204, 205, or 206.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n\n91\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n500 Data Analysis for Managers V 1-3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program.\nDescriptive statistics, probability, common,\ndiscrete, and continuous distribution\nfunctions, sampling and estimation, and\nstatistical inference.\n501 F oundations in Marketing V 2-3\nFoundation topics in marketing for MBA\nstudents.\n502 Foundations in Operations Management\nV 2-3 Foundation topics in operations\nmanagement for MBA students.\n503 Foundations in Business Law V 2-3\nFoundation topics in business law for MBA\nstudents.\n504 Foundations in Finance V 2-3 Foundation\ntopics in finance for MBA students.\n514 Business Analytics: Transforming\nData into Decisions 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program and completion\nof MBA Prerequisites, including: B_A 500, 501,\n502, 503, 504, ACCTG 550 and ECONS 555.\nAdvanced decision-making concepts utilizing\nrelevant datasets for data-driven problem-\nsolving and formulating decision analyses to\nevaluate and recommend management action.\n520 Resources, Stakeholders and Competitive\nAdvantage 3 Course Prerequisite: Admission\nto the MBA program. Creating competitive\nadvantage using resources provided by key\nstakeholders.\n579 MBA Capstone V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: Admission to the MBA\nprogram. Analyze, evaluate, and recommend\nmanagement actions for a specific strategic\nbusiness project (for an existing organization\nor new venture).\n590 Seminar in Management Teaching\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to PhD\nprograms in business. Conceptual and skills-\nbased knowledge for teaching including\ndesigning curriculum, developing and\ndelivering course materials, evaluations, and\nteaching practice.\n595 Applying Design Thinking to Career and\nLife 3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to the\nOnline MBA program. Applying the principles\nof design thinking to life and career decisions;\nwill reflect on the meaning of work and life\nand how to build (one of the many options\nthat lead to) one’s best life.\n596 Doctoral Topics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 15 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to PhD programs in\nbusiness. Advanced topics in business research\nand theory.\n597 Emerging Trends in Business 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the Online MBA\nprogram. Evaluation of the emerging trends\nand forces that continually shape and reshape\nthe business environment; topics will focus\non emerging issues pertinent to technology,\nmarket dynamics (preferences, behaviors,\nethnographics and demographics), business\npractices, and the legislative/regulatory\nenvironment among other topics.\n598 Research and Professional Development\n1 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to PhD programs in business. Ph.D.-\nlevel professional development colloquium\ndesigned to improve research, teaching, and\npresentation skills and to provide professional\nsocialization. S, F grading.\n599 Strategic Planning for Personal and\nProgram Success 1 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program. Background\nand framework for successfully transitioning\ninto the role of a working professional MBA\nstudent, including personal assessments and\nplanning, case methods, and ethics training;\ndesigned to ensure successful outcomes of MBA\nstudents and leaders.\n600 Beyond the MBA: Applications of\nPrinciples, Theory, and Practice 1 Course\nPrerequisite: Completion of 27 MBA credits and\ncompletion of MBA Prerequisites, including:\nB_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG 550 and\nECONS 555. Leveraging the MBA for lifetime\nsuccess; framework and tools for successfully\nsynthesizing and applying the MBA in the\nglobal workplace, as a manager and a leader.\nS, F grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program and\ncompletion of MBA Prerequisites, including:\nB_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG 550 and\nECONS 555. Independent research in special\nproblems, directed study, and/or examination\ncredit for students in a non-thesis master’s\ndegree program. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 702 credit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe Business Administration PhD program.\nIndependent research and advanced study for\nstudents working on their doctoral research,\ndissertation and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n800 credit. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Accounting\nbusiness.wsu.edu/accounting/\nTodd 242\n509-335-8541\nChair and Professor, B. Wong-on-Wing; Professors, J.\nGramlich, R. Toolson; Associate Professors, B. Barnes,\nS. Gill, C. Latham, L. Xu; Assistant Professors, X. Gao,\nK. Harris, J. Jaggi, C. Potter, R. Sommerfeldt; Clinical\nFaculty, J. Porter; Instructors, K. Jones, S. Bergstedt, J.\nGriffeath, N. Pearson; Professor Emeritus, D. Sanders.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nACCOUNTING\n(120 HOURS)\nThe objectives of the Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration with a major in accounting are to\nprovide knowledge about practical and conceptual\naccounting, basic accounting information systems,\nfinancial reporting and taxation, auditing, and\nthe use of accounting information for managerial\ndecision-making purposes. This provides\npreparation for careers in private, governmental,\nand non-profit accounting. It also provides a\nfoundation to enter the Master of Accounting\nprogram for those interested in a professional career\nin public accounting or consulting.\nGraduation Requirements\nTo graduate with a Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration with a major in Accounting,\nstudents are required to complete all admission\nand graduation requirements listed in the Carson\nCollege of Business (CCB) section of this catalog\nand the coursework included in the sample 4-year\nplan listed below.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nB A 100 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI]\n1 Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 4\n_______\n1 \nFor Students in the Honors Program: ECONS\n198 is an approved substitute for ECONS 101 and\n102; COM 102/H D 205/MKTG 279 requirement is\nwaived; HONORS 198 is an approved substitute for\nHBM 101; ENGLISH 198 is an approved substitute\nfor ENGLISH 101; ACCTG 298 is an approved\nsubstitute for ACCTG 230 and 231. Honors students\nmay need to enroll in elective coursework to meet\nUniversity requirement of 120 credits.\n2 \nMATH 201 will be waived with an ALEKS score\nof 80% or higher, or the completion of MATH 202\nor equivalent. MATH 106 will be accepted as an\nalternative to MATH 201 for transfer students.\n3 \nAlternative to MATH 202 is MATH 140 or 171.\n4 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n5 \nAll students must complete the International\nExperience Requirement. Options for completing\nthe requirement can be found in the Carson College\nof Business Academic Unit section of the catalog\nunder Business. Students should consult with their\nadvisor to determine the best option.\n6 \nMATH/STAT 212 will be accepted as alternative to\nMGTOP 215 for transfer students.\n7 \nSocial Science or Humanities Electives (6 credits):\nAny courses with the [SSCI] or [HUM] designation,\nor courses in ANTH, ASIA, CES, CRM J, DTC, ECONS,\nENGLISH (excluding ENGLISH 402 or 403), FINE\nART, FOR LANG, HISTORY, HONORS 270, 280, 370,\n380, H D, HUMANITY, PHIL, POL S, PSYCH, SOC,\nand WOMEN ST not used to fulfill other (including\nUCORE) requirements.\n8 \n300-400-level Accounting or Business Electives\n(6 credits): Any 300-400-level three-credit course\noffered by the Carson College of Business with the\nexception of courses from the CCB core, the set of\nrequired accounting courses, or any 498 Internships\nor 499 Special Topics courses.\nDescription of Courses\nACCOUNTING\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nACCTG\n220 Introductory Accounting for Non-\nBusiness Majors 3 Course Prerequisite:\nEnrollment not granted if credit already\nearned for ACCTG 230 or 231. Survey of\nselected introductory financial and managerial\naccounting topics. Credit not granted if credit\nhas been earned in ACCTG 230 and/or 231.\n230 Introduction to Financial Accounting\n3 Course Prerequisite: Completed 27\nsemester credits. Introduction to corporate\nfinancial reporting via the preparation and\ninterpretation of financial statements.\n231 Introduction to Managerial Accounting\n3 C o u r s e P r e r e q u i s i t e : A C C T G 2 3 0 .\nIntroduction to managerial accounting;\ngeneration and use of accounting data for\nplanning and controlling business operations.\n298 I n t r o d u c t i o n t o F i n a n c i a l a n d\nManagerial Accounting - Honors 4\nCourse Prerequisite: Must be an Honors\nstudent. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for ACCTG 230 and/or ACCTG\n231. Introduction to the preparation and\ninterpretation of financial statements and to\nthe use of accounting data for planning and\ncontrolling business operations. Credit not\ngranted for both ACCTG 298 and 230 and/or\n231.\n330 Intermediate Accounting I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ACCTG 230 and 231, or\nACCTG 298; admitted to a major or minor\nin the College of Business or Data Analytics.\nConceptual and technical issues of financial\nreporting and ethical, political, and economic\nconsequences related to accounting choice.\n331 Intermediate Accounting II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ACCTG 330 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. Continuation of ACCTG 330.\n335 Taxation of Business Entities and\nIndividuals 3 Course Prerequisite: ACCTG\n230 and 231, or ACCTG 298; admitted to a\nmajor or minor in the College of Business.\nFundamentals of tax information used in\nmaking sound business and financial decisions.\n338 Cost Accounting 3 Course Prerequisite:\nACCTG 231 or 298 with a C or better; admitted\nto a major or minor in the College of Business.\nManagement uses of cost information; cost\nsystems and system design; cost analysis.\n420 Accounting and Culture 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ACCTG 230; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business; junior\nstanding. Cultural differences and how they\naffect accounting practices and standards\nin a variety of countries. Not an accounting\ntechnical course.\n430 Advanced Accounting 3 Course Prerequisite:\nACCTG 331 with a C or better; admitted to\na major or minor in the College of Business.\nPartnership equities and extended forms of\ncorporate ownerships and government entities.\n433 [M] Accounting Systems and Auditing\n3 Course Prerequisite: ACCTG 330 with a C\nor better; admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business or Data Analytics.\nAccounting systems design; internal control\nand computerization.\n435 Individual Income Taxes 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ACCTG 335 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. The study of individual income\ntaxes from both compliance and planning\nperspectives. Credit not granted to those taking\nACCTG 335 prior to Fall 1999.\n437 Professional Research 3 Course Prerequisite:\nACCTG 331 with a C or better; ACCTG 335\nwith a C or better; admitted to a major or\nminor in College of Business. Methodology\nused by accounting professionals to research\napplied problems and communicate results.\n438 [M] Advanced Cost Accounting and\nManagement 3 Course Prerequisite: ACCTG\n338 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business. Cost/\nmanagerial accounting as it is used for decision\nmaking and strategic planning; emphasis on\nbudgeting, product cost, and performance\nmeasurement.\n439 [M] Auditing 3 Course Prerequisite: ACCTG\n433 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business. Nature\nof auditing, generally accepted auditing\nstandards, and audit procedures as related\nto auditing of financial statements by\nindependent accountants.\n443 Business Processes and Controls 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ACCTG 433 with a C or\nbetter; admitted to a major or minor in the\nCollege of Business. Introduction to business\nprocesses and internal controls, including risk\nassessment and detection of fraud.\n496 Special Topics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By department permission.\nContemporary topics in accounting including\ninternational financial reporting standards,\nforensic accounting, and international\naccounting.\n498 Accounting Internship V 2-15 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 15\nhours. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Cooperative educational\ninternship with a business, government or\nnon-profit organization. S, F grading.\n\n93\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n530 Accounting Theory 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the Master of Accounting\nprogram. Recent developments with respect to\nthe determination of income and the valuation\nof assets.\n532 Contemporary Accounting Cases and\nProblems 3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to\nthe Master of Accounting program. Accounting\ntheory applied to external financial reporting\npractices.\n533 Accounting, Performance Measurement\nand Controls 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program and\ncompletion of MBA Prerequisites, including:\nB_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG 550\nand ECONS 555. Managerial evaluation of\nbudgeting, cost accounting, and financial\nanalysis techniques; their utilization in control\nof operations.\n535 Advanced Taxation 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the Master of Accounting\nprogram. Federal income tax impact on\ncorporations, S corporations, partnerships,\nestates, trusts and their beneficial owners.\n537 Professional Research 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the Master of Accounting\nprogram. Methodology used by accounting\nprofessionals to research applied problems\nin taxation, accounting, and auditing;\ncommunicate results.\n538 Seminar in Cost/Managerial Accounting\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to the Master\nof Accounting program. Cost concepts, cost\nand managerial accounting systems; current\nissues and research in cost and managerial\naccounting.\n539 Seminar in Public Accounting and\nAuditing 3 Course Prerequisite: Admission\nto the Master of Accounting program. Public\naccounting and auditing to present; current\nissues including statistical sampling and\ncomputers.\n540 Corporate Taxation 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the Master of Accounting\nprogram. Application of federal tax provisions\nand rules pertaining to corporations and\nshareholders; tax planning and consequences\nof corporate decisions.\n541 F l o w T h r o u g h E n t i t i e s 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Admission to the Master of\nAccounting program. Tax law and preparation\nrequirements for entities in which tax elements\npasses thorough to the owner’s individual\nincome tax return.\n542 Gifts, Estates and Trusts 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the Master of\nAccounting program. Estate and gift tax law.\n543 Special Topics in Accounting 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Course Prerequisite: Admission to the\nMaster of Accounting program. Critical topics\nin accounting including new developments.\n544 Advanced Accounting Systems and\nAuditing 3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to\nthe Master of Accounting program. Advanced\ntopics in accounting systems, auditing and\ncontrols.\n545 I n t e r n a t i o n a l Ta x a t i o n 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the Master\nof Accounting program. Tax issues for\ninternational transactions of businesses and\nindividuals.\n546 Accounting for Income Taxes 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the Master of\nAccounting program. Comprehensive coverage\nof accounting income taxes.\n550 I n t r o d u c t i o n t o F i n a n c i a l a n d\nManagerial Accounting V 2-3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program.\nFundamentals of financial and managerial\naccounting; primarily for graduate students\nwho wish to meet the MBA core requirements\nin accounting.\n596 Doctoral Topics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 15 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to PhD programs in\nbusiness. Advanced topics in accounting.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study\nV 1-18 May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA, Master\nof Accounting, or Business PhD programs.\nIndependent study, special projects, and/\nor internships. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor before enrolling in 600\ncredit, which cannot be used toward the core\ngraded credits required for a graduate degree.\nS, F grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the Master of Accounting\nprogram. Independent research in special\nproblems, directed study, and/or examination\ncredit for students in a non-thesis master’s\ndegree program. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 702 credit. Independent research and\nadvanced study for students working on their\ndoctoral research, dissertation and/or final\nexamination. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nBUSINESS LAW\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nB LAW\n210 Law and the Legal Environment of\nBusiness 3 Fundamentals of business law;\nthe legal system, legal reasoning, public,\ncommercial, managerial and property law, and\ngovernment regulation.\n411 Legal Environment of Business II 3\nCourse Prerequisite: B LAW 210; admitted to\na major or minor in the College of Business;\njunior standing. S, F grading.\n510 Business Law and Ethics 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA or Business\nPhD programs. Legal process and reasoning;\ncommercial, managerial, and employment\nlaw; government regulations; contracts, torts,\ncrimes; ethical conflicts and ethical decision\nmaking.\n511 Business Law II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the Master of Accounting\nprogram. Law of partnerships, corporations,\nsecurities regulations, negotiable instruments,\nsecured transactions, property, insurance\nand bankruptcy; government regulation of\nbusinesses and professions.\nDepartment of Finance and\nManagement Science\nbusiness.wsu.edu/finance/\nTodd Hall Add 470\n509-335-8727\nDepartment Chair, Omer L. requirements.\nFINANCE\n(120 HOURS)\nPreparation for careers in financial management,\ninvestment analysis, financial institutions\nmanagement, financial services, real estate, or risk\nmanagement and insurance.\nGraduation Requirements\nTo graduate with a Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration with a major in Finance, students\nare required to complete all admission and\ngraduation requirements listed in the Carson\nCollege of Business (CCB) section of this catalog\nand the coursework included in the sample 4-year\nplan listed below.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nB A 100
