\n5\nComplete Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 4\n_______\n1 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n2 \nFor Students in the Honors Program: ECONS\n198 is an approved substitute for ECONS 101 and\n102; COM 102/H D 205/MKTG 279 requirement is\nwaived; HONORS 198 is an approved substitute for\nHBM 101; ENGLISH 198 is an approved substitute\nfor ENGLISH 101; ACCTG 298 is an approved\nsubstitute for ACCTG 230 and 231. Honors students\nmay need to enroll in elective coursework to meet\nUniversity requirement of 120 credits.\n3 \nMATH 201 will be waived with an ALEKS score\nof 80% or higher, or the completion of MATH 202\nor equivalent. MATH 106 will be accepted as an\nalternative to MATH 201 for transfer students.\n4 \nAlternative to MATH 202 is MATH 140 or 171.\n5 \nMATH/STAT 212 will be accepted as alternative to\nMGTOP 215 for transfer students.\n6 \nAll students must complete the International\nExperience Requirement. Options for completing\nthe requirement can be found in the Carson\nCollege of Business Academic Unit section of the\ncatalog under Business or Business Administration\n(Vancouver). Students should consult with their\nadvisor to determine the best option.\n7 \nSocial Science or Humanities Electives (6 credits):\nAny courses with the [SSCI] or [HUM] designation,\nor courses in ANTH, ASIA, CES, CRM J, DTC, ECONS,\nENGLISH (excluding ENGLISH 402 or 403), FINE\nART, FOR LANG, HISTORY, HONORS 270, 280, 370,\n380, H D, HUMANITY, PHIL, POL S, PSYCH, SOC,\nand WOMEN ST not used to fulfill other (including\nUCORE) requirements.\n8 \n300-400-level Business Elective (3 credits): ECONS\n301 or 305, or any 300-400-level course taught by\nCCB, which cannot be from the CCB core, the set\nof required Finance courses, or any 498 Internships\nor 499 Special Topics courses.\n9 \n300-400-level Finance Electives (6 credits): Any\n300-400-level FIN course. May not include courses\nfrom the CCB Core, the set of required Finance\ncourses, or any 498 Internships or 499 Special Topics\ncourses.\n10 \nSocial Science or Humanities Electives (6 credits)\nAny courses in ANTH, CRM J, DTC, ECONS,\nENGLISH (excluding ENGLISH 402 or 403), FINE\nART, FOR LANG, HISTORY, HONORS 270, 280,\n370, 380, H D, POL S, PSYCH, SOC, and WOMEN\nST not used to fulfill other (including UCORE)\nrequirements.\n11 \nElectives: 300-400-level coursework as needed to\nmeet University requirements of 120 credits and 40\nupper-division credits.\nDescription of Courses\nFINANCE\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nFIN\n223 [QUAN] Personal Finance 3 Consumer\ncredit, financial institutions, investments,\nmutual funds, insurance, social security, home\nownership, taxes, estate planning. Credit not\napplicable to business major requirements.\n325 Introduction to Financial Management\n3 Course Prerequisite: ACCTG 230 or 298;\nECONS 101 or 198; MGTOP 215, STAT 212,\nSTAT 360, or STAT 370; MATH 140, 171,\n172, 182, 202, or 220; junior standing. Time\nvalue of money, financial securities and\nmarkets, financial decision making, valuation\ntechniques, and cost of capital.\n330 Introduction to Financial Wellbeing 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ACCTG 230 or 298; ECONS\n101 or 198; FIN 325 or concurrent enrollment.\nIntroduction to financial planning including\nbudgeting, credit, investing, retirement and\nestate planning, and tax considerations.\n345 Real Estate 3 Course Prerequisite: FIN 325 or\nconcurrent enrollment; admitted to a major or\nminor in the College of Business. Relationships\nbetween location and value; patterns of urban\nland use; legal, financial, and organizational\nframework of the real estate business.\n346 Washington Real Estate Regulations 1\nWashington real estate regulations found in\nthe Revised Code of Washington (RCW) and\nthe Washington Administrative Code (WAC).\nS, F grading.\n350 Risk and Insurance 3 Course Prerequisite:\nFIN 325 or concurrent enrollment. Concepts in\nrisk management and insurance; personal risks\nand treatment methods; legal principles in\nrisk and insurance; overview of the insurance\nindustry, company operations, and insurance\nregulation.\n421 F i n a n c i a l I n s t i t u t i o n s a n d\nIntermediation 3 Course Prerequisite: FIN\n325 with a C or better; admitted to a major or\nminor in the College of Business. Characteristics\nof financial markets and institutions; analysis\nof fixed-income securities; and introduction to\nfinancial risk management.\n\n95\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n422 Financial Institutions Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better;\nFIN 421 or concurrent enrollment; admitted to\na major or minor in the College of Business.\nProblems facing financial institution managers\nand solution techniques; credit risk analysis\nand management; financial institutions\nstructure and regulation.\n425 [M] Intermediate Financial Management\n3 Course Prerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or\nbetter; admitted to a major or minor in the\nCollege of Business. Application of finance\ntheory and principles to corporate decisions\nsuch as capital budgeting, cost of capital,\nfinancing decisions, and valuation.\n426 Short-Term Financial Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business, or a major in Economic Sciences.\nShort-term financial management, working\ncapital components, cash management, short-\nterm investing and borrowing.\n427 [M] Investment Analysis 3 Course\nPrerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for FIN 437. Investment\nobjectives, modern portfolio theory, valuation,\nequilibrium, market efficiency and asset\nclasses. Credit not granted for more than one\nof FIN 427 and 437.\n428 P o r t f o l i o T h e o r y a n d F i n a n c i a l\nEngineering 3 Course Prerequisite: FIN 427\nor 437 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business. Pricing of\nforwards, futures, options, and swaps, financial\nderivatives markets, and managing portfolio\nrisk.\n429 Financial Modeling 3 Course Prerequisite:\nFIN 325 with a C or better; FIN 421, 425, 427,\nor 437, or concurrent enrollment; admitted to\na major or minor in the College of Business.\nCorporate finance, portfolio, option pricing,\nrisk management and fixed income modeling.\n430 Financial Plan Development 3 Course\nPrerequisite: FIN 325; FIN 330. Comprehensive\nfinancial plan development including data\ngathering and analysis, using financial\nplanning software, client interactions, ethics\nand practice standards.\n437 [M] Cougar Investment Fund I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for FIN 427. Students manage\na portion of the university’s endowment;\nincluding security analysis, valuation,\nequilibrium, market efficiency, and modern\nportfolio theory. Credit not granted for more\nthan one of FIN 427 and 437.\n438 Cougar Investment Fund II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: FIN 427 or 437 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. Students manage a portion of\nthe university’s endowment. Topics include\nportfolio risk management, return attribution,\nprivate equity, and hedge funds.\n445 [M] Real Estate Valuation 3 Course\nPrerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better; FIN\n345 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business. Principles\nand practices of real property valuation; factors\naffecting real property values and income;\nappraisal and location theory.\n447 Real Estate Finance and Investments 3\nCourse Prerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. Instruments and institutions of\nreal estate and financing: decision-making\ntools, mortgage financing analysis, mortgage\nsecurities and real estate portfolios.\n451 Life Insurance and Financial Planning 3\nCourse Prerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. Analysis of the personal risks of\npremature death, poor health, and retirement\nsecurity; financial planning solutions to these\nrisks, including life insurance, health insurance\nand annuities.\n452 Property and Liability Insurance 3\nCourse Prerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business. Analysis and management of\nbusiness property, liability and consequential\nloss exposures; issues in the property and\nliability insurance industry.\n456 Risk Management 3 Course Prerequisite:\nFIN 325 with a C or better. Identification and\nanalysis of loss exposures of business and\nnon-profit organizations; application of risk\ntreatment measures including loss control and\nrisk financing alternatives.\n481 [M] International Finance 3 Course\nPrerequisite: FIN 325 with a C or better; I BUS\n380 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business. Financial\nmanagement of multinational businesses;\ninternational financial market rates and capital\nflows. International economic institutions,\nsources of capital, and investments.\n496 Special Topics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor\nin the College of Business; junior standing.\nTopics may include finance, real estate or risk\nmanagement/insurance.\n498 Finance Internship V 2-15 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 15\nhours. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Cooperative educational\ninternship with a business, government or\nnon-profit organization. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n500 Macroeconomic Theory I 3 Introduction\nto dynamics, growth and investment,\noverlapping generations models, Ramsey\nmodel, consumption and investment.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ECONS 500,\nFIN 500). Required preparation must include\nintermediate macroeconomics and one year of\ncalculus. Required preparation must include\nintermediate macroeconomics and one year\nof calculus.\n501 Microeconomic Theory I 3 Microeconomic\ntheory, multivariate optimization, consumer\nand producer theory, competitive partial\nequilibrium, introduction to imperfect\ncompetition. (Crosslisted course offered as\nECONS 501, FIN 501). Required preparation\nmust include intermediate microeconomics\nand one year of calculus. Required preparation\nmust include intermediate microeconomics\nand one year of calculus.\n502 Macroeconomic Theory II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 500. Macroeconomic\ntheory, short-run fluctuations and nominal\nrigidities, monetary economics and inflation,\nreal business cycle models, unemployment\ninternational macroeconomics. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as ECONS 502, FIN 502).\n503 Microeconomic Theory II 3 General\nequilibrium, welfare economics and social\nchoice, market failure, game theory, economics\nof information. (Crosslisted course offered as\nECONS 503, FIN 503).\n510 Statistics for Economists 3 Statistical\ntheory underlying econometric techniques\nutilized in quantitative analysis of problems\nin economics and finance. (Crosslisted course\noffered as ECONS 510, FIN 510). Required\npreparation must include college calculus and\nmatrix algebra. Required preparation must\ninclude college calculus and matrix algebra.\n511 Econometrics I 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS\n510. Single equation linear and nonlinear\nmodels; estimation, inference, finite and\nasymptotic properties, effects and mitigation of\nviolations of classical assumptions. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as ECONS 511, FIN 511).\n512 Econometrics II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nECONS 501; ECONS 511. Econometric\nmethods for systems estimation; simultaneous\nequations, discrete and limited dependent\nvariable, panel data, and time series data.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ECONS 512, FIN\n512).\n521 Interest Rates and Financial Markets 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admission to the MBA\nprogram and completion of MBA Prerequisites,\nincluding: B_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG\n550 and ECONS 555. Real and nominal interest\nrates; bond pricing; term and risk structure of\ninterest rates; investment and commercial\nbanking; financial futures.\n525 Advanced Financial Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admission to the MBA\nprogram. Theory of financial management;\nquantitative analysis of financial problems\nof the firm; empirical studies on financing\nmodern corporations.\n\n96\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n526 F i n a n c i a l M a n a g e m e n t 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program\nand completion of MBA Prerequisites,\nincluding: B_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG\n550 and ECONS 555. Advanced topics in\ncorporate finance, including capital budgeting,\ncost of capital, capital structure, pay-out policy,\nand enterprise valuation.\n527 Investment Analysis 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program and\ncompletion of MBA Prerequisites, including:\nB_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG 550 and\nECONS 555. A decision-making approach to\nthe problems of asset management for personal\nand business portfolio.\n528 P o r t f o l i o T h e o r y a n d F i n a n c i a l\nEngineering 3 Course Prerequisite: FIN 527;\nadmission to the MBA program. The theory of\nportfolio management and the use of derivative\nsecurities in portfolio risk management.\n581 I n t e r n a t i o n a l F i n a n c e 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program\nand completion of MBA Prerequisites,\nincluding: B_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504,\nACCTG 550 and ECONS 555. Principles of\ninternational finance; financial management\nof multinational corporations; international\ninvestments.\n594 Theory of Industrial Organization 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ECONS 502; ECONS\n503; ECONS 511. Theory of market structure\nand firm behavior, including price and\nnon-price competition, information and\nstrategic behavior, and technological change.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ECONS 594, FIN\n594).\n595 Advanced Topics in Resource and\nProduction Economics V 1-6 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 12\nhours. Topics may include resource scarcity,\ndecision making under risk, bioeconomics,\nproduction applications, welfare analysis.\n596 Advanced Topics in Financial Economics\n3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 12 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to PhD programs in business, or\nECONS 500 and ECONS 501. Topics may\ninclude financial theory and empirical\nmethods as applied to financial management,\ninvestments, international finance, and\nmarkets/institutions. (Crosslisted course\noffered as FIN 596, ECONS 596).\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study\nV 1-18 May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA, Master\nof Accounting, or Business PhD programs.\nIndependent study, special projects, and/\nor internships. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor before enrolling in 600\ncredit, which cannot be used toward the core\ngraded credits required for a graduate degree.\nS, F grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Students\nmust have graduate degree-seeking status\nand should check with their major advisor/\ncommittee chair before enrolling for 702\ncredit. Independent research and\nadvanced study for students working on their\ndoctoral research, dissertation and/or final\nexamination. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nMANAGEMENT AND OPERATIONS\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nMGTOP\n215 B u s i n e s s S t a t i s t i c s 4 (3-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 201, 202, 106, 140, 171,\n172, 220, or ALEKS score of 80%; B A 204 or 212,\nor concurrent enrollment. Data presentation,\nprobability, distributions, inferences, and\nlinear regression as applied to business and\neconomics.\n340 Operations Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MGTOP 215, STAT 212, STAT\n360, or STAT 370; MATH 202, 140, 171, 172,\n182, or 220; B A 204, 205, and 206, or B A 212;\njunior standing. Management of operations,\nemphasizing production planning, inventory\ncontrol, scheduling, forecasting, quality\nmanagement, supply chain management, and\nfacility layout and location.\n412 [ M ] D a t a A n a l y s i s a n d B u s i n e s s\nForecasting 3 Course Prerequisite: MGTOP\n215, STAT 212, STAT 360, or STAT 370; junior\nstanding. Regression models, inference,\nresidual analysis, time series modeling and\nforecasting as applied to business.\n418 Quality Improvement for Management\n3 Course Prerequisite: MGTOP 215, STAT 212,\nSTAT 360, or STAT 370; junior standing. Total\nquality management as used in industries;\nphilosophy of Deming and others, control\ncharts, process capability analysis, team tools.\n452 Supply Chain Management in the\nDigital Age 3 Course Prerequisite: MGTOP\n340. Managing and modeling commercial\nsupply chains, emphasizing electronic\ncommerce, purchasing, supplier selection,\nlogistics, global distribution networks, and\nsupply chain coordination.\n470 Business Modeling with Spreadsheets 3\nCourse Prerequisite: B A 204 or 212; MATH 202,\n140, 171, 172, 182, or 220; junior standing.\nUse of advanced spreadsheet tools and Visual\nBasic programming to build and analyze\nmathematical models of business problems.\n496 Seminar 3 May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: By department permission.\n498 Internship V 2-15 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 15 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By department permission.\nCooperative educational internship with\na business, government or non-profit\norganization. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n516 Time Series 3 ARIMA models; identification,\nestimation, diagnostics, and forecasting;\nseasonal adjustments, outlier detection,\nintervention analysis and transfer function\nmodeling. (Crosslisted course offered as\nMGTOP 516, STAT 516). Recommended\npreparation: STAT 443. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n519 Applied Multivariate A n a l y s i s 3\nMultivariate normal distribution, principal\ncomponents, factor analysis, discriminant\nfunction, cluster analysis, Hotteling’s T2\nand MANOVA. (Crosslisted course offered\nas MGTOP 519, STAT 519). Recommended\npreparation: STAT 443.\n540 Deterministic Business Models 3 Decision\nanalysis, linear optimization models, nonlinear\nmodels, network analysis including PERT, and\ndynamic programming as applied to business.\n556 Advanced Business Modeling 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program.\nSpreadsheet modeling and solution of business\nproblems using mathematical programming;\nMonte Carlo simulation, queuing theory, and\ndecision analysis.\n581 Operations Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program.\nAnalytical approach to solving problems in\nproduction and operations management.\n591 Statistical Analysis for Business\nDecisions 3 Course Prerequisite: Admission\nto the MBA program. Analytical skills\nfor decision-making; data collection and\nanalysis, sampling, inferential, regression\nmethodologies, experimental design, time\nseries, forecasting analysis.\n596 Doctoral Topics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 34 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to PhD programs in\nbusiness. Advanced topics in management and\noperations.\n597 Doctoral Topics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to PhD programs in\nbusiness. Advanced topics in management and\noperations.\n\n97\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n598 Research and Professional Development\n1 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to PhD programs in business. Ph.D.-\nlevel professional development colloquium\ndesigned to improve research, teaching, and\npresentation skills and to provide professional\nsocialization. S, F grading.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study\nV 1-18 May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA, Master\nof Accounting, or Business PhD programs.\nIndependent study, special projects, and/\nor internships. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor before enrolling in 600\ncredit, which cannot be used toward the core\ngraded credits required for a graduate degree.\nS, F grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program. Independent\nresearch in special problems, directed study,\nand/or examination credit for students in a\nnon-thesis master’s degree program. Students\nmust have graduate degree-seeking status\nand should check with their major advisor/\ncommittee chair before enrolling for 702\ncredit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe Business Administration - Operations\nand Management Science PhD program.\nIndependent research and advanced study for\nstudents working on their doctoral research,\ndissertation and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n800 credit. S, U grading.\nSchool of Hospitality\nBusiness Management\nbusiness.wsu.edu/Hospitality/\nTodd Hall 342\n509-335-5766\nDirector and Ivar B. Haglund Chair, and Professor,\nR. Harrington; Taco Bell Distinguished Professor, D.\nGursoy; Craig Schafer Fellow and Professor, H. J. Kim;\nProfessors, M. Chen, C. Chi; Founding Director for the\nGranger Cobb Institute for Senior Living and Associate\nProfessor, N. Swanger; Assistant Professors, B. Chen,\nR. Hammond, K. Philander, S. Seo; Associate Clinical\nProfessor, J. Harbour; Assistant Clinical Professors, M.\nBeattie, B. Marlowe, J. Sandstrom; Culver Hospitality\nRelations Manager, A. Alonzo; Executive Chef and\nCatering Services Manager, J. Callison; Professor\nEmeritus, W. Terry Umbreit.\nAn integral part of the Carson College of\nBusiness, the School of Hospitality Business\nManagement provides specialized instruction\ndealing with the major organizational, managerial,\nfinancial, and technical issues relative to operation\nof hospitality businesses. The school prepares\ngraduates for managerial responsibilities both\nhere and abroad. The curriculum provides a\nsound business education on the fundamental\nfeatures in various segments within the industry.\nIt includes courses in general education, business,\nand hospitality management. The program of\nstudy leads to a degree of Bachelor of Arts in\nHospitality Business Management, with majors\nin hospitality business management, senior living\nmanagement, or wine and beverage business\nmanagement.\nThe School of Hospitality Business\nManagement will produce graduates who:\n• Complete their 1000-hour industry requirement,\nearning employer evaluation scores of 80% or\nhigher.\n• Apply qualitative and quantitative hospitality\nbusiness skills to solve problems.\n• Identify service gaps and propose solutions\nfor service recovery, while considering multiple\nstakeholders.\n• As members of a team, through a group project,\nevaluate a hotel’s position and present acceptable\nfindings and/or solutions considering the\nimplications for multiple stakeholders.\n• Gain deeper understanding of different cultures\nand business operations from these cultures,\npreferably through studying abroad.\nGranger Cobb Institute for Senior Living\nSenior Living is a growing, dynamic industry\nwhere residents age 55+ make their homes in\nindependent, assisted living, or memory care\ncommunities. This model promotes active, social\ninteraction among residents and their families,\nwhile providing a safe and caring environment.\nManagers and professional staff make a positive\ndifference for residents and enhance the quality of\ntheir lives on a daily basis. This degree will prepare\nyou for managerial and leadership positions in\nan industry that is nearly recession-proof. It will\nposition you in a growing industry, provide you\nwith sound business fundamentals with a focus on\nhospitality operations, and provide you with a very\nrewarding work-life balance.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nHOSPITALITY BUSINESS MANAGEMENT\n(120 HOURS)\nHBM Requirements\nIn addition to the admission and graduation\nrequirements listed in the Carson College of\nBusiness (CCB) section of this catalog, all students\nmajoring in Hospitality Business Management\nmust complete 1,000 hours of work experience in\nthe hospitality industry. In order for hours to count\nfor the requirement, they must meet the following\ncriteria:\n• Hours must be worked after high-school\ngraduation.\n• All hours must be documented as paid.\n• Hours must be worked at a company whose\nprimary source of revenue is derived from\nhospitality services.\n• The employer evaluation for the hours must\nreflect an average of 80% across the ratings criteria\non the form.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nB A 100 3\nCOM 102 [COMM], H D 205 [COMM], or\nMKTG 279 [COMM]\n1 \n3 or 4\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI]\n1 \n3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] or 105 [WRTG]\n1 To be\nadmitted into the Event Management minor,\nstudents must meet the following minimum\nrequirements:\n• Complete 27 credits\n• WSU cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and not on\nacademic probation\nThe minor in event management requires a\nminimum of 19 credits of coursework, including:\n• HBM 301\n• HBM 383\n• HBM 384\n• HBM 401\n• 9 credits from the following: HBM 235, 358, 381,\n480, 494, 498, IBUS 435.\n• Students must maintain an overall GPA of at least\n2.50 in courses required for the HBM major.\n• A minimum of 9 credits of upper-division\ncoursework must be taken in residence at WSU\nor though WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses.\n• Up to 6 credits may be transferred from another\ninstitution.\nTo be admitted into this minor, students must\nmeet with a business advisor and declare their\ninterest. Students must ensure that they meet all\ncourse prerequisites before enrolling in any College\nof Business courses.\nIn addition, students must complete 400 hours of\ninternship/industry experience to earn the minor.\nIn order for hours to count for the requirement, they\nmust meet the following criteria:\n• Hours must be worked after high-school\ngraduation;\n• All hours must be documented as paid;\n• Hours must be worked at a company whose\nprimary source of revenue is derived from hospitality\nservices; and\n• The employer evaluation for the hours must\nreflect an average of 80% across the ratings criteria\non the form.\nHospitality Business Management\nPlease see the Carson College of Business section\nof this Catalog for additional instructions. To be\nadmitted into the Hospitality Business Management\n(HBM) minor, students must meet the following\nminimum requirements:\n• Complete 27 credits\n• WSU cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and not on\nacademic probation\nThe minor in hospitality business management\nrequires a minimum of 19 credits of coursework,\nincluding:\n• ACCTG 230\n• HBM 101 or 401\n• 9 c r e d i t s o f u p p e r - d i v i s i o n H B M\ncourses (excluding 498 and 499 courses)\n• 6 credits of College of Business courses at any\nlevel\n• Students must maintain an overall GPA of at least\n2.50 in courses required for the HBM major.\n• A m i n i m u m o f 9 c r e d i t s o f u p p e r -\ndivision coursework must be taken in residence at\nWSU or though WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses.\n• Up to 6 credits may be transferred from another\ninstitution.\nTo be admitted into this minor, students must\nmeet with a business advisor and declare their\ninterest. Students must ensure that they meet all\ncourse prerequisites before enrolling in any College\nof Business courses.\nIn addition, students must complete 400 hours of\ninternship/industry experience to earn the minor.\nIn order for hours to count for the requirement, they\nmust meet the following criteria:\n• Hours must be worked after high-school\ngraduation;\n• All hours must be documented as paid;\n• Hours must be worked at a company whose\nprimary source of revenue is derived from hospitality\nservices; and\n• The employer evaluation for the hours must\nreflect an average of 80% across the ratings criteria\non the form.\nSenior Living Management\nPlease see the Carson College of Business section\nof this Catalog for additional instructions. To be\nadmitted into the Senior Living Management (SLM)\n\n100\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\nminor, students must meet the following minimum\nrequirements:\n• Complete 27 credits\n• WSU cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and not on\nacademic probation\nThe minor in senior living management requires\na minimum of 19 credits of coursework including:\n• ACCTG 230\n• HBM 101 or 401\n• HBM 375\n• H D 308, 350, 360, or 405, or PSYCH 363\n• HBM 494\n• HBM 470\n• Any CCB course – 3 credits (HBM 280 or MKTG\n360 or MGMT 450 are recommended)\n• Students must maintain an overall GPA of at least\n2.50 in SLM minor courses.\n• A minimum of 9 credits of upper-division\ncoursework must be taken in residence at WSU\nor though WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses.\n• Up to 6 credits may be transferred from another\ninstitution.\nTo be admitted into this minor, students must\nmeet with a business advisor and declare their\ninterest. Students must ensure that they meet all\ncourse prerequisites before enrolling in any College\nof Business courses.\nIn addition, students must complete 400 hours of\ninternship/industry experience to earn the minor.\nIn order for hours to count for the requirement, they\nmust meet the following criteria:\n• Hours must be worked after high-school\ngraduation;\n• All hours must be documented as paid;\n• Hours must be worked at a company whose\nprimary source of revenue is derived from hospitality\nservices; and\n• The employer evaluation for the hours must\nreflect an average of 80% across the ratings criteria\non the form.\nWine and Beverage Business\nManagement\nPlease see the Carson College of Business section\nof this Catalog for additional instructions. To be\nadmitted into the Wine and Beverage Business\nManagement (WBBM) minor, students must meet\nthe following minimum requirements:\n• Complete 27 credits\n• WSU cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and not on\nacademic probation\nThe minor in wine and business management\nrequires a minimum of 19 credits of coursework\nincluding:\n• ACCTG 230\n• B A 212; or B A 204, 205, and 206\n• HBM 231, 350, 358, and 490\n• MKTG 360\n• Students must maintain an overall GPA of at least\n2.50 in WBBM minor courses.\n• A minimum of 9 credits of upper-division\ncoursework must be taken in residence at WSU\nor though WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses.\n• Up to 6 hours may be transferred from another\ninstitution.\nTo be admitted into this minor, students must\nmeet with a business advisor and declare their\ninterest. Students must ensure that they meet all\ncourse prerequisites before enrolling in any College\nof Business courses.\nIn addition, students must complete 400 hours of\ninternship/industry experience to earn the minor.\nIn order for hours to count for the requirement, they\nmust meet the following criteria:\n• Hours must be worked after high-school\ngraduation;\n• All hours must be documented as paid;\n• Hours must be worked at a company whose\nprimary source of revenue is derived from hospitality\nservices; and\n• The employer evaluation for the hours must\nreflect an average of 80% across the ratings criteria\non the form.\nDescription of Courses\nHOSPITALITY BUSINESS MANAGEMENT\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nHBM\n101 Professional and Career Development\nfor the Business World 1 Preparation for\nemployment in today’s business environment;\nfocus on career/professional development\n(resume and cover letter development,\ninterview skills, career services, professional\nexpectations, networking, and etiquette).\n131 Introduction to Hospitality Business\nManagement 3 Historical development and\norganizational structure of the hospitality\nservice industries. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n158 Basic Restaurant Operations and Service\n3 General restaurant operating concepts,\ndining room service procedures and food\nsafety; sanitation principles.\n231 Introduction to Beverage Management\n1 Overview of the beverage industry including\nhistory, trends, opportunities, logistics, legal/\nregulatory for non-alcoholic beverages and\nalcoholic beverages.\n235 [SSCI] Travel, Society, and Business 3\nSocial, cultural, economic, and environmental\npractices and principles in global travel and\ntourism. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n258 Fundamentals of Cooking 3 (1-6) Practical\napplications of cooking techniques, dining\nroom service, and restaurant operations\nincluding safety, sanitation, flow of goods and\nindustry trends.\n275 Special Topics V 1-15 May be repeated for\ncredit. S, F grading.\n280 Hospitality Systems 3 Management\nfunctions relating to the planning and\noperation of various lodging, food, and\nbeverage businesses.\n298 Internship Experience V 1 (0-3) to 12 (0-\n36) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 12 hours. Cooperative educational\ninternship with a hospitality business,\ngovernment, or non-profit organization. S, F\ngrading.\n301 Introduction to Event Planning 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major in the College\nof Business or minor in Hospitality Business\nManagement; junior standing. Overview\nof event planning industry, including\ncomponents, interrelationships, economics,\nand theory.\n350 B e v e r a g e M a n a g e m e n t 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Must be at least 21 years old.\nBeverage operations; detailed study of wines\nand spirits; consideration of social impacts\nsuch as trends in consumption.\n358 Foodservice Systems and Control 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ACCTG 230 or 298; B A 204, 205,\nand 206 or concurrent enrollment, or B A\n212 or concurrent enrollment; admitted to a\nmajor in the College of Business or minor in\nHospitality Business Management. Ahn;\nInternational Business Fellows, M. Beattie, J. Callison,\nM. Cicek, J. M. Cote, M. Featherman, S. Fotopoulos,\nJ. Gramlich, D. Gursoy, J. Harbour, R. Harrington, J.\nKim, T. Kokta, B. Marlowe, M. Mayes, D. Muehling,\nD. Paul, N. Pearson, M. Reyes, J. Rose, J. Sandstrom,\nB. Wong-on-Wing.\nThe International Business Institute (IBI) was\nestablished to coordinate international activities\nin the Carson College of Business. The IBI draws\nfaculty, staff, and students together to achieve\nexcellence in the internationalization of business\neducation, research, and service. It administers\nthe international experience requirement for the\nCarson College of Business and advises all business\nmajors on international experiences and global\nengagements. The IBI aims at encouraging the\nbusiness faculty, staff, and students to be involved\nin interesting and exciting activities in the global\nbusiness.\nDepartment of\nManagement,\nInformation Systems, and\nEntrepreneurship\nbusiness.wsu.edu/academics/MISE/\nTodd 442\n509-335-5319\nDepartment Chair and Associate Professor, R. Crossler;\nSenior Associate Dean and Professor, D. Compeau; Senior\nAssociate Dean and Professor, T. Morgan.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nENTREPRENEURSHIP\n(120 HOURS)\nEntrepreneurship is the recognition, creation,\nevaluation, and pursuit of opportunities for\nindividual and social gains through the application\nof creativity and the securing of resources. The\nentrepreneurship major at WSU is not just for\nstudents who want to start a business. The major will\nhelp develop a broader mindset about innovation,\nrisk-taking, and action that is valuable to students\nwho work in large companies, non-profits, and new\ncommercial or social ventures.\nGraduation Requirements\nTo graduate with a Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration with a major in Entrepreneurship\nstudents are required to complete all admission\nand graduation requirements listed in the Carson\nCollege of Business (CCB) section of this catalog\nand the coursework included in the sample 4-year\nplan listed below.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nB A 100 May\nnot include courses from the CCB core, the set of\nrequired ENTRP courses, or any 498 Internships or\n499 Special Topics courses.\nMANAGEMENT\n(120 HOURS)\nThe Management major has been developed\nfor students interested in pursuing a career as a\nprofessional manager. In addition to learning vital\nmanagement skills such as planning, organizing,\nleadership, and controlling, students will gain\nmarketable skills by choosing one of two tracks.\nThe Human Resource Management (HRM) track\nprovides skills in areas such as selection, training,\nmotivating, evaluating, and compensating\nemployees. The Innovation and Change (I&C)\ntrack provides skills in areas such as managing\ninnovation in networks and teams and managing\norganizational change processes.\nGraduation Requirements\nTo graduate with a Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration with a major in Management,\nstudents are required to complete all admission\nand graduation requirements listed in the Carson\nCollege of Business (CCB) section of this catalog\nand the coursework included in the sample 4-year\nplan listed below.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nB A 100 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] May not include courses\nfrom the CCB Core, the set of required MIS courses,\nor any except 498 Internship or 499 Special Topics\ncourses not used to fulfill major requirements.\n10 \nElectives: 300-400-level coursework as needed to\nmeet University requirements of 120 credits and 40\nupper-division credits.\nMinors\nEntrepreneurship\nPlease see the Carson College of Business section\nof this Catalog for additional instructions. To be\nadmitted into the Entrepreneurship minor, students\nmust meet the following minimum requirements:\n• Complete 27 credits.\n• WSU cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and not on\nacademic probation\nThe entrepreneurship minor requires 18 credits of\ncoursework including:\n• ACCTG 230\n• ENTRP 426\n• One management course: ENTRP 489, ENGR 401,\nor an approved substitute\n• One marketing/communication course: ENTRP\n490, COMSTRAT 380, or an approved substitute\n• Two semesters of business plan courses\n(minimum 6 credits): ENTRP 485 and 486; ENTRP\n496 and 496 (Special Topics); BIO ENG 410 and 411\nor approved substitutes.\nStudents must maintain and overall GPA of 2.50\nin the entrepreneurship minor courses.\nA minimum of 9 credits of upper-division\ncoursework must be taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses.\nTo be admitted into this minor, students must\nmeet with a business advisor and declare their\ninterest. Students must ensure that they meet all\ncourse prerequisites before enrolling in any College\nof Business courses.\nHuman Resource Management\nPlease see the Carson College of Business section\nof this Catalog for additional instructions. To be\nadmitted into the Human Resource Management\n(HRM) minor, students must meet the following\nminimum requirements:\n• Complete 27 credits.\n• WSU cumulative GPA of at least 2.50 and not on\nacademic probation\nThe minor in human resource management\nrequires 19 credits of coursework, including:\n• MGTOP 215 or PSYCH 311\n• MGMT 301\n• MGMT 450\n• HD 205 or MIS 250\n• And two of the following: MGMT 455, MGMT\n456, MGMT 496\nStudents must maintain an overall GPA of at least\n2.50 in the HRM minor courses.\nA minimum of 9 credits of upper-division\ncoursework must be taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses.\nTo be admitted into this minor, students must\nmeet with a business advisor and declare their\ninterest. Students must ensure that they meet all\ncourse prerequisites before enrolling in any College\nof Business courses.\nDescription of Courses\nENTREPRENEURSHIP\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nENTRP\n426 Entrepreneurial Finance 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor\nin the College of Business. Raising capital\nfor new enterprises; venture capital, IPOs,\ndebt financing, leasing and valuing start-up\nventures.\n485 [M] New Venture Planning 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor\nin the College of Business; junior standing.\nSkills, behaviors, and knowledge necessary for\ncreating and growing new ventures; evaluating\nopportunities, developing growth strategies,\nobtaining venture financing, intellectual\nproperty, and building a management team.\n486 [M] Launching New Ventures 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ENTRP 485 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College of\nBusiness; junior standing. Focus on turning an\nidea into a serious business venture; research\nnew business opportunities and become skilled\nin developing business tools and processes to\ncarry out venture-launch strategies; compete\nin the WSU Business Plan Competition.\n489 Entrepreneurial Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business or major in Economics.\nPhilosophy and nature of entrepreneurship for\nall business organizations; analytical, financial\nand interpersonal entrepreneurial skills.\n490 [M] Entrepreneurial Marketing 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business or Professional Sales\nCertificate. Concepts, issues, and techniques of\nmarketing in entrepreneurial ventures and the\nrole of entrepreneurship in marketing efforts\nof all firms.\n492 [CAPS] Small Business Strategy and\nPlanning 3 Course Prerequisite: FIN 325; I\nBUS 380; MGTOP 340; MKTG 360; admitted\nto a major or minor in the College of Business;\nsenior standing. Application of management\ntheory and principles to small firms; applied\nconsulting experience with operating\nbusinesses.\n496 [M] Special Topics V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business. Course covers new or\ntime-sensitive topics in entrepreneurship.\n498 Entrepreneurship Internship V 2-15 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n15 hours. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Cooperative educational\ninternship with a business, government, or\nnonprofit organization. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n501 Technology Entrepreneurship 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program.\nBasic business concepts and processes applied\nto technology commercialization and venture\ncreation.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study\nV 1-18 May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program.\nIndependent study, special projects, and/\nor internships. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor before enrolling in 600\ncredit, which cannot be used toward the core\ngraded credits required for a graduate degree.\nS, F grading.\nMANAGEMENT\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nMGMT\n101 Fundamentals of Business 3 Enrollment\nnot allowed if credit for B A 100 already earned.\nIntroduction to the practice of business with\nexplanations of business environments,\nstrategy, organization, functional areas,\nterminology, processes, tasks and ethics. Credit\nnot allowed for MGMT 101 if credit already\nearned in B A 100.\n\n105\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n301 P r i n c i p l e s o f M a n a g e m e n t a n d\nOrganization 3 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. Principles of management\nand administration aimed at improving\neffectiveness of all types of organizations.\nCredit not allowed for MGMT 101 if credit\nalready earned in MGMT 301.\n315 Women in Management and Leadership\n3 Analysis of women’s historical and\ncontemporary role in American management.\n401 Leading People and Organizations 3\nCourse Prerequisite: B A 201, 202, and 203, or\nB A 211, or MGMT 301; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business or option\nof Personnel Psychology & Human Resource\nManagement; junior standing. Leadership,\nmotivation, team building, group dynamics,\ninterpersonal and group conflict, and job\ndesign.\n450 Personnel and Human Resources\nManagement 3 Course Prerequisite: B A\n201, 202, and 203, or B A 211, or MGMT\n301; MGTOP 215, PSYCH 311, STAT 212,\nSTAT 360, or STAT 370; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business, major in\nEconomic Sci, or option of Personnel Psych &\nHuman Resource Mgt. Policy and practice in\nhuman resource utilization, selecting, training,\nmotivating, evaluating, and compensating\nemployees; labor relations; EEO legislation.\n455 Recruiting and Hiring Human Capital\n3 Course Prerequisite: MGMT 450 with a\nC or better; admitted to a major or minor\nin the College of Business, or major in\nEconomic Sciences, or option of Personnel\nPsychology & Human Resource Management.\nSelection issues; methods of forecasting,\nplanning, recruitment, selection; analysis of\npsychometric properties of tests; techniques\nfor assessing reliability and validity.\n456 [ M ] E v a l u a t i n g a n d R e w a r d i n g\nEmployees 3 Course Prerequisite: MGMT\n450 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business, or major\nin Economic Sciences, or option of Personnel\nPsychology & Human Resource Management.\nTheoretical, research, and applied issues related\nto the compensation of employees.\n483 [M] Management of Innovation and\nChange 3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to a\nmajor or minor in the College of Business, major\nin Economic Sciences, or option of Personnel\nPsychology & Human Resource Management;\njunior standing. Analysis of innovation and\nchange theories in organizations; managing\ninnovation in networks and teams; technology,\nstructure, culture, and environment.\n485 [M] Negotiation Skills 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business, or major in Economic Sciences,\nor option of Personnel Psychology & Human\nResource Management, or to the Professional\nSales Certificate Program; junior standing.\nBargaining skills across a broad range of\nbusiness settings; experiential work.\n487 B u s i n e s s E t h i c s a n d C o r p o r a t e\nResponsibility 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business, major in Economic Sciences, or\noption of Personnel Psychology & Human\nResource Management; junior standing. The\nnature and sources of individual and corporate\nethical responsibilities in the business\ncontext and ways of addressing conflicting\nresponsibilities.\n491 [CAPS] Strategic Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: FIN 325; I BUS 380; MGTOP 340;\nMIS 250; MKTG 360; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business; senior\nstanding. Capstone course integrating diverse\nfunctional knowledge for strategy formulation,\nimplementation and competitive advantage\nfrom the perspective of top management.\n496 Seminar 3 May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business, or option of Personnel\nPsychology & Human Resource Management.\n498 Internship V 2-15 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 15 hours. Course Prerequisite: Admission to the\nMBA program. Special topics in management,\norganization behavior, organization theory,\nhuman resource management and strategic\nmanagement.\n590 S t r a t e g y F o r m u l a t i o n a n d\nO r g a n i z a t i o n a l D e s i g n 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program\nand completion of MBA Prerequisites,\nincluding: B_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG\n550 and ECONS 555. Fundamentals of using\ninformation systems for business intelligence\nand decision support.\n421 Business Intelligence Strategy 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MIS 250 with C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business; junior standing. The process of\nmaking strategic business decisions through\nthe use of business intelligence, including\ndefining business problems, managing of\nbusiness intelligence assets, identifying the\nnecessary data to answer identified problems,\nand interpreting business intelligence output\nto strategically inform decision making.\n426 Emerging Technologies 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 12 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: MIS 250; admitted to a\nmajor or minor in the College of Business;\nsenior standing. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Marketing\nand International Business\nwww.business.wsu.edu/marketing/\nTodd 367\n509-335-0924\nProfessor and Department Chair, J. Joireman; Professors,\nB. Howlett, D. Muehling, U. Umesh (Vancouver);\nAssociate Professors, C. Miller, A. Perkins, A. SaVinhas\n(Vancouver); Assistant Professors, B. Balducci, K.\nChase, K. Gunasti; Clinical Professors, M. Cicek, J.\nGiese (Tri-Cities), T. Kokta, R. Pimentel (Vancouver);\nProfessors Emeriti, J. Johnson, D. Stem, P. Tansuhaj.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nINTERNATIONAL BUSINESS\n(120 HOURS)\nPreparation for careers with multinational\ncorporations, governmental and intergovernmental\nagencies both domestic and international. Students\nmust complete a minimum of one semester of at\nleast 11 weeks in length and 12 transferable credits\nfrom a pre-approved partnership program.\nThe International Business major requires its\nstudents to demonstrate competency in a foreign\nlanguage. With sufficient high school preparation,\nstudents can elect to take an online examination\nupon entrance to WSU (fee based tests such as\nSTAMP or LTI). If additional preparation in a foreign\nlanguage is necessary, students will work with a CCB\nadvisor to develop an appropriate course of study.\nAssessed proficiency in a second language will be\nat the intermediate level or completion of a foreign\nlanguage course through the 204 level. This may\nbe completed at any time before graduation. Check\nwith an advisor for specifics. Education Abroad is\nstrongly recommended for language acquisition.\nThe following courses in any foreign language (or\nany course for which one of these is a prerequisite)\nwill be accepted as meeting the foreign language\ncompetency standard set by International Business\nin the Carson College of Business: 204, 261, 306,\n307, 308, 406, 407, or 408.\nThis requirement is for all students except\ninternational students whose primary language is\nnot English. A third language is strongly encouraged\nfor students who have achieved competency in two\nlanguages by the time they enter the university or\nare admitted to the major.\nIn addition to completing international business\ncourses, students will gain marketable skills by\nchoosing a concentration area or a double major\nwithin the Carson College of Business (CCB).\nStudents choosing to complete a concentration area\nmust take 3 classes (9 credits) in one of the following\nareas: Global Trade, Sustainable Development,\nEntrepreneurship, Finance, Hospitality Business\nManagement, Management Information Systems,\nManagement, or Marketing (see course options\nfor each concentration area in footnotes below).\nStudents interested in pursuing a double-major\ncan do so in the following business majors:\nAccounting, Entrepreneurship, Finance, Human\nResources Management, or Marketing. Students\npursuing double majors must complete at least\n15 additional credits (18 credits for accounting)\nfrom courses specifically required by the second\nmajor and distinct from those used to satisfy the\nInternational Business major.\nStudents majoring in International Business are\nalso encouraged to pursue areas of expertise, such\nas in Business Economics, a double major in foreign\nlanguage for the professions such as Chinese,\nFrench, German, or Spanish for the Professions, in\nPolitical Sciences, or pursue the Certificate in East\nAsian Studies for Business majors.\nGraduation Requirements\nTo graduate with a Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration with a major in International\nBusiness, students are required to complete a\nminimum of one semester of at least 11 weeks\nin length and 12 transferable credits from a pre-\napproved study abroad program; a concentration\nor double major as listed above; and all admission\nand graduation requirements listed in the Carson\nCollege of Business section of this catalog and the\ncoursework included in the sample 4-year plan\nlisted below.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nB A 100 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI]\n1 \n3\nForeign Language Requirement\n2 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 201\n3 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nB A 102 1\nECONS 101 or 102\n1 \n3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] or 105 [WRTG]\n1 \n3\nForeign Language Requirement \n2 \n4\nHBM 101\n1 \n1\nMATH 202 [QUAN]\n4 \n3\nComplete Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 1\nApply for Admission into the Major\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nACCTG 230\n1 \n3\nB A 201, 202, and 203, or B A 211 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] \n5 \n3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nPOL S 102 or 103 3\nSecond Term Hours\nACCTG 231\n1 \n3\nB A 204, 205, and 206, or B A 212 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] (with lab)\n5 \n4\nI BUS 280 3\nMIS 250 3\nComplete Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 2\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nStudy Abroad recommended this term\n6\nB LAW 210 3\nCOM 102 [COMM], H D 205 [COMM], or\nMKTG 279 [COMM]\n1 \n3 or 4\nI BUS 380 3\nMGTOP 215\n7 \n4\nSOC 101, 102, or PSYCH 105 3\nSecond Term Hours\nFIN 325 3\nI BUS 453 [M] 3\nMGTOP 340 3\nMKTG 360 3\n300-400-level International Business\nConcentration\n8 \n3\nComplete Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 402 or 403 3\nHumanities [HUM]\n9 \n3\nI BUS 480 3\n300-400-level International Business\nConcentration\n8 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nECONS 327 or I BUS 470 3\nMGMT 491 [CAPS] or ENTRP 492 [CAPS] 3\n300-400-level International Business\nConcentration [M] \n8 \n3\nElectives\n9 \n3\nComplete Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 4\n_______\n1 \nFor Students in the Honors Program: ECONS\n198 is an approved substitute for ECONS 101 and\n102; COM 102/H D 205/MKTG 279 requirement is\nwaived; HONORS 198 is an approved substitute for\nHBM 101; ENGLISH 198 is an approved substitute\nfor ENGLISH 101; ACCTG 298 is an approved\nsubstitute for ACCTG 230 and 231. Honors students\nmay need to enroll in elective coursework to meet\nUniversity requirement of 120 credits.\n2 \nForeign Language Requirement: Approved courses\ninclude ARABIC 203-204; CHINESE 203-204;\nFRENCH 203-204; GERMAN 203-204; ITALIAN\n203-204; JAPANESE 203-204; KOREAN 203-204;\nRUSSIAN 203-204; or SPANISH 203-204. Foreign\nlanguage competency can also be determined by\ntesting out at the intermediate level (tests such as\nSTAMP or LTI) or certification by a WSU faculty\nmember who is a native speaker of the target\nlanguage. May be taken as part of study abroad.\nNon-native English speakers and bilingual students\nshould check with department regarding this\nrequirement.\n\n108\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n3 \nMATH 201 will be waived with an ALEKS score\nof 80% or higher, or the completion of MATH 202\nor equivalent. MATH 106 will be accepted as an\nalternative to MATH 201 for transfer students.\n4 \nAlternative to MATH 202 is MATH 140 or 171.\n5 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n6 \nStudy Abroad Requirement: Students must\ncomplete a minimum of one semester of at least 11\nweeks in length and 12 transferable credits from a\npre-approved study abroad program.\n7 \nMATH/STAT 212 will be accepted as alternative to\nMGTOP 215 for transfer students.\n8 \n3 0 0 - 4 0 0 - l e v e l I n t e r n a t i o n a l B u s i n e s s\nConcentration or Double Major (9 credits): Students\nchoosing a concentration must complete 9 credits\nin one of the International Business concentrations:\na) Global Trade: ECONS 320, 428, 430, I BUS 415\n[M]; b) Sustainable Development: ECONS 320, 326,\n427, 428; c) Entrepreneurship: ENTRP 426, 485 [M],\n486 [M], 490 [M]; d) Finance: FIN 421, 427 [M],\n481 [M]; e) Hospitality Business Management:\nHBM 381 [M], 490 or 491, 494 [M], I BUS 435; f)\nManagement: MGMT 401 [M], 483 [M], 487; g)\nManagement Information Systems: MIS 372 [M],\n374, 420, 441; h) Marketing: I BUS 482 [M], MKTG\n407, 468. Students choosing to double major in\nanother business discipline should take required\ncourses for their second major during this semester.\n9 \nHumanities or Electives: 300-400-level coursework\nas needed to meet University requirements of 120\ncredits and 40 upper-division credits.\nMARKETING\n(120 HOURS)\nPreparation for careers in marketing management,\nsales, retail management, marketing research, brand\nmanagement, and promotion.\nGraduation Requirements\nTo graduate with a Bachelor of Arts in Business\nAdministration with a major in Marketing,\nstudents are required to complete all admission\nand graduation requirements listed in the Carson\nCollege of Business (CCB) section of this catalog\nand the coursework included in the sample 4-year\nplan listed below.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nB A 100 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI]\n1 \n3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 201\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nB A 102 1\nCOM 102 [COMM], H D 205 [COMM], or\nMKTG 279 [COMM]\n1 or\nElective \n5 \n3\nElectives\n10 \n5\nComplete Carson Career Amplifier Program\n-- Tier 4\n_______\n1 \nFor Students in the Honors Program: ECONS\n198 is an approved substitute for ECONS 101 and\n102; COM 102/H D 205/MKTG 279 requirement is\nwaived; HONORS 198 is an approved substitute for\nHBM 101; ENGLISH 198 is an approved substitute\nfor ENGLISH 101; ACCTG 298 is an approved\nsubstitute for ACCTG 230 and 231. Honors students\nmay need to enroll in elective coursework to meet\nUniversity requirement of 120 credits.\n2 \nMATH 201 will be waived with an ALEKS score\nof 80% or higher, or the completion of MATH 202\nor equivalent. MATH 106 will be accepted as an\nalternative to MATH 201 for transfer students.\n3 \nAlternative to MATH 202 is MATH 140 or 171.\n4 \nSocial Science or Humanities Electives (6 credits)\nAny courses in ANTH, CRM J, DTC, ECONS,\nENGLISH (excluding ENGLISH 402 or 403), FINE\nART, FOR LANG, HISTORY, HONORS 270, 280,\n370, 380, H D, POL S, PSYCH, SOC, and WOMEN\nST not used to fulfill other (including UCORE)\nrequirements.\n5 \nAll students must complete the International\nExperience Requirement. Options for completing\nthe requirement can be found in the Carson\nCollege of Business Academic Unit section of\nthe catalog under Business (Pullman) or Business\nAdministration (Vancouver). Students should\nconsult with their advisor to determine the best\noption.\n6 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n7 \nMATH/STAT 212 will be accepted as alternative to\nMGTOP 215 for transfer students.\n8 \n300-400-level Business Electives (6 credits): Any\n300-400-level courses taught by CCB. May not\ninclude courses from the CCB core, the set of\nrequired MKTG courses, or any 498 Internships or\n499 Special Topics courses.\n9 \n300-400-level Marketing Electives (3 credits): Any\n300-400-level MKTG course not used to fulfill major\nrequirements.\n10 \nElectives: 300-400-level coursework as needed to\nmeet University requirements of 120 credits and 40\nupper-division credits.\nDescription of Courses\nINTERNATIONAL BUSINESS\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nI BUS\n280 International Relations and Global\nLeadership 3 Introduction to the study of\nglobal business concentrating on international\nrelations and leadership.\n380 I n t e r n a t i o n a l B u s i n e s s 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: B A 201, 202, and 203, or B A 211;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business; junior standing. International\npolitical economy; business relationships\nbetween nations; corporations and economic\ninstitutions.\n399 Foreign Study V 1-15 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 15 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By department permission.\nParticipation in approved programs of study at\na foreign educational institution. S, F grading.\n415 [M] Law of International Trade 3 Course\nPrerequisite: B LAW 210; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business. Legal\norganization of the international community;\ninternational aspects of trade and development,\neconomic cooperation, and technical, social,\nand cultural cooperation.\n\n109\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n416 [M] Public International Law 3 Course\nPrerequisite: B LAW 210; admitted to a major or\nminor in the College of Business. Law governing\nstates, intergovernmental organizations, and\nnongovernmental organizations (including\nmultinational enterprises); human rights law;\nenvironmental law; and dispute settlement.\n435 I n t e r n a t i o n a l To u r i s m 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business, or option of Personnel\nPsychology & Human Resource Management.\nInternational and domestic tourism; effects of\ntourism on the society.\n453 [M] International Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: B A 201, 202, and 203, or B A 211,\nor MGMT 301; admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business or option of Personnel\nPsychology & Human Resource Management.\nCross-cultural implications of management\ntheories and approaches; the role of national\nculture in management theory and practice.\n470 International Trade and Finance 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ECONS 101 or 198;\nECONS 102 or 198. Analysis and description of\ninternational trade flows; commercial policy;\nmultinational firms, foreign exchange markets;\nopen economy macroeconomics; international\nmonetary systems. (Crosslisted course offered\nas ECONS 327, I BUS 470).\n480 Advanced International Business and\nLeadership 3 Course Prerequisite: I BUS 280;\nI BUS 380. Fundamentals of international\nbusiness, corporate strategy, and leadership in\nthe global context.\n482 [M] International Marketing 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MKTG 360; admitted to a\nmajor or minor in the College of Business.\nOpportunities, characteristics, trends in foreign\nmarkets; alternative methods; strategies;\norganizational planning, control; problems of\nadapting American marketing concepts and\nmethods.\n496 Special Topics V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By department permission.\n498 International Business Internship V\n2-15 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 15 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nBy department permission. Cooperative\neducational internship with a business,\ngovernment or non-profit organization. S, F\ngrading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: By department\npermission. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n580 International Business Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admission to the MBA\nprogram and completion of MBA Prerequisites,\nincluding: B_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG\n550 and ECONS 555. Decision making in the\ninternational environment; political, cultural,\nand economic risk management.\n582 International Marketing Management\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to the MBA\nprogram and completion of MBA Prerequisites,\nincluding: B_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504,\nACCTG 550 and ECONS 555. Principles of\ninternational marketing, marketing decision\nmaking in international environments,\nproblems of adapting marketing programs to\ninternational markets.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study\nV 1-18 May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program.\nIndependent study, special projects, and/\nor internships. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor before enrolling in 600\ncredit, which cannot be used toward the core\ngraded credits required for a graduate degree.\nS, F grading.\nMARKETING\nNo letter-graded course offered by the Carson College\nof Business may be taken for a Pass, Fail (P, F) grade.\nMKTG\n279 [ C O M M ] P r o f e s s i o n a l P e r s u a s i v e\nCommunications 3 Basic psychological\nprinciples of influence and the development of\npersuasive professional communication skills\nfor career advancement and as life skills.\n360 Marketing 3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted\nto a major or minor in the College of Business,\nor junior standing. An introduction to the\nmarketing process and the strategic managerial\ndecisions that are made with regard to product,\nprice, promotion, and distribution. Credit not\nallowed for MGMT 101 if credit already earned\nin MKTG 360.\n368 Marketing Research 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMKTG 360; admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business. Use of secondary and\nprimary data to facilitate marketing managers’\ndecision-making capabilities; applied\nmarketing research techniques including focus\ngroups, surveys, experiments and statistical\nanalyses; preparation of marketing research\nreports.\n379 Professional Sales 3 Theory, principles,\nand practices of professional sales with special\nattention to the business-to-business market.\n407 Consumer Behavior 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMKTG 360; admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business, or major in Economic\nSciences. Investigation of social processes\naffecting consumer decision-making and\nbehavior; models of consumer behavior are\ncovered, as are the psychological phenomena\nof learning, motivation, and attitude\ndevelopment, and the sociological influences\nof social class, reference groups and culture.\n450 Digital Marketing 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMKTG 360; admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business, or Professional Sales\ncertificate. Understanding and implementing\nmarketing theory and analytics on social media\nand in online environments.\n461 [M] Product Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MKTG 360; admitted to a major or\nminor in the College of Business. Management\nof existing products and product lines, and\ndesign, development, pricing and marketing\nof new products in the firm.\n467 Consumer Judgment and Decision-\nMaking 3 Course Prerequisite: MKTG 360;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Business, or major in Economic Sciences.\nExamination of how consumers search\nand process information (e.g. prices, brand\nnames, advertising), form judgments, make\ndecisions (e.g. choice, purchase, invest, sell),\nand feel about their decisions afterwards (e.g.\npost-decision regret, satisfaction); perceptual,\ncognitive and emotional biases in decision-\nmaking and their implications for marketers,\nconsumers, and policy makers.\n468 Public Policy and Marketing 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MKTG 360; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Business, or major\nin Economic Sciences. The use of marketing\nprinciples and techniques to benefit society;\nthe importance of marketing as it relates to\ngovernment regulation of marketing structure,\nconsumer protection, and consumer welfare.\n470 Retail Management 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMKTG 360; admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Business, or major in Economic\nSciences. Retailing system; organization,\nmerchandising models, pricing, promotion,\nlocation, and control procedures; management\ndecision processes.\n477 Integrated Marketing Communications\n3 Course Prerequisite: MKTG 360; admitted\nto a major or minor in the College of\nBusiness, or major in Economic Sciences. An\noverview of the managerial approaches and\ntheoretical perspectives relevant to planning,\nimplementing, and evaluating integrated\nmarketing communications strategies.\n478 [ M ] S a l e s M a n a g e m e n t 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: MKTG 360. Sales management\nstrategies and plans to achieve a firm’s\nmarketing objectives, including the hiring,\nfiring, training, motivation, compensation,\ndeployment, and evaluation of sales personnel.\n479 Advanced Professional Sales 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MKTG 379. Advanced theory\nand principles of professional sales with special\nattention to the business-to-business market\nand an emphasis on the application of theory\nand principles to selling skills.\n480 Business to Business Marketing 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MKTG 360; admitted to\na major or minor in the College of Business,\nor Professional Sales certificate. Marketing\nstrategies for creating customer and firm value\nin business-to-business markets.\n487 Research Practicum 3 Course Prerequisite:\nBy department permission. Independent\nresearch project with faculty member\nincluding problem statement, literature review,\nhypotheses, data collection, and reporting of\nresults.\n\n110\nBusiness\nWashington State University, 2021\n495 [M] Marketing Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MKTG 360; admitted to a\nmajor or minor in the College of Business;\nsenior standing. Integrative marketing\ncapstone course; the evaluation and design\nof marketing strategy; covers industry,\ncompetitor, and customer analysis with the\ngoal of recommending and implementing an\nappropriate marketing strategy. Recommended\npreparation: MKTG 368 and 407.\n496 Special Topics V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. S, F grading.\n505 Survey of Marketing 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA, Master of Accounting,\nor Business PhD programs. Marketing\nmanagement; relevance of marketing\nto company profitability and consumer\nsatisfaction; decision regarding price, product,\npromotion, and distribution.\n506 Marketing Strategy 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program and completion\nof MBA Prerequisites, including: B_A 500, 501,\n502, 503, 504, ACCTG 550 and ECONS 555.\nMarketing analyses needed to recommend\nand implement a marketing strategy. Includes\ncoverage of industry, competitor, and customer\nanalysis as well as decision factors related to\nsegmentation, positioning, and the marketing\nmix.\n507 Consumer Behavior 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program. Marketing\nstructure and behavior from economic and\nbehavioral perspectives; social evaluation and\nbehavioral implications of marketing strategy.\n555 Marketing Analytics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to the MBA program. Development\nof marketing analytics skills utilizing large data\nsets to identify marketing and consumer trends\nin online and offline markets.\n561 New Product Marketing 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program\nand completion of MBA Prerequisites,\nincluding: B_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504, ACCTG\n550 and ECONS 555. Introduction of new\nproducts that are based on new technology;\nexploration of actual products in the market.\n565 Seminar in Marketing 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: Admission to the MBA\nprogram. Marketing structure and behavior\nfrom economic and behavioral perspectives;\nsocial evaluation and behavioral implications\nof marketing strategy.\n577 Promotional Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA program\nand completion of MBA Prerequisites,\nincluding: B_A 500, 501, 502, 503, 504,\nACCTG 550 and ECONS 555. Integrated\npromotion into the marketing plan; methods,\norganization, communications, media\nselection, and campaigns.\n590 Seminar in Consumer Behavior 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to PhD programs in\nbusiness. Advanced, doctoral-level topics in\nconsumer behavior.\n591 Seminar in Marketing Management\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to PhD\nprograms in business. Advanced, doctoral-level\ntopics in marketing management.\n592 Seminar in Marketing Theory 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to PhD programs in\nbusiness. Advanced, doctoral-level topics in\nmarketing theory.\n593 Seminar in Research Design 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to PhD programs in\nbusiness. Advanced, doctoral-level topics in\nresearch design.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study\nV 1-18 May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the MBA, Master\nof Accounting, or Business PhD programs.\nIndependent study, special projects, and/\nor internships. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor before enrolling in 600\ncredit, which cannot be used toward the core\ngraded credits required for a graduate degree.\nS, F grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit.
