Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nGene and Linda Voiland\nSchool of Chemical\nEngineering and\nBioengineering\nvoiland.wsu.edu\nWegner Hall 105\n509-335-4332\nInterim Director, Associate Professor and Paul\nHohenschuh Distinguished Professor, A. Kostyukova;\nVoiland Distinguished Professors, N. Kruse, Y.\nWang; Professors, B. Ahring, H. Beyenal, S. Ha, J. N.\nPetersen, P. Pfromm, M. Rezac, K. Schulz, B. J. Van\nWie; Associate Professors, W. Dong, D. Lin, H. Lin,\nJ-S. McEwen, S. Saunders, A. Vasavada, X. Zhang;\nAssistant Professors, D. Thiessen, D. Tolkatchev, X.\nWang, D. Wu; Professors Emeriti, D. C. Davis, H.\nDavis, C. F. Ivory K. C., Liddell, R. Mahalingam, R. C.\nMiller, W. J. Thomson, R. Zollars.\nThe mission of the Gene and Linda Voiland School\nof Chemical Engineering and Bioengineering is to\ndeliver academic programs in Chemical Engineering\nand Bioengineering that advance the boundaries\nof knowledge, educate competent engineering\nprofessionals, and contribute to the needs of\nsociety. Faculty, staff, and students engage in\ndiscovery, teaching, application, and integration,\nalong with periodic review of achievement, to\ndevelop practitioners and scholars prepared to\nmake meaningful and responsible contributions\nto society.\nThe Program Educational Objectives for\nbaccalaureate degree programs in Chemical\nE n g i n e e r i n g a n d B i o e n g i n e e r i n g d e f i n e\nachievements of which these graduates are capable.\nAs appropriate for their chosen career paths, within\nfive to ten years of graduation, program graduates\nwill be able to:\n• Engage successfully in graduate or professional\neducation or entry-level employment.\n• Perform responsibly and professionally in their\nchosen career paths.\n• Exhibit continued growth of effective\ncommunication and collaboration skills.\n• Demonstrate ongoing development of competent\nand innovative problem solving skills.\n• Continue learning and accept increasing levels\nof responsibility over time.\nThese long-term educational objectives will\nbe achieved through development of our\nStudent Outcomes in a culture of integration\nand engagement. Student Outcomes lay a solid,\nwell-rounded foundation from which to build\nlonger-term capabilities. Systemic integration\nof theory and practice deepens students’\nunderstanding and builds confidence they will need\nfor bold innovation and lifelong learning. Frequent\nengagement of students with peers, faculty, and\nexternal constituencies builds their interpersonal\nskills, refines their understanding, and leads them to\nopportunities for advanced study or employment.\nDedicated faculty who effectively teach, mentor,\nrefer, and model professional behaviors prepare our\ngraduates for the professional world.\nThe school offers courses of study leading to the\ndegrees of Bachelor of Science in Bioengineering,\nBachelor of Science in Chemical Engineering,\n\n111\nChemical Engineering and Bioengineering\nWashington State University, 2021\nMaster of Science in Chemical Engineering, and\nDoctor of Philosophy, with a focus in chemical\nengineering. We also graduate students who receive\nthe Master of Science in Engineering and the Doctor\nof Philosophy in Engineering Science with an\nemphasis in bioengineering.\nChemical Engineering\nThe curriculum in chemical engineering\nprovides thorough knowledge of basic science and\nengineering. This includes material and energy\nbalances, chemical and physical equilibria, rate\nprocesses, and economic balances. With such\ntraining, graduates may participate in the design\nand operation of chemically based products or they\nmay engage in research leading to new or improved\nchemical processes, products, and uses. Graduates\nalso find rewarding work in plant operation, plant\nmanagement, university teaching, sales-service, and\nother functions requiring chemical engineering\ntraining. Many students also use their educations\nin chemical engineering as preparation for other\nprofessional degrees such as medicine or law. The\nchemical engineering program is accredited by the\nEngineering Accreditation Commission of ABET,\nwww.abet.org.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nTo guide our student activities in developing\nthe skills to meet the School’s objectives we will\nmonitor their attainment of the Student Outcomes\nas set forth by ABET. These are: 1) an ability to\nidentify, formulate, and solve complex engineering\nproblems by applying principles of engineering,\nscience, and mathematics, 2) an ability to apply\nengineering design to produce solutions that\nmeet specified needs with consideration of public\nhealth, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural,\nsocial, environmental, and economic factors, 3) an\nability to communicate effectively with a range\nof audiences, 4) an ability to recognize ethical\nand professional responsibilities in engineering\nsituations and make informed judgments, which\nmust consider the impact of engineering solutions\nin global, economic, environmental, and societal\ncontexts, 5) an ability to function effectively on a\nteam whose members together provide leadership,\ncreate a collaborative and inclusive environment,\nestablish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives,\n6) an ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions, and\n7) an ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\nIn addition to these Outcomes we will also monitor\nthe program criteria for chemical, biochemical,\nbiomolecular or similarly named engineering\nprograms, as set forth by the American Institute\nof Chemical Engineers (AIChE). These criteria are,\nrespectively: “The curriculum must provide (1) a\nthorough grounding in the basic sciences including\nchemistry, physics, and biology, with some content\nat an advanced level, as appropriate to the objectives\nof the program. The curriculum must include (2)\nthe engineering application of these basic sciences\nto the design, analysis, and control of chemical,\nphysical, and/or biological processes, including the\nhazards associated with these processes.” (Numerals\nadded to original AIChE statement).\nSee https://voiland.wsu.edu/undergraduate/che/.\nBioengineering\nBioengineering is an engineering discipline that\nintegrates engineering and life sciences to address\nissues important to human and animal well-being\nand to society at large. As such, the educational\nobjective of the BS Bioengineering degree is to\nprepare graduates for productive employment,\nadvanced study, or professional programs where\nthey apply principles and methods of both\nengineering and life sciences to solve problems\naffecting human and animal health and well-being.\nGraduates may apply their expertise in human and\nanimal medicine, biotechnology, or related biology-\nbased engineering fields.\nWith these integrated science and engineering\nskills, bioengineering graduates are able to make\nvaluable contributions to human and animal\nhealth care and environments, bio-based product\ndevelopment, and biotechnology. At Washington\nState University, bioengineering cooperates with\nand finds applications in numerous disciplines\nof engineering, veterinary medicine, and medical\nsciences. The bioengineering curriculum easily\naccommodates pre-medical, pre-dental, and pre-\nveterinary requirements for those students wishing\nto apply to professional schools in health care fields.\nThe bioengineering program is accredited by the\nEngineering Accreditation Commission of ABET,\nwww.abet.org.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nBioengineering graduates are able to demonstrate\nthe following Student Outcomes:\n• An ability to identify, formulate, and solve\ncomplex engineering problems by applying\nprinciples of engineering, science, and mathematics.\n• An ability to apply engineering design to\nproduce solutions that meet specified needs with\nconsideration of public health, safety, and welfare,\nas well as global, cultural, social, environmental,\nand economic factors.\n• An ability to communicate effectively with a\nrange of audiences.\n• An ability to recognize ethical and professional\nresponsibilities in engineering situations and\nmake informed judgments, which must consider\nthe impact of engineering solutions in global,\neconomic, environmental, and societal contexts.\n• An ability to function effectively on a team\nwhose members together provide leadership, create\na collaborative and inclusive environment, establish\ngoals, plan tasks, and meet objectives.\n• An ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions.\n• An ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\nSee https://voiland.wsu.edu/undergraduate/be/.\nComputer Requirement\nAll Chemical Engineering and Bioengineering\nstudents are required to purchase laptop\ncomputers. Computer requirements are described at\nhttps://voiland.wsu.edu/undergraduate/computer-\nrequirement/.\nTransfer Students\nStudents who are planning to transfer to Chemical\nEngineering or Bioengineering at Washington\nState University from other institutions should\ncoordinate their programs with the school to\nestablish a schedule of studies leading to the\nbachelor’s degree. This is desirable because of\nsophomore professional requirements and course\nsequences. A strong preparation in chemistry,\nmathematics (through differential equations), and\nphysics is necessary prior to transfer to minimize\nthe time required at Washington State University to\ncomplete bachelor’s degree requirements. Inquiries\nconcerning specific questions are welcomed.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nAs preparation for work toward an advanced\ndegree in Chemical Engineering, a student should\nhave completed the equivalent of the following\nchemical engineering schedule of studies. A Bachelor\nof Science degree in Chemical Engineering from\nan institution with an ABET accredited program\nnormally will satisfy this requirement.\nStudents seeking advanced training in\nbioengineering should use the Engineering Science\ndegree program. Such students should have\ncompleted the equivalent of the bioengineering\nprogram outlined above. A Bachelor of Science\ndegree from any ABET accredited engineering\nprogram would normally satisfy this requirement.\nSpecial programs are also available for students\nwith bachelor’s degrees in chemistry, biology, or\nother areas of science who wish to obtain advanced\ndegrees.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBIOENGINEERING - GENERAL OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents who plan to pursue pre-med studies should\nconsult their advisor for further information about\nappropriate courses.\nAdmission to the Major Criteria –\nBioengineering Program\nIncoming first-year students, transfer students,\nand students changing from a different major may\nbe admitted to the Bioengineering degree program\nupon completion of MATH 171 with a C or better or\nconcurrent enrollment, and CHEM 105 with a C or\nbetter or concurrent enrollment. To remain in the\nmajor the student must earn a grade of C or better\nin all courses and maintain good academic standing\n(i.e. a 2.0 or higher GPA each term and an overall\ncumulative GPA of 2.0 at WSU).\nStudents who are deficient under the University’s\nAcademic Regulations 38 and 39 or whose GPA in\nBioengineering courses falls below 2.0 are subject to\nloss of eligibility of the major. The Bioengineering\nundergraduate studies committee will determine the\neligibility for readmission and probation conditions\nfor students who are deficient and apply for re-entry\ninto the major.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\n\n112\nChemical Engineering and Bioengineering\nWashington State University, 2021\nENGR 120\n1 \n2\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIO ENG 140 1\nBIOLOGY 107 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 106 or 116 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] or 305 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 172 or 182 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIO ENG 205 1\nCHE 201 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 220 or 230 2 or 3\nMATH 273 or 283 2\nPHYSICS 201 and 211, or 205 4 or 5\nSecond Term Hours\nBIO ENG 210 2\nCE 211 3\nMATH 315 3\nPHYSICS 202 and 212, or 206 4 or 5\nSTAT 370 or 423 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIO ENG 310 3\nBIO ENG 321 3\nBIO ENG 322 [M] 1\nBIO ENG 350 3\nE E 261 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIO ENG 330 3\nBIO ENG 340 4\nBioengineering Elective\n2 \n3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI], 102 [SSCI], or 198 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIO ENG 410 [M] 3\nBIO ENG 440 4\nCommunication [COMM] or Interview\n_______\n1 \n3 credit 300-400-level engineering course may be\nsubstituted for ENGR 120 by approval of advisor.\n2 \nBioengineering Electives (6 credits): Must have a\nBIO ENG subject, selected from the following: BIO\nENG 425, 435, 455, 476, or 481.\n3 \nTechnical Electives (12 credits): Approved courses\ninclude BIOLOGY 106, 251, CPT S 121, E E 214, 262,\nME 116, 212, 216, MSE 201, PHIL 365, or any 300-\n400 level BIO ENG, BIOLOGY, CE, CHE, CHEM, CPT\nS, E E, MATH, MBIOS, ME, MSE, NEUROSCIENCE,\nPHYSICS, or STAT course as approved by advisor.\nMust include sufficient 300-400-level courses to\nmeet University requirement of 40 credits upper-\ndivision coursework.\nBIOENGINEERING - PRE-MED OPTION\n(127 HOURS)\nStudents who plan to pursue pre-med studies should\nconsult their advisor for further information about\nappropriate courses.\nAdmission to the Major Criteria –\nBioengineering Program\nIncoming first-year students, transfer students, and\nstudents changing from a different major may be\nadmitted to the Bioengineering degree program\nupon completion of MATH 171 with a C or better\nor concurrent enrollment, and CHEM 105 with a C\nor better or concurrent enrollment. To remain in the\nmajor the student must earn a grade of C or better\nin all courses and maintain good academic standing\n(i.e. a 2.0 or higher GPA each term and an overall\ncumulative GPA of 2.0 at WSU).\nStudents who are deficient under the University’s\nAcademic Regulations 38 and 39 or whose GPA in\nBioengineering courses falls below 2.0 are subject to\nloss of eligibility of the major. The Bioengineering\nundergraduate studies committee will determine the\neligibility for readmission and probation conditions\nfor students who are deficient and apply for re-entry\ninto the major.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nENGR 120\n1 \n2\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIO ENG 140 1\nBIOLOGY 107 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 106 or 116 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] or 305 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 172 or 182 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIO ENG 205 1\nBIOLOGY 106 4\nCHE 201 3\nMATH 220 or 230 2 or 3\nMATH 273 or 283 2\nPHYSICS 201 and 211, or 205 4 or 5\nSecond Term Hours\nBIO ENG 210 2\nCE 211 3\nMATH 315 3\nPHYSICS 202 and 212, or 206 4 or 5\nSTAT 370 or 423 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIO ENG 310 3\nBIO ENG 321 3\nBIO ENG 322 [M] 1\nCHEM 345 4\nE E 261 3\nMBIOS 301 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIO ENG 330 3\nBIO ENG 340 4\nCHEM 348 4\nMBIOS 303 or CHEM 370 4\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIO ENG 350 3\nBIO ENG 410 [M] 3\nBIO ENG 440 4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIO ENG 411 [CAPS] 3\nBioengineering Electives\n2 \n6\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI] or 198 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nComplete BIO ENG Exit Interview\n_______\n1 \n3 credit 300-400 level engineering course may be\nsubstituted for ENGR 120 by approval of advisor.\n2 \nBioengineering Electives (6 credits): Must have a\nBIO ENG subject, selected from the following: BIO\nENG 425, 435, 455, 476, or 481.\nCHEMICAL ENGINEERING - GENERAL\n(124 HOURS)\nAt least 63 of the total hours required for this degree\nmust be in 300-400-level courses.\nAdmission to the Major Criteria –\nChemical Engineering Program\nIncoming first-year students, transfer students,\nand students changing from a different major may\nbe admitted to the Chemical Engineering degree\nprogram upon completion of MATH 171 with a\nC or better or concurrent enrollment, and CHEM\n105 with a C or better or concurrent enrollment. To\nremain in the major the student must earn a grade\nof C or better in all CHE courses, earn a grade of C\nor better in all required electives, and maintain good\nacademic standing (i.e. a 2.0 or higher GPA each\nterm and an overall cumulative GPA of 2.0 at WSU).\nStudents who are deficient under the University’s\nAcademic Regulations 38 and 39 or whose GPA in\nCHE courses falls below 2.0 are subject to loss of\neligibility of the major. The Chemical Engineering\nundergraduate studies committee will determine the\neligibility for readmission and probation conditions\nfor students who are deficient and apply for re-entry\ninto the major.\nGraduation Requirements\nNo Washington State University courses listed in\nthis schedule of study may be taken on a pass/fail\nbasis. With the exception of CHE 488, 495, 498,\n499 and ENGR 489, all listed CHE courses, required\nelectives, and the prerequisites to these courses must\nbe completed with a grade of C or better.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHE 101 1\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\n\n113\nChemical Engineering and Bioengineering\nWashington State University, 2021\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] or 305 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI], 107 [BSCI],\nor 110 [BSCI] 3 or 4\nCHE 110\n1 \n2\nCHEM 106 or 116 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 172 or 182 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHE 201 3\nCHEM 345 4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 273 or 283 2\nPHYSICS 201 and 211, or 205 4 or 5\nSecond Term Hours\nCHE 211 3\nCHEM 348 or MBIOS 303 4\nMATH 220 or 230 2 or 3\nMATH 315 3\nPHYSICS 202 and 212, or 206 4 or 5\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHE 301 3\nCHE 310 3\nCHEM 331 3\nCHEM 333 or 334 [M] 1 or 2\nTechnical Elective\n21 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nCHE 321 3\nCHE 332 3\nCHE 334 3\nCHE 498 1\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] [M] or 403 [WRTG] [M] 3\nSTAT 423 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHE 352 3\nCHE 432 [M] 3\nCHE 441 3\nCHE 450 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI] or 198 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCHE 433 [M] 2\nCHE 451 [M] [CAPS] 3\nCHE Elective\n31 \n6\nTechnical Elective\n21 \n3\nExit Interview\n_______\n1 \nThree credit 300-400-level CHE course may be\nsubstituted for CHE 110 by approval of advisor. The\nCHE course can be included as three credits of the\nCHE or Technical Electives.\n2 \nTechnical Electives (6 credits): MSE 201 or any\n300-400-level BIO ENG, CHEM, CHE, CE, E E,\nENGR, MATH, ME, MSE, PHYSICS, or STAT course\nas approved by advisor.\n3 \nCHE Electives (6 credits): Any 400-level CHE course\nnot used to fulfill major requirements. A maximum\nof 3 credits is allowed in CHE 488, 495, and 499\ncombined.\nDescription of Courses\nBIOENGINEERING\nBIO ENG\n140 Introduction to Bioengineering 1 Seminar\non current topics and issues in bioengineering;\ncareer options in bioengineering. S, F grading.\n205 B i o e n g i n e e r i n g P r o f e s s i o n a l\nPreparation and Ethics 1 Professional\npreparation for careers in bioengineering;\nethical, social, and professional issues in\nbioengineering. S, F grading.\n210 Bioengineering Analysis 2 (1-3) Course\nPrerequisite: CHE 201 with a C or better; MATH\n220 or concurrent enrollment. Analytical\nproblem solving, modeling and computer\nmethods for bioengineering applications.\n310 Introduction to Transport Processes\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 315 and CHE\n101 and CHE 211, each with a C or better or\nconcurrent enrollment; OR MATH 315 with a\nC or better or concurrent enrollment and BIO\nENG 205 with an S or concurrent enrollment;\nadmitted major in Chem Engr or Bioengr.\nFundamentals of the phenomena governing\nthe transport of momentum, energy, and mass.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CHE 310, BIO\nENG 310).\n321 Mechanics of Biological Materials 3\nCourse Prerequisite: CE 211 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Bioengineering.\nMechanical behavior of biological and\nengineering materials; relationships between\nexternal loads and internal stresses and strains\nwithin a structure.\n322 [M] Mechanics of Biological Materials\nLab 1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: BIO ENG\n321 or concurrent enrollment; and STAT 370\nor concurrent enrollment or STAT 423 or\nconcurrent enrollment; admitted to the major\nin Bioengineering. Laboratory experiments\nfocused on mechanics of biological and\nengineering materials; experimental design\nand statistical analysis of data; scientific\nwriting.\n330 Bioinstrumentation 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: E E 261 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Bioengineering.\nPrinciples of instrumentation applicable to\nbioengineering systems; experimental design\nfor measurement systems.\n340 Unified Systems Bioengineering I 4 (3-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: BIO ENG 210 or concurrent\nenrollment; E E 261 with a C or better; admitted\nto the major in Bioengineering. Foundation for\ndynamic modeling and design of physiological\nsystems; part one of two-semester course.\n350 Introduction to Cellular Bioengineering\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 315 with a C or\nbetter; admitted to the major in Bioengineering.\nIntegrating cellular biology and engineering\nscience by applying quantitative engineering\nprinciples for development of cellular-based\nmaterials, diagnostic devices and sensor\ndesigns.\n410 [M] Bioengineering Capstone Project\nI 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite: BIO ENG 321\nwith a C or better; BIO ENG 322 with a C or\nbetter; BIO ENG 330 with a C or better; BIO\nENG 340 with a C or better. Part I of capstone\nengineering design project; customer needs,\ndesign requirements, conceptual design,\nbusiness assessment, project proposal, and\npresentation.\n411 [CAPS] Bioengineering Capstone Project\nII 3 (2-2) Course Prerequisite: BIO ENG 410 with\na C or better; senior standing. Detailed design\nand business case for a biological engineering-\nrelated process, machine, structure, or system.\nRecommended preparation: ECONS 101 or\n102.\n425 Biomechanics 3 Course Prerequisite: BIO\nENG 321 with a C or better or CE 215 with a C\nor better; MATH 315 with a C or better. Methods\nfor analysis of rigid body and deformable\nmechanics; application to biological tissue,\nespecially bone, cartilage, ligaments, tendon\nand muscle. (Crosslisted course offered as BIO\nENG 425/525, ME 525). Credit not granted for\nmore than one of BIO ENG 425, BIO ENG 525,\nor ME 525.\n435 Bioelectric Phenomena and Devices\n3 Course Prerequisite: E E 261 or 304;\njunior standing. The electrophysiology\nof excitable tissues (neurons and muscle)\nand human health applications involving\nrecording activity or stimulating these tissues.\nEngineering principles are integrated with\nneural physiology for design and analysis of\nbiomedical devices.\n440 Unified Systems Bioengineering II 4 (3-\n3) Course Prerequisite: BIO ENG 210 with a\nC or better; BIO ENG 340 with a C or better.\nContinuation of BIO ENG 340; emphasis on\nfeedback control system analysis and design,\nwith examples from physiological systems.\n455 M e t a b o l i c E n g i n e e r i n g 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: BIO ENG 210 or CHE 211; CHE\n201; MATH 220; MATH 315. Understanding\nmetabolic properties of organisms such that\ncells can be modified for use as biochemical\nplants to produce desired bioproducts.\n(Crosslisted course offered as BIO ENG 455,\nCHE 474).\n475 I n t r o d u c t i o n t o B i o c h e m i c a l\nEngineering 3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 321\nand 332 each with a C or better, OR BIO ENG\n310, and 340, and 350 each with a C or better.\nApplication of chemical engineering principles\nto the processing of biological and biochemical\nmaterials. (Crosslisted course offered as CHE\n475, BIO ENG 475.)\n476 Biomedical Engineering Principles\n3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 310 with a C or\nbetter. The application of chemical engineering\nprinciples to biomedical processes. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CHE 476, BIO ENG 476.)\n481 Advanced Topics in Bioengineering V\n1-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite: Junior\nstanding; instructor permission. Advanced\ntopics in bioengineering.\n\n114\nChemical Engineering and Bioengineering\nWashington State University, 2021\n488 Professional Practice Coop/Internship\nI V 1-2 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite: By\ndepartment permission. Practicum for students\nadmitted to the VCEA Professional Practice and\nExperiential Learning Program; integration\nof coursework with on-the-job professional\nexperience. (Crosslisted course offered as ENGR\n488, BIO ENG 488, CHE 488, CE 488, CPT S 488,\nE E 488, ME 488, MSE 488, SDC 488). S, F grading.\n495 Internship in Bioengineering V 1-3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Course Prerequisite: BIO ENG 205;\njunior standing; instructor permission. Work\nexperience related to academic learning. S, F\ngrading.\n499 Special Problems in Bioengineering V 1-4\nMay be repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Course Prerequisite: Sophomore\nstanding; instructor permission. Independent\nstudy conducted under the jurisdiction of\nan approving faculty member; may include\nindependent research studies in technical or\nspecialized problems; selection and analysis of\nspecified readings; development of a creative\nproject; or field experiences. S, F grading.\n525 Biomechanics 3 Methods for analysis of rigid\nbody and deformable mechanics; application\nto biological tissue, especially bone, cartilage,\nligaments, tendon and muscle. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as BIO ENG 425/525, ME 525).\nCredit not granted for more than one of BIO\nENG 425, BIO ENG 525, or ME 525.\n541 Systems Bioengineering 3 Physiological\nsystems emphasizing the cardiovascular,\npulmonary, renal, endocrine, musculoskeletal,\nnervous and sensory systems.\n550 Cellular Bioengineering 3 Cellular biology\nintegrated with engineering science; cellular\nphenomena from an engineering perspective;\nquantitative engineering principles for cellular-\nbased materials, diagnostic devise and sensor\ndesigns.\nCHEMICAL ENGINEERING\nCHE\n101 Overview of Chemical Engineering 1\nCurrent topics, issues, and career options in\nChemical Engineering.\n110 Introduction to Chemical Engineering\n2 Course Prerequisite: CHE 101 with a C\nor better; CHEM 105 with a C or better or\nconcurrent enrollment in CHEM 106, 331,\n345, or 348; MATH 171 with a C or better or\nconcurrent enrollment in MATH 172, 182, 273,\nor 315. Introduction to chemical engineering;\ndevelopment of problem solving skills.\n201 Chemical Process Principles and\nCalculations 3 Course Prerequisite: CHE\n110 with a C or better, or BIO ENG 140 with\nan S, or junior standing; CHEM 106 with a C\nor better or concurrent enrollment in CHEM\n331, 345, or 348; MATH 172 or 182 with a C\nor better, or concurrent enrollment in MATH\n273 or 315. Fundamental concepts of chemical\nengineering; problem-solving techniques and\napplications in stoichiometry, material and\nenergy balances, and phase equilibria.\n211 Process Simulation 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCHE 201 with a C or better; MATH 315 with a C\nor better or concurrent enrollment. Computer\nsolutions to problems in chemical engineering\nprocessing.\n301 Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics\n3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 101 with a C or\nbetter or concurrent enrollment; CHE 211\nwith a C or better or concurrent enrollment;\nCHEM 331 with a C or better or concurrent\nenrollment; admitted to the major in Chemical\nEngineering. Basic concepts and laws; property\nrelationships; compression and liquefaction;\nphase equilibria; reaction equilibria;\napplications in stagewise processing.\n310 Introduction to Transport Processes\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 315 and CHE\n101 and CHE 211, each with a C or better or\nconcurrent enrollment; OR MATH 315 with a\nC or better or concurrent enrollment and BIO\nENG 205 with an S or concurrent enrollment;\nadmitted major in Chem Engr or Bioengr.\nFundamentals of the phenomena governing\nthe transport of momentum, energy, and mass.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CHE 310, BIO\nENG 310).\n321 Kinetics and Reactor Design 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CHE 301 with a C or better; CHEM\n331 with a C or better; MATH 315 with a C\nor better; admitted to the major in Chemical\nEngineering. Chemical reaction kinetics\napplied to the design of reactors, non-ideal\nflow, mixing, catalysis.\n332 Fluid Mechanics and Heat Transfer\n3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 301 with a C or\nbetter; CHE 310 with a C or better; admitted\nto the major in Chemical Engineering. Design\ncalculations, operations, and evaluation of\nequipment used in fluid flow, heat transfer,\nand evaporation.\n334 Chemical Engineering Separations\n3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 301 with a C or\nbetter; CHE 310 with a C or better; CHEM 345\nwith a C or better; admitted to the major in\nChemical Engineering. Design and evaluation\nof equipment used in continuous contacting.\n352 Chemical Process Safety 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CHE 321 with a C or better; CHE\n332 with a C or better; admitted to the major\nin Chemical Engineering. Introduction to\ntechnical fundamentals of chemical process\nsafety.\n422 Catalysis: From Fundamentals to\nIndustrial Applications 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CHE 301 with a C or better;\nCHE 321 with a C or better. An introduction\nto modern catalysis systems for chemical\nengineers, with an emphasis on heterogeneous\ncatalysis.\n432 [M] Chemical Engineering Lab I 3 (1-6)\nCourse Prerequisite: CHE 321 and 334 with\na C or better; CHE 332 with a C or better or\nconcurrent; CHE 352 with a C or better or\nconcurrent; ENGLISH 402 or 403 with a C\nor better or concurrent; STAT 423 with a C or\nbetter; admitted to Chemical Engr. Statistical\ndesign and analysis of experiments; safety;\nexperiments in heat and mass transfer;\nseparations, other unit operations, kinetics,\ncontrol; technical reports and presentations.\n433 [M] Chemical Engineering Lab II 2 (0-\n6) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 4 hours. Course Prerequisite: CHE\n432 with a C or better. Laboratory experiments\nin heat and mass transfer; separations,\nother unit operations, kinetics, control;\ndesign calculations; technical reports and\npresentations.\n441 Process Control 3 Course Prerequisite: CHE\n321 with a C or better; CHE 332 with a C or\nbetter; CHE 334 with a C or better; admitted to\nthe major in Chemical Engineering. Measuring\ninstruments, automatic control, process and\ninstrument characteristics and theory applied\nto industrial control problems.\n450 Chemical Process Analysis and Design\nI 3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 321 with a C\nor better; CHE 332 with a C or better; CHE\n334 with a C or better; CHE 352 with a C or\nbetter or concurrent; ENGLISH 402 or 403\nwith a C or better or concurrent; admitted to\nthe major in Chemical Engineering. Chemical\nengineering design; computer tools; safety\nand environmental constraints; cost and\nequipment optimization.\n451 [CAPS] [M] Chemical Process Analysis\nand Design II 3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 450\nwith a C or better. Development, design, and\neconomic evaluation of chemical and related\nprocesses as practiced in industry.\n461 Introduction to Nuclear Engineering 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MATH 315; admitted to\na major in engineering or physical sciences;\nsenior standing. Applied nuclear physics;\napplication to the nuclear fuel cycle and\nnuclear reactor core design; nuclear reactor\nsystems and safety. (Crosslisted course offered\nas ME 461, CHE 461).\n462 Applied Electrochemistry 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CHE 301 with a C or better; CHE\n310 with a C or better; CHE 321 with a C or\nbetter; CHEM 331 with a C or better; admitted\nto the major in Chemical Engineering.\nThermodynamics, kinetics, and transport\nprocesses that occur in a simple model\nelectrochemical system and how to apply them\ninto more complicated real systems.\n463 Introduction to Upstream/Midstream\nTechnology 3 Course Prerequisite: CHE\n301. An introduction for chemical engineers\nto oil and gas exploration, production,\ntransportation, and storage.\n\n115\nChemistry\nWashington State University, 2021\n465 Integrated Envirochemical Engineering\n3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 321 with a C or\nbetter; CHE 334 with a C or better. Application\nof chemical engineering principles in\nassessment and remediation of industrial\nproblems in air pollution, water pollution, and\nsolid and hazardous waste.\n474 M e t a b o l i c E n g i n e e r i n g 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: BIO ENG 210 or CHE 211; CHE\n201; MATH 220; MATH 315. Understanding\nmetabolic properties of organisms such that\ncells can be modified for use as biochemical\nplants to produce desired bioproducts.\n(Crosslisted course offered as BIO ENG 455,\nCHE 474).\n475 I n t r o d u c t i o n t o B i o c h e m i c a l\nEngineering 3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 321\nand 332 each with a C or better, OR BIO ENG\n310, and 340, and 350 each with a C or better.\nApplication of chemical engineering principles\nto the processing of biological and biochemical\nmaterials. (Crosslisted course offered as CHE\n475, BIO ENG 475.)\n476 Biomedical Engineering Principles\n3 Course Prerequisite: CHE 310 with a C or\nbetter. The application of chemical engineering\nprinciples to biomedical processes. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CHE 476, BIO ENG 476.)\n481 Special Topics in Chemical Engineering\nV 1-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 9 hours. Pulp and paper processing,\nadvanced separations, and atomistic methods\nin chemical engineering.\n485 Interfacial Phenomena 3 Chemical and\nphysical nature of the interface including\nthe molecular basis for interfacial forces and\nresulting macroscopic phenomena. Credit not\ngranted for both CHE 485 and 585.\n488 Professional Practice Coop/Internship\nI V 1-2 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite: By\ndepartment permission. Practicum for students\nadmitted to the VCEA Professional Practice and\nExperiential Learning Program; integration\nof coursework with on-the-job professional\nexperience. (Crosslisted course offered as ENGR\n488, BIO ENG 488, CHE 488, CE 488, CPT S\n488, E E 488, ME 488, MSE 488, SDC 488). S, F\ngrading.\n495 Chemical Engineering Internship 2 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum 4\nhours. Students work full time in engineering\nassignments in approved industries with prior\napproval of advisor and industrial supervisor.\nS, F grading.\n498 Technical Seminar 1 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 2 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nChemical Engineering. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Sophomore\nstanding; instructor permission. Independent\nstudy conducted under the jurisdiction of\nan approving faculty member; may include\nindependent research studies in technical or\nspecialized problems; selection and analysis of\nspecified readings; development of a creative\nproject; or field experiences. S, F grading.\n510 Transport Processes 3 Transport of mass,\nenergy, and momentum; unsteady and steady\nstates as applied to chemical processing;\nmacroscopic and microscopic analyses.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n527 C h e m i c a l T h e r m o d y n a m i c s 3\nThermodynamic laws for design and\noptimization of thermodynamic systems,\nequations of state, properties of ideal and\nreal fluids and fluid mixtures, stability,\nphase equilibrium, chemical equilibrium;\napplications of thermodynamic principles.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n529 Chemical Engineering Kinetics 3\nInterpretation of kinetic data and design of\nnonideal chemical reactors; fundamentals of\nheterogeneous catalysis, catalyst preparation,\ncharacterization, and theory. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n541 Chemical Engineering Analysis 3\nMathematical analysis of chemical engineering\noperations and processes; mathematical\nmodeling and computer application.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n549 Biochemical Conversion Laboratory\n2 (1-3) Analytical techniques in biomass\nc h a r a c t e r i z a t i o n ; b i o p r o d u c t / b i o f u e l\nproduction from renewable biomass including\nbiochemical processes.\n560 Biochemical Engineering 3 Chemical\nengineering applied to biological systems;\nfermentation processes, biochemical reactor\ndesign, downstream processing, transport\nphenomena in biological systems, biochemical\ntechnology. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n574 Protein Biotechnology 3 Biotechnology\nrelated to the isolation, modification and large\nscale commercial production, patenting and\nmarketing of useful recombinant proteins and\nproducts. (Crosslisted course offered as MPS\n574, CHE 574, MBIOS 574). Recommended\npreparation: MBIOS 513.\n581 A d v a n c e d To p i c s i n C h e m i c a l\nEngineering V 1-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 9 hours. Filtration,\nreaction engineering, two-phase flow, non-\nNewtonian fluids, interfacial phenomena,\nfluidization, novel separations, biomedical\nengineering.\n585 Interfacial Phenomena 3 Chemical and\nphysical nature of the interface including\nthe molecular basis for interfacial forces and\nresulting macroscopic phenomena. Credit not\ngranted for both CHE 485 and 585.\n596 Research Methods and Presentation\n3 Establish sound practices for responsible\nconduct of graduate research and ethics;\ntechniques used for performing thorough\nliterature searches, establishing and testing\nr e s e a rc h h y p o t h e s e s , a n d s u c c e s s f u l\npresentation of research results.\n597 Research Methods and Presentation II 2\nEstablishing sound practices for presentation\nof research programs and research results.\n598 Research Seminar 1 May be repeated for\ncredit. Seminar presentations on current topics\nin chemical engineering research. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit.
