S, U\ngrading.\nDepartment of\nCommunication and Society\nmurrow.wsu.edu\nStudent Services, Murrow 226\n509-335-7333\nDescription of Courses\nCOMMUNICATION AND SOCIETY\nCOMSOC\n230 Principles of Group Communication\n3 Theoretical and practical aspects of\ncommunication in groups; classroom exercises\nand films demonstrate principles and develop\nskills.\n301 Foundations of Persuasion 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor\nin the College of Communication. Theories\nof persuasion and social action; study of\nstrategies and techniques for the persuasive\nuse of language and other symbols.\n321 [DIVR] Intercultural Communication\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to any\nmajor. Culture and cultural differences, race\nand ethnicity, stereotypes, and intercultural\ncommunication in contexts.\n324 [M] Reasoning and Writing 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to any major or minor\nin the College of Communication; sophomore\nstanding. Theories of persuasion and social\naction; study of strategies and techniques\nfor the persuasive use of language and other\nsymbols.\n325 Environmental Communication 3\nCourse Prerequisite: COM 101 or 105; COM\n210 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Communication;\njunior standing. How communication shapes\nhuman understanding and decision making\nconcerning the natural environment in local,\nnational, and global contexts.\n326 Organizing for Social Change 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to any major; junior\nstanding. Models of social change campaigns,\nsocial movements, and organizing grassroots\norganizations.\n421 [CAPS] Intercultural Communication\nand Globalization 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to any major; junior standing.\nHow global processes shape intercultural\ncommunication and how globalization is\nunderstood, advanced, and opposed by\ndifferent groups.\n480 Science Communication Campaigns 3\nCourse Prerequisite: COM 309; COMSOC 325;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College of\nCommunication; senior standing. Develop an\neffective communication campaign to address\na science communication challenge.\n495 C o m m u n i c a t i o n a n d S o c i e t y\nProfessional Internship V 2-12 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: By application\nonly. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to a\nmajor in the College of Communication; by\ninterview only. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\nDepartment of Journalism\nand Media Production\nmurrow.wsu.edu\nStudent Services, Murrow 226\n509-335-7333\nAssociate Professor (Career track/Scholar) and Chair,\nB. Shors; Professors, L. Pintak, A. Tan; Associate\nProfessor, E. Hindman; Assistant Professors, J.\nFoley, J. Henrichsen, B. Irom; Associate Professors\n(Career track/ Scholar), M. Marcelo, L. Waananen-\nJones; Assistant Professors (Career track/Scholar), A.\nBoggs, M. Loveless, S. Pande, W. Raney, K. Rhoden, R.\nTaflinger; Assistant Professors (Career track/Teaching),\nG. Bedoyan, W. Loftus.\nStudents earning a degree in Journalism and Media\nProduction will be prepared to join the many\nexciting and rapidly evolving careers in traditional\nand new media. Our courses balance conceptual\nunderstanding, critical thinking, ethical principles,\nand hands-on skill development. Our labs and\nstudios include industry-standard equipment\nand software. Students with a passion for writing,\nreporting, creating, producing, learning, and\npresenting will have ample opportunities to develop\ntheir natural talents.\nBroadcast News: Learn to film, write, report,\nanchor, and edit news content for television, radio,\nand online platforms. Career Options: television\nanchor; sports or entertainment broadcast reporter;\ndigital content producer; radio reporter.\nBroadcast Production: Learn to produce,\ndirect, and operate complex video equipment for\nmulti-camera sports, news, music performances,\nand other reality-based programs in the studio or\nat large outdoor venues. Career options: Television\nor film producer; director; production management;\nfilm and video editor.\nMultimedia Journalism: Learn about the news\nwriting from features to sports and investigations,\nas well as how to produce online video and audio\nstories. Career options: Reporter; editor; magazine\nwriter; photojournalist; digital content producer;\npodcaster.\nMedia and Technology: Learn to communicate\neffectively through speaking, writing, and the use\nof media technology to create effective messages for\norganizations and audiences. Career options: Media\nResearcher, Media technician, Media specialist,\nManager of Technology.\nMinor in Sport Communication: Learn how\nto communicate sports to mass media audiences\nwith hands-on skills and a theoretical foundation.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBROADCAST NEWS\n(120 HOURS)\nAdmission Requirements\nStudents are admitted directly into their desired\nmajor in the College of Communication upon\nadmission and enrollment at Washington State\nUniversity.\nTo remain admitted in any major in the College\nof Communication, a student must complete all\nrequired courses and have a minimum cumulative\n2.0 GPA. COM 300 must be completed with a C\nor better, and only two attempts are allowed and\na “W” is counted as an attempt. With an appeal\nto the department chair, a student may request to\ntake COM 300 for a 3rd attempt during a summer\nsession. All pre-requisites must be met in order\nto move through the Murrow curriculum. If a\nstudent fails to complete the required curriculum,\nthey will not be able to remain admitted in the\nMurrow College. If a student is failing to complete\nacademic requirements in a reasonable timeline,\nan advisor will work with the student to identify\nanother academic path. Students must remain in\ngood academic standing in order to graduate with\na degree from the Murrow College.\nDirect to Degree for Transfer Students\nTransfer students bringing in 30 or more semester\ncredits from an outside institution, and a 3.0 or\nhigher transfer GPA will be directly admitted\ninto the Murrow College. After consulting with a\nMurrow Professional Academic Advisor, a student\ntransferring with junior status (60 or more semester\ncredits), with a 3.0 or higher transfer GPA, and who\nhas completed COM 101 or COM 105 from another\ninstitution, will be allowed to take COM 300 in\ntheir first semester at WSU with all remaining 100\nlevel required communication courses. All transfer\nstudents are required to consult with a Murrow\nProfessional Academic Advisor prior to enrollment\nat WSU.\n\n132\nCommunication\nWashington State University, 2021\nAdditional majors within the Strategic\nCommunications Degree\nStudents with a primary major in Journalism\nand Media Production, can elect to earn an\nadditional major within the degree or within the\ncollege, with the exception of Integrated Strategic\nCommunication, by completing the second set\nof major requirements and two additional upper-\ndivision courses in COM, COMJOUR, COMSOC\nand COMSTRAT. These courses cannot be used\nelsewhere in the degree. If interested in this option,\nplease consult with a Murrow Professional Academic\nAdvisor.\nDouble Degree\nStudents with a primary major/degree in\nJournalism and Media Production can earn a\nsecond degree in the department of Strategic\nCommunication. To be admitted into a second\nMurrow degree option, please consult with a\nMurrow Professional Academic Advisor. *Note:\nto earn a second degree, you must complete 150\ncredits.\nAcademic Requirements\nBelow is a detailed schedule of studies in a 4-year\nformat. However, students will develop their\nown academic plan in consultation with their\nprofessional academic advisor through the Murrow\nCenter for Student Success. The BA in Journalism\nand Media Production is broken down into four\nmain categories as found in myWSU under your\nAcademic Requirements:\n1. Journalism and Media Production Degree\nRequirements: COM 320; 415; 440; COMJOUR\n350; COMSOC 321; and one Advanced Media and\nSociety course from approved list (in footnotes) (18\ncredits).\n3. COM 300 must be completed with a C\nor better, and only two attempts are allowed and\na “W” is counted as an attempt. With an appeal\nto the department chair, a student may request to\ntake COM 300 for a 3rd attempt during a summer\nsession. All pre-requisites must be met in order\nto move through the Murrow curriculum. If a\nstudent fails to complete the required curriculum,\nthey will not be able to remain admitted in the\nMurrow College. If a student is failing to complete\nacademic requirements in a reasonable timeline,\nan advisor will work with the student to identify\nanother academic path. Students must remain in\ngood academic standing in order to graduate with\na degree from the Murrow College.\nDirect to Degree for Transfer Students\nTransfer students bringing in 30 or more semester\ncredits from an outside institution, and a 3.0 or\nhigher transfer GPA will be directly admitted\ninto the Murrow College. All transfer\nstudents are required to consult with a Murrow\nProfessional Academic Advisor prior to enrollment\nat WSU.\nAdditional majors within the Strategic\nCommunication Degree\nStudents with a primary major in Journalism\nand Media Production, can elect to earn an\nadditional major within the degree or within the\ncollege, with the exception of Integrated Strategic\nCommunication, by completing the second set\nof major requirements and two additional upper-\ndivision courses in COM, COMJOUR, COMSOC\nand COMSTRAT. These courses cannot be used\nelsewhere in the degree. Four of the six courses\nrequired for the minor must be from the College of\nCommunication. Required courses include COM\n105 and COM 225. Additional requirements include\none survey course from COM 101, SPMGT 101, 276;\none promotional course from COMSTRAT 312, 380,\nSPMGT 379, 464; one conceptual course from COM\n320, 440, 471, SPMGT 365, 367; and one portfolio\ncourse from COM 475 (departmental approval\nrequired), 486, COMJOUR 486. Nine credits of\nupper-division work must be taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. Student may be\nadmitted in the minor after they have earned a\nminimum of 60 credits with a cumulative WSU GPA\nof 2.7 or higher. Transfer students can be admitted\nto this minor after completing 60 total credits and\none semester at WSU with a 2.7 or higher WSU\nGPA. Students must maintain a GPA of 2.0 or higher\nto remain in the minor. Check with the Murrow\nCollege Student Services Office for additional\ninformation.\nDescription of Courses\nJOURNALISM AND MEDIA PRODUCTION\nCOMJOUR\n150 Introduction to Broadcast Equipment\n1 Orientation to broadcast equipment; audio,\nstudio television, and field television, as\napplied to various functions. S, F grading.\n275 Communication Seminar V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 9\nhours. Varying specialty topics in journalism,\nmass media, and broadcast production.\n333 [M] Reporting Across Platforms 3 Course\nPrerequisite: COM 210 with a C or better; COM\n300 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Communication.\nInstruction in reporting, writing and editing\nnews stories suitable for publication and on-air\npresentation.\n335 Broadcast News Reporting 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: COMJOUR 333; admitted to\na major in the College of Communication.\nFundamentals of broadcast reporting;\ndevelopment of editorial and news judgment,\nwriting skills, and proficiency in field camera\nproduction and editing.\n350 News and Society 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCOM 101; COM 102; COM 105; COM\n138; admitted to a major in the College\nof Communication; sophomore standing.\nFundamentals of historic, contemporary, and\nemerging models of news production; social\ncontexts and effects, alternative sources, and\ncritiques of news.\n355 Beginning Television Production 3 (1-6)\nCourse Prerequisite: COMJOUR 333; admitted\nto a major in the College of Communication.\nBeginning television studio production,\ndirecting, lighting, graphic design, editing,\nvideo/audio compression.\n360 Writing for Television 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major in the College\nof Communication. Theory and practice of\nwriting scripts: analysis of dramatic, comedic,\ncommercial, documentary scripts; writing\nscripts for each genre.\n390 Video for the Web 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: COM 210 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Communication; sophomore standing.\nCapture, design, edit, and compress quality\nvideo and audio; basic lighting techniques.\n425 [M] Reporting of Public Affairs 3 Course\nPrerequisite: COMJOUR 333; admitted to\na major in the College of Communication;\njunior standing. Research covering public and\nprivate sectors.\n433 Audio Journalism 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nCOMJOUR 333; admitted to a major in the\nCollege of Communication. Audio journalism\ndesigned to refine a range of skills including\nreporting; on-air presentation; podcasting;\nwriting for audio; and sportscasting.\n455 Advanced Television Production 4 (3-\n3) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 8 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nCOMJOUR 355; admitted to a major in the\nCollege of Communication. Field production;\nediting; advanced studio production.\n465 [M] Advanced Television News 4 (0-\n12) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 8 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nCOMJOUR 335; admitted to a major in the\nCollege of Communication; junior standing.\nWriting, reporting, and editing broadcast news;\ndevelopment and production of broadcast\nquality news.\n466 Documentary Video 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor in\nthe College of Communication. Video editing\nfor news reporting; feature-length editing for\nnews and public affairs topics; documentaries;\nvisual storytelling.\n481 B r o a d c a s t M a n a g e m e n t 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to a major or minor\nin the College of Communication; junior\nstanding. The role of innovation and\nentrepreneurship for the future of media.\n486 Murrow News Service 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: COMJOUR 335, 355,\nor 425; admitted to a major in the College of\nCommunication; senior standing. Advanced\njournalism and media production to produce\ninvestigative, watchdog news reports for media\noutlets and public.\n487 Sports Journalism 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCOM 300 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nor minor in the College of Communication;\njunior standing. Writing-intensive course with\na focus on writing, reporting, and coverage of\nsports; students cover sporting events, conduct\ninterviews, and attend news conferences\noutside of class.\n495 Broadcasting Professional Internship V\n2-12 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 12 hours. Course Prerequisite: COM\n300 with a C or better; admitted to a major in\nthe College of Communication. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\nDepartment of Strategic\nCommunication\nmurrow.wsu.edu\nMurrow 226\n509-335-7333\nAssociate Dean, Professor, and Chair, S. Hust;\nAssociate Dean and Professor, P. Bolls; Director of\nIntegrated Strategic Communication (Everett) and\nScholarly Associate Professor, B. Atwood; Director\nof Integrated Strategic Communication (Global) and\nScholarly Associate Professor, R. Cooney; Director\nof Integrated Strategic Communication (Vancouver)\nand Scholarly Associate Professor, N. Iyer; Dean and\nProfessor, B. Pinkleton; Professor, E. Austin; Associate\nProfessors, P. Borah, A. Boyd, Y. Lee, J. Willoughby;\nAssistant Professors, T. Gillig, Y. I. Lee, W. Peng;\nScholarly Associate Professor, L. Paxson (Everett);\nScholarly Assistant Professors, J. Barnes, E. Candello\n(Vancouver), C. Hawkins-Jedlicka, C. Newman, D.\nPetek, B. Pingel, R. Richardson (Everett), M. Ritsch\n, E. Tomson, C. Wilder (Everett); Teaching Assistant\nProfessors, C. Curtis, M. Kistler, L. Tsui. Lecturers, T.\nEdwards, I. Haider.\nStudents pursuing a Bachelor of Arts in Strategic\nCommunication learn to communication creatively\nand persuasively to build mutually beneficial, long\nterm relationships between organizations and\ntheir target populations. Majors leading to the\ndegree are Advertising, Public Relations, Risk and\nCrisis Communication, and Integrated Strategic\nCommunication. At the Everett, Global, and\nVancouver campuses, only the Integrated Strategic\nCommunication major is available.\n• Advertising: Learn how to effectively appeal to\nconsumers by designing and evaluating advertising\ninitiatives using a variety of media platforms.\nCareer Options: Advertising Coordinator; Digital\nMedia Planner; Marketing; Ad Sales; Social Media\nStrategist; and Creative Director.\n• Public Relations: Learn how to foster beneficial\nrelationships with key stakeholders and build and\nmaintain a positive public image for a company\nor person. Career Options: Public Relations\nSpecialist; Event Planner; Media Relations; Lobbyist;\nDevelopment Officer; Campaign Manager; and\nSocial Engagement Manager.\n• Risk and Crisis Communication: Learn how\nto design and implement crisis campaigns at the\nindividual and societal levels, and well as steer\nindustry through time of risk and crisis via effective\ncommunication strategies. Career options: Crisis\nCommunicator; Crisis Interventionist; Health\n\n136\nCommunication\nWashington State University, 2021\nCommunication Coordinator; Risk Communication\nSpecialist; and Public Information Officer.\n• Integrated Strategic Communication: Learn\nto acquire and analyze information to create\ncommunication products (writing, visual, and\nspeaking) that address communication objectives\nvia multiple media platforms. Career options:\nDigital Advertising Coordinator; Social Media\nStrategist; Brand Strategist; and Consumer Analyst.\n• Health Communication and Promotion: The\nminor in Health Communication and Promotion\nrequires a minimum of 18 credits. Students pursuing\na degree in the Murrow College may only apply\ntwo courses from their major coursework to this\nminor. For all other areas of study, check with your\nprimary advisor.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nADVERTISING\n(120 HOURS)\nAdmission Requirements\nStudents are admitted directly into their desired\nmajor in the College of Communication upon\nadmission and enrollment at Washington State\nUniversity.\nTo remain admitted in any major in the College\nof Communication, a student must complete all\nrequired courses and have a minimum cumulative\n2.0 GPA. COM 300 must be completed with a C\nor better, and only two attempts are allowed and\na “W” is counted as an attempt. With an appeal\nto the department chair, a student may request to\ntake COM 300 for a 3rd attempt during a summer\nsession. All pre-requisites must be met in order\nto move through the Murrow curriculum. If a\nstudent fails to complete the required curriculum,\nthey will not be able to remain admitted in the\nMurrow College. If a student is failing to complete\nacademic requirements in a reasonable timeline,\nan advisor will work with the student to identify\nanother academic path. Students must remain in\ngood academic standing in order to graduate with\na degree from the Murrow College.\nDirect to Degree for Transfer Students\nTransfer students bringing in 30 or more semester\ncredits from an outside institution, and a 3.0 or\nhigher transfer GPA will be directly admitted\ninto the Murrow College. After consulting with a\nMurrow Professional Academic Advisor, a student\ntransferring with junior status (60 or more semester\ncredits), with a 3.0 or higher transfer GPA, and who\nhas completed COM 101 or COM 105 from another\ninstitution, will be allowed to take COM 300 in\ntheir first semester at WSU with all remaining 100\nlevel required communication courses. All transfer\nstudents are required to consult with a Murrow\nProfessional Academic Advisor prior to enrollment\nat WSU.\nAdditional majors within the Strategic\nCommunications Degree\nStudents on the Pullman campus, with a primary\nmajor in Strategic Communication, can elect to earn\nan additional major within the degree, with the\nexception of Integrated Strategic Communication,\nby completing the second set of major requirements\nand two additional upper-division courses in COM,\nCOMJOUR, COMSOC and COMSTRAT. These\ncourses cannot be used elsewhere in the degree.\nIf interested in this option, please consult with a\nMurrow Academic Advisor.\nDouble Degree\nStudents with a primary major/degree in Strategic\nCommunication can earn a double degree in the\ndepartment of Journalism and Media Production. To\nbe admitted into a second Murrow degree option,\nplease consult with a Murrow Professional Academic\nAdvisor. *Note: to earn a second degree, you must\ncomplete 150 credits.\nAcademic Requirements\nBelow is a detailed schedule of studies in a\n4-year format. However, students will develop\ntheir own academic plan in consultation with\ntheir professional academic advisor through the\nMurrow Center for Student Success. Required courses\nincluded COM 101 or 105, COM 210, and COM\n478. Additional requirements include one content\ncreation course from COMSTRAT 310, 383, 477, and\nCOM 395; and two courses in specialized message\ncreation and evaluation from COM 309, 486,\nCOMSOC 477, and COMSTRAT 485. Nine credits\nof upper-division work must be taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. Students may may\nbe admitted to the minor once they have completed\n60 credits, have a WSU cumulative GPA of 2.7 or\nbetter, and are admitted to a major. Transfer students\n\n139\nCommunication\nWashington State University, 2021\ncan be admitted to this minor after completing 60\ntotal credits and one semester at WSU with a 2.7\nor higher WSU GPA. Students must maintain a 2.0\ncumulative GPA to remain in the minor. Students\npursuing a degree in the Murrow College may apply\nonly two courses from their major coursework to\nthis minor. Check with the Murrow College Student\nServices Office for additional Information.\nDescription of Courses\nHEALTH COMMUNICATION AND\nPROMOTION\nCOMHLTH\n570 Health Communication and Behavior\nChange 3 Application of behavior change\ntheories to construction and evaluation of\nhealth communication campaigns.\n571 Communicating Health in Practice\n3 Health communication and promotion\nacross a variety of settings and mediums, from\ninterpersonal to promotional campaigns.\n572 Communicating Health to Specialized\nPopulations 3 Literature and theory of cross-\ncultural communication and cultural aspects of\nhealth.\n573 C o m m u n i c a t i n g H e a l t h i n a\nDigital Landscape 3 Development and\nimplementation of health-related content\nthrough a variety of digital platforms.\n574 Health Message Design and Effectiveness\n3 Behavior change theories as they relate to\nhealth communication message design and\nevaluation.\nSTRATEGIC COMMUNICATION\nCOMSTRAT\n275 Strategic Communication Seminar V\n1-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 9 hours. Various specialty topics in\nstrategic communication.\n310 Digital Content Promotion 3 Course\nPrerequisite: COM 210 with a C or better;\nadmitted to a major or minor in the College\nof Communication; sophomore standing.\nPractice and promotion of public relations and\nadvertising through digital and social media.\n312 Principles of Public Relations 3 Principles,\ntheories, methods and objectives of public\nrelations; public relations problems and\npractices.\n380 Advertising Principles and Practices 3\nAdvertising history, theory and practice by\nadvertising agencies and organizations.\n381 [M] Creative Media Strategies and\nTechniques for Advertising 3 Course\nPrerequisite: COM 210 with a C or better; COM\n300 with a C or better; admitted to a major\nin the College of Communication; junior\nstanding. Development of creative content for\npersuasive campaigns through different media.\n382 Media Planning 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCOMSTRAT 380; admitted to a major in the\nCollege of Communication; junior standing.\nMedia planning theories, strategies, and\npractices.\n383 [M] Media Strategies and Techniques\nfor Public Relations 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCOM 210 with a C or better; COM 300 with\na C or better; admitted to a major in the\nCollege of Communication. Development of\ncreative content for persuasive public relations\ncampaigns through different media.\n395 Introduction to Integrated Strategic\nCommunication and Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: COMSTRAT 312 or 380;\nsophomore standing. Analysis and application\nof strategic communication theory and\nconcepts to influence attitudes and purchasing\nbehavior.\n475 Strategic Communication Seminar\nin Public Relations 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: Admitted to any major;\njunior standing. Theory, methods, and\napplications of communication and campaign\nmanagement; political communication, health\ncommunication, freedom of expression, special\naudiences.\n476 Consumer Insights and Branding 3\nCourse Prerequisite: COM 309; admitted to\na major in the College of Communication.\nAdvertising account planning based on a\nthorough understanding of target audiences\nand consumer research; linking client\nobjectives, account management, creative and\nmedia planning.\n477 Message Design for Communication\nCampaigns 3 Course Prerequisite: COMSTRAT\n310; admitted to a major in the College of\nCommunication; junior standing. Theory-\nbased design, market testing, and evaluation\nof messages for positive social outcomes.\n478 H e a l t h C o m m u n i c a t i o n 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to any major; junior\nstanding. Mediated communication in disease\nprevention and health intervention. (Formerly\nCOM 478).\n480 [M] Advertising Agency Operation\nand Campaigns 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCOMSTRAT 380; COMSTRAT 381; COMSTRAT\n382; admitted to a major in the College of\nCommunication; senior standing. Principles\nand functions of advertising management:\ncampaign planning, execution, presentation\nand evaluation.\n483 Risk Communication 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to any major; junior standing.\nResearch on perceptions of risk among\nstakeholders about complex environmental\nand natural resource issues. (Formerly\nCOMSOC 477).\n485 [M] Public Relations Management and\nCampaigns 3 Course Prerequisite: COM 309;\nCOMSTRAT 312; COMSTRAT 383; admitted\nto a major in the College of Communication;\nsenior standing. Application of public relations\nprinciples, management, persuasion theory\nand research methods to public relations\nissues.\n495 Strategic Communication Professional\nInternship V 2-12 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 12 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: COM 300 with a C or\nbetter; admitted to a major in the College of\nCommunication. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to a\nmajor in the College of Communication; by\ninterview only. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n561 P e r s u a s i o n f o r P r o f e s s i o n a l\nCommunicators 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to an online degree program or\ngraduate certificate in communication.\nIntroduction to theories, concepts, strategies,\nand processes of persuasion and social influence.\n562 C r e a t i v e M e d i a S t r a t e g i e s a n d\nTechniques 3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted\nto an online degree program or graduate\ncertificate in communication. The strategies,\nprocesses, procedures and steps involved in\ncreating marketing communications materials\nfor a variety of different media.\n563 Professional Digital Content Promotion\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to an online\ndegree program or graduate certificate in\ncommunication. The application of writing,\ncritical thinking, and persuasion skills to the\npractice and promotion of PR and advertising\nin both digital and social media outlets.\n564 C o n s u m e r B e h a v i o r a n d B r a n d\nDevelopment 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to an online degree program or\ngraduate certificate in communication. Tactics\nand strategies for consumer analysis and brand\ndevelopment; skills necessary for uncovering\nconsumer insights to link client objectives,\naccount management, creative development,\nand media planning.\n565 Professional Marketing Communication\nM a n a g e m e n t a n d C a m p a i g n s 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admitted to an online\ndegree program or graduate certificate in\ncommunication. An overview of behavior\nchange theories with a focus on strategic\nmarketing campaign design and evaluation;\nlearning to use theory and research to more\neffectively plan, design, execute and evaluate\nstrategic communication campaigns.\n701 Master’s Independent Capstone Project\nand /or Examination V 1-6 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to an\nonline degree program or graduate certificate\nin communication. Capstone project or final\nexamination for professional master’s degree\nunder the Graduate School. The credits will\ninclude a balloted evaluation of the student’s\ncompletion of the program’s capstone/\nexamination requirements by the program’s\ngraduate faculty. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and obtain approval from\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 701 credit. S, U grading.\n\n140\nCreative Media and Digital Culture\nWashington State University, 2021\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the online master’s program\nin strategic communication. Independent\nresearch in special problems, directed study,\nand/or examination credit for students in a\nnon-thesis master’s degree program. Students\nmust have graduate degree-seeking status\nand should check with their major advisor/\ncommittee chair before enrolling for 702\ncredit. S, U grading.\nProgram in Creative Media\nand Digital Culture -\nVancouver\ncas.vancouver.wsu.edu/creative-media-\ndigital-culture\nScience & Engineering Building (VSCI),\nRoom 130\n360-546-9620\nProgram Director and Professor, D. Grigar; Instructors,\nJ. Barber, B. Grell, W. Luers, M. Rabby, W. Luers;\nAcademic Director, TBD; Academic Coordinator, T.\nFordyce\nThe Creative Media and Digital Culture (CMDC)\nis an academic program, unique to Washington\nState University Vancouver, which houses the\nB.A. in Digital Technology and Culture, the Game\nStudies and Design certificate, and the Social Media\ncertificate. Anchored within the field of digital media\nwith emphasis on the intersection of art, technology,\nand the humanities, the Program features a strong\ninterdisciplinary and transdisciplinary focus across\nvarious colleges in the WSU system, and emphasizes\ncritical thinking, creativity, and technological\nexpertise. The goal of the Program is to offer a\nbroad-based degree that prepares students for the\nmedia-rich, technologically complex 21st Century.\nThe DTC degree of the CMDC offers a program\nof study in Media Authoring and certificates in\nGame Studies and Design as well as Social Media. In\naddition to foundational course work in DTC,\nstudents also take classes in Anthropology, English,\nFine Arts, History, Political Science, Psychology,\nSociology and other disciplines. Directed studies\nand internships encourage students to gain real\nworld experience and engage in projects aimed\nat serving the community, both of which help\nstudents with professional career networking and\ndeveloping a commitment to public service.\nAlong the way, the DTC program provides\nan intellectual environment comprised of\nspecial events like lectures, residency programs,\nperformances by internationally known artists,\nand field trips to media arts shows and exhibits,\nand it offers its students state-of-the-art computer\nlabs and studios in which to work and learn. Class\nsizes are kept small to assure one-on-one contact\nwith faculty.\nOptions in Digital Technology and Culture\nStudents may also select Digital Technology and\nCulture as a primary or secondary concentration\nwithin the Bachelor of Arts in Humanities or the\nBachelor of Arts in Social Sciences.\nThe Primary Concentration option requires the\ncompletion of at least 24 semester credit hours of\napproved DTC course work, including at least 15\nupper-division semester credits.\nThe Secondary Concentration option requires the\ncompletion of at least 15 semester credit hours of\napproved DTC course work, including at least six\nupper-division semester credits.\nCertificates\nThe Game Studies and Design Certificate\nrequires 15 semester credit hours of DTC course\nwork, including two foundational courses and\nthree courses that focus in either design or\ndevelopment. The Social Media Certificate, a\ncollaboration between the program and the\nEdward R. Murrow College of Communication,\nrequires 15 semester credit hours, including four\nfoundational courses and one additional course in\nmedia authoring.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n• Demonstrate competency with computers for\ndesigning, distributing, researching, retrieving,\nand preserving digital works in various mediums\nfor humane and effective human-computer\ninteractions\n• Synthesize media forms for multimedia contexts\n• Employ the principles for sophisticated\nmanipulation of various forms of digital media\n• Understand the production and assessment of\nmedia objects\n• Know the basics of information architecture and\nknowledge management along with ways digital\ninformation can be structured for retrieval and\narchival purposes for different audiences\n• Question the way digital media functions in\nmultiple cultural contexts\n• Recognize various forms of language processing\nand their implications for media authoring\n• Appreciate the history of technological\ndevelopment, from local to global perspectives, and\nits implications for a variety of mediums\n• Utilize an interdisciplinary perspective in order\nto understand the basics of social, economic, and\neducation changes brought about by digital media\n• Be practiced and capable communicators in all\nmediums\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nDIGITAL TECHNOLOGY AND CULTURE -\nCREATIVE MEDIA AND DIGITAL CULTURE\nOPTION (VANCOUVER ONLY)\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Creative Media\nand Digital Culture option of the DTC major upon\nmaking their intention known to the department.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] Completion of the Game Studies\nand Design Certificate requires a total of 15 credits.\nStudents are required to complete DTC 392 or 476\nand 492 plus 9 credits chosen from one of two\noptions. Students who select the Design Option\nselect three courses (9 credits) from DTC 335, 336,\n354, and 435. Students who select the Development\nOption select three courses (9 credits) from DTC\n338, 355, 477, and 478.\nSocial Media\nThe Social Media Certificate prepares students\nfor working in the emerging field of digital\ncommunication and product promotion. It covers\nsocial media in a variety of aspects, including\nits role in advertising and public relations, how\ncampaigns work, and the relational nature of\nonline engagement. Completion of the Social Media\nCertificate requires a total of 15 credits. Required\ncourses: COMSTRAT 312, 380; DTC 330, 331; and\na minimum of one course from DTC 336, 354, 355.\nDescription of Courses\nDIGITAL TECHNOLOGY AND CULTURE\nDTC\n101 [ A R T S ] I n t r o d u c t i o n t o D i g i t a l\nTechnology & Culture 3 Inquiry into\ndigital media, including origins, theories,\nforms, applications, and impact with a focus\non authoring and critiquing multimodal texts.\n104 Digital Foundations 1 Foundational\ncomputing skills: hardware, file management,\ncommon operating systems and applications,\nlibrary resources, and professionalization.\n201 [ARTS] Tools and Methods for Digital\nTechnology 3 An introduction to the tools\nand methods of production for multimedia\nauthoring in digital contexts.\n204 Introduction to Text Analysis 3\nI n t r o d u c t i o n t o c o m p u t a t i o n a l a n d\nstatistical text analysis using the open\nsource programming language R; designed\nfor students with no prior experience with\nprogramming but who wish to extend their\nmethodological tool kit to include quantitative\nand computational approaches to the study of\ntext. (Crosslisted course offered as DTC 204,\nDATA 204.)\n206 [DIVR] Digital Inclusion 3 Examination\nof global reach of digital environments,\nstructures, and tools with focus on inclusion\nin terms of access, availability, affordability,\nadoption, and application across cultures.\n208 [ARTS] Introduction to Digital Cinema\n3 A practical introduction to the technological\nand cultural transformations driving the\nevolution of cinematic techniques from\nthe birth of motion pictures to emerging\ntechnology.\n209 Introduction to Data Visualization 3 An\nintroduction to the tools and methods of data\nvisualization in multiple contexts. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as DTC 209, DATA 209.)\n330 Social Media Case Studies 3 Inquiry\ninto ways businesses and individuals use\nsocial media as a marketing tool with special\nemphasis on media impact.\n331 Social Media Practices 3 Inquiry into social\nmedia practices from a ground-up approach,\nfocusing on social media message creation and\nconsumption; online self-presentation; online\nrelationships; reputation management; social\nmedia data analysis.\n335 3D Digital Animation 3 (2-2) 3-D digital\nanimation for creative and professional\nproductions, art skills, story-telling and team\nproblem-solving techniques.\n336 Multimedia Design 3 Course Prerequisite:\nDTC 201. Design practices and process for\ncomposing for a multimedia environment\nincluding color, pattern, and shape.\n338 Special Topics in Digital Technology\nand Culture 3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 6 hours. Major trends\nor artists in digital technology and culture.\n354 [ARTS] [M] Digital Storytelling 3\nNonlinear, multi-linear, and interactive\nnarrative using elements of creative writing\nsuch as character, dialog, setting, plot and\nimage. (Crosslisted course offered as DTC 354,\nENGLISH 354).\n355 [M] Multimedia Authoring 3 Development\nfor new computer-based media; multimedia\na u t h o r i n g p r o j e c t s ; e x a m i n a t i o n o f\ninformation technology.\n356 [M] Information Structures 3 Course\nPrerequisite: DTC 101. Social and cultural\nrole of information; research with electronic\nsources; production, validation, storage,\nretrieval, evaluation, use, impact of electronic\ninformation.\n375 [M] Language, Texts and Technology 3\nCourse Prerequisite: DTC 101. Relationship\nbetween technology and communication;\nwriting practices from a historical point of\nview.\n392 Video Games Theories and History 3\nHistory and theory of video games with a focus\non innovation and cultural impact.\n435 Advanced Animation 3 (2-2) Course\nPrerequisite: DTC 335. Advanced investigation\nof tools and methods for 2D and 3D digital\nanimation.\n475 [DIVR] Digital Diversity 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Cultural impact\nof digital media in cultural contexts; issues of\nrace, class, gender, sexuality online.\n476 Digital Strategies 3 Examines multiple\ndigital strategies for engagement with\nimmersive and emerging technologies.\n477 Advanced Multimedia Authoring 3\nCourse Prerequisite: DTC 355. Advanced\nwriting, imaging and teamwork skills for\nauthoring in new computer-based media;\nwebsite project in client-oriented context.\n478 Usability and Interface Design 3 (0-\n6) Course Prerequisite: DTC 355. Design of\nwebsites using best practices of visual literacy,\ninterface architecture, and usability.\n491 Advanced Digital Cinema 3 Course\nPrerequisite: DTC 201 or 208. Exploration of\nadvanced techniques, theories, and aesthetic\nstrategies of cinema in the age of digital\nmedia, including video remix, mobile cinema,\nwebisodes, cinematic games, hyperlinked\nvideo, and database cinema.\n492 E n g i n e s a n d P l a t f o r m s 3 Course\nPrerequisite: DTC 355. A study of software\nplatforms and engines used for media design,\nwith special focus on intuitive tools, rapid work\nflow, multimedia platform environments, and\nasset management.\n497 [ C A P S ] S e n i o r S e m i n a r 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Completion of Junior Writing\nPortfolio; admitted to the major in Digital\nTechnology and Culture; senior standing.\nMajor multimedia project for nonprofit\norganization or small business with special\nfocus on project management, planning, and\nexecution.\n498 Internship V 1-6 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in Digital\nTechnology and Culture; junior standing;\ndepartment permission. (Crosslisted course offered as DTC 561,\nENGLISH 561).\nDepartment of Criminal\nJustice and Criminology\ncrmj.wsu.edu\nWilson-Short 111\n509-335-8611\nChair and Associate Professor, M.-A. Neuilly (Wolf);\nProfessors, D. Brody, C. Hemmens, F. Lutze, M.\nStohr; Associate Professors, L. Drapela, K. DuBois, D.\nMakin, D. Willits; Assistant Professors, H. Mellinger,\nA. Pedneault, A. Raza; Teaching Assistant Professor,\nJ. Snyder.\nThe Department of Criminal Justice and Criminology\noffers substantive studies in criminal justice and\ncriminology in conjunction with a liberal arts\neducation. It prepares students for a broad range of\ncareers in criminal justice institutions, government\nagencies at local, state, and federal levels, private\nsupport and welfare organizations, private security\nwork, and domestic and international corporations,\nas well as for the pursuit of graduate study or law\nschool; develops leadership qualities; and promotes\nthe ideal of professional achievement in public\nservice.\nCriminal Justice and Criminology is the\ninterdisciplinary study of the problem of crime\nand of the institutions, policies and practices by\nwhich society responds to the problem of crime, as\nwell as theories of human behavior and normative\nphilosophies directly related to the maintenance\nof social order, the control of crime and the\nachievement of a just society. Specific courses in\nthe program focus on social control issues and\npolicies, substantive and procedural criminal law,\nthe organization and workings of criminal justice\ninstitutions (police, courts, corrections, juvenile\njustice), issues relevant to groups in American\nsociety (gender, minorities), research and evaluation\nskills, theories of crime and delinquency, ethics,\nand the evaluation of management, programs, and\npolicies conducted by justice system institutions.\nStudents are also required to complete related\ncourses on the larger political, legal, economic\nand social environments in which crime and\nthe criminal justice system operate. Taught by\na multi-disciplinary faculty, courses cover such\nareas as public administration, American public\npolicy, constitutional law, and gender and\npolitics. Additional elective courses are offered\nby departments within the College of Arts and\nSciences.\nWe expect that graduating students will have\nan understanding of: 1) the causes of crime, 2)\nthe components, processes, and programs of the\ncriminal justice system, 3) the interconnectedness\nof theory, research, and practice, 4) the complexities\nof achieving justice in a multi-cultural society, 5) the\nintricacies of policy formation and implementation,\nand 6) the ability to understand and interpret social\nscience research.\nThe course of study leads to the Bachelor of Arts in\nCriminal Justice and Criminology, and the Master’s\nDegree and Ph.D. Degree in Criminal Justice and\nCriminology.\nTransfer Students\nStudents planning to transfer to Washington State\nUniversity at the end of the freshman or sophomore\nyear should follow as closely as possible the general\nand core course requirements set forth in the\nschedule of studies. If this is done, there should be\nno difficulty in completing the requirements for\nthe bachelor’s degree within the normal period of\nfour years.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nUndergraduates who are pursuing their studies at\nother institutions or through other curricula at this\ninstitution and who contemplate graduate work in\nthis program will do well to elect courses similar to\nthose required in the schedule of studies.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe B.A. in Criminal Justice and Criminology is\ndesigned to empower students as critical thinkers,\ncreative evaluators, ethical actors, and effective\ncommunicators concerning matters of crime and\nadministration of justice at the local, state, national,\nand international levels.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nCRIMINAL JUSTICE AND CRIMINOLOGY\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Criminal Justice\nand Criminology major upon completing CRM J\n101 and earning a minimum WSU cumulative GPA\nof 2.0 or better.\nStudents who major in criminal justice and\ncriminology must complete the 18 credits criminal\njustice core (CRM J 101, 201, 311, 320, 321, and 480)\nand 12 credits in criminal justice electives of which\n2 courses must be an [M].\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCRM J 101 [SSCI] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nElectives 6\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nCRM J 201 3\nDiversity [DIVR] or CRM J 205 [DIVR] 3\nHISTORY Sciences [SSCI] 3\nCRM J 321 3\nElectives 9\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCRM J 320 3\nCRM J Electives\n2 \n3\nElectives\n3 \n9\nSecond Term Hours\nCRM J Electives\n2 \n3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nElectives\n3 \n9\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCRM J Electives\n2 \n6\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or Electives\n3 \n9\nSecond Term Hours\nCRM J 480 [CAPS] 3\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or Electives\n3 \n10\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nCRM J Electives (12 credits): Any CRM J course not\nused to fulfill the CRM J core requirements. Must\ninclude 2 [M] courses.\n3 \nElectives: 300-400-level coursework as needed to\nmeet University requirements of 120 credits and 40\nupper-division credits.\nMinors\nCriminal Justice and Criminology\nThe student who minors in Criminal Justice will\nlearn about the various components and activities\nof our system of justice, such as the police,\ncourts, corrections, and juvenile justice. A minor\nin Criminal Justice will be useful to any student\ndesiring knowledge of how our American system\nof justice works.\nThe minor in Criminal Justice and Criminology\nrequires 18 credits of coursework in criminal justice\n(CRM J), including CRM J 101. 9 credits must be\ntaken at the 300-400 level and taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. All coursework\nwith the exception of CRM J 490 and 499 must be\ngraded. CRM J 499 may not be applied toward the\nminor unless approved in advance by department.\nInterested students should contact the Department\nof Criminal Justice and Criminology for details.\n\n143\nCriminal Justice and Criminology\nWashington State University, 2021\nDescription of Courses\nCRIMINAL JUSTICE\nCRM J\n101 [ S S C I ] I n t r o d u c t i o n t o t h e\nAdministration of Criminal Justice 3\nAgencies and processes in the administration\nof criminal justice. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n201 Introduction to Criminological Theory\n3 Analysis of conceptions of crime and\nseriousness as determined by societal factors.\n205 [ D I V R ] R e a l i z i n g J u s t i c e i n a\nMulticultural Society 3 The pursuit of\njustice and the historical, contemporary, and\nfuture issues and challenges facing society and\nthe criminal justice system.\n270 Introduction to Policing 3 Historical\ndevelopment and contemporary challenges\nassociated with policing with special emphasis\non the conflicting role expectations facing\npolice officers. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n280 Introduction to American Criminal\nCourts 3 History, purpose, structure, and\nprocess associated with criminal courts;\nemphasizes the roles of attorneys and judges\nand court processes from initial appearance\nto appeal. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n311 Research Methods for Criminal Justice\n3 Course Prerequisite: CRM J 101. Discussion\nof research methods appropriate for the study\nof crime and criminal justice policies and\ninstitutions.\n320 Criminal Law 3 Course Prerequisite: CRM\nJ 101. Substantive criminal law; principles,\nfunctions, and limits; basic crime categories,\nstate and national legal research materials.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n321 Quantitative Methods for Criminal\nJustice 3 Course Prerequisite: CRM J 101.\nCritical discussion of skills and methods\nneeded for the analysis of implementation and\nimpact of criminal justice policies.\n330 C r i m e C o n t r o l P o l i c i e s 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. Analysis of ideologies,\nassumptions, and performance of crime\ncontrol policies. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n365 Juvenile Justice and Corrections 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. History, philosophy,\nlegal process, performance, and outcomes of\nthe juvenile justice and corrections systems.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CRM J 365, SOC\n367). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n370 Policing and Society 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCRM J 101. Development, organization,\npolicies, and performance of the police.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n380 Criminal Courts in America 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. Structure and process\nof the prosecution and adjudication of\nindividuals charged with crimes in the criminal\ncourt system.\n381 Crime and Justice in the Movies 3 (2-2)\nCourse Prerequisite: CRM J 101. Mass media\nas both reflector and shaper of public attitudes\nand opinions about crime, criminals, law,\norder, and justice; using films. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CRM J 381, POL S 381).\n385 Institutional Corrections 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. Ideologies of\npunishment and correction, intermediary\nsanctioning and reintegration policies in the\ncriminal justice system.\n390 Criminal Justice Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. Predominate and\nprogressive thought and theory of criminal\njustice administration in the U.S.; exploring\nimportant and troubling issues faced by\nthose involved in managing criminal justice\nagencies.\n400 [M] Special Topics in Criminal Justice\nand Criminology 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. Selected topics in\ncriminal justice and criminology. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n403 [CAPS] Violence Toward Women 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Violence toward\nwomen and its relationship to broader social\nissues such as sexism and social control.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CRM J 403,\nWOMEN ST 403).\n405 [M] Comparative Criminal Justice\nSystems 3 Course Prerequisite: CRM J 101.\nComparative study of criminal justice systems\nin the US and selected foreign countries.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CRM J 405, POL\nS 405). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n420 [M] Criminal Procedure 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. Principal court\ndecisions concerning standards of conduct\nand rights in the criminal process. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n424 Community Cor rections 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. Theory practice and\nhuman impact of treating criminal offenders\nin the community. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n426 Victimology and Public Policy 3\nExamination of victimization; policy responses\nto victims; victim’s rights.\n427 Crime Prevention Strategies 3 Personal,\nenvironmental, community-based and\ngovernment crime prevention strategies and\nissues.\n428 Drug and Alcohol Use and Abuse 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101. Drug use, impact on\nbehavior and drug control policies.\n450 [M] Senior Seminar: Ethical Issues in\nCriminal Justice 3 Course Prerequisite: CRM\nJ 101; senior standing. Examination of ethical\nissues in decision making in criminal justice.\n468 Addictive Behavior Among Diverse\nPopulations 3 Course Prerequisite: Junior\nstanding. Overview of social, cultural, and\nhistorical perspectives on dealing with\naddictive behavior. (Crosslisted course\noffered as PSYCH 468, CRM J 468, SOC 468).\nRecommended preparation: SOC 101, PSYCH\n105, or CRM J 101.\n480 [CAPS] [M] Senior Capstone in Criminal\nJustice and Criminology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 101; CRM J 311; CRM J\n321; senior standing. Experiential learning\nemphasizing refining skills and preparing\nstudents for the myriad of challenges awaiting\nthem in public safety.\n490 Criminal Justice Internship V 2-12 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 12\nhours. On/off-campus internship in criminal\njustice institutions (police, FBI, jails, law firms,\netc.); written assignments and readings will be\nrequired. Course Prerequisite: CRM J 101.\nIndependent study conducted under the\njurisdiction of an approving faculty member;\nmay include independent research studies in\ntechnical or specialized problems; selection\nand analysis of specified readings; development\nof a creative project; or field experiences. S, F\ngrading.\n505 C o m p a r a t i v e C r i m i n a l J u s t i c e 3\nComparative study of crime laws and criminal\njustice systems in selected foreign countries.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n510 Leadership in Criminal Justice 3 Study of\nleadership models and theories as they apply\nto criminal justice institutions.\n511 Criminal Justice Management 3 Examines\nthe theoretical framework for understanding\ncriminal justice organizations through\nexamining management theory, organizational\ndynamics, and administration research.\n512 Juvenile Justice 3 Examination of the major\ntheories and contemporary issues related\nto juvenile delinquency, the juvenile justice\nsystem, gangs, and juvenile corrections.\n513 Multicultural Issues in Criminal Justice\n3 Critical examination of race, gender, and\nother diversity and cultural issues within the\nU.S. criminal justice system.\n514 Professional Development in Criminal\nJustice and Criminology 1 Professional\naspects of research, teaching, and service\nactivities in criminal justice and criminology.\nS, F grading.\n520 Criminal Justice Research Methods 3\nThe design and execution of criminal justice\nresearch; critical examination of current\nresearch methods in criminal justice.\n\n144\nCriminal Justice and Criminology\nWashington State University, 2021\n521 Advanced Topics in Criminal Justice\nResearch Methods 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: CRM J 520. Exploration\nof specialized topics in research methodology;\ntopics may include qualitative methods, GIS,\nethnography, and survey design.\n522 Foundations of Quantitative Methods\n4 Application of foundational quantitative\nmethods utilized in the field of Criminal Justice\nand Criminology.\n523 Intermediate Quantitative Methods 4\nCourse Prerequisite: CRM J 522. Intermediate-\nlevel quantitative methods including logistic\nregression, factor analysis, propensity scoring\nand model building.\n524 Advanced Topics in Quantitative\nMethods 3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: CRM J 523. Advanced quantitative\nmethods used in criminal justice, including\ntime series, HLM, multi-level modeling, spatial\nanalysis, and repeated measures analysis.\n530 C r i m i n a l J u s t i c e : P r o c e s s a n d\nInstitutions 3 Processes of criminal justice\nin the context of the social, political, and\neconomic environments. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n531 Drugs, Alcohol, and Crime 3 Examination\nof the research and theory surrounding the\nrelationship between alcohol, drugs, crime,\nand the criminal justice system.\n540 Seminar in Evaluation Research 3\nInterrelationship of ideology, data, policy\ndevelopment, and policy implementation\nin public policy analysis. (Crosslisted course\noffered as CRM J 540, POL S 541). Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n541 Seminar in Corrections 3 Current issues\nrelated to the control, management, and\nsanctioning of criminal offenders. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n542 Community Corrections 3 Examines\ncorrectional processes in a community setting,\nincluding probation, parole, and innovative\ncommunity-based strategies for dealing with\nthe offender.\n555 Seminar in Criminological Theory\n3 Individual, situational and ecological\ncorrelates of criminal behavior; data sources\nand empirical research.\n560 Prosecution and Adjudication 3 The\nfunction of courts and the behavior of\nprosecutors, defense attorneys and judges\nwithin the criminal justice system.\n570 The Police and Society 3 Community and\nselected social institutional factors as related to\ntheir influence on police systems. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n572 Seminar in Comparative Policing 3 Study\nof the history, organization, and policies of\npolicing systems in selected countries and of\ntransnational policing. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n580 Gender and Justice 3 Criminal justice\nsystem’s treatment of women offenders,\nvictims, and professionals.\n591 Seminar in the Administration of\nCriminal Justice 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Current\nissues, problems, and critical concerns within\nthe field of administration of criminal justice.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n592 Proseminar in Administration, Justice,\nand Applied Policy Studies 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Same as POL S 542.\n594 S p e c i a l To p i c s i n C o m p a r a t i v e\nCriminology and Criminal Justice 3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Intensive study of specific topics in\ncomparative criminal justice or criminology.\n595 Advanced Topics in Criminal Justice\nInstitutions and Processes 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. In-depth study of issues associated with\ncriminal justice institutions and processes.\n596 Special Topics: Criminal Justice and\nPublic Health 3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 6 hours. Examination of\npublic health ramifications of criminal justice\npolicy and practice; public health approaches\nto violence and substance abuse prevention.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Crop and\nSoil Sciences\ncss.wsu.edu\nJohnson Hall 115\n509-335-3475\nProfessor and Department Chair, R. T. Koenig. CROP\nSCIENCE: Professors, I. C. Burke, K. S. Gill, S.\nHulbert, P. W. Jacoby, S. S. Jones, D. Lyon, M. M. Neff,\nW. F. Schillinger; Associate Professors, A. H. Carter,\nS. C. Fransen, K. M. Murphy, M. O. AGRICULTURE AND FOOD\nSYSTEMS: Professor, J. Goldberger; Assistant Professor,\nA. Warner; Senior Instructors, J. D. Baser, J. Durfey.\nADJUNCT and AFFILIATE FACULTY: R. Abi-Ghanem,\nB. Baik, H. Bolton, R. A. Boydston, R. Bricklemyer,\nC. Campbell, P. Castiglione, W. Chen, D. Cobos, D.\nCollins, H. Collins, C. Coyne, N. Embertson, A.M.\nFortuna, K. Garland-Campbell, R-A. Hernan Mauricio,\nJ. Hu, D. Huggins, M. Islam, D. Jarvis, R. C. Johnson,\nA. Kennedy, T. Kisha, J. Lafferty, X. Liu, R. McGee,\nP. N. Miklas, C. F. Morris, F. Muehlbauer, S. Norberg,\nC. D. Pannkuk, J. Payumo, C. Pierce, C. Qualset, C.\nReardon, S. Rustgi, M. Saglam, Z. Shi, G. K. Stahnke, C.\nSteber, J. D. Streubel, F. L. Young, L. Yu. PROFESSORS\nEMERITI: R. Allan, D. Bezdicek, J. Burns, C. G. Cogger,\nJ. R. Davenport, B. E. Frazier, S. O. Guy, J. B. Harsh,\nW. J. Johnston, A. Kleinhofs, S. Kuo, T. Lumpkin, T. W.\nMiller, F. Pierce, R. G. Stevens, M. K. Swan, S. E. Ullrich.\nThe Department of Crop and Soil Sciences supports\nundergraduate programs of study leading to the\nBachelor of Science interdisciplinary degrees in\nIntegrated Plant Sciences and Agricultural and Food\nSystems. Students are encouraged to participate as\npart-time employees in research programs and seek\nprofessional internships for experiential learning\nexperiences. Departmental and college scholarships\nare available based on ability, need, and interest.\nStudents gain professional and social contacts with\nthe faculty and other students through student\nclubs and other activities. Students planning to\ntransfer to Washington State University should take\ncourses that meet general university and Integrated\nPlant Sciences or Agricultural and Food Systems core\nrequirements.\nUndergraduate minors in Crop Science, Soil\nScience, Geospatial Analysis, and Agricultural\nand Food Systems, as well as an undergraduate\nCertificate in Organic Agriculture, are also available.\nWe offer graduate programs of study leading to the\ndegrees of Master of Science in Crop Science, Master\nof Science in Soil Science, Doctor of Philosophy\n(Crop Science), and Doctor of Philosophy (Soil\nScience). A graduate Certificate in Sustainable\nAgriculture is also available.\nINTEGRATED PLANT SCIENCES\nThe science of plant life from molecule to market\nis the focus of the new Integrated Plant Sciences\n(IPS) Degree program. Delivered collaboratively by\ndepartments within the College of Agricultural,\nHuman, and Natural Resource Sciences, the IPS\n\n145\nCrop and Soil Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\ndegree provides students with an exciting depth\nand breadth of knowledge that crosses a variety of\nplant science disciplines, including crop and soil\nsciences, horticulture and landscape architecture,\nentomology, plant pathology, and food science.\nStudents pursuing a Bachelor of Science degree\nin Integrated Plant Sciences may choose among\nseven majors. Information regarding the IPS majors,\nincluding student learning outcomes, is available\nunder the Integrated Plant Sciences catalog section\nand http://ips.wsu.edu.\nAgricultural Biotechnology\nThe Agricultural Biotechnology major in IPS is\na designed for students interested in careers that\ninclude laboratory or research technicians in plant\nbiotechnology, breeding, genetics, entomology,\nplant pathology, molecular biology, and physiology,\nas well as for students preparing for advanced\ndegrees in these areas. The program emphasizes the\ndevelopment and application of new technology\nto ensure a safe and abundant food and fiber\nsupply. Students may find employment in industry,\ngovernment, or university laboratories.\nField Crop Management\nThe Field Crop Management major in IPS is\nideal for students interested in agronomy, crop\nproduction, and plant, soil, and pest management.\nCrop scientists (or agronomists) are involved\nin improving food, feed, and fiber production.\nGraduates qualify for careers in agribusiness,\ncorporate and technical farm management,\nprofessional consulting, research, and sales\npositions.\nTurfgrass Management\nThe Turfgrass Management major in IPS is geared\ntoward students interested in pursuing careers as\ngolf course managers, athletic field managers, or\npersonnel managers in those venues. Students will\ntake courses in turf management, turf production,\nplant pathology, entomology, soil fertility, and\nplant breeding to learn how to maintain healthy\nturfgrass systems. Additionally, students gain hands-\non experience at the Palouse Ridge Golf Course,\nan 18-hole championship golfing facility at the\nPullman campus.\nAGRICULTURAL FOOD SYSTEMS\nThe Agricultural and Food Systems (AFS) program\nis an exciting, college-wide, interdisciplinary\nprogram that offers a Bachelor of Science degree\nwith five majors and a Master of Science degree.\nInformation regarding the AFS majors, including\nstudent learning outcomes, is available in the\nAgricultural and Food Systems catalog section\nand http://afs.wsu.edu.\nAgricultural Education\nCombining the best of both agriculture and\nteaching, the Agricultural Education major in AFS\nprepares students to educate the next generation of\nagricultural leaders and consumers. Highly sought\nafter by employers, they teach high school and\nmiddle school agricultural science classes, as well\nas serve as FFA advisors, adult education instructors,\ncommunity outreach coordinators, university\nextension agents, and agricultural industry\nrepresentatives.\nAgricultural Technology and Production\nManagement\nStudents in the Agricultural Technology and\nProduction Management hands-on major in AFS\ngain a science-based overview of agriculture and\nfood systems, with an emphasis on the practical\napplication of technology to agricultural production\nsystems. The program combines students’ inherent\ncreativity and interest in physical and biological\nsciences, technology, mathematics, business,\nand related subjects with their desire to develop\ninnovative solutions to a variety of agricultural\nproblems.\nOrganic and Sustainable Agriculture\nSignificantly different than conventional\nagriculture, organic food production is one of\nthe fastest growing segments of agriculture, with\nretail sales generally increasing by 10 to 20 percent\nannually since 1991. Washington State has been\na leader in this burgeoning new industry. This\nrevolutionary new major is the first of its kind to\nbe offered in the United States. Students in the\nOrganic and Sustainable Agriculture major in\nAFS take a diverse array of courses in the natural,\nenvironmental, economic, and social sciences, as\nwell as a number of courses focused on organic\nproduction practices.\nPREPARATION FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS\nIN CROP AND SOIL SCIENCES\nPreparation for graduate study requires the\nselection of courses that will benefit later work\ntoward a Master of Science or a Doctor of\nPhilosophy degree. Normally, preparation for an\nadvanced degree in crop science includes course\nwork with a strong emphasis in plant sciences,\nbiochemistry, computer science, genetics, and\nstatistics. Preparation for an advanced degree in soil\nscience includes course work in chemistry, physical\nsciences, statistics, and soil science.\nMinors\nCrop Science\nA minor in crop science may be obtained by students\nfrom this and other departments. A minimum of 16\ncredit hours for the minor must include 9 hours\nof upper-division work taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses. See crop science\nadvisor.\nGeospatial Analysis\nThe minor requires a minimum of 16 semester\ncredits including the following core: SOIL SCI 368,\n374, and SOIL SCI 468/568; and 6 credits from the\nfollowing: AGTM 305, 405, CPT S 111, MIS 250,\nSOE 446, 464, with a minimum GPA of at least 2.0 in\nthe required courses. Exceptional students may take\ngraduate-level courses with instructor permission.\nCourses used for the minor in geospatial analysis\nmay not be used for the minor in soils sciences.\nAt least 9 hours must be 300-400-level work taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nSoil Science\nA minor in soil science may be obtained by students\nfrom this and other departments. Sixteen credits in\nsoil science are required, at least 9 of which must\nbe in 300-400-level courses taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. SOIL SCI 201\nis required. One credit of Soil Science-related\nexperiential learning (SOIL SCI 495, 498, or 499)\nis required. See soil science advisor for other soil\nscience options.\nDescription of Courses\nCROP SCIENCE\nCROP SCI\n102 Introduction to Cultivated Plants 3\nExploring cultivated plant classification\nand morphology, crop reproduction, basic\nplant processes, and the biotic and abiotic\nfactors which can influence these processes.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HORT 102, CROP\nSCI 102).\n202 Crop Growth and Development 4 (3-\n3) Course Prerequisite: HORT/ CROP SCI\n102. Morphology, anatomy, growth and\ndevelopment of agronomic and horticultural\ncrops. (Crosslisted course offered as HORT 202,\nCROP SCI 202).\n301 Turfgrass Management 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 102, 106, 107, or 120.\nPrinciples of establishment and management\nof turf for lawns, parks, and golf courses. Field\ntrip required. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n302 Forage Crops 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nBIOLOGY 102, 106, 107, 120, or 135.\nAdaptation, production, and utilization of\nforage crops. Field trip required.\n305 Ecology and Management of Weeds 3\n(2-3) Course Prerequisite: HORT 202 or AFS\n201. Weed ecology/management in crop and\nnon-crop systems; weed growth/development,\nidentification, weed control (chemical,\nmechanical, biological), and environmental\nissues\n350 International Agricultural Extension\n3 Course Prerequisite: AFS 101; sophomore\nstanding. Understanding of agricultural\nextension systems globally through online\ninternational collaborative project.\n360 World Agricultural Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 3 units of [B] or [BSCI] GER\nor UCORE categories. Study of agro-\nenvironmental characteristics of world\nagriculture; historical and contemporary\nfeatures of world food production. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CROP SCI 360, SOIL SCI\n360). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n401 [M] Turfgrass Science 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCROP SCI 301. Integration of the principles\nof turfgrass science into turf management\nfor environmental stewardship of turfgrass\nsystems. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n\n146\nCrop and Soil Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n403 Advanced Cropping Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: HORT 202. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n416 Soil Processes in the Earth’s Critical Zone\n3 Soil geochemistry and processes; theory and\napplications with a focus on reactions at the\nsolid, liquid, and gaseous interface between\nthe lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere,\nand biosphere. (Crosslisted course offered as\nSOE 416/516, SOIL SCI 416/516). Credit not\ngranted for both SOE/SOIL SCI 416 and SOE/\nSOIL SCI 516. Laboratory exercises and\nmethodology for characterization of soil\nfertility and chemistry including CEC,\nacidity, carbon, nitrogen, and plant nutrients.\nRecommended preparation: CHEM 220.\n443 [M] Soil Management for Sustainable\nand Organic Farming Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SOIL SCI 201.
