Recommended preparation:\nIntroductory biology, physics, and calculus.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n515 Environmental Biophysics Laboratory\n1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: SOIL SCI 514\nor concurrent enrollment. Experimental\nmethods and procedures in environmental\nmeasurements; temperature, wind, radiation,\nand humidity measurements in biological\nenvironments. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n516 Soil Processes in the Earth’s Critical Zone\n3 Soil geochemistry and processes; theory and\napplications with a focus on reactions at the\nsolid, liquid, and gaseous interface between\nthe lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere,\nand biosphere. (Crosslisted course offered as\nSOE 416/516, SOIL SCI 416/516). Credit not\ngranted for both SOE/SOIL SCI 416 and SOE/\nSOIL SCI 516. Recommended preparation:\nBasic knowledge of soils (e.g. SOIL SCI 201 or\nequivalent; CHEM 106; PHYSICS 102).\n521 Physical Chemistry of Soils 3 Chemical\nequilibrium and kinetics of soil solution\nspeciation, mineral precipitation and\ndissolution, adsorption and partitioning\nreactions, and ion exchange. Soil constituents;\nsoil solutions: mineral equilibria; absorption\nreactions; acid/base reactions; oxidation-\nreduction; soil contaminants. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n\n148\nCrop and Soil Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n531 Soil Microbiology 3 (2-3) Biology and\nsignificance of organisms inhabiting soil\nand their role in nutrient cycling, ecosystem\nfunction, agriculture, and bioremediation.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n533 Advanced Vadose Processes 2 Methods\nand models for water, heat, vapor and\nsolute transport in the vadose zone; transfer\nfunctions to describe solute transport;\nnon-linear parameter estimation; fate and\ntransport of water, heat, and solutes in the\nvadose zone; hydrological and geochemical\nprocesses in unsaturated subsurface materials.\nRecommended preparation: upper division or\ngraduate course in soil physics or chemistry.\n541 Soil-Plant-Microbial Interactions 3\nSoil-plant-microbial relationships to plant\nnutrition, plant health, and environmental\ncleanup; rhizosphere chemistry and microbial\necology. Required preparation must include\ntwo upper-division courses in biology,\nmicrobiology or soils.\n544 Nitrogen Cycling in the Earth’s Systems\n3 Nitrogen dynamics in terrestrial, aquatic, and\natmospheric systems; nitrogen transformations\nin natural and managed systems and responses\nto human activities. (Crosslisted course offered\nas BIOLOGY 544, SOIL SCI 544).\n547 Soil Fertility Management 3 Philosophy\nof fertilizer recommendations based on soil\nand plant tissue testing; principles of fertilizer\nmanufacture, placement and use. Required\npreparation must include introductory soils\nand upper-division soil fertility courses.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n568 GIS Spatial Analysis 4 (2-6) Geographic\ninformation systems applied to analysis of\nlandscape data; maps, geographic coordinate\nsystems and projections, geodatabases. Credit\nnot granted for both SOIL SCI 468 and 568.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 702 credit. S, U\ngrading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe Soil Science PhD program. Independent\nresearch and advanced study for students\nworking on their doctoral research, dissertation\nand/or final examination. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nProgram in Data Analytics\ndata-analytics.wsu.edu\nMorrill Hall 108\n509-335-3736\nDirector and Professor, N. Dasgupta (Pullman).\nData analytics is the application of powerful\nnew methods—drawn from computer science,\nmathematics and statistics, and domain sciences—to\ncollect, curate, analyze, discover and communicate\nknowledge from “big data.”\nThere has been an explosion of demand for\nskilled data analysts who can communicate, solve\nproblems, and work effectively in teams. Data\nanalytics tools and techniques are used by many\ndifferent industries to create, manage, explore, and\nanalyze large, complex datasets in order to evaluate\npast performance, predict future trends, and make\nbetter decisions.\nOur students are trained in advanced statistical,\ndata, and computer science skills as well as\nconcentrated domain knowledge. This combination\nenables WSU graduates to effectively work in teams\nand easily communicate with colleagues and\nmanagers to solve problems.\nThe nine specialization tracks are curricular\npartnerships between the College of Arts and\nSciences and the Voiland College of Engineering and\nArchitecture, Carson College of Business, College of\nEducation, and the College of Agriculture, Human,\nand Natural Resource Sciences.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n• Demonstrate competency in data literacy—\ndynamic, structured, unstructured, numerical, and\ntext data.\n• Demonstrate competency with quantitative\nreasoning to make decisions in a logical,\nmathematical manner.\n• Demonstrate competency with data wrangling\nand exploratory data analysis.\n• Demonstrate and articulate an understanding of\ndomain literacy and nuances of data.\n• Utilize an interdisciplinary perspective in order\nto understand the elements of data analytics.\n• Effectively communicate through writing and\nspeech the story of the data from start to finish.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nDATA ANALYTICS\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents are admitted to the Data Analytics major\nupon completion of 24 semester credits with a 2.0\ncumulative GPA.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 121 or 131 4\nDATA Data Visualization: DTC 101, DTC 201,\nFour of the following – DTC 335, DTC 336, DTC\n354, DTC 355 [M], DTC 435, DTC 477, DTC 478.\nEconomics: ECONS 101, ECONS 102, ECONS 301,\nECONS 302; Choose three from: ECONS 311 [M],\nECONS 321, ECONS 323, ECONS 324 [M], ECONS\n327, ECONS 424, ECONS 425, ECONS 426, ECONS\n451, ECONS, 452 [M], ECONS 490 [M], STAT 443.\nLife Sciences: BIOL 106, BIOL 107, CHEM 101 or\nCHEM 105, CHEM 102 or CHEM 106, BIOL 301.\nChoose one 300-400 level elective course. Choose three from: PSYCH 105, SOC\n430, PSYCH 333, ED PSYCH 400, ED PSYCH 404,\nPOLS 416, PHIL 350.\nDescription of Courses\nData Analytics\nDATA\n115 Introduction to Data Analytics 3 Basic\nconcepts, principles, and tools used in data\nanalytics.\n204 Introduction to Text Analysis 3\nI n t r o d u c t i o n t o c o m p u t a t i o n a l a n d\nstatistical text analysis using the open source\nprogramming language R; designed for students\nwith no prior experience with programming but\nwho wish to extend their methodological tool\nkit to include quantitative and computational\napproaches to the study of text. S,\nF grading.\nSchool of Design and\nConstruction\nsdc.wsu.edu\nCarpenter Hall 118\n509-335-5539\nDirector and Professor, R. E. Smith; Professors, P. Hirzel,\nJ. Kaytes, G. Kessler, T. Miyasaka; Associate Professors,\nJ. Abell, J. Day, J. P. Gruen, R. Krikac, M. Melcher,\nA. Rahmani, J. Theodorson; Assistant Professors, O.\nAl-Hassawi, S. Call, M. Ghandi, K. Kraszewska, A.\nPulay, K. Shrestha, T. Tafazzoli, V. Vahdat; Scholarly\nAssociate Professors, S. Austin, R. Cherf, J. Peschel, C.\nVielle; Scholarly Assistant Professors, D. Drake, M.\nSánchez.\nThe School of Design and Construction (SDC) offers\ncollaborative learning experiences for students in\narchitecture, interior design, landscape architecture,\nconstruction management, and construction\nengineering to design and construct places in\nour environment. The integrated model teaches\nstudents the skill sets required for their chosen\ndesign major while giving students a substantial\nadvantage when entering the job market.\nPrograms of study in the SDC lead to the following\ndegrees: a Bachelor of Science in Architectural\nStudies (a four-year pre-professional degree) followed\nby a one-, two-, or three-year professional Master\nof Architecture degree that is accredited by the\nNational Architectural Accreditation Board (NAAB);\na Bachelor of Arts in Interior Design accredited by\nthe Council for Interior Design Accreditation (CIDA)\nand a Master of Arts in Interior Design ; a Bachelor of\nLandscape Architecture accredited by the Landscape\nArchitecture Accreditation Board (LAAB) ; and a\nBachelor of Science in Construction Management (a\nfour-year degree) that is accredited by the American\nCouncil for Construction Education (ACCE), and a\nBachelor of Science in Construction Engineering in\nconjunction with Civil Engineering.\nIt is crucial that students in the design and\nconstruction professions learn about a range of\nbuilt environments, places, ideas, cultures, and\nexperiences that are not readily available in the\nPalouse—and difficult to teach in the classroom.\nWhen possible, travel experiences are incorporated\nthrough courses labeled as “study tours” where\ntravel is integral to the course, woven throughout\nother courses in the curriculum, and included as\nprofessional development activities.\nStudy abroad may be incorporated into the\nfourth year of study or during the summer. Foreign\nstudies options include WSU sponsored programs,\nand programs offered by other institutions.\nCoordination is through the Office of International\nPrograms—Global Learning.\nStudents in the SDC also participate in a\nsenior portfolio review and/or capstone project\npresentation prior to graduation. These experiences\nare unique networking opportunities for graduating\nstudents to interact with design and construction\nprofessionals, and to receive feedback on their\nexisting portfolios or projects.\nA variety of student clubs and organizations\nprovide students with linkages to their professional\ncounterparts. Student organizations with chapters\nat the SDC include the American Institute of\nArchitecture Students (AIAS); Alpha Rho Chi;\nAmerican Society of Interior Designers (ASID);\nAmerican Society of Landscape Architects (ASLA);\nAssociated Students of Construction Management\n(ASCM); Associated General Contractors of America\n(AGC); the Design Build Institute of America (DBIA);\nand Mechanical Contractors Association of America\n(MCAA).\nARCHITECTURE\nThe four-year, pre-professional Bachelor of Science\nin Architectural Studies degree at WSU provides a\nthorough foundation in the field of architecture\nas preparation for continued education in a\nprofessional degree program; employment in the\narchitecture profession with a licensed architect;\nand employment options in fields related to\narchitecture.\nThe Master of Architecture (M.Arch.) degree\nis the professional degree accredited by the\nNational Architectural Accrediting Board (NAAB).\nCompletion of this degree allows students to\ntake state exams and become licensed architects.\nStudents must successfully complete a four-year\nundergraduate degree in architecture or a previous\nfive-year Bachelor of Architecture degree to be\neligible for the one- or two-year M.Arch. program.\nStudents with baccalaureate degrees in disciplines\nother than architecture are eligible to apply for the\nthree-year M.Arch. program. Please consult the WSU\nGraduate Catalog and/or http://sdc.wsu.edu/ for\nspecific information regarding this degree, as well\nas admission requirements and course descriptions.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nStudents graduating in architecture are able to: 1)\nunderstand the role of architecture within current\ncultural and global conditions, 2) understand\nthe role of architecture in the enhancement and\n\n150\nDesign and Construction\nWashington State University, 2021\npreservation of natural resources, 3) understand\nthe role of history and its transformations over\ntime, 4) develop a desire and passion for life-long\nlearning, and 5) develop intellectual and analytical\nskills that will be the foundation for future leaders.\nIt is the intent of the program to graduate future\nprofessionals who are committed to excellence in\nthe built environment through the incorporation\nof intellectual, analytical, and artful aspects of\narchitecture. Within this context, students and\nfaculty seek to investigate issues within diverse\ncontexts in order to creatively advance the built\nenvironment.\nTransfer Students\nStudents planning to transfer into the\narchitecture program at Washington State University\nshould contact an advisor for more information.\nCONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT\nThe management of construction projects has\nbecome more complex due to the shortage of\nresources, specialized materials, sophisticated\ndelivery methods and the financial and legal\nresponsibilities encountered during the project life\ncycle. From construction management to project\nmanagement and program management, the\nneeds of the industry and the built environment\nare expanding at an unprecedented rate. At the\nheart of the building process is the construction\nprofessional.\nThe WSU Construction Management (CM)\nprogram provides students with the tools and\nskills necessary to develop strong administrative,\nleadership and management expertise to be\nsuccessful in today’s construction industry. Students\npursuing a degree in construction management will\nbe expected to understand a wide variety of topics\nthat make up the built environment. This expertise\nincludes understanding properties of materials and\nconstruction systems required for the construction\nprofessional. Concepts regarding contract\nadministration, sustainability, risk management,\nestimating and scheduling are critical skills.\nStudents in this program are encouraged to\ndevelop an inquisitive and inventive mind to\nunderstand management techniques, methods, and\nsequencing. It is also important that the graduate\nin construction management be knowledgeable\nin the field of business. Courses offered in a\nvariety of departments are required to assure\nthis breadth of understanding. The Bachelor of\nScience in Construction Management degree\nprogram is accredited by the American Council for\nConstruction Education (ACCE).\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe mission of WSU-CM is to educate, prepare\nand provide opportunities for students to\nbecome valuable resources to our economy, the\nconstruction management profession, and the built\nenvironment. ACCE requirements establish twenty\n(20) pre-defined student learning outcomes that\nare comprehensive in nature. These measurable\noutcomes are introduced, reinforced, and assessed\nthroughout the CM curriculum in an effort to\nensure students are entering the construction\nindustry with appropriate foundational knowledge\nand requisite skills to be work ready, day one. Upon\ngraduating from an accredited ACCE bachelor’s\ndegree program, a graduate shall be able to:\n• Create written communications appropriate to\nthe construction discipline.\n• Create oral presentations appropriate to the\nconstruction discipline.\n• Create a construction project safety plan.\n• Create construction project cost estimates.\n• Create construction project schedules.\n• Analyze professional decisions based on ethical\nprinciples.\n• Analyze construction documents for planning\nand management of construction processes.\n• Analyze methods, materials, and equipment used\nto construct projects.\n• Apply construction management skills as a\nmember of a multidisciplinary team.\n• Apply electronic-based technology to manage\nthe construction process.\n• Apply basic surveying techniques for construction\nlayout and control.\n• Understand different methods of project delivery\nand the roles and responsibilities of all constituencies\ninvolved in the design and construction process.\n• Understand construction risk management.\n• Understand construction accounting and cost\ncontrol.\n• Understand construction quality assurance and\ncontrol.\n• Understand construction project control\nprocesses.\n• Understand the legal implications of contract,\ncommon, and regulatory law to manage a\nconstruction project.\n• Understand the basic principles of sustainable\nconstruction.\n• Understand the basic principles of structural\nbehavior.\n• Understand the basic principles of mechanical,\nelectrical and piping systems.\nTransfer Students\nStudents planning to transfer into the construction\nmanagement program at Washington State\nUniversity should contact an advisor for more\ninformation.\nINTERIOR DESIGN\nAccredited by the Council for Interior Design\nAccreditation (CIDA), the Bachelor of Arts in\nInterior Design is a professional degree program\nthat provides the common body of knowledge\nrelated to interior design as recognized by CIDA.\nThe interior design program is based on a concern\nfor human beings and the creation of interior\nsettings that support human activities and values.\nThe curriculum is structured to create unique\nlearning experiences each semester. Studios focus\non a multitude of design theories rooted in a variety\nof relevant disciplines. Lecture course content is\nintegrated into the studio experience to reinforce\nspecified skills and knowledge. With increasing\nchallenge and complexity, multidisciplinary\nexposure and experiences continue throughout\nthe curriculum to inform design solutions as\nwell as prepare students to work with a myriad of\nprofessionals upon graduation.\nProfessional/Global Experience\nThe WSU Interior Design program values\nexperiential learning as an important component\nof a student’s education. In addition to travel\nexperiences throughout the curriculum, all fourth-\nyear students must present their portfolio of creative\nwork at an off-campus review to graduate.\nIn the fall semester of the fourth year, students\nwill participate in a professional and/or global\nexperience, choosing one of the following options:\n• Option 1: Internship—students can choose to\ncomplete a 5-credit internship and are encouraged\nto seek opportunities beyond the region.\n• Option 2: Study Abroad—students can choose\nto participate in the department’s study abroad\nprogram providing them an opportunity to\nexperience design within the context of another\nculture.\n• Option 3: Community Studio—students can\nwork with faculty on community-based projects.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nA graduate of the interior design program is a\ncreative thinker and problem solver. An education in\ninterior design develops intellectual curiosity, which\nsupports continued professional development\nthroughout life. Students develop skills that allow\nthem to analyze information, evaluate issues, and set\npriorities while generating creative design solutions\nfor projects of a complex scale. As graduates of\nWSU’s Interior Design program, students can take\nthe initiative, make critical judgments of their own\ndesigns, as well as others, and operate within a team\ncontext; all of which contributes to their future\nsuccess as professionals.\nTransfer Students\nStudents wishing to transfer from another\ninstitution into the interior design program should\ncontact an advisor for more information.\nGraduate Studies\nThe Master of Arts in Interior Design (MA)\nprogram increases students’ understanding of the\nrelationship between human behavior and interior\nenvironments through advanced study and hands-\non research. Students gain knowledge and skills\nthat prepare them to analyze information and\nrelationships, evaluate issues, and set priorities,\nwhile creating functional and high-quality design\nsolutions for complex projects. The degree is offered\nin three tracks depending on prior academic and\nprofessional background. Please consult the WSU\nGraduate catalog and/or http://sdc.wsu.edu for\nspecific information regarding this degree, as well\nas admission requirements and course descriptions.\nLANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE\nLandscape architecture involves designing and\nimplementing opportunities for people to engage\nwith their environment. It is an interdisciplinary\nfield dedicated to crafting meaningful places across\ndiverse scales and contexts.\nThe Bachelor of Landscape Architecture (BLA) is a\nprofessional degree program that prepares students\nto enter and advance the diverse profession of\nlandscape architecture, address complex societal\nissues, and envision solutions that optimize the\nphysical environments where people work, live,\nand recreate.\nThe BLA curriculum is structured to create unique\nlearning experiences each semester. Broadly\nspeaking, the curriculum emphasizes practical\nand applied experiential learning, draws from\ncourses across campus, and provides students\nwith opportunities to think critically and integrate\n\n151\nDesign and Construction\nWashington State University, 2021\ndiverse bodies of knowledge. The professional\ncourse of study is divided into two segments: pre-\nlandscape architecture and the second – fourth year\nprofessional landscape architecture program (BLA).\nCompletion of the program leads to the degree of\nBachelor of Landscape Architecture and allows\nthe graduate to enter the profession. At least three\nadditional years of professional experience and\nsuccessful completion of the landscape architectural\nlicense examination (LARE) are necessary for\nregistration as a licensed landscape architect in\nmost states.\nThe core component of the landscape architecture\ncurriculum is the studio experience. The studios are\nstructured to facilitate understanding of the web\nof relationships among physical, biological, and\nsocial systems. Through the studio curriculum\nstudents learn habits of linking ecological processes\nwith space making and necessarily consider\ninterdependence, reciprocity, and change.\nFirst year projects focus on the basic elements\nand principles of design and design process. The\nsecond year emphasizes the concept of site and the\nmethods for and consequences of manipulating\nthe ground and vegetation. Coursework includes\nsite design, site engineering, plant materials, and\ndesign history. The third year reinforces and extends\nstudents’ understanding of the field of landscape\narchitecture and emphasizes integration of theory,\npractice, and construction. Studios focus on design\nfor communities in the broadest sense. In the fourth\nyear, coursework emphasizes design in the context\nof landscape complexity, systems thinking, and\nthe overlap of global and local issues. Students\ndevelop and execute independent projects. In the\nprojects they are encouraged to think of design\nas an answer to a question and regard their work\nas an opportunity to develop, test, and challenge\nwhat they have learned in the first three years of\ntheir design education. Computer visualization and\nfreehand drawing skills are threaded throughout\nthe curriculum.\nIn addition to travel experiences throughout the\ncurriculum, all fourth-year students must present\ntheir capstone project and a portfolio of creative\nwork at an off-campus review to graduate.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe program has identified four themes that include\n12 critical student learning outcomes (SLO) essential\nfor students to achieve the LA program goals. The\noutcomes are multifaceted and interrelated.\nTheme One: Define and refine design\nproblems and questions\nUpon successful completion of the BLA at WSU,\nstudents will be able to\n• Identify and characterize the complex nature of\nproblems and questions associated with human/\nlandscape interactions across a broad range of scales\n• Articulate an understanding of identified\nproblems and questions within the theoretical and\nhistorical context of the profession of landscape\narchitecture\nTheme Two: Discover and determine\nappropriate design processes\nUpon successful completion of the BLA at WSU,\nstudents will be able to\n• Identify appropriate methods of design inquiry\nand problem solving processes to produce creative\nsolutions to identified problems and questions\n• Identify, collect, and analyze necessary\ninformation using appropriate technologies and\nanalytical techniques as they relate to the identified\nproblem or question.\n• Explore and critically analyze alternative design\nor planning solutions to the identified problem or\nquestion\n• Engage in assessment and evaluation practices\nthroughout the entire design process\nTheme Three: Explore and develop\ncommunication skills\nUpon successful completion of the BLA at WSU,\nstudents will be able to\n• Justify and defend the proposed design or\nplanning solution within the context of aesthetic,\nsocial, political, economic, and environmental\nconditions.\n• Communicate the entire problem solving process\nor method of inquiry in written, oral, and graphic\nways using appropriate media\nTheme Four: Cultivate awareness of\nprofessional practices\nUpon successful completion of the BLA at WSU,\nstudents will be able to\n• Understand multiple aspects of practice\n• Show a capacity for collaboration\n• Integrate and apply diverse perspectives to design\nsolutions\n• Possess knowledge and understanding about\nallied fields and the value of interdisciplinary design\nTransfer Students\nTransfer students who have completed the\nequivalent of the pre-LA curriculum may apply to\nthe professional program by submitting a portfolio\nand academic transcripts. Contact the landscape\narchitecture program for more information.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBACHELOR OF SCIENCE IN\nARCHITECTURAL STUDIES\n(120 HOURS)\nArchitectural Studies (ARCH) is a four-year program\nstructured into one year of pre-professional\ncoursework and three years of major (professional)\ncoursework. Professional program courses begin in\nsecond year fall. Due to the sequential nature of\ncourses there are no spring admits.\nTo be considered for admission into the ARCH\nprogram, a student must have completed the\nfollowing pre-professional coursework (or their\napproved equivalents): COM 102 [COMM],\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG], FINE ART 101, 201, or 202\n[ARTS], HIST 105 [ROOT], PSYCH 105 or SOC 101\n[SSCI], and SDC 100, 120, 140, each with a grade\nof C or better and an overall GPA of 3.3 or higher.\nStudents not meeting the admission to major\ncriteria above will be considered until enrollment\nlimits are reached. Average enrollment limit into\nthe second year of the architecture major are 45\nstudents. Greater emphasis is given to performance\nin SDC 100, 120, and 140. Completion of all\npre-professional coursework does not guarantee\nacceptance into the professional program. Students\nare encouraged to work with SDC advisors to\nidentify an alternate major should they not be\nadmitted to their primary choice of major.\nTransfer Students\nA limited number of transfer students are\nconsidered each year. Requirements include\ncompletion of the pre-professional courses (or\napproved equivalents). Emphasis is given to\ncumulative GPA. A design portfolio may be\nrequested for additional evaluation.\nSchedule of Studies\nThe plan below is a suggested path to completion\nof the architectural studies degree. Students will\nmeet with an advisor each semester to confirm\nacademic schedule and monitor progress towards\ngraduation.\nStudents are required to earn a grade of C or better\nin all major courses required for the degree (ARCH\n201, 203, 209, 210, 215, 301, 303, 309, 351, 352,\n401, 403, 451; CST M 201, 202, 332, 333; SDC 100,\n120, 140, 250, 300, 350).\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCOM 102 [COMM] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN]\n12 \n3\nSDC 100 [ARTS] 3\nSDC 120 3\nSecond Term Hours\nFINE ART 101, 201, or 202 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPHYSICS 101 [PSCI] \n2 \n3\nPHYSICS 111 [PSCI] 1\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] or SOC 101[SSCI] 3\nSDC 140 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nARCH 201 5\nARCH 210 3\nCST M 201 3\nSDC 250 3\nSDC 300 1\nSecond Term Hours\nARCH 203 5\nARCH 209 3\nARCH 215 3\nCST M 202 3\nSDC 350 [M] 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nARCH 301 5\nARCH 309 [M] 3\nARCH 351 3\nARCH 451 3\nCST M 332 3\n\n152\nDesign and Construction\nWashington State University, 2021\nSecond Term Hours\nARCH 303 5\nARCH 352 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] 4\nCST M 333 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nARCH 401 6\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nSupportive Electives\n3 \n4\nSecond Term Hours\nARCH 403 [CAPS] 6\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSupportive Electives\n3 \n3\n_______\n1 \nAll first-year students must take the math\nplacement exam. Completion of MATH 108 with\na grade of C or better, a minimum ALEKS math\nplacement score of 75%, or passing MATH 140,\n171, or 202 is required for PHYSICS 101 [PSCI].\nMATH 108 does not fulfill the University [QUAN]\nrequirement for graduation.\n2 \nMath and Physics are not required for admission\nto the major (professional program, beginning in\nsecond year); however, Math and Physics are course\nprerequisites for ARCH 351/352 and CST M 332/333\nin the third year.\n3 \nSupportive Electives: At least 7 credits of any\n300-400-level courses from ARCH, CST M, DESIGN,\nI D, LND ARCH, SDC, or other courses approved in\nconsultation with ARCH Program Head not used to\nfulfill major requirements.\nCONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT PROGRAM\n(120 HOURS)\nConstruction Management (CM) is a four-year\nprogram structured into one year of pre-professional\ncoursework and three years of major (professional)\ncoursework. Professional program courses begin in\nsecond year fall. Due to the sequential nature of\ncourses there are no spring admits.\nTo be considered for admission into the CM\nprogram, a student must have completed at least\n31 semester hours of pre-professional coursework\nincluding the following courses (or their approved\nequivalents): CST M 102, Communication [COMM],\nECONS 101 and 102 [SSCI], ENGLISH 101 [WRTG],\nSOE 101 [PSCI], HISTORY 105 [ROOT], Humanities\n[HUM] or Diversity [DIVR], MATH 171 [QUAN], and\nSDC 100 [ARTS], each with a grade of C or better and\nan overall GPA of 3.3 or higher.\nStudents not meeting the admission to major\ncriteria above will be considered until enrollment\nlimits are reached. Average enrollment limit into the\nsecond year of the construction management major\nis 50 students. Completion of all pre-professional\ncoursework does not guarantee acceptance into\nthe professional program. Students are encouraged\nto work with SDC advisors to identify an alternate\nmajor should they not be admitted to their primary\nchoice of major.\nTransfer Students\nA limited number of transfer students are\nconsidered each year. Requirements include\ncompletion of the pre-professional courses (or\napproved equivalents). Emphasis is given to\ncumulative GPA.\nSchedule of Studies\nThe plan below is a suggested path to completion\nof the construction management degree. Students\nwill meet with an advisor each semester to confirm\nacademic schedule and monitor progress towards\ngraduation.\nStudents are required to earn a grade of C or better\nin all major courses required for the degree (CST M\n102, 201, 202, 222, 252, 254, 332, 333, 356, 362,\n368, 370, 371, 451, 460, 462, 473, 475, 483; ARCH\n351, 352, 463)\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nPre-Professional Program (1st Year)\nCommunication [COMM] 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSDC 100 [ARTS] 3\nSOE 101 [PSCI] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCST M 102\n1 \n2\nDiversity [DIVR] or Humanities [HUM]\n2 \n3\nECONS 102 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nProfessional Program (2nd - 4th Years)\nARCH 351 3\nCST M 222 2\nCST M 201 3\nCST M 254 2\nPHYSICS 101 OR 201 3\nPHYSICS 111 OR 211 1\nSecond Term Hours\nACCTG 230 3\nARCH 352 3\nB LAW 210 3\nCST M 202 3\nCST M 252 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nC E 302 2\nCST M 332 3\nCST M 362 [M] 3\nCST M 370 3\nCST M 451 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCST M 333 3\nCST M 356 3\nCST M 368 3\nCST M 371 3\nCST M 483 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nARCH 463 3\nCST M 460 3\nCST M 462 3\nMGMT 301 3\n300-400-level CST M Elective 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] 3\nCST M 473 3\nCST M 475 [CAPS] [M] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] or Humanities [HUM]\n2 \n3\n300-400-level Business Elective\n3 \n3\nComplete Senior Exit Survey\n_______\n1 \nTransfer students from community colleges or\ninstitutions outside WSU may test out of CST M\n102 via an application from the School of Design\nand Construction.\n2 \nUniversity Requirements include 3 credits of\n[HUM] and 3 credits of [DIVR].\n3 \nBusiness Elective: Any 300-400-level ACCTG, B\nLAW, ECONS, ENTRP, FIN, HBM, I BUS, MGMT,\nMGTOP, MIS, or MKTG course. Another course\nmay be approved in consultation with Construction\nManagement Program Head.\nINTERIOR DESIGN\n(120 HOURS)\nInterior Design (ID) is a four-year program structured\ninto one year of pre-professional coursework and\nthree years of major (professional) coursework.\nProfessional program courses begin in second year\nfall. Due to the sequential nature of courses there\nare no spring admits. To be considered for admission\ninto the ID program, a student must have completed\nthe following pre-professional coursework (or their\napproved equivalents):\nCOM 102 [COMM], ENGLISH 101 [WRTG], FINE\nART 101, 201, or 202 [ARTS], HISTORY 105 [ROOT],\nPSYCH 105 or SOC 101 [SSCI], and SDC 100, 120,\n140, each with a grade of C or better and an overall\nGPA of 3.3 or higher.\nStudents not meeting the admission to major\ncriteria above will be considered until enrollment\nlimits are reached. Average enrollment limits\ninto the second year of the interior design major\nare 25-30 students. Greater emphasis is given to\nperformance in SDC 100, 120, and 140. Completion\nof all pre-professional coursework does not\nguarantee acceptance into the professional program.\nStudents are encouraged to work with SDC advisors\nto identify an alternate major should they not be\nadmitted to their primary choice of major.\nTransfer Students\nA limited number of transfer students are\nconsidered each year. Requirements include\ncompletion of the pre-professional courses (or\napproved equivalents). Emphasis is given to\ncumulative GPA. A design portfolio may be\nrequested for additional evaluation.\nSchedule of Studies\nThe plan below is a suggested path to completion\nof the interior design degree. Students will meet\nwith an advisor each semester to confirm academic\nschedule and monitor progress towards graduation.\nStudents are required to earn a grade of C or better\nin all major courses required for the degree (SDC\n100, 120, 140, 250, 300, 350, 473; I D 197, 201, 203,\n205, 215, 277, 297, 312, 321, 325, 326, 333, 350,\n397, 415, 425, 426, 460).\n\n153\nDesign and Construction\nWashington State University, 2021\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCOM 102 [COMM] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSDC 100 [ARTS] 3\nSDC 120 3\nSOC 101 [SSCI] or PSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological [BSCI] \n1 \n3 or 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nFINE ART 101, 201, or 202 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] \n2 \n3\nSDC 140 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nI D 197 3\nI D 201 4\nI D 205 3\nI D 277 1\nSDC 250 3\nSDC 300\n3 \n1\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nI D 203 4\nI D 215 3\nI D 297 3\nSDC 350 [M] 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nI D 312 2\nI D 321 4\nI D 325 3\nI D 326 3\nI D 397 3\nSecond Term Hours\nI D 333 4\nI D 350 3\nI D 415 3\nI D 460 3\nSupportive Electives\n4 \n4 or 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nI D 425 or 490 5\nSupportive Electives \n4 \n7\nSecond Term Hours\nI D 426 [CAPS] 5\nPhysical Science [PSCI] \n1 \n4 or 3\nSDC 473 [M] 3\nPortfolio Review\n5\nComplete Senior Exit Survey\n_______\n1 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n2 \nAll first-year students must take the ALEKS math\nplacement exam. Prerequisites may be required\ndepending on the score.\n3 \nStudents must complete SDC 300 by the end of\nthe second year.\n4 \nSupportive Electives: At least 10 credits of any\n300-400-level courses from ARCH, CST M, I D,\nDESIGN, LND ARCH, SDC, or other courses\napproved in consultation with I D Program Head\nnot used to fulfill major requirements. Italian\nLanguage course is considered a supportive elective\nfor students who study abroad. Total credits must\nmeet the University requirement of 120 credits of\ncoursework.\n5 \nPortfolio Review required in the final semester of\nprogram.\nLANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE\n(120 HOURS)\nLandscape Architecture (LA) is a four-year program\nstructured into one year of pre-professional\ncoursework and three years of major (professional)\ncoursework. Professional program courses begin in\nsecond year fall. Due to the sequential nature of\ncourses there are no spring admits.\nTo be considered for admission into the LA\nprogram, a student must have completed the\nfollowing pre-professional coursework (or their\napproved equivalents): COM 102 [COMM],\nENGLISH 101[WRTG], FINE ARTS 101, 201, or 202\n[ARTS], HIST 105 [ROOT], PSYCH 105 or SOC 101\n[SSCI], and SDC 100, 120, 140, each with a grade of\nC or better and a cumulative GPA of 3.3 or higher.\nStudents not meeting the admission to major\ncriteria above will be considered until enrollment\nlimits are reached. Average enrollment limits into\nthe second year of the landscape architecture\nmajor are 25-30 students. Greater emphasis is\ngiven to performance in SDC 100, 120, and 140.\nCompletion of all pre-professional coursework does\nnot guarantee acceptance into the professional\nprogram. Students are encouraged to work with SDC\nadvisors to identify an alternate major should they\nnot be admitted to their primary choice of major.\nTransfer Students\nA limited number of transfer students are\nconsidered each year. Requirements include\ncompletion of the pre-professional courses (or\napproved equivalents). Emphasis is given to\ncumulative GPA. A design portfolio may be\nrequested for additional evaluation.\nSchedule of Studies\nThe plan below is a suggested path to completion\nof the landscape architecture degree. Students will\nmeet with an advisor each semester to confirm\nacademic schedule and monitor progress towards\ngraduation.\nStudents are required to earn a grade of C or better\nin all major courses required for the degree (HORT\n330, 331; LND ARCH 222, 262, 263, 297, 327, 362,\n363, 365, 366, 367, 380, 450, 470, 485; SOIL SCI\n201; SDC 100, 120, 140, 250, 300, 350, 473).\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 120 [BSCI]\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] or SOC 101 [SSCI] 3\nSDC 100 [ARTS] 3\nSDC 120 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCOM 102 [COMM] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nFINE ART 101, 201, or 202 3\nSDC 140 3\nSOE 101 [PSCI] 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDigital Tools Requirement I\n2 \n3\nLND ARCH 222 1\nLND ARCH 262 4\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN]\n3 \n3\nSDC 250 3\nSDC 300\n4 \n1\nSecond Term Hours\nLND ARCH 263 4\nLND ARCH 297 3\nLND ARCH 365 4\nSDC 350 [M] 3\nSOIL SCI 201 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDigital Tools Requirement II\n5 \n3\nHORT 330 3\nLND ARCH 327 3\nLND ARCH 362 4\nLND ARCH 366 4\nSecond Term Hours\nHORT 331 3\nLND ARCH 363 4\nLND ARCH 367 3\nLND ARCH 380\n6 \n3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nLND ARCH 470 4\nSupportive Electives\n7 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nLND ARCH 450 [M] 3\nLND ARCH 485 [CAPS] [M] 4\nSDC 473 [M] 3\nSupportive Electives\n7 \n3\nComplete Digital Portfolio\n_______\n1 \nStudents are encouraged to complete BIOLOGY\n120 [BSCI] and SOE 101 [PSCI] during the first year;\nhowever, these are not a requirement for admission\nto the professional program. If BIOLOGY 120 is not\ntaken in Fall, BIOLOGY 106 can be substituted in\nthe Spring.\n2 \nDigital Tools Requirement I (3 credits): Select from\nI D 197, LND ARCH 210, or approved alternative.\n3 \nAll first-year students must take the ALEKS math\nplacement exam. Prerequisites may be required\ndepending on the score.\n4 \nStudents must complete SDC 300 by the end of\nthe second year.\n5 \nDigital Tools Requirement II (3 credits): Select from\nI D 397, LND ARCH 467, SOIL SCI 368, or approved\nalternative.\n6 \nIf LND ARCH 380 is not available, may use\nBIOLOGY 372, 462, SOE 300, 454, or 464.\n7 \nSupportive electives: At least 6 credits of\n300-400-level courses from ARCH, CST M, DESIGN,\nI D, LND ARCH, SDC, or other courses approved\nin consultation with LA Program Head not used to\nfulfill major requirements.\n\n154\nDesign and Construction\nWashington State University, 2021\nMinors\nArchitectural Studies\nThe minor in architectural studies requires a\nminimum of 18 credits of which at least 9 must\nbe upper-division and taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses. To be eligible to\napply for the minor a student must have completed\nSDC 120 and have a minimum cumulative GPA of\n3.00. Additional requirements include: ARCH 309,\nSDC 140, 250, 350; and 3 credits of 300-400-level\nARCH coursework.\nConstruction Management\nThe minor in construction management requires a\nminimum of 17 credits, 9 of which must be upper-\ndivision and taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses. To be eligible to apply for the\nminor a student must be admitted to a major and\nhave a minimum GPA of 2.70. The minor is limited\nto 10 students per year. The required courses are CST\nM 102, 252, 370, 462, 3 credits of business electives,\nand 3 credits of construction emphasis electives.\nApproved business electives include ECONS 327,\nWOMEN ST 315, or any 300-400-level ACCTG, B\nLAW, ENTRP, FIN, HBM, I BUS, MGMT, MGTOP,\nMIS, or MKTG course. Approved construction\nemphasis electives include any 300-400-level CST\nM course.\nDescription of Courses\nARCHITECTURE\nARCH\n201 Architectural Design I 5 (0-10) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nArchitectural Studies. Introduction to\narchitectural design focusing on composition,\nconceptual design and principles of\norganization, scale, proportion, rhythm and\n3-D development.\n203 Architectural Design II 5 (0-10) Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 201 with a C or better.\nIntroduction to architectural design focusing\non the art and aesthetics of structural\nexpression and principles of structure as an\nordering system.\n209 Design Theory I 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Architectural Studies.\nDesign theory relating to building technology,\nsystems and crafts which influence design\ndecisions.\n210 Digital Analysis and Representation\n3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nmajor in Architectural Studies or Landscape\nArchitecture. Introduction to analysis and\nrepresentation with a focus on the use of digital\ntools. (Crosslisted course offered as ARCH 210,\nLND ARCH 210).\n215 Issues in Sustainable Architecture 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admitted to the major\nin Architectural Studies. Introduction to\nthe framework, challenges, and solutions of\nsustainable design in the built environment.\n220 Architectural Histor y I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nArchitectural Studies or majors pursuing non-\nArchitecture degrees. Historic development\nof world architecture from prehistory to late\nmedieval; social, technical and scientific\ninfluences.\n301 Architectural Design III 5 (0-10) Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 203 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Architectural Studies.\nIntroduction of architectural design focusing\non environmental and social issues. Travel for\nsite visit required.\n303 Architectural Design IV 5 (0-10) Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 301 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Architectural Studies.\nContinuation of study of architectural design/\nform as influenced by cultural, spiritual and\nsymbolic issues. Travel for site visit required.\n309 [M] Modern Architecture and Theory\n3 Course Prerequisite: SDC 250 with a C or\nbetter; SDC 350 with a C or better; admitted\nto the major in Architectural Studies. Built and\ntheoretical developments in architecture from\nthe nineteenth century to present; content\nmay be linked to study tour with associated\ntravel required.\n351 Architectural Structures I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 108 with a C or better, or\n140, 171, 202, or 206, or a minimum ALEKS\nmath placement score 75%; admitted major\nin Architectural Studies or Construction\nManagement. Introduction to statics and\nmechanics; analysis and design of statically\ndeterminate architectural structures using\ntimber, steel, and reinforced concrete systems.\n352 Architectural Structures II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 351 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Architectural Studies\nor Construction Management. Continuation\nof ARCH 351.\n401 Architectural Design V 6 (0-12) Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 303 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Architectural Studies.\nAdvanced architectural design focusing on\ntechnology, systems and crafts of buildings.\nTravel for site visit required.\n403 [CAPS] Comprehensive Design Studio I 6\n(0-12) Course Prerequisite: ARCH 401 with a C\nor better; admitted to the major in Architectural\nStudies; senior standing. Integrated capstone\nstudio focusing on design and construction\ndocuments, costs, and specifications. Travel\nto site may be required.\n409 [M] Design Theory VI 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Architectural Studies.\nAdvanced design theory relating to social and\nenvironmental issues which influence housing\ndesign for the urban environment.\n428 Architecture and Culture in the Islamic\nWorld 3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nmajor or minor in Architectural Studies; junior\nstanding. A thematic course exploring the\nrelationship between architecture and culture\nin the context of Islamic civilization.\n436 Contemporary Furniture Design 3\n(1-4) Course Prerequisite: Admitted major\nin Architectural Studies, Construction\nManagement, Interior Design, or Landscape\nArchitecture. Investigation of issues related\nto the design and fabrication of furniture;\nstudents design and fabricate projects in the\nschool shop.\n440 Architectural Acoustics for Construction\nManagement 2 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Architectural Studies\nor Construction Management. Introduction to\nthe art and science of architectural acoustics\nwith emphasis on understanding construction\nperformance specifications. (Crosslisted course\noffered as ARCH 440, CST M 440).\n446 Computer Animation I 3 (1-4) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted major in Architectural\nS t u d i e s , C o n s t r u c t i o n M a n a g e m e n t ,\nInterior Design, or Landscape Architecture.\nIntroduction to computer animation\nproduction and building simulation; applicable\nfor all majors.\n451 Computer-aided Design I 3 (2-2) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nArchitectural Studies. Computer-aided design\nrelated to 3D modeling and construction\ndocuments.\n452 Computer-aided Design II 2 (1-2)\nCourse Prerequisite: Admitted to the major\nin Architectural Studies or Construction\nManagement. Continuation of ARCH 451.\nComputer-aided design related to 3D modeling\nand construction documents.\n456 Field Sketching/Journal Keeping 3\n(2-2) Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nmajor in Architectural Studies, Construction\nManagement, Interior Design, or Landscape\nArchitecture. Field-sketching/journal-keeping\nstrategies to facilitate investigation and\ncomprehension of the built environment.\n463 Architectural Structures III 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 352 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Architectural Studies\nor Construction Management. Wind and\nseismic loads on architectural structures; high-\nrise systems; reinforced concrete and masonry\nstructures. Credit not granted for both ARCH\n463 and ARCH 563.\n464 Architectural Structures IV 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 463 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Architectural Studies\nor Construction Management. Deflection\ntheory; classical and computer analysis for\nstatically indeterminate architectural structure\nsystems. Credit not granted for both ARCH 464\nand ARCH 564.\n472 Codes and Acoustics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted major in Architectural Studies,\nConstruction Management, or Interior Design.\nBuilding codes and specifications; sound\ntheory, control, and acoustic systems applied\nto buildings.\n\n155\nDesign and Construction\nWashington State University, 2021\n480 Architecture Internship V 1-16 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 16\nhours. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n510 Summer Graduate Design Studio 6 (0-\n12) Intensive summer studio focusing on\ndesign projects that address prevailing issues\nin a particular context and locale (regional,\nnational, or international city) outside of\nPullman.\n511 Graduate Design Studio I 6 (0-12) Graduate\nstudio experience researching a single topic of\narchitectural relevance. Travel for site visit\nrequired.\n513 Graduate Design Studio II 6 (0-12) Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 511 with a C or better.\nGraduate studio experience researching a\nsingle topic of architectural relevance. Travel\nfor site visit required.\n515 Research Methods and Programming 3\nExploration of traditional research methods\nand investigations for architects.\n520 Directed Topics in Architecture V 1-3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Topics related to areas of emphasis in\nthe program and student specialization.\n525 History and Theory 3 History and theory of\n20th century architecture focusing on cultural\nand philosophical principles related to design.\n527 Site and Landscape Design 3 Exploration\nof issues of site context analysis, topography,\nplanning, and landscape design.\n530 Philosophies and Theories of the Built\nEnvironment 3 Course Prerequisite: Graduate\nstanding in Architecture, Interior Design, or\nLandscape Architecture. Focus on systematic\nthought which may describe behavior of the\nbuilt environment. (Crosslisted course offered\nas ARCH 530, I D 530, LND ARCH 530).\n531 Advanced Tectonics 3 Tectonic theory of\nconcrete and metal construction with focus\non skin design and technology as formative\nelements in architecture.\n540 Research Methods 3 Research methods, from\nquantitative to technical to philosophical,\ndirected toward qualitative research.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ARCH 540, I D\n540, LND ARCH 540).\n542 Issues in Architecture 3 Examination of\nissues in architecture related to society, culture,\nenvironment, politics, and philosophy.\n560 Interdisciplinary Seminar 3 Explores\napproaches to design thinking in the topic\nareas of people and place, history, theory and\ncriticism, and physical design. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as ARCH 560, I D 560, LND\nARCH 560).\n563 Architectural Structures III 3 Wind and\nseismic loads on architectural structures; high-\nrise systems; reinforced concrete and masonry\nstructures. Credit not granted for both ARCH\n463 and ARCH 563.\n564 Architectural Structures IV 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ARCH 463 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major in Architectural Studies\nor Construction Management. Deflection\ntheory; classical and computer analysis for\nstatically indeterminate architectural structure\nsystems. Credit not granted for both ARCH 464\nand ARCH 564.\n570 Advanced Architectural Design Studio\nI 6 (0-12) Advanced study of design problems\nrelating to culture, environment, technology,\nurban planning, or other topics. Travel for site\nvisit required.\n571 Advanced Architectural Design Studio\nII 6 (0-12) Course Prerequisite: ARCH 570.\nAdvanced study of design problems relating\nto culture, environment, technology, urban\nplanning, or other topics. Travel for site visit\nrequired.\n573 Ethics and Practice 3 Ethical and professional\npractice issues related to the business and\npractice of architecture; investigations into\nmarketing client and business orientation.\n577 Theories and Method s o f U r b a n\nConstruction 3 Morphology, theoretical\nconcepts, planning and spatial structure of\ncities and analysis of the transformation of\nthe city core in Europe and America.\n580 Architecture Practicum V 1-4 May be\nrepeated for credit. Course Prerequisite:\nGraduate student in M Architecture degree\nprogram. Internship, travel study, or\nindependent study related to the field of\narchitecture.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n701 Master’s Independent Capstone Project\nand /or Examination V 1-6 May be\nrepeated for credit. Mechanical\nsystems for buildings; building heating,\nventilating, and air conditioning systems, heat\nflow concepts.\n333 Building Science II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCST M 332 with a C or better; admitted to the\nmajor in Architectural Studies or Construction\nManagement. S, F grading.\n555 Global Engagement in Design and\nConstruction 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: Graduate student in\nArchitecture, Interior Design, or Landscape\nArchitecture. Engagement with contemporary\nand historical issues relevant to the built\nenvironment, landscape, climate, industry,\nand/or culture of the city, region, or country\nunder consideration.\nProgram in Digital\nTechnology and Culture\ndtc.wsu.edu\nMorrill 108\n509-335-0698\nDirector and Professor, K. Christen (Pullman); Associate\nProfessors, P. Christensen (Tri-Cities), D. Gast (Tri-\nCities); Assistant Professors (CT), K. Carlson Becker, P.\nDeVries, R. Gregory, A. Plemons, J. Riddle, J. Sanders;\nLecturers, P. Mudd (Tri-Cities), L. Roper.\nDigital Technology and Culture is a multidisciplinary\nacademic degree program that combines creative\nproduction and critical exploration of digital\nmedia across multiple contexts. DTC emphasizes\na historical, social, political, and cultural\nunderstanding of digital media and production to\nprepare students for communicating and engaging\nwith diverse audiences and stakeholders locally and\nglobally. The DTC program 1) prepares students\nfor human-centered problem solving across\ntechnological formats, 2) supports open and ethical\ncommunication to understand local, regional,\nnational, and global situations, 3) promotes diversity\nand equity through pedagogical, educational, and\noutreach models, and 4) encourages innovative\nand creative research, scholarship, and production\nthat invites critical perspectives, integrates diverse\nknowledge systems, and encompasses progressive\nuses of technology.\nThe DTC core includes five courses that\nintroduce cultural critique and critical production,\ninformation structures, design principles, histories\nof technology and computing, and theories of\ninclusion, equity and diversity. The core also\nincludes an internship and senior seminar to\nprovide students with practical methods and\napplications of the skills acquired throughout their\ndegree program. Students can choose from three\noptions and electives to fulfill the degree program.\nThese options are designed to meet individual\ninterests and strengths while providing a holistic\nunderstanding of the production, creation, and\napplication of digital media and technologies across\nsocial and cultural environments.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n• Demonstrate competency with technology for\ndesigning and distributing digital works in various\nmediums.\n• Demonstrate competency with design principles\nthrough both the production and analysis of media\nobjects.\n• Demonstrate and articulate an understanding of\nthe way digital media and information function and\ncirculate in multiple cultural contexts.\n• Demonstrate an understanding of the history\nof technological development, from local to global\nperspectives, and its implications for a variety of\nmediums.\n• Utilize an interdisciplinary perspective in order\nto understand the global changes brought about\nby digital media.\n• Effectively communicate through writing and\nspeech why and how digital media productions\nmake meaning.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nDIGITAL TECHNOLOGY AND CULTURE\n(120 HOURS)\nDTC Admission Requirements, Pullman and Tri-\nCities Campuses\nThe DTC major requires 39 credits composed of a\n15-credit required core that includes an internship,\noptions of 21 credits, and 3 DTC-related elective\ncredits. A student may be admitted to the DTC\nmajor at any point during a semester. To be\nadmitted, a student must have completed DTC 101\nwith a C or better. To remain in good standing in the\nmajor, students must complete DTC 201 and DTC\n206 with a C or better and maintain an overall GPA\nat WSU of 2.0 or higher.\nNo DTC course may be taken on a pass, fail basis.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDTC 101 [ARTS] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nForeign Language or Electives\n1 \n3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nDTC 201 [ARTS] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language or Electives\n1 \n3 or 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n2 \n4\nDTC 206 [DIVR] 3\nElectives 9\nSecond Term Hours\nDTC Option Elective\n3 \n3\nDTC Track Course\n4 \n3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n2 \n4\nElectives 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDTC Option Elective\n3 \n3\nDTC Track Courses\n4 \n6\nElectives\n5 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nDTC Option Elective\n3 \n3\nDTC Track Course\n4 \n3\nElectives\n5 \n9\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDTC 498 3\nDTC Option Elective\n3 \n3\nIntegrated Capstone [CAPS] 3\nElectives\n5 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nDTC 497 3\nElectives\n5 \n12\nSenior Exit Survey\n_______\n1 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n2 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n3 \nDTC Option Electives (12 credits): Students choose\nany four DTC classes not already completed for the\nmajor. May substitute one class (three credits) in\nthe elective option with DTC 499. The degree must\n\n161\nDigital Technology and Culture\nWashington State University, 2021\ninclude two writing in the major [M] courses. These\nmay be taken as a part of the option course work or\nas a DTC elective.\n4 \nDTC Track Courses (12 credits): Students complete\none of five tracks: Track One - Digital Cinema, and\nAnimation (DTC 208, 335, 354, and 435 or 491),\nTrack Two - Web Development (DTC 355 [M], 375\n[M], 477 and 478), Track Three - Game Studies (DTC\n354, 355 [M], 392 or 476, and 492), Track Four - Data\nVisualization and Curation (DTC 204 or 209, 331,\n356 [M] and 476), or Track Five - Integrative Media\nand Design (DTC 336, 354, 355 [M], and 436).\n5 \nElectives must include sufficient 300-400-level\ncoursework to meet the University requirement of\n40 credits of upper-division coursework.\nMinors\nDigital Technology and Culture\nA minor in DTC requires 18 hours including DTC\n101, 201, DTC/ENGLISH 336, 355, and 375, plus\none more 3-hour course from the following: DTC\n335, 356, 435, 477, 478, FINE ART 331, 332, 333,\n363, 434, or 435. 9 hours of upper-division work\nmust be taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses.\nCertificates\nGame Studies and Design\nCertificate\nThe Game Studies and Design Certificate prepares\nstudents for conceptualizing and producing video\ngames and gameful environments with a special\nfocus on genres such as educational, serious, and\ngames for change. Completion of the Game Studies\nand Design Certificate requires a total of 15 credits.\nStudents are required to complete DTC 392 or 476\nand 492 plus 9 credits chosen from one of two\noptions. Students who select the Design Option\nselect three courses (9 credits) from DTC 335, 336,\n354, and 435. Students who select the Development\nOption select three courses (9 credits) from DTC\n338, 355, 477, and 478.\nGraphic Design Certificate\nThe Graphic Design Certificate prepares students to\nbe premiere visual communicators working across\ndigital and print mediums in a variety of contexts\nincluding industry, non-profit, and freelance areas.\nCompletion of the Graphic Design Certificate\nrequires a total of 15 credits. Students are required to\ncomplete DTC 201 and FINE ART 102 plus 9 credits\nchosen from the following options: DTC 336, 436;\nFINE ART 332, 433.\nDescription of Courses\nDIGITAL TECHNOLOGY AND CULTURE\nDTC\n101 [ A R T S ] I n t r o d u c t i o n t o D i g i t a l\nTechnology & Culture 3 Inquiry into\ndigital media, including origins, theories,\nforms, applications, and impact with a focus\non authoring and critiquing multimodal texts.\n104 Digital Foundations 1 Foundational\ncomputing skills: hardware, file management,\ncommon operating systems and applications,\nlibrary resources, and professionalization.\n201 [ARTS] Tools and Methods for Digital\nTechnology 3 An introduction to the tools\nand methods of production for multimedia\nauthoring in digital contexts.\n204 Introduction to Text Analysis 3\nI n t r o d u c t i o n t o c o m p u t a t i o n a l a n d\nstatistical text analysis using the open\nsource programming language R; designed\nfor students with no prior experience with\nprogramming but who wish to extend their\nmethodological tool kit to include quantitative\nand computational approaches to the study of\ntext. (Crosslisted course offered as DTC 204,\nDATA 204.)\n206 [DIVR] Digital Inclusion 3 Examination\nof global reach of digital environments,\nstructures, and tools with focus on inclusion\nin terms of access, availability, affordability,\nadoption, and application across cultures.\n208 [ARTS] Introduction to Digital Cinema\n3 A practical introduction to the technological\nand cultural transformations driving the\nevolution of cinematic techniques from\nthe birth of motion pictures to emerging\ntechnology.\n209 Introduction to Data Visualization 3 An\nintroduction to the tools and methods of data\nvisualization in multiple contexts. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as DTC 209, DATA 209.)\n330 Social Media Case Studies 3 Inquiry\ninto ways businesses and individuals use\nsocial media as a marketing tool with special\nemphasis on media impact.\n331 Social Media Practices 3 Inquiry into social\nmedia practices from a ground-up approach,\nfocusing on social media message creation and\nconsumption; online self-presentation; online\nrelationships; reputation management; social\nmedia data analysis.\n335 3D Digital Animation 3 (2-2) 3-D digital\nanimation for creative and professional\nproductions, art skills, story-telling and team\nproblem-solving techniques.\n336 Multimedia Design 3 Course Prerequisite:\nDTC 201. (Crosslisted course offered as DTC 561,\nENGLISH 561).\nSchool of Economic Sciences\nses.wsu.edu\nHulbert 101\n509-335-5555\nDirector and Regents Professor, J. J. McCluskey;\nAssociate Director and Professor, A. Espinola-\nArredondo; Regents Professor, R. C. Mittelhammer;\nProfessors, R. G. Batina, T. R. Fortenbery, G. I. Galinato,\nR. K. Gallardo, H. A. Love, B. Mandal, T. L. Marsh, V.\nA. McCracken, F. Munoz-Garcia, J. Yan, J. K. Yoder;\nAssociate Professors, J. Bai, M. P. Brady, J. H. Cook,\nB. W. Cowan, S. Ortigueira; Assistant Professors, W.\nBlundell, J. Luckstead, S. Manian; Research Professor,\nE. L. Jessup; Associate Research Professor, D. Moore;\nAssistant Research Professor, T. P. Nadreau; Clinical\nAssociate Professors, M. J. Gibson, P. Kuzyk, A. J.\nPrera; Clinical Assistant Professor, E. R. Gurocak; WSU\nExtension Professor, J. S. Neibergs; Professors Emeriti,\nK. Casavant, R. E. Rosenman, C. R. Shumway, P. R.\nWandschneider.\nThe School of Economic Sciences (SES) offers\nprograms leading to the degree of Bachelor of\nScience in Economic Sciences with options in\nAgricultural Economics; Business Economics;\nInternational Economics and Development;\nEconomics, Policy and Law; Environmental and\nResource Economics; Financial Markets; and\nQuantitative Economics. Graduate degrees offered\ninclude the Master of Science in Applied Economics,\nDoctor of Philosophy in Economics, and Doctor of\nPhilosophy in Agricultural Economics.\nThe School also advises the Bachelor of Science in\nAgricultural and Food Systems, the Agricultural and\nFood Business Economics major.\nUndergraduate Program\nThe course of study for the Bachelor of Science\nin Economic Sciences is sufficiently broad to\naccommodate students with a variety of interests\nand career goals. It provides training for students\ninterested in business, law, finance, agricultural\nmarkets, environmental policy and natural\nresources, and economic development. The\nprogram also gives students the preparation needed\nfor graduate study in business, law, agricultural\neconomics, finance, and general economics. The\nprogram provides students the flexibility to choose\ncourses outside the School of Economic Sciences\nwhile still meeting degree requirements and allows\nstudents to pursue double majors in such fields as\nbusiness, math, or political science.\nThe degree requires a set of core courses taken\nby all School of Economic Sciences undergraduate\ns t u d e n t s . T h e s e c o u r s e s d e v e l o p a d e e p\nunderstanding of the basic principles of economics\nand the research methods needed for economic\nanalysis in any field of economic sciences. Students\nthen branch out to further apply the core tools in\none of seven option areas:\n• The agricultural economics option deals with\neconomic issues related to food and fiber supply\nand demand and the natural resource base that\nsupports agricultural production and societal needs.\nApplications to public decision making and private\ndecisions of farms, ranches, and agribusinesses are\nconsidered.\n• The business economics option trains students\nto use economic concepts and data analysis skills\nto analyze management, marketing, and finance\nproblems faced by businesses operating in a market\nsystem.\n• The international economics and development\noption provides students an understanding of how\npolicies, institutions and endowments influence\nphysical, human, and natural capital accumulation\nwhich leads to the emergence of poor and rich\ncommunities and countries.\n• The economics, policy and law option provides\nstudents with the analytical skills used in law school\nand policy-making including those relevant in tax,\nlaw, regulation, program, and policy arenas.\n• The environmental and resource economics option\ntrains students to make decisions while weighing\nthe trade-offs between protecting, restoring,\ndeveloping, and allocating natural resources.\n• The financial markets option provides students\nwith analytical and quantitative training in the\nsubstantial overlap between economics and finance.\nThe option requires coursework that focuses on the\nanalysis of financial markets.\n• The quantitative economics option provides\nstudents with the skills to understand and use more\nadvanced statistical and mathematical models,\npreparing them for careers involving data analytics\nor for advanced degrees -- such as a Master of Science\nor Ph.D. in economics, agricultural economics, or\nrelated field.\nIn all options, students combine course work in\neconomic sciences with courses outside the School\nof Economic Sciences. According to their individual\ninterests, students supplement their economic\nsciences training with elective coursework in many\nareas including agricultural sciences, business,\ncomputer science, engineering, environmental\nscience, history, mathematics, philosophy, political\nscience, and statistics.\nThe School of Economic Sciences also advises\nthe college-wide Agricultural and Food Business\nEconomics major. This major focuses on agricultural\nbusiness with an emphasis in economics. Please\nvisit http://afs.wsu.edu for more information.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nGraduates from the School of Economic Sciences\nwill evaluate and apply economic concepts and\nquantitative methods; will think critically, integrate\nconcepts, and evaluate results in performing\neconomic analyses; and will communicate\neffectively. Students will be able to apply economic\nconcepts, together with quantitative methods and\ntechnical information relating to the decision\nenvironment, to assist policy makers and target\ngroups in evaluating economic trade-offs and in\nmaking rational economic decisions. Graduates will\nalso be capable of analyzing and evaluating broad\neconomic and social problems concerning the\nallocation of individual, firm and social resources\nwithin their specific degree interest area. Students\nwill be capable of communicating the results of\neconomic analyses in a clear, compelling, and\ninformative manner.\nA wide variety of courses is available to non-\nmajors who want to take selected courses to\nsupport their programs in other departments.\nStudents from other departments may declare\na minor in economics, agribusiness economics,\nbusiness economics, environmental and resource\neconomics and management, or sustainable\ndevelopment (see below).\nThe school advises for the interdisciplinary\nsustainable development minor that addresses\nhow economic and social systems interact with\nmajor resource and environmental issues, both\ninternationally and domestically. This is an\ninterdisciplinary program with participation by the\ndepartments such as Anthropology, Architecture,\nEconomics, International Business, Political Science,\nthe School of the Environment, and Sociology. The\nprogram is built on the premise that as a society\nwe have a responsibility to ourselves and to future\ngenerations to steward resources in ways that foster\nlong-term environmental and socio-cultural health\nand economic viability for all peoples.\nTransfer Students\nStudents planning to transfer to Washington\nState University from other institutions should\ntake courses that meet the 100- and 200-level\ncourse requirements in economics, mathematics,\naccounting, English, communication, and\nUniversity Common Requirements (UCORE).\nStudents planning to transfer into economic sciences\nby the end of their sophomore year should have\nsatisfactorily completed the required introductory\neconomics, statistics, and mathematics courses if\nthey plan to complete the required work for a degree\nin two additional years.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nStudents planning to pursue graduate study in\neconomics or agricultural economics are urged to\nselect the quantitative economic option and consult\nwith a faculty member in the School of Economic\nSciences. All options, however, prepare students for\ngraduate school but are less quantitatively focused.\nStudents planning graduate study are advised to\ndevelop strong skills through courses in English\ncomposition, and additional work in statistics and\n\n163\nEconomic Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nmathematics. Coursework recommendations for\nspecific graduate areas include:\n• Law School: ACCTG 230; B LAW 210; PHIL 103,\n201; POL S 300; and, depending on legal interests,\nelective Econ courses from the following: ECONS\n322, 324, 327, 425, 451; B LAW 411 suggested.\n• Business School: ACCTG 230, 231; MIS 250.\nAdditional courses in business are not required for\nadmission to most graduate schools of business.\nIt might be useful, however, to take introductory\ncourses in the major areas of business: B LAW 210,\nFIN 325, MGTOP 340, MKTG 360, ECONS 352 and\nECONS 452.\n• Economics and Agricultural Economics: MATH\n171 and 220 are recommended to satisfy the major’s\nmath requirements. MATH 172, 273, STAT 360 are\nalso useful. A good grade in courses such as ECONS\n301, 302, 311 (B+ or higher) and in electives such\nas ECONS 424 or 425 is also expected for students\nseeking to be admitted at Masters and PhD program\nin Economics and Agricultural Economics.\n• Public Administration: ACCTG 230 and POL S\n340; MIS 250 and POL S 443, 446 recommended.\nElective: ECONS 322.\nEmployment Opportunities\nThe undergraduate program provides the basic\nknowledge and tools necessary to secure professional\npositions in a wide range of industries and public\norganizations. Some students take graduate work\nto broaden their career opportunities. School of\nEconomics Sciences graduates compete favorably\nfor jobs in government, business, and non-\ngovernmental organizations, using their strong\nanalytical skills to offer a different perspective for\nproblem-solving and decision-making. Recent\ngraduates have been employed in finance, banking,\nagribusiness, industry, internet-based companies,\nnon-profit organizations, government agencies,\nand at universities. Many are working in foreign\ncountries.\nGraduate Program\nAll School of Economic Sciences graduate degree\nprograms classify as STEM (CIP Code 45.0603:\nEconometrics and Quantitative Economics) for\ninternational student VISA purposes.\nThe Master of Applied Economics degree program\ntrains students to be industry leaders in quantitative\neconomic analysis. Students will graduate with\nstrong knowledge and skills in economic analysis,\napplied econometrics, and data analytics. The\ndegree includes courses that teach machine learning\nand data science. Students will enhance their skills\nin communicating economic findings based on\ninvestigations of data to industry-type audiences.\nStudents in this program should expect to find\nemployment in private corporations, government,\nconsulting, banks, NGOs, and related entities.\nThe Master of Sciences in Applied Economics\nprovides specialization and research experience\nappropriate for positions in private corporations\nand government ser vice as management\nspecialists, policy analysts, forecasters or economic\nconsultants. Students may also use this degree to\nprepare for doctoral studies in economics or related\nfields. Students can focus their studies in general\neconomics, business economics or agribusiness, or\nenvironmental and resource economics by selecting\nsupporting and elective courses.\nThe School of Economic Sciences offers two\ndoctoral programs – the Ph.D. in Economics\nand the Ph.D. in Agricultural Economics. Both\ndegrees prepare students for careers as professional\neconomists in academic, government, international\norganizations, or the private sector. The program\nprovides students with an excellent foundation in\nthe theory and methods of economics along with\napplications in their choice of at least two Ph.D.\nfields. To further strengthen their quantitative\ntraining, students may simultaneously pursue a\nMaster of Science in statistics.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nAGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents are admitted to the Agricultural Economics\noption upon making their intention known to\nthe department. Admitted students must meet\nthe following two benchmarks to remain in good\nstanding:\n• Minimum WSU Cumulative GPA of 2.0.\n• Cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher in ECONS 301,\n302, and 311.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 201\n1 \n3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] 3\nECONS 101 or 102 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 202 [QUAN]\n2 \n3\nConcentrated Area Course \n3 \n3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 101 [PSCI] OR CHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nCOM 102 [COMM], COM 210 [COMM], or\nH D 205 [COMM] 3 or 4\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nECONS 302 3\nConcentrated Area Course \n3 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nACCTG 230 3\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBLAW 210 3\nECONS 301 3\nSTAT 212 or MGTOP 215 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nACCTG 231 3\nConcentrated Area Course \n3 \n3\nECONS 311 [M] 3\nSequence Course\n4 \n3\nElectives 1\nSecond Term Hours\nConcentrated Area Course \n3 \n3\nECONS 335 OR FIN 325 3\nSequence Course\n4 \n3\nElectives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nECONS 431 3\nECONS 483, 495, 497, 499, or HONORS 450 3\nECONS 490 [CAPS] [M] 3\nENGLISH 301, 402 [M], or 403 [M] 3\nSequence Course\n4 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nSequence Course\n4 \n3\n400-level ECONS Elective\n5 \n3\nElectives 9\n_______\n1 \nMATH 201 will be waived with an ALEKS score of\n80% or higher, or the completion of MATH 202 or\nequivalent. Alternative to MATH 201 is MATH 106,\n172, or 220.\n2 \nAlternative to MATH 202 is MATH 171.\n3 \nConcentrated Area Courses: Four courses from\nany one of the following concentration areas: (1)\nAgricultural Production: ANIM SCI 101, HORT/\nCROP SCI 102 or ENTOM 150, CROP SCI 360,\nMGTOP 340; (2) Real Estate & Land Management:\nFIN 325, 345, 445 [M], MIS 250; (3) Food Safety\n& Policy: FS 110, 201, 220, 303; (4) Globalization:\ntwo semesters foreign language, ECONS 327/I BUS\n470, ECONS 428, 430, SOC 415; (5) Sustainability:\nCROP SCI 360, ECONS 326/SOC 375, SOE 110, 285;\n(6) Independent Concentration - upon approval of\nadvisor.\n4 \nPick two sequences (4 courses): ECONS 350 + 450\n[M]; or ECONS 351 + 451; or ECONS 352 + 452 [M].\n5 \nAny 400-level ECONS course not used to fulfill\nmajor requirements.\nBUSINESS ECONOMICS\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents are admitted to the Business Economics\noption upon making their intention known to\nthe department.
