Admitted students must\nmeet the following two benchmarks to remain in\ngood standing:\n• Minimum WSU cumulative GPA of 2.0.\n• Cumulative GPA of 2.0 or higher in ECONS 301,\n302, and 311.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] (with lab)\n1 \n4\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI]\n1 \n3\nECONS 101 or 102 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 172 4\nElectives 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCOM 102 [COMM], 210 [COMM], or\nH D 205 [COMM] 3 or 4\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nEconomics Emphasis Course\n2 \n2 or 3\nECONS 301 4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nEconomics Emphasis Course\n2 \n3\nECONS 302 3\nMATH 220 2\nSTAT 212 or MGTOP 215 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nEconomics Emphasis Course\n2 \n3\nECONS 300-400-level Elective\n3 \n3\nECONS 311 [M] 3\nElectives 6\nSecond Term Hours\nECONS 300-400-level Elective\n3 \n3\nECONS 420 3\nECONS 424 3\nElectives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nECONS 400-500-level Elective\n3 \n3\nECONS 483, 495, 497, 499, or HONORS 450 3\nMATH 364, 401, or ECONS 526 3\nMATH 420 or ECONS 527 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nECONS 400-500-level Elective\n3 \n3\nECONS 490 [CAPS] [M] 3\nENGLISH 301, 402 [M], or 403 [M] 3\nSTAT 360, 443, or ECONS 525 3\nElectives 3\n_______\n1 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n2 \nEconomics Emphasis Courses (3 courses required\nfrom one area): (1) Math: MATH 273, 301, and\n315; (2) Management Operations: MGTOP 340,\n412, and 452; (3) Computer Science: CPT S 121,\n122, and 224.\n3 \nECONS courses not used to fulfill major\nrequirement.\nMinors\nAgribusiness Economics\nThe minor in Agribusiness Economics requires 18\ncredits and includes ECONS 101; ECONS 301 or 305;\nECONS 350 and 450, or ECONS 351 and 451, or\nECONS 352 and 452; ECONS 335; and 3 elective\ncredits in ECONS. 9 credits of upper-division work\nmust be taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses. A 2.0 GPA is required in the\nminor and no courses may be taken pass/fail.\nBusiness Economics\nTo be admitted to the business economics minor,\nstudents must have a cumulative 2.0 GPA. A minor\nin Business Economics requires 18 credits of ECONS\ncourses, nine of which must be at the 300-400\nlevel and taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses. ECONS 101 and 102 (or 198\nand a 300-400-level ECONS course), 305 or 321,\n320, 326 or 327, and 404 are required. A 2.0 GPA\nis required in the minor and no courses may be\ntaken pass/fail.\nEconomics\nTo be admitted to the economics minor, students\nmust have a cumulative 2.0 GPA. A minor in\nEconomics requires 18 credits of ECONS courses,\nnine of which must be at the 300-400-level taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nECONS 101 and 102 (or 198 and a 300/400-level\nECONS courses), and 302 or 320 are required. In\naddition, ECONS 301 or 305, and two 300-level or\nhigher ECONS electives are required (only three\nhours of ECONS 497 or 499 may be used to fulfill\nthe upper-division ECONS electives requirement).\nA 2.0 GPA is required in the minor and no courses\nmay be taken pass/fail.\nEnvironmental and Resource\nEconomics and Management\nThe minor in Environmental and Resource\nEconomics and Management requires a minimum\nof 18 credits. The following courses are required:\nECONS 101, 301 or 305, 326, and 330; one of ECONS\n430, 431, or 433; and 3 elective credits in ECONS.\n9 hours of upper-division work must be taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nA 2.0 GPA is required in the minor and no courses\nmay be taken pass/fail. A student wishing to declare\na minor should consult with an advisor as early as\npossible to develop the required program.\nSustainable Development\nThe program offers a minor in sustainable\ndevelopment. The minor is comprised of ECONS\n326, one course from each of the following four\naspect areas: policy, history, and theory (HISTORY\n409, 494, PHIL 370, POL S 430, PSYCH 466, SOE\n335 [M], or 438); environmental (ARCH 490, 494,\nBIOLOGY 330, 372 [M], CE 401, CROP SCI 360,\nSOE 110, 285, 300, 303, or 483); social/cultural\n(ANTH 203, 309, ANTH/SOC 418, SOC 331, 332,\n415, 430, SOE 312, WOMEN ST 332, or WOMEN ST\n460); economic (ECONS 330, 427, 428, 430, 431, I\nBUS 380, or I BUS 496); and one additional course\nfrom any of the aspect areas. The minor requires\n18 credits, with at least 9 credits at the 300-400\nlevel taken in residence at WSU or through WSU-\napproved education abroad or educational exchange\ncourses. A 2.0 GPA is requried in the minor and no\ncourses may be taken pass/fail. Students wishing to\napply for the minor may do so with the School of\nEconomic Sciences.\nDescription of Courses\nECONOMIC SCIENCES\nECONS\n101 [SSCI] Fundamentals of Microeconomics\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 101, MATH 103\n(or higher) or concurrent enrollment, MGTOP\n215, STAT 205, STAT 212 or concurrent\nenrollment, or a minimum ALEKS score of\n40%. Enrollment not allowed if credit earned\nfor ECONS 198 with a C or higher and ECONS\n102. Theory and policy of human responses to\nscarcity; how this affects business competition,\ninternational trade, industrial organization,\ninvestment, and income distribution.\n102 [SSCI] Fundamentals of Macroeconomics\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 101, MATH 103\n(or higher) or concurrent enrollment, MGTOP\n215, STAT 205, STAT 212 or concurrent\nenrollment, or a minimum ALEKS score of 40%.\nEnrollment not allowed if credit earned for\nECONS 198 with a C or higher and ECONS 101.\nTheory and policy related to unemployment,\ninflation, foreign trade, government spending,\ntaxation, and banking.\n\n167\nEconomic Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n105 Introduction to Economic Sciences\nSeminar 1 For new undergraduate economics\nmajors, an introduction to advising, study\noptions and program of study planning, degree\ncompletion, and career planning.\n198 Economics Honors 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the Honors College. Enrollment\nin ECONS 198 is not allowed if credit has\nalready been earned for ECONS 101 and 102.\nIntroduction to economic theory and policy\nissues.\n299 Topics in Economics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 101, 102, or ALEKS math\nplacement score of 45%. Issues in economics.\n301 Intermediate Microeconomic Theory\nwith Calculus 4 Course Prerequisite: ECONS\n101 or 198; MATH 171 with a C or better, or\nMATH 202 with a C or better. Calculus-based\nintermediate microeconomic theory for majors\nin the School of Economic Sciences.\n302 Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis\n3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS 102 or 198;\nMATH 171 with a C or better, or MATH 202\nwith a C or better. Income, employment, and\ninflation theory with policy implications.\nRecommended preparation: ECONS 101 as\nrequired background.\n305 Intermediate Microeconomics without\nCalculus 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS 101 or\n198. Price determination and market behavior\nunder different market structures and the\nproblems posed for public policy; not calculus-\nbased.\n311 [M] Introductory Econometrics 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 101, 102, or 198; STAT\n212, 360, or MGTOP 215; MATH 171 with a\nC or better, or MATH 202 with a C or better.\nMethods of empirical analysis in the context of\neconomic analysis and forecasting problems.\n320 Money and Banking 3 Course Prerequisite:\nECONS 102 or 198. Analysis of banking\ninstitutions and monetary policy in the US,\nwith comparison to abroad. Recommended:\nECONS 101.\n321 Economics of Sports in America 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 101 or 198. Economic\naspects of American sports; fan demand;\nadvertising; team output decisions; league/\nconference organization; government and\nsports.\n322 Public Economics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nECONS 101 or 198. Theory and practice of\nthe public sector; taxes, expenditures, and\nadministration at local, state, and federal\nlevels.\n323 Labor Economics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nECONS 101 or 198. Functioning of labor\nmarkets; introduction to collective bargaining\nand labor law.\n324 [M] The Economics of Health Care 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ECONS 101 or 198.\nThe economics of allocating, financing and\ndelivering medical care services. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n325 [M] The Economics of Organization,\nContracting, and Law 3 Course Prerequisite:\nECONS 101 or 198. Examination of the\neconomic and legal aspects of contractual\nand non-contractual ways of organizing\ntransactions by business.\n326 Aspects of Sustainable Development\n3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS 101 or 198.\nEcological, economical, and sociological\na s p e c t s o f s u s t a i n a b l e d e v e l o p m e n t .\n(Crosslisted course offered as ECONS 326, SOC\n375).\n327 International Trade and Finance 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ECONS 101 or 198;\nECONS 102 or 198. Analysis and description of\ninternational trade flows; commercial policy;\nmultinational firms, foreign exchange markets;\nopen economy macroeconomics; international\nmonetary systems. (Crosslisted course offered\nas ECONS 327, I BUS 470).\n329 The Economics of Gaming 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 101, 102, 198, or a\nminimum ALEKS math placement score of\n45%. Exploration of the critical role that\neconomics plays in the design, development,\nand success of modern electronic games.\n330 Natural Resource Economics 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 101 or 198. The role of\neconomics in natural resource management\nand policy. Course equivalent to OSU’s AREC\n351.\n335 [QUAN] Business Finance Economics 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MATH 101 with a C or\nbetter, 103 with a C or better, 106, 171, 201,\n202, or a minimum ALEKS math placement\nscore of 45%. Financial management, decision\nmaking, and analysis for small businesses;\ncapital market institutions and valuation\nprocesses.\n350 Introduction to Farm and Ranch\nManagement 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS\n101 or 198. Decision making, planning,\nimplementation and control of farms and\nranches using economic principles, records,\nfinancial reports, budgeting and investment\nanalysis.\n351 Introduction to Food and Agricultural\nMarkets 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS 101\nor 198. Current topics in economics.\n404 Economics for Managers 3 Topics in the\napplication of economics for business decision\nmaking with an introduction to calculus.\nCredit not granted to graduate students in the\nSchool of Economic Sciences.\n420 Monetary Theory and Policy 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 301; ECONS 302. Current\nissues in monetary economics with a special\nemphasis on policy.\n424 Strategy and Game Theory 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 301. Strategic behavior\nof firms, consumers, and political parties in\neveryday interaction. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n425 Industrial Organization 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 301 or 305. Economic\ntheories of firm behavior and the influence\nof market industry parameters; buyer/seller\nconcentration, information asymmetries,\nproduct differentiation, and entry conditions.\n426 Transportation Economics and Supply\nChain Analysis 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS\n301 or 305; ECONS 311. In-depth analysis and\napplication in transport economics, modeling,\nand policy evaluation across all transportation\nmodes.\n427 E c o n o m i c D e v e l o p m e n t 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 301 or 305. Development\ntheories, policies, and performance of\nThird World economies; population, land\nreform, foreign trade, aid, investment, debt,\ndependency.\n428 [DIVR] Global Capitalism Today:\nP e r s p e c t i v e s a n d I s s u e s 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 101, 102, or 198.\nLogic and consequences of capitalism as\nglobal system; multinational corporations;\nunderdevelopment and overdevelopment;\nexternal debt, population, and environmental\ncrisis.\n430 Managing the Global Environment\n3 Study of policy and management tools\nto address environmental issues of global\nsignificance.\n431 Economic Analysis of Environmental\nand Natural Resource Policies 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ECONS 301. Nature and practice\nof environmental policy analysis using\neconomics concepts and the analysis of\nmodels applied to natural resource problems\nand issues.\n433 Topics in International Environmental\nL a w, P o l i c y a n d I n s t i t u t i o n s 3\nInterdisciplinary study of the political\ndevelopment of the European Union and its\nimpact on modern Italy; natural resource,\nenvironmental and agricultural policy and law.\n450 [ M ] A d v a n c e d F a r m a n d R a n c h\nManagement 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS\n101 or 198; ECONS 350. Business and financial\nprinciples applied to organization and\noperation of farms and ranches.\n451 A d v a n c e d F o o d E c o n o m i c s a n d\nMarketing 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS\n301, 305, or 351; ECONS 311. (Crosslisted course offered as\nECONS 503, FIN 503).\n504 Production and Consumption Economics\n3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS 502; ECONS 503.\nAdvanced duality topics, demand and supply\nsystem modeling, financial economics and\nrisk.\n505 Economics for Agricultural Decision\nMaking 3 Managerial economics with specific\napplications to agricultural issues.\n506 Mathematics Primer for Economists\n3 Intensive overview of the essential\nmathematical tools needed for graduate study\nin topics of economic sciences.\n509 Quantitative Methods in Economic\nDynamics 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS\n502; ECONS 503; ECONS 511. Basic numerical\nmethods of optimization, equation solving,\nfunction approximation, numerical dynamic\nprogramming, random number generation\nand simulation, and the solution of dynamic\nstochastic general equilibrium models;\neconometric estimation methods of nonlinear\nstructural economic models, including\nBayesian Estimation, Generalized Method of\nMoments, Indirect Inference, and Simulated\nMethod of Moments.\n510 Statistics for Economists 3 Statistical\ntheory underlying econometric techniques\nutilized in quantitative analysis of problems\nin economics and finance. (Crosslisted course\noffered as ECONS 510, FIN 510). Required\npreparation must include college calculus and\nmatrix algebra. Required preparation must\ninclude college calculus and matrix algebra.\n511 Econometrics I 3 Course Prerequisite: ECONS\n510. Single equation linear and nonlinear\nmodels; estimation, inference, finite and\nasymptotic properties, effects and mitigation of\nviolations of classical assumptions. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as ECONS 511, FIN 511).\n512 Econometrics II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nECONS 501; ECONS 511. Econometric\nmethods for systems estimation; simultaneous\nequations, discrete and limited dependent\nvariable, panel data, and time series data.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ECONS 512, FIN\n512).\n513 Econometrics III 3 Course Prerequisite:\nECONS 502; ECONS 503; ECONS 512. Linear\nand non-linear models and maximum\nlikelihood estimation and inference; semi-\nparametric and parametric methods; limited\ndependent variable models.\n514 Econometrics IV 3 Course Prerequisite:\nECONS 502; ECONS 503; ECONS 512.\nConstrained estimation, testing hypotheses,\nbootstrap resampling, BMM estimation and\ninference, nonparametric regression analysis,\nand an introduction to Bayesian econometrics.\n521 Topics in Economic Sciences V 1-3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Current topics in the development and\napplication of the economic sciences. Required\npreparation must include intermediate micro-\nand macro-economics, and econometrics\ncourse work.\n522 Financial and Commodity Derivatives\n3 Design, trading, structure, and pricing\nof derivatives; working knowledge of how\nderivative securities work, how they are used,\nand how they are priced.\n523 Big Data Management and Processing\nfor Economics 3 Introduction to data\nmanagement and processing; efficient\ncollection, storage, cleaning, version control,\nand data analysis; effective programming\nfor achieving these goals. Recommended\npreparation: one 3-credit introductory statistics\ncourse. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n524 Applied Machine Learning for Economics\n3 Introduction to machine learning algorithms\nand concepts; supervised and unsupervised\nlearning methods; foundational theory\nand application to data; statistical and\ncomputational methods. Recommended\npreparation: linear algebra, calculus, and\nstatistics with calculus. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n525 Master’s Econometrics 3 Theory and\npractice of multiple regression methods;\napplications to the study of economic and\nother phenomena; use of computer regression\nprograms. Required preparation must include\nintroductory statistics course. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n526 M a t h e m a t i c a l E c o n o m i c s w i t h\nApplications 3 Linear algebra, matrix\nalgebra, calculus-based analysis of consumer\nand producer theory, comparative statistics,\nand constrained optimization. Public sector and public choice economics,\nincluding government debt and tax policy,\npublic decision making, bureaucratic behavior\nand rent-seeking, with applications.\n593 Applications in Microeconomic Topics 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ECONS 502; ECONS 503;\nECONS 511. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Educational\nLeadership and Sport\nManagement\neducation.wsu.edu/college/elsm\nCleveland 351\n509-335-9117\nChair and Professor, S. Kruse; Associate Professors,\nK. Huggins, S. Licen, Y. Rhee, K. Rodela; Assistant\nProfessors, S. Calderone, S. Jedlicka, J. Walls; Teaching\nAssociate Professors, K. Cowin, T. Crawford, G. Hill;\nTeaching Assistant Professors, C. Lebens, R. McBride;\nLecturer, R. Rada.\nThe department offers courses of study leading\nto a Bachelor of Arts in Sport Management or an\nundergraduate minor in Sport Management. Masters\ndegrees (Master of Arts; Master of Education) are\noffered in the areas of educational leadership and\nsport management. The Doctor of Philosophy\n(Education) and the Doctor of Education degrees\nare offered in Educational Leadership.\nThe Department of Educational Leadership\nand Sport Management, housed in the College\nof Education, has excellent facilities for\nundergraduate and graduate study and research.\nThe department sponsors and hosts a number\nof state, national, and international programs.\nPrograms for superintendent, principal, and\nprogram administrator certification are available at\nthe Pullman, Spokane, Tri-Cities, and Vancouver\ncampuses. A state-wide cohort-based superintendent\nprogram is also available.\nApplication for Graduate Study\nStudents who plan to study toward an advanced\ndegree should contact the Office of Graduate\nEducation in the College of Education. Individuals\napplying for admission to a graduate program must\ncomplete an application to the WSU Graduate\nSchool, and submit the following materials to the\nCollege of Education Office of Graduate Education:\nDepartmental Application form; a statement of\nprofessional objectives; official college transcripts;\nthree (3) letters of recommendation from individuals\nqualified to comment on the applicant’s academic\nand professional abilities, and the Graduate Record\nExamination (for the Sport Management program\nonly). Interested students should contact the Office\nof Graduate Education for specific requirements of\neach program area.\nBachelor of Arts in Sport Management\nThe Department of Educational Leadership\nand Sport Management offers a major in Sport\nManagement, which leads to a Bachelor of Arts in\n\n170\nEducational Leadership and Sport Management\nWashington State University, 2021\nSport Management. This degree provides professional\npreparation for students wishing to pursue a\nmanagement career with sport organizations or in\nthe sport and recreation industry. Students must\ncomplete a core program in sport management and\nmust select an area of specialization from business\nor communication. Additional information on the\nareas of specialization can be obtained from the\ndepartment. A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.75\nis required for admission to the major or minor.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe Sport Management curriculum is designed to\nenable graduating students to:\n• Identify and analyze ethical, legal, and socio-\ncultural issues and formulate responses for\nuse in managerial decision making and policy\ndeterminations in sport.\n• Employ principles of strategic planning, and\nfinancial and human resource management.\n• Assess marketing and media needs in sport and\nformulate short-term and long-term solutions.\n• Develop and apply critical thinking and abstract\nreasoning skills in analyzing sport management\nissues and in managerial planning and decision\nmaking.\n• Demonstrate information literacy and\ncommunication skills.\n• Conceive, plan, execute, and evaluate a sports\nevent.\nPractical application of theory and knowledge is\nobtained through enrollment in practicum hours\nand through the completion of a 10-12-credit\ninternship at the end of the required coursework.\nThe internship serves as the bridge between the\nstudent’s college career and opportunities for\nemployment in sport management.\nThe general prerequisite for enrollment in\n300-400-level sport management courses is\nadmission to the Sport Management major or\nminor. Additional prerequisites for specific courses\nare listed in the course descriptions. The department\nchair or assistant chair must approve any exceptions\nto these requirements.\nUndergraduate Minors\nThe Department of Educational Leadership\nand Sport Management offers an undergraduate\nminor in Sport Management. Students interested\nin declaring a minor in Sport Management should\ncontact the department or consult its website for\nadditional information.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nSPORT MANAGEMENT\n(120 HOURS)\nWSU seeks to prepare the best possible sport\nmanagement professionals and therefore seeks\nhighly qualified individuals. Admission to, or\ncontinued enrollment in the sport management\nprogram may be denied to any candidate who\ndoes not meet the minimum criteria. Applicants\nwho meet the minimum requirements are eligible\nfor consideration, but not assured admission.\nEnrollment is limited and admission competitive.\nApplications are evaluated by program faculty who\nprovide recommendations based on a variety of\nfactors including but not limited to fulfillment of\nadmission criteria, professionalism, and likelihood\nof success in the program.\nThe application for admission opens mid-semester\nand the deadline for application submission is the\nFriday before finals week, with admission effective\nthe following term. Candidates must complete\nformal admission procedures and be admitted to\nthe Sport Management major prior to taking any\n300-400-level Sport Management coursework,\nexcept SPMGT 394. Students transferring from\nother institutions need to enroll in SPMGT 276 to\nbe eligible for admission. The following minimum\ncriteria must be met for consideration for admission:\nMinimum Criteria for Admission to the Sport\nManagement Major:\n• Completion of at least 30 credits of coursework.\nMinimum WSU cumulative GPA of 2.75.\n• A grade of C or better in each of the following\ncourses: COM 102 or HD 205, ENGLISH [WRTG]\nUCORE, MATH [QUAN] UCORE, and SPMGT 276.\nThe application requires a written statement\n(maximum of two pages) describing relevant\nwork experience, involvement in extracurricular\nactivities, and professional goals. This statement will\nbe evaluated by faculty on the basis of the breadth\nand depth of the experiences, as well as for writing\nconventions and clarity of expression.\nStudents will be required to maintain a 2.75\nminimum GPA. If a student’s cumulative GPA falls\nbelow 2.75 the student will be placed on probation.\nA second semester below 2.75 will result in the\nstudent being released from the major.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI]\n1 \n3\nENGLISH [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSPMGT 101 [DIVR] or Diversity [DIVR] 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] (with lab)\n1 \n4\nCOM 102 [COMM] or HD 205 [COMM] 3 or 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nACCTG 230 3\nArts [ARTS] 3\nSPMGT 276 3\nSPMGT 394 1\nElectives 6\nSecond Term Hours\nArea of Specialization\n23 \n6\nSPMGT 290 3\nSPMGT 394 1\nElectives 6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArea of Specialization\n23 \n6\nSPMGT 365 3\nSPMGT 367 [M] 3\nSPMGT 374 or SPMGT 377 3\nSPMGT 394 2\nSecond Term Hours\nArea of Specialization\n23 \n6\nSPMGT 374 or SPMGT 377 3\nSPMGT 379 3\nSPMGT 464 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArea of Specialization\n23 \n3\nENGLISH 402 [M] 3\nSPMGT 468 [M] 3\nSPMGT 489 [CAPS] 3\nSPMGT 490 1\nElectives 2\nSecond Term Hours\nSPMGT 491\n4 \n10-12\n_______\n1 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n2 \nBusiness Specialization: 21 credits are required\nwith a minimum of 9 credits of 300-400-level\ncoursework. Required courses include B LAW 210,\nECONS 101, MGMT 301 and MKTG 360. Approved\nelective courses include any ACCTG, B LAW,\nECONS, ENTRP, FIN, IBUS, MGMT, MGTOP, MIS,\nor MKTG course.\n3 \nCommunication Specialization: 21 credits\nare required with a minimum of 9 credits of\n300-400-level coursework. Approved courses\ninclude any COM, COMJOUR, COMSOC or\nCOMSTRAT course.\n4 \nEnrollment in SPMGT 491 requires senior\nstanding, satisfactory completion of SPMGT 490\nand a cumulative GPA of 2.75. Additionally, the\ninternship contract must be approved by the\ninternship coordinator prior to enrollment in this\ncourse.\nMinors\nSport Management\nThe minor in sport management requires 18\ncredits of course work. The minor is designed for\nstudents with an interest in sport organizations\nor sport-related business. Sport management is an\nappropriate area for students with a variety of career\ninterests, including: business, communication,\neducation, kinesiology, law, and the social sciences.\nTo be considered for admission to the sport\nmanagement minor, a student must have earned\nat least 60 credits, have a minimum cumulative GPA\nof at least 2.75 and be admitted to a major. Graded\ncourses in the minor may not be taken pass/fail. The\ndepartment chair or assistant chair must approve\nany exceptions to these requirements. Required\ncourses include SPMGT 276 and 290, and 12 credits\nfrom SPMGT 101, 365, 367, 374, 377, 379, 384, 394,\n464, 468, 496, or 497. Credits for the minor must\ninclude 9 credits of upper-division work taken in\n\n171\nEducational Leadership and Sport Management\nWashington State University, 2021\nresidence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nStudents are required to maintain a 2.75\nminimum GPA. If a student’s cumulative GPA falls\nbelow 2.75, the student is placed on probation. A\nsecond semester below 2.75 results in the student\nbeing released from the minor.\nDescription of Courses\nEDUCATIONAL ADMINISTRATION AND\nSUPERVISION\nED AD\n501 Philosophy of Education 3 Development\nof American educational philosophy.\n503 Values and Ethics for Educational\nLeaders 3 Study of ethical theories, the moral\ndilemmas of public schooling, and the skills of\nethical reasoning; professional code of ethics.\n506 Social Context of Education 2 The\ninterpretation of social context issues including\nhistorical, legal and cultural factors as these\ninfluence policies and practice in education.\n507 Social Foundations of Education 3\nEducational adaptations to the economic and\nsocial trends and forces.\n509 L e a d i n g S c h o o l I m p r o v e m e n t 3\nLeadership functions and strategies used in\nplanning, evaluating, and influencing school\nimprovement.\n510 Improvement of Instruction 3 Analysis\nand evaluation of instructional models\nwith emphasis on information processing;\nimplications for changing teaching style.\n512 Leadership Studies for Social Justice 3\nLeadership theories and approaches including\npresent educational problems, leadership\ntheories, and perspectives.\n513 Organizational Behavior 3 Human\nbehavior within various social and cultural\norganizational settings.\n514 Basic Principles of Curriculum Design\n3 The application of theoretical concepts and\napproaches in the planning and design of\ncurricula.\n515 Curriculum Implementation 3 Research\nand practice; innovation and change\nin curricular organization emphasizing\nimplementation.\n516 Instructional and Curricular Leadership\nV 2-3 Theory, research, and practice of\nproviding instructional and curricular\nleadership in schools and other educational\nsettings.\n520 Seminar in Curriculum and Instruction\nV 2-3 Contemporary issues, analyses and\ndevelopments of educational programs.\n521 Topics in Education V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nRecent research, developments, issues, and/or\napplications in selected areas of education.\n522 Topics in Education V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nRecent research, developments, issues, and /\nor applications in selected areas of education.\n531 Special Topics 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 3 hours. Topical issues\nin education responding to shifting demands\nand skills needed by parents, teachers, school\nadministrators and community leaders.\n532 Special Topics 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 3 hours. Topical issues\nin education responding to shifting demands\nand skills needed by parents, teachers, school\nadministrators and community leaders.\n534 Special Topics 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 3 hours. Topical issues\nin education responding to shifting demands\nand skills needed by parents, teachers, school\nadministrators and community leaders.\n539 Applied Research for Educational\nLeaders 3 Integrates the principles, skills,\nand tools of research into the leadership and\nmanagerial practices of educational leaders.\n561 Introduction to College Student\nDevelopment 3 Student development theory,\nrelated research and the application of theory\nto practice in student affairs work.\n580 School Organization and Administration\n3 Readings and discussions on the theories\nand practices of school organization and\nadministration. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n581 Politics in Education 3 Examining the\nintrapersonal, organizational politics and\npolitical dilemma, particularly as they pertain\nto marginalized groups.\n582 Policy Formation and Analysis in\nEducation 3 Political and organizational\npolicy formation processes in educational\norganizations; policy analysis in education.\n583 Community and Communications 3\nSocial, political, and economic relationships\nbetween education and the community;\nmethods of public polling and campaign\nstrategy techniques.\n584 Human Resource Management 3 Human\nrelations in education; problems involved and\npractical solutions considered.\n585 Financial Management in Education\n3 Economics and financing of education;\nfinancial planning, budget development,\ni n v e s t m e n t a n a l y s i s , b o n d i n g , c o s t\neffectiveness; current trends in educational\nfinance. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n587 Seminar in School Administration V\n1-6 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Interdisciplinary seminars;\nrelated studies; discussions in several areas by\nspecialists.\n588 The Law and Education 3 Fundamental\nlegal principles within which public education\nfunctions; applicable school codes of\nWashington and other states; review important\ncourt cases.\n589 Leadership Development Seminar 3\nImproving knowledge and skills in strategic\nplanning, decision making, leadership issues,\nconflict, motivation, staff development,\nproductivity, and stress.\n590 Internship V 1-6 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 12 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By interview only. Internship in\nprofessional positions. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, U grading.\nSPORT MANAGEMENT\nThe general prerequisite for enrollment in 300 and\n400-level sport management courses is 60 hours of\ncoursework and admission to the sport management\nmajor or sport management minor. Students of junior\nor senior status in a major who require a 300 or 400-level\nsports management course for their program will be\nallowed to enroll in the required course. Additional\nprerequisites for specific courses are listed in the course\ndescriptions. The program director must approve any\nexceptions to these requirements.\nSPMGT\n101 [DIVR] Sport and Popular Culture:\nTrends and Issues 3 Explores how sport\nshapes or reinforces cultural and social values\nand ideologies.\n\n172\nEducational Leadership and Sport Management\nWashington State University, 2021\n276 Introduction of Sport Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ENGLISH 101 with a C or\nbetter; COM 102 with a C or better or H D 205\nwith a C or better; MATH [QUAN] with a C\nor better; 2.5 cumulative GPA. Principles and\nconcepts in sport management; overview of\nsport industries and career opportunities. Not\nopen to seniors or first-year students during\ntheir first semester.\n290 Sport Programs 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nENGLISH 101 with a C or better; COM 102\nwith a C or better or H D 205 with a C or\nbetter; MATH [QUAN] with a C or better; 2.5\ncumulative GPA. Recent research, developments,\nissues, and /or applications in selected areas of\nSport Management.\n540 Current Issues in Sport Management 3\nSolutions-oriented investigation of current\nissues faced by sport managers/administrators;\ninterpretation of research literature; procedures\nfor issue resolution.\n563 Sport Governance and Policy 3 Sources,\ntypes, and patterns of authority that influence\nthe governance of sport policy; governmental\nand organizational policy-making processes.\n564 Marketing of Sport Events and Programs\n3 Principles of sport marketing including\npublic relations, corporate sponsorship, and\nservice quality for sport organizations.\n565 Ethical Perspectives of Sport and\nPhysical Activity 3 Ontological, ethical,\naesthetic views of physical activity. S, U\ngrading.\nSchool of Electrical\nEngineering and Computer\nScience\nschool.eecs.wsu.edu\nEME 102\n509-335-6602\nDirector, Boeing Centennial Chair in Computer\nEngineering, and Professor, P. Pande; Associate\n\n173\nElectrical Engineering and Computer Science\nWashington State University, 2021\nDirector, Boeing Centennial Chair in Computer\nScience, and Professor, A. Kalyanaraman; Huie-Rogers\nEndowed Chair in Computer Science and Regents\nProfessor, D. Cook; Distinguished Professor in Power\nand Regents Professor, A. Bose; Boeing Distinguished\nProfessor of Electrical Engineering, and Professor,\nV. Venkatasubramanian; Professors, S. Broschat, J.\nDelgado-Frias, D. Heo, L. Holder, S. Roy, A. Saberi, N.\nSchulz, B. Shirazi, A. Srivastava, K. Wang; Associate\nProfessors, V. Arnaoudova, B. Belzer, Z. Dang, J.\nDoppa, A. Gebremedhin, H. Ghasemzadeh, S. Gupta,\nC. Hundhausen, D. Kim, S. Lotfifard, P. Pedrow, J.\nSchneider, K. Sivakumar; Assistant Professors, G. Bhat,\nH. Cai, A. Dubey, A. Sukumaran Rajam, D. Tao, Y. Yan,\nJ. Yu; Clinical Professor, A. O’Fallon; Clinical Associate\nProfessors, A. Abu-Hajar, S. Arslan Ay, M. Kejariwal, J.\nThompson; Scholarly Associate Professors, J. Murray, M.\nTorabi Konjin; Clinical Assistant Professor, J. Guerrero;\nScholarly Assistant Professors, A. Jillepalli, S. Xie, B.\nZeng; Teaching Assistant Professor, C. Cole; Professors\nEmeriti, D. Bakken, T. Fischer, C. Hauser, G. Hower, G.\nLaRue (Associate), R. Olsen, J. Ringo.\nThe School of Electrical Engineering and\nComputer Science offers courses of study leading\nto the degrees of Bachelor of Science in Electrical\nEngineering, Computer Engineering, Software\nEngineering, or Computer Science, Bachelor of Arts\nin Computer Science, Master of Science in Electrical\nEngineering, Computer Engineering, or Computer\nScience, Doctor of Philosophy in Electrical and\nComputer Engineering, and Doctor of Philosophy\nin Computer Science. The programs of study leading\nto a bachelor of science in electrical engineering,\ncomputer engineering, or software engineering\nare accredited by the Engineering Accreditation\nCommission of ABET, http://www.abet.org. The\nbachelor of arts and bachelor of science computer\nscience programs are accredited by the Computing\nAccreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.\nabet.org. In collaboration with the College of Arts\nand Sciences, an interdisciplinary degree leading\nto the Bachelor of Science in Data Analytics is\nalso available (see Mathematics and Statistics for\ncomplete information).\nAll the undergraduate programs in the School\nof EECS have five educational objectives. The first\neducational objective varies slightly across our\ndegree programs: 1) Our graduates have professional\ncareers in the electrical engineering industry or\nacademia or are engaged in advanced studies\n(Electrical Engineering); 1) Our graduates have\nprofessional careers in the computer engineering\nindustry or academia or are engaged in advanced\nstudies (Computer Engineering); 1) Our graduates\nhave professional careers in the software engineering\nindustry or academia or are engaged in advanced\nstudies (Software Engineering); and 1) Our graduates\nhave professional careers in the computing industry\nor academia or are engaged in advanced studies (B.S.\nand B.A. Computer Science). The four remaining\neducational objectives are the same for all degree\nprograms: 2) Our graduates adapt to changes in\ntechnology as well as to the needs of society. 3) Our\ngraduates continue to seek knowledge to thrive in\nan increasingly globalized society. 4) Our graduates\nare successful team members or team leaders. 5)\nOur graduates conduct themselves with integrity\nand incorporate proper ethical considerations in\ntheir work.\nElectrical Engineering\nThe curriculum in electrical engineering\nis designed to give the student fundamental\nknowledge in the areas of general interest to\nall electrical engineers. The course of study is\ntherefore oriented toward the basic theory and\nconcepts which prepare students for entry into\nany of the many activities open to members of the\nprofession including research, design, development,\noperations, management, teaching, sales, and\nconsulting. Laboratory experience is emphasized\nto provide for familiarity with electrical, electronic\nand computing equipment and with experimental\ntechniques. Modern laboratories are available\nfor electrical circuits, electronics, power systems,\nwireless communications and computers. Students\nare exposed to a variety of up-to-date computing\nenvironments to aid in their studies.\nThe curriculum is designed so that the equivalent\nof the first three to four semesters may be transferred\nfrom community colleges with minimal difficulty.\nThe additional basic material common to all\nbranches of electrical engineering is concentrated\nin the junior year, and maximum flexibility is\npermitted in the senior year, allowing the student\nto develop a breadth of interest or to select an area of\nspecialty. The program offers a two-semester senior\ndesign project that typically involves industry\ncooperation, and provides students with valuable\nexperience in applying their skills to solve real-\nworld problems.\nElectrical Engineering Student Learning\nOutcomes\nStudents in electrical engineering will have\nacquired the following skills and knowledge by\nthe time of graduation: 1) an ability to identify,\nformulate, and solve complex engineering problems\nby applying principles of engineering, science, and\nmathematics; 2) an ability to apply engineering\ndesign to produce solutions that meet specified\nneeds with consideration of public health, safety,\nand welfare, as well as global, cultural, social,\nenvironmental, and economic factors; 3) an\nability to communicate effectively with a range\nof audiences; 4) an ability to recognize ethical\nand professional responsibilities in engineering\nsituations and make informed judgments, which\nmust consider the impact of engineering solutions\nin global, economic, environmental, and societal\ncontexts; 5) an ability to function effectively on a\nteam whose members together provide leadership,\ncreate a collaborative and inclusive environment,\nestablish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives;\n6) an ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions; 7)\nan ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\nComputer Engineering\nComputer engineering is a field of study\nthat encompasses the fundamental principles,\nmethods, and modern tools for the design and\nimplementation of computing systems. Advances\nin technology are yielding smaller and higher-\nperforming computer systems that appear in various\napplications, including communication systems,\nconsumer products, and household appliances\nto name just a few. The computer engineering\nprogram provides a balanced perspective of both\nhardware and software elements of computing\nsystems, and of their relative design trade-offs and\napplications. Computer engineering builds upon\nfundamental courses in mathematics, science, and\nthe engineering disciplines to achieve a sound\nknowledge foundation and to develop breadth.\nLaboratory experiences are emphasized to provide\nstudents with background on experimental design\nand simulation techniques. Since core course\nsequences are completed in the junior year, students\nare able to pursue their career objectives with\nopportunities to select from a broad range of elective\ncourses. These include computer engineering topics\nsuch as hardware design, VLSI design, embedded\nsystems, computer architecture, networking, and\noperating systems.\nThe program culminates with a two-semester\nsenior design project. The project involves industry\ncooperation and provides students with a major\ndesign experience addressing a broad range of issues,\nincluding technical subjects as well as economics,\nsafety, and ethical and societal considerations.\nComputer Engineering Student Learning\nOutcomes\nStudents in Computer Engineering will have\nacquired the following skills and knowledge\noutcomes by the time of graduation: 1) an ability to\nidentify, formulate, and solve complex engineering\nproblems by applying principles of engineering,\nscience, and mathematics; 2) an ability to apply\nengineering design to produce solutions that\nmeet specified needs with consideration of public\nhealth, safety, and welfare, as well as global, cultural,\nsocial, environmental, and economic factors; 3) an\nability to communicate effectively with a range\nof audiences; 4) an ability to recognize ethical\nand professional responsibilities in engineering\nsituations and make informed judgments, which\nmust consider the impact of engineering solutions\nin global, economic, environmental, and societal\ncontexts; 5) an ability to function effectively on a\nteam whose members together provide leadership,\ncreate a collaborative and inclusive environment,\nestablish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives;\n6) an ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions; 7)\nan ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\nComputer Science\nComputer science is a discipline that provides\na scientific foundation for computing expertise\nand skills. The curriculum is geared to provide\nthe fundamental computing concepts derived\nfrom mathematics and sciences, and the practical\napplication of these concepts through substantial\nhands-on course project experiences. The\ncoursework in computer science prepares students\nfor a variety of careers that involve the extensive\nuse of computers.\nThere are two major degrees offered within\nComputer Science: the BS in Computer Science,\nand the BA in Computer Science. Graduates in\nboth the degree programs will have a solid technical\nbackground in mathematics and sciences. The BS\ndegree requires substantial basic and advanced\ncomputer science course work and is the traditional\ncomputer science degree. The BA degree is designed\n\n174\nElectrical Engineering and Computer Science\nWashington State University, 2021\nfor multi-disciplinary students who wish to learn\nthe basics of computer science and apply it to a\ndifferent field. A minor in another area, such as art,\nbiochemistry, music, psychology, architecture, etc.,\nis encouraged.\nThe program offers courses in a wide variety of\ntopics including theory of computation, design\nand analysis of algorithms, software engineering,\noperating systems, computer networks and security,\ncomputer graphics, parallel and distributed systems,\nartificial intelligence, machine learning, and\ndatabase systems. The coursework is supplemented\nby several general purpose computing labs dedicated\nto computer science students, and specialized labs\nfor courses such as operating systems, software\nengineering, and computer networking. Option\narea course sequences allow students to specialize in\nspecific areas such as artificial intelligence, software\nengineering, data sciences, and computer systems.\nComputer Science Student Learning\nOutcomes\nStudents in computer science will have acquired\nthe following skills and knowledge by the time\nof graduation: 1) an ability to analyze a complex\ncomputing problem and apply principles of\ncomputing and other relevant disciplines to identify\nsolutions; 2) an ability to design, implement, and\nevaluate a computing-based solution to meet a given\nset of computing requirements in the context of the\nprogram’s discipline; 3) an ability to communicate\neffectively in a variety of professional contexts; 4) an\nability to recognize professional responsibilities and\nmake informed judgments in computing practice\nbased on legal and ethical principles; 5) an ability to\nfunction effectively as a member or leader of a team\nengaged in activities appropriate to the program’s\ndiscipline; 6) an ability to apply computer science\ntheory and software development fundamentals to\nproduce computing-based solutions; 7) an ability to\nacquire and apply new knowledge as needed, using\nappropriate learning strategies.\nSoftware Engineering\nSoftware engineering applies engineering\npractices to the development of software. The\nSoftware Engineering curriculum includes all\nthe core requirements of the Computer Science\nprogram, along with advanced courses in software\ndevelopment, testing and validation, maintenance,\nsecurity, and management and integration.\nStudents learn about the real world challenges\nand requirements of the software engineering\nprofession, such as delivering high quality software\nthat meets user expectations, delivering software on\ntime and within budget, maintaining software, and\nworking effectively as part of a team. The program\noffers a two-semester senior design project that\ntypically has an industry sponsor and provides\nstudents with valuable experience in applying their\nskills to the collaborative development of large-scale\nsoftware applications.\nSoftware Engineering Student Learning\nOutcomes\nStudents in software engineering will have\nacquired the following skills and knowledge by\nthe time of graduation: 1) an ability to identify,\nformulate, and solve complex engineering problems\nby applying principles of engineering, science, and\nmathematics; 2) an ability to apply engineering\ndesign to produce solutions that meet specified\nneeds with consideration of public health, safety,\nand welfare, as well as global, cultural, social,\nenvironmental, and economic factors; 3) an\nability to communicate effectively with a range\nof audiences; 4) an ability to recognize ethical\nand professional responsibilities in engineering\nsituations and make informed judgments, which\nmust consider the impact of engineering solutions\nin global, economic, environmental, and societal\ncontexts; 5) an ability to function effectively on a\nteam whose members together provide leadership,\ncreate a collaborative and inclusive environment,\nestablish goals, plan tasks, and meet objectives;\n6) an ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions; 7)\nan ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\nData Analytics\nAn interdisciplinary undergraduate degree in data\nanalytics is also available. See the Program in Data\nAnalytics for complete information.\nTransfer Students\nStudents planning to transfer from other\ninstitutions should carefully note the sequence\nof courses. Transfers from community colleges\nshould consult the information available on the\nUndergraduate Admission Web site or should write\ndirectly to the School of Electrical Engineering and\nComputer Science for specific information.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBACHELOR OF ARTS, COMPUTER SCIENCE\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents may be admitted to the Bachelor of Arts\nin Computer Science degree program in either the\nSchool of Electrical Engineering and Computer\nScience (Pullman), or in the School of Engineering\nand Applied Sciences (Tri-Cities). Admission\nrequirements are the same on all campuses, but the\napplication process may vary.\nStudents are admitted to the Computer Science\nmajor upon demonstrating they are calculus-\nready and making their intention known to the\ndepartment. Calculus-ready is defined as having\nan ALEKS math placement score of 83% or higher;\nor completion of MATH 108, and 171 or a higher\ncalculus course with a grade of C or better; or\ncompleting the Math AP with a score of 2 (places\nthe student in MATH 171), or 3 (credit is given for\nMATH 171); or achieving an IB score of HL 5; or\nachieving a CLEP score of 50.\nTo remain in good standing students must\ncomplete CPT S 121, 122, and 223, or CPT S 131,\n132, and 233, MATH 171, 172, 216, and PHYSICS\n201/211, each with a grade of C or better, and\nearn a cumulative WSU GPA of 2.5 or higher upon\ncompletion of the above courses.\nAlternate Pathway:\nCompletion of ALL standard pathway benchmarks\nand additionally: ENGLISH 101 or 105, CPT S 260,\nand MATH 273 or 301, all with a grade of C or better,\nand a 2.5 cumulative WSU GPA (or transfer GPA if\nno WSU GPA exists).\nNo courses listed in this schedule of study may\nbe taken on a pass/fail basis. With the exception\nof CPT S 488, 489, and ENGR 489 all listed E E and\nCPT S courses, required electives, and prerequisites\nto these courses must be completed with a grade\nof C or better.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCPT S 121 or 131\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 171 4\nPHIL 201 [QUAN] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCPT S 122 or 132\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 172 4\nMATH 216 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 223 or 233\n1 \n3\nCPT S 260 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMinor Elective\n2 \n3\nSTAT 212 or 360 3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nCPT S 355 3\nMATH 220 2\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 322 [M] 3\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] [M] 3\nMinor Electives (choose two)\n2 \n5 or 6\nScience Elective (with lab)\n3 \n4\nSecond Term Hours\n300-400-level Minor Elective\n2 \n3\nCPT S 302 3\nCPT S 317 3\nCPT S 360 or 370\n1 \n4\nScience Elective\n3 \n3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400-level Minor Elective\n2 \n3\nCPT S 350 3\nCPT S 421 \n4 \n3\nCPT S 427 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSecond Term Hours\n300-400-level Minor Elective\n2 \n3\nAdvanced CPT S Electives (choose two)\n5 \n6\nCPT S 423 [CAPS]\n4 \n3\nComplete CPT S Exit Interview and Survey\n_______\n\n175\nElectrical Engineering and Computer Science\nWashington State University, 2021\n1 \nStudents may choose between a C/C++ (CPTS 121,\n122, 223, 360) path or a Java programming (CPTS\n131, 132, 233, 370) path. Students should stick to\none path option. The Java track is not available in\nTri Cities.\n2 \nElective credits may include a minor program.\nCompletion of a minor is strongly encouraged.\n3 \nScience electives: A minimum of 15 credits\nrequired. Must include a year-long sequence (two\nsemesters including a laboratory in each semester)\nof [BSCI] or [PSCI], and two additional science\ncourses, one of which must have a laboratory\ncomponent. Electives include BIOLOGY 106, 107;\nCHEM 101, 102 or 105, 106; PHYSICS 101/111,\n102/112 or 201/211, 202/212.\n4 \nConsult with an advisor at campus of residence for\nallowed substitutions.\n5 \nAdvanced CPT S Electives: 6 credits required. These\ncredits must be in 300- or 400- or 500-level CPT S\ncourses and they must include at least one of the\nfollowing courses: CPT S 315, 415, 451, 471, or 475.\nA maximum of 3 credits from CPT S 490 and 499,\nor 3 credits from CPT S 488 or 499 may be selected\nas CPT S electives. Consult with advisor at campus\nof residence for course choices.\nBACHELOR OF SCIENCE, COMPUTER\nSCIENCE\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents are admitted to the Computer Science\nmajor upon demonstrating they are calculus-\nready and making their intention known to the\ndepartment. Calculus-ready is defined as having\nan ALEKS math placement score of 83% or higher;\nor completion of MATH 108, and 171 or a higher\ncalculus course with a grade of C or better; or\ncompleting the Math AP with a score of 2 (places\nthe student in MATH 171), or 3 (credit is given for\nMATH 171); or achieving an IB score of HL 5; or\nachieving a CLEP score of 50.\nTo remain in good standing students must\ncomplete CPT S 121, 122, and 223, or CPT S 131,\n132, and 233, MATH 171, 172, 216, and PHYSICS\n201/211, each with a grade of C or better, and\nearn a cumulative WSU GPA of 2.5 or higher upon\ncompletion of the above courses.\nAlternate Pathway:\nCompletion of ALL standard pathway benchmarks\nand additionally: ENGLISH 101, CHEM 105, CPT S\n260, and MATH 273 or 301, all with a grade of C or\nbetter, and a 2.5 cumulative WSU GPA (or transfer\nGPA if no WSU GPA exists).\nNo courses listed in this schedule of study may be\ntaken on a pass/fail basis. With the exception of CPT\nS 488, 490, 499, and ENGR 489, all listed E E and\nCPT S courses, required electives, and prerequisites\nto these courses must be completed with a grade\nof C or better.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 121 or 131\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nPHIL 201 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCPT S 122 or 132\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 172 4\nMATH 216 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 223 or 233\n1 \n3\nCPT S 260 3\nMATH 220 2\nMATH 273 or 301 2 or 3\nPHYSICS 201 [PSCI] 3\nPHYSICS 211 [PSCI] 1\nSecond Term Hours\nCPT S 317 3\nCPT S 322 [M] 3\nCPT S 355 3\nPHYSICS 202 3\nPHYSICS 212 1\nCPT S Technical Elective\n2 \n3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 302 3\nCPT S 350 3\nCPT S 360 or 370\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] [M] 3\nCPT S Technical Elective \n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nCPT S 427 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nSTAT 360 3\nComputer Science Electives\n3 \n6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCPT S 421 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI]\n4 \n3\nCPT S Technical Electives \n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences with Lab [BSCI] 4\nCPT S 423 [CAPS] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nComputer Science Electives\n3 \n6\nComplete CPT S Exit Interview and Survey\n_______\n1 \nStudents may choose between a C/C++ (CPT S 121,\n122, 223, 360) path or a Java programming (CPT S\n131, 132, 233, 370) path. A total of\n15 credits are required for each track. Any electives\nwithin a track must be chosen from the list of\napproved technical electives in footnote 3. Power\nTrack: required: E E 362 [M], 491, at least 6 credits\nfrom E E 486, 489, 492, 493, 494, and remaining\ncredits from list of approved technical electives;\nMicroelectronics Track: required: E E 351, 476, 496,\nand at least two from E E 431, 434, 464, 466, 488,\n489, 499, with a maximum of 3 credits from 488\nand 499 combined; Systems Track: required: E E 464,\n489, at least one from E E 432, 451, and one from E E\n351, 431, 432, 451, 470, and remaining credits from\nlist of approved technical electives; General Track: at\nleast one from E E 324 [M], 351, 362 [M], 489, and\nremaining credits from list of approved technical\nelectives with a minimum of nine credits 400-level E\nE courses; or Computer Engineering Track: required:\nE E 434, 466, at least one from E E 324 [M], 334, 431,\n476, CPT S 360, and remaining credits from list of\napproved technical electives with a minimum of\nthree credits 400-level E E courses.\n3 \nTechnical Electives approved for Power Track,\nSystems Track, General Track (minimum 9 credits\n400-level E E courses), and Computer Engineering\nTrack (minimum 3 credits 400-level E E courses)\ninclude: ASTRONOM 435, CE 463, CHEM 331, 333,\n345, MATH 320 [M], 325, 340, 364, 401 [M], 402\n[M], 415, 420, 421 [M], 440, 441, 448, 453, 464,\n466, ME 304, 401, MSE 402, 403, PHYSICS 303, 304,\n320, 443, 450, and 463, or any 300-400-level CPT S\nor E E course not used to fulfill other requirements.\nSOFTWARE ENGINEERING\n(121 HOURS)\nStudents are admitted to the Software Engineering\nmajor upon demonstrating they are calculus-\nready and making their intention known to the\ndepartment. Calculus-ready is defined as having\nan ALEKS math placement score of 83% or higher;\nor completion of MATH 108, and 171 or a higher\ncalculus course with a grade of C or better; or\ncompleting the Math AP with a score of 2 (places\nthe student in MATH 171), or 3 (credit is given for\nMATH 171); or achieving an IB score of HL 5; or\nachieving a CLEP score of 50.\nTo remain in good standing students must\ncomplete CPT S 121, 122, and 223, or CPT S 131,\n132, and 233, MATH 171, 172, 216, and PHYSICS\n201/211 or CHEM 105, each with a grade of C or\n\n177\nElectrical Engineering and Computer Science\nWashington State University, 2021\nbetter, and earn a cumulative WSU GPA of 2.5 or\nhigher upon completion of the above courses.\nAlternate Pathway (Everett students follow this\npathway):\nCompletion of ALL standard pathway benchmarks,\nexcept CPT S 223/233, and additionally: ECONS 101\nor 102, ENGLISH 101 or 105, MATH 220, and two\nof MATH 273 301, PHIL 201 or STAT 212, all with\na grade of C or better, and a 2.5 cumulative WSU\nGPA (or transfer GPA if no WSU GPA exists). Everett\napplicants follow the alternate pathway.\nNo courses listed in this schedule of study may\nbe taken on a pass/fail basis. All listed E E and CPT\nS courses, required electives, and prerequisites to\nthese courses must be completed with a grade of\nC or better.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 121 or CPT S 131\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] or 105 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nMath Requirement\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nCPT S 122 or CPT S 132\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 172 4\nMATH 216 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 223 or CPT S 233\n1 \n3\nCPT S 260 3\nMATH 220 2\nMath Requirement\n2 \n2 or 3\nPHYSICS 201/211 [PSCI] or CHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCPT S 321 3\nCPT S 355 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or ECONS 102 [SSCI] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 302 3\nCPT S 317 3\nCPT S 322 [M] 3\nCPT S 360 or CPT S 370\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] or 403 [WRTG] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Science [BSCI] 3\nCPT S 350 3\nCPT S 487 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMATH/CPT S 453 or STAT 419 3\nSTAT 360 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCPT S 421 3\nCPT S 422 [M] 3\nCPT S 427 3\nCPT S 484 3\nSoftware Engineering Option Course\n3 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nCPT S 423 [CAPS] 3\nCPT S 476 3\nData and Information Management Elective\n4 \n3\nSoftware Engineering Option Courses\n3 \n6\nComplete CPT E Exit Interview and Survey\n_______\n1 \nStudents may choose between a C/C++ (CPT S 121,\n122, 223, 360) path or a Java programming (CPT S\n131, 132, 233, 370) path. Students should stick to\none path option. The Java track is not available in\nTri-Cities.\n2 \nMath Requirement: minimum 5 credits from the\nfollowing: MATH 273, MATH 301, PHIL 201, STAT\n212.\n3 \nSoftware Engineering Option Courses (9 credits\nrequired): Any 400 level course in CPT S, E E, or\nMATH not used to fulfill major requirements.\nUpper-division courses in other disciplines may be\nused with prior approval by advisor.\n4 \nData and Information Management Elective (3\ncredits required): Choose at least one from CPT S\n315, 415, 451, 471, 475.\nMinors\nComputer Engineering\nThe minor in computer engineering consists\nof a minimum of 18 credits, 9 of which must be\n300-400-level taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses. Required courses include CPT\nS 223 or 233, E E 214, E E 234, and E E 324, and\n6 credits from any 300-400-level CPT S course\n(excluding CPT S 302), E E 334, 434, or 466. All\nprerequisites for these courses must be met. Each\nstudent’s program of study requires approval\nof the computer engineering undergraduate\ncoordinator. For all courses and their prerequisites,\na grade of C or better is required to complete the\nminor.\nComputer Science\nThe minor in computer science consists of 20 credits\nwhich must include CPT S 121, 122, and 223, or CPT\nS 131, 132, and 233; and three 300-400-level CPT\nS courses, taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses, excluding CPT S 302 and 401.\nAll prerequisites for courses in the minor must be\nmet. The minor program must be approved by the\ncomputer science undergraduate coordinator. For\nall courses and their prerequisites, a grade of C or\nbetter is required to complete the minor.\nElectrical Engineering\nThe minor in electrical engineering consists of 18\ncredit hours, 9 of which must be 300-400-level\nand taken in residence at WSU or through WSU-\napproved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses. The 18 credits must include\nthe following courses: E E 214, 261, and 262.\nThe remaining credits must be selected from any\n300-400-level E E courses excluding E E 302 and E\nE 304. All prerequisites for minor courses must be\nmet. The minor program must be approved by the\nelectrical engineering undergraduate coordinator.\nFor all courses and their prerequisites, a grade of C\nor better is required to complete the minor.\nSoftware Engineering\nThe minor in Software Engineering consists of\n20 credits from CPT S 121, 122, 223 (or CPT S\n131, 132, 233) and three 300-400-level courses\nchosen from CPT S 321, 322, 422, 476, 478, 484,\nor 487. A maximum of 8 course credits from the\nrequirements of the student’s major can be used\nto satisfy the requirements of the minor. 9 hours\nmust be 300-400-level courses taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. For all courses and\ntheir prerequisites, a grade of C or better is required\nto complete the minor.\nDescription of Courses\nCOMPUTER SCIENCE\nWith the exception of the Computer Skills and Literacy\ncourses, enrollment in 300-400-level computer science\ncourses is restricted to admitted majors or minors in\ncomputer science, computer engineering, or electrical\nengineering, and to juniors and seniors admitted to\nother degree programs requiring these computer science\ncourses.\nCPT S\n111 [QUAN] Introduction to Computer\nProgramming 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 101 with a C or better, MATH 103 with\na C or better, or higher level MATH course\nwith a C or better, or a minimum ALEKS\nmath placement score of 45%. Elementary\nalgorithmic problem solving, computational\nmodels, sequential, iterative and conditional\noperations, parameterized procedures, array\nand list structures and basic efficiency analysis.\n121 Program Design and Development C/\nC++ 4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite: MATH 108,\n171, 172, 182, 201, 202, 206, or 220, each\nwith a C or better, or a minimum ALEKS\nmath placement score of 80%, or adequate\nCPT S placement test score determined by the\ndepartment. Formulation of problems and\ntop-down design of programs in a modern\nstructured language (C/C++) for their solution\non a digital computer.\n122 Data Structures C/C++ 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: CPT S 121 with a C or better.\nAdvanced programming techniques: data\nstructures, recursion, sorting and searching,\nand basics of algorithm analysis taught in C/\nC++ programming language.\n131 Program Design and Development Java\n4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite: Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 108, 171, 172, 182, 201, 202, 206, or\n220, each with a C or better, or ALEKS math\nplacement score of 80% or higher, or adequate\nCPT S placement test score determined by the\ndepartment. Formulation of problems and\ntop-down design of programs in a modern\nstructured language for their solution on a\ndigital computer. Taught in Java programming\nlanguage.\n\n178\nElectrical Engineering and Computer Science\nWashington State University, 2021\n132 Data Structures Java 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: CPT S 131 with a C or better.\nAdvanced programming techniques: data\nstructures, recursion, sorting and searching,\nand basics of algorithm analysis. Taught in\nJava programming language.\n215 Data Analytics Systems and Algorithms\n3 Course Prerequisite: CPT S 122, CPT S 132, or\nCS 122. Exploration of fundamental concepts,\nconstructs, and techniques of modern data\nanalytics systems. (Crosslisted course offered\nas CPT S 215, CS 215).\n223 Advanced Data Structures C/C++ 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CPT S 122 with a C or better;\nMATH 216 with a C or better or concurrent\nenrollment. Advanced data structures, object\noriented programming concepts, concurrency,\nand program design principles taught in C/C++\nprogramming language.\n224 Programming Tools 2 Course Prerequisite:\nCPT S 122 with a C or better, or CPT S 132\nwith a C or better. Debugging tools, scripting\nlanguages, UNIX programming tools.\n233 Advanced Data Structures Java 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CPT S 132 with a C or better;\nMATH 216 with a C or better or concurrent\nenrollment. Advanced data structures, object\noriented programming concepts, concurrency,\nand program design principles. Taught in Java\nprogramming language.\n260 Introduction to Computer Architecture\n3 Course Prerequisite: CPT S 223 with a C or\nbetter or concurrent enrollment, or CPT S 233\nwith a C or better or concurrent enrollment.\nComputer systems architecture; logic, data\nrepresentation, assembly language, memory\norganization and trends.\n302 Professional Skills in Computing and\nEngineering 3 Course Prerequisite: CPT S\n122 or 132, OR CPT S 121 or 131 and E E 261;\nadmitted to a major in Computer Science,\nComputer Engineering, Electrical Engineering,\nSoftware Engineering, or Data Analytics;\njunior standing. Foundation in computing\nand engineering professional development.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CPT S 302, E E\n302). Credit not granted for both CPT S/E E\n302 and CPT S 401.\n315 Introduction to Data Mining 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CPT S 215, 223, 233, or CS 315,\nwith a C or better; admitted to the major\nor minor in Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, Electrical Engineering, Software\nEngineering, or Data Analytics. The process\nof automatically extracting valid, useful, and\npreviously unknown information from large\nrepositories. (Crosslisted course offered as CPT\nS 315, CS 315).\n317 Automata and Formal Languages 3\nCourse Prerequisite: CPT S 122 or 132, with\na C or better; MATH 216 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Computer\nScience, Computer Engineering, Electrical\nEngineering, Software Engineering, or Data\nAnalytics. Finite automata, regular sets,\npushdown automata, context-free language,\nTuring machines and the halting problem.\n321 Object-Oriented Software Principles 3\nCourse Prerequisite: CPT S 223 or 233, with\na C or better; admitted to the major or minor\nin Computer Science, Computer Engineering,\nElectrical Engineering, Software Engineering, or\nData Analytics. Object-oriented programming\nfor flexibility, efficiency, and maintainability;\nlogic and UI decoupling; complexity analysis,\ndata structures, and algorithms for industry-\nquality software.\n322 [M] Software Engineering Principles\nI 3 Course Prerequisite: CPT S 215, 223, or\n233, with a C or better; admitted to the major\nor minor in Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, Electrical Engineering, Software\nEngineering, or Data Analytics. Introduction\nto software engineering; requirements analysis,\ndefinition, specification including formal\nmethods; prototyping; design including object\nand function oriented design.\n323 Software Design 3 Course Prerequisite: CPT\nS 223 or 233, with a C or better; CPT S 322\nwith a C or better or concurrent enrollment;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Cpt Sci,\nCpt Engr, E E, Swr Engr, or Data Analytics.\nEnrollment not allowed if credit earned in CPT\nS 487. Practical aspects of software design and\nimplementation using object-oriented, aspect-\noriented and procedural programming. Credit\nnot granted for both CPT S 323 and 487.\n350 Design and Analysis of Algorithms 3\nCourse Prerequisite: CPT S 215, 223, or 233,\nwith a C or better; CPT S 317 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Computer\nScience, Computer Engineering, Electrical\nEngineering, Software Engineering, or Data\nAnalytics. Analysis of data structures and\nalgorithms; computational complexity and\ndesign of efficient data-handling procedures.\n355 Programming Language Design 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CPT S 223 or 233, with a C or\nbetter; admitted to the major or minor in\nComputer Science, Computer Engineering,\nElectrical Engineering, Software Engineering,\nor Data Analytics. Design concepts of high-\nlevel programming languages; survey of\nexisting languages, experience using some\nlanguages.\n360 Systems Programming C/C++ 4 (3-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: CPT S 223 with a C or better;\nCPT S 260 with a C or better or E E 234 with\na C or better; admitted to the major or minor\nin Computer Science, Computer Engineering,\nElectrical Engineering, Software Engineering,\nor Data Analytics. Implementation of systems\nprograms, concepts of computer operating\nsystems; laboratory experience in using\noperating system facilities taught in C/C++\nprogramming language.\n370 Systems Programming Java 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: CPT S 233 with a C or better; CPT\nS 260 with a C or better or E E 234 with a C\nor better; admitted to the major or minor in\nComputer Science, Computer Engineering,\nElectrical Engineering, Software Engineering,\nor Data Analytics. Implementation of systems\nprograms, concepts of computer operating\nsystems; laboratory experience in using\noperating system facilities. Taught in Java\nprogramming language.\n401 C o m p u t e r s a n d S o c i e t y 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CPT S 215, 223, or 233; admitted\nto the major in Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, Electrical Engineering, Software\nEngineering, or Data Analytics; junior\nstanding. Skills and literacy course. Ethical\nand societal issues related to computers and\ncomputer networks; computers as enabling\ntechnology; computer crime, software theft,\nprivacy, viruses, worms. Credit not granted for\nboth CPT S 401 and CPT S/E E 302.\n411 Introduction to Parallel Computing 3\nCourse Prerequisite: CPT S 215, 223, or 233,\nwith a C or better; admitted to the major\nor minor in Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, Electrical Engineering, Software\nEngineering, or Data Analytics. Fundamental\nprinciples of parallel computing, parallel\nprogramming experience on multicore\nmachines and cluster computers, and design\nof algorithms and applications in parallel\ncomputing. Recommended preparation: CPT\nS 350.\n415 Big Data 3 Course Prerequisite: CPT S 215,\n223, or 233, with a C or better; admitted to\nthe major or minor in Computer Science,\nComputer Engineering, Electrical Engineering,\nSoftware Engineering, or Data Analytics. Big\ndata models, databases and query languages,\nmodern distributed database systems and\nalgorithms. (Crosslisted course offered as CPT\nS 415, CS 415).\n421 Software Design Project I 3 (1-6) Course\nPrerequisite: C or better in CPT S 321 and 322;\nor C or better in CPT S 322 and CPT S 360 or\n370; or C or better CPT S 322 and concurrent\nenrollment in CPT S 360 or 370; admitted\nmajor or minor in Cpt S, Cpt Engr, E E, Sftwr\nEngr, or Data Anlytc. System and propagation\nissues for wireless telecommunications;\ncellular, PCS, microwave, and satellite system\nanalysis, design, measurement, and testing.\n434 ASIC and Digital Systems Design 3 (2-\n3) Course Prerequisite: E E 234 with a C or\nbetter; E E 321 with a C or better; admitted to\nthe major or minor in Electrical Engineering,\nComputer Science, Computer Engineering,\nor Software Engineering. Application Specific\nIntegrated Circuit and Digital System Design\nmethods, semi-custom, full-custom, and\nfield-programmable devices; digital system\narchitectures, electronics, and tests.\n439 Critical Infrastr ucture Security:\nThe Emerging Smart Grid 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Senior standing. Smart electric\ngrid, communication networks, distributed\ncomputing, fault tolerant computing, cyber\nsecurity, analyzing interdependencies between\nthe smart grid components, smart grid\nstandards and protocols. (Crosslisted course\noffered as E E 439, CPT S 439).\n451 Digital Communication Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 341 with a C or better, STAT 360\nwith a C or better, or STAT 443 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Electrical\nEngineering, Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, or Software Engineering. Digital\ncommunication techniques; performance\nof digital communication systems in noise;\nmatched filter detection; quantization.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n455 Introduction to Computer Networks 3\nCourse Prerequisite: CPT S 360, 370, or E E\n234, with a C or better; admitted to the major\nor minor in Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, Electrical Engineering, Software\nEngineering, or Data Analytics. (Crosslisted course\noffered as CPT S 455, E E 455).\n464 Digital Signal Processing I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 341 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Electrical\nEngineering, Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, or Software Engineering. Discrete\nand fast Fourier transforms; Z-transform;\nsampling; discrete convolution; digital filter\ndesign; effects of quantization.\n466 VLSI Design 3 Course Prerequisite: E E 234\nwith a C or better; admitted to the major or\nminor in Electrical Engineering, Computer\nScience, Computer Engineering, or Software\nEngineering. Very Large Scale Integrated\ncircuit, system and physical design using CAD\nsoftware; project specification, modeling,\nimplementation, documentation and\nreporting.\n\n183\nElectrical Engineering and Computer Science\nWashington State University, 2021\n476 Analog Integrated Circuits 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 311 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Electrical\nEngineering, Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, or Software Engineering. Analysis\nand design of analog integrated circuits in\nCMOS and BiCMOS technologies; current\nmirrors, gain stages, operational amplifiers,\nfrequency response, and compensation. Credit\nnot granted for both E E 476 and 576.\n483 Topics in Electrical and Computer\nEngineering V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Current\ntopics in electrical engineering and computer\nengineering.\n485 Electric Energy Distribution Systems\n3 Course Prerequisite: E E 361 with a C or\nbetter; admitted to the major or minor in\nElectrical Engineering, Computer Science,\nC o m p u t e r E n g i n e e r i n g , o r S o f t w a r e\nEngineering. Fundamentals of distribution\nsystems engineering, distribution system\nmodeling and analysis, distribution load flow\nanalysis, voltage regulation, recent advances in\ndistribution automation.\n486 Power Electronics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nE E 361 with a C or better; admitted to the\nmajor or minor in Electrical Engineering,\nComputer Science, Computer Engineering, or\nSoftware Engineering. S, F\ngrading.\n489 Introduction to Control Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 341 with a C or better or\nconcurrent enrollment; admitted to the major\nor minor in Electrical Engineering, Computer\nScience, Computer Engineering, or Software\nEngineering. State variable models, system\nresponse, stability analysis, root locus analysis\nand design; frequency-response and state-space\nanalysis and design.\n491 Performance of Power Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 361 with a C or better;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Electrical\nEngineering, Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, or Software Engineering. Static\nand dynamic behavior of power systems,\npowerflow, and economic considerations.\n492 Renewable Energy Sources 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: E E 361 with a C or better or\nconcurrent enrollment; admitted to the\nmajor or minor in Electrical Engineering,\nComputer Science, Computer Engineering,\nor Software Engineering.
