Analysis\nand equipment fundamentals of power system\nprotection; symmetrical components, fault\ncalculations; fuses; and relays including burden\ncalculations.\n494 Protective Relay Labs 3 (1-6) Course\nPrerequisite: E E 361 with a C or better; E E 493\nwith a C or better or concurrent enrollment;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Electrical\nEngineering, Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, or Software Engineering.\nExperiments and measurements of protective\nrelay equipment under test, simulated fault\nand fault conditions.\n495 Internship in Electrical Industry V\n2-4 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 8 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nElectrical Engineering major; by permission\nonly. Students work full time on engineering\nassignments in approved industries. S, F\ngrading.\n496 S e m i c o n d u c t o r D e v i c e s 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: CHEM 105, 4 credits of PHYSICS\n202, or PHYSICS 202 and 212; admitted to\nthe major or minor in Electrical Engineering,\nComputer Science, Computer Engineering, or\nSoftware Engineering. Equilibrium statistics\nof electrons and holes; carrier dynamics; p-n\njunctions, metal-semiconductor junctions,\nBJTs, Mosfets, solar cells, and LEDs.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n501 Linear System Theory 3 Dynamic systems\nfrom the state variable approach; observability,\ncontrollability, stability, and sensitivity of\ndifferential and nondifferential systems.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n502 Linear Multivariable Control 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 501. Optimal linear feedback\ncontrol, optimal stochastic observers, LQG/LTR\ndesign methodology, modern Wiener-Hopf\ndesign, robust controllers. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n503 Structure, Dynamics and Control of\nLarge-scale Networks 3 Course Prerequisite:\nE E 501; E E 507. Introduction and development\nof computational and analytical methods\nrequired to characterize large-scale networks.\n504 Modern Optics 3 Diffraction theory, Fourier\ntransforming and imaging properties of lenses,\nspatial filtering, holography, temporal and\nspatial coherence, imaging through random\nmedia. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n505 Nonlinear System Theory 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 501. Overview of nonlinear\nphenomena, Lyapunov stability, input-output\nstability, periodic orbits, singular perturbation,\ndifferential geometric methods, bifurcations\nand complex behaviors. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n507 Random Processes in Engineering 3\nFunctions of random variables; random\nsequences; stochastic processes; mean-square\nstochastic calculus; ergodicity; spectral density;\nlinear transformations, filtering, dynamic\nsystems. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n508 Estimation Theory for Signal Processing,\nCommunications, and Control 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 501; E E 507. Principles of\nstatistical estimation; LLSE; Kalman filtering;\nsmoothing; prediction; maximum- likelihood\nand Bayesian estimation. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n509 Adaptive Control 3 Course Prerequisite: E E\n501. Model reference adaptive systems (MRAS),\nadaptive observers, adaptive control, on-line\nidentification, robustness issues, self-tuning\nregulators.\n511 Protection of Power Systems II 3\nProtection of electrical equipment as related\nto electric power systems with emphasis on\ndigital algorithms. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n518 Advanced Electromagnetic Theory I\n3 Electromagnetic waves, electromagnetic\ntheorems and concepts, solutions to the\nwave equation in rectangular, cylindrical and\nspherical coordinates. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n520 Plasma Engineering 3 Electromagnetics,\nkinetic theory, and fluid mechanics of plasmas\nin space, arcs, plasma processing, coronas, and\nfusion reactors.\n521 Analysis of Power Systems 3 Concepts\nand practices of modern power engineering,\nincluding steady-state and dynamic analysis,\neconomics and control design.\n522 High Voltage Engineering 3 High voltage\nengineering concepts and techniques that\nfacilitate design, research, and development\nof modern electric power apparatus and\ninterconnected components.\n523 Power Systems Stability and Control 3\nCourse Prerequisite: E E 521 with a B- or better.\nDynamic analysis of interconnected electric\npower system; modeling of synchronous\ngenerators, loads and transmission network;\nsmall-signal stability and transient stability\nanalysis; dynamic stability controls.\nRecommended preparation: E E 489 with a B-\nor better.\n\n184\nElectrical Engineering and Computer Science\nWashington State University, 2021\n524 Advanced Computer Architecture 3\nInstruction set architectures, pipelining and\nsuper pipelining, instruction level parallelism,\nsuperscalar and VLIW processors, cache\nmemory, thread-level parallelism and VLSI.\n(Crosslisted course offered as E E 524, CPT S\n561).\n525 Power System Applications of Power\nElectronics 3 Course Prerequisite: E E 521.\nPower electronic converters in modern power\nsystems, FACTS devices, HVDC, compensation;\nmicrogrids and integration renewable energy\nresources; modeling and control.\n526 High Voltage Overhead Transmission\nLines 3 Course Prerequisite: Graduate\nstanding in Electrical Engineering. Electrical\nanalysis, performance, and design of high\nvoltage transmission lines; power capacity,\nelectromagnetic environment, electromagnetic\ncompatibility, measurements, grounding.\n527 Antenna Theory and Design 3 Antenna\nfundamentals, analytical techniques,\ncharacteristics and design procedures for\nselected types of wire, broadband, and aperture\nantennas. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n528 Advanced Topics in Electromagnetics\n3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Advanced topics of current\ninterest in wave propagation (electromagnetics,\nacoustics, or optics).\n529 Power Quality 3 Existing and future power\nquality issues, including identification,\nmeasurement, and mitigation; power quality\ndefinitions, standards, and classification;\nvoltage quality; power systems harmonics;\nDER integration; and emerging power quality\nconcerns. Recommended preparation: E E 491\nor equivalent.\n530 Digital Signal Processing II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 507. Frequency selective\ndigital filtering, least-squares filtering,\nadaptive filtering, multirate signal processing.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n535 Numerical Solutions to EM Problems\n3 Theory and use of finite-difference time-\ndomain; numeric dispersion; absorbing\nboundary conditions; scattering; radiation;\ntime-domain vs. frequency-domain.\n536 P o w e r S y s t e m s E c o n o m i c s a n d\nElectricity Markets 3 Economic dispatch\nand optimal power flow; electricity market;\nshort-term load forecasting; electricity price\nforecasting; price-based unit commitment;\narbitrage in electricity markets; market power\nanalysis.\n545 Data Compression 3 Course Prerequisite: E\nE 507. Source coding with a fidelity criterion;\nquantization theory; predictive, transform and\nsubband coding; noiseless source codes.\n548 Information Theory and Channel Coding\n3 Course Prerequisite: E E 507. Information\ntheory; entropy, mutual information, source\nand channel coding theorems, channel\ncapacity, Gaussian channels; channel coding:\nblock and convolutional codes.\n551 Data Communication Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: E E 507. (Crosslisted course offered as\nCPT S 562, E E 562).\n571 Advanced Wireless Integrated Circuits\nand Systems 3 Analysis and design\nmethodologies of state-of-the-art wireless\nintegrated circuits and systems.\n576 Analog Integrated Circuits 3 Analysis and\ndesign of analog integrated circuits in CMOS\nand BiCMOS technologies; current mirrors,\ngain stages, operational amplifiers, frequency\nresponse, and compensation. Credit not\ngranted for both E E 476 and 576.\n581 Advanced Topics in Power Systems V\n2-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite: E E\n521. Jordan\nThe School of Engineering and Applied Sciences\n(SEAS) offers undergraduate programs leading to the\ndegrees of Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering\n(BSCE), Computer Science (BSCS), Electrical\nEngineering (BSEE), and Mechanical Engineering\n(BSME); and Bachelor of Arts in Computer Science\n(BACS).\nAt the graduate level SEAS offers programs\nleading to the Master of Science degree in Computer\nScience, Electrical Engineering, Environmental\n\n185\nEngineering and Architecture\nWashington State University, 2021\nEngineering, and Mechanical Engineering. Students\ninterested in earning a Master of Science degree in\nCivil Engineering, or a Doctor of Philosophy degree\nin Civil Engineering, Computer Science, Electrical\nEngineering, or Mechanical Engineering should\napply for admission to the corresponding Pullman\nprogram and state in their application an intention\nto reside on the Tri-Cities campus.\nCIVIL ENGINEERING\nThe BSCE program is accredited by the Engineering\nAccreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.\nabet.org.\nThe education objectives for the BSCE program\nare:\n• Graduates are engaged in civil engineering\ncareers in industry, government or academia, or\npursuing advanced studies;\n• Graduates are successful team members or team\nleaders who conduct themselves with integrity and\nhigh standards of ethics;\n• Graduates demonstrate competence and ongoing\ndevelopment of their professional skills to adapt to\nchanges in technology and the needs of a globalized\nsociety.\nThe student learning outcomes for the BSCE\nprogram are that graduates will attain:\n• An ability to identify, formulate, and solve\ncomplex engineering problems by applying\nprinciples of engineering, science, and mathematics\n• An ability to apply engineering design to\nproduce solutions that meet specified needs with\nconsideration of public health, safety, and welfare,\nas well as global, cultural, social, environmental,\nand economic factors\n• An ability to communicate effectively with a\nrange of audiences\n• An ability to recognize ethical and professional\nresponsibilities in engineering situations and\nmake informed judgments, which must consider\nthe impact of engineering solutions in global,\neconomic, environmental, and societal contexts\n• An ability to function effectively on a team\nwhose members together provide leadership, create\na collaborative and inclusive environment, establish\ngoals, plan tasks, and meet objectives\n• An ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions\n• An ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies\nCOMPUTER SCIENCE\nThe BSCptS and BACptS programs are accredited by\nthe Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET,\nhttp://www.abet.org.\nThe education objectives for both the BSCS and\nBACS programs are:\n• Our graduates have professional careers in\nindustry or academia or are engaged in advanced\nstudies.\n• Our graduates keep abreast and adapt to changes\nin technology as well as the needs of a globalized\nsociety.\n• Our graduates are successful team members or\nteam leaders who conduct themselves with integrity\nand act ethically.\nThe student learning outcomes for both the BSCS\nand BACS programs are that graduates will be able\nto:\n• Analyze a complex computing problem and\napply principles of computing and other relevant\ndisciplines to identify solutions.\n• Design, implement, and evaluate a computing-\nbased solution to meet a given set of computing\nrequirements in the context of the program’s\ndiscipline.\n• Communicate effectively in a variety of\nprofessional contexts.\n• Recognize professional responsibilities and make\ninformed judgments in computing practice based\non legal and ethical principles.an understanding of\nprofessional, ethical, legal, security, and social issues\nand responsibilities\n• Function effectively as a member or leader of\na team engaged in activities appropriate to the\nprogram’s discipline\n• Apply computer science theory and software\ndevelopment fundamentals to produce computing-\nbased solutions\n• Acquire and apply new knowledge as needed,\nusing appropriate learning strategies.\nELECTRICAL ENGINEERING\nThe BSEE program is accredited by the Engineering\nAccreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.\nabet.org.\nThe education objectives for the BSEE program\nare:\n• Our graduates have professional careers in\nindustry or academia or are engaged in advanced\nstudies.\n• Our graduates keep abreast of, and adapt to,\nchanges in technology as well as the needs of a\nglobalized society\n• Our graduates are successful team members or\nteam leaders who conduct themselves with integrity\nand act ethically.\nThe student learning outcomes for the BSEE\nprogram are that graduates will attain:\n• An ability to identify, formulate, and solve\ncomplex engineering problems by applying\nprinciples of engineering, science, and mathematics\n• An ability to apply engineering design to\nproduce solutions that meet specified needs with\nconsideration of public health, safety, and welfare,\nas well as global, cultural, social, environmental,\nand economic factors\n• An ability to communicate effectively with a\nrange of audiences\n• An ability to recognize ethical and professional\nresponsibilities in engineering situations and\nmake informed judgments, which must consider\nthe impact of engineering solutions in global,\neconomic, environmental, and societal contexts\n• An ability to function effectively on a team\nwhose members together provide leadership, create\na collaborative and inclusive environment, establish\ngoals, plan tasks, and meet objectives\n• An ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions\n• An ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies\nMECHANICAL ENGINEERING\nThe BSME program is accredited by the Engineering\nAccreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.\nabet.org.\nThe education objectives for the BSME program\nare:\n• Graduates will be involved in the practice of\nengineering or in pursuit of graduate studies.\n• Graduates will perform successfully as members\nof professional teams in the global arena.\n• Graduates will function professionally and\ncontinuously improve their professional skills.\nThe student learning outcomes for the BSME\nprogram are that graduates will attain:\n• An ability to identify, formulate, and solve\ncomplex engineering problems by applying\nprinciples of engineering, science, and mathematics\n• An ability to apply engineering design to\nproduce solutions that meet specified needs with\nconsideration of public health, safety, and welfare,\nas well as global, cultural, social, environmental,\nand economic factors\n• An ability to communicate effectively with a\nrange of audiences\n• An ability to recognize ethical and professional\nresponsibilities in engineering situations and\nmake informed judgments, which must consider\nthe impact of engineering solutions in global,\neconomic, environmental, and societal contexts\n• An ability to function effectively on a team\nwhose members together provide leadership, create\na collaborative and inclusive environment, establish\ngoals, plan tasks, and meet objectives\n• An ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions\n• An ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies\nCOURSES AND DEGREE REQUIREMENTS:\nThe listing for the courses and degree requirements\nfor the BS in Civil Engineering may be found in\nthis catalog under the Department of Civil and\nEnvironmental Engineering.\nCourses and degree requirements for the BA in\nComputer Science, the BS in Computer Science, and\nthe BS in Electrical Engineering may be found in this\ncatalog under the School of Electrical Engineering\nand Computer Science.\nCourses and degree requirements for the BS in\nMechanical Engineering may be found under the\nSchool of Mechanical and Materials Engineering.\nVoiland College of\nEngineering and\nArchitecture\nvcea.wsu.edu/\nCarpenter Hall 526\n509-335-5593\nDean and Professor, M. Rezac; Associate Dean for\nResearch and Graduate Studies and Professor, D.\nField; Associate Dean for International Programs and\nProfessor, J. Iannelli; Associate Dean for Academic\nAffairs and Associate Professor, K. Sivakumar;\nAssociate Dean for Student Success and Associate\nResearch Professor, S. Pressley.\nThe Voiland College of Engineering and\nArchitecture offers degree programs through its\nSchool of Design and Construction, the Gene and\nLinda Voiland School of Chemical Engineering\nand Bioengineering, the Department of Civil\nand Environmental Engineering, the School of\n\n186\nEngineering and Architecture\nWashington State University, 2021\nElectrical Engineering and Computer Science, the\nSchool of Engineering and Applied Sciences (Tri-\nCities), the School of Engineering and Computer\nScience (Vancouver), and the School of Mechanical\nand Materials Engineering. In addition, as listed\nbelow, the college offers ENGR courses relevant to\nseveral degree programs. A minor is available to\nall non-engineering majors at the university. The\nminor provides an understanding of the ways in\nwhich engineering can be applied to solve real-\nworld problems.\nSupplementing the curriculum, the Voiland\nCollege Professional Practice and Experiential\nLearning Office (ProPEL) guides students in what\nit means to be a professional, to act professionally\nand to develop real-world skills. Professional\npractice and experiential learning partnerships in\nindustry help Voiland students apply knowledge\nacquired in the classroom to real-world situations,\ndevelop critical thinking skills, clarify the\nattitudes about careers in their field, and improve\nprofessional soft skills. The Voiland College\nInternships and Career Services Office, home to\nthe ProPEL program, provides guidance on search\nstrategies for internships, cooperative education,\nindustry mentoring, apprenticeships, practicums,\nand research experiences, both domestic and\ninternational.\nMinors\nEngineering\nThe College of Engineering and Architecture offers\na minor in engineering. The minor in engineering\nrequires 17 hours, 9 of which must be upper-\ndivision taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses. Students must complete MATH\n172 and PHYSICS 201 to be admitted to a minor in\nEngineering and enrolling in any upper-division\nengineering courses. Courses must be selected\nfrom the following prefixes: BIO ENG, CHE, CE,\nENGR, E E, ME, and MSE. With the approval of\nthe Associate Dean for Undergraduate Programs and\nStudent Services, up to 3 credits from the ARCH or\nCST M prefix may be used to fulfill a lower division\ncourse requirement for the Engineering minor. All\ncourses taken for the engineering minor must be\npassed with a grade of C or better.\nDescription of Courses\nENGINEERING\nENGR\n101 Success in Engineering Study V 1-2 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n3 hours. Course Prerequisite: Participation in\nthe STARS program; by department consent.\nEngineering study with an emphasis on\nworking in groups and evaluating personal\nneeds and goals.\n107 [QUAN] Introductory Mathematics for\nEngineering Applications 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 106 with a grade of C or\nbetter, or a minimum ALEKS math placement\nscore of 75%. Application of mathematics\nprinciples to engineering problems across\nengineering disciplines; concepts from\ntrigonometry to differential equations\nnecessary for sophomore engineering courses.\n120 Innovation in Design 2 (1-3) Introduction\nto engineering disciplines, problem solving,\ndesign teamwork and ethics.\n121 Grand Challenges in Engineering 1 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n2 hours. Introduction to the Grand Challenge\nScholars Program and the National Academy\nof Engineering’s Grand Challenges through\na creative learning experience in research or\ndesign, an interdisciplinary experience, an\nentrepreneurship or innovation experience,\na global or cross-cultural experience, and a\nservice learning experience. S, F grading.\n201 Metal Fabrication 3 (1-6) Credit not\ngranted for students who have already\ncompleted AGTM/ENGR 202, 203, or 204.\nTheory, applications, and practices of welding,\nmachining, and associated techniques in\nfabricating with metals. (Crosslisted course\noffered as AGTM 201, ENGR 201).\n202 Welding 1 (1-3) Credit not granted for\nstudents who have already completed AGTM/\nENGR 201. Theory application and practices\nof welding and associated techniques in\nfabricating with metals. One of 3 two-week\nsessions of Metal Fabrication. Each session\nincludes 3 hours lecture and 12 hours lab per\nweek. (Crosslisted course offered as AGTM 202,\nENGR 202).\n203 Machining 1 (1-3) Credit not granted for\nstudents who have already completed AGTM/\nENGR 201. Theory application and practices\nof machining and associated techniques in\nfabricating with metals. One of 3 two-week\nsessions of Metal Fabrication. Each session\nincludes 3 hours lecture and 12 hours lab per\nweek. (Crosslisted course offered as AGTM 203,\nENGR 203).\n204 Metal Fabrication 1 (1-3) Credit not granted\nfor students who have already completed\nAGTM/ENGR 201. Theory application and\npractices of cutting and associated techniques\nin fabricating with metals. One of 3 two-week\nsessions of Metal Fabrication. Each session\nincludes 3 hours lecture and 12 hours lab per\nweek. (Crosslisted course offered as AGTM 204,\nENGR 204).\n401 Entrepreneurship Boot Camp and the\nEntrepreneurial Mindset 3 Focus on\ncommercializing ideas, modifying existing\nproducts, exploiting market opportunities, and\ncreating new enterprises.\n420 Multidisciplinary Engineering Design\nI 3 (1-4) Course Prerequisite: Admitted to an\nengineering major; senior standing. Needs\nanalysis and conceptualization of technological\nproducts and business plan for target market;\nmultidisciplinary team development.\n421 [ C A P S ] [ M ] M u l t i d i s c i p l i n a r y\nEngineering Design II 3 (1-4) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to an engineering\nmajor; senior standing. Prototype solution\ndeveloped and evaluated and business plan\ncompleted; presentation to stake holders;\nteam development and assessment. Field trip\nrequired.\n430 Interdisciplinary Design I 3 (1-4) Course\nPrerequisite: Senior standing. Programming,\nresource flows, site analysis and schematic\ndesign; multidisciplinary team development.\n431 [CAPS] Interdisciplinary Design II 3\n(1-4) Course Prerequisite: ENGR 430 with\na C or better; admitted to an engineering\nmajor; senior standing. Master plan, design\ndevelopment, construction documentation,\nsustainability analysis; multidisciplinary team\ndevelopment.\n488 Professional Practice Coop/Internship\nI V 1-2 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite: By\ndepartment permission. Practicum for students\nadmitted to the VCEA Professional Practice and\nExperiential Learning Program; integration\nof coursework with on-the-job professional\nexperience. (Crosslisted course offered as ENGR\n488, BIO ENG 488, CHE 488, CE 488, CPT S\n488, E E 488, ME 488, MSE 488, SDC 488). S, F\ngrading.\n489 Professional Practice Coop/Internship\nII 1 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 3 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nSophomore standing; by department\npermission. Practicum for students admitted\nto the VCEA Professional Practice and\nExperiential Learning Program; continuation\nof ENGR 488. (Crosslisted course offered as\nENGR 489, SDC 489). S, F grading.\n530 Interdisciplinary Research and Design\nI 3 (1-4) Literature review, resource flows,\nresearch proposal, and multidisciplinary team\ndevelopment.\n531 Interdisciplinary Research and Design II\n3 (1-4) Design analysis, sustainability analysis,\nresearch and scholarly work development;\nmultidisciplinary team development.\nSchool of Engineering and\nComputer Science - WSU\nVancouver\necs.vancouver.wsu.edu\nVECS 201, Vancouver Campus\n360-546-9639\nDirector and Associate Professor, X. Zhao; Professors,\nH. Gurocak, D. Kim; Associate Professors, X. Chen, T.\nKaracolak, J. H. Kim, P. Sekhar, S. Solovitz, H. Tan, S.\nWallace, F. Zhao, X. Zhang; Assistant Professors, J.\nCampos do Prado, H. Gao, S. U. Kim, A. Wisniewska;\nScholarly Associate Professors, J. Lynch, H. Rad;\nScholarly Assistant Professors, P. Bonamy, M. Bozorgi,\nB. McCamish; Adjunct Faculty, S. Austin, S. Begum,\nJ. Enz, F. Kabir, D. Lowe, T. Pritchard, K. Wang;\nAcademic Coordinators, K. Deford, C. Potter.\n\n187\nEngineering and Computer Science, WSU Vancouver\nWashington State University, 2021\nThe School of Engineering and Computer Science\n(ENCS) is an academic unit of the WSU Voiland\nCollege of Engineering and Architecture that houses\nthe engineering and computer science programs\nlocated at WSU Vancouver.\nThe undergraduate curricula provide students with\na solid foundation upon which they can build to\nmeet the challenges associated with their individual\ncareer paths and to adapt to rapidly changing\ntechnologies. We emphasize the fundamentals\nand give students significant choice in designing\ntheir academic course of study to meet their career\ngoals. In Computer Science, students can choose\nfrom a variety of courses in areas such as intelligent\nsystems, software and hardware systems, and data-\nintensive computation. In Mechanical Engineering,\nstudents can customize their study through four\noption areas: (1) Micro/nanotechnology; (2) Design\nand Manufacturing; (3) Mechatronics (robotics and\nautomation); (4) Renewable Energy. The Renewable\nEnergy track is an interdisciplinary option track\n— available to ECE students and MECH students\n— incorporating elements of all ENCS disciplines.\nIn Electrical Engineering, students can choose\nupper division elective courses such as computer\narchitecture, signal processing, IC fabrication,\nRF/Antenna Design, Power systems, and others.\nEffective writing, speaking and presentation skills,\nand ethics are also emphasized as important\nattributes of our graduates.\nThe School of ENCS is located at Washington State\nUniversity’s campus in Vancouver, Washington\nand is intended to directly serve students in the\nsouthwest Washington region. The programs\nwere established and designed to prepare students\nto satisfy the needs of regional companies and\norganizations for engineering and computing\nprofessionals. The curricula also prepare students\nfor continued education at the graduate level\nin computer science, electrical engineering, and\nmechanical engineering.\nThe School offers courses of study leading to\nthe degrees of Bachelor of Science in Computer\nScience (BSCS), Bachelor of Science in Electrical\nEngineering (BSEE), Bachelor of Science in\nMechanical Engineering (BSME), Master of Science\nin Computer Science (MSCS), Master of Science in\nElectrical Engineering (MSEE), and Master of Science\nin Mechanical Engineering (MSME).\nThe undergraduate programs in Electrical\nEngineering and Mechanical Engineering are\naccredited by the Engineering Accreditation\nCommission of ABET, www.abet.org. The\nundergraduate program in Computer Science\nis accredited by the Computing Accreditation\nCommission of ABET, www.abet.org.\nCOMPUTER SCIENCE PROGRAM\nIt is the objective of the computer science program\nto provide a broad education in the science and\napplication of computing. Students are expected to\ngain proficiency in the design and implementation\nof software systems, as well as the application of the\ntheory of computing to that process. In addition, all\nstudents will develop a background in the hardware\narchitectures that underlie software systems and\nthe mathematics that provide the basis for science\nand computing. The degree program also requires\nstudents to obtain a background in other scientific\ndisciplines and to develop effective communication\nskills.\nEducational Objectives\nThe goal of our program is to prepare our graduates\nfor successful professional practice and advanced\nstudies by providing a broad education in computer\nscience and by offering the opportunity to deepen\ntheir technical understanding in particular areas of\ncomputer science through technical electives.\nAs a graduate of the WSU Vancouver Computer\nScience program:\n• You will be a knowledgeable and skilled computer\nscientist.\n• You will exhibit the workplace behaviors\nexpected by employers.\n• You will be committed to high standards of\nprofessionalism.\n• You will adapt to the changing landscape of\ncomputer science.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nOur graduates will have an ability to:\n• Analyze a complex computing problem and to\napply principles of computing and other relevant\ndisciplines to identify solutions.\n• Design, implement, and evaluate a computing-\nbased solution to meet a given set of computing\nrequirements in the context of the program’s\ndiscipline.\n• Communicate effectively in a variety of\nprofessional contexts.\n• Recognize professional responsibilities and make\ninformed judgments in computing practice based\non legal and ethical principles.\n• Function effectively as a member or leader of\na team engaged in activities appropriate to the\nprogram’s discipline.\n• Apply computer science theory and software\ndevelopment fundamentals to produce computing-\nbased solutions.\nELECTRICAL ENGINEERING PROGRAM\nElectrical Engineering is a diverse field of\nengineering study encompassing much of\nthe underlying technology of our modern\nworld. Electrical engineers lead the design of\nmicroelectronics, computers, tablets, smartphones,\ncommunication networks, control systems and\npower generation and distribution. Aerospace\nand military systems include major subsystems\nconceived and designed by electrical engineers.\nThe lower division electrical engineering\ncurriculum covers the fundamental aspects of\nthe field, emphasizing the theory, principles and\nknowledge expected of all electrical engineers. The\nupper division curriculum includes elective courses\nsuch as computer architecture, signal processing,\nIC fabrication, RF/Antenna Design, Power systems,\nand others.\nThe curriculum incorporates extensive hands-\non experiences through laboratory work and\ndesign projects. All electrical engineering students\nparticipate in a senior design project with a team\nof students, usually spanning multiple engineering\ndisciplines.\nEducational Objectives\nThe goal of our program is to prepare our graduates\nfor successful professional practice and advanced\nstudies by providing a broad education in electrical\nengineering and by offering the opportunity to\ndeepen their technical understanding in a particular\nconcentration area of related technical electives.\nOur graduates will:\n• Apply technical knowledge and skills as electrical\nengineers to provide effective solutions in industrial\nand governmental organizations.\n• Utilize effective communication, team, and\nproject management skills to work productively\nwithin their professions and communities.\n• Conduct themselves as responsible professionals\ncontributing to the greater benefit of society\nthrough technology.\n• Pursue professional development and/or graduate\nstudies to meet the emerging and evolving demands\nand increasing responsibilities of a successful career.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nOur graduates will have:\n• An ability to identify, formulate, and solve\ncomplex engineering problems by applying\nprinciples of engineering, science, and mathematics.\n• An ability to apply engineering design to\nproduce solutions that meet specified needs with\nconsideration of public health, safety, and welfare,\nas well as global, cultural, social, environmental,\nand economic factors.\n• An ability to communicate effectively with a\nrange of audiences.\n• An ability to recognize ethical and professional\nresponsibilities in engineering situations and\nmake informed judgments, which must consider\nthe impact of engineering solutions in global,\neconomic, environmental, and societal contexts.\n• An ability to function effectively on a team\nwhose members together provide leadership, create\na collaborative and inclusive environment, establish\ngoals, plan tasks, and meet objectives.\n• An ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions.\n• An ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\nMECHANICAL ENGINEERING PROGRAM\nMechanical Engineering provides an excellent\neducation for today’s technological world.\nMechanical engineers are the backbone of\nthe engineering profession and work in every\nindustry from transportation, communications,\nand electronics to bioengineering, commerce,\nand manufacturing in business, government, and\nuniversities. Mechanical engineers work with\nmotion, energy, and force, and are involved with\nanalyzing and manufacturing the products they\ndesign. They design consumer products, develop\nrobotic systems, computer control systems for\nmachinery, commercial jets, instruments for\nmedicine, high performance sporting equipment,\nand supervise manufacturing operations.\nOur undergraduate curriculum covers the\nfundamental aspects of the field, emphasizes basic\nprinciples and their use in solving engineering\nproblems. The upper division course of study\nfocuses on design, manufacturing process, robotics,\ncomputer-aided engineering, thermal and fluid\nsystems, mechanics of materials, micro- and nano-\ndevice design and manufacturing, and machine\nintegration and automation. The curriculum\nincorporates hands-on experiences through\nlaboratory work and design projects. The program\nprovides flexibility to students in customizing their\nstudy through four option areas:\n• Micro/Nano Technology Option: Provides\n\n188\nEngineering and Computer Science, WSU Vancouver\nWashington State University, 2021\neducation in basic semiconductor concepts,\nfundamentals of microscopic phenomena in\nmicrofluidics, micro device fabrication techniques,\nnano-science and its impact on design of the next\ngeneration engineering systems.\n• Design and Manufacturing Option: Emphasizes\nmechanical system design and realization through\ncomputer aided engineering, material failure in\nmechanical design, and advanced manufacturing.\n• Mechatronics (robotics and automation) Option:\nConcentrates on design of mechanical systems with\nelectronic and computer controls, automation and\nrobotics.\n• Renewable Energy Option: Includes work in Solar\nPower, Wind Power, as well as enhanced coursework\nin other option track courses. The Renewable Energy\ntrack is an interdisciplinary option track - available\nto ECE students as well as MECH students.\nEducational Objectives\nThe goal of our program is to prepare our\ngraduates for successful professional practice\nand advanced studies by providing a broad\neducation in mechanical engineering and by\noffering the opportunity to deepen their technical\nunderstanding in a particular concentration area\nof related technical electives. Our graduates will:\n• Apply technical knowledge and skills as\nmechanical engineers to provide effective solutions\nin industrial and governmental organizations.\n• Utilize effective communication, team, and\nproject management skills to work productively\nwithin their professions and communities.\n• C o n duct themselves in a responsible,\nprofessional, and ethical manner.\n• Continue their education through completion\nof training courses, workshops, seminars, and/\nor graduate studies relevant to their professional\ndevelopment.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nOur graduates will have:\n• An ability to identify, formulate, and solve\ncomplex engineering problems by applying\nprinciples of engineering, science, and mathematics.\n• An ability to apply engineering design to\nproduce solutions that meet specified needs with\nconsideration of public health, safety, and welfare,\nas well as global, cultural, social, environmental,\nand economic factors.\n• An ability to communicate effectively with a\nrange of audiences.\n• An ability to recognize ethical and professional\nresponsibilities in engineering situations and\nmake informed judgments, which must consider\nthe impact of engineering solutions in global,\neconomic, environmental, and societal contexts.\n• An ability to function effectively on a team\nwhose members together provide leadership, create\na collaborative and inclusive environment, establish\ngoals, plan tasks, and meet objectives.\n• An ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions.\n• An ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\nAdmission to the Major\nAdmission to a degree program is required by\nWSU prior to the granting of a baccalaureate\ndegree. Qualification for initial admission, as well\nas continuation of admitted status, will be evaluated\nbased on several criteria including academic\nintegrity, overall grade point average (GPA), GPA\nin mathematics, science, and major core courses;\ncomputer science, electrical engineering, or\nmechanical engineering. Students will be admitted\nto the major once the required courses have been\ncompleted. Additional details regarding admission\nto the major are available in the schedules of studies\nfor each major or from the School of ENCS academic\ncoordinators.\nTransfer Students\nThe School of Engineering and Computer Science\ncooperates closely with Washington community\ncolleges to facilitate the transfer of students into\nits computer science, electrical engineering, and\nmechanical engineering programs. Students\nplanning to transfer into the School of ENCS are\nstrongly encouraged to contact an ENCS academic\ncoordinator to evaluate the transfer course credits\nand to help plan the continuation of their academic\ncareer at Washington State University Vancouver.\nStudents will note that a number of the courses\noffered by the School of ENCS have identical\ncourse numbers and similar descriptions to courses\noffered by the School of Electrical Engineering and\nComputer Science and the School of Mechanical\nand Materials Engineering on the Pullman campus.\nThe transfer of course credit between these Schools is\nnot automatic or guaranteed. Students intending to\ntake courses in one School for credit in another are\nadvised to consult with the academic coordinator\nfor their degree program, in advance, to assess how\nthe courses may fulfill their degree requirements.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nThe Master of Science in Computer Science\nprogram in the School of ENCS is a thesis program\nand requires 30 credit hours, including 21 hours\nof graded course work and 9 credits of thesis\nresearch (CS 700). The program has a theme on\nCloud Computing a modern and critical set of\ntechnologies that span core areas of Computer\nScience. The coursework and research are in\nthe general areas of computing theory; artificial\nintelligence; big data; software development; and\nsystems and networks. Sophisticated facilities are\navailable for instruction and research, including a\nhigh performance computing cluster and dedicated\nhigh-bandwidth network facilities. Teaching and\nresearch assistantships are available for qualified\nstudents.\nBefore undertaking graduate study in computer\nscience, the student should have completed a\nbaccalaureate degree substantially similar to the\nBSCS degree described below in the BSCS schedule\nof studies. Students from other academic disciplines\nare encouraged to apply, however such students will\nbe required to take or have taken the equivalent\nof the following courses: CS 317, CS 360 and CS\n450, including all prerequisites for these courses.\nAn undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 is a\nminimum for admission to the MS program.\nThe Master of Science in Electrical Engineering\nprogram in the School of ENCS is a thesis program\nand requires a minimum of 30 credit hours. This\nincludes 21 hours of graded coursework beyond\nthe bachelor’s degree, plus a minimum of 4\nthesis credits (ECE 700). The program has Lab-\non-a-Chip theme, which is used as a unifying\nplatform to make connections between courses.\nThe coursework and research are in the general\nareas of antenna design; RF/microwave systems;\nMicro/nanoelectronics; MEMS; sensors and signal\nprocessing; nanotechnology; electrical power\nsystems; and digital/embedded systems. Our\nlaboratories, including a class-100 clean room and\nRF laboratories, are equipped with state-of-the-art\nequipment. Teaching and research assistantships\nare available for qualified students.\nA Bachelor of Science degree from an accredited\nprogram in electrical engineering provides a good\nbackground for the MSEE graduate program.\nStudents with bachelor degrees in other engineering\ndisciplines, mathematics, and the physical\nsciences may be admitted, but will be required\nto make up requisite undergraduate deficiencies.\nAn undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 is a\nminimum for admission to the MS program.\nThe Master of Science in Mechanical Engineering\nprogram in the School of ENCS is a thesis program\nand requires a minimum of 30 credit hours. This\nincludes 21 hours of graded coursework beyond the\nbachelor’s degree, plus a minimum of 4 thesis credits\n(MECH 700). The program has a theme of Digital\nDesign and Manufacturing a modern and critical\nset of digital technologies for advanced modeling,\nsimulation, analysis, integration of information\ntechnology, sensing, automation, and big data\nto rapidly design and manufacture products. The\ncoursework and research are in the general areas of\nproduct design, sustainable engineering, advanced\nmaterials, automation, and new manufacturing\nprocesses. Teaching and research assistantships are\navailable for qualified students.\nA Bachelor of Science degree from an accredited\nprogram in mechanical engineering provides a\ngood background for the MSME graduate program.\nStudents with bachelor degrees in other engineering\ndisciplines, mathematics, and the physical\nsciences may be admitted, but will be required\nto make up requisite undergraduate deficiencies.\nAn undergraduate grade point average of 3.0 is a\nminimum for admission to the MS program.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBACHELOR OF SCIENCE, COMPUTER\nSCIENCE (VANCOUVER ONLY)\n(120 HOURS)\nFor the major in the Computer Science degree\nprogram on the Vancouver campus, students are\nadmitted to the major upon demonstrating they are\nready to take MATH 171 (Calculus I) or higher and\nmaking their intentions known to the department.\nTo remain in good standing, students must pass\nCS 121, 122, 166, MATH 171, 172, and PHYSICS\n201/211 (or their transfer equivalents) with a grade\nof C or better and have a WSU cumulative GPA of\n2.5 when the final benchmark is completed.\nNo courses listed in this schedule of studies may\nbe taken on a pass/fail basis. All listed computer\nscience courses, and their prerequisites, must be\ncompleted with a grade of C or better.\n\n189\nEngineering and Computer Science, WSU Vancouver\nWashington State University, 2021\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCS 121 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCS 122 4\nCS 166 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 172 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCS 223 3\nCS 260 3\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI] 3\nMATH 220 2\nPHYSICS 201 [PSCI] 3\nPHYSICS 211 [PSCI] 1\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab 4\nCS 224 3\nCS 261 3\nMATH 273 or 301 2-3\nPHYSICS 202 3\nPHYSICS 212 1\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCS 317 3\nCS 360 4\nCS Option Course\n1 \n3\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] 3\nSTAT 360 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCS 320 [M] 3\nCS 351 3\nCS 355 3\nCS Option Course\n1 \n3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCS 420 [CAPS] [M] 3\nCS 450 3\nCS Option Courses\n1 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nCS 402 [M] 3\nCS 421 3\nCS 460 3\nCS Option Course\n1 \n3\nCS Security Option Course\n2 \n3\n_______\n1 \nCS Option Courses: 15 credits of option area\ncourses are required for completion of the degree\nprogram. The option courses must be chosen from\n300-400-level CS courses and may also include up\nto 6 hours from the following list: MATH 315, 320,\n325, 364, 420, 448, 453, 466, ECE 324, 366, and\n424. Other computer science-related courses may be\nsubstituted, as approved by the department.\n2 \nCS Security Option Courses: 3 credits of security\noption area courses are required for completion of\nthe degree program. These credits are in addition to\nthe 15 credits of CS Option Courses required above.\nCS Security Option Courses must be chosen from\nthe following courses: CS 425, 426, and 427.\nBACHELOR OF SCIENCE, ELECTRICAL\nENGINEERING (VANCOUVER ONLY)\n(121 HOURS)\nFor the major in the Electrical Engineering degree\nprogram on the Vancouver campus, students are\nadmitted to the Electrical Engineering major upon\ndemonstrating they are ready to take MATH 171\n(Calculus I) or higher and making their intention\nknown to the department.\nTo remain in good standing, students must\ncomplete the benchmark courses: CS 251, ECE 214,\n234, 260, MATH 171, 172, 220, 273, 315, CHEM\n105, PHYSICS 201 and 211, and PHYSICS 202 and\n212 (or their transfer equivalents) with a grade of\nC or better and obtain a WSU cumulative GPA of\n2.5 or higher when the final benchmark course is\ncompleted.\nNo courses listed in this schedule of studies may\nbe taken on a pass/fail basis. All upper-division\nelectrical engineering courses must be completed\nwith a minimum 2.0 average GPA.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nECE 101 2\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCS 251 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 172 4\nPHYSICS 201 [PSCI] 3\nPHYSICS 211 [PSCI] 1\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] 3 or 4\nECE 214 3\nMATH 220 2\nMATH 273 2\nPHYSICS 202 3\nPHYSICS 212 1\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nECE 234 3\nECE 260 4\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI] 3\nMATH 315 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nECE 321 3\nECE 325 4\nECE Elective\n1 \n3\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] 3\nSTAT 360 3\nSecond Term Hours\nECE 341 3\nECE 370 3\nECE Electives\n1 \n9\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nECE 411 3\nECE 451 2\nECE Electives\n1 \n9\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nECE 405 [M] 3\nECE 452 [M] [CAPS] 3\nECE Electives\n1 \n6\n_______\n1 \nECE Electives must be chosen from CS 330, 466,\nECE 302, 316, 324, 327, 345, 349, 366, 414, 421,\n424, 425, 461, 462, 466, 471, 476, 483, 495, 496,\nMECH 441, 467, 468, or be pre-approved by a\nfaculty advisor.\nBACHELOR OF SCIENCE, MECHANICAL\nENGINEERING (VANCOUVER ONLY)\n(121 HOURS)\nFor the major in the Mechanical Engineering degree\nprogram on the Vancouver campus, students are\nadmitted to the Mechanical Engineering major\nupon demonstrating they are ready to take MATH\n171 (Calculus I) or higher and making their\nintentions known to the department.\nTo remain in good standing, students must\ncomplete the benchmark courses: MECH 211,\n212, 215, MATH 171, 172, 220, 273, 315, CHEM\n105, and PHYSICS 201 and 211 (or their transfer\nequivalents) with a grade of C or better and obtain\na WSU cumulative GPA of 2.5 or higher when the\nfinal benchmark is completed.\nNo courses listed in this schedule of studies may\nbe taken on a pass/fail basis. All upper-division\nmechanical engineering courses must be completed\nwith a minimum 2.0 average GPA.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nMECH 103 2\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 106 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 172 4\nMECH 101 2\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nECONS 101 [SSCI] or 102 [SSCI] 3\nMATH 220 2\nMATH 273 2\nMECH 211 3\nMECH 251 2\nPHYSICS 201 3\nPHYSICS 211 1\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] 3 or 4\nMATH 315 3\nMECH 212 3\nMECH 215 3\nPHYSICS 202 3\n\n190\nEngineering and Computer Science, WSU Vancouver\nWashington State University, 2021\nPHYSICS 212 1\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] 3\nMECH 301 3\nMECH 303 3\nMECH 304 3\nMECH 309 [M] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nMECH 310 4\nMECH 314 3\nMECH 348 3\nMECH 404 3\n400-level MECH Option Courses/Technical\nElectives\n1 \n3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMECH 402 3\nMECH 414 3\nMECH 416 [M] 2\n400-level MECH Option Courses/Technical\nElectives\n1 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMECH 417 [CAPS] 3\n400-level MECH Option Courses/Technical\nElectives\n1 \n6\n_______\n1 \nTechnical Electives or 400-level MECH Option\nCourses: The program emphasizes fundamentals\nand provides flexibility in selecting a course of\nstudy through five technical electives. Students\ncan either take any five elective courses (15\ncredits), provided they meet the prerequisites, or\nthey can choose to take a set of related electives\ncomprising an option area and additional electives\nof their choice. Students are required to work with\ntheir faculty advisor to develop their schedule of\nstudies as they are admitted to the program at\nthe junior level. The following are the technical\nelective courses and option areas: (Option 1) Micro\nand Nanotechnology: MECH 431, 435, 438, 450;\n(Option 2) Design and Manufacturing: MECH 476,\n477, 485, 489; (Option 3) Mechatronics: MECH 405,\n467, 468; (Option 4) Renewable Energy: MECH 441,\nECE 421, choice of two courses from MECH 405,\n431, 439, 442, 450, 468.\nMinors\nComputer Science (Vancouver\nonly)\nThe minor in computer science consists of 21\ncredit hours, 10 of which must be 300-400-level\ncourses taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses. Required courses include CS 121\nor 251, 122, 224, 360, and two (6 credits minimum)\n300-400 level CS courses, excluding CS 402. All\ncourses must be completed with a grade of C or\nbetter and all course prerequisites must be met. The\nminor course of study must be pre-approved by the\ncomputer science academic coordinator.\nElectrical Engineering (Vancouver\nonly)\nStudents majoring in other disciplines may elect to\nobtain a minor in electrical engineering. The minor\nin electrical engineering consists of 20 credit hours\nthat must include ECE 214, 260, 321, 325, and\nany two upper division ECE 3XX or 4XX courses\nexcept ECE 451 and 452. Though it is not required,\nstudents may choose their two optional courses in\nthe following concentrations:\n• VLSI design: ECE 349 and 366\n• Digital signal processing: ECE 341 and 414\n• Computer engineering: ECE 324 and 424\n• Power systems: ECE 461 and 462\nAll minor courses, except ECE 214, 260, 321 and\n341, must be taken in residence at WSU Vancouver.\nThe University requires at least 9 credit hours for any\nminor be 300-400-level and taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. All prerequisites\nfor minor courses must be met. All minor courses\nmust be completed with a minimum 2.0 GPA.\nMechanical Engineering\n(Vancouver only)\nA mechanical engineering minor requires a\nminimum of 16 semester hours, 9 of which must\nbe in upper-division course work and taken in\nresidence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange\ncourses. This minor requires (1) MECH 211 and\n212, (2) Four out of the following MECH 215, 303,\n309, 314, 348, 431, 438, 441, 450, 467, or 468. At\nleast one of these four courses must be MECH 215,\n303, or 348. All prerequisites for minor courses\nmust be met. All courses must be completed with\na minimum 2.0 average GPA.\nDescription of Courses\nCOMPUTER SCIENCE - VANCOUVER\nEnrollment in 400-level computer science courses is\nrestricted to admitted majors or minors in computer\nscience and to juniors and seniors admitted to other\ndegree programs requiring these computer science courses.\nCS\n121 Program Design and Development 4 (3-\n3) Course Prerequisite: MATH 171 with a C or\nbetter or concurrent enrollment. Formulation\nof problems and top-down design of programs\nin a modern structured language for their\nsolution on a digital computer.\n122 Data Structures 4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite:\nCS 121 with a C or better, or CS 251 with a C\nor better. Advanced programming techniques:\ndata structures, recursion, sorting and\nsearching, and basics of algorithm analysis.\n166 Discrete Mathematics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCS 122 with a C or better or concurrent\nenrollment; MATH 171 with a C or better\nor concurrent enrollment. Introduction to\nthe theoretical foundations of computing.\nCombinatorics, relations, trees, graphs,\nBoolean algebra, proof methods, and discrete\nprobability as applied to computer science.\n215 Data Analytics Systems and Algorithms\n3 Course Prerequisite: CPT S 122, CPT S 132, or\nCS 122. Exploration of fundamental concepts,\nconstructs, and techniques of modern data\nanalytics systems. (Crosslisted course offered\nas CPT S 215, CS 215).\n223 Advanced Data Structures 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CS 122 with a C or better; CS 166\nwith a C or better. Advanced data structures,\nobject oriented programming concepts, and\nprogram design principles.\n224 Programming Tools 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCS 122 with a C or better. (Crosslisted course offered as CPT\nS 315, CS 315).\n317 Automata and Formal Languages 3\nCourse Prerequisite: CS 122 with a C or better;\nCS 166 with a C or better. Fundamentals of conduction,\nconvection, and radiation heat transfer;\nanalytical, numerical, and empirical modeling\nfor solids, liquids, and gases.\n405 Introduction to Microcontrollers 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MECH 304. Microcontroller\narchitecture, microcontroller programming,\nmechanical system design with embedded\nmicrocontrollers.\n414 Machine Design II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMECH 215; MECH 309; MECH 314. Static\nand fatigue failure theories applied to design\nof mechanical elements, stress analysis and\nfinite elements; design for fatigue life of various\nmechanical elements, design and selection of\nstandard mechanical components, and design\nof clutches and brakes.\n416 [M] Mechanical Systems Design I 2 Course\nPrerequisite: MECH 310; MECH 404; MECH\n414 or concurrent enrollment. First term of the\nyear-long capstone design; integrative design\nin mechanical engineering; multidisciplinary\ndesign project considering technical and\nnontechnical contexts.\n417 [CAPS] Mechanical Systems Design II\n3 Course Prerequisite: MECH 416; junior\nstanding. Second term of the year-long\ncapstone design; integrative design in\nmechanical engineering; multidisciplinary\ndesign project considering technical and\nnontechnical contexts.\n431 S e m i c o n d u c t o r D e v i c e s 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: CHEM 105; 4 credits of PHYSICS\n202, or PHYSICS 202 and 212. Crystal\nproperties, energy bands, semiconductor\ncharge carriers, p-n junctions, field-effect\ntransistors, bipolar junction transistors,\noptoelectronic devices, integrated circuits.\n435 Introduction to Microfluidics 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 315; MECH 303. Overview\nof microfluidics, scaling laws, intermolecular\nforces, surface tension, passive scalar\ntransport, electrowetting, electrokinetics,\ndielectrophoresis, microfabrication.\n438 Microfabrication Technology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CHEM 105; MATH 315; 4 credits\nof PHYSICS 202, or PHYSICS 202 and 212.\nMicroelectronic fabrication technology,\nsemiconductor material, diffusion, thermal\noxidation, ion implantation, lithography,\netching, thin film deposition, CMOS\nintegration and MEMS. Credit not granted for\nboth MECH 438 and MECH 538.\n439 F o u n d a t i o n s o f A e r o d y n a m i c s 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MATH 315; MECH 303.\nGoverning equations of fluid mechanics,\npotential flow, introduction to aerodynamics,\nthin airfoil theory, compressible flow, viscous\neffects.\n441 Fundamentals of Renewable Energy\n3 Course Prerequisite: 4 credits of PHYSICS\n202, or PHYSICS 202 and 212; MATH 273.\nAn examination of the fundamentals and\nthe impact of renewable energy technology,\nincluding wind, solar, hydroelectricity, and\nalternate fuels.\n442 Advanced Thermal Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MECH 404. Analysis and design of\nadvanced thermal systems at macro, mini and\nmicro scales; applied design software packages;\ndesign projects. Credit not granted for both\nMECH 442 and MECH 542.\n450 Advanced Topics in Micro and Nano\nTechnology 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nCHEM 106; 4 credits of PHYSICS 202, or\nPHYSICS 202 and 212. Microfabrication\ntechnology, bulk and surface micromachining,\nsensors and actuators, microelectromechanical\nsystems (MEMS), nanofabrication technology,\nmicro/nano scale material and device\nmeasurements. Credit not granted for both\nMECH 450 and MECH 550.\n467 Automation 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nMECH 304 and 348, OR ECE 260. Design\nof automation systems, motion control,\nprogrammable logic. Credit not granted for both\nMECH 468 and MECH 568.\n476 Advanced Manufacturing Engineering\n3 Course Prerequisite: MECH 310. Advanced\ntopics in manufacturing processes, including\ninterrelationships between the properties of\nthe material, the manufacturing process and\ndesign of components. Credit not granted for\nboth MECH 476 and MECH 576.\n\n195\nEngineering and Technology Management\nWashington State University, 2021\n477 Manufacturing for Polymer Composites\n3 Course Prerequisite: MECH 309. S, F grading.\n501 Digital Design and Manufacturing\n3 Fundamentals of digital design and\nmanufacturing; exposure to current research\ntopics in the area.\n509 MEMS Engineering 3 (2-3) Introduction\nto the design, fabrication and application of\nmicroelectromechanical systems.\n515 Advanced Heat Transfer 3 Energy\nconservation equations; forced convection\nwith internal and external flow, free\nconvection, boiling and condensation, mass\ntransfer, numerical methods.\n516 Micro/Nanoscale Thermal Engineering\n3 Fundamentals and applications of micro/\nnanoscale thermal science and engineering.\n521 Fundamentals of Fluids I 3 Mass and\nmomentum conservation equations, Navier-\nStokes equations, compressible flows, inviscid-\npotential flows, advanced viscous flows\nincluding boundary layer numerical methods.\n523 Computational Fluid Dynamics and\nHeat Transfer 3 Partial differential equation\nsystems, finite difference method, stability\nanalysis, methods for wave equation, heat\nequation, Laplace equation, finite volume\nmethod.\n529 Experimental Methods for Mechanical\nE n g i n e e r i n g R e s e a r c h 3 Research\nmethods for mechanical engineers, including\nexperimental design, techniques, analysis, and\npresentation.\n532 Finite Elements 3 Theory of finite elements;\napplications to general engineering systems\nconsidered as assemblages of discrete elements.\n538 M i c r o f a b r i c a t i o n Te c h n o l o g y 3\nMicroelectronic fabrication technology,\nsemiconductor material, diffusion, thermal\noxidation, ion implantation, lithography,\netching, thin film deposition, CMOS\nintegration and MEMS. S, U grading.\nEngineering and Technology\nManagement Program\netm.wsu.edu\nCarpenter 533\n509-335-5595\nProgram Director, G. T. Vanek; Faculty: Graduate\nStudies Committee Chair and Scholarly Associate\nProfessor, A. Squires; Assistant/Associate Professors,\nK. Bachman, W. J. Gray, L. Magpili, D. Paulus; Adjunct\nInstructors, R. Crick, L. Scheinkopf.\nWashington State University’s Engineering\nand Technology Management (ETM) program\nprepares engineering and business professionals\nto make strategic and operational decisions and\nbecome leaders in the management of technology.\nCourses provide practicing professionals with the\nknowledge, tools, and skills to manage projects,\noperations, organizations, and people. The ETM\nprogram is specifically tailored for those who want\nto advance their careers while still working full time.\nOffered 100% online, live classes are available from\nanywhere.\nConvenience and quality for students and their\nemployers is at the forefront of our goals. Each\ncourse session is streamed live through Zoom,\ngiving students the ability to interact with faculty\nand peers in the class in real time. Integrated\naudio, video, file sharing, and messaging platforms\nallow discussions to be conducted and serve as\ncollaborative tools for team projects, breakout\ndiscussion groups, and student presentations.\nAll classes are archived as well and are available\nfor review during the semester. For students\ninterested in a modular approach or wishing to\ndevelop depth in a specified area, the ETM program\noffers six graduate level certificates which can be\ncompleted on a compact schedule. Each course can\nbe applied towards two certificates and the master’s\ndegree.\nList of Certificates\n• Constaints Management\n• Industrial Leadership\n• Logistics and Supply Chain Management\n• Project Management\n• Six Sigma Quality Management\n• Systems Engineering Management\nAdmission Requirements\nStudents who apply to the Master of Engineering\nand Technology Management degree program\nare generally employed in an engineering or\ntechnical field and have earned a bachelor’s degree\nfrom an accredited school with a minimum GPA\nof 3.0. One of our strictest requirements is that\napplicants are working in, and/or, have significant\nindustry or engineering experience and math\nthrough at least college algebra; although calculus is\npreferred. Prospective students must provide email\naddresses for three professional references willing\nto write letters of recommendation (not required\nfor admission to the certificate program), a resume\nshowing relevant work experience, and a three-\nto five- paragraph personal statement outlining\nthe applicability of the program in light of career\ngoals and work history. Applications should be\nsubmitted a minimum of six weeks prior to the\n\n196\nEngineering and Technology Management\nWashington State University, 2021\nstart of the semester to allow for careful review of\nqualifications and processing.\nFor questions about the on-line certificates or\nmaster’s degree program, please contact the ETM\noffice at (509) 335-5595 or by email etm@wsu.edu.\nProgram Mission\nThe mission of the Engineering and Technology\nManagement Master’s Degree Program is to empower\ngraduates to develop as successful professionals with\nadvanced technical and management skills that\nallow them to ascend to leadership roles in globally\ncompetitive industries.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe purpose of the WSU Voiland School\nof Engineering and Architecture Program in\nEngineering and Technology Management is\nto prepare students for high-level professional\ndevelopment in positions that require an\nunderstanding of management principles in\nengineering, projects, and organizations.\nObjective 1: Provide graduates with\ncurrent management knowledge and\ntools.\n• Communicate effectively with logical, clear, and\norganized thinking, to a broad range of audiences.\n• Clearly articulate ideas in group settings to a\nrange of audiences.\n• Demonstrate effective writing skills.\n• Demonstrate active listening skills and foster\nopen communication.\n• Behave ethically and professionally in\nfulfillment of responsibilities with consideration\nof global, economic, environmental, societal, and\norganizational impacts.\n• Identify and articulate ethical issues.\n• Make decisions consistent with societal and\norganizational standards.\n• Demonstrate a desire for and ability to acquire\nand apply new knowledge through effective\nlifelong learning strategies, to address current local,\nnational, and global challenges.\n• Anticipate the local and global impact of\ndecisions.\n• Remain current in technological development.\n• Remain cognizant of current issues, local,\nnational, and international.\nObjective 2: Provide graduates with\nthe expertise and confidence to assume\nleadership positions in technical\nenvironments.\n• Demonstrate the ability to successfully establish,\nlead, manage and work in multidisciplinary teams.\n• Provide leadership, motivation, and feedback to\nteam members.\n• Prioritize and identify critical issues.\n• Make relevant contributions to team success.\n• Demonstrate problem-solving abilities and\nrational effective decision making under uncertainty\nby applying the principles and core concepts of\nETM.\n• Identify core issues and problems.\n• Show ability to find innovative solutions.\n• Constructively challenge current assumptions\nand practices.\n• Be able to make sound decisions under\nuncertainty\n• Understand the financial implications of\nengineering decisions\nObjective 3: Increase the graduate’s value\nto an employer.\n• Apply the principles and core concepts of ETM to\nreal-world problems to develop optimal, affordable,\nsustainable solutions in real-world situations.\n• Create and execute plans in a technical\nenvironment.\n• Manage limited resources.\n• Adapt professional life to the global environment.\n• Prepared to advance to higher levels of\nmanagement\n• Demonstrate the ability to understand, analyze,\nand improve organizational practices through the\nuse of current technology, analysis, and design to\naddress evolving business and customer needs.\n• Apply measurement and analytical tools to\nimprove process systems.\n• Apply measurement and analytical tools to\nincrease the quality of products and/or services.\n• Provide leadership, guidance, and assistance to\ncoworkers when implementing changes.\n• Understand the financial and legal workings of\norganizations\nDescription of Courses\nENGINEERING MANAGEMENT\nE M\n403 Managing Variability Using Statistics\n3 Managing variability and uncertainty using\nstatistics for engineering decision-making\ninvolving risk. Credit not granted for both E\nM 403 and 503.\n420 Contract Project Management 3 Contract\nproject bids, proposals, contracts, project\ndelivery/organization; estimating, scheduling,\nresource loading, project monitoring and\ncontrols, safety and quality. Credit not granted\nfor both E M 420 and 520.\n426 Constraints Management 3 Identifies\nfactors that block improvements in any system;\neffective breakthrough solutions; continual\nsystems improvements for manufacturing,\nadministration, projects. Credit not granted\nfor both E M 426 and E M 526.\n430 A p p l i c a t i o n s o f C o n s t r a i n t s\nManagement 3 Understanding and applying\nproved solutions developed by the theory of\nconstraints in areas of production, project\nmanagement, finance, and distribution. Credit\nnot granted for both E M 430 and E M 530.\n438 Lean Tools for Systems Improvement\n3 Integration of the best of Lean, Six Sigma,\nand Theory of Constraints to accelerate the\ncontinuous improvement process. Credit not granted for\nboth E M 464 and E M 564.\n470 Systems Improvement: Integrating TOC,\nLean, and Six Sigma 3 Leveraging Theory\nof Constraints, Lean, and Six Sigma to achieve\nintegrated systems level improvement. Credit not granted\nfor both E M 480 and E M 580. Recommended\npreparation: an undergraduate course in\nstatistics.\n485 Design of Experiments 3 Design for quality\nimproved products; processes and services\nusing designed experiments, including robust/\nparameter design. Credit not granted for both E\nM 403 and 503.\n505 Finance for Technical Systems 3 Time\nvalue of money, capital budgeting, accounting\nprinciples, cost, valuation, risk, cost\naccounting and sensitivity analyses: concepts\nfor engineering decision-making.\n508 Legal Concepts for Engineering and\nTechnical Managers 3 Basic legal obligations\nof engineering/technical managers; identify,\nminimize and recognize risks and liability;\ncontemporary legal environment and business\nlaw.\n520 Contract Project Management 3 Contract\nproject bids, proposals, contracts, project\ndelivery/organization; estimating, scheduling,\nresource loading, project monitoring and\ncontrols, safety and quality. Credit not granted\nfor both E M 420 and 520.\n522 Leading People and Organizations\n3 Strategies of supervision with practical\napplication techniques presented to create\nindividual and organizational motivation.\n526 Constraints Management 3 Identifies\nfactors that block improvements in any system;\neffective breakthrough solutions; continual\nsystems improvements for manufacturing,\nadministration, projects. Credit not granted\nfor both E M 426 and E M 526.\n\n197\nEnglish\nWashington State University, 2021\n530 A p p l i c a t i o n s o f C o n s t r a i n t s\nManagement 3 Understanding and applying\nproved solutions developed by the theory of\nconstraints in areas of production, project\nmanagement, finance, and distribution. S, U\ngrading.\nDepartment of English\nenglish.wsu.edu/\nAvery 202, Pullman campus\n509-335-2581\nChair and Professor, D. Potts; Regents Professor, D. Lee;\nProfessors, N. Bell, T. Butler, D. Campbell, P. Chilson,\nK. Christen, R. Christopher, R. Eddy, D. Grigar, W.\nHamlin, M. Hanly, T. Lewis, M. Mays, S. Ross, C.\nSiegel; Associate Professors, A. Boyd, M. Edwards, J.\nHegglund, D. Law, S. Linden, B. Monroe, T. Reed, B. Sitko, J. Taylor.\nMajors in English provide students with a broad\ncritical and cultural understanding of literature\nand literary studies, and emphasize the writing\nand analytical skills that are vital to success in the\nuniversity, in professional and graduate school,\nand in the workplace. The program of study is\nflexible and allows English majors to focus on\nparticular areas of intellectual interest, to pursue\nelectives, minors, and second majors in other\ndepartments, and to shape their academic careers\nin line with professional and personal interests.\nThe curriculum is designed for (1) students who\ndesire a broad education emphasizing language\nand literature, (2) students who wish to teach or to\nprepare for graduate studies in literature or rhetoric\nand composition, (3) students who intend to use\nthe background and skills learned in the major as\na foundation for careers in writing, editing, law,\nbusiness, or public service and public relations.\nThe curriculum provides majors the opportunity\nto complete their studies with a small discussion\nseminar, internship, or senior project in their area\nof emphasis.\nStudents who are preparing to teach English in the\npublic schools of Washington should examine the\nsummary of requirements for majors and minors\nlisted in the Department of Teaching and Learning\nin this catalog, and they should confer with the\nCollege of Education concerning the requirements\nfor certification.\nThe Department of English offers courses of study\nleading to the degrees of Bachelor of Arts, Master\nof Arts, and Doctor of Philosophy (English). The\ndepartment participates in the interdepartmental\nprogram in American Studies leading to the\ndegrees of Master of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy\n(American Studies). The department also\nadministers the Program in Women’s, Gender, and\nSexuality Studies (WGSS), offering interdisciplinary\ncourses of study leading to the Bachelor of Arts\ndegree in its field. Students interested in this field\nshould consult the requirements listed under WGSS.\nStudents may also complete an English degree\nconsisting, in part, of international literature,\nphilosophy, art, architecture, and music courses\nfrom the Humanities sequence offered jointly by\nthe School of Languages, Cultures, and Race and the\n\n198\nEnglish\nWashington State University, 2021\nDepartment of English, within the Literary Studies\noption described below.\nEnglish Major Options\nSix options are offered for the English major, all\nleading to the degree of Bachelor of Arts in English:\nLiterary Studies is for students who desire a general\nliberal arts education emphasizing literature, critical\nthinking, and writing; and for those preparing for\ngraduate education in English or literary studies.\nEnglish is often selected as a major by students with\ndouble majors or minors in other departments.\nRhetoric and Professional Writing is for students\npreparing for careers in business, public service,\nlaw, or other professions requiring writing and\nreading skills. It is also suitable for those seeking\ncareers in higher education specializing in rhetoric\nand composition.\nTeaching is for students who need specific\ntraining in the teaching of language and literature\nat the secondary level; it is coordinated with the\nDepartment of Teaching and Learning.\nCreative Writing is for students interested in\ncreative writing in various forms (poetry, fiction,\nnonfiction prose), in editing and publishing, and in\ncareers drawing on related creative and professional\nskills.\nIntegrative English Studies is for students interested\nin integrating courses from the above three options.\nLinguistics is for students interested in languages,\ntypes of linguistic structure, and theories of\nlinguistic analysis.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nA graduate in English studies is a creative and\ncritical thinker and writer. An education in English\npresents students with opportunities to:\n• Read literary and cultural texts carefully and\ncritically.\n• Produce a variety of creative and critical texts\nusing appropriate technologies that contribute to\nliterary and cultural discourses.\n• Develop abilities in critical reading, writing,\nand thinking necessary for them to communicate\nsuccessfully with other audiences both within and\noutside the University.\n• Explore the record of human experience in\nlanguage\nFor more information, please see: http://english.\nwsu.edu/undergraduate-studies.html.\nWomen’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies\nWomen’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies is an\ninterdisciplinary degree program offering courses\nin which students work together to explore the\nways that race, ethnicity, sexuality, social class,\nnationality, age, and ability intersect to shape\ngendered experience, injustice, and social change.\nUsing an intersectional lens, students gain expertise\nin analyzing gendered social roles and the ways in\nwhich they affect personal lives, artistic expression,\nwork, social relationships, institutional structures,\nthe production of knowledge, and national and\ninternational political and economic relations.\nWGSS offers a BA in Women’s Studies and minors\nin Queer Studies and Women’s Studies. For more\ninformation, consult the separate entry for\n“Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies.”\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nStudents interested in a graduate program\nin English at Washington State University\nshould pursue preparation in English courses\ngenerally approximating one of the first three\nundergraduate programs described above. Students\nwith undergraduate majors in such subjects as\nphilosophy, foreign languages, and history may also\nbe accepted for graduate study in the department.\nStudents preparing for degrees which require a\nforeign language reading competency should begin\nstudying a qualifying language before entering\ngraduate school. See the “Language Requirements”\npage on the Department of English Graduate Studies\nWeb site for further details: https://english.wsu.\nedu/graduate-studies/.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nCREATIVE WRITING OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the English – Creative\nWriting Option upon making their intention\nknown to the department.\nRequirements in this option involve a minimum\nof 45 credits, approximately half in creative writing\nand related professional courses, the remainder\nin supporting literature courses approved by the\nadvisor. In addition to these requirements, students\nare urged to select UCORE courses in American and\nworld cultures, history, and society to round out the\nliberal arts education that they will bring to careers\nin creative writing, editing, publishing, and related\nfields.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] \n2 \n3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, or Elective 3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nENGLISH 251 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nForeign Language, if necessary, or Elective 3 or 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nENGLISH 351 or 353 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives (literature courses recommended) 7\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nENGLISH 352 3\n300-400-level Literature Elective\n3 \n3\nHumanities Electives\n2 \n3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 302 [M] 3\nENGLISH 357, 402 [M], 498, OR 499 3\n300-400-level Literature Elective\n3 \n3\nElectives 6\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 451 [M], 452 [M], or 453 3\nWriters of Color Course \n4 \n3\n300-400-level Electives 9\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\n300-400-level Creative Writing or Literature\nElective \n5 \n3\n400-level Literature Elective \n3 \n3\n300-400-level Electives 6\nComplete English Portfolio\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 446 3\nENGLISH 451 [M], 452 [M], or 453 3\n300-400-level Creative Writing or Literature\nElective \n5 \n3\nElectives 3\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nHumanities Electives: At least one from HUMANITY\n101, 103, 302 [M], 303, 304, 335, 350, 410, or 450\nis required.
