Bell, Coordinator\nA student may be admitted to the English –\nLinguistics Option upon making their intention\nknown to the department.\nA student in the Bachelor of Arts in English\n- Linguistics option may expect a broad liberal\neducation in literature, anthropology, mathematics,\nand philosophy around a core of language. The\nstudent will gain a substantial familiarity with\nseveral languages and types of linguistic structure\nand will become conversant with formal theories\nof linguistic analysis. Students who complete the\noption in linguistics will earn a Bachelor of Arts in\nEnglish degree.\nThe linguistics option requires 45 credits, variously\ndistributed in the following sequence, depending\nupon the special emphasis which the student and\nadvisor select together.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nENGLISH 256 [SSCI] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nLinguistics MATH, CPT S, or STAT Elective\n2 \n3\nLinguistics PHIL Elective\n2 \n3\nForeign Language, if needed, or Elective\n3,4 \n3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nENGLISH 444 3\nLinguistics Core Electives\n5 \n3\nForeign Language, if needed, or Elective\n3,4 \n3 or 4\nElectives\n4 \n3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 456 [M] 3\n300-400-level FOR LANG Elective\n2 \n3\nLinguistics Emphasis Elective\n2 \n3\nElectives\n4 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 443 3\n300-400-level FOR LANG Elective\n2 \n3\nLinguistics Emphasis Elective 3\nElectives\n4 \n6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nPHIL 443 [M] 3\nLinguistics Core Electives \n5 \n3\nElectives\n4 \n9\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 457 3\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nLinguistics Emphasis Elective \n2 \n3\n300-400-level Electives 7\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nLinguistics Electives: minimum 21 credits required,\nwith a minimum of 12 credits from 300-400-level\ncourses. Coursework must include: a) a minimum\nof 3 credits selected from CPT S 111, 121, 401,\n440, 443, MATH 140, 171, 172, 182, 202, 273, 283,\nPSYCH 311, STAT 205, 212, 360, 443; b) minimum\nof 3 credits in PHIL 201, 401, 499; c) minimum of\n6 credits in 300-400-level FOR LANG courses; and\nd) Emphasis Electives: Remaining courses should\nbe taken in an area of emphasis and chosen in\nconsultation with an advisor to include sufficient\n300-400-level coursework to meet the 40-credit\nUniversity requirements. Approved courses include\nany unused Linguistics Elective or Linguistics Core\nElective, COMSOC 321, 421, ENGLISH 546, any\nunused FOR LANG course, PSYCH 490, 492, TCH\nLRN 333, and TCH LRN 414.\n3 this major are encouraged\nto pursue a second major, minor, or certificate and\nshould speak to their advisor about complementary\noptions.\n5 \nLinguistics Core Electives: Minimum of 6 credits\nto be selected from ANTH/FOR LANG 350, ANTH\n450, ENGLISH 112, 454, 458, or 499.\nLITERARY STUDIES OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the English – Literary\nStudies Option upon making their College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nAmerican Literature Elective: Choose from\nENGLISH 210, 368, 371, 372, 470, 480, 481, or 482.\n3 \nEnglish or Humanities Elective: At least one from\nHUMANITY 101, 103, 302 [M], 303 [M], 304 [M],\n335, 350, 410, or 450 is required. Other approved\ncourses include ENGLISH 210, 366, 368, 370, 371,\n372, 373, 419, and 480-489 not used to fulfill other\nmajor requirements.\n4 \nWriters from Marginalized Groups Elective: Choose\nfrom ENGLISH 309, 311, 314 [M], 317, 321, 322 [M],\n341 [M], 345 [M], or 409. Students should consider\nthe University requirement of two [M] courses when\nselecting course.\n5 \nEnglish Literature Elective: Choose from ENGLISH\n366, 370, 373, 419, 483, 484, 485, 486, 487, 488,\n489, HUMANITY 302 [M], 303 [M], 304, 335, 338,\n350, 410, or 450.\nMinors\nCreative Writing\nThe Creative Writing minor requires a minimum of\n16 credits, at least 9 of which must be upper-division\nand taken in residence at WSU or through WSU-\napproved education abroad or educational exchange\ncourses. Required courses include ENGLISH 251 or\n252; 9 credits to be chosen from ENGLISH 351, 352,\n353, 354, 355, 358, 359, 446, 451, 452, 453; 3 credits\nof any 300-400 level ENGLISH course; and 1 credit\nof ENGLISH 357 358, 498, 499.\nEnglish\nThe student must complete a minimum of 18 hours\nin English courses (excluding 101 and 198), half of\nwhich must be 300-400-level and taken in residence\nat WSU or through WSU-approved education\nabroad or educational exchange courses; ENGLISH\n302 is required.\nHumanities Minor\nThe Department of English administers the\nHumanities minor. For details, see the separate\nentry under “Humanities.”\nLinguistics\nThe student must complete 18 credits to earn\nthe minor in Linguistics, half of which must be\n300-400-level taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses. Required courses: ENGLISH 256;\nENGLISH 443; ENGLISH 444; ENGLISH 457; two\nfrom ANTH 350, 450, ENGLISH 112, 454, 458, or\nPHIL 443.\nProfessional Writing\nThe professional writing minor requires 18 hours,\nhalf of which must be 300-400-level and taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses,\nand include ENGLISH 301, 402 or 403 and 461. In\naddition, 12 hours from ENGLISH 255, 256, 300,\n354, 355, 401, 402, 403, 405, 478 and 498 are\nrequired.\nCertificates\nEditing and Publishing Certificate\nThis career-oriented program equips students with\na working, practical knowledge in the creative and\nprofessional fields of editing and publishing. To\nearn the certificate, students must complete the\nfollowing three core courses: ENGL 355, 357, and\n405 (9 credits), plus one (3 credit) elective from the\nfollowing: ENGL 451, 452, 453, or 477. Students\nmust also complete two 1-credit internships from\na slate of approved editorial-based positions. The\ncapstone course is a 1-credit directed study approved\nby the student’s advisor. Students must complete all\ncoursework with a 3.0 GPA or better.\nProfessional Science and\nTechnology Writing Certificate\nTo earn the Professional Science and Technology\nWriting Certificate, students must complete\nENGLISH 301, 402, and 495, and two electives from\nANIM SCI 280, 285, ANTH 260, 309, BIOLOGY 110,\n125, 135, 330, 393, 394, 401, BIOLOGY/WOMEN ST\n407, CES 465, ENTOM 150, FS 201, HISTORY 381,\n382, HORT 150, MATH 398, MBIOS 320, PHIL 350,\n365, 370, PSYCH 320, 401, 403, PSYCH/WOMEN\nST 324, SOC 333, SOE 210, 275, 285, 312, 335, 438,\nSOIL SCI 360, or STAT 205. All coursework must be\ncompleted with a 3.00 GPA or higher. The certificate\ncan be earned through the Global Campus and/or\non-campus offerings. The university undergraduate\ncertificate fee will apply.\nProfessional Writing Certificate\nTo earn the Professional Writing Certificate, students\nmust complete the following five courses with a\n\n202\nEnglish\nWashington State University, 2021\n3.0 GPA or better: ANTH 350, ENGLISH 301, 355,\n402, and 498. ENGLISH 498 must be taken only\nafter the other four courses have been completed.\nThe certificate can be earned through the Global\nCampus and/or on-campus offerings. The university\nundergraduate certificate fee will apply.\nTeaching English as a Foreign\nLanguage Certificate\nTo earn the Teaching English as a Foreign\nLanguage Certificate, students must complete 18\nhours including the following courses: ENGLISH\n443, 444, 456, 457, FOR LANG 440 or 441, and 3\ncredits of ENGLISH 498. ENGLISH 256 is highly\nrecommended.\nDescription of Courses\nENGLISH\nENGLISH\n100 Introductory College Composition 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Appropriate Writing\nExam score. Designed to introduce students\nto writing and reading in the university.\n101 [WRTG] College Composition 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Appropriate Writing Exam score\nor completion of ENGLISH 100 with an S\ngrade. Designed to further develop students’\nacademic writing, critical thinking, rhetorical\nstrategies, reading and library skills. Credit not\ngranted for more than one of ENGLISH 101\nand 105.\n102 Writing Tutorial 1 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 2 hours. Student-\ncentered group tutorial focusing on writing\nimprovement; concurrently connected to the\nENGLISH 101 course. S, F grading.\n104 I n t r o d u c t o r y C o m p o s i t i o n f o r\nMultilingual Writers 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAppropriate Writing Exam score. Designed to\nintroduce non-native speakers of English to\nwriting and reading in the university.\n105 [WRTG] College Composition for\nMultilingual Writers 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAppropriate Writing Exam score, or ENGLISH\n104 with a C or better. Designed to further\ndevelop academic writing, critical thinking,\nreading, library skills, and rhetorical strategies\nfor non-native speakers of English. Credit not\ngranted for more than one of ENGLISH 101\nand 105.\n106 [COMM] Communicating in Academic\nContexts 3 Designed to help improve listening\nand speaking skills for better participation in\nacademic interactions across campus. For ESL\nstudents.\n107 Writing Tutorial for Multilingual\nWriters 1 (0-3) May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 5 hours. Student-\ncentered group tutorial focusing on writing\nimprovement usually connected to the\nENGLISH 105 course. S, F grading.\n108 [HUM] Introduction to Literature 3\nReading short stories, novels, plays, and poetry\nby diverse voices; role of conventions, culture,\nhistory in interpretation of literature. Walsh, R. S.\nZack; Associate Professors, D. W. Crowder, D. G. James,\nJ. Owen; Assistant Professors, E. Murray, T. Northfield;\nAssistant Research Professors, S. Bossert, J. Guterriez\nIllan, B. Hopkins, N. Naeger, L. Nottingham; Assistant\nExtension Professor, W. S. Wheeler; Professors Emeriti,\nJ. J. Brown, J. F. Brunner, V. Hebert, V. Jones, G. E. Long,\nK. S. Pike, G. L. Piper, L. K. Tanigoshi, W. J. Turner.\nInsects and related arthropods are dominant\ncomponents in all terrestrial and most freshwater\necosystems. There are more species of insects than all\nthe other species of animals and plants combined.\nThis almost unimaginable diversity provides the\nmost fertile resource for scientific inquiry within\na number of areas of biology. Entomology at\nWashington State University is active, robust, and\ndynamic. The curriculum provides the opportunity\nto investigate the basic and applied aspects of the\nscience. Facilities and training are available for study\nin major areas of entomology including, but not\nlimited to, apiculture, behavior, integrated biological\ncontrol and sustainable pest management, ecology,\ninsect/plant interactions, population genetics,\nphysiology, taxonomy/systematics, biological\ndiversity, environmental toxicology, and medical/\nveterinary entomology. We believe that a detailed\nunderstanding of insect biology is a prerequisite\nto developing rational, effective, and sustainable\nmanagement practices.\nThe entomology curriculum provides the\nopportunity to study basic and applied aspects of\nentomology and prepares students employment\nin all aspects and levels of the science. Courses\nprovide needed training for students in agriculture,\neducation, veterinary medicine, microbiology,\npublic health, environmental sciences, and natural\nsciences.\nThe department offers courses of study leading\nto the degrees of Bachelor of Science in Biology\nwith an Entomology option https://www.catalog.\nwsu.edu/General/Academics/Info/10; Master of\nScience in Entomology, and Doctor of Philosophy\n(Entomology). Additional information can be\nobtained on the web at http://entomology.wsu.edu.\nIntegrated Pest Management\nIntegrated pest management is a multidisciplinary\nfield. The Agriculture and Food Security major\nprepares students to manage plant pests and diseases.\nStudents learn to understand the complexity of\nrelationships within agricultural ecosystems, how\nexternal factors influence these systems, and how\nto effectively manage pests and diseases without\nincurring undue risks to human or environmental\nhealth. The major is offered under Agricultural and\nFood Systems, http://afs.wsu.edu/.\nStudents electing this major will take courses\nin the Departments of Crop and Soil Sciences,\nEntomology, Horticulture, and Plant Pathology.\nStudents acquire a holistic perspective and ecological\nunderstanding of the philosophy, principles, and\npractices of pest management and are trained to\nbecome professional crop protection specialists.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nAs preparation for work toward an advanced\ndegree in entomology, a student should have\ncompleted an undergraduate major in one of the\nbiological or physical sciences, forestry, agriculture,\nor a closely related field. Potential students with\nmajors in other disciplines are considered on an\nindividual basis. Background work should include\ncourses in the biological and physical sciences,\ngenetics, ecology, entomology, and the plant and\nanimal sciences.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n(For the Master of Science and Doctor of Entomology\nDegrees)\nThe Department of Entomology offers graduate\nprograms leading to Doctoral and Master of Science\ndegrees. Upon completion of a Degree Program in\nEntomology, it is expected that graduates will be\nhave:\n• Knowledge of Entomology and Its Application\n• Exercise Critical and Creative Thinking\n• Perform Statistical Analyses and Research\nMethods\n• They will be able to begin and complete a\nresearch program by using the knowledge they have\naccrued by active field research.\nThe curriculum provides the opportunity to study\nthe basic and applied aspects of the science. Facilities\nand training are available for graduate study in major\nareas of entomology, including (but not limited to)\napiculture; behavior; integrated biological control\nand sustainable pest management; ecology; insect/\nplant interactions; medical/veterinary entomology;\npopulation genetics; physiology; systematics;\nphylogeny and genomics; biological diversity and\nenvironmental toxicology. Departmental faculty,\nadjunct faculty, and affiliate faculty may all serve\nas student advisors. Faculty are housed both on\ncampus and at Research and Extension Centers\nthroughout the state; the ability to significantly\ninteract with both on- and off-campus advisors\nand mentors offers students opportunities and\nperspectives not available in most programs. We\nmaintain strong cooperative interactions with the\nUSDA ARS lab in Yakima, Washington. Students\nwhose major advisor resides at a Research and\nExtension Center (Wenatchee, Prosser, Puyallup,\nMt. Vernon or USDA Wapato) typically come to\nPullman for at least two semesters then relocate to\nthe center where they will conduct their research\nand take the remainder of their coursework via\ninteractive videoconference systems. Each student’s\nprogram of study is individualized based on their\nresearch interests, prior academic experience, and\ncollaboration with their major advisor.\nDescription of Courses\nENTOMOLOGY\nENTOM\n101 [BSCI] Insects and People: A Perspective\n3 The world’s most abundant animals and their\nextensive effects on people yesterday and\ntoday.\n102 [BSCI] Insects, Infection and Illness:\nMedical Entomology for Non-Science\nMajors 4 (3-3) Multidisciplinary aspects of\ninfectious disease caused by insect transmission\nof pathogens.\n103 [BSCI] Discover Insects: Laboratory for\nNon-Science Majors 1 (0-3) The biology and\ndiversity of insects provide the context for\ntraining in the scientific method, including\nways to take measurements, gather data, and\norganize information.\n150 [BSCI] Insects, Science, and World\nCultures 3 (2-3) An interdisciplinary view\nof the global impact of insects on humans in\nthe arts, myths and legends, cuisine, human\nnutrition, agriculture, sustainability, and\nmedicine; exploration of the use of insects and\ntheir products in culture, scientific research,\nand forensics. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n201 [BSCI] Science in the Public Eye 3 Course\nPrerequisite: [PSCI] UCORE or concurrent\nenrollment, [BSCI] UCORE or concurrent\nenrollment, or sophomore standing. Scientific\nliteracy in biology and medicine, using\nevolutionary theory as the unifying framework\nfor all life.\n340 Agricultural Entomology 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 106 or 107. Control,\nidentification, and biology of insects and\nrelated arthropods. Course equivalent to OSU’s\nEnt 311 and UI’s Ent 322.\n\n207\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\n343 [M] General Entomology 3 Biology, natural\nhistory, and importance of insects and related\narthropods.\n344 [M] General Entomology Laboratory 2\n(0-6) Identification and taxonomy of insects\nand related arthropods; insect collection and\nfield work required.\n351 E c o l o g i c a l a n d I n t e g r a t e d P e s t\nManagement 3 Course Prerequisite:\nBIOLOGY 106, 107, or 120. Philosophy,\necological foundation, tactics, and strategies\nof ecologically-based and integrated pest\nmanagement.\n361 Honey Bee Biology 3 Biology of the honey\nbee, including behavior, genetics, evolution,\npollination, sociality, and beekeeping\npractices. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n401 Biology and Society, Past and Present\n3 Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106.\nDevelopment of biological ideas and\nknowledge from antiquity to present with\nemphasis on major advances achieved\nthrough invertebrate models. Recommended\npreparation: BIOLOGY 150. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n448 Medical and Veterinary Entomology 3\nBiology and ecology of parasitic arthropods\nand their direct impacts on human and animal\nhealth; transmission of pathogens. Credit not\ngranted for both ENTOM 448 and ENTOM 548.\n460 Biotechnology and the Environment 3\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106, 107, or 120;\n3 credit hours CHEM. Benefits, regulations,\nand human and environmental impacts\nof biotechnology used for crop protection,\nagricultural and energy production, and\nenvironmental remediation and management.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ENTOM 460, SOE\n460).\n490 Special Topics in Entomology V 1-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n10 hours. Credit not granted for both ENTOM\n490 and ENTOM 590. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n511 Science Writing Workshop 2 Instruction,\ntools, and peer review support to write\ngraduate research proposal or journal article.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CROP SCI 511,\nENTOM 511, SOIL SCI 511).\n539 Taxonomic Entomology 4 (2-6) Survey of\napproximately 200 major families; collecting\nand preservation techniques. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n540 Taxonomy of Immature Insects V 2-4\nIdentification of eggs, larvae, nymphs, and\npupal stages of insects. Insect collection\nrequired.\n548 Medical and Veterinary Entomology 3\nBiology and ecology of parasitic arthropods\nand their direct impacts on human and animal\nhealth; transmission of pathogens. Credit not\ngranted for both ENTOM 448 and ENTOM 548.\n550 Insect Physiology 3 General principles of\ninsect physiology; the mechanisms of vital\nprocesses in insects; organ, cellular, subcellular,\nchemical and physical levels. Required\npreparation must include BIOLOGY 332, 352,\nCHEM 345, ENTOM 340, or 343. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n555 Agricultural Chemical Technology\nfor Crop Protection & Production 3\nMechanistic examination of agricultural\nchemical technology; synthetic and biological\npesticides and fertilizers; mechanism of\nbiological activity; deployment; management.\n556 Insecticides: Toxicology and Mode of\nAction 1 Insecticides in terms of historical\nperspective, classification, synthesis, toxicity,\nmode of action, and metabolism. Required\npreparation must include MBIOS 303; CHEM\n345; BIOLOGY 352, 420, or 350.\n557 Herbicides: Toxicology and Mode of\nAction 1 Herbicides in terms of historical\nperspective, classification, synthesis, toxicity,\nmode of action, and metabolism. Required\npreparation must include MBIOS 303; CHEM\n345; BIOLOGY 352, 420, or 350.\n558 Pesticide Topics 1 Current issues concerning\npesticides in terms of toxicity, mode of action,\nand metabolism. Required preparation must\ninclude MBIOS 303; CHEM 345; BIOLOGY\n352, 420, or 350.\n590 Special Topics in Entomology V 1-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n10 hours. Credit not granted for both ENTOM\n490 and ENTOM 590. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n593 Seminar 1 May be repeated for credit.\nReporting and discussing problems and\nresearch in entomology.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 702 credit. S, F\ngrading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe Entomology PhD program. Independent\nresearch and advanced study for students\nworking on their doctoral research, dissertation\nand/or final examination. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nINTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT\nIPM\n201 Introduction to Pest Management in a\nQuality Environment 2 Pest management\nto maximize plant protection and safeguard\nthe quality of the environment.\n399 Pest Management Internship V 1-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n7 hours. Supervised individual practicum with\nIPM-oriented businesses, organizations, and\ngovernmental agencies; professionally related\nfield interaction. S, F grading.\n452 Pesticides and the Environment 3\nImmediate and prolonged effects of pesticides\non human and other animals; legal and\nmoral repercussions of pesticide use. Credit\nnot granted for both IPM 452 and 552.\nRecommended for graduate-level course: 12\ncredit hours of biology or ecology courses.\n552 Pesticides and the Environment 3\nImmediate and prolonged effects of pesticides\non human and other animals; legal and\nmoral repercussions of pesticide use. Credit\nnot granted for both IPM 452 and 552.\nRecommended for graduate-level course: 12\ncredit hours of biology or ecology courses.\nSchool of the Environment\nenvironment.wsu.edu\nWebster Physical Science Bldg, 1228\n509-335-3009\nStudent Svs: Webster 1227, 509-335-8538\nDirector and Professor, C. K. Keller; Associate Director\nfor Undergraduate Education and Clinical Associate\nProfessor, A. B. King; Associate Director for Research\nand Graduate Studies and Professor, M. S. Carroll;\nProfessors, S. M. Bollens, S. Hampton, P. B. Larson,\nC. T. Robbins, L. A. Shipley, J. Vervoort; Associate\nProfessors, C. M. Cooper, A. K. Fremier, J. Harrison,\nS. Henderson, S. L. Katz, M. Kramer, S. P. Long, B. C.\nMoore, M. Ostrom, G. Rollwagen-Bollens, R. D. Sayler,\nM. Swanson; Assistant Professors, C. S. Goldberg, J.\nManning, J. McIntyre, K. Moffett, S. Roley, D. Singh,\nD. H. Thornton; Clinical Assistant Professor, M. Berger;\nSenior Instructor, K. Wilkie; Instructors, J. Menard, W.\nSchlosser, K. Whitman; Adjunct Faculty, H. Brenkert-\nSmith, S. Caddy, J. Chappell, S. Converse, R. Cook, D.\nDauble, R. Everett, J. Forbey, R. Gootee, B. Green, J.\nGross, C. Grue, L. Heinse, T. Johnson, E. Laija, B. T.\nMaletzke, O. Neill, T. Paveglio, P. L. Pavek, P. Regan,\nJ. L. Rachlow, L. Reed, T. S. Ridel, M. Rowe, M. A.\nSchroeder, S. Self, E. W. Shallenberger, K. Strickler, B.\nTissot, T. N. Tollefson; Affiliate Faculty, J. Bishop, C.\nBustamante, L. Carpenter-Boggs, A. Felsot, J. Freed,\nJ. Garcia-Pabon, J. Goldberger, T. Hudson, P. Jacoby,\nC. Mack, L. New, T. Norton, A. Perleberg, C. Shultz,\nJ. Stark, S. Sylvester, P. Thiers, K. Zobrist; Professors\nEmeriti, D. M. Baumgartner, K. A. Blatner, W. Budd,\nR. C. Chapman, F. F. Foit, A. Ford, D. Gaylord, D. P.\nHanley, L. H. Hardesty, G. W. Hinman, J. R. Pratt, P.\nE. Rosenberg, R. L. Shew, A. Watkinson, G. D. Webster,\nJ. A. Wolff, G. I. Young.\nH u m a n s a r e r a p i d l y a l t e r i n g p l a n e t a r y\nbiogeochemical processes and earth systems\nwithout fully knowing the consequences.\n\n208\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\nEnvironmental challenges include food, water, and\nenergy shortages, changing climate and weather\npatterns, rising and acidifying oceans, depleted\nsoil and forest resources, and endangerment of a\nthird or more of all the natural biological diversity\nof life on Earth. In response, society is shifting\npriorities to address these issues and students are\nlooking for degrees that provide interdisciplinary\ntraining to tackle these emerging problems. Never\nbefore has there been such urgent need to address\ncomplex, multidimensional environmental and\nsocial problems.\nThe WSU School of the Environment strives to\ncreate synergy by marrying research, teaching, and\nextension efforts to ensure an ecologically sound,\nsocially responsible, and economically viable future\nfor communities in Washington. The School\nintegrates the geosciences (the physical context\nfor global change), ecosystem and natural resource\nsciences (the biological context), and social/\nsustainability sciences (the human context). School\nfaculty are located throughout WSU – in Pullman,\nTri-Cities, Vancouver, and the WSU research and\nextension centers.\nFaculty and students in the School are:\n• Generating fundamental knowledge about the\nEarth, environmental and ecological processes,\nnatural resources, and human-environment\ninteractions.\n• Developing solutions to state, national, and\nglobal environmental problems (e.g., sustainable\nuse of water, forests, wildlife, and other natural\nresources).\n• Providing cutting-edge interdisciplinary\nundergraduate and graduate training to the next\ngeneration of research scientists, environmental and\nnatural resource managers, environmental leaders,\npolicy makers, and global citizens.\n• Facilitating the integrated research and education\nnecessary to support the Land Grant mission to\nachieve a sustainable future.\n• Promoting the long-term conservation and\nenhancement of biological diversity and natural\nresources in an ecologically sustainable manner.\nThe WSU School of the Environment has defined\nseveral core themes to better address new and\nemerging challenges in the study of earth,\nenvironment, and ecology. These include:\n•“Water: Connecting Earth and Life,” current\nstrengths in eco-hydrology: modeling land and\nwater interactions, biophysical, chemical and\necological dynamics in freshwater ecosystems and\nwater resources in the Columbia River Basin.\n•“Global Change: Sustaining Healthy Landscapes\nand Communities,” existing strengths in\nlandscape and spatial ecology, wildlife ecology and\nconservation of biodiversity, restoring ecosystems,\nand environmental social science.\n•“Dynamic Earth,” Earth system science, with\nexisting strengths in earth system chemistry,\nplanetary evolution and deep time, and geologic\nand environmental hazards.\nSpecific information below describes courses and\nmajors under the Bachelor of Science in Earth and\nEnvironmental Sciences.\nBS in EARTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL\nSCIENCES\nThe School of the Environment offers a BS in Earth\nand Environmental Sciences with majors in: Earth\nSciences, Environmental and Ecosystem Sciences,\nForest Ecology and Management, and Wildlife\nEcology and Conservation Sciences. Additional\ninformation about the School can be found at:\nhttp://environment.wsu.edu/.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nGraduates of the School of the Environment\nare concerned with the diverse environmental\nchallenges confronting the future of all life on Earth.\nStudents learn to communicate and use critical\nthinking and creative problem solving to address\npressing issues confronting global ecology and\nsustainability on a dynamic and changing Earth.\nStudents apply scientific methods, quantitative and\nsymbolic reasoning, and decision-making processes\nas individuals or teams to explore complex scientific\nand environmental issues and analyze problems in\nboth the natural and social sciences. We emphasize\nrealistic experiential education (e.g., hands-on\nlabs, field trips and camps) to prepare students\nfor graduate studies or employment in the fields\nof natural resources, environmental science or\nearth sciences. Graduates achieve expertise in a\nprofessional specialty and develop the technical\nskills and a deeper understanding of the science\nand environmental management needed to succeed\nin a global society increasingly dependent on\ndeveloping a sustainable future.\nWeb Link: http://environment.wsu.edu/\noutcomes/\nEarth Sciences Major\nEarth Science is the study of the Earth, its\ncomposition, processes, structure, origin and\nevolution. Virtually every aspect of modern life is\nin some way dependent on the science of geology.\nThe geologic record provides the context for\nunderstanding episodes of past rapid global change.\nIt is also the geologist’s job to evaluate groundwater\nquality and quantity for drinking water supply,\ndiscover new reserves of energy and raw materials,\nassess geologic hazards in land-use planning and\nunravel the mechanisms of volcanism, earthquakes,\nplate tectonics and the origins of life.\nIn addition to the University Common\nRequirements (UCORE), basic science courses\nand the School of the Environment common\ncore, students majoring earth sciences complete a\nseries of 300-400-level courses designed to provide\ntraining for professional geological work as well as\npreparation for postgraduate study.\nThe School of the Environment has well-\nequipped geological laboratory facilities, including\nelectron microprobe, X-ray diffraction and\nfluorescence instruments, a laser ablation cell\nand 6 mass spectrometers for the determination\nof trace elements, isotope ratios, and organic\ncompounds. There are active research programs in\nvolcanology, geochemistry, tectonics, groundwater\nand contaminant hydrology, sedimentology,\nstratigraphy, and astrobiology.\nEarth Sciences majors are expected to graduate\nwith a complete understanding of earth, including\nits constituent materials, environments, and\nprocesses through which these materials form and\ninteract, and its physical, chemical, and biological\nevolution. Students are expected to be capable\nof examining and interpreting relations among\ngeologic materials in the field. Problem solving and\ncritical thinking will be applied in the classroom,\nlaboratory, and field, and effective communication\nskills will be expected. Students will demonstrate\nquantitative understanding of earth materials and\nprocesses.\nThe Geology Club is open to all students\ninterested in geology and allied sciences. It provides\nadditional opportunities for our students to learn\nabout local and regional geology. Weekend field\nand mineral collecting trips take advantage of the\nvery diverse geology of the inland northwest region,\nand provides other out-of-class opportunities for\nstudents to informally interact with each other,\nfaculty and professionals outside of WSU.\nAs preparation for work toward an advanced\ndegree in geology, a student should have completed,\nor plan to take without graduate credit, the following\nor their equivalents: SOE 102, 207, 210, 315, 320,\n340, 350, 356; one year of general physics; one\nyear of general inorganic chemistry; mathematics\nthrough two semesters of calculus. A minimum GPA\nof 3.0 is normally required for admission.\nEnvironmental and Ecosystem Sciences\nMajor\nThe Environmental and Ecosystem Sciences\nmajor is offered for students interested in\nbiological, physical, or socioeconomic aspects of\nenvironmental and natural sciences. This is the\nmost flexible of our majors, offering exceptional\nopportunities for tailoring of courses to match\nindividual student interests and needs within the\nrealm of environmental and ecosystem sciences.\nEnvironmental and Ecosystem Sciences is\nconcerned with natural and managed environments\nand their interactions with biological and human\nsystems. Emphasis is put on the comprehensive\nunderstanding of environmental and ecological\ncontexts, assessment of beneficial and disruptive\nanthropogenic impacts, and methodologies to\nanalyze and resolve conflict in complex systems.\nStudents acquire interdisciplinary perspectives\nand understanding necessary to prepare them\nfor a variety of roles in the study, planning and\nmanagement of the environment.\nAll students in Environmental and Ecosystem\nSciences major will receive a well-rounded, general\nscience background in the physical and life sciences.\nThey will develop an in-depth, interdisciplinary\nexpertise in an area of concentration within the\nfield. In addition to the University Common\nRequirements (UCORE), basic science courses and\na common core taken by all students completing a\nBS in Earth and Environmental Sciences, students\nselect a structured set of courses in concert with\ntheir advisor based upon their area(s) of primary\ninterest. Lists of approved electives are available\nfrom an advisor.\nThe School of the Environment has well-equipped\nlaboratory facilities for physical, chemical, and\nbiological assessment of aquatic ecosystems (streams\nand lakes), modeling environmental processes,\nand evaluating impacts of human activities. There\nare active research programs examining effects of\ninvasive species, ecosystem restoration, and many\naspects of water resource management.\nThe Environmental Science Club provides\nopportunities for students with common interests\nto share ideas and discuss relevant topics concerning\nenvironmental issues. The club contributes to\nsustainability programs at WSU and helps promote\nenvironmentally conscious activities on and around\n\n209\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\nthe WSU campus. In addition, it provides out of class\nopportunities for students to interact with faculty\nand other professionals. These interactions create\nopportunities for networking that helps students\nfind summer and permanent employment as well\nas internship opportunities in their chosen field.\nForest Ecology and Management Major\nThe Forest Ecology and Management major is\ndesigned to provide students the educational basis\nfor successfully pursuing a professional career\nin forestry. Each forestry student, in addition to\ncompleting the university UCORE requirements,\nbasic science requirements, the School of the\nEnvironment environmental common core\ntakes a block of forestry classes in such areas as\nforest measurements, sampling, remote sensing,\ngeographic information systems, plant ecology\nand silviculture. In addition, students completing\nthe basic requirements of this degree also have the\noption to select a limited number of professional\nelectives to further focus their basic skill set. For\nexample, by selecting the correct courses students\nmay easily complete a minor in geospatial analysis.\nStudents completing this degree also meet the\nqualifications required in U.S. Office of Personnel\nManagement for forester.\nThe student chapter of the Society of American\nForesters (Forestry Club) provides out of class\nopportunities for students to interact with each\nother socially and professionally, with the faculty\nand other professionals in the region. Students\nregularly work on forestry related projects for\nlandowners in the area under the supervision of\nfaculty members, gaining practical field experience\nand further insights into the profession. These\nexperiences are often helpful in obtaining summer\njobs, internships and professional employment\nupon graduation.\nWildlife Ecology and Conservation Major\nThe Wildlife Ecology and Conservation major\nprovides students with a basic background in the\nsciences plus additional courses emphasizing wildlife\necology and management of wildlife habitats and\npopulations. Students are prepared to pursue a variety\nof careers focusing on wildlife biology and wildlife\nmanagement. The core requirements plus approved\nwildlife electives may allow majors to meet the US\nOffice of Personnel Management requirements for\nwildlife biologist, wildlife refuge manager, general\nbiologist, and zoologist. Through judicious use of\nelectives a student can also meet additional civil\nservice requirements for fish biologist and range\nconservationist. Wildlife students can further\nindividualize and often enhance their professional\ncredentials by minoring in another subject such as\ncriminal justice, geospatial analysis, or forestry.\nIn addition to the University Common\nRequirements (UCORE), basic science courses and\nthe School of the Environment common core,\nstudents in this major complete a core of wildlife\nclasses emphasizing wildlife ecology, management,\nnutrition, population ecology, and conservation\nbiology. Opportunities for specialization and pursuit\nof individual student interests beyond the wildlife\ncore are provided through approved electives in the\nareas of habitat ecology, aquatic ecology, animal\necology, and conservation biology. Students\nseeking to complete the key science perquisites for\nadmission to the College of Veterinary Medicine\nmay do so as a part of this major through the pre-\nvet option.\nThe student chapter of The Wildlife Society\nprovides out of class opportunities for students\nincluding lectures, field trips, hands-on learning\nwhile interacting with socially and professionally\nwith each other, faculty and other professionals.\nThese types of contacts along together with\nemploying organizations and interaction with\ncareer services on campus help students obtain\nsummer and permanent employment, as well as\ninternship and cooperative education opportunities\nin their chosen field.\nTeaching and research facilities and laboratories\non campus provide students with knowledge and\ntraining in wildlife ecology and conservation,\nincluding Bear Research Education and Conservation\nProgram, Wild Ungulate and Small Mammal\nResearch Facility, Large Carnivore Conservation Lab,\nEndangered Species Lab, Conservation Genetics and\nEnvironmental DNA Lab, Geographic Information\nSystem Lab, and the E.H. Steffen Center. These\nfacilities and nearby natural forest, rangeland and\naquatic ecosystems provide opportunities for field\nand experiential learning.\nPre-Veterinary Medicine\nStudents seeking to complete the key science\nperquisites for admission to the College of\nVeterinary Medicine may do so through the proper\nselection of basic science courses and through the\nuse of their electives within the Wildlife Ecology\nand Conservation Sciences.\nMinors\nThe School of the Environment offers minors in:\nEarth Science, Environmental Science, Forestry,\nNatural Resources, and Wildlife Ecology. Please\ncontact one our offices for more information.\nTransfer Students\nTransfer students should plan to complete the\nbasic required courses in English composition,\nchemistry, speech, biological sciences, mathematics,\nmicroeconomics, social sciences, and arts and\nhumanities by the end of their sophomore year.\nStudents may be granted credit for equivalent\ntechnical courses taken at other academic\ninstitutions. Refer to WSU Transfer Guides for\nCommunity Colleges, available through the web,\nfor details.\nGraduate Programs\nGraduate programs provide students with an\nincreased depth of knowledge of the scientific\nbasis of their profession and a more complete\nunderstanding of the holistic nature of global\nchange science.\nThe School of the Environment offers thesis-based\nMS degrees in:\n• Environmental Sciences\n• Geology\n• Natural Resource Sciences\nPhD degrees are offered in:\n• Environmental and Natural Resource Sciences\n• Geology\nFor each graduate degree, students may specialize\nin a variety of biological, geochemical, physical\nor social science aspects of Earth, environmental\nor natural resource science through advanced\ncoursework and graduate research. Graduate\ncourse requirements are flexible, and students with\ndegrees in related fields are encouraged to apply. To\nbe accepted to graduate study, applicants must (1)\nmeet the Graduate School’s minimum admission\nrequirements, (2) complete the department’s\nsupplemental application form, (3) submit Graduate\nRecord Exam (GRE) scores and (4) have at least one\nmember of the department’s faculty willing to serve\nas the student’s major advisor. (Note: the School\nof the Environment does not have a minimum\nrequired GRE score for admission.) Students\ninterested in graduate study should consult the\nWSU Graduate Bulletin and contact the School\nof the Environment for further information on\nopportunities and requirements.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nEARTH SCIENCES\n(123 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Earth Sciences\nmajor upon making their intention known to the\nSchool of the Environment.\nA student maintains eligibility for the major by\ncompleting each of the following courses with a\nC or better by the start of the third semester in the\nmajor: SOE 101 or 102, SOE 110, and CHEM 101 or\n105. The following courses must be completed with\na C or better by the end of the fourth semester in the\nmajor: MATH 171, PHYSICS 101/111 or 201/211,\nand SOE 350. In addition, admitted students must\nmaintain a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0.\nA student who does not meet these minimum\nrequirements for maintaining eligibility in the major\nmay be released by the School of the Environment\nafter two semesters of failing to meet minimums.\nA student may be eligible to re-enter into the same\nmajor when minimum requirements are met.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 101[PSCI] or 105 [PSCI] 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 106 or electives\n1 \n3\nSOE 101 or 102 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 102 or 106 4\nECONS 101 [SSCI] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 108 or electives\n1 \n2\nSOE 210 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] 4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nPHYSICS 101 or 201 3\nPHYSICS 111 or 211 1\nSOE 350 4\nSecond Term Hours\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or 171 [QUAN]\n1 \n4\n\n210\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\nSOE 110 4\nProfessional Electives\n2,3 \n6 - 8\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Term Hours\nSummer Session: SOE 207 \n4 \n3\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nSOIL SCI 368 3\nSTAT 360, 370, or 412 3\nForeign Language, if needed, or Electives\n5 \n3 - 4\nProfessional Electives\n2,3 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nCOM 102 [COMM] or H D 205 [COMM] 3 or 4\nECONS 352 3\nSOE 315 or 461 3\nForeign Language, if needed\n5 \n0 or 4\nProfessional Electives\n23 \n6 - 8\nThird Term Hours\nSummer Session: SOE 408 [CAPS] [M],\nif needed\n3,6 \n0 or 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nSOE 300 or BIOLOGY 372 3 or 4\nProfessional Electives\n2,3 \n10\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSOE 312 [DIVR] 3\nSOE 404 [CAPS] [M], if needed, or\nProfessional Electives\n2,3,6 \n3\nElectives/Professional Electives\n2,3 \n6\nExit Survey\n7\n_______\n1 \nMATH 106 and 108 are required courses. However,\nif students have tested into or taken MATH 140, 171,\n172 or ALEKS with an 80% or better, MATH 106 and\n108 will be waived. If waived, students may need\nto take additional credits to meet the University\nminimum requirement of 120 credits.\n2 \nProfessional Electives: Students will complete a\ntotal of 31 credits of professional electives, 21 of\nwhich must be selected from one of three emphasis\nareas: 1) Solid Earth – approved courses include SOE\n303, 320, 340 [M], 404 [M], 405, 498; SOIL SCI 374;\n2) Earth Surface Processes, Soils, and Geography –\napproved courses include; BIOLOGY 469 [M]; SOE\n303, 311, 320, 335 [M], 340 [M], 404 [M], 405, 408\n[M], 412 [M], 416, 444; SOIL SCI 302, 374, 441/442;\nTCH LRN 487, or 3) Water and Climate – approved\ncourses include BIOLOGY 469 [M]; CE 401, 402,\n403; SOE 303, 311, 320 390, 408 [M], 412, 463,\n465, 475; SOIL SCI 374, 414/415. The remaining 10\ncredits of professional electives can be 300-400-level\ncourses chosen from any of the emphasis areas and\nmay need to include an [M] course, or selected from\na related field or sub-discipline and approved by the\nacademic advisor. Course used to fulfill the [CAPS]\nrequirement cannot be used to fulfill Professional\nElectives.\n3 \nThe School of the Environment requires students\nto take three [M] courses. The [CAPS] course required\nfor each emphasis fulfills one of the [M] courses. The\nremaining two [M] courses will be selected from the\nprofessional electives.\n4 \nSOE 207 is the approved Experiential Elective for\nEarth Science majors.\n5 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n6 \nUniversity [CAPS] course required for each\nemphasis is as follows: 1) Solid Earth - SOE 408\n[CAPS] [M]; 2) Earth Surface Processes, Soils, and\nGeography - SOE 404[CAPS] [M] or 408 [CAPS] [M];\nand 3) Water and Climate - SOE 404 [CAPS] [M].\n7 \nStudents must complete a School of the\nEnvironment exit survey, administered during the\nfinal semester.\nENVIRONMENTAL AND ECOSYSTEM\nSCIENCES\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Environmental\nand Ecosystem Sciences major upon making their\nintention known to the School of the Environment.\nA student maintains eligibility for the major by\ncompleting each of the following courses with a\nC or better by the end of the fourth semester in\nthe major: MATH 106, MATH 108, BIOLOGY 106,\nBIOLOGY 107, CHEM 101 or 105, CHEM 102 or\n106, SOE 101 or 102, and SOE 110. In addition,\nadmitted students must maintain a minimum\ncumulative GPA of 2.0.\nA student who does not meet these minimum\nrequirements for maintaining eligibility in the major\nmay be released by the School of the Environment\nafter two semesters of failing to meet minimums.\nA student may be eligible to re-enter into the same\nmajor when minimum requirements are met.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 106 or electives\n1 \n3\nSOE 110 [BSCI] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 101 [PSCI] or 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 108 or electives\n1 \n2\nSOE 101 or 102 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nECONS 101 [SSCI] 3\nSOE 210 or 250\n2 \n3 or 4\nForeign Language, if needed\n3 \n0 - 4\n200-level Required Electives\n4 \n2 or 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 102 or 106 4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSOE 300 or BIOLOGY 372 [M]\n2 \n3 or 4\nSTAT 212 [QUAN], MATH 140 [QUAN], or\n171 [QUAN] 4\nForeign Language, if needed\n3 \n0 - 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nCOM 102 [COMM] or H D 205 [COMM] 3 or 4\nSOIL SCI 368 3\nProfessional Electives\n5 \n7\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR], if needed, or Electives\n6 \n3\nSOE 312 [DIVR] or POL S 430\n6 \n3\nSOE 315 or 461 3\nSOE Experiential Requirement or Electives\n7 \n3\nProfessional Electives\n5 \n4\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nSOE 403, STAT 360, 370, or 412 \n8 \n3\nSOE 404 [CAPS] [M], 454 [CAPS] [M], or\n477 [CAPS] \n9 \n3\nWriting in the Major [M] or Electives\n10 \n3\nProfessional Electives\n5 \n7\nSecond Term Hours\nWriting in the Major [M] or Electives\n10 \n3\nProfessional Electives\n5,9 \n13\nExit Survey \n11\n_______\n1 \nMATH 106 and 108 are required courses. However,\nif students have tested into or taken MATH 140, 171,\n172 or ALEKS with an 80% or better, MATH 106 and\n108 will be waived. If waived, students may need\nto take additional credits to meet the University\nminimum of 120 credits.\n2 \nStudents who take SOE 250 must also take\nBIOLOGY 372.\n3 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n4 \nApproved 200-level required electives include SOE\n204, 230, 250, 275, 285. Not all courses available\non all campuses.\n5 \nEnvironmental and Ecosystem Sciences\nProfessional Electives (31 credits) are courses\nselected by students in concert with their advisor\nand pertain to their major and/or to a specific sub-\ndiscipline of interest. Professional electives may\nalso include courses from outside of their major\nas needed to complete a minor in another field of\nstudy. Approved courses include but are not limited\nto: ECONS 330, or any 300-400-level SOE or SOIL\nSCI course, or as approved by advisor.\n6 \nSOE 312 satisfies both the [DIVR] and the Society\nand Environmental Management requirements.\n7 \nSOE Experiential Requirement: Students in the\nSchool of the Environment are required to fulfill the\nSOE Experiential Requirement before graduation.\nThis requirement is designed to give students\nexperience they will not receive in the traditional\nclassroom-oriented course, and to better prepare\nthem for a successful career after graduation.\nStudents may choose 3 credits of coursework from\nSOE 492 or 495, or as approved by advisor. As an\nalternative to coursework, students may meet the\nrequirement by documenting at least 135 hours of\nrelevant practical experience. Students choosing the\npractical experience option may need an additional\n3 credits of electives to meet the University\nrequirement of 120 total credits.\n\n211\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\n8 \nMATH 172 is a prerequisite for STAT 360 and 370.\n9 \nStudents who take SOE 477 [CAPS] may need\nto take an [M] course within their Professional\nElectives to fulfill the requirement for 3 [M] courses.\n10 \nThe School of the Environment requires students\nto complete 3 [M] courses. Check with advisor for\ncourse recommendation.\n11 \nStudents must complete a School of the\nEnvironment exit survey, administered during the\nfinal semester.\nFOREST ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Forest Ecology and\nManagement major upon making their intention\nknown to the School of the Environment.\nA student maintains eligibility for the major by\ncompleting each of the following courses with a\nC or better by the end of the fourth semester in\nthe major: MATH 106, MATH 108, BIOLOGY 106,\nBIOLOGY 107, CHEM 101 or 105, SOE 204 and SOE\n301. In addition, admitted students must maintain\na minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0\nA student who does not meet these minimum\nrequirements for maintaining eligibility in the major\nmay be released by the School of the Environment\nafter two semesters of failing to meet minimums.\nA student may be eligible to re-enter into the same\nmajor when minimum requirements are met.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] 4\nECONS 101 [SSCI] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 106 or Electives\n1 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 101 [PSCI] or 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 108 or Electives \n1 \n2\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCOM 102 [COMM] or H D 205 [COMM] 3 or 4\nECONS 330 3\nSOE 204 2\nSOE 300 or BIOLOGY 372 3 or 4\nSOE 301 3\nSecond Term Hours\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or STAT 212 [QUAN] 4\nSOE 302 3\nSOE 312 [DIVR] 3\nSOIL SCI 201 3\nSOIL SCI 374 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nSOE 210 4\nSOE 304 4\nSOE 305 3\nSOIL SCI 368 3\nForeign Language, if needed\n2 \n0-4\nSecond Term Hours\nECONS 352 3\nSOE 315 or 461\n3 \n3\nSOE 403 3\nSOE 438 3\nSOE Experiential Requirement or electives\n4 \n3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSOE 446 [M] or 450 [M]\n5 \n3\nSOE 454 [CAPS] [M]\n5 \n3\nSTAT 412 3\nProfessional Electives\n6 \n3\nComplete Forestry Experiential Requirement\n7\nSecond Term Hours\nSOE 464 [M]\n5 \n3\nSOE 484 3\nSOE 485 4\nSOIL SCI 468 4\nForeign Language, if needed\n2 \n0-4\nExit Survey\n8\n_______\n1 \nMATH 106 and 108 are required courses. However,\nif students have tested into or taken MATH 140, 171,\n172 or ALEKS with an 80% or better, MATH 106 and\n108 will be waived. If waived, students may need\nto take additional credits to meet the University\nminimum requirement of 120 credits.\n2 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n3 \nSOE 315 requires additional prerequisites of CHEM\n102 or 106, and SOE 101 or 102.\n4 \nSOE Experiential Requirement: Students in the\nSchool of the Environment are required to fulfill the\nSOE Experiential Requirement before graduation.\nThis requirement is designed to give students\nexperience they will not receive in the traditional\nclassroom-oriented course, and to better prepare\nthem for a successful career after graduation.\nStudents may choose 3 credits of coursework from\nSOE 492 or 495, or as approved by advisor. As an\nalternative to coursework, students may meet the\nrequirement by documenting at least 135 hours of\nrelevant practical experience. Students choosing the\npractical experience option may need an additional\n3 credits of electives to meet the University\nrequirement of 120 total credits.\n5 \nThe School of the Environment requires students\nto take three [M] courses.\n6 \nForest Ecology and Management Professional\nElective (3 credits) is a course selected by students\nin concert with their advisor and pertaining to their\nmajor and/or to a specific sub-discipline of interest.\nApproved Professional electives include, but are not\nlimited to: any CRM J course or any 200-400-level\nANIM SCI, BIOLOGY, MBIOS, SOE, or SOIL SCI\ncourse.\n7 \nForestry Experiential Requirement: Forestry majors\nwill need to complete an additional 135 hours of\nvolunteer or paid work related to their field of\nstudy and approved by their advisor to meet the\nrequirements of the Forestry Core.\n8 \nStudents must complete a School of the\nEnvironment exit survey, administered during the\nfinal semester.\nWILDLIFE ECOLOGY AND CONSERVATION\nSCIENCES - HONORS ACCELERATED PRE-\nVET PROGRAM\n(124 HOURS)\nThis program allows qualified students in the\nHonors College to earn both a Bachelor of Science\nin Earth and Environmental Science and Doctor of\nVeterinary Medicine within a seven-year span.\nA student may be admitted to the Wildlife Ecology\n& Conservation Sciences major by making their\nintention known to the School of the Environment\nno later than the first semester of the sophomore\nyear.\nA student maintains eligibility for the major’s\naccelerated pre-vet program by completing each\nof the following courses with a C or better by the\nend of the third semester in the major: MATH 106,\nMATH 108, BIOLOGY 106, BIOLOGY 107, CHEM\n105, and SOE 300. In addition, admitted students\nmust maintain a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0.\nA student who does not meet these minimum\nrequirements for maintaining eligibility in the major\nmay be released by the School of the Environment\nafter two semesters of failing to meet minimums.\nA student may be eligible to re-enter into the same\nmajor when minimum requirements are met.\nFirst-Third Years\nStudents will participate in a three-year program,\ncompleting all Honors requirements, the Wildlife\nEcology and Conservation Sciences core, and pre-\nveterinary medicine requirements. Students must\ncomplete a minimum of 90 undergraduate credits\nincluding 30 credits of upper-division coursework\nin the first three years.\nFourth-Seventh Years\nStudents will enter the College of Veterinary\nMedicine and complete the requirements for total\ncredits and upper-division credits before earning\nthe BS in Earth and Environmental Sciences in their\nfourth year. Those students finishing all required\nclasses would complete only the DVM curriculum\nfrom this point on. Successful completion of the\nCollege of Veterinary Medicine program will earn\nthe Doctor of Veterinary Medicine.\nInterested students must be advised by faculty\nin the School of the Environment, and should\ncontact the school no later than the first semester\nof the sophomore year. NOTE: If the student is\nnot accepted or withdraws from the accelerated\ntrack, the student could earn the BS in Earth and\nEnvironmental Sciences and/or apply to the College\nof Veterinary Medicine under normal procedures.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 4\nCHEM 105 4\nENGLISH 298 3\nForeign Language, if needed\n1 \n0 - 4\nMATH 106\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 106 or 116 4\nECONS 198 3\nForeign Language, if needed\n1 \n0 - 4\nMATH 108\n2 \n2\n\n212\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nHONORS 280 3\nSOE 300\n3 \n3\nSOE 310 4\nSOIL SCI 368 3\nSTAT 212 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 345 4\nHONORS 290\n4 \n0 - 3\nHONORS 398\n5 \n0 - 1\nPHYSICS 101 3\nPHYSICS 111 1\nSOE 312 3\nSOE 431 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 301 4\nHONORS 370 3\nMBIOS 303 4\nSOE 301 3\nSOE 435 4\nSecond Term Hours\nHONORS 380 3\nHONORS 390 3\nHONORS 450 3\nSOE 302 3\nSOE 446 [M] 3\nSOE 450 [M] or 464 [M] 3\nComplete School of the Environment Exit Survey\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDVM coursework 15\nSecond Term Hours\nDVM coursework 15\n_______\n1 \nLanguage proficiency equivalent to four years of\nhigh school foreign language or four semesters of\ncollege-level foreign language are required by the\nHonors College for graduation.\n2 \nMATH 106 and 108 are required courses. HONORS 398\nshould be taken sophomore or junior year.\nWILDLIFE ECOLOGY AND CONSERVATION\nSCIENCES - PRE-VETERINARY OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Wildlife Ecology\nand Conservation Sciences major upon making their\nintention known to the School of the Environment.\nA student maintains eligibility for the major by\ncompleting each of the following courses with a\nC or better by the end of the fourth semester in\nthe major: Math 106, Math 108, Biology 106,\nBiology 107, Chemistry 105, SOE 204 and SOE\n300.
