However,\nif students have tested into or taken MATH 140, 171,\n172 or ALEKS with an 80% or better, MATH 106 and\n108 will be waived. If waived, students may need\nto take additional credits to meet the University\nminimum requirement of 120 credits.\n2 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n3 \nAdvanced Wildlife Elective (6 credits): Choose\nfrom SOE 318, 431, 446 [M], 450 [M], and 464 [M].\nSelecting at least one [M] course is recommended.\nThe School of the Environment requires students to\ntake three [M] courses.\n4 \nChoose one of the following three Water Science\ncourses: SOE 275 (fall), 411 (fall), or 461 (spring).\n5 \nWildlife Ecology and Conservation Sciences\nProfessional Electives (13 credits) are courses\nselected by students in concert with their advisor\nand pertain to their major and career goals. Selecting\nat least one [M] course is recommended. The School\nof the Environment requires students to take three\n[M] courses.\n6 \nChoose one of the following Animal Systematics\nCourses: BIOLOGY 423, 428, or 432 [M].\n7 \nChoose one of the following two plant courses:\nSOE 305 (Fall), or 306 (Spring).\n8 \nChoose one of the following two integrated\ncapstone courses: SOE 471 [CAPS] (spring), or 454\n[CAPS] [M] (fall).\n9 \nSOE Experiential Requirement: Students in the\nSchool of the Environment are required to fulfill the\nSOE Experiential Requirement before graduation.\nThis requirement is designed to give students\nexperience they will not receive in the traditional\nclassroom-oriented course, and to better prepare\nthem for a successful career after graduation.\nStudents may choose 3 credits of coursework from\nSOE 492 or 495, or as approved by advisor. As an\nalternative to coursework, students may meet the\nrequirement by documenting at least 135 hours of\nrelevant practical experience. Students choosing the\npractical experience option may need an additional\n3 credits of electives to meet the University\nrequirement of 120 total credits.\n10 \nStudents must complete a School of the\nEnvironment exit survey, administered during the\nfinal semester.\nMinors\nEarth Sciences\nAn Earth Science minor requires a minimum of\n16 credit hours. Required course: SOE 101 or 102.\nRestricted electives: at least 12 credit hours from SOE\n210, 230, 303, 315, 320, 340, 350, 405, 475. Credit\nhours for the minor must include 9 credit hours\nof 300-400-level course work taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses.\nEnvironmental Science\nA minor in Environmental Science requires a\nminimum of 16 credit hours. Students must\ncomplete SOE 110, 444, and a minimum of 8\nadditional credits hours selected from SOE 230,\n250, 275, 285, 300, 303, 312, 315, 335, 450, 454,\nand 483, or any advisor approved elective. Of\nthese 16 credit hours, 9 credit hours must be in\nupper-division work taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses. This minor is not\nopen to students majoring in Wildlife Ecology and\nConservation Sciences or in Environmental and\nEcosystem Sciences.\nForestry\nA minor in Forestry requires a minimum of 16\ncredit hours. Required courses: SOE 204, 300, 301,\nand 305. Restricted electives: at least 5 credit hours\nselected from SOE 435, 446, 450, 461, 464, SOIL\nSCI 368, 468. Credit hours must include 9 credit\nhours of upper-division work taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses.\nNatural Resources\nA Natural Resources Minor requires a minimum\nof 16 credit hours. Required course: SOE 100.\nRestricted electives: at least 15 credit hours from\nSOE 300, 301, 302, 305, 312, 403, 411, 417, 435,\n438, 450, 461, 464, and ECONS 330, with at least 9\ncredit hours of SOE courses with a natural resources\nfocus (wildlife, forestry, environmental science) or\nother approved courses numbered 300 or higher.\nThis minor is not open to students majoring in\nWildlife Ecology and Conservation Sciences or\nEnvironmental and Ecosystem Sciences. Credit\nhours for the minor must include 9 credit hours\nof upper-division work taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses.\nWildlife Ecology\nThe minor in Wildlife Ecology requires a minimum\nof 19 credit hours . Required courses: SOE 310 and\n435. Restricted electives: at least 11 credit hours\nfrom SOE 431, 441, 446, 450, and no more than\none of BIOLOGY 423, 428, or 432. Credit hours\nfor the minor must include 9 credit hours taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nCertificates\nWater Resources Science and\nManagement\nThe Certificate in Water Resources Science and\nManagement, administered by the School of the\nEnvironment, is an interdisciplinary certificate\nfor students interested in water resources. The\ncertificate includes 15 credits and an experiential\nrequirement. Students must complete a minimum\nof one course from each of four water cluster areas\nlisted below. Courses listed under more than one\ncluster area will not count toward two cluster\nareas simultaneously. Note that listed courses may\nrequire prerequisites. To ensure an interdisciplinary\nexperience, selected courses must represent two or\nmore different subject areas. A final grade of “C”\nor better is required for each course applied to the\ncertificate and a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or better\nis required for the certificate program as a whole.\nSubsurface and Surface Hydrology: CE 351, 402,\n460, SOE 250, 303, 315, 463, SOE/CE 475, SOIL SCI\n414;\nWater Chemistry/Ecology/Biology: AGTM 315,\nBIOLOGY 390, 465, 469, BSYSE 554, CE 341, 418,\nSOE 275, 300, 411, 412, 417, 454, 463, 464, 465,\n492;\nWater Methods & Analysis: CE 315, 341, 351, 415,\n416, 418, 419, 442, 450, 451, SOE 311, SOIL SCI 468;\nWater Policy & Management: CE 405, 456, CROP\nSCI 360, ECONS 330, 430, 431, HISTORY 422, SOC\n\n214\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\n331, 332, SOE 438, 444, 461;\nExperiential Requirement: In addition to the\ncourse requirements described above, the certificate\nalso includes an experiential requirement of\nrequired attendance at a minimum of three water-\nrelated activities hosted by the certificate program.\nParticipants in the program are required to attend\nWater Meeting and Social and Water Research Center\nInvited Lecture Event, both of which are conducted\nevery Fall and Spring semester. Additional activities\nthat may fulfill the Experiential Requirement\ninclude: field trips, documentary film screenings\nwith discussion, and water-related internships.\nThese additional activities require committee\napproval and/or competitive application.\nDescription of Courses\nSCHOOL OF THE ENVIRONMENT\nSOE\n100 An Introduction to Our Environment:\nGeology, Ecology, and Environmental\nStewardship 1 A holistic understanding\nof the Earth’s environment; knowledge of\ngeology, ecology, environmental science,\nand human political dimensions; basic\ncomprehension of environmental issues.\n101 [PSCI] Welcome to the Earth: An\nIntroduction to Geology 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for SOE 102. Introductory\nphysical geology for non-science majors;\nemphasis on western US. Credit not granted\nfor both SOE 101 and 102.\n102 Geology for Science Majors 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 103, 106, 140, 171, 201, or\n202, or concurrent enrollment in any of these,\nor a minimum ALEKS math placement score of\n40%. Enrollment not allowed if credit already\nearned for SOE 101. Modern concepts of earth\nscience; mineral rock, resource, and map study.\nField trip required. Credit not granted for both\nSOE 101 and 102.\n103 [PSCI] Other Worlds: Comparative\nPlanetology of our Solar System 3 Study\nof the geological processes and environments\non planets and moons of our solar system.\n105 [PSCI] Natural Resources and Natural\nHazards 3 Survey of key natural resources, the\nphysical processes by which nature and society\nproduce those resources, and the processes\nof related natural hazards. Recommended\nPreparation: MATH 103 or higher with a C or\nbetter, or a minimum ALEKS math placement\nscore of 45%.\n110 [BSCI] The Environment, Human Life,\nand Sustainability 4 (3-3) Interactions\nbetween humans and their environment;\nm u l t i d i s c i p l i n a r y i n t r o d u c t i o n t o\nenvironmental concepts and concerns.\n204 Field Methods for Careers in the\nNatural Sciences 4 (3-3) Introduction to\nbasic concepts, field techniques and the use of\nspreadsheets in natural resources. Field trips\nrequired.\n207 Geology Field Camp 3 (0-9) Course\nPrerequisite: SOE 101 or 102; SOE 210.\nIntroduction to geologic field methods; basic\ngeologic mapping.\n210 [PSCI] Earth’s History and Evolution 4 (3-\n3) Introduction to earth’s history and evolution\nthrough observations, data collection and\nanalysis, readings and writing exercises.\n230 [PSCI] Introductory Oceanography 3\nInterdisciplinary study of ocean systems:\nmarine geology, chemistry, physics and\nbiology; oceans’ influence on climate and\nresponse to human activity.\n250 [PSCI] Introduction to Earth System\nScience 3 Course Prerequisite: SOE 110 or\nBIOLOGY 106, each with a C or better. Earth’s\nfundamental systems (the geo-, atmo-, hydro-,\nand bio-spheres) in the context of global\nchange. Recommended: CHEM 101 or 105.\n275 Rivers: Form, Function, and Management\n3 Introduction to rivers, stream ecology, and\nrestoration.\n280 [PSCI] How the Earth’s Climate System\nWorks 3 Understanding how the Earth’s\nclimate system works to provide a scientific\nfoundation for making informed evaluations\nabout management and policy.\n285 The Science and Policy of Climate\nChange 3 Course Prerequisite: SOE 110. The\nscience of the climate system; the case for\nreducing greenhouse gas emissions, and the\nbest policies to do so.\n300 Natural Resource Ecology 3 Ecology as\napplied to management of natural resource\necosystems; biological diversity, conservation\nbiology, global climate change in natural\nresource ecology. Field trips required.\n301 Forest Plants and Ecosystems 3 (2-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: SOE 300 or BIOLOGY\n372 or concurrent enrollment in either.\nIdentification and ecology of forest plants with\nemphasis on trees and the ecosystems in which\nthey occur. Field trips required.\n302 Arid Land Plants and Ecosystems 3 (2-\n3) Course Prerequisite: SOE 300 or BIOLOGY\n372; SOE 301. Identification and ecology of\narid land plants (trees, shrubs, grasses, forbs)\nand the ecosystems in which they occur. Field\ntrips required.\n303 E n v i r o n m e n t a l G e o l o g y 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SOE 101 or 102. Geological\nhazards and geologic problems associated with\nhuman activities. Required field trip.\n304 Ecosystem Field Measurements 4 (3-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: SOE 204; SOE 300 or\nBIOLOGY 372 or concurrent enrollment in\neither; SOE 301 or concurrent enrollment.\nMeasurement and analysis of forests, wildlife\nhabitat, and rangelands using field equipment\nand spatial sampling techniques; development\nof employment skills in forestry, forest\nrestoration, and wildlife management.\n305 Silviculture 3 Course Prerequisite: SOE 204;\nSOE 300 or BIOLOGY 372; SOE 301. Stand\ndynamics, natural regeneration methods,\nintermediate stand treatment, relationships of\nnatural resource management to silvicultural\npractice. Field trips required.\n306 Plants in the Environment 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SOE 300. How plants interact\nwith their physical and biotic environments;\nphysiological function of plant acclimation,\nadaptation, and tolerance with emphasis on\nforests and trees.\n310 Methods in Wildlife Ecology 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 106 with a C or better.\nField and laboratory sampling techniques in\nwildlife research and management.\n311 Modeling the Environment 4 (3-3)\nConstruction and testing of computer\nsimulation models of environmental systems.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n312 [DIVR] Natural Resources, Society, and\nthe Environment 3 Social views of natural\nresources; processes by which these views are\ndeveloped and expressed; social conflict over\nnatural resources.\n314 Service Learning in Ecuador: Building\nSustainable Local Solutions for Human\nand Environmental Health 3 Experience\nworking alongside local communities in\nEcuador on projects that will improve rural\naccess to sustainable energy, clean water,\nimproved ecosystem health, and sustainable\nlivelihoods. Spring break field trip required.\n315 Water and the Earth 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: CHEM 102 or 106; one of MATH\n108, 140, 171, 172, 182, 201, 202, or ENGR 107;\none of SOE 101, SOE 102, 4 credits PHYSICS\n101 or 201, or PHYSICS 101 and 111, or\nPHYSICS 201 and 211. Global hydrologic cycle,\nincluding rivers and weathering, groundwater,\nrainwater and the atmosphere, oceans, human\nimpacts. Field research required.\n318 Wildlife Genetics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nBIOLOGY 106; BIOLOGY 107 with a C or\nbetter; one of MATH 106, 108, 140, 171, or\na minimum ALEKS math placement score of\n80%. Application of genetic tools for wildlife\nconservation and management, including\nforensics, detection of rare species, and\npopulation estimation. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n320 S e d i m e n t a r y P e t r o l o g y a n d\nSedimentation 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nSOE 350. Sedimentary rock composition and\norigins applying fundamental principles of\nsedimentology. Field trip required.\n322 Geology of the Pacific Northwest 3\nCourse Prerequisite: SOE 101 or 102. Physical\ngeology of the Pacific Northwest focusing on\ngeological processes important in its evolution.\nField trips required.\n335 [M] Environmental Policy and Law 3\nCourse Prerequisite: SOE 110. Global, national,\nand regional environmental issues and policy.\n340 [M] Structural Geology and Plate\nTectonics 4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite: One\nof MATH 106, 108, 140, 171, or a minimum\nALEKS math placement score of 80%; SOE\n210. Basic understanding and techniques of\nworking in deformed rocks in mountain belts.\nField trip required.\n\n215\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\n350 Earth Materials 4 (2-6) Course Prerequisite:\nCHEM 101 or 105; SOE 101, 102, 210, or 230.\nComposition, physical properties, structure,\ncrystallography, identification, and origin of\nminerals. Field trip required.\n356 Magmatic Processes 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: SOE 350. Study of volcanic\nactivity, generation and evolution of magma,\nand the formation and growth of Earth’s crust.\nField trips required.\n357 Introduction to Metamorphic Rocks\nand Minerals and How They Impact\nOur World 3 (2-3) Fundamental processes\nin the field of earth sciences; application of\ntheoretical concepts from metamorphism to\nchallenges and realities of the modern world,\nincluding climate, earthquakes, and industry.\n390 Living on the Edge: Global Climate\nChange and Earth History 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Global earth\nsystem: ocean, earth, atmosphere, biosphere,\nand cryosphere; human impact on the climate\nsystem; climate change data predictions;\ndebates.\n402 Human Health and the Environment 3\nProblem-solving approach to adverse effects\non human health caused by contamination\nof environmental media or anthropogenic\nchanges in ecosystems.\n403 Sampling for Terrestrial Ecosystem\nManagement 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisites:\nSOE 204; STAT 212 or 412. Simple random\nsampling, stratified sampling, and sampling\nin proportion to importance; foundation\npresented for selecting a sampling scheme,\nimplementing it in the field, and assessing\nvariance.\n404 [CAPS] [M] The Ecosystem 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SOE 110; BIOLOGY 106;\nBIOLOGY 372 or concurrent enrollment;\njunior standing. Ecosystem organization\nand processes; theory and applications to\ncontemporary environmental problems.\n405 Near Surface Geophysics 4 (3-3) Exploration\nof near surface geophysics techniques as\napplicable, but not limited to, groundwater\nanalysis, environmental remediation,\narchaeology, and natural resources detection.\n406 Introduction to Radiological Science\n3 Course Prerequisite: One course each in\nbiology, calculus, chemistry, and physics.\nFundamentals of atomic physics, interactions\nof radiation with matter, radiation dosimetry\nand biology, radioecology, and radiological\nhealth protection.\n408 [CAPS] [M] Field Geology 3 (0-9) Course\nPrerequisite: SOE 207; SOE 340; SOE 350;\nsenior standing. Advanced field problems\nand methods; data interpretation and report\npreparation. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n411 [M] Limnology and Aquatic Ecosystem\nManagement 3 (2-3) Introduction to\nthe science and management of aquatic\necosystems, emphasizing lakes.\n412 [M] Global Biogeochemistry 3 Cycles of\nbiogeochemically important elements and\nanthropogenic changes to those cycles in\nterrestrial and aquatic environments on a\nglobal scale. Field trip required. Credit not\ngranted for both SOE 412 and SOE 512.\n416 Soil Processes in the Earth’s Critical Zone\n3 Soil geochemistry and processes; theory and\napplications with a focus on reactions at the\nsolid, liquid, and gaseous interface between\nthe lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere,\nand biosphere. (Crosslisted course offered as\nSOE 416/516, SOIL SCI 416/516). Credit not\ngranted for both SOE/SOIL SCI 416 and SOE/\nSOIL SCI 516. Recommended preparation:\nBasic knowledge of soils (e.g. SOIL SCI 201 or\nequivalent; CHEM 106; PHYSICS 102).\n417 Fisheries Science and Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: SOE 411 or BIOLOGY\n412; STAT 212 or MATH 171. Background\non the development of fisheries science\nand examination of the natural and social\nscientific theories and techniques applied to\nthe management of fisheries.\n420 L o n g - t e r m R e s e a r c h i n F o r e s t\nEcosystems: Old-growth Forests of\nYosemite National Park 3 Course\nPrerequisite: By instructor permission. Field\nresearch methods course in forest ecosystems\nat site in old-growth mixed-conifer forest in\nYosemite National Park. Course usually runs\nin late May.\n430 Introduction to Wildland Fire 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SOE 300 or BIOLOGY 372; SOE\n301. Physical nature and behavior of wildland\nfire; the fire environment; fire ecology; practice\nof wildland fire management. Field trip\nrequired.\n431 Wildlife Nutrition 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 106 with a C or\nbetter; BIOLOGY 107 with a C or better;\njunior standing. Nutritional requirements\nand interactions of wildlife populations.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n435 Wildlife Ecology 4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite:\nBIOLOGY 372 or SOE 300; STAT 212 or 412;\njunior standing. The ecology of wildlife species\nand the contributing biological processes.\nOvernight field trip required.\n438 Natural Resource and Public Lands\nPolicy and Law 3 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. Development, content and\nimplementation of natural resources and\nenvironmental policy and law in the U.S.\nEmphasis on both historical development\nand current issues in this field. Recommended\npreparation: SOE 312.\n441 Population Ecology and Conservation 4\n(3-3) Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 372 or SOE\n300 with a C or better in either; SOE 435 with\na C or better; STAT 212 with a C or better and\nconcurrent enrollment in STAT 412, or STAT\n412 with a C or better. Ecology, conservation,\nmanagement of vertebrate populations,\nespecially threatened and endangered species;\ndesigned for wildlife and conservation biology\nmajors.\n444 Environmental Assessment 3 National\nand state policy frameworks for environmental\nassessment that support integration of science\nand the public into agency decision-making\nprocess. Credit not granted for both SOE 444\nand SOE 544. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n445 Hazardous Waste Management 3\nEnvironmental, technical, and political aspects\nof hazardous waste management; evaluative\nmethods, risk assessment, and current\nmanagement requirements. Credit not granted\nfor both SOE 445 and SOE 545. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n446 [M] Wildlife Habitat Ecology 3 (2-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: SOIL SCI 368 or concurrent\nenrollment; STAT 212 or 412; senior standing.\nThe ecology of how wildlife use, respond to,\nand affect resources in their environment.\n450 [M] Conservation Biology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Patterns of\nbiological diversity, factors producing changes\nin diversity, values of diversity, management\nprinciples applied to small populations,\nprotected areas, landscape linkages, biotic\nintegrity, restoration, legal issues and funding\nsources.\n454 [CAPS] [M] Restoration Ecology 3 (2-\n3) Course Prerequisite: Senior standing.\nEcological principles used to restore biological\ncommunities; ecological processes and species\non degraded landscapes.\n460 Biotechnology and the Environment 3\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106, 107, or 120;\n3 credit hours CHEM. Benefits, regulations,\nand human and environmental impacts\nof biotechnology used for crop protection,\nagricultural and energy production, and\nenvironmental remediation and management.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ENTOM 460, SOE\n460).\n461 Watershed Management 3 Principles\nand practices of management of forest and\nrangelands for protection, maintenance, and\nimprovement of water resource values. Field\ntrip required. Recommended preparation: SOE\n204 or sufficient background in spreadsheets.\n463 Water in the Environment 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 140 or 171, or 4 credits\nPHYSICS 101 or 201, or PHYSICS 101 and\n111, or PHYSICS 201 and 211, or PHYSICS\n205. Water flows in the natural environment,\ni n c l u d i n g c l o u d f o r m a t i o n , r a i n f a l l ,\nevaporation, infiltration, groundwater, river\nflows, lakes, estuaries, mixing, and erosion.\n464 [M] Landscape Ecology 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Linkages between\nspatial patterns and processes in a variety of\nlandscapes and the qualitative tools used in\nthe investigation of these linkages.\n465 Aquatic Microbial Ecology 2 Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 372. Biological,\necological and environmental impact of\nmicrobes in aquatic systems.\n\n216\nEnvironment\nWashington State University, 2021\n470 Introduction to Economic Geology 3\n(2-3) Course Prerequisite: SOE 340; SOE 350.\nGenesis, evolution and tectonic setting of ore\ndeposits combining theory, description, and\ndetailed hand specimen analysis. Field trip to\nmajor mining districts. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n471 [ C A P S ] I n t e r n a t i o n a l W i l d l i f e\nConservation 3 Course Prerequisite: Junior\nstanding. A broad survey of international\nwildlife conservation that touches on\nbiological, social, and political aspects of\nwildlife management; focus on understanding\nthe unique challenges that are encountered in\nthe international arena.\n474 [CAPS] [M] Physics and Chemistry of\nthe Earth 4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite: CHEM\n101 or 105; CHEM 102 or 106; 4 credits of\nPHYSICS 101 or 201, or PHYSICS 101 and 111,\nor PHYSICS 201 and 211; SOE 101, 102, or 210;\njunior standing. Earth’s operations as described\nby sub-disciplines of geology, chemistry,\nphysics, and mathematics; earth’s composition\nas related to solar system formation.\n475 Groundwater 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nCE 317 or SOE 315; MATH 140 or concurrent\nenrollment, or MATH 172 or 182 or concurrent\nenrollment. Introduction to groundwater\noccurrence, movement, quality, and resource\nmanagement, emphasizing physical and\nbiogeochemical principles. Field trip required.\n(Crosslisted course offered as SOE 475, CE\n475). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n476 Biology and Ecology of Pacific Salmon\n3 Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106 or 107;\nCHEM 101 or 105. The life histories, habitat\nrequirements, and current issues facing Pacific\nsalmon. Credit not granted for both SOE 476\nand SOE 576.\n477 [ C A P S ] E n v i r o n m e n t a l D i s p u t e\nResolution and Conflict Management\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing.\nExploration of the consequences of complex\nsocial, economic, and environmental\ndynamics that lead to disputes and conflicts\nover environmental and natural resources;\ndevelop toolbox of skills and approaches that\nmay be used to facilitate collaborative solutions\nand resolution of disputes.\n480 How to Build a Habitable Planet 3 An\nintroduction to the origin and evolution of\nEarth including the effects of water, CO2,\nand humans on the planet; exploration of\nradioactive decay, geochronology, radiogenic\nand stable isotope geochemistry, and chemical\nproxies in dynamic systems.\n483 Sustainability: Applied Improvement or\nPromotion Projects 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMinimum 3 credits of [PSCI] or [BSCI]; senior\nstanding. An applied multidisciplinary\nintroduction to sustainability; classroom\nlearning followed with an applied sustainability\nimprovement or promotion project for\nWashington State University.\n484 Forest Management and Planning 3\nKnowledge, skills, and experience in drafting\na management plan and managing forested\nproperties for a variety of values, ranging\nfrom generation of diverse forest products\nto maintenance of important environmental\nvalues associated with forest lands.\n485 Disturbance Ecology 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: SOE 204; SOE 301; SOE 302 or\nconcurrent enrollment. Fire, disease, and other\ndisturbances are primary drivers of structure\nand composition in terrestrial ecosystems;\nstudy of management of insect outbreaks and\nfungal organisms in combination with fire and\nother disturbances.\n486 Applied Remote Sensing: From Drones\nto Satellites 3 Course Prerequisite: SOIL SCI\n368 or concurrent enrollment, or SOIL SCI 374\nor concurrent enrollment. Remote sensing to\nmeasure changes in forests, plants, wildlife,\nwildfire, crops, and geologic features; analyzing\nand applying data from satellites, drones,\nairplanes, and lidar to measures on the ground.\n491 Senior Seminar 1 Course Prerequisite:\nSenior standing. Recommended preparation:\nAdmission to a major in science, mathematics,\nor engineering.\n492 Special Topics V 1-3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 12 hours.\nSpecialized topics within the discipline;\ncontent will vary each term. Open to all\nSOE majors. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n495 Undergraduate Internship V 1-12 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: By interview\nonly. Practical experience in appropriate\nagencies; for career students in earth science,\nenvironment and ecosystem science, forestry,\nand wildlife. S, F grading.\n498 Seminar 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 3 hours. Research papers\npresented by students, faculty, and visiting\nscientists on geological research. Credit not\ngranted for both SOE 498 and SOE 598. S, F\ngrading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n501 Graduate Skills Seminar 1 Seminar\ndesigned to introduce first year graduate\nstudents to the science graduate program;\nroles and responsibilities of graduate students,\nteaching assistants and researchers. S, F\ngrading.\n505 Geodynamics 4 (3-3) Overview of topics\nin geodynamics including conductive and\nconvective heat transfer, mantle convection,\nplate flexure, faulting, and plate tectonics.\nRecommended preparation: Calculus and\nintroductory physics.\n510 Species Distribution Modeling 3 Theory\nand application of species distribution models,\nincluding niche, occupancy, and spatial\ncapture-recapture models; manipulation of\nspatial data and software packages (ArcGIS, R,\nMaxEnt, PRESENCE). Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n512 [M] Global Biogeochemistry 3 Cycles of\nbiogeochemically important elements and\nanthropogenic changes to those cycles in\nterrestrial and aquatic environments on a\nglobal scale. Field trip required. Credit not\ngranted for both SOE 412 and SOE 512.\n516 Soil Processes in the Earth’s Critical Zone\n3 Soil geochemistry and processes; theory and\napplications with a focus on reactions at the\nsolid, liquid, and gaseous interface between\nthe lithosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere,\nand biosphere. (Crosslisted course offered as\nSOE 416/516, SOIL SCI 416/516). Credit not\ngranted for both SOE/SOIL SCI 416 and SOE/\nSOIL SCI 516. Recommended preparation:\nBasic knowledge of soils (e.g. SOIL SCI 201 or\nequivalent; CHEM 106; PHYSICS 102).\n520 Radiation Instr umentation 3 (2-\n3) Methods for analysis of radiation and\nradiative materials, including use of radiation\nmonitoring equipment and analysis of\ninstrument data.\n521 Uses and Regulation of Radiation 3 Uses\nand regulation of radiation and radioactive\nmaterials in medicine, industry, power\nproduction, and scientific research.\n524 Advanced Topics in Sedimentology 3\n(2-3) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Modern aspects of\nsedimentary rocks. Field trip required.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n526 E c o l o g y o f t h e C o l u m b i a R i v e r\n3 I n t e r d i s c i p l i n a r y a p p r o a c h t o t h e\ninterconnections between the physical,\ngeological, chemical, biological, and social\ndimensions of this large, iconic aquatic\necosystem. Recommended preparation:\nBIOLOGY 372.\n531 Fundamentals of Environmental\nToxicology 3 Fundamentals of toxicology;\nenvironmental fate and biological effects of\nchemical pollutants in air, water, and food.\n532 Applied Environmental Toxicology 3\nOverview of and current issues in the field of\nenvironmental toxicology.\n535 Integrated Water Resources Science\nand Management 3 Introduction to the\nphysical, social, and cultural drivers that\nshape how water is managed within the larger\nenvironmental and human landscape.\n536 Climate Change Impacts on Physical,\nNatural, and Human Systems 3 Methods\nfor studying human-caused climate variability\nand change; discussion of impacts on the\nphysical environment and natural and human\nsystems.\n540 Agroecology 3 Social and ecological aspects\nof agriculture and human food systems.\n\n217\nFine Arts\nWashington State University, 2021\n541 Orogenic Systems 3 (2-3) Detailed analysis\nof the construction of mountain belts. Field\ntrip required. Recommended preparation: B.S.\nin Geology or related field. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n542 Extensional Tectonics 3 Case study of\nWestern US Basin and Range Province to\nexplore processes and dynamics of extensional\ntectonics. Field trip required. Recommended\npreparation: B.S. in Geology or a related\nfield. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n544 Environmental Assessment 3 National\nand state policy frameworks for environmental\nassessment that support integration of science\nand the public into agency decision-making\nprocess. Credit not granted for both SOE 444\nand SOE 544. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n545 Hazardous Waste Management 3\nEnvironmental, technical, and political aspects\nof hazardous waste management; evaluative\nmethods, risk assessment, and current\nmanagement requirements. Credit not granted\nfor both SOE 445 and SOE 545. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n548 Applied Spatial Ecology 3 Foundational\nresearch principles in spatial ecology applied to\nnew data; production of methods and results\nsections suitable for publication, using R and\nGIS programming. Recommended preparation:\nIntroductory-level experience with R and\nArcGIS.\n555 S y s t e m D y n a m i c s M o d e l s o f\nEnvironmental Systems 3 Analysis of\nenvironmental system dynamics; development\nand uses of simulation models using the Stella\nsoftware on Macintosh. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n556 Foraging Ecology of Herbivores 2\nSynthesis of foraging behavior concepts\nincluding nutritive quality of forages, digestive\nand metabolic constraints, and diet and habitat\nselection. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n560 Advanced Igneous Petrology 3 (2-3)\nOrigin, evolution, and tectonic significance of\nigneous rocks. Field trip required. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n562 Watershed Biogeochemistry 3 Sources,\ntransformations, fates and impacts of\nbiogeochemically important compounds as\nthey move downstream through watersheds\nto the coastal zone.\n576 Biology and Ecology of Pacific Salmon\n3 The life histories, habitat requirements, and\ncurrent issues facing Pacific salmon. Credit not\ngranted for both SOE 476 and SOE 576.\n577 Advanced Environmental Hydrology 2\nWater (ground, soil, surface, plant, atmosphere)\ndynamics and support of ecosystem functions\nand organization in natural, disturbed, and\nhuman/impacted systems. Recommended\npreparation: college-level physics, multivariate\ncalculus, and introduction to hydrology.\n583 Radiogenic Isotopes and Geochronology\n3 Radiogenic isotopes and their uses as\nchronometers (radiometric dating) and as\ntracers of earth evolution and differentiation.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking students.\n584 Stable Isotope Geochemistry 3 Principles\nand applications of isotope geochemistry in\nthe geological sciences. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n592 Advanced Topics in Environmental and\nNatural Resource Sciences V 1-4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Course Prerequisite: By instructor\npermission.\n593 Graduate Seminar in Ear th and\nEnvironmental Sciences 1 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 8 hours.\n594 Environmental and Natural Resources\nIssues and Ethics 3 Ethical systems applied\nto natural resources; issues of professionalism\nand ethics in natural resource management.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking students.\n597 Advanced Topics in Geology V 1-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Topics of current interest in geology.\n598 Seminar 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 3 hours. Research papers\npresented by students, faculty, and visiting\nscientists on geological research. Credit not\ngranted for both SOE 498 and SOE 598. S, F\ngrading.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee chair\nbefore enrolling for 702 credit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\na School of the Environment PhD program.\nIndependent research and advanced study for\nstudents working on their doctoral research,\ndissertation and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n800 credit. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Fine Arts\nfinearts.wsu.edu\nFA Center 5072\n509-335-8686\nDepartment Chair and Associate Professor, S. Meisel;\nProfessors, T. Brown, K. Haas; Associate Professors,\nA. Bawa (Vancouver), P. Christenson (Tri-Cities),\nD. DeHart, H. Higgs (Vancouver), M. Holloman, M.\nKinkel, I. Palmer, R. Safavi; Assistant Professor, J.\nHedges; Career Track Faculty, H. Meredith, D. Janssen;\nInstructors, D. Doty, A. Rocha.\nThe Fine Arts Department provides a range of\nexperiences in the visual arts. The department offers\ndiverse courses of study leading to the degrees of\nBachelor of Arts in Fine Arts (within this degree,\nthere are three options at the undergraduate\nlevel: an Art Studio option, and an Art History\noption as BA-FA degrees, and a Bachelor of Fine\nArts BFA in studio). At the graduate level there is\nthe terminal degree of Master of Fine Arts (MFA).\nThe Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Fine Arts\nprograms are designed to open doors into the world\nof visual expression and intellectual development.\nIn particular, we encourage students to sample a\nvariety of art disciplines and make an informed\nchoice about their direction in art. The department\nincludes seven areas of emphasis within which to\ndevelop a program: drawing, painting, sculpture,\nprintmaking, ceramics, photography, digital media\nand interdisciplinary studies. These are supported\nby a strong art history component.\nStudents with a BA in Fine Arts - Art Studio\nOption or the BFA in Fine Arts, should have a\nbroad understanding of the visual arts with an\nunderstanding of arts-related concepts/terms\n(including subject matter, form, and content) and\nbasic studio production, a grounding in art history,\nand an awareness of contemporary trends in art and\ntheory. They should be able to articulate in visual\nform a range of approaches, from a representational\npoint of view through a more conceptual focus,\nmake critical judgments about contemporary art\nand culture, and have an acceptable command of\nverbal and written expression.\nStudents with a BA in Fine Arts - Art History\nOption are given broad exposure to the history\nof the visual arts. As an interdisciplinary field, art\nhistory is an intellectual arena in which students\ndevelop their perceptual skills and analytical tools to\nengage diverse art forms from multiple perspectives.\nStudents begin with foundation survey courses,\nthe History of World Art (FA 201 and FA 202), and\nthen take upper-division courses to consider art\nfrom specific cultures and historical time periods.\nIn these courses, students gain familiarity with\ncontextual issues concerning the production and\nconsumption of art. They develop research and\nwriting skills necessary to think critically about art\nand visual culture. Students are also introduced to\nbasic aspects of studio production to enhance their\nvisual skills and knowledge of material practices.\nStudents complete their studies by writing a thesis\npaper and developing knowledge of one foreign\nlanguage.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nStudents with a BFA should have a working\nknowledge of the processes and media that produce\n\n218\nFine Arts\nWashington State University, 2021\nworks of visual art, including a clear understanding\nof the terms: subject matter, form, and content,\nas well as specialized technical, conceptual and\nimaginative expertise in a given field. They should\nbe able to articulate in visual form a range of\napproaches, from a representational point of view\nthrough a more conceptual focus, make critical\njudgments about contemporary art and culture,\nand have an acceptable command of verbal and\nwritten expression.\nAdmission Process\nProspective applicants for admission to the\nmajor are responsible for acquainting themselves\nwith all requirements and procedures. Details\nincluding specific course requirements and portfolio\nsubmission are available in the departmental office\nor at finearts.wsu.edu.\nTransfer Credits\nThe Department of Fine Arts will accept up to 18\ncredit hours in art toward the major and 9 credit\nhours in art toward the minor.\nExchange Program\nThe Department of Fine Arts has a tuition-free\nexchange for four students with the School of\nFine Arts at Nihon University, Tokyo, Japan. All art\nmajors at WSU are eligible for this one-year study\nin Japan. Selection is made in the winter. Other\nopportunities for undergraduate study abroad in\nEurope, Australia, and the Far East are available from\nthe Office of International Programs.\nGraduate Study\nThe MFA program at Washington State University\nis a three-year interdisciplinary program where\nstudents may focus in, but are not limited to,\nceramics, drawing, digital media, painting,\nphotography, printmaking, and sculpture.\nEmphasis is placed on personal and conceptual\nartistic development in light of contemporary art\npractices. Graduates meet with faculty for one-on-\none studio discussions. The program culminates\nin a thesis exhibition held in the Jordan Schnitzer\nMuseum of Art WSU. A final oral examination and\na thesis document are also required. The degree\nrequires 57 graded credit hours and 5 credit hours\nof thesis work (FINE ART 700) totaling 62 credits.\nThe MFA Handbook is viewable at finearts.wsu.edu.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBACHELOR OF ARTS IN FINE ARTS - ART\nHISTORY OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Bachelor courses.\nFor the Bachelor of Arts in Fine Arts a total of\nat least 48 credits of FINE ART with a minimum\ncumulative GPA of 2.0 is required; 30 of these credits\nmust be in 300-400-level courses.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nFINE ART 102 3\nFINE ART 201 [ARTS] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nFINE ART [M]\n2 \n3\nFINE ART 493 4\nElectives 3\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nFINE ART [M]: Repeatable [M] course cannot be\nused to fulfill both of the two required [M] courses.\nMinors\nArt\nA minor in art requires 18 hours including FINE\nART 102 or FINE ART 103; FINE ART 110; and one\ncourse from FINE ART 201 or 202. The remaining\n9 hours of electives must be in 300-400-level FINE\nART courses taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses.\nArt History\nA minor in art history requires 18 hours including\nFINE ART 201 and 202. The remaining 12 hours\nof electives must be in 300-400-level art history\ncourses. 9 hours of upper-division work must\nbe taken in residence at WSU or through WSU-\napproved education abroad or educational exchange\ncourses.\nExhibition Studies\nExhibition Studies is an interdisciplinary minor\ndesigned to facilitate successful career options of\nmuseum, gallery, collections management and /\nor cultural institution professions. The minor\nrequires 18 credits of coursework including 9 credits\nof 300-400 level coursework taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. A grade of C or\nhigher must be earned in all courses used to fulfill\nminor requirements. Required courses include 2\ncore courses (6 credits) selected from FINE ART 103,\n201, 490 (3 credits with the Museum of Art/WSU,\ndepartmental approval required), and HISTORY\n427. An additional 2 courses (6 credits) must be\nselected from ANTH 201, 430; I D 205, and SOC 373.\nThe remaining 6 credits of electives must selected\nfrom the following approved courses: AMDT 308;\nAMER ST/DTC/ENGLISH 475; ANTH 201, 350, 430;\nARCH 456; COM 101, 105, 471; DTC/ENGLISH 336;\nFINE ART 102, 103, 201, 301, 303, 304, 307, 333,\n381, 385, 405, 434, 435; FOR LANG 350; HISTORY\n400, 427; ID 205, 305, 312; LND ARCH 327; MGMT\n401; SDC 250, 350; SOC 373, 430; SOIL SCI 201,\n202; TCH LRN 480. ANTH 498; FINE ART 490, 495;\nHISTORY 498, and SOIL SCI 498 and other courses\nmay be used towards the elective coursework\nrequirement if approved by the Department of\nFine Arts.\nCertificates\nBusiness of Art\nThe Business of Art Certificate is open to all majors.\nThis program harnesses the skills and mindset of\nthe entrepreneur to empower students interested\nin implementation of applied, innovative arts\nprojects and prepares students to access careers that\nrequire skills in both business and art. To complete\nthe certificate students must complete 15 credits\nconsisting of two core courses and three additional\nelectives with a minimum GPA of 2.0. Required core\ncourses include one from FINE ART 102, 103, or 110;\nand ENTRP 490. Three additional electives should\nbe drawn from ENTRP 426; ENTRP 489 or FIN 223;\nFINE ART 332, 340, or 350; and FINE ART 363.\nDescription of Courses\nFINE ARTS\nFINE ART\n101 [ARTS] Introduction to Art 3 Course\nPrerequisite: For non-majors only. For non-\nmajors. Appreciation of various visual art\nforms; emphasis on contemporary period.\n102 [ARTS] 2D Art and Design 3 (0-6)\nIntroduction to two-dimensional art and\ndesign through an interdisciplinary approach\nusing a combination of manual methods,\ndigital imaging technologies, and machine\ntools.\n103 [ARTS] 3D Art and Design 3 (0-6)\nIntroduction to three-dimensional art and\ndesign through an interdisciplinary approach\nusing a combination of manual methods, digital\nimaging technologies, and machine tools.\n110 [ARTS] Drawing 3 (0-6) Composition in\npictorial space, visualization of ideas, drawing\nfrom life.\n111 Figure Drawing 3 (0-6) Course Prerequisite:\nFINE ART 102 or 110. Introduction to drawing\nthe human figure.\n201 [ARTS] World Art History I 3 Art and\narchitecture of Western and Non-Western\ncultures from approximately 3000 BCE to 1300\nCE.\n202 [ARTS] World Art History II 3 Art and\narchitecture of Western and Non-Western\ncultures from 1300 to 2010.\n301 Arts of Native North America 3 Diversity\nof visual forms, traditional and contemporary,\nwithin changing historical and cultural\ncontexts.\n302 [M] Arts of Asia 3 Art and architecture of\nIndia, China and Japan within their historical,\nreligious and cultural contexts. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as FINE ART 302, ASIA 302).\n303 [ARTS] Modern Art-19th Century 3\nHistory of 19th century art in Europe and the\nUnited States.\n304 Modern Art-20th Century 3 Modern art in\nthe 20th century.\n305 [ARTS] [M] Arts of Ancient Greece and\nRome 3 The arts of ancient Greece, Etruria,\nand Rome from the Greek Dark Ages to the\nearly Christian era.\n\n220\nFine Arts\nWashington State University, 2021\n307 [ARTS] [M] The Arts of Renaissance\nEurope 3 Course Prerequisite: FINE ART 202\nor concurrent enrollment. The arts of southern\nand northern Europe from 1300 to 1550.\n308 [M] Women Artists I 3 Women artists of\nthe Middle Ages through the 18th century.\n(Crosslisted course offered as FINE ART 308,\nWOMEN ST 308).\n310 [M] Women Artists II 3 Women artists of\nthe 19th to 20th century. (Crosslisted course\noffered as FINE ART 310, WOMEN ST 310).\n312 Advanced Drawing 3 (0-6) May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: FINE ART 110.\nAdvanced projects using drawing media and\nprocess.\n313 Drawing from the Body 3 (0-6) May be\nrepeated for credit. Course Prerequisite: FINE\nART 111. Continuation of FINE ART 111.\nContemporary discourse surrounding the\nbody; exploration through the practice of\ndrawing and performative actions.\n320 Beginning Painting 3 (0-6) Course\nPrerequisite: FINE ART 110. Introduction\nto problems in painting; development of\ncomposition and color.\n321 Intermediate Painting 3 (0-6) May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n9 hours. Course Prerequisite: FINE ART 320.\nProblems and ideas in painting.\n331 Art, Science, and Technology 3 Survey of\nart’s relationship to science and technology\nfrom Renaissance to present day; emphasis on\nhistorical overview and cultural implications.\n332 Introduction to Digital Media - Print\nand Web 3 (0-6) Course Prerequisite: FINE ART\n102 or concurrent enrollment, or FINE ART\n103 or concurrent enrollment, or FINE ART\n110 or concurrent enrollment. Introduction\nto principles and processes of digital media\nthrough print and web based projects;\nemphasis on theoretical investigations,\nconceptual development\n333 Introduction to Digital Media - Video\nand Sound 3 (0-6) Course Prerequisite: FINE\nART 102 or concurrent enrollment, or FINE\nART 103 or concurrent enrollment, or FINE\nART 110 or concurrent enrollment. Principles\nand processes of digital media through\nvideo and sound-based projects; theoretical\ninvestigations and conceptual development.\n337 Experimental Animation 3 (2-2) Digital\nand analog animation techniques; conceptual\ndevelopment of narrative structures. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as ENGLISH 337, FINE ART 337).\n340 [ARTS] Ceramics 3 (0-6) Course Prerequisite:\nFINE ART 103 or 110. Course Prerequisite: FINE ART 340.\n350 [ARTS] Sculpture 3 (0-6) Course Prerequisite:\nFINE ART 103 or 110. May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum 9\nhours.\n361 Special Topics - Drawing V 1-6 May be\nrepeated for credit.\n362 Special Topics - Painting V 1-6 May be\nrepeated for credit.\n363 Special Topics - Digital Media V 1-6 May\nbe repeated for credit.\n364 Special Topics - Ceramics V 1-6 May be\nrepeated for credit.\n365 Special Topics - Sculpture V 1-6 May be\nrepeated for credit.\n366 Special Topics - Printmaking V 1-6\n367 Special Topics - Photography V 1-6 May\nbe repeated for credit.\n370 Introduction to Printmaking 3 (0-\n6) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 9 hours. Contemporary\ntheories of art and how those theories are\ndeveloped.\n408 [CAPS] Art History Thesis 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nmajor in Fine Arts, with an Art History option;\njunior standing. Thesis directed by student’s\ndepartment; original research paper regarding\nvisual culture using art historical research skills.\n423 Advanced Painting V 3 (0-6) to 6 (0-12)\nMay be repeated for credit. cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n512 Graduate Drawing 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n520 Graduate Painting 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n521 Graduate Painting 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n522 Graduate Painting 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n530 Graduate Digital Media 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n531 Graduate Digital Media 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n532 Graduate Digital Media 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n540 Graduate Ceramics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n541 Graduate Ceramics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n542 Graduate Ceramics 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n550 Graduate Sculpture 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n551 Graduate Sculpture 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n552 Graduate Sculpture 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n555 Critical Practices 9 (4-10) May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 36 hours.\nStudio practice, critical analysis of the student’s\nown and others’ work, investigation of critical\ntheory and visual culture through display\nand making art via a variety of disciplines.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n570 Graduate Printmaking 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n571 Graduate Printmaking 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n572 Graduate Printmaking 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\n580 Graduate Photography 3 May be repeated\nfor credit;
