S, U grading.\nSchool of Food Science\nsfs.wsu.edu\nFood Science & Human Nutrition Bldg, 106\n509-335-4763\nfood.science@wsu.edu\nInterim Director and Associate Professor, G. Ganjyal;\nProfessors, C. Edwards, T. Henick-Kling, C. Ross, M.\nZhu; Associate Professors, F. Critzer, J. Harbertson;\nAssistant Professor, M. Michael; Instructors, T.\nBernhard, B. Ewing, F. Younce; UI Affiliates: Professors,\nC. Bohach, S. Minnich, G. Moller, D. Ryu; Associate\nProfessors, B. Smith, G. Unlu; Assistant Professor, C.\nCantley.\nThe School of Food Science (SFS) works closely\nwith the University of Idaho (UI) to offer courses\nof study in the undergraduate major field of food\nscience. Some traveling to the UI campus will\noccur usually starting the junior year. Students\ncomplete a prescribed course of study leading to the\nBachelor of Science in Food Science with an option\nin general science emphasizing areas in processing\nand engineering, food sensory, food safety,\nhospitality and business management, business,\nscience, enology, or an option in fermentation\nscience. Graduate degrees are also offered leading\nto Master of Science in Food Science and a Doctor\nof Philosophy in Food Science.\nFood Science\nFood Science is the scientific discipline that\nsupports the food and beverage manufacturing\nindustry. Food Science is a multidisciplinary science\nthat applies biology, chemistry, engineering,\nmicrobiology, nutrition, physics, and other sciences\nto improve the safety and quality of food products;\ncreate healthy food products; and design new, safer,\nand more sustainable food preservation methods.\nFood scientists strive to improve the quality and\nnutrition of foods through traditional and emerging\npreservation technologies. Food scientists conduct\nresearch to mitigate chemical and microbial risk\nfactors in foods and to understand the causes of\nfood deterioration and spoilage. Food scientists are\nemployed around the world by large and small food\nprocessing companies, food ingredient suppliers,\nfood quality assurance and testing labs, federal and\nstate governmental agencies, and academia. Food\nscientists also work with existing and emerging\ncompanies preparing organic, natural, kosher, and\nhalal food products.\nGraduates of the food science program are\nwell positioned to meet the evolving challenges,\nneeds, and opportunities of the food industry not\nonly in the Pacific Northwest, but also nationally\nand internationally. Graduates begin careers in\nfood quality assurance, food safety microbiology,\ntechnical sales, production management, product\nextension or development, regulatory affairs, or\nresearch in the food/allied industries or federal/\nstate regulatory agencies.\nFood Science students learn to convert food\ncommodities into high quality, safe and nutritious\nfood products. As part of the BS degree, students\nreceive training and learn skills relative to the\nproduction, processing, preservation, safety,\nevaluation, and distribution of foods. The food\nprocessing industry is continually challenged to\nevaluate existing foods for quality, as well as the\ndevelopment of new foods to better meet consumer\ndemands and the nutritional needs of the world.\nStudents who work at the WSU Creamery can gain\npractical processing and leadership skills in the\nstate-of-the-art creamery where world-renowned\nCougar Gold Cheese is made.\nIn the first two years of college, students enroll\nin science courses and complete most University\nCommon Requirements (UCORE). In the junior\nand senior years, the curriculum emphasizes\ncourses in food processing and engineering, food\nchemistry, food analysis, food microbiology,\nsensory evaluation, and other specialized areas such\nas the processing and manufacture of cereal and\ndairy products, and fermented foods. A student may\nbe admitted to the Food Science or Fermentation\nScience option upon making their intention known\nto the department. Contact the Food Science\nAdvisor to begin the process, food.science@wsu.edu.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nOur graduating seniors will:\n• Demonstrate a level of comprehension of Food\nScience concepts and analyses equivalent to or\ngreater than that required by the Institute of Food\nTechnologists Core Competencies Guidelines.\n• Critically evaluate and summarize a food science\nissue or problem.\n• Apply critical thinking and problem-solving skills\nto address current challenges in the food industry.\n• Communicate effectively in both written and\noral format with an audience possessing varying\ndegrees of food science knowledge.\nSee http://sfs.wsu.edu/blog/2013/08/05/student-\nlearning-outcomes-bs-food-science/.\n\n222\nFood Science\nWashington State University, 2021\nOptions in Food Science\nThe General Option emphasizes open electives\nso students can take specific classes in their area\nof interest or choose a minor to complement their\ndegree. This option prepares students to work in the\nfood industry and related industries, government\nagencies, and governmental organizations. This\ndegree is IFT accredited and provides a strong science\nbackground leading to graduate or professional\ndegrees in various fields.\nThe Fermentation Science Option is for students\ninterested in yeasts, bacteria and molds, the\nscience behind fermented beverages and foods,\nand industrial-scale applications of fermentation\ntechnologies. This option prepares students to\nwork in the food, supplement, and pharmaceutical\nsectors, as well as ciders and wineries.\nOther Opportunities\nStudents with specific interests can gain\nadditional education by taking elective courses,\nparticipating in internships with food companies,\nand/or conducting a research project with a faculty\nmember. Summer internships are available to gain\npractical hands-on training. Contact your advisor\nfor more information. Graduate programs are\nalso available that lead to the degrees of Master of\nScience and Doctor of Philosophy in Food Science.\nTransfer Students\nStudents planning to transfer to the School of\nFood Science should coordinate their programs of\nstudy with advisors to select courses applicable to\nthe degree requirements. Many of the University\nCommon Requirements (UCORE) courses and\nintroductory biology, chemistry, microbiology, and\nphysics courses can be completed at community\ncolleges. We especially recommend students take\nthe appropriate science and mathematics courses\nrequired in our first two years of study, so students\nare on track when transferring to WSU.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nStudents who identify an interest in graduate work\nare encouraged to contact the advisor no later than\nthe end of the junior year, so a course of study can be\nplanned which schedules appropriate prerequisites\nto graduate courses and an introduction to research\nprojects. Students from other science majors\nwho wish to obtain an advanced degree in food\nscience are encouraged to apply as they may be\nwell prepared for graduate studies. Students are\nrequired to take certain core courses required of food\nscience undergraduates in addition to those needed\nfor their graduate program. For more complete\ninformation on our graduate program, admission\nrequirements, and program requirements, review\nthe School of Food Science website at http://sfs.wsu.\nedu/graduate-program/. Please see faculty profiles\nat http://sfs.wsu.edu/personnel/faculty-extension-\nspecialists/ for research opportunities.\nAdmission to the graduate program is based on\nability to complete graduate-level work as evidenced\nby undergraduate transcripts; the compatibility of\nthe student’s objectives with faculty expertise and\nprogram objectives; and availability of graduate\nfaculty to act as major advisor for the applicant.\nThe School of Food Science requires GRE and\nTOEFL scores, in addition to admission materials\nrequired by the WSU Graduate School.\nThe School of Food Science welcomes inquiries\nabout our program. Potential students can contact\nthe School via phone (509-335-4763), email (food.\nscience@wsu.edu), FSHN Bldg Rm 106, or visit the\nSchool of Food Science website (http://sfs.wsu.edu).\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nFERMENTATION SCIENCE OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Fermentation\nScience option upon making their intention know\nto the department.\nThe fermentation science option under the B. S\nin Food Science degree is for the student interested\nin yeasts, bacteria and molds, the science behind\nfermented beverages and foods, and industrial-\nscale applications of fermentation technologies.\nThis option prepares students to work in the food,\nsupplement, and pharmaceutical sectors, as well as\nciders and wineries.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] or 105 [WRTG] 3\nVIT ENOL 113 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 106 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or MATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 345 4\nCOM 102 [COMM] or H D 205 [COMM] 3 or 4\nPHYSICS 101 3\nPHYSICS 111 1\nSTAT 212 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 370 or MBIOS 303 3 or 4\nFS 220 3\nFS 304 3\nMBIOS 101, or MBIOS 304 and 305 4 or 6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFS / PL P 301 3\nFS 302 [M] 1\nFS 303 3\nMicrobiology/Genetics Elective\n1 \n3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nOption Elective\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nFS 418 1\nFS 422 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nLaboratory Elective \n3 \n2\nOption Elective\n2 \n3\nThird Term Hours\nSummer Session: FS 495 or 496 2\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFS 429 3\nFS 460\n4 \n3\nFS 465 3\nLaboratory Elective\n3 \n2\nMKTG 360 3\nElectives\n5 \n2\nSecond Term Hours\nFS 402 3\nFS 405 3\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS]\n6 \n3\nElectives\n5 \n6\n_______\n1 \nMicrobiology/Genetics Elective (3 hours\nminimum): BIOLOGY/MBIOS 301, FS 416, MBIOS\n450.\n2 \nOption Electives (6 hours minimum): BIO ENG\n350, FS 329, 432 and 433, 470, HBM 350.\n3 \nLaboratory Electives (4 hours minimum): FS 417,\n423, 430, 461[M], 466.\n4 \nHORT/VIT ENOL 435 can be substituted per\nadvisor approval.\n5 \nElectives may need to include [M] course to\nmeet the University requirement of two Writing\nin the Major [M] courses. ENGLISH 402 [M] is\nrecommended to fulfill this requirement. Students\nare encouraged to take these credits within the FS\nprefix for career preparation.\n6 \nFS 489 [CAPS] is recommended, but requires FS 416\nand 460 as prerequisites.\nGENERAL OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Food Science –\nGeneral Option major upon making their intention\nknown to the department.\nThe general option under the food science\nmajor is for the student interested in the science\nof food processing, quality, safety and product\ndevelopment. Students gain practical training in\nthe application of chemistry and microbiology to\nthe processing of foods.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nFS 110 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 107 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 106 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] or 105 [WRTG] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 345 4\nCOM 102 [COMM] or H D 205 [COMM] 3 or 4\n\n223\nFood Science\nWashington State University, 2021\nPHYSICS 101 3\nPHYSICS 111 1\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nEmphasis Electives\n1 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 140 or 333 3\nCHEM 370 OR MBIOS 303 3 or 4\nFS 220 3\nMBIOS 101, or MBIOS 304 and 305 4 or 6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFS 302 [M] 1\nFS 303 3\nFS 416 3\nFS 417 2\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSTAT 212 4\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nFS 418 1\nFS 422 3\nFS 423 1\nFS 432 3\nFS 433 1\nEmphasis Electives\n1 \n4\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFS 460 3\nFS 461 [M] 1\nEmphasis Electives\n1 \n3\nFood Science Electives\n2 \n8\nSecond Term Hours\nFS 462 3\nFS 470 3\nFS 489 [CAPS] 3\nEmphasis Electives\n1 \n2\nFood Science Electives\n2 \n4\n_______\n1 \nEmphasis Electives (12 credits required): Approved\ncourses include ACCTG 230; AFS 101, 201, 401;\nCROP SCI/HORT 102; ECONS 101, 201, 351;\nENGLISH 402 [M] or 403 [M]; ENTOM 101, 150;\nHBM 258; HORT 435; MGMT 301; MKTG 360;\nSOIL SCI 101; or VIT ENOL 113; or as approved\nby advisor.\n2 \nFood Science Electives (minimum 12 credits, but\nadditional FS courses count towards Emphasis\nelectives): Approved courses include FS 201,\n301, 304, 329, 401, 402, 405, 406, 407, 409, 429,\n430, 436, 464, 465, 466, 475, 495, 496, 499, or as\napproved by advisor.\nDescription of Courses\nFOOD SCIENCE\nFS\n110 Introduction to Food Science 3 Chemistry,\nmicrobiology, and processing of food and\nfood products; concepts of food preservation,\npackaging and marketing of foods; world food\nissues. Field trip may be required. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n201 [BSCI] Science on Your Plate 3 Applications\nof science, scientific literacy, and critical\nthinking as related to the development and\nmanufacture of modern food products and\ntheir use in modern civilizations. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n220 Food Safety and Quality 3 Regulation,\nsafety, and wholesomeness of food products;\nmicrobiological, chemical, and physical\nrisks associated with food; hazard analysis as\nrelated to food safety, processing and quality;\nsanitation and pest management principles;\nmethods for analyzing the sensory qualities\nof food products; problem management\nassociated with food quality assurance.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n301 Food Mycology 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nMBIOS 101 or concurrent enrollment, or\nMBIOS 304 and 305, either with concurrent\nenrollment. Survey of the fungi important\nin food production, storage, and spoilage.\n(Crosslisted course offered as FS 301, PL P\n301). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n302 [M] Food Processing Lab 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Concurrent enrollment with FS\n303. Application of specialized techniques,\nconcepts and practices of food processing.\nField trip required. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n303 Food Processing 3 Course Prerequisite: FS\n110; FS 220; concurrent enrollment in FS 302;\nMATH 140 or 171; STAT 212 or concurrent\nenrollment. Specialized techniques, concepts\nand practices of food processing. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n304 Cereal Chemistry and Processing 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CHEM 345. Cereal and legume\nstructure, chemistry, and function as it relates\nto processing and utilization. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n329 Dairy Foods Composition and Quality 4\n(3-3) Course Prerequisite: FS 110; CHEM 345.\nIntroduction to the dairy processing industry.\nChemistry of milk components. Standards of\nidentity of dairy products. Quality control\ntests of fluid milk. Microbiology of fluid\nmilk. Organoleptic properties of fluid milk.\nChemical changes during storage. Federal,\nstate, and international regulations applied\nto dairy foods. Cleaning and sanitation in\ndairy manufacturing plants. Dairy effluents\nand waste management. Two 1-day field trips\nrequired. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n350 Instrumental and Sensory Analysis\nof Food 5 (3-6) Course Prerequisite: CHEM\n345; FS 110 or 201; FS 302 and 303; STAT\n212. Evaluation of the chemical and physical\nproperties of foods including both sensory and\ninstrumental analysis. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n401 Topics in Food Science V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Selected topics in food science.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n402 Industrial Fermentations 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MBIOS 101 or 305; MBIOS\n303. Science and technology associated\nwith industrial-scale food fermentations.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n405 Ciders and Other Fermented Foods 3 (2-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106 and 107, or\nMBIOS 101, or MBIOS 304 and 305. Chemistry,\nmicrobiology, and technology associated\nwith the production of cider, beer, and other\nfood fermentations. Two half-day field trips\nrequired. (Crosslisted course offered as FS 405,\nANIM SCI 405). Recommended preparation: FS\n304 and 465. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n406 Evaluation of Dairy Products 2 Identifying\nattributes of different dairy products caused\nby production, processing, and storage\nissues; determining probable cause of those\nattributes and how to reduce their occurrence.\nRecommended preparation: FS 329; FS 429; FS\n430. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n407 Evaluation of Dairy Products Lab 1 (0-\n3) Course Prerequisite: FS 406 or concurrent\nenrollment. Identifying defects in dairy\nproducts and intense training for Collegiate\nDairy Products Evaluation Competition.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents. S, F grading.\n409 Principles of Environmental Toxicology\n3 Nature, properties, effects, and detection of\ntoxic substances in the environment and in\nenvironmentally exposed species, including\nhumans. Credit not granted for both FS\n409 and 509. Recommended preparation:\nBIOLOGY 102 or 107; CHEM 102; CHEM 105;\nCHEM 106; STAT 212. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n416 Food Microbiology 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMBIOS 101, or MBIOS 304 and 305. Purpose\nfor enumeration, detection and identification\nof microorganisms in food products;\nphysical, chemical and environmental factors\ninfluencing growth and survival of foodborne\nmicroorganisms; pathogenic and spoilage\nmicroorganisms in food and their control.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n417 Food Microbiology Laboratory 2 (0-6)\nCourse Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment\nin FS 416. Methods for enumeration, detection,\nand identification of spoilage and pathogenic\nmicroorganisms in foods. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n418 Oral Seminar in Food Science 1 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n2 hours. Course Prerequisite: FS 110 or 220;\nadmitted to the major in Food Science;\njunior standing. Development of skills and\ncommunication tools and techniques for oral\npresentations of current food science research.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n\n224\nFood Science\nWashington State University, 2021\n423 Sensory Evaluation of Food and Wine\nLab 1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: FS 422 or\nconcurrent enrollment. Practical application\nof FS 422 including theory, principles and\napplication of sensory evaluation techniques\nfor appearance, aroma, flavor and texture of\nfoods and wine. Recommended preparation:\nAge 21 or older. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n429 Dairy Processing 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMBIOS 303 or CHEM 370; 4 credits of\nPHYSICS 101, or PHYSICS 101 and 111. Basic\ndairy chemistry, microbiology, and processing\nfrom cow to consumer; dairy quality, safety,\nand sanitation; milk components, fluid milk,\nconcentrated milk, cream, butter, ice cream,\nfermented milk, cheese, and dairy powders.\nCredit not granted for both FS 429 and FS 529.\nRecommended preparation: FS 110 or VIT\nENOL 113. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n430 Dairy Processing Lab 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: FS 429 or concurrent enrollment.\nHands-on training in processing of various\ndairy products (e.g., fluid milk, butter, ice\ncream, cheese, and yogurt); milk pick-up and\nraw milk quality; cleaning and sanitation of\ndairy plants. Credit not granted for both FS 430\nand FS 530. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n432 Food Engineering 3 Course Prerequisite: FS\n303; 4 credits of PHYSICS 101, or PHYSICS 101\nand 111. Food engineering for improving the\nefficiency of food processing operations and\nquality processed food; heat transfer, stream,\nair-vapor mixtures, refrigeration and fluid\nflow. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n433 Food Engineering Lab 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: FS 432 or concurrent enrollment.\nTo enhance the learning experience of the\nstudents taking FS 432 through laboratories,\nproblem sessions and group discussions.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n436 Principles of Sustainability 3 Course\nP r e r e q u i s i t e : J u n i o r s t a n d i n g . I s s u e s\nand processes in sustainability; resource\nm a n a g e m e n t , w a s t e g e n e r a t i o n a n d\nmanagement; industrial approaches to\nsustainability; case studies. Credit not granted\nfor both FS 436 and 536. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n460 Food Chemistry 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCHEM 345; MBIOS 303. Fundamentals of food\nchemistry; composition of foods and the changes\nthat occur during processing. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n461 [M] Food Chemistry Laboratory 1 (0-\n3) Course Prerequisite: FS 460 or concurrent\nenrollment. Experiments related to the\nproperties, reactions and interactions of\nchemical components of foods. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n462 Food Analysis 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nCHEM 345; FS 302; FS 303; senior standing.\nIntroductory food analysis; methods common\nto many food commodities. Recommended\npreparation: FS 460; FS 461. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n464 Food Toxicology 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMBIOS 303. General principles of toxicological\nevaluation of chemicals which enter the food\nchain; toxicology of food additives, colors,\npreservatives, drugs, pesticides and natural toxins\nin foods and risk characterization. Credit not\ngranted for both FS 464 and FS 564. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n465 Wine Microbiology and Processing 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MBIOS 303; MBIOS 101\nor 305. Technical principles related to the\nprocessing and fermentation of wines with an\nemphasis on microbiology. (Crosslisted course\noffered as FS 465, VIT ENOL 465). Credit not\ngranted for both FS/VIT ENOL 465 and FS\n565. Recommended preparation for graduate\nstudents: MBIOS 303; MBIOS 304; MBIOS 101\nor 305. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n466 Wine Microbiology and Processing\nLaboratory 1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: FS\n465 or concurrent enrollment; MBIOS 101 or\n304. Hands-on winemaking; application of\nchemical microbiological methods for wine\nanalysis. Field trip required. (Crosslisted course\noffered as FS 466, VIT ENOL 466). Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n470 Advanced Food Technology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: FS 302; FS 303. Physical principles\nof food preservation and recent advances in\nfood technology. Credit not granted for both\nFS 470 and FS 570. Recommended preparation:\nFS 416; FS 432; FS 460. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n475 Quality Management Tools for Food\nProducts 3 Course Prerequisite: FS 302 or\nconcurrent enrollment; FS 303 or concurrent\nenrollment; STAT 212 or concurrent\nenrollment. Fundamental concepts for\nquality management and improvement of\nbio manufactured goods, and application of\nprinciples of statistical process control in a\nvariety of situations and systems. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n489 [CAPS] Food Product Development 3\n(1-6) Course Prerequisite: FS 302; FS 303; FS\n416; FS 460; senior standing. Course serves\nas a capstone experience for food science\nseniors, and will require the application of food\nchemistry, food processing/engineering, and\nmicrobiology course knowledge in formulating\na new food product. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n495 Internship in Food Science 2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n4 hours. Course Prerequisite: Sophomore\nstanding. Students work full time in industrial\nassignments with prior approval of advisor and\nindustrial supervisor. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students. S, F grading.\n496 Internship in a Winery 2 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 4 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: Sophomore standing.\nIndustrial assignments at a regional, national\nor international winery. (Crosslisted course\noffered as FS 496, VIT ENOL 496). Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students. S, F\ngrading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students. S, F grading.\n501 Topics in Food Science V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Selected topics in food science.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n509 Principles of Environmental Toxicology\n3 Nature, properties, effects, and detection of\ntoxic substances in the environment and in\nenvironmentally exposed species, including\nhumans. Credit not granted for both FS\n409 and 509. Recommended preparation:\nBIOLOGY 102 or 107; CHEM 102; CHEM 105;\nCHEM 106; STAT 212. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n510 Functional Foods and Health 3 Benefits\nof foods beyond basic nutrition; bioactive\ncompounds in functional foods and\nnutraceuticals relating to disease prevention and\nhealth promotion. Recommended preparation:\nBIOLOGY 101; BIOLOGY 102, or BIOLOGY\n106; BIOLOGY 107; MBIOS 303. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n511 Food Lipids 3 Occurrence, structure, chemical\nand physical properties; functions of lipids in\nfoods. Recommended preparation: FS 460;\nMBIOS 303. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n512 Food Proteins and Enzymes 2 Chemistry/\nbiochemistry of proteins/enzymes applied\nto food research and industry; protein\nfunctionality/enzyme technology application\nto food industry. Recommended preparation:\nFS 460; MBIOS 303. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n513 F o o d C a r b o h y d r a t e s 3 S t r u c t u r e\nfunction relationships of polysaccharides\nwithin food systems as a function of their\nrespective molecular structures and physical\ncharacteristics. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n515 Food Fermentations -- Microbiology and\nTechnology 3 Fundamental understanding\nof food fermentation science and technology\nknowledge and principles; application of\nscientific knowledge to assess and solve\nfood fermentation science and technology\nproblems. Recommended preparation: MBIOS\n101 or 305; MBIOS 303. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n516 Food Laws 2 Become familiar with\ngovernment statutes and regulations that\ncontribute to a safe, nutritious, and wholesome\nfood supply. Understand more about the\nlaw and the US legal system relevant to the\nregulation of the manufacture and sale of food\nand supplements, including jurisdictional\nissues, administrative law, and tort, contract,\ncorporate, environmental, labor, and criminal\nlaw issues. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n\n225\nGeneral Studies - Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n517 Scientific Writing 2 May be repeated for\ncredit. Fundamentals of good technical writing\nand presentation; preparing and writing thesis/\ndissertation, scientific publications, and\nresearch grants; bibliography organization and\nciting, statistical data analysis, and preparation\nof graphics, tables, and posters; reviewing and\nevaluating current research. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n518 Oral Seminar 1 May be repeated for credit.\nDevelopment of skills and communication\ntools and techniques for oral presentations\nof current food science research. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n529 Dairy Processing 3 Basic dairy chemistry,\nmicrobiology, and processing from cow\nto consumer; dairy quality, safety, and\nsanitation; milk components, fluid milk,\nconcentrated milk, cream, butter, ice cream,\nfermented milk, cheese, and dairy powders.\nCredit not granted for both FS 429 and FS 529.\nRecommended preparation: FS 110 or VIT\nENOL 113. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n530 Dairy Processing Lab 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in FS 529.\nHands-on training in processing of various\ndairy products (e.g., fluid milk, butter, ice\ncream, cheese, and yogurt); milk pick-up and\nraw milk quality; cleaning and sanitation of\ndairy plants. Credit not granted for both FS 430\nand FS 530. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n531 Advanced Food Safety and Quality 3\nAnalysis of the safety, regulation, protection,\nand quality of processed food products\nand their manufacturing environment.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n532 Advanced Food Microbiology 3 Current\ntopics in food-borne pathogens, including\nnovel detection method, virulence and\npathogenesis, and their interaction with\nenvironment and host. Recommended\npreparation: BIOLOGY 107, MBIOS 305, or FS\n416. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n536 Principles of Sustainability 3 Issues\nand processes in sustainability; resource\nm a n a g e m e n t , w a s t e g e n e r a t i o n a n d\nmanagement; industrial approaches to\nsustainability; case studies. Credit not granted\nfor both FS 436 and 536. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n538 P h y s i c a l P r o p e r t i e s o f F o o d 2\nThermophysical behavior of foods and\nbiopolymers, including water transport/\nactivity, rheological, thermal, dielectric,\nand barrier properties; Newtonian and non-\nNewtonian flow; Viscous, viscoelastic, and\nHookean behavior; relationship between\nrheology of food biopolymers and structure,\ncomposition, temperature, and plasticizer\ncontent. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n564 Food Toxicology 3 General principles\nof toxicological evaluation of chemicals\nwhich enter the food chain; toxicology of\nfood additives, colors, preservatives, drugs,\npesticides and natural toxins in foods and risk\ncharacterization. Credit not granted for both\nFS 464 and FS 564. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n565 Wine Microbiology and Processing 3\nTechnical principles related to the processing\nand fermentation of wines with an emphasis\non microbiology. (Crosslisted course offered\nas FS 465, VIT ENOL 465). Credit not\ngranted for both FS/VIT ENOL 465 and FS\n565. Recommended preparation for graduate\nstudents: MBIOS 303; MBIOS 304; MBIOS 101\nor 305. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n570 Advanced Food Technology 3 Physical\nprinciples of food preservation and recent\nadvances in food technology. Credit\nnot granted for both FS 470 and FS 570.\nRecommended preparation: FS 416; FS 432;\nFS 460. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n583 Advances in Cereal Chemistry and\nTechnology 3 Chemistry and functionality\nof cereal grains as related to their processing,\nproduct development, and nutrition.\nRecommended preparation: CHEM 345, FS\n460, or MBIOS 303. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nGeneral Studies — Liberal\nArts\nCAS Advising Center, Daggy 201\n509-335-8731\nInformation about Bachelor of Arts in Humanities\nor Social Sciences may be found under the School\nof Languages, Cultures, and Race.\nGeneral Studies — Sciences\nThompson 309\n509-335-4581\nAssociate Director, S. Ritchie\nGeneral Studies - Sciences is for students who\nhave varied interests that may cut across the usual\ndepartmental boundaries and who wish to play a\nrole in deciding on a suitable curriculum of study.\nGeneral Studies- Sciences seeks to prepare students\nfor a wide variety of opportunities after graduation\nranging from professional and graduate school\nto entry into business and industry. Graduates of\nGeneral Studies- Sciences are expected to: 1) have\na thorough understanding and knowledge of their\nmajor area of study; 2) understand and critically\nanalyze research and journals from their field of\nstudy; 3) communicate clearly about their field\nto a wide variety of audiences, and 4) understand\nthat they will need to engage in lifelong learning\nto stay current in their field. The degree offered is\nthe Bachelor of Science. The degree is not identified\nwith a specific subject-matter field on the diploma.\nStudents work with specific academic advisors in\nthe College of Arts and Sciences to plan individual\nprograms of study leading towards the Bachelor of\nScience degree. If you are interested in pursuing\nGeneral Studies - Sciences, you must meet with\nthe appropriate advisor as soon as possible. There\nare three options under General Studies - Sciences:\nGeneral Studies - Biological Sciences, General\nStudies - Mathematics, and General Studies -\nPhysical Sciences. Program planning and advising\nare provided by the School of Biological Sciences,\nthe Department of Mathematics and Statistics,\nand the Department of Physics and Astronomy,\nrespectively. For more information on specific\nadvisors and how to contact them, go to https://\ncas.wsu.edu/undergraduate-studies/advising/meet-\nour-advisors/\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n• Ability to understand and communicate\neffectively about scientific or mathematical\nconcepts.\n• Ability to think critically and adapt concepts to\nanalyze and solve problems\n• Ability to apply scientific or mathematical skills\nin formulating logical hypotheses to explain natural\nphenomena.\n• Ability to design tests of hypotheses through\nexperiments, observational studies, mathematical\nmodels, or statistical tests.\n• Ability to identify central body of knowledge in a\nscientific discipline or mathematical specialty.\n• Ability to use scientific or mathematical\nknowledge to analyze contemporary social,\ncultural, and environmental issues and contribute\nto informed opinion.\nPlans of Study\nStudents may follow Plan A or Plan B for each of\nthe General Studies options below, except for the\nMathematical Science option which offers only the\nPlan A option. All options require 120 credit hours\nfor the degree. In addition, students will satisfy\nthe University Core Requirements and College\nof Arts and Sciences graduation requirements.\nStudents must complete two [M] courses and at\n\n226\nGeneral Studies - Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nleast 40 of the 120 hours for the degree must be at\nthe 300-400-level. Honors students must complete\nthe Honors College requirements which replace\nthe UCORE requirements but must satisfy the\nCollege of Arts and Sciences additional graduation\nrequirements.\nStudents who complete a General Studies Science\ncurriculum receive a Bachelor of Science degree. The\ntranscript (not the diploma) will identify the option\nand areas of concentration.\nPlan A—Primary/Secondary\nConcentration:\nPrimary concentration: a minimum of 24\nsemester credits, including at least 15 upper division\n(300-400-level) credits, must be completed in\nbiological sciences, in mathematics, or in a single\nphysical science with a minimum 2.00 primary\nconcentration GPA.\nSecondary concentration: a minimum of 15\nsemester credits, including at least 6 upper division\n(300-400-level) credits, must be completed in an\narea specified by the option or in another academic\nprogram with a minimum 2.00 GPA.\nPlan B—Three Related Areas in Biological\nSciences or Physical Sciences:\nA combination of biological sciences or physical\nsciences courses of at least 39 credits in three or\nmore related academic areas; 9 credits in each\nacademic area are required and 21 upper division\n(300-400-level) credits must be completed with\nat least a 2.0 GPA. The related areas in general\nbiological sciences include biology, biochemistry,\nbotany, genetics and cell biology, microbiology,\nzoology, and approved biology-based courses in\nagriculture. The related areas in general physical\nsciences are broadly defined and include astronomy,\nchemistry, geology, mathematics, physics, and\napproved courses in computer sciences and\nengineering.\nOptions\nGeneral Studies - Biological Sciences is an\noption for students who want a curriculum of\nstudy that cuts across disciplines but has biology\nat the core of integrative studies. This degree\nhas two plans of study (Plan A or Plan B). Both\nrequire prerequisites of one year biology, one\nsemester introductory calculus, one year general\nchemistry, and one semester organic chemistry.\nThe academic areas from which courses may be\ndrawn include biology, biochemistry, botany,\ngenetics and cell biology, microbiology, zoology,\nand approved biology-based courses in agriculture.\nHowever, students may not use General Studies\nBiological Sciences as part of a double major with\neither biology or zoology. Students will work with\ntheir academic advisor in the School of Biological\nSciences to plan individual courses of study for this\noption of the Bachelor of Science degree.\nGeneral Studies - Mathematical Sciences is an\noption for students who want a curriculum of study\nthat cuts across disciplines but has Mathematics\nat the core of integrative studies. Plan A is the\nonly option offered for this degree. It requires\nprerequisites of three semesters of calculus and\nlinear algebra. Students will work with the academic\nadvisor in the Department of Mathematics and\nStatistics to plan individual courses of study for this\noption of the Bachelor of Science degree.\nGeneral Studies - Physical Sciences is an\noption for students who want a curriculum of\nstudy that cuts across disciplines but has Physics\nor another Physical Science such as Chemistry\nat the core of integrative studies. This degree has\ntwo plans of study (Plan A or Plan B). Both require\nprerequisites of one year calculus, one year calculus-\nbased physics, and one year general chemistry.\nStudents must satisfy all prerequisite work for\n300-400 level courses. Students will work with the\nacademic advisor in the Department of Physics and\nAstronomy to plan individual courses of study for\nthis option of the Bachelor of Science degree.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nGENERAL STUDIES - BIOLOGICAL/\nMATHEMATICAL/PHYSICAL SCIENCES\nPLAN A AND PLAN B (120 HOURS)\nThe Biological/Mathematical/Physical Sciences\nplan within General Studies is for students who are\ninterested in interdisciplinary programs in science\nor mathematics which offer broader options in\ncourse selections than are possible within single\ndepartments. Students who wish to earn a Bachelor\nof Science degree will devise an approved, coherent\nprogram of study with the coordinator which\nfulfills an academic or career goal and includes\nprerequisites consistent with the 300-400-level\nmajor course work. In addition, each student will\nsatisfy the University Core Requirements and any\nadditional requirements of the College of Arts and\nSciences. Students must complete two [M] courses\nand at least 40 of the 120 hours for the degree must\nbe at the 300-400-level.\nGeneral Studies—Biological Sciences. This\ndegree has two plans of study (Plan A or Plan B).\nBoth require BIOLOGY 106 and 107, CHEM 105,\n106, and 345, and MATH 140 or 171.\nPlan A students complete 24 credits (minimum\n15 credits at the 300-400 level) from the following\nacademic areas: biology, biochemistry, botany,\ngenetics and cell biology, microbiology, zoology,\nand approved biology-based courses in agriculture.\nIn addition, students must complete a 15 credits\n(minimum 6 credits upper division) from a\nconcentration area outside of the biological\nsciences. Both concentration areas require a\nminimum 2.0 GPA.\nPlan B students complete a total of 39 credits\n(minimum 21 credits at the 300-400 level) in three\nor more departments or program areas chosen\nfrom biology, biochemistry, botany, genetics and\ncell biology, microbiology, zoology, and approved\nbiology-based courses in agriculture. Students\nmust complete a minimum of 9 credits in each\ndepartment or program area with a minimum 2.0\nGPA.\nStudents may not use General Studies Biological\nSciences as part of a double major with either biology\nor zoology. Students will work with their academic\nadvisor in the School of Biological Sciences to plan\nindividual courses of study for this option of the\nBachelor of Science degree.\nGeneral Studies- Mathematical Sciences.\nPrimary Concentration: Students are required to\ncomplete minimum of 24 credits (minimum 15\ncredits at the 300-400 level) including MATH 171,\n172, 273, and 220. Other approved coursework\nincludes any MATH course, or STAT 360, 370, 422,\n423, 443, 446, 447, or 456. Secondary concentration:\na minimum of 15 semester credits (including a\nminimum 6 credits at the 300-400-level), must\nbe completed in another academic department,\nprogram or area published in the catalog. Both\nconcentration areas require a minimum 2.0 GPA.\nGeneral Studies- Physical Sciences. This\ndegree has two plans of study (Plan A and Plan B).\nBoth require CHEM 105 and 106, MATH 171 and\n172, and PHYSICS 201 and 202.\nPlan A students must have a primary and secondary\nconcentration. For the primary concentration\nstudents are required to complete minimum of\n24 credits (minimum 15 credits at the 300-400\nlevel) from one of the following areas: applied\ntechnologies (computer science, engineering, or\nother technical disciplines), astronomy, chemistry,\ngeology, mathematics, physics, or statistics. Students\nwill work with the academic advisor for this program\nin the Department of Physics and Astronomy. For\nthe secondary concentration a minimum of 15\nsemester credits (including a minimum 6 at the\n300-400-level), must be completed in another\nacademic department, program or area published\nin the catalog. Both concentration areas require a\nminimum 2.0 GPA.\nPlan B students must complete 39 credits\n(minimum of 21 credits in the 300-400 level) in\nthree or more physical sciences with a minimum of\n9 credits in each concentration area and a minimum\n2.0 GPA in each concentration area.\nPaul G. Allen School of\nGlobal Health\nglobalhealth.wsu.edu\nPaul G. Allen Center for GAH; 245 SE Ott\nRoad\n509-335-2489\nglobalhealth@wsu.edu\nSenior Director, Creighton Chair, and Regents Professor,\nG. Palmer; Director and Professor Dr. T. Kawual;\nAssociate Director and Professor, T. Baszler; Regents\nProfessor, D. R. Call; Professors, T. E. Besser, K. A.\nBrayton, T. Marsh, J. Yoder; Associate Professors, J.\nCelli, L. Knodler, V. Vadyvaloo; Assistant Professors,\nP. Fernandez, B. Gunn, M.A. Islam, M. Letko, E.\nLofgren, A. Omsland; Clinical Assistant Professors, F.\nLankester, S.T. Mwangi, S. Omulo; Research Professor,\nM. K. Njenga; Assistant Research Professor, E. Osoro;\nAffiliate Professors, A. S. Dhillon, S. Kurtz, D. A.\nMoore, W. M. Sischo; Affiliate Associate Professors,\nT. Bankhead, A. Kalyanaraman, R. Quinlan, M.\nMcGuire, M. Memon, S. Roy, D. H. Shah; Affiliate\nAssistant Professors, O. Cornejo, A. Nicola, M. Quinlan;\nAffiliate Research Professor, A. Du; Adjunct Faculty, R.\nBishop, S. Broschat, S. Cleveland, A. Dijkeng, J. Futse,\nM. F. Galletti, R. Iles, G. Kaufman, K. K. Lahmers, Y.\nLin, B. Martin, M. Mousel, E. Mpolya, S. M. Noh, I.\nO. Olatoye, S. Ramabu, G. Shirma, M. Ueti; Regents\nProfessor Emeritus, T. F. McElwain.\nThe Paul G. Allen School for Global Health (Allen\nSchool) provides innovative solutions to global\n\n227\nHistory\nWashington State University, 2021\ninfectious disease challenges through research,\neducation, global outreach, and application of\ndisease control at the animal-human interface. It\nadvances science, people, and policy to discover\nnovel approaches for disease intervention and\ndelivery of preventive health care for animals and\nhumans. Graduate study leading to the Master\nof Science and Doctor of Philosophy degrees is\noffered for individuals with strong backgrounds\nin biological, economic, engineering, physical,\nand social sciences. The objectives of the program\nare to provide the graduate student with a broad\nknowledge of and research experience in global\nanimal health with concentration in their specific\ndisciplines placed in the global context of disease\nprevention and control. The curriculum is research\nintensive emphasizing the identification of\nknowledge gaps that constrain progress in improved\nglobal health, acquisition of contemporary and\ninnovative investigative skills to address these\ngaps, and understanding of policy pathways to\ndirect and enhance implementation of health\nsolutions. Specialization includes animal and\nzoonotic disease epidemiology and pathogenesis,\neconomic burden of disease and effect on food\nsecurity, emerging and endemic disease surveillance\nand diagnosis, infectious diseases epidemiology and\npathogenesis, vaccine discovery and development,\nimplementation strategy and evaluation, and\nanimal health policy and metrics.\nThe program offers flexibility for students with\nbackgrounds in any of the core disciplines to pursue\nadvanced training in global animal health, with\nindependent study and original research in areas\nof the student’s own interests. Students conduct\nresearch on the WSU-Pullman campus, including\nin the state-of-the-art BSL2 and BSL3 laboratories\nin the Allen Center, and in global field sites. The\ninterdisciplinary nature of the program assures the\nstudent of interaction with scientists representing\na wide range of research interests in global health\nand provides the student with a broad range of\nspecialized facilities which are available in the\ncooperating academic units.\nUNIQUE ASPECTS OF THE PROGRAMS\n• Multidisciplinary options. Students working\nwith Allen School faculty can enroll in specific\ndisciplinary programs such as Anthropology,\nEconomics, Immunology/Infectious Diseases, and\nMolecular Biosciences or develop an individualized\nInterdisciplinary Program.\n• Real-world education. Blending rigorous\nacademic training with experiential learning\n• Learning from leaders in the discipline. Providing\nstudents with opportunities to work with top\nscientists, practitioners, and leaders in global animal\nhealth, both on campus and in the field.\nCertificates\nGlobal Animal Health Pathway\nThe Global Animal Health Pathway (GAHP)\nrequires a minimum of 15 course credits to earn a\ncertificate. These credits will be satisfied through\nboth required and elective courses: 5 credits will\nbe satisfied through required coursework, 6 credits\n(minimum) will be satisfied through the required\nGAH Project, and the remaining credits, up to 4, will\nbe satisfied through elective courses or additional\nproject work. Elective credits may be obtained from\ncourses offered by WSU, and on-line courses offered\nthrough the University of Washington Global\nHealth Pathway that are approved for the GAHP.\nRequired courses and approved elective courses are\nlisted below. Students wishing to enroll in the GAHP\nprogram must maintain a minimum satisfactory\nlevel or 3.00 GPA in graded professional coursework\nand remain in the upper 75% of the DVM class.\nREQUIRED COURSES (5 credits): VET MED 501,\n597 (Section 6), 576, 600, and GLANHLTH 503.\nREQUIRED GLOBAL ANIMAL HEALTH PROJECT\n(6 credits minimum): All GAHP students will be\nrequired to complete a global animal health proj-\nect. The student will work with an Allen School\nfaculty mentor to design a project, which may be\ncompleted in conjunction with a project team out-\nside the Allen School. The project must be oriented\ntoward global animal health and be approved by\nthe GAHP Advisory Committee. The student will\nregister for VET MED 600P (Scientific Writing and\nPresentation – required in DVM curriculum, see\nabove under required courses) for project write-up\nand presentation. The student will devote at least\n6 weeks (6 credits) during one summer to complete\nthis requirement and should register for one or\nmore of the following WSU courses to meet the re-\nquired course credit. Coursework: VET MED 504,\n599, 676, or 690.\nELECTIVE COURSES (up to 4 additional cred-\nits): Elective course credits may be earned through\nformal classroom instruction during any semester\nor summer session and/or through the completion\nof an additional summer project. Coursework: VET\nMED 504, 599, 676, 690, SPANISH 362, or SPAN-\nISH 405.\nForeign Language Skills: A foreign language is not\nrequired, but is highly recommended. The foreign\nlanguage proficiency provides students with an in-\ndepth understanding of cultural and contextual\nelements critical to working in the field of global\nanimal health. Further, foreign language proficien-\ncy will increase the graduate’s competitiveness for\nglobal health career opportunities upon graduation.\nDescription of Courses\nGLOBAL ANIMAL HEALTH\nGLANHLTH\n500 Animal Health and Food System Policy\nand US State Government 1 Policy-making\nprocess relating to trade, animal health and\nfood systems at the state and provincial levels.\n501 Animal Health and Food System Policy\nand US National Government 1 Policy-\nmaking process relating to trade, animal health\nand food systems at the national level.\n502 Animal Health and Food System Policy\nand Intergovernmental Organizations 1\nInternational policy-making emphasizing the\nimpact of international standards and policy\nof food safety, animal health, trade and public\nhealth.\n503 Animal Human Disease Interface 1 Use\nof evidence-based tools in addressing global\nanimal health challenges at the human-animal\ninterface.\n504 Multidisciplinary Approaches to Global\nHealth Challenges 1 Multidisciplinary\ncollaboration around an important global\nhealth problem that includes a significant\nanimal health component.\n563 Deconstruction of Research 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Graduate standing in a WSU\nbiomedical based graduate program. Nature\nand development of scientific investigation\nthrough oral and written avenues, and\nmethods of critical analyses applied to\nquestions of biomedical interest. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as NEUROSCI 563, GLANHLTH\n563, MBIOS 563, VET MICR 563, VET PATH\n563, VET PH 563).\n564 Topics in Biomedical Experimentation\nV 1-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Examination of the\nphilosophy of experimental design and\npractical application and analysis of various\nexperimental approaches in biomedical\nresearch. Recommended preparation: graduate\nstanding in a WSU biomedical-based program,\nand an advanced undergraduate or graduate\nstatistics course. (Crosslisted course offered as\nNEUROSCI 564, GLANHLTH 564, MBIOS 564,\nPHIL 564, VET MICR 564, VET PATH 564, VET\nPH 564).\nDepartment of History\nhistory.wsu.edu\nWilson-Short 301\n509-335-5139\nDepartment Chair and Professor, M. Sutton; Professors,\nR. Bauman, P. Boag, W. Brecher, S. Kale, L. Mercier, S.\nPeabody, J. Spohnholz, O. Svingen; Associate Professors,\nB. Farley, L. Gordillo, L. Hatter, L. Heidenreich, N.\nKawamura, R. McCoy, J. Sanders, R. Sun, J. Thigpen,\nX. Wang, A. Wright; Assistant Professor, A. Chastain;\nClinical Faculty, K. Faunce, S. Fountain, T. Hanshew,\nT. Jordan, K. Phoenix, C. Stratton, C. Weller, K.\nWhalen; Instructors, J. Dodson, R. Ellis, R. Franklin, N.\nHarrington, S. Herzog, F. Hill, B. Miller, L. Musgrave,\nE. Smelyansky, L. Turner-Rahman, A. Whelchel; Staff,\nJ. Pike, L. Torkelson.\nOfferings in the field of history may be classified as\nAmerican, Asian, European, and Latin American.\nThe Department of History’s Undergraduate\nDegree Program is designed to produce several\noutcomes. We expect students who complete the\nrequirements for an undergraduate major in History\nto: 1) express sophisticated and abstract concepts\nclearly in writing; 2) be familiar with the nature of\nhistorical argument and methodologies; 3) frame\nresearch topics and do research at an appropriate\nundergraduate level; 4) have a mastery of the broad\noutlines of historical developments, themes, issues,\nand patterns; 5) develop critical thinking skills that\nwill allow and encourage them to become life-long\nlearners.\nA major in history can be used in government\nservice, the new specialty of public history teaching,\nseveral areas of business and industry, and many\nother fields. It can also be used in preparation for\nstudy of the law, the ministry, archival work, and\nlibrarianship. Double majors or complementary\n\n228\nHistory\nWashington State University, 2021\nminors combining history with other fields are\neasily arranged.\nThe department offers courses of study leading to\nthe degrees of Bachelor of Arts in History, Bachelor of\nArts in Social Studies, Master of Arts in History, and\nDoctor of Philosophy. In cooperation with others,\nthe department participates in the interdisciplinary\nProgram in American Studies leading to the degree\nof Doctor of Philosophy.\nUndergraduate Learning Goals\n• Thesis: To clearly state an argument, describe\nthe topic comprehensively, and deliver all relevant\ninformation for full understanding.\n• Source Criticism: To identify and consider\nthe influence of historically-based contexts and\nassumptions.\n• Historiography: To demonstrate awareness of the\ncontested character of history and the historical\nrecord.\n• Analysis of Evidence: To integrate and synthesize\nknowledge from multiple sources through effective\nqualitative and/or quantitative evidence analysis.\n• Research Skills: To demonstrate research retrieval\nskills through the identification and selection of\nappropriate sources.\n• Communication Skills: To communicate\neffectively through formal written work, oral\npresentations, and other media.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nStudents who have had basic undergraduate\ntraining in history (approximately 12 hours)\nand who have had undergraduate majors in\nsuch subjects as American literature, economics,\nanthropology, and political science may be well\nprepared for graduate study in several fields of\nspecialization in history. Adequate opportunities\nare provided for removing deficiencies by taking\nappropriate courses or special examinations.\nUndergraduates who are pursuing their studies\nat other institutions or through other curricula at\nthis institution and who contemplate graduate work\nin this department should select courses similar to\nthose required in the schedule of studies.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nHISTORY - EDUCATION OPTION\n(126 HOURS)\nStudents who wish to earn a teaching credential\nmust apply to the Teacher Preparation Program\nin the College of Education. They should consult\nwith an advisor in history about choosing\nadditional electives that may apply toward a minor\nor second major and that complements a History\nendorsement.\nTo be admitted to the History - Education option,\na student must make their intention known to\nthe department and have earned at least a 2.5\ncumulative GPA.\nA grade of C or better is required in all history\ncourses used to fulfill the requirements for this\ndegree.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 101 [HUM] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nECONS 102 [SSCI] or POL S 101 [SSCI] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 102 [HUM] 3\nHISTORY 121 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] (Non-History)\n2 \n3\nECONS 102 [SSCI] or POL S 101 [SSCI] 3\nENGLISH 201 [WRTG], 301 [WRTG],\n302 [M], or 402 [WRTG]\n3 \n3\nHISTORY 110 3\nHISTORY 308 or 410 3\nSecond Term Hours\n200-level HISTORY course\n4 \n3\nHISTORY 111 3\nHISTORY 120 3\nHISTORY 380 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400-level HISTORY courses\n5 \n6\nHISTORY 300 [M] 3\nTCH LRN 301 3\nForeign Language, if needed\n6 \n0 - 3\nTCH LRN 470 3\nFifth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nTCH LRN 415 16\nComplete History Department’s Exit Survey\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nOnly 3 HISTORY courses may be used to meet\nUCORE requirements.\n3 \nOne from ENGLISH 201, 301, 302, or 402 is\nrequired for admission to the Teacher Education\nProgram. \nHistory education majors must choose their 12\nhours of 300-400-level electives from the following:\none from early U.S.: HISTORY 411, 413, 414, 415, or\n416; one from Modern U.S.: HISTORY 412, 417, 418,\nor 419; one from Europe: HISTORY 340, 341, 342,\n350, 381, 382, 386, 440, 441, 444, 445, 447, 448,\n449, 450, 453, 454, 455, 459, 463, 467, 468, or 489;\nand one from non-West: HISTORY 306, 315, 331,\n335, 337, 370, 373, 374, 387, 388, 425, 430, 432,\n433, 434, 435, 436, 439, 464, 466, 472, 473, 474,\n475, 476, 477, 483, 491, 492, 494, or 495.\n6 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\nHISTORY - GENERAL OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\n36 credits of history are required, including 6 credits\nof US history, 6 credits of European history, and 9\ncredits of Non-Western/Global history; 21 credits\nat the 300-400-level, which must include HISTORY\n300 and 469; and a 12-credit concentration (at least\n6 credits 300-400-level) in the same or in related\ndisciplines with the advisor’s approval.\nTo be admitted to the History – General option,\na student must make their intention known to\nthe department and have earned at least a 2.0\ncumulative GPA.\nIt is assumed that prior to the junior year the\nstudent will have completed courses meeting\nUCORE and College of Arts and Sciences\nrequirements for graduation.\nA grade of C or better is required in all history\ncourses used to fulfill the requirements for this\ndegree.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term 300-400 level and one [M] course - must\ninclude 6 hours US history (HISTORY 110, 111, 150,\n201, 216, 235, 280, 298, 308, 313, 314, 320, 321,\n322, 390, 398, 409, 410, 411, 412, 413 [M], 414,\n415, 416, 417, 418, 419, 421, 422, 423, 486, or 496),\n6 hours European history (HISTORY 101, 102, 340,\n341, 342, 350, 381, 382, 386, 440, 441, 444, 445,\n447, 448, 449, 450 [M], 453, 454, 455, 459, 436,\n439, 466, 472 [M], 473, 474, 475, 476 [M], 477 [M],\n483, 491, 492, or 495).\n3 \nConcentration Courses (12 credits, minimum 6\ncredits at the 300-400-level): Courses in the same\nor related disciplines with the advisor’s approval.\nIn consultation with their advisor, students\nare encouraged to select a concentration area\nthat best meets their career objectives. Internal\nconcentrations and courses include: Africa and\nthe Middle East: HISTORY 272, 273, 274, 306, 396,\n472, 473; American West: HISTORY 308, 319, 320,\n398, 421, 422; Asia: HISTORY 201, 270, 271, 272,\n273, 275, 306, 370, 373, 374, 387, 472, 473, 474,\n475, 476, 477, 479;
