Europe: HISTORY 101, 102, 340, 341,\n342, 350, 355, 386, 435, 436, 440, 441, 444, 445,\n447, 448, 449, 450, 453, 454, 459, 462, 467, 468;\nGender and Sexuality: HISTORY 298, 335, 336, 337,\n350, 398, 399; History of Imperialism/Colonialism:\nHISTORY 341, 388, 413, 414, 435, 436, 439, 454,\n462, 479, 491, 495; Latin America: HISTORY 230,\n231, 232, 331, 335, 430, 432, 433, 434; Popular\nCulture and the Arts: HISTORY 130, 216, 232, 320,\n321, 322, 355, 423, 444, 448, 492; Public History:\nHISTORY 315, 410, 427, 438, 498 (required); Race\nand Ethnicity: HISTORY 150, 235, 280, 298, 308,\n313, 314, 315, 398; Social Movements: HISTORY\n130, 313, 399, 407, 423, 426, 445; Science and\nTechnology: HISTORY 381, 382, 400, 483, 494;\nUnited States: HISTORY 110, 111, 150, 216, 298,\n308, 313, 319, 320, 326, 388, 390, 398, 399, 407,\n409, 410, 411, 412, 413, 414, 415, 416, 417, 418,\n419, 421, 422, 426; War and Peace: HISTORY 386,\n387, 388, 390, 416, 445, 449, 455, 464, 466, 468.\nStudents may not use the 12-credit concentration\nareas to fulfill the 6 hours of US history, 6 hours\nof European history, and 9 hours of Non-Western/\nGlobal history required in the major.\n4 \nElectives should include sufficient 300-400-level\ncourses to meet University requirement of 40 credits\nof upper division coursework.\nHISTORY - PRE-LAW OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\n36 credits in history are required including 6 credits\nof US history, 6 credits of European history, and 9\ncredits of Non-Western/Global history; 12 credits\nof 100-200-level HISTORY; 3 credits of additional\nHISTORY; 21 credits of 300-400-level, which must\ninclude HISTORY 300 and 469. Included in the\nprogram of study below are 30 credits of courses in\ncommunication, social sciences and humanities,\neconomics and business that are valuable\npreparation for study of the law. In addition to\nthese requirements, students are urged to elect,\nin consultation with their advisor, courses that\ncomplement the curriculum’s broad based liberal\narts education.\nTo be admitted to the History Pre-Law option,\na student must make their intention known to\nthe department and have earned at least a 2.5\ncumulative GPA.\nA grade of C or better is required in all History\ncourses used to fulfill the requirements for this\nmajor.\nIt is assumed that prior to the junior year that\nstudents will have completed courses meeting\nUCORE and College of Arts and Sciences\nrequirements for graduation.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nCOM 102 [COMM] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nANTH 101 [DIVR] 3\nArts [ARTS] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nSOC 101 3\nPre-Law Option 3\nElectives 4\nHISTORY Electives\n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nPre-Law Option\n3 \n6\nForeign Language, if needed, or Elective 3 or 4\nHISTORY Electives\n2 \n6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nHISTORY 300 [M] 3\nPre-Law Option\n3 \n6\nForeign Language, if needed, or Elective 3 or 4\nHISTORY Elective\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nPre-Law Option\n3 \n3\nHISTORY Electives\n2 \n6\n300-400-level Electives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400-level Pre-Law Option\n3 \n3\nHISTORY Electives\n2 \n6\n300-400-level Electives 6\nSecond Term Hours\nHISTORY 469 [M] 3\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nHISTORY Elective\n2 \n3\n300-400-level Electives 3\nComplete History Department’s Exit Survey\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nHistory Electives – 30 credits required, minimum\n15 credits at 300-400 level and one [M] course - must\ninclude 6 hours US history (HISTORY 110, 111, 150,\n201, 216, 235, 280, 298, 308, 313, 314, 320, 321,\n322, 390, 398, 409, 410, 411, 412, 413 [M], 414,\n415, 416, 417, 418, 419, 421, 422, 423, 486, or 496),\n6 hours European history (HISTORY 101, 102, 340,\n341, 342, 350, 381, 382, 386, 440, 441, 444, 445,\n447, 448, 449, 450 [M], 453, 454, 455, 459, 462,\n463 [M], 467, or 468), and 9 hours Non-Western/\nGlobal history (HISTORY 230, 231, 270, 271, 272,\n273, 274, 275, 306, 331, 335, 337, 370, 373, 374,\n387, 388, 425, 430 [M], 432, 433, 434, 435, 436,\n439, 466, 472 [M], 473, 474, 475, 476 [M], 477 [M],\n483, 491, 492, or 495).\n3 \nPre-Law requirements (may also fulfill UCORE\nrequirements) – Political Science: POL S 300 and\ntwo courses from POL S 101, 102, or 206; Business/\nAccounting: two courses from ECONS 101, 102,\n198, ACCTG 230, or B LAW 210; Social Sciences/\nHumanities: one course from PHIL 201, 360, 370,\nor 470; English: one course from ENGLISH 201, 301\nor 402 [M].\nSOCIAL STUDIES - EDUCATION OPTION\n(132 HOURS)\nSocial Studies is a major for students who plan to\nearn both a BA and a teaching endorsement in the\nmultidisciplinary fields of history and the social\nsciences: anthropology, economics, geography,\npolitical science, psychology, sociology. Social\nStudies majors who wish to earn a teaching\ncredential must apply to the Teacher Preparation\nProgram in the College of Education. They should\nconsult with an advisor in history about choosing\nadditional electives that may apply toward a minor\n\n230\nHistory\nWashington State University, 2021\nor second major and that complement a Social\nStudies endorsement.\nTo be admitted to Social Studies - Education\nOption, a student must make their intention known\nto the department and have earned at least a 2.5\ncumulative GPA.\nA grade of C or better is required in all history\ncourses used to fulfill the requirements for this\ndegree.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] (Non-History)\n1 \n3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n2 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 101 [HUM] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nANTH 101 [DIVR] or 203 [DIVR] 3\nHISTORY 102 [HUM] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n2 \n4\nSOC 102 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\n200-level HISTORY course\n3 \n3\nECONS 102 3\nHISTORY 110 3\nPOL S 101 [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language, if needed\n4 \n0-4\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 201 [WRTG], 301 [WRTG],\n302 [M], or 402 [WRTG]\n5 \n3\nHISTORY 111 3\nHISTORY 120 3\nHISTORY 308 or 410 3\nForeign Language, if needed\n4 \n0-4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nEuropean History Elective\n6 \n3\nHISTORY 121 3\nHISTORY 300 [M] or SOC 320 3\nTCH LRN 301 3\nSecond Term Hours\nANTH/POL S/PSYCH/SOC Elective\n7 \n3\nGeography Elective\n8 \n3\nHISTORY 380 3\nHISTORY 422 3\nHISTORY 469 [M] 3\nThird Term Hours\nTCH LRN 317 (Summer Session) 2\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS]\n1 \n3\nNon-Western/Global History Elective\n9 \n3\nTCH LRN 464 3\nTCH LRN 465 3\nTCH LRN 466 2\nSecond Term Hours\nAmerican History Elective\n10 \n3\nED PSYCH 468 3\nHISTORY 480 3\nTCH LRN 467 [M] 3\nTCH LRN 469 2 - 3\nTCH LRN 470 3\nFifth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nTCH LRN 415 16\nComplete History Department’s Exit Survey\n_______\n1 \nOnly 3 HISTORY courses may be used to meet\nUCORE requirements.\n2 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n3 \n200-level HISTORY course: Choose one from\nHISTORY 230, 231, 232, 270, 271, 272, 273, 274,\nor 275.\n4 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n5 \nOne from ENGLISH 201, 301, 302, or 402 is\nrequired for admission to the Teacher Education\nProgram. Students who take ENGLISH 302 will need\nto take an additional [WRTG] or [COMM] course.\n6 \nEuropean History Elective (3 credits required):\nApproved courses include HISTORY 340, 341, 342,\n350, 381, 382, 386, 440, 441, 444, 445, 447, 448,\n449, 450 [M], 453, 454, 455, 459, 462, 463 [M], 467,\nand 468.\n7 \nANTH/POL S/PSYCH/SOC Electives (3 credits\nrequired): Approved courses include ANTH 307,\n316, 320, 330, 331, 350, POL S 300, 316, 427, 450,\n455, PSYCH 310, 324, 361, 470, SOC 320, 346, 351,\n384, and 430. Courses may not be used to fulfill\nmore than one major requirement.\n8 \nGeography Elective (3 credits required): Approved\ncourses include ANTH 309, HISTORY 319, 495, and\nTCH LRN 487.\n9 \nNon-Western/Global History Elective (3 credits\nrequired): Approved courses include HISTORY 306,\n331, 335, 337, 370, 373, 374, 387, 388, 425, 430\n[M], 432, 433, 434, 435, 436, 439, 464, 466, 472\n[M], 473, 474, 475, 476 [M], 477 [M], 483, 491, 492,\n494, and 495.\n10 \nAmerican History Elective (3 credits required):\nApproved courses include HISTORY 313, 314, 315,\n319, 320, 321, 322, 390, 398, 409, 410, 411, 412, 413\n[M], 414, 415, 416, 417, 418, 419, 421, 423, and 486.\nMinors\nAsian Studies\nA minor in Asian Studies requires 20 credits,\nincluding a minimum of one semester of college-\nlevel study of a single Asian language or 4 credits\nfrom a study abroad program taken in an Asian\ncountry. Approved language courses include\nARABIC, CHINESE, JAPANESE, or KOREAN 101,\n102, 203, or 204. Of the 20 required credits of\nAsian language courses, or ASIA courses, at least\n9 credits must be 300-400-level coursework taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducational exchange courses. Native speakers of\nan Asian language are exempt from the language\nrequirement for the minor (they instead take 4\nadditional credits of ASIA courses).\nHistory\nA minor in history requires 18 hours, 9 of which\nmust be in 300-400-level courses taken in residence\nat WSU or through WSU-approved education\nabroad or educational exchange courses. A grade\nof C or better is required in all course work for the\nminor.\nModern Asia\nAsia’s population, economic power, cultural\ninfluence, political volatility, environmental\nimpacts, and military threats make it the world’s\nmost dynamic region, and its importance will\ncontinue to grow in the coming generations.\nLearning about it is more critical than ever. The\nminor in Modern Asia is designed to deepen\nstudents’ appreciation of the complexity and\ndiversity of the region encompassing East Asia,\nSouth Asia, and the Middle East. Students who\nfocus on one country or region will also develop\npan-Asian perspectives.\nStudents who have completed 60 credits may be\nadmitted to the minor in Modern Asia. The minor\nrequires a 2.0 GPA and a minimum of 18 credits\ntaken from ASIA 201, 301, 303; HISTORY/ASIA 270,\n271, 272, 273, 275, 373, 374, 387, 472, 473, 474,\n475, 476, 477, 478, 479, 483, 499. These courses\nmust be taken in residence at WSU, through WSU\nGlobal Campus, or through departmental approval\nof education abroad or educational exchange\ncourses.\nWar and Society\nThe minor in War and Society addresses political,\nsocial, economic, and cultural impacts of war. The\nminor requires 18 credits, 9 of which must be taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nA grade of C or better is required in all course work\nfor the minor. Approved courses include: HISTORY\n386, 387, 388, 390, 416, 418, 449, 455, 464, 466,\n468.\nCertificates\nCertificate in East Asian Studies\nfor Business Majors\nThe Certificate in East Asian Studies for College of\nBusiness Majors requires a total of 17 credit hours\nand is open to any declared College of Business\nundergraduate major in good standing.\nThe requirements are: CHINESE 101 and 102,\nJAPANESE 101 and 102, or KOREAN 101 or 102, or 8\ncredits of other East Asia language available through\nstudy abroad; ASIA 479; one from ASIA 120, 121,\n122, 123, 275, 315, 320, 321, 322, 330, 373, 374,\n475, 476, or 477; and one from FIN 481, I BUS 380,\n435,453, 482, or ECONS 327/I BUS 470.\nStudents who complete two semesters of foreign\nlanguage beyond the one-year requirement may\nsubstitute those courses for three credits required\nfrom ASIA 121, 275, 315, 374, 475, or 477. Study\nabroad is encouraged, and appropriate credit toward\ncompletion of certificate will be accepted at the\ndiscretion of the Asia Program Director. No more\nthan 4 credits earned at other institutions that may\napply towards the certificate and no more than 4\ncredits may be pass/fail. Native speakers of an East\n\n231\nHistory\nWashington State University, 2021\nAsian language may waive the foreign language\nrequirement, but must take eight additional credits\nof courses from the list of “cultural survey” courses\nas approved by advisor. For courses used to meet the\ncertificate requirements, a minimum cumulative\nGPA of 2.0 is required for successful completion of\nthe certificate.\nCertificate in East Asian Studies\nfor Engineering and Architecture\nMajors\nThe Certificate in East Asian Studies for College\nof Engineering and Architecture Majors requires\na total of 17 credit hours and is open to any\ndeclared College of Engineering and Architecture\nundergraduate major in good standing.\nThe requirements are: CHINESE 101 and 102,\nJAPANESE 101 and 102, or KOREAN 101 or 102, or 8\ncredits of other East Asia language available through\nstudy abroad; ASIA 479; and 6 credits from ASIA\n120, 121, 122, 123, 275, 315, 320, 321, 322, 330,\n373, 374, 475, 476, or 477. A minimum of 6 credits\nmust be upper-division.\nStudents who complete two semesters of foreign\nlanguage beyond the one-year requirement may\nsubstitute those courses for three credits required\nfrom ASIA 121, 275, 315, 374, 475, or 477. Study\nabroad is encouraged, and appropriate credit toward\ncompletion of certificate will be accepted at the\ndiscretion of the Asia Program Director. No more\nthan 4 credits earned at other institutions that may\napply towards the certificate and no more than 4\ncredits may be pass/fail. Native speakers of an East\nAsian language may waive the foreign language\nrequirement, but must take eight additional credits\nof courses from the list of “cultural survey” courses\nas approved by advisor. For courses used to meet the\ncertificate requirements, a minimum cumulative\nGPA of 2.0 is required for successful completion of\nthe certificate.\nDescription of Courses\nASIA\nASIA\n111 Asian Film 3 Asian film from a cultural\nperspective. Taught in English. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CHINESE 111, ASIA 111,\nJAPANESE 111). Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n120 Traditional Chinese Culture 3 Cultural\ndevelopment of China from early times\nthrough the golden age of Chinese civilization.\nTaught in English. (Crosslisted course offered\nas CHINESE 120, ASIA 120, HUMANITY 120).\n121 [HUM] Modern Chinese Culture 3 An\nintroduction to the culture of modern China,\nincluding Hong Kong and Taiwan. All readings\nin English. (Crosslisted course offered as\nCHINESE 121, ASIA 121). Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n122 Traditional Japanese Culture 3 Traditional\nJapanese society and culture from ancient\nthemes to the 19th century. Taught in English.\n(Crosslisted course offered as JAPANESE 120,\nASIA 122).\n123 [HUM] Modern Japanese Culture 3 Issues,\ntrends, and forms of popular culture that\ndefine modern and contemporary Japanese\nlife. Taught in English. (Crosslisted course\noffered as JAPANESE 123, ASIA 123).\n131 Masterpieces of Asian Literature 3\nIntroduction to Asian literature. Taught in\nEnglish. (Crosslisted course offered as CHINESE\n131, ASIA 131, HUMANITY 131, JAPANESE\n131). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n201 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n220 Global Issues, Regional Realities 3\nIntroduction to the study of interconnections\nof global and local issues and themes;\nuniversalizing and particularizing tendencies\nin contemporary societies. Taught in English.\n(Crosslisted course offered as FOR LANG 220,\nASIA 220).\n270 [DIVR] India: History and Culture 3\nSurvey of South Asian history, societies and\ncultures - development of civilization and\ncontemporary societies of India and South\nAsia. (Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY\n270, ASIA 270).\n271 [DIVR] Southeast Asian History: Vietnam\nto Indonesia 3 Historical introduction to\nSoutheast Asian social, religious, political,\neconomic and cultural institutions including\nVietnam, Thailand, Burma, the Philippines\nand Indonesia. (Crosslisted course offered as\nHISTORY 271, ASIA 271).\n272 [DIVR] Introduction to Middle Eastern\nHistory 3 History of the Middle East from\nMuhammad to the present; political and\nreligious development and the impact\nof empires. (Crosslisted course offered as\nHISTORY 272, ASIA 272).\n273 [ D I V R ] F o u n d a t i o n s o f I s l a m i c\nCivilization 3 Islamic civilization presented\nthrough the main ideas, institutions and\ncultural forms; Golden Age of Islam and\nMuslim contributions to world civilizations.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY 273,\nASIA 273).\n275 [DIVR] Introduction to East Asian\nCulture 3 Survey of East Asia (China, Japan,\nKorea, and others) history from 1766 BCE\nto the present. (Crosslisted course offered as\nHISTORY 275, ASIA 275).\n280 [HUM] Islam in Theory and Practice 3\nFundamental principles of Islam, including the\nrelation between faith and practice, and the\nsocial, economic, political, and judicial systems\nin Islam. (Crosslisted course offered as PHIL\n280, ASIA 280).\n301 [DIVR] East Meets West 1 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 3 hours.\nAnalytical themes to explore historical and\ncontemporary interactions between U.S.\nand Asia in cultural, political, and economic\ndimensions. Taught as a multicultural\nsymposium.\n302 [M] Arts of Asia 3 Art and architecture of\nIndia, China and Japan within their historical,\nreligious and cultural contexts. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as FINE ART 302, ASIA 302).\n303 Topics in Asian Studies V 1-2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 4\nhours. Topics in Asian Studies.\n306 Cultures and Peoples of the Middle East\n3 Contemporary Arab cultures in a historical\nperspective within the framework of Western-\nMiddle Eastern relations. (Crosslisted course\noffered as HISTORY 306, ASIA 306).\n314 [HUM] [M] Philosophies and Religions\nof India 3 Metaphysical, epistemological,\nethical, aesthetic, social, and political views\nof Hinduism, Buddhism, and Islam, and their\ninfluence on Indian civilization. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as PHIL 314, ASIA 314).\n315 [HUM] [M] Philosophies and Religions\nof China and Japan 3 The philosophies\nand religions of China and Japan, and their\nmetaphysical, epistemological, ethical, social,\nand political positions and views of God and\ngods. (Crosslisted course offered as PHIL 315,\nASIA 315).\n320 [DIVR] [M] Issues in East Asian Ethics\n3 Philosophical foundations of ethical\nthought in East Asia; informed responses to\nmodern ethical dilemmas. Taught in English.\n(Crosslisted course offered as JAPANESE 320,\nASIA 320, CHINESE 320, HUMANITY 320).\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n321 [M] Gender and Love in East Asian\nCulture 3 The theme of gender with respect to\nlove, courage, self-sacrifice, and vulnerability\nin traditional Chinese and Japanese literature\nand culture. (Crosslisted course offered as\nCHINESE 321, ASIA 321, JAPANESE 321).\n322 [DIVR] Ecology in East Asian Cultures\n3 Major ecological issues in East Asia through\ncultural representations, and analysis of their\nimplications to the U.S. (Crosslisted course\noffered as ASIA 322, CHINESE 322, HUMANITY\n322, JAPANESE 322).\n330 [M] The Art of War 3 (2-2) The philosophy\nbehind war, military strategy and its\nconsequences and representation in literature\nand film from East Asia. Taught in English.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CHINESE 330,\nASIA 330). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n370 History of Ancient and Medieval India\n3 Historical development to 1500 CE of states,\nreligions, caste society, gender customs and\nsocial ecology in India. (Crosslisted course\noffered as HISTORY 370, ASIA 370).\n373 [HUM] Chinese Civilization 3 Growth of\nChinese civilization from the Bronze Age to the\npresent. (Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY\n373, ASIA 373).\n374 [HUM] Japanese Civilization 3 Overview\nof Japanese history from the Stone Age to the\npresent, including political, social, economic,\nand cultural history. (Crosslisted course offered\nas HISTORY 374, ASIA 374).\n\n232\nHistory\nWashington State University, 2021\n387 World War II in Asia and the Pacific 3\nImperial rivalries in Asia; Japanese militarism;\nmilitary, ideological and social aspects of the\nwar; the atomic bomb; memory of the war.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY 387,\nASIA 387).\n472 [M] The Middle East Since World War\nI 3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing.\nDevelopments in the Middle East since World\nWar I including nationalism, fundamentalism,\nand revolution. (Crosslisted course offered as\nHISTORY 472, ASIA 472). Credit not granted\nfor more than one of HISTORY 472/572 and\nASIA 472.\n473 The Middle East and the West 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. East-west\ntensions in the context of historical relations\nbetween the Middle East and West Europe since\nthe rise of Islam. (Crosslisted course offered as\nHISTORY 473, ASIA 473).\n474 [CAPS] Modern South Asia: Community\nand Conflict 3 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. Historical transformation\nof communities and communal conflicts\nin modern South ASIA from 1500 to\npresent; themes: caste, religion, geography,\nenvironment and economy. (Crosslisted course\noffered as HISTORY 474, ASIA 474).\n475 The People’s Republic of China, 1949\nto Present 3 The major political, social,\neconomic and cultural developments during\nthe People’s Republic of China. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as HISTORY 475, ASIA 475, POL\nS 475).\n476 [M] Revolutionary China, 1800 to\nPresent 3 Continuity and change in the\npolitical, social, cultural and economic\nexperience of China since 1800. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as HISTORY 476, ASIA 476, POL\nS 476).\n477 [DIVR] [M] Modern Japanese History 3\nExamination of political, socioeconomic and\ncultural changes and the international crises\nin modern Japan since the 19th century.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY 477,\nASIA 477). Readings and interpretive\nproblems in Latin American history.\n539 Slavery, Abolition and Emancipation\nin World History 3 History of slavery and\nabolition as a world-wide phenomena; trends\nand debates in historiographical literature.\nCredit not granted for both HISTORY 439 and\nHISTORY 539.\n540 Seminar in History 3 May be repeated for\ncredit.\n547 [ H U M ] E u r o p e i n t h e F r e n c h\nRevolutionary and Napoleonic Era,\n1789 to 1815 3 The history of Europe during\nthe French Revolution and the Napoleonic\nEra (1789-1815). Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. Independent research\nand advanced study for students working on\ntheir doctoral research, dissertation and/or final\nexamination. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nThe Honors College\nhonors.wsu.edu\nElmina White Honors Hall 130\n509-335-4505\nDean and Professor, M. G. Norton; Associate Dean\nand Associate Professor, D. Shier; Assistant Dean and\nProfessor, R. Bond; Professor, K. Andersen; Associate\nProfessors, L. Gerber, A. Lampman, J. Schultz; Adjunct\nAssociate Professors, C. Custer, C. Hanon; Professor\nEmeritus, C. Elstad.\nThe mission of the Honors College is to offer\nstudents of high ability and initiative an enriched,\nfour-year core curriculum that satisfies university\ngraduation requirements and promotes global\ncompetencies. The Honors College helps students\ndevelop genuine intellectual curiosity and a life-\nlong love of learning through a series of courses\nand independent work. Honors students acquire\nthe broad foundations of liberal learning in the\nnatural and social sciences, the arts and humanities,\nand cultures of the world. In addition, the Honors\n\n237\nHonors\nWashington State University, 2021\nCollege requires competency in foreign language\nand encourages education abroad as premier\nvehicles for acquiring key competencies for an\nincreasingly globalized society and economy.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nHonors College undergraduates understand the\nimportance of becoming citizens of the world.\nThey engage in multiple leadership opportunities,\npursue research projects that result in a thesis\nor creative project, and often participate in an\ninternational educational experience. Their Honors\ncurriculum emphasizes skills that help them achieve\nexcellence, both within their major as well as their\nHonors coursework. As stated on our website,\nhttps://honors.wsu.edu/learning-goals-outcomes/\nstudents in the Honors College commit to the\nfollowing learning outcomes as they pursue higher\neducation at WSU: critical and creative thinking,\ncommunication, information literacy, scientific\nliteracy, quantitative and symbolic reasoning,\ncultural competency, and integration of knowledge.\nSpecifically, as a general education program, the\nHonors College expects that its graduates will be\nable to: (1) construct a reasoned and evidence-\nbased position on an issue that takes into account\ntheir own and others’ views; (2) use the library\ncatalog, databases, and the Internet to find relevant\ninformation while critically evaluating the quality\nof those information resources; (3) demonstrate\nrespect for different cultural systems and traditions\nand their contributions to society; (4) choose\nthe appropriate methodology and theoretical\nframework to solve a problem or answer a question\nin their discipline; (5) write and speak effectively\nin different contexts for a variety of audiences;\n(6) learn to apply quantitative tools and draw\nconclusions; and (7) demonstrate competency in\na foreign language.\nCourses offered through the Honors College are\nopen only to students enrolled in the program. For\nadmissions, see the Honors College section of the\ncatalog.\nHonors College Requirements\nA bachelor’s degree earned through the Honors\nCollege requires approximately the same number of\ntotal semester hours as required by the University\nCommon Requirements (UCORE). Students who\ncomplete the Honors College requirements are\nnot required to complete the University Common\nRequirements for graduation. Students who\ntransfer from Honors without completing the\nHonors College requirements will be responsible\nfor fulfilling the UCORE.\nHonors College students are required to complete\nthe courses specified in the schedule of studies.\nThe mathematics requirement for students in the\nHonors College can be met in a number of ways (see\nfootnote 1). In addition, students complete a three-\ncredit Honors Thesis in the junior or senior year.\nA few majors will fulfill this requirement through\ndesign projects in their field. Each student must\nchoose a thesis advisor, complete a significant piece\nof writing, and make a public presentation. Students\nwho present an outstanding thesis may receive a\n“Pass with Distinction” on their final transcript.\nThe Honors Certificate of Global Competencies\nrequires a thesis with an international topic as\nwell as participation in a study abroad experience\nand completion of at least six credits while abroad.\nStudents can also demonstrate competency by\ncompleting a foreign language through the 204\nlevel. The MESI Certificate in Mindfulness-based\nEmotional and Social Intelligence requires a\ncombination of coursework, mindfulness training,\nand co-curricular service learning.\nThe Honors College requires its students to\ndemonstrate competency in a foreign language.\nWith sufficient high school preparation, students\ncan elect to take an online examination upon\nentrance to the Honors College. If additional\npreparation in a foreign language is necessary,\nstudents will work with an Honors advisor to\ndevelop an appropriate course of study.\nFor continued enrollment in the Honors College,\nstudents must maintain a minimum 3.2 cumulative\nGPA. Any graded courses used to fulfill Honors\nCollege graduation requirements must receive a\ngrade of C or better. Successful completion of the\nHonors College requires that students fulfill the\nHonors Curriculum and have a cumulative GPA of\n3.2 or better.\nEach semester, students enrolled in the Honors\nCollege typically take one to two Honors courses\nin addition to their major courses. Honors College\nrequirements and recommended timeline are listed\nbelow:\nFirst Year\n• ENGLISH 298\n• Math requirement\n1\n• Foreign Language competency requirement\n2\n• [BSCI] or [PSCI] with lab\nSecond or Third Year\n• HONORS 270 Principles and Research Methods\nin Social Sciences\n3\n• HONORS 280 Contextual Understanding in the\nArts and Humanities\n• HONORS 290 Science as a Way of Knowing\n4\nThird or Fourth Year\n• HONORS 370 Case Study: Global Issues in Social\nScience or 3 credits ED ABRD 991.\n• HONORS 380 Case Study: Application of Arts\nand Humanities to Global Issues or 3 credits ED\nABRD 992.\n• HONORS 390 Case Study: Application of Science\nto Global Issues or 3 credits ED ABRD 993.\n• HONORS 450 Honors Thesis\n5\nOptional Coursework:\n• HONORS 198 Honors First-Year Experience\n• HONORS 298 Approaches to Global Leadership\n• HONORS 398 Honors Thesis Proposal Seminar\n• HONORS 430 (Education Abroad Research)\n_______\n1 \nStudents typically take the math required by their\nmajor. Honors College accepts: MATH 105, 140,\n171, 172, 202, 251 and 252 combined, and 273,\n283, STAT 205, or STAT 212. Check with an Honors\nCollege advisor for any questions concerning the\nmath requirement.\n2 \nAssessed proficiency in a second language at\nthe intermediate level or completion of a foreign\nlanguage through the 204 level. May be completed\nat any time before graduation. Check with an\nHonors advisor for specifics. Education Abroad is\nstrongly recommended for language acquisition.\nThe following foreign language level courses in any\nlanguage will be accepted as meeting the foreign\nlanguage competency standard set by the Honors\nCollege: 204, 261, 306, 307, and 308.\n3 \nECONS 198 is an approved substitute for this\nrequirement.\n4 \nApproved substitutes for this course include:\nCHEM 116, MATH 182, PHYSICS 205 or 206.\n5 \nThree credits required. HONORS 398 strongly\nrecommended as preparation. Approved substitutes\nfor this course include: BIO ENG 411, CE 465, CHE\n451, CPT S 423, ENGR 421, E E 416, and ME 416.\nCertificates\nHonors Certificate of Global\nCompetencies\nThe Certificate of Global Competencies is an\nelective certificate for Honors students whose\ninternational interests and/or career objectives can\nbe enhanced by an integrated program of language\nstudy, academic coursework, and study abroad.\nStudents receive a notation on their transcript IN\nADDITION to the Honors Certificate of Completion.\nThe Certificate of Global Competencies builds on\nthe courses required for the Honors Certificate of\nCompletion. Students who enter with good foreign\nlanguage preparation usually will not require extra\ntime to complete both certificates. Fifteen graded\ncredits are required for the Certificate of Global\nCompetencies. A grade of C or better must be earned\nin each of the required, elective and transfer courses\nin order to qualify for the certificate. The university\nundergraduate certificate fee will apply. Students\nare strongly encouraged to work with an Honors\nadvisor to plan an appropriate schedule of studies.\nThe certificate entails requirements in four areas: 1.\nForeign language competence: 3-6 graded credits\nat the 204 level or higher. 2. Education abroad: 6-9\ngraded credits from one term abroad or longer in an\napproved program. A “term” may include a summer\nsession with a full academic load. A typical semester\nabroad in an approved program will result in 12-\n15 WSU credits. 3. HONORS 430 and presentation\n(3-6 credits, graded): May be completed through\ncoursework abroad or at WSU. HONORS 430\nincludes an oral presentation scheduled at the\nHonors College during the first semester following\nthe completion of HONORS 430. 4. Honors Thesis\n(HONORS 450, 3 credits, S, F): Your Honors Thesis\nmust incorporate an international perspective\nsignificantly developed in the thesis. See an\nHonors advisor for approval of the international\ncomponent.\nMindfulness-Based Emotional and\nSocial Intelligence\nThe Mindfulness-Based Emotional and Social\nIntelligence (MESI) certificate is open to all students\nof the Honors College and offers a transformative\nprogram combining academic coursework,\ncommunity engagement, and mindfulness practices\nto help prepare students for lives of personal and\nprofessional integrity and engagement. To earn\nthe certificate, students must complete 15 or\nmore credits distributed as follows: (A) 9 credits\nin identified MESI-related sections of HONORS\n198, 270, 280, 290, 298, 370, 380, or 390; (B) 3\n\n238\nHonors\nWashington State University, 2021\ncredits related to community engagement from\nHONORS 211, 212, 499 or – in connection with\nan Honors thesis or capstone project – HONORS\n450; (C) 2 credits of workshops, practica or retreats\noffered in connection with the MESI program,\nincluding HONORS 201, 301 or others approved\nby an Honors advisor; (D) at least 1 additional credit\nfrom any of the above categories. A grade of C or\nbetter must be earned in each of the letter-graded\ncourses applied toward the certificate. Students\nare strongly encouraged to work with an Honors\nCollege advisor to plan an appropriate schedule of\nstudies. See an Honors College advisor for approval\nof each component of the certificate.\nDescription of Courses\nUNIVERSITY HONORS\nBIOLOGY 298 – Honors Biology for Non-Science\nMajors\nCHEM 116 – Chemical Principles Honors II\nECONS 198 – Economics Honors\nENGLISH 298 – Writing and Research Honors\nMATH 182 – Honors Calculus II\nMATH 230 – Honors Introductory Linear Algebra\nMATH 283 – Honors Calculus III\nPHYSICS 205 – Physics Honors I\nPHYSICS 206 – Physics Honors II\n- see Honors College courses below -\nHONORS\n198 Honors First-Year Experience 1 Course\nPrerequisite: Must be an Honors student.\nMaking a successful transition to college\nincluding advising, schedule planning and\nundergraduate research opportunities. S, F grading.\nDepartment of Horticulture\nhorticulture.wsu.edu\nJohnson Hall 149\n509-335-9502\nRegents Professor, B. W. Poovaiah; Professors, L. K.\nChalker-Scott, K. M. Evans, M. Keller, D. S. Main, C.\nA. Miles, S. Musacchi, M. J. Pavek, C. P. Peace, M. D.\nWhiting; Associate Professors, B. R. Bondada, L. W.\nDeVetter, S. P. Ficklin, L. A. Kalcsits, M. M. Moyer;\nAssistant Professors, T. S. Collins, P. M. McCord, C. A.\nTorres; Associate Research Professor and Instructor, M.\nG. Kumar; Assistant Research Professors, Y. Ma, R. M.\nSharpe; Associate Research Professor, S. Jung; Senior\nInstructor, C. Kawula; Adjunct/Affiliate Faculty, C.\nBenedict, C. J. Coyne, A. Dhingra, I. Hanrahan, G. A.\nHoheisel, L. A. Honaas, P. E. Jacoby, J. P. Mattheis, J.\nR. McFerson, R. McGee, D. W. McMoran, R. Navarre,\nD. R. Rudell, M. R. Salazar-Gutiérrez, , R. K. Thornton,\nT. D. Waters, M. J. Willett, C. Wohleb, W. H. Wolfe,\nT. Yang, I. Zasada, Y. Zhang; Professors Emeriti, M.\nAhmedullah, P. K. Andrews, L. R. Askham, D. C.\nElfving, J. K. Fellman, W. G. Hendrix, L. K. Hiller, R.\nHummel, W. M. Iritani, L. Knowles, N. R. Knowles,\nF. E. Larsen, V. Lohr, R. Maleike, P. P. Moore, M. E.\nPatterson, E. Proebsting, J. M. Roberts, L. E. Schrader,\nK. A. Struckmeyer, R. E. Thornton.\nThe Department of Horticulture offers programs of\nstudy leading to the degrees of Bachelor of Science\nin Integrated Plant Sciences, Bachelor of Science in\nAgricultural and Food Systems, Bachelor of Science\nin Viticulture and Enology, Master of Science in\nHorticulture, Master of Science in Agriculture,\nDoctor of Philosophy in Horticulture, and Doctor\nof Philosophy in Molecular Plant Sciences. A minor\nin Horticulture is also available.\nINTEGRATED PLANT SCIENCES AND\nAGRICULTURAL AND FOOD SYSTEMS\nThe science of plant life from molecule to market\nis the focus of the Integrated Plant Sciences (IPS)\nDegree program. Delivered collaboratively by\ndepartments within the College of Agricultural,\nHuman, and Natural Resource Sciences, the IPS\ndegree provides students with an exciting depth\nand breadth of knowledge that crosses a variety\nof plant science disciplines, including crop and\nsoil sciences, horticulture, entomology, plant\npathology, and food science. Students pursuing\na Bachelor of Science degree in Integrated Plant\nSciences may choose among five majors highly\nsought by employers in the state, nationally,\nand internationally: Agricultural Biotechnology;\nField Crop Management; Fruit and Vegetable\nManagement; Landscape, Nursery, and Greenhouse\nManagement; or Turfgrass Management. More\ninformation regarding IPS is available under the\nIntegrated Plant Sciences catalog section and\nat http://ips.wsu.edu.\nThe department is also involved with the College\nof Agricultural, Human and Natural Resource\nSciences interdisciplinary Agricultural and Food\nSystems Degree Program. The Agricultural and Food\nSystems (AFS) program is an exciting, college-wide,\ninterdisciplinary program that offers a Bachelor\nof Science degree with five majors and a Master\nof Science degree. Majors available through AFS\ninclude Agricultural Technology and Production\nManagement, Agricultural Education, Organic\n\n239\nHorticulture\nWashington State University, 2021\nand Sustainable Agriculture, Agricultural and\nFood Business Economics, and Agriculture and\nFood Security. More information regarding AFS is\navailable under the Agricultural and Food Systems\ncatalog section and at http://afs.wsu.edu.\nStudents are encouraged to participate as part-\ntime employees in research programs and seek\nprofessional internships for applied learning\nexperiences. Departmental and college scholarships\nare available based on ability, need, and interest.\nStudents gain professional and social contacts with\nthe faculty and other students through student club\nactivities, including Horticulture Club.\nAgricultural Biotechnology\nThe Agricultural Biotechnology major is designed\nfor students interested in careers such as laboratory\nor research technicians in plant biotechnology,\nbreeding, genetics, entomology, plant pathology,\nmolecular biology, or physiology, as well as for\nstudents preparing for advanced degrees in these\nareas. The program emphasizes the development\nand application of new technology to ensure a\nsafe and abundant food and fiber supply. Students\nmay find employment in industry, government, or\nuniversity labs.\nFruit and Vegetable Management\nThe Fruit and Vegetable Management major offers\nspecialization in the science and practice of growing,\nharvesting, handling, storing, processing, and\nmarketing tree fruits, small fruits, and vegetables.\nGraduates can look forward to careers as growers\nand farm managers, production field advisors,\nsales representatives in the horticultural services\nindustry, managers of produce firms, and brokers\nand marketers of fruit and vegetable products.\nLandscape, Nursery, and Greenhouse\nManagement\nThe Landscape, Nursery, and Greenhouse\nManagement major is a horticulture-based program\nthat prepares students for opportunities in plant\npropagation, the production and marketing of\npotted crops, bedding plants, trees, shrubs, and\ncut flowers, and in landscape plant management.\nThis is an exciting major for students interested\nin owning or managing a nursery or greenhouse,\nattending graduate school in horticulture, working\nfor university extension offices and research\ngreenhouses, maintaining landscapes and parks, or\nworking as wholesale horticultural-product brokers.\nVITICULTURE AND ENOLOGY\nThe BS in Viticulture and Enology is for students\ninterested in wine-grape growing and winemaking,\nas well as contributing to critical research and\ndevelopment opportunities in the wine industry.\nThis program offers the technical, scientific,\nand practical experience needed to gain the\nessential skills for producing high quality grapes\nand premium table wines. It prepares students\nfor successful careers in the wine industry in\nWashington and beyond. A unique feature of this\ndegree is that students have the flexibility to begin\ntheir coursework on either the Pullman or Tri-Cities\ncampus, but must finish on the Tri-Cities campus.\nUndergraduate Transfer Students\nStudents planning to transfer to Washington\nState University should take courses which meet\nthe University Common Requirements (UCORE),\nand that meet the core requirements for Integrated\nPlant Sciences and Agricultural and Food Systems.\nStudents are strongly encouraged to consult with\nan advisor within the Department of Horticulture\nfor further guidance.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nPreparation for graduate study requires the\nselection of courses that will benefit later work\ntoward a Master of Science or a Doctor of Philosophy\ndegree. Normally, preparation for an advanced\ndegree in horticulture includes course work outlined\nunder one of the majors with a strong emphasis in\nplant sciences, chemistry, environmental science,\ngenetics, mathematics, and statistics.\nLANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE\nPlease see the School of Design and Construction\nin this catalog for information about Landscape\nArchitecture.\nMinors\nHorticulture\nA minimum of 16 hours in courses carrying a HORT\nsubject is required, of which at least 9 hours must be\nin 300-400-level courses and taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. A maximum of 3\nhours of the 16 hours may be from the following\ncourses: HORT 399, 495, 499.\nViticulture and Enology\nThe minor in Viticulture and Enology requires at\nleast 16 credit hours of course work, 9 of which\nmust be in the 300-400 level and taken in residence\nat WSU or through WSU-approved education\nabroad or educational exchange courses. The\nminor requires VIT ENOL 113, 313, and 422, and\n7 additional credit hours from BIOLOGY 420, FS\n460, HBM 350, PL P 300, SOIL SCI 201, or any VIT\nENOL course - with the following exception: No\nmore than 4 credits of VIT ENOL 399, 495, 496,\nor 499 may be used towards this minor. At least 3\nof the 7 additional credits must be upper division.\nCourses not in the elective course list may be used\nwith advisor approval.\nDescription of Courses\nHORTICULTURE\nHORT\n102 Introduction to Cultivated Plants 3\nExploring cultivated plant classification\nand morphology, crop reproduction, basic\nplant processes, and the biotic and abiotic\nfactors which can influence these processes.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HORT 102, CROP\nSCI 102).\n150 [BSCI] Science and Art of Growing\nPlants 4 (3-3) Understand and apply the\nscience behind how plants grow and the art of\ngrowing plants for personal and commercial\nuse.\n202 Crop Growth and Development 4 (3-\n3) Course Prerequisite: HORT/ CROP SCI\n102. Morphology, anatomy, growth and\ndevelopment of agronomic and horticultural\ncrops. (Crosslisted course offered as HORT 202,\nCROP SCI 202).\n310 Pomology 3 Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY\n106, BIOLOGY 107, BIOLOGY 120, or HORT\n202. Botany, history, production, and uses\nof temperate-zone tree and small fruit crops.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n313 Viticulture 3 Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY\n106, BIOLOGY 107, BIOLOGY 120, or\nHORT 202. Botanical relationships, plant\ncharacteristics, fruiting habits, location,\nculture, marketing, and utilization of grapes,\nberries, and other small or bush fruits. Field trip\nrequired. (Crosslisted course offered as HORT\n313, VIT ENOL 313). Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n320 Olericulture 3 Science, business, and\nart of vegetable crop production: culture,\nfertility, growth, physiology, handling,\nmarketing; garden, commercial, greenhouse,\ntropical, specialty vegetables. Recommended\npreparation: BIOLOGY 106, BIOLOGY 107,\nBIOLOGY 120, or HORT 202. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n321 Olericulture Laboratory 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in HORT\n320. Production principles and practices of\nvegetable crops; plant characteristics, cultivars,\nnutrition, growth, and development. Field\ntrip required. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n330 Landscape Plants for Urban and\nCommunity Environments 3 (2-3) Plants\nfor solving problems in human-dominated\nlandscapes: their characteristics, functions\nsuch as storm water management and climate\nchange mitigation, ecology, identification,\nand selection. Recommended preparation:\nBIOLOGY 120 or HORT 202.\n331 Landscape Plant Installation and\nManagement 3 (2-3) Principles and practices\nfor installation and management of interior\nand exterior landscapes; specifications, site\npreparation transplanting, growth control,\nproblem diagnosis. Recommended preparation:\nBIOLOGY 106, BIOLOGY 107, BIOLOGY 120,\nHORT 202, HORT 231, or HORT 232.\n332 Interior Plantscaping 3 Design, selection,\ninstallation, management, and maintenance of\nplantings within buildings; effects of interior\nplants on people and the environment.\nRecommended preparation: 3 hours BIOLOGY\nor HORT. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n346 Landscape Irrigation Systems 3 (2-\n3) System component selection; layout,\ninstallation, operation of irrigation systems\nfor turf and landscape plantings; basic system\nhydraulics; efficient water use.\n\n240\nHorticulture\nWashington State University, 2021\n350 Food Systems in Western Washington\n3 Course Prerequisite: CROP SCI/HORT 102;\nECONS 101; SOIL SCI 201. Introduction to\nlocal and regional food systems unique to\nwestern Washington with an emphasis on the\nfarm-to-table processes of foods and beverages.\n(Course offered as HORT 350, AFS 350).\n351 P l ant Propagation 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 106, BIOLOGY 107,\nBIOLOGY 120, or HORT 202. Physiological\nand biochemical basis for sexual and asexual\npropagation of plants by seed, cutting, layering,\ngrafting, budding, specialized plant structures\nand micropropagation. Field trip required.\n357 Greenhouse Management and Crop\nProduction 3 Importance of greenhouse\nstructure and operational systems to quality\nplant production; production requirements\nfor spring greenhouse crops. Recommended\npreparation: 3 hours BIOLOGY or HORT.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n358 Greenhouse Management and Crop\nProduction Lab 1 (0-2) Course Prerequisite:\nConcurrent enrollment in HORT 357.\nProduction practices for spring greenhouse\ncrops. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n399 Professional Work Experience V 1 (0-3) to\n4 (0-12) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 8 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the Viticulture and Enology major,\nIPS major or by interview; junior standing.\nPlanned and supervised work experience.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HORT 399, VIT\nENOL 399). S, F grading.\n409 Seminar in Viticulture and Enology 1\nCurrent topics and recent developments in the\nfield of viticulture and enology. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as HORT 409, VIT ENOL 409).\n413 Advanced Viticulture 3 Course Prerequisite:\nBIOLOGY 420; HORT 313; SOIL SCI 201.\nWine and juice grape production in eastern\nWashington; wine and fruit physiology,\nclimate and soils, and fruit quality. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as HORT 413, VIT ENOL 413).\nCredit not granted for both HORT/VIT ENOL\n413 and HORT 513. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n416 Advanced Horticultural Crop Physiology\n3 Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106,\nBIOLOGY 107, BIOLOGY 120, or HORT 202;\njunior standing. Physiological processes related\nto growth, development, and productivity of\nhorticultural crops; advances in recombinant\nDNA technology; the impact on horticultural\npractices. Credit not granted for both\nHORT 416 and HORT 516. Recommended\npreparation: BIOLOGY 420. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n418 [M] Post-harvest Biology and Technology\n3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 420.\nPhysical and physiological basis for handling\nand storage practices; perishable organ\nontogeny and physiological disorders; post-\nharvest environment requirements. Field\ntrip required. Credit not granted for both\nHORT 418 and HORT 518. Recommended\npreparation: HORT 202. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n421 Fruit Crops Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 6 hours HORT, BIOLOGY, or VIT\nENOL. Current research and management\nstrategies for production and quality of\ntemperate-zone fruit crops. Credit not\ngranted for both HORT 421 and HORT 521.\nRecommended preparation: HORT 310 or\nHORT 313.\n425 [CAPS] [M] Trends in Integrated Plant\nSciences 3 Course Prerequisite: Junior\nstanding. Critical examination of current\nimpacts and future trends in plant sciences.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HORT 425, CROP\nSCI 425.)\n435 Chemistry and Biochemistry of Fruit\nand Wine 3 Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY\n420; MBIOS 101 or 305; MBIOS 303 or\nCHEM 370. Study of the chemistry and\nbiochemistry of fruits; biochemistry and\nphysiology of individual fruit compounds,\naspects of processing including winemaking.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HORT 435, VIT\nENOL 435). Credit not granted for both HORT/\nVIT ENOL 435 and HORT 535. Recommended\npreparation: Analytical chemistry.\n440 Winery Operations and Equipment\n3 Course Prerequisite: CHEM 345. Major\nequipment and unit operations in the\nwinemaking process, with primary focus on\noperations from receipt of grapes through\nbottling process. (Crosslisted course offered as\nVIT ENOL 440, HORT 440).\n441 Winery Operations and Equipment Lab\nField Trip 1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: VIT\nENOL 113; VIT ENOL/HORT 440 or concurrent\nenrollment. Lab companion course for VIT\nENOL/HORT 440; offered only as a week-long\nfield trip over spring break to visit wineries and\nwine industry suppliers; specific visits will vary\nby year, but will include visits to two or three\nwineries, at least one cooperage and several\nequipment and packaging suppliers; requires\nparticipation for all 5 days of spring break.\n(Crosslisted course offered as VIT ENOL 441,\nHORT 441).\n445 [M] Plant Breeding 4 Genetic principles\nunderlying plant breeding and an introduction\nto the principles and practices of plant\nbreeding. (Crosslisted course offered as CROP\nSCI 445, HORT 445). Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n480 Plant Genomics and Biotechnology 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MBIOS/BIOLOGY 301.\nAdvanced concepts in plant genomics and\nbiotechnology with emphasis on approaches,\ntechniques, and application. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as HORT 480, CROP SCI 480).\nRecommended preparation: BIOLOGY 420 or\nHORT 416.\n495 Research Experience V 1-4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: Not open to\ngraduate students. Planned and supervised\nu n d e r g r a d u a t e r e s e a rc h e x p e r i e n c e .\n(Crosslisted course offered as CROP SCI 495,\nHORT 495, SOIL SCI 495).\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. Credit not granted for both HORT/\nVIT ENOL 435 and HORT 535. Recommended\npreparation: Analytical chemistry.\n545 Statistical Genomics 3 (2-3) Develop\nconcepts and analytical skills for modern\nbreeding by using Genome-Wide Association\nStudy and genomic prediction in framework of\nmixed linear models and Bayesian approaches.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CROP SCI 545,\nANIM SCI 545, BIOLOGY 545, HORT 545, PL\nP 545.) Recommended preparation: BIOLOGY\n474; MBIOS 478. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n550 Bioinformatics for Research 4 (3-3)\nFoundational knowledge about advanced\nbioinformatics analyses of next-generation\nsequencing data. S, F\ngrading.\nDepartment of Human\nDevelopment\nhd.wsu.edu\nJohnson Tower 501\n509-335-8439\nChair and Associate Professor, M. Bumpus; Professors,\nM. Diversi, D. Handy, L. Hill, J. Lanigan, L. Parker,\nE. Soliday; Associate Professors, C. Bolkan, B. Boyd,\nM. Cleveland, B. Cooper, R. Cooper, P. Pendry, K.\nRodgers, Y. Sano, A. Whitehall, E. Weybright; Assistant\nProfessors, C. Bletscher, T. Burkhard, J. Duckworth, J.\nHewa, M. K. Patton, S. Perone, S. Reisz, A. Salazar,\nS. Waters, R. Weaver; Instructors, L. Krupke; Adjunct\nInstructors, T. Ashford, D. Bice, W. Ewest, M. Garcia,\nS. Grant, N. Kaivan, N. Porter, S. Rusca, C. Seeley, M.\nStrey; Professors Emeriti, M. K. Deen, J. Dillman, S.\nHorton, A. Lawrence, J. McReynolds, D. Nelson, K.\nPeterson, T. Power, G. Tan, M. Tate, M. Wandschneider,\nM. Young.\n\n242\nHuman Development\nWashington State University, 2021\nUndergraduate Program\nIn the Department of Human Development,\nstudents focus on how children, youth, adults,\nand families develop, change, and face challenges\nthroughout the lifespan. The Department of Human\nDevelopment is a multidisciplinary department\ndevoted to understanding the nature of human\ndevelopment within the context of families,\nschools, and communities. Students completing\na Human Development degree are well prepared\nfor a wide range of careers working with children,\nadolescents, adults, and/or families in a variety of\nprofessional settings; many Human Development\ngraduates are also well equipped to enter graduate\nschool in a number of disciplines.\nHuman Development majors may choose to\nfocus their studies in one of seven options: Family\nand Consumer Sciences Education, Lifespan\nDevelopment, Early Childhood Education, Child/\nYouth Development, Gerontology, Family Services\nor Prevention Science. All options lead to a Bachelor\nof Arts in Human Development.\nThe Family & Consumer Sciences Education option\nis for students interested in teaching in a junior or\nsenior high school setting. Family and consumer\nsciences teachers instruct courses in foods and\nnutrition, family health, human development,\napparel and textiles, family resource management,\nfamily communication, and interior design.\nGraduates are prepared for Family and Consumer\nSciences and Career and Technical Education state\ncertification. They are also well prepared for careers\nwith agencies and organization that serve the needs\nof families in the community.\nThe Lifespan Development option is for students\nwho desire to deepen their understanding of the\nfoundations of development from childhood,\nadolescence, to adulthood. Students in this option\nwill gain psychosocial and bioecological perspectives\non the interrelationships between individuals,\nfamilies, organizations, and communities. A\nLifespan Development focus opens the doors for\nmany helping professions. Students are ready\nfor careers in public and private human service\nagencies, and local, state and federal government.\nThe Early Childhood Education option focuses\non children birth-age 5. Students gain a deeper\nunderstanding of the importance of building\nrelationships with children, observing and\ndocumenting their development and learning,\nplanning and implementing age-appropriate\ncurricula and assessing the success of the planned\ncurricula. This option prepares students to be\nearly childhood educators as they complete a 270-\nhour practicum in a high-quality, early childhood\nclassroom. While this option focuses on preparing\nfor a teaching role, students are also ready for careers\noutside of the classroom working with young\nchildren and their families.\nThe Child/Youth Development option is designed for\nstudents preparing for careers or graduate education\nfocused primarily on children and adolescents.\nExamples include careers developing programming\nfor youth (e.g., parks and recreation, after-school\nprograms, youth development programs); working\nwith youth engaged in systems of care, including\nthose who have experienced trauma (e.g. residential\ntreatment facilities, foster care systems, behavioral\nhealth or developmental services); working in the\njuvenile justice system; counseling youth and\nfamilies.\nThe Gerontology option is for students who desire\nto deepen their understanding of the foundations of\ndevelopment across the entire lifespan, particularly\nin adulthood to later life. Students in this option\nwill gain an overview of the interdisciplinary\nfield of gerontology and explore psychosocial and\nbioecological perspectives on adult development\nand aging over the life course as it affects individuals,\nfamilies, and communities and has social, political,\nand economic implications world-wide. Examples\nof careers in Gerontology include working directly\nwith older adults in a variety of settings and\nadministering programs for older adults.\nThe Human Services option is for students who seek\nto improve the quality of life for individuals, families\nand communities through direct service, advocacy\nor policy. Students will gain an understanding\nof: the foundations of human development\nincluding conditions which support or limit\noptimal functioning, family functioning and\nfamily dynamics and how those relate to human\ndevelopment across the lifespan, service delivery\nsystems, and strategies for working with diverse\nclientele. Students in this option may be interested\nin careers such as family social service programs,\nadvocacy and nonprofit work, community\neducation, and counseling support. This option\nwill also prepare students for advanced education\nin social work, counseling, and family law.\nThe Prevention Science option is designed\nfor students who are interested in taking a\ndevelopmental approach to improving public\nhealth. Specifically, the Prevention Science option\nfocuses on (a) identifying risk and protective factors\nthat shape human development throughout the\nlifespan, and (b) designing, implementing, and\nevaluating interventions, programs, and policies\nthat promote well-being for individuals, families,\nand communities. The option in Prevention Science\nis a good fit for students interested in graduate\nstudies in fields such as Prevention Science, Public\nHealth, and Community Psychology; in addition,\nthis option will prepare students for careers in fields\nsuch as community coalition coordinator, public\nhealth prevention coordinator, and residential\nyouth counselor.\nThe department also offers four certificates: early\nchildhood education, adolescence, gerontology,\nand family studies. Students completing a human\ndevelopment degree may also complete a minor or\napproved certificate of study. A minor or certificate\nof study should be selected in consultation with a\nhuman development advisor, preferably by the end\nof the third semester.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nWe expect our graduating students will\ndemonstrate: 1) an understanding of social,\nemotional, cognitive, and physical development\nacross the lifespan in the family context; 2) an\nunderstanding of how contextual systems interact\nto influence family and individual development; 3)\nthe ability to critically select, evaluate, and utilize\ninformation to understand and benefit individuals\nand families; 4) writing, listening, and speaking\nappropriate for human development related\noccupations; 5) application of human development\nknowledge and skills in professional settings.\nGraduate School Preparation\nThe human development degree provides\npreparation for graduate work leading to teaching,\nresearch, counseling, or administrative positions\nin domains such as academia, social services, and\ncounseling.\nGraduate Program\nT h e d e p a r t m e n t a l s o a d m i n i s t e r s a n\ninterdisciplinary doctoral program in Prevention\nScience. Students in the program learn to conduct\nbasic research on risk and protective factors, and\nto develop, evaluate, and disseminate evidence-\nbased programs to promote the well-being of\nchildren, youth, and their families. The program\nis offered in collaboration with the Colleges\nof Communication, Education, Medicine, and\nNursing, as well as WSU Extension. Graduates are\nprepared for careers as faculty members, program\nevaluators, research analysts, and research associates\nto work in a range of settings including universities,\nresearch institutes, social service agencies, and\nconsulting firms.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nCHILD AND YOUTH DEVELOPMENT\nOPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents can be admitted as a Human Development\nmajor after completing 24 credits and earning a GPA\nof at least 2.0. A cumulative GPA of 2.6 or better in\nall H D courses that apply to the option, including\nsubstitutions is required to (a) maintain admission\nin the major; and (b) complete the Bachelor of\nArts degree in Human Development. Of the 44\ncredits required for the major and Child and Youth\nDevelopment option, a minimum of 21 must be\ntaken at WSU.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI]\n1 \n3\nH D 101 [SSCI] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nWritten Communication [WRTG] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] (with lab)\n1 \n4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nH D 200 2\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nElective\n2 \n3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nH D 204 3\nH D 220 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nElectives\n2 \n6\n\n243\nHuman Development\nWashington State University, 2021\nSecond Term Hours\nH D 306, 307, or 408 3\nH D 350 [DIVR] 3\nElectives\n2 \n9\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nH D 306, 307, or 408 3\nH D 310 [M] 3\nChild and Youth Elective\n3 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nChild and Youth Electives\n3 \n6\nElectives 9\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nH D 410 [M] 3\nH D 479 3\nH D 497\n4 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nH D 498\n5 \n3\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nElectives 9\n_______\n1 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n2 \nElectives must include sufficient 300-400-level\ncoursework to meet the University requirement of\n40 credits of upper-division coursework.\n3 \nChild and Youth Electives (9 credits; minimum 6\nH D credits): Students must complete at least three\ncourses from the following: H D 300, 301, 302, 341,\n360, 418, 430, ANTH 302, PSYCH 464, SOC 352,\n362, 367.\n4 \nH D 497 is required and must be completed prior\nto H D 498, but no more than two semesters before\nH D 498.\n5 \nThe internship course (H D 498) is also available\nduring the summer term of the junior or senior\nyear. Students may take H D 498 for up to 9 credits.\nFor students completing the Child and Youth\nDevelopment options, the H D 498 internship\nexperience must focus on a field relevant to child\nand/or adolescent development.\nEARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents can be admitted as a Human Development\nmajor after completing 24 credits and earning a GPA\nof at least 2.0. A cumulative GPA of 2.6 or better in\nall H D courses that apply to the option, including\nsubstitutions is required to (a) maintain admission\nin the major; and (b) complete the Bachelor of\nArts degree in Human Development. Of the 48-49\ncredits required for the major and Early Childhood\nEducation option, a minimum of 21 must be taken\nat WSU.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI]\n1 \n3\nH D 101 [SSCI] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nWritten Communication [WRTG] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] or\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] (with lab)\n1 \n4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nH D 200 2\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nElective\n2 \n3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nH D 204 3\nH D 220 3\nH D 306 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nElective\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nH D 300 or 302 3\nH D 341 3\nH D 350 [DIVR] 3\nElectives\n2 \n6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nH D 235 1\nH D 300, 302, or 403 3\nH D 310 [M] 3\nH D 482 3\nElectives\n2 \n5\nSecond Term Hours\nH D 300, 302, or 403 3\nH D 342 4\nElectives\n2 \n8\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nH D 445\n3 \n3\nH D 482 3\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nElectives\n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nH D 410 3\nH D 446\n4 \n6\nElectives\n2 \n6\n_______\n1 \nFor a total of 7 credits—one Biological Sciences\n[BSCI] and one Physical Sciences [PSCI] course,\nincluding one lab course.\n2 \nElectives must include sufficient 300-400-level\ncoursework to meet the University requirement of\n40 credits of upper-division coursework.\n3 \nH D 445 must be taken before H D 446 but no more\nthan two semesters before H D 446.\n4 \nAll H D majors complete a practicum/internship\nexperience. H D 446 is reserved for students\ncompleting the option in Early Childhood\nEducation and requires a half-day each day, 5 days\na week for a semester.\nFAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES\nOPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents can be admitted as a Human Development\nmajor after completing 24 credits and earning a GPA\nof at least 2.0.
