Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 702 credit. S, U\ngrading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nVeterinary Science PhD program. Independent\nresearch and advanced study for students\nworking on their doctoral research, dissertation\nand/or final examination. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nInterdisciplinary\ng r a d s c h o o l . w s u . e d u / i n d i v i d u a l -\ninterdisciplinary-doctoral-degree/\n324 French Administration Bldg.\n509-335-6424\nProgram Chair and Director, Lisa Gloss; Program\nCoordinator, Kelly Hewitt.\nIndividual Interdisciplinary Doctoral\nProgram\nGraduate study leading to the Individual\nInterdisciplinary Doctor of Philosophy degree\nis offered as an interdepartmental curriculum\nby graduate faculty from across WSU. The\ninterdisciplinary nature of the research must span\nthree distinct disciplines, typically drawing on\nfaculty expertise from three different departments.\nThe objectives of the program are to provide a\nmechanism for graduate students to develop and\npursue an individually tailored doctoral degree.\nAdmission to the IIDP is highly selective.\nStudents must be extremely motivated and\nhave demonstrated a strong ability to conduct\ninterdisciplinary research. Applicants must have\na bachelor’s degree and a master’s degree from an\naccredited university with a 3.0 GPA for bachelor’s\nwork and 3.5 GPA for master’s work.\nAny faculty member who is recognized as a\ngraduate faculty in his/her home department may\nparticipate in training students in the Individual\nInterdisciplinary Doctoral Program. When\nadmitted, the student’s home department becomes\nthe IIDP program, and the department chair is the\nDean of the Graduate School.\nBefore completing an application to the IIDP, the\nstudents must identify members of their dissertation\ncommittee, consisting of a major advisor and at\nleast four additional faculty members, from at least\nthree academic units. This dissertation committee\noversees the development of the student’s doctoral\nproject and helps the student to produce high quality\ndoctoral research, with rigorous interdisciplinary\nmethodology and approach.\nThe program offers flexibility for students with\ndiverse backgrounds and prepares students to\nbe effective researchers, engaging teachers, and\ninnovative thinkers, under the mentorship of\nleading teachers and researchers in various fields.\nStudents will develop knowledge and understanding\nof appropriate concepts, methods, and materials\nof the three disciplines in their research while\ncreatively integrating this knowledge into their\ninterdisciplinary scholarship.\nPolicies and procedures of the Graduate School\napply to all admissions. Interested students may\ndirect their inquiries to Lisa Gloss at lmgloss@wsu.\nedu.\nDescription of Courses\nINTERDISCIPLINARY\nINTERDIS\n490 McNair Preparation for Graduate School\n1 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 2 hours. Course Prerequisite: Junior\nstanding. Preparation for McNair Scholars and\nothers for graduate study. No credit earned\ntoward degree; not qualified for financial aid.\n501 Research Communication 2 Written and\noral research communication for a variety\nof audiences; use of active exercises, brief\npresentations, and interactive assignments to\nemphasize communication skill development\nand application.\n580 Leadership Development V 1-3 Course\nPrerequisite: By permission only. Meetings and\nworkshops designed to develop professional\nand leadership skills for doctoral students.\n585 Preparing to Teach Online 3 Theory and\ninstructional strategies for graduate students\ninterested in teaching online in higher\neducation.\n590 Preparation for College Teaching 2\nCross-discipline instructional development\nfor graduate teaching assistants; course\ndevelopment teaching techniques, university\npolicies and procedures. S, F grading.\n591 Interdisciplinary Studies 1 Contemporary\nissues in interdisciplinary education and\nresearch. Open to all interested students.\n597 Preparing the Future Professoriate\n2 Course Prerequisite: By permission only.\nUnderstanding and contextual knowledge\nof the professoriate and issues facing higher\neducation.\n598 Interdisciplinary Seminar 1 Course\nPrerequisite: INTERDIS 591 or admission to\nthe IIDP program. Assists IIDP students in\nthe preparation of their program proposal,\nwhich serves as the qualifying examination for\ncontinuation in the IIDP. The IIDP Graduate\nCommittee will review and evaluate the\nproposal. S, F grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nIIPD PhD program. Independent research and\nadvanced study for students working on their\ndoctoral research, dissertation and/or final\nexamination. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Kinesiology\nand Educational\nPsychology\neducation.wsu.edu/college/kep\nCleveland 351\n509-335-9117\nChair and Professor, P. Erdman; Professors, O.\nAdesope, A. Cox, B. French, B. McNeill, M. Trevisan,\nS. Ullrich-French; Associate Professors, K. Carbonneau,\nR. Catena, C. Connolly, K. Hildenbrand, H. Liao;\nAssistant Professors, S. Dai, R. Danielson, C. Gotch,\nS. Prashad, Z. Strong; Teaching Associate Professors,\nK. Holmstrom, P. Morgan, J. Schultz; Scholar Assistant\nProfessors, T. Goetz, S. Landis; K. Pietz; Research\nAssistant Professor, Bruce Austin.\nThe department offers courses of study leading\nto a Bachelor of Science in Sports Medicine,\nand Bachelor of Science in Kinesiology; and\nan undergraduate minor in Strength and\nConditioning. Masters degrees offered are Master of\nArts in Educational Psychology, Master of Science in\nKinesiology, and Masters in Athletic Training. The\n\n255\nKinesiology and Educational Psychology\nWashington State University, 2021\nDoctor of Philosophy (Education) is offered with\nspecialization in Educational Psychology. The Ph.D.\nin Counseling Psychology is in teach-out status with\nno new applicants being accepted.\nThe Department of Kinesiology and Educational\nPsychology, housed in the College of Education,\nhas excellent facilities for undergraduate/graduate\nstudy and research. The department sponsors and\nhosts a number of state, national, and international\nprograms.\nThe Learning and Performance Research Center\n(LPRC) is home to an array of educational and\npsychological research projects. LPRC provides\nleadership, training, consultation, and state-of-the-\nart solutions to challenging educational research\nquestions at the university, state, national, and\ninternational levels. The Psychometric Laboratory is\nhome to an array of educational and psychological\nmeasurement projects. The MERIT Laboratory is\nhome to multimedia learning research focused on\nimproving multimedia instruction, learning, and\nperformance, with consideration of both cognition\nand affect perspectives. The Large Scale Data (LSD)\nLaboratory is home to research on large-scale data\nwith expertise in big-data analytics and quantitative\nmethods.\nThe Exercise Physiology and Performance\nLaboratory (EPPL) provides research, teaching, and\nexercise testing opportunities to WSU students,\nfaculty, and the Pullman community. The Gait\nand Posture Biomechanics Laboratory research\nis focused on (1) the development of a clinical\nassessment tool to detect fall-risk in pregnant\npatients, (2) quantifying and reducing the risk\nof falls for pregnant workers, and (3) improving\nbalance to help sport and exercise performance.\nThe Psychology of Physical Activity Laboratory\nincludes research about optimizing physical activity\nexperiences, motivation for long-term physical\nactivity, and the psychological benefits of physical\nactivity. The Concussion and Sports Medicine\nLaboratory conducts research (a) to understand\nhow head injuries (traumatic brain injury) affect\nthe patient and develop research based tool for\nthe medical community to evaluate patients post\ntraumatic injury, (b) to evaluate the role neck\nstrength plays in the incidence of concussion, (c)\non the biomechanical impacts magnitudes that\noccur in youth sports, and (d) on the effectiveness\nof current education in concussion awareness.\nThe Cognitive Motor Neuroscience Laboratory\nexamines the neural processes underlying motor\nbehavior in clinical and typical populations across\nthe lifespan using behavioral, neuroimaging (EEG),\nand computational approaches. All the labs provide\nservice and research opportunities for students and\nthe WSU community.\nApplication for Graduate Study\nStudents who plan to work toward an advanced\ndegree should contact the Office of Graduate\nEducation in the College of Education. Individuals\napplying for admission to do graduate work must\ncomplete an application to the WSU Graduate\nSchool, and submit the following materials to the\nCollege of Education Office of Graduate Education:\nDepartmental Application form; a statement of\nprofessional objectives; official college transcripts;\nthree (3) letters of recommendation from individuals\nqualified to comment on the applicant’s academic\nand professional abilities, and the Graduate Record\nExamination (GRE). Interested students should\ndirectly contact the Office of Graduate Education\nfor specific requirements of each program area.\nFor those students interested in pursuing the\nMaster’s in Athletic Training degree, this is part of\na 5-year comprehensive program which includes\nthe undergraduate degree in Sports Medicine. All\napplication questions should be directed to the AT\nProgram Clinical Coordinator. See the website for\nspecific information, requirements, and contact\ninformation.\nEducational Psychology is the study of how\nhumans learn and retain knowledge, primarily in\neducational settings like classrooms. This includes\nemotional, social, and cognitive learning processes.\nAreas of focus might include teaching, testing and\nassessment methods, psychometrics, classroom or\nlearning environments, and learning, social, and\nbehavioral problems that may impede learning,\ntechnology in learning, etc. Graduates work as\nprofessors, education specialists, learning analysts,\nprogram evaluators, and find positions in research\ninstitutions, school systems, the testing industry,\ngovernment agencies, and private industry.\nOur program offers two degree options with a\nspecialization in Educational Psychology; the\nMaster of Arts (M.A.) and the Doctor of Philosophy\n(Ph.D.). Students pursuing a master’s degree can\nexpect to complete the program in two years and\ndoctoral students can expect to finish in three to\nfive years beyond the master’s degree.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe learning outcomes on which students are\nrated include:\n• Ability to think critically, evaluate, understand,\napply, and communicate scientific research\n• Ability to evaluate and apply research designs\n• Ability to evaluate and apply statistical and\nmeasurement principles to their area of research\n• Be aware and evaluate how diversity issues and\nprotected populations influence research\n• Development of professional identity appropriate\nfor future career plans\nBachelor of Science in Kinesiology\nThe Kinesiology major leads to the Bachelor of\nScience in Kinesiology degree. The Kinesiology\nmajor is composed of a broad spectrum of courses\ndesigned to expose students to a variety of\nexperiences, concepts, and philosophies centered\non human movement. A grade of C or better must\nbe obtained in all departmental core courses,\nelective core courses, and in UCORE courses used\nas prerequisites for departmental courses. All letter-\ngraded courses specifically required for each major\nmust be taken for a letter grade (i.e., not pass, fail).\nIn order to apply for admission in Kinesiology,\nstudents must have 24 semester credits completed,\nearn a grade of C or better in Human Anatomy\n(KINES 262) and Motor Development (KINES 199),\nand have a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.75\nincluding the semester of application. Meeting\nthe minimum requirements does not guarantee\nadmittance. Applications are accepted in September\n(1st to 30th) and February (1st to 28th).\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nGraduates with a degree in Kinesiology will be\nable to:\n• Identify moral questions, reflect on the\nimplications and apply to discipline issues.\n• Be continuous, collaborative learners who further\ntheir own professional development and use their\nabilities to contribute to the profession.\n• Identify the central body of knowledge in\nkinesiology and use scientific literacy, quantitative\nreasoning and discipline knowledge to analyze\ncontemporary issues.\n• Communicate effectively to a broad range\nof audiences using appropriate traditional and\nemerging technological media.\n• Use pedagogical knowledge to inform their\npractice.\n• Promote respect of diverse populations and\nthought.\nPractical application of theory and knowledge\nin the Kinesiology major is obtained through\nenrollment in practicum hours (KINES 390) during\nthe third year and through the completion\nof a 10-12 credit internship at the end of the\nrequired coursework. The internship serves as the\nbridge between the student’s college career and\nopportunities for employment in Kinesiology.\nMaster of Science in Kinesiology\nKinesiology is the study of human movement. The\nMaster of Science degree in Kinesiology provides\nadvanced education in human movement and\nfoundational research skills that can be applied to\nits understanding. Our faculty and research labs\nspecialize in areas such as biomechanics, exercise\nphysiology, motor control, and physical activity\npsychology. Students pursuing a master’s degree\ncan expect to complete the program in two years.\nThere are thesis and non-thesis options. Graduating\nstudents may choose to become researchers,\ntechnicians, educators, or practitioners in general\nkinesiology or in a specialized sub-discipline.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe learning outcomes on which students are\nrated include:\n• Ability to think critically, evaluate, understand,\napply, and communicate scientific research.\n• Demonstrate advanced kinesiology knowledge\nin chosen area of focus.\n• Ability to understand and apply research\nprinciples.\n• Awareness and understanding of how diversity\nissues, special and protected populations influence\nresearch and practice.\n• Development of professional identity appropriate\nfor future career plans.\nBachelor of Science in Sports Medicine\nThis is part of a 5-year comprehensive program\nwhich includes the Master’s in Athletic Training\ndegree. This is a competitive admission program.\nUpon acceptance into the program students have\naccess to some of the highest quality learning\nopportunities available.\nAthletic training education uses a competency-\nbased approach both in the classroom and clinical\nsetting. Educational content is based on cognitive\n(knowledge), psychomotor (skill), and affective\n(professional behaviors) competencies and clinical\nproficiencies. Additional policies and procedures\nare outlined in the ATP Handbook. Given the\navailability of clinical experiences, students may not\nbe a varsity athlete and an athletic training student.\nCertification for athletic training requires the\nsuccessful completion of a master’s degree in\n\n256\nKinesiology and Educational Psychology\nWashington State University, 2021\nathletic training from an institution that has been\naccredited by the Commission on Accreditation\nof Athletic Training Education and successful\ncompletion of the national exam given by the Board\nof Certification.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nSuccessful graduates will become proficient in the\nfollowing knowledge and skill areas in accordance\nwith professional guidelines as articulated by\nCAATE. Students will:\n• Provide acute care of injuries and illnesses\nto address planning, examination, immediate\nemergent or musculoskeletal management,\ntransportation, and education to clients.\n• Be proficient in using knowledge of basic science\nand research methodology to interpret evidence-\nbased research related to athletic training to answer\nquestions and guide clinical practice.\n• Be prepared, capable, and experienced in working\nas part of an inter-professional healthcare team.\n• Develop advanced understanding of issues\nrelated to athletic training curriculum development,\nimplementation and administration.\n• Demonstrate attitudes, behaviors, and practices\nthat support personal well-being and life-long\nlearning.\n• Become proficient in prevention and health\npromotion to include general prevention principles,\nfitness and wellness principles.\n• Be able to integrate aspects of physical and\nmental health, cultural competence, ethics, and\npatient and community values to improve the\npatients’ outcome.\n• Exemplify leadership, professional engagement\nand advocacy to strengthen the profession of\nathletic training.\nUndergraduate Minors\nThe Department of Kinesiology and Educational\nPsychology offers an undergraduate minor in\nStrength and Conditioning. Courses for the minor\nmay not be taken pass, fail. The strength and\nconditioning minor combines field experiences\nworking in a collegiate D1 training environment\nand coursework on the scientific knowledge to\nimplement safe and effective strength training\nand conditioning programs for a diverse range\nof abilities. The primary goal in programming is\ntargeted performance improvements, which also\nincludes informed decisions about nutrition and\ninjury prevention, and referral to other professionals\nwhen appropriate. Students interested in declaring\na minor in Strength and Conditioning should\ncontact the department.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nKINESIOLOGY\n(120 HOURS)\nThe Kinesiology major leads to the Bachelor\nof Science in Kinesiology. The major provides\nan interdisciplinary understanding of human\nmovement through the study of anatomy,\nphysiology, movement analysis, biomechanics,\nmotor learning, exercise physiology, and sport\npsychology and ethics. Kinesiology provides a\nfoundation for personal training certification,\nhealth and fitness club employment, teaching,\ncoaching, physical therapy, and sports medicine.\nBecause of the high demand for this program,\nstudents must meet minimum admission\nrequirements, as listed below, in order to apply\nto the Kinesiology program. Applicants who\nmeet the minimum requirements are eligible\nfor consideration, but not assured admission.\nEnrollment is limited and admission competitive.\nAdmission application dates are September 1st to\n30th, and February 1st to 28th, with admission\neffective the following term. Candidates must\ncomplete formal admission procedures and be\nadmitted to the Kinesiology major prior to taking\nany 300- or 400-level courses. The following\nminimum criteria must be met for consideration\nfor admission:\nMinimum Admission Criteria\n1. Completion of at least 24 semester credits of\ncoursework.\n2. A cumulative GPA of 2.75.\n3. A grade of C or better in each of the following\ncourses: KINES 199 and KINES 262.\n4. A written statement (maximum of two pages)\ndescribing relevant work experience/involvement\nin extracurricular activities related to Kinesiology.\nA grade of C or better must be obtained in all\ndepartmental core courses, cognate courses,\nand in UCORE courses used as prerequisites for\ndepartmental courses listed on this schedule\nof studies. All letter-graded courses specifically\nrequired for this major must be taken for a letter\ngrade (i.e., not pass, fail).\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nKINES 138 1\nKINES 199 3\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nCognate\n1 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 140 [BSCI] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nKINES 201 3\nKINES 262 4\nSTAT 212 [QUAN] or PSYCH 311 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 102, 106, or 107 4\nKINES 261 3\nKINES 264 3\nKINES 266 3\nSOC 245 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 101 [PSCI] or 105 [PSCI] 4\nCommunication [COMM] 3\nKINES 162 or PHYSICS 101 and 111 3 or 4\nCognate\n1 \n3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 251 4\nKINES 311 3\nKINES 362 3\nCognate\n1 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nKINES 312 [M] 3\nKINES 380 3\nKINES 390 1\nElectives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nKINES 313 3\nKINES 461 [M] 3\nKINES 484 [CAPS] 3\nCognate\n1 \n5 - 7\nSecond Term Hours\nKINES 485 \n2 \n12 or 10\n_______\n1 \nCognate (17 - 19 credits): Choose from ANTH\n205, 405, ATH T 263, 267, BIOLOGY 107 (if not\nused to fulfill major requirement), 220, 315 (if not\nused to fulfill major requirement), 490, CES 222,\n308, CHEM 102, 106, 345, COM 225, 478, H D 101,\n220, 306, 307, 308, 405, KINES 305, 411, 412, 413,\n414, 490, 499, MATH 106, 108, 140, 171, MBIOS\n101, 301, 303, 305, PHIL 365, PHYSICS 102, PSYCH\n230, 265, 320, 321, 324, 333, 350, 361, 363, 470,\nSOC 101, 250, 334, 356, SPMGT 101 (if not used\nto fulfill UCORE Diversity [DIVR] requirement),\nor as approved by advisor. Must include sufficient\n300-400-level courses to meet the University\nrequirement of 40 upper-division credits.\n2 \nMinimum 10 credits required.\nSPORTS MEDICINE\n(120 HOURS)\nThe Bachelor of Science in Sports Medicine\ncomprises the first 4 years of a 5-year Master’s in\nAthletic Training (MAT) Program. All 5 years of\nthe accelerated program must be completed at\nWashington State University. The Commission\non Accreditation of Athletic Training Education\n(CAATE) requires all students to graduate from\na Master’s Level Athletic Training (AT) program\nin order to be eligible to sit for the Board of\nCertification Exam (BOC), which allows a student\nto become a certified athletic trainer.\nAdmission into the undergraduate degree and\napplication to the Master’s in Athletic Training\nprogram will take place in the Fall of the second\n(sophomore) year with pre-admittance status to the\nMAT program. To be eligible to apply for admission\nto the program, students must have completed\nboth KINES 262 and ATH T 267 with a C or better\ngrade, have a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.00,\nand have completed 20 hours of observation in the\nathletic training clinic. Admission is competitive\nand meeting the requirements does not guarantee\nadmission. Contact the department for additional\ninformation on the application process.\nStudents who are accepted into the Master’s in\nAthletic Training (MAT) program begin graduate\n\n257\nKinesiology and Educational Psychology\nWashington State University, 2021\ncoursework in their 4th year. Applicants who are\nselected will be required to maintain a 3.0 GPA\n(B average), achieve a B- or better in all required\nsports medicine/athletic training classes, and show\nprogressive clinical development to remain in the\nathletic training program.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nKINES 138 1\nKINES 199 3\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSTATS 212 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 140 [BSCI] 3\nH D 205 [COMM] 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nKINES 262 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nATH T 267 3\nBIOLOGY 102, 106, or 107 4\nKINES 264 3\nPHIL 365 [HUM] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nATH T 263 2\nATH T 290 2\nCHEM 101 [PSCI] 4\nKINES 162 3\nKINES 311 3\nKINES 361 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nATH T 305 3\nATH T 370 3\nATH T 591 or KINES 390 2\nBIOLOGY 251 4\nKINES 362 3\nSecond Term Hours\nATH T 371 [M] 3\nATH T 591 or KINES 390 2\nKINES 313 3\nKINES 380 3\nKINES 461 [M] 3\nKINES 484 [CAPS] 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nATH T 450 [M] 3\nATH T 530 or ATH T 499\n1 \n3\nATH T 535 or Electives 3\nATH T 592 or Electives\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nATH T 464 3\nATH T 531 or Electives 3\nATH T 560 \n2 \n0 - 3\nATH T 592 or Electives \n2 \n3\nKINES 411 3\n_______\n1 \nATH T 499 topic must be approved by advisor.\n2 \nATH T 560 and 592 coursework required for\nMaster’s in Athletic Training (MAT) degree.\nAdditional coursework required for MAT:\nATH T 565, 575, 585, 590, 593, 595, 598, 599; exit\ninterview.\nMinors\nStrength and Conditioning\nThe minor in Strength and Conditioning requires 31\ncredits of course work and practical experience. The\nminor is designed for students with an interest in\npursuing a profession as a strength and conditioning\ncoach, personal trainer, coach, or athletic trainer. To\nbe eligible for admission to the minor in Strength\nand Conditioning, a student must have earned\nat least 60 credits, have a minimum cumulative\nGPA of at least 2.75 and be admitted to a major.\nGraded courses in the minor may not be taken\npass/fail. Admission is competitive and requires an\napplication process. The minor requires KINES 262,\n264, and 311 as prerequisite coursework. Required\ncourses include KINES 305, 362, 380, and 411. In\naddition, students will have vocational practicum\nexperiences with KINES 412, 413, and 414 under the\nsupervision of approved strength and conditioning\nexperts. Each practicum is 120-150 hours per term,\nwith a required total of 400 hours for the completion\nof the minor. Credits for the minor must include 9\ncredits of upper-division work taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses.\nCertificates\nLeadership in Coaching\nCertificate\nThe Leadership in Coaching Certificate serves\na fundamental and professional need to help\nprepare competent, ethical, and positive coaches\nfor recreation and sport settings. Coaches play an\nimportant role in many communities and proper\ncoaching technique, procedure, attitude and\nbehavior are essential for effective and successful\ncoaching of any sport or activity. Preparing\ncoaching professionals fulfills a job segment for\nsport and recreation activities that include working\nwith agencies such as school districts, parks and\nrecreation, YMCA, Boys and Girls Club, Sky Hawks\nSport Camps, specialized sport camps and clubs, etc.\nThe intent of the certificate coursework is to provide\ncoaching specific knowledge through analyzing\nand understanding sport industry trends, fitness\nand wellness concepts, coaching administration,\nleadership principles in physical activity and\nparticipating in supervised coaching practical.\nAdmittance: Any current WSU student in\ngood academic standing will be admitted into\nthe program. Prerequisites for KINES 390 will be\nwaived for any current student admitted into the\ncertificate program who is not currently majoring\nin Kinesiology.\nAny non-degree seeking student who currently\nholds a BS or BA degree from an accredited\ninstitution can also apply for admittance into\nthe certificate program. Any prerequisites for\nthe courses within the certificate program will be\nwaived for non- degree seeking students.\nThe Leadership in Coaching Certificate requires\n15 credits. Required coursework includes SPMGT\n101 or KINES 201; SPMGT 290; KINES 315; and\nKINES 399. Three additional required credits are\nearned in practical/applied coaching experience\nworking with sports and recreational teams under\nthe supervision of qualified coaches and leaders*\nthrough KINES 390 and/or SPMGT 394*.\n*ASEP Certification and National Alliance for\nYouth Sport (NAYS) Certification.\nDescription of Courses\nATHLETIC TRAINING\nATH T\n263 Emergency Response 2 (1-2) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in Sports\nMedicine or MAT program. Experience with\nthe profession of athletic training, and the\nWSU Athletic Training Program.\n305 Nutrition Related to Fitness and Sport 3\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 140 with a C or\nbetter, or 333 with a C or better; admitted to\nthe major in Kinesiology or Sports Medicine.\nCurrent and evidence-based knowledge\nregarding the application and compliance\nof sound nutritional and diet considerations\nwithin special active populations. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as KINES 305, ATH T 305.)\n370 Injur y Pathologies of the Lower\nExtremity 3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted\nto the major in Sports Medicine or MAT\nprogram. Lugo-Lugo; Professors,\nM. Bloodsworth-Lugo, J. Grenier-Winther (Vancouver),\nL. Guerrero, D. Leonard, V. Navarro-Daniels; Associate\nProfessors, M. Hubert, X. Liu, R. Ong, J. Streamas;\nAssistant Professors, S. Ginsburg, A. Ramírez; Career\nTrack Professor, S. Davis; Career Track Associate\nProfessors, J. Bonzo, W. Cao, C. Gulam (Vancouver),\nK. Niimi, M. Pieracci (Tri Cities), M. Previto; Career\nTrack Assistant Professors, R. Abo, J. Arellano-\nSerratos (Tri Cities), K. Jennings, S. Lopez-Lopez, M.\nSileoni; Lecturers, M. Black, J. Pérez, C. Shull; Adjunct\nInstructors, B. Hazelwood (Vancouver), M. Lee López\n(Vancouver) Associate Director of Humanities and\nSocial Sciences programs, and Academic Advisor for\nComparative Ethnic Studies, A. Chow; Academic\nAdvisor for Foreign Languages and Cultures, L. Heustis;\nAcademic Advisor for Humanities, A. Rocha; Academic\nAdvisor for Social Sciences, D. Spencer-Curtis; Academic\nCoordinator, S. Alvarez.\nThe School of Languages, Cultures, and Race\n(SLCR) cultivates deeper understandings of\nlinguistic, cultural, national, citizenship, and racial\nperspectives in a global context as explored through\nan interdisciplinary approach grounded on the\nhumanities and social sciences. Located in historic\nThompson Hall, the School stands as a bridge\nbetween the past and the future through its degrees:\nAmerican studies and culture, comparative ethnic\nstudies, foreign languages and cultures, humanities,\nand social sciences. Foreign languages have been\noffered at WSU since 1890 and Thompson remains\nthe site for one of the first dedicated language\nlearning centers in the nation (established in\n1911). The interdisciplinary degrees in Humanities\nand Social Sciences date back to 1911. At the same\ntime, the School includes the contemporary and\ntransdisciplinary envisioning of culture and race\nstudies that American Studies and Culture, and\nComparative Ethnic studies embody. Together,\nthese programs collaborate in finding innovative\nresponses to the challenges of our ever-changing\nsocieties.\nThe School fosters critical literacy, intercultural\nengagement, and the pursuit of global social\njustice through grounded, holistic engagement in\ninterdisciplinary inquiry and programs. Language\nstudies in context, the study of transnational\ncultural and race matters, and integrative approaches\nto linguistic, social, and cultural phenomena\nprovide students with the skills, experiences, and\nperspectives necessary to thrive in an increasingly\ndiverse and heterogeneous global society. The\nschool interests are centered on the following:\n• Critical analysis of culture and its products\naround the globe.\n• The effects of popular culture and media on\nsocial articulations of race and ethnicity.\n• Social and cultural production of languages.\n• Social and cultural influence of languages.\n• Intersectional and interdisciplinary scholarship\nin the humanities and the social sciences.\n• Innovative approaches in teaching and scholarly\nproduction.\nAbove all, the school encourages its constituencies\nto make a difference by learning about and\ndemonstrating a commitment to issues in our\nchanging world through undergraduate and\ngraduate education, scholarship, and outreach.\nThe School offers Bachelor of Arts degree programs\nin Comparative Ethnic Studies, Foreign Languages\nand Cultures (Chinese Language and Culture,\nFrench, Japanese, and Spanish), Humanities\n(including an International Studies track with major\nconcentration areas in Latin American Area Studies,\nGermanic Area Studies, French and Francophone\nArea Studies, and European Area Studies; and\nother tracks in Linguistics, and Religious Studies),\nand Social Sciences (with an option in Personnel\nPsychology/ Human Resources, available at WSU-\nVancouver only.) The Humanities and Social\nSciences degrees are not identified with a specific\nsubject-matter field on the diploma. Additional or\nsecond majors in Language for the Professions are\navailable in French, German, Japanese, and Spanish.\nThe School offers undergraduate minors in\nlanguage (Chinese, French, German, Japanese, and\nSpanish) and cultural minors in American Indian\nStudies, Film Studies, French Area Studies, German\nArea Studies, Global Studies, Latin American Area\nStudies, Popular Culture, and Russian Area Studies.\nLanguage certificates in Arabic, Italian, Korean,\nand ‘Core Competencies in Spanish Language and\nCulture’ are available as well.\nThe School offers two graduate degree programs:\na Master of Arts program in Hispanic Studies, and\nMaster of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy program\nin American Studies and Culture.\nFacilities\nThe School is supported by the Language\nLearning Resource Center (LLRC) located in the\nhistoric Thompson Hall since 1911. It provides\nindividual foreign language students with access to\n12 Windows 7 PC’s, as well as two HD TVs with VCR\n& Blu-Ray DVD players, a dedicated computer with\na high-speed duplex scanner plus a flat-bed scanner\nand editing software (Photoshop, Adobe Acrobat\nProfessional, etc.) LLRC also provides foreign\nlanguage courses with class access to 18 Windows\n7 Enterprise computers. The upper mezzanine\nlevel (balcony) holds 9 Windows 7 computers and\na 55&Prime; HD-TV with a dedicated HD-DVD &\nBlu-Ray player. In addition, the lab/classroom in\nThompson 28 (ground floor) holds 15 Windows 7\ncomputers and an HD LCD Projector.\nUNDERGRADUATE STUDIES\nBachelor of Arts in Comparative Ethnic\nStudies\nThe Comparative Ethnic Studies program\n(CES) within the SLCR brings together leading\nscholars committed to teaching and research, who\nhave created an intellectual community at the\nforefront of critical cultural studies in the Pacific\nNorthwest. Comparative Ethnic Studies embraces\ninterdisciplinary, comparative, and transnational\napproaches to studying race relations and the\nintersectionality of race, gender, class, citizenship,\nsexuality, and globalization. The course work fosters\nan in-depth understanding of the complexities of\nformations of race and culture.\nThe major in comparative ethnic studies prepares\nstudents to work and function in the multiracial\nand multicultural world in which we live. Students\nmajoring in comparative ethnic studies must\ncomplete 36 hours in CES, as outlined in the\nprogram of studies. CES also offers a minor in\nComparative Ethnic Studies. Courses for the minor\nmay not be taken pass/fail. Students interested in\ndeclaring a major or minor in CES should contact\nthe College of Arts and Sciences Advising Center at\nDaggy 201, 509-335-8731, or the School.\n\n264\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nUpon completion of the BA in Comparative\nEthnic Studies, students will be able to:\n• Recognize and summarize impact and\nintersections of race, class, gender, and sexuality.\n• Identify and articulate one’s social location\nin a complex, structurally unequal, and often\ncontradictory world.\n• Display familiarity with multiple perspectives,\nemploy other interpretations, and consider a range\nof human experiences in analysis.\n• Identify and assess social norms and assumptions\nand envision alternative social norms and practices.\n• Ask critical questions and formulates a relevant\nresearch plan; access information tools to get\nrelevant answers.\n• Articulate and utilize the basic tools and texts of\nthe interdiscipline.\n• Examine the influence of historical context on\nthe formation of local, national, and global political\nand social narratives.\n• Engage in active and critical verbal and/or\nwritten discussion of issues from scholarly sources.\nBachelor of Arts in Foreign Languages and\nCultures\nThe Bachelor of Arts in Foreign Languages and\nCultures provides WSU students with the linguistic\nproficiency and intercultural competence that will\nallow them to become true and effective global\nleaders. The degree offers several major programs\nof study: Chinese Language and Culture, French,\nJapanese, and Spanish, with teaching options in\nFrench, Japanese, and Spanish, as well as Language\nfor the Profession Second Majors in French,\nGerman, Japanese, and Spanish. Language minors\nare available in Chinese, French, German, Japanese,\nand Spanish. Cultural minors are also possible in\nFrench Area Studies, German Area Studies, Global\nStudies, Latin American Area Studies and Russian\nArea Studies. Two year programs of study leading\nto Language Certificates in Arabic, Italian, Korean,\nand ‘Core Competencies in Spanish Language\nand Culture’ are available. Students interested in\ndeclaring a major or minor or obtaining a certificate\nshould contact the College of Arts and Sciences\nAdvising Center at Daggy 201, 509-335-8731, or\nthe School.\nStudent Learning Outcomes for European\nLanguages (French and Spanish programs)\nMajors:\nThe program outcomes promote linguistic\nproficiency and intercultural competence:\n• Linguistic Proficiency: Students can demonstrate\nan Advanced Low level of proficiency (as defined\nin ACTFL Proficiency Guidelines) in the target\nlanguage in speaking, writing, listening and reading.\n• Speaking: Students are able to handle a variety of\ncommunicative tasks. They are able to participate in\nmost informal and some formal conversations on\ntopics related to school, home, and leisure activities.\nThey can also speak about some topics related to\nemployment, current events, and matters of public\nand community interest.\n• Writing: Students are able to meet basic work and/\nor academic writing needs. They demonstrate the\nability to narrate, describe and express viewpoints\nabout familiar topics in major timeframes with\nsome control of aspect.\n• Listening and Reading: Students are able to\nunderstand short conventional narrative and\ndescriptive texts (spoken and/or written) such\nas descriptions of persons, places, and things,\nand narrations about past, present, and future\nevents with a clear underlying structure though\ntheir comprehension may be uneven. They can\nunderstand the main facts and some supporting\ndetails. Comprehension may often derive primarily\nfrom situational and subject-matter knowledge.\n• Intercultural Competence: Students will\ndemonstrate knowledge and understanding of\nother cultures and their products. By the time they\ngraduate from our program, they will be able to:\n• Recognize and describe the historical, social,\neconomic, and political forces that shape society\nin the target culture.\n• Analyze and critique the products of the target\nculture (film, literature, art, popular culture, media,\netc.) within their context, including conducting\nbasic research tasks.\n• Examine the validity of one’s own cultural\nbeliefs, behaviors and norms by contrasting and\ncomparing them with those of the target culture.\n• Perceive and value cultural diversity and\nreinterpret the place of the self as an identity\nculturally situated in the global context.\nStudent Learning Outcomes for Asian\nLanguages (Chinese and Japanese\nprograms) Majors:\nThe program outcomes promote linguistic\nproficiency and intercultural competence:\n• Linguistic Proficiency: Students can demonstrate\nan Intermediate High level of proficiency (as\ndefined in ACTFL Proficiency Guidelines) in the\ntarget language in speaking, writing, listening, and\nreading.\n• Speaking: Students are able to handle with\nease and confidence a substantial number of\ncommunicative tasks and social situations that\nrequire an exchange of basic information related to\ntheir home, work, school, recreation, and particular\ninterests. They can also speak about topics related to\ncurrent issues and matters of public and community\ninterest using connected discourse of paragraph\nlength. They can generally be understood by native\nspeakers who are unaccustomed to dealing with\nnon-natives.\n• Writing: Students are able to meet all practical\nwriting needs and write narrative, descriptive,\nand expository passages related to work and/or\nschool experiences. They can express their ideas\nin all major timeframes using proper vocabulary,\ngrammar, and writing styles when writing about\neveryday events and situations. Their writing is\ngenerally comprehensible to natives not used to\nthe writing of non-natives.\n• Listening: Students are able to understand simple\nsentence-length speech in basic personal and social\ncontexts with ease and confidence. They can derive\nsubstantial meaning or main points from some\nconnected texts.\n• Reading: Students are able to understand fully\nand with ease short, non-complex texts that\nconvey basic information and deal with personal\nand social topics as well as some connected texts\nfeaturing description and narration. They can\nderive substantial meaning and main points and\nunderstand supporting details from more advanced,\nconnected texts.\n• Intercultural Competence: Students can\ndemonstrate knowledge and understanding of the\ntarget cultures and their products. By the time they\ngraduate from our program, they will be able to:\n• Recognize and describe the historical, social,\neconomic, and political events/forces that shape\nsociety in the target culture.\n• Analyze and critique the products of the target\nculture (film, literature, art, popular culture, media,\netc.) within their context, including conducting\nbasic research tasks.\n• Examine the validity of one’s own cultural\nbeliefs, behaviors and norms by contrasting and\ncomparing them with those of the target culture.\n• Perceive and value cultural diversity and\nreinterpret the place of the self as an identity\nculturally situated in the global context.\nLanguage Teacher Training Program\nStudents preparing to teach should consult the\ncatalog listing of the Department of Teaching and\nLearning for certification requirements and for\nteaching majors and minors. Those who intend to\nmajor in foreign languages and education should\nbegin the study of the major language in the first\nyear and of the minor language, if any, not later\nthan the beginning of the second year. Students\nare also required to take FOR LANG 440. Teacher\ntraining is available in the language programs of\nFrench and Spanish.\nBachelor of Arts in Humanities\nThis degree promotes an integrative, cross-\ndisciplinary approach and allows students to work\nas full partners in the design of their program of\nstudies. It is appropriate for students who have\nvaried interests that may cut across the usual\ndepartmental boundaries and who wish to play a\nrole in deciding on a suitable curriculum of study\nwhere disciplines in the humanities and/or the arts\nare the primary components. The Bachelor of Arts in\nHumanities also offers additional program options\nin International Area Studies, Linguistics (See Dept.\nof English), and Religious Studies. These degrees are\nnot identified with a specific subject-matter field on\nthe diploma but it will be reflected in the transcript.\nStudents interested in being admitted to this major\nshould contact the College of Arts and Sciences\nAdvising Center at Daggy 201, 509-335-8731, or\nthe School.\nLearning Goals\nThe stated learning goals specify knowledge and\nskill appropriate to the humanities degree but may\nvary depending on the focus of the degree, as chosen\nby the student. In addition, the student’s University\nexperience in terms of assignments, course selection,\nclassroom participation, internships, performances,\ncommunity services, and service learning activities\nare considered, and outcomes are measured in terms\nof society and self; critical thinking and creativity;\nwriting, listening and speaking skills; information\nliteracy; quantitative and symbolic reasoning skills;\nand depth, breadth and application of knowledge.\n• To expose students to a thorough and integrated\nstudy of humanities, cultures, histories, languages,\narts, and other related disciplines, as appropriate\nto the student’s interest and the program of\nstudies pursued, that will allow them to develop\na diverse and transdisciplinary perspective and\nunderstanding.\n• To expose students to a diversity of ways to\nIntegrate and synthesize knowledge from multiple\nsources.\n\n265\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\n• To help students develop means of expressing\nconcepts, propositions, and beliefs in coherent,\nconcise and technically correct forms appropriate to\ntheir disciplinary standards and professional goals.\n• To help students think, react, and work in\nimaginative ways stimulated by a higher degree\nof disciplinary synergies that will promote\ntransdisciplinary innovation, and divergent\nthinking.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nA student completing the General Studies -\nHumanities degree programs will be able to:\n• Integrate learned skills and knowledge\nderived from their concentrations or areas of\nstudy, demonstrating depth, breadth, and the\ndevelopment of a transdisciplinary perspective in\nthe humanities.\n• Demonstrate proficiency in using disciplinary-\nappropriate methods for research, critical analysis,\ncreative work or professional performance.\n• Communicate conclusions, interpretations, and\nimplications clearly, concisely, and effectively, both\norally and in writing for different types of audiences.\n• Articulate and apply values, principles, and\nideals derived from an individual as well as\nintegrated understanding of their areas of study\nthat demonstrate awareness of current modes of\nexpression and thought.\nBachelor of Arts in Social Sciences\nThis degree promotes an integrative approach\nand allows students to work as full partners in the\ndesign of their program of studies. It is appropriate\nfor students who have varied interests that may\ncut across the usual departmental boundaries and\nwho wish to play a role in deciding on a suitable\ncurriculum of study, where disciplines in the social\nsciences or related areas such as administrative\nstudies or communications are primary components\nin the design of this degree. At WSU-Vancouver only\nthe Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences also offers an\noption in Personnel Psychology/ Human Resources.\nThe degree is not identified with a specific subject-\nmatter field on the diploma but it will be reflected in\nthe transcript. Students interested in being admitted\nto this major should contact the College of Arts and\nSciences Advising Center at Daggy 201, 509-335-\n8731, or the School.\nLearning Goals\nThe stated learning goals specify knowledge and\nskill appropriate to the focus of the degree, based on\nthe disciplines that conform the program of studies\nchosen by the student. In addition, the student’s\nUniversity experience in terms of assignments,\ncourse selection, classroom participation,\ninternships, performances, community services,\nand service learning activities are considered,\nand outcomes are measured in terms of society\nand self; critical thinking and creativity; writing,\nlistening and speaking skills; information literacy;\nquantitative and symbolic reasoning skills; and\ndepth, breadth and application of knowledge.\n• To expose students to a thorough and integrated\nstudy of social sciences and related disciplines\nidentified by the student’s interests that will allow\nthem to develop a diverse and transdisciplinary\nperspective and understanding.\n• To expose students to a diversity of ways to\nintegrate and synthesize knowledge from multiple\nsources.\n• To help students develop means of expressing\nconcepts, propositions, and beliefs in coherent,\nconcise and technically correct forms appropriate\nto their professional goals.\n• To help students think, react, and work in\nimaginative ways that will promote transdisciplinary\ninnovation, and divergent thinking.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nA student completing the Bachelor of Arts in\nSocial Sciences degree program will be able to:\n• Integrate learned skills and knowledge using\nmulti-disciplinary perspectives from their\nconcentrations or areas of study in the social\nsciences and related disciplines, demonstrating\ndepth and breadth.\n• Demonstrate proficiency in using disciplinary-\nappropriate methods for critical analysis, and\napplied research, as well as engagement in\nprofessional performance.\n• Communicate conclusions, interpretations, and\nimplications clearly, concisely, and effectively, both\norally and in writing for different types of audiences.\n• Articulate and apply values, principles, and\nideals derived from an individual as well as\nintegrated understanding of their areas of study\nthat demonstrate awareness of current societal\nchallenges.\nAdditional Majors in Language for the\nProfessions\nStudents who are admitted to a major may seek\nan additional major focusing on the professional\napplication of a specific language. This additional\nmajor does not lead to a degree. These additional\nmajors - French for the Professions, German for\nthe Professions, Japanese for the Professions, and\nSpanish for the Professions - offer skills-based,\nproficiency-oriented learning that prepares\nstudents to communicate in the target language\nin professional settings. The unique combination\nof applied foreign language instruction and in-\ndepth study of the culture(s) in which the target\nlanguage is spoken trains students to achieve a level\nof proficiency in the language that enables them\nto identify and analyze cultural traits and concepts\nrelevant to those countries and communities.\nThe distinctive focus of this curriculum, i.e. on\nboth language proficiency and intercultural\nproficiency, provides students entering today’s\nincreasingly global and diverse workplace with the\ncommunication skills necessary to work effectively\nwithin, between, and across different language\ncommunities. This will enhance marketability and\noptions for employment and allow students to\nbecome effective global leaders and entrepreneurs.\nLearning Goals\nTo support and enhance the University’s stated\ngoal of promoting global leadership, the School is\nin the unique position to provide WSU students\nwith the communication skills and intercultural\ncompetence that will allow them to become engaged\nparticipants on a global scale in their chosen field.\na. Linguistic proficiency: Depending on the target\nlanguage, students can demonstrate an Intermediate\nMid-High level of proficiency (as defined in ACTFL\nProficiency Guidelines) in the target language in\nspeaking, writing, listening and reading.\nb. I n t e r c u l t u r a l c o m p e t e n c e : S t u d e n t s\nwill demonstrate knowledge and understanding\nof other cultures and their norms as they relate to\nprofessional dealings.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nUpon completion of this program, students will\nbe able to:\n• Recognize and describe the cultural forces\n(history, social values, economic practices, and\npolitics) that shape the professional practices in\nthe target culture.\n• Analyze and critique professional behaviors\nand practices (i.e., through the history of specific\ncompanies, case studies, or current events) within\ntheir disciplinary context, including conducting\nbasic research tasks.\n• Examine one’s own behaviors and norms in the\nprofessional world by contrasting and comparing\nthem with those of the target culture.\n• Identify and value diversity as well as the place\nof the self as an identity culturally situated in the\nglobal context.\nGRADUATE STUDIES\nComplete details on preparation for graduate\nstudy and graduate programs are available from\nthe graduate studies advisor and on the school’s\nwebsite: slcr.wsu.edu.\nGraduate Program in American Studies\nand Culture\nThe American Studies and Culture M.A. and\nPh.D. degrees at Washington State University offer\ninterdisciplinary research training that aims to map\nstructural inequalities and resistance movements\nin a U.S. and a global context. Alumni go on to\nacademic positions in a variety of institutions,\nbringing a critical, intersectional lens to the study of\nAmerican cultural and social formations. With a core\nfaculty in the fields of cultural, ethnic, gender, and\ncitizenship studies, students drawn to the program\nhave a strong interest in the scholarly study of and\nchallenge to social inequalities, whether manifested\nin popular culture, immigration policies, gender-\nracial discrimination, or other contemporary or\nhistorical loci. The Program offers a broad array\nof intellectual possibilities for developing critical\ninterventions in borderlands studies, the study of\ncolonialism and empire, race and ethnic studies,\ngender, indigenous studies, sports studies, digital\nculture and media, film and television studies, and\ndisability studies.\nMission\nThe Graduate Program in American Studies and\nCulture seeks to prepare professional educators to\nengage in critical scholarship and public dialogue\nabout culture locally, nationally, and globally, with\ndeep understanding that is situated historically and\nin the contemporary period.\nProgram Goals\n• To train students in the field of American studies\nand culture for a broad, critical, and interdisciplinary\nknowledge of cultural formations, historically, in\nthe contemporary period, and in global context.\n• To equip students to engage in scholarly and\npublic dialogue about American culture.\n• To prepare graduates to be effective teachers in\nthe field of American Studies and Culture and an\ninterdisciplinary sub-specialization of their choice.\n\n266\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nBy the end of this program, students will be able\nto:\n• Demonstrate broad, critical, and interdisciplinary\nknowledge of American culture, (i.e., historically, in\nthe contemporary period, in global context).\n• Synthesize knowledge from several disciplinary\nperspectives.\n• Think critically about limits of disciplinary\nknowledge domains.\n• Analyze documentary (primary source) evidence\nfrom written, visual, and oral genres.\n• Identify and employ primary and secondary\nsource materials located through library and online\nscholarly research tools.\n• Design and complete original research in\nthe discipline and an interdisciplinary area of\nspecialization.\n• Write clear, publishable analytic prose\nscholarship.\n• Contribute critically to professional and to public\nconversations.\n• Teach undergraduate curriculum effectively\n• Admission is competitive and qualifying graduate\nstudents can be financially supported by teaching\nassistantships.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nCHINESE LANGUAGE AND CULTURE\n(120 HOURS)\nA minimum of 34 credits beyond the 203 level (or\nthe equivalent level in competence) in the major\nlanguage is required for a Bachelor of Arts degree\nin Foreign Languages and Cultures. CHINESE\n101, 102, and 203 do not count toward the major.\nStudents who place into 102 and receive a B or\nbetter qualify for an additional 4 departmental\nadvanced placement credits; students placing into\n203 or above and receiving a B or better qualify\nfor 8 departmental advanced placement credits. A\nmaximum of 8 departmental AP credits is possible.\nSee school for details.\nMajors must complete either a minor in a second\nforeign language, a concentration of at least 16\ncredits in a related field, or a second major.\nStudents are admitted to the Chinese major upon\nmaking their intentions known to the School of\nLanguages, Cultures and Race. However, no course\nin which a C- or lower grade is earned will be\ncounted toward the major. 300-400-level courses\ntaken pass, fail may not be included for credit\ntoward the major. No course may be repeated for\ncredit toward the major unless thus designated in\nthe catalog. No course may count for both the major\nand the minor.\nMajors and prospective majors are strongly\nencouraged to spend at least one semester abroad,\nliving in the target culture and enhancing their\nfluency. Many accredited study abroad programs are\navailable; students should work with their advisers\nin the selection of a program.\nOf the 34 credits required for the major, a\nminimum of 15 must be taken in residence with 6\nof these credits at the 400 level. A maximum of 12\ncredits per semester or 18 credits per year earned in\na study abroad program may be applied toward the\nmajor. Credits for CHINESE 105, 205, 305, and 405\nmay not be applied toward the major.\nAll majors must complete an exit proficiency\nexamination during the semester in which they\ncomplete the last language course of their major.\nThere is a fee charged for the exam.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHINESE 101, 102, 203 or Elective 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nFOR LANG 101, 110, 120, 130, or 220 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCHINESE 102, 203 or Elective \n1 \n4\nCHINESE 111, 120, 121, or 131 3\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n2 \n4\nCHINESE 203 or Elective\n1 \n4\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives\n3 \n4\nSecond Term Hours\nCHINESE 204 or 307 3\nCHINESE 311 [M], 320 [M], 321[M], or\n330 [M] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n2 \n4\nElectives\n3 \n3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHINESE 306, 307, or 308 3\nCHINESE 361, 363, 364, or 450 3\nChinese Area Studies Elective\n4 \n3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nElective\n3 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nCHINESE 306, 307, or 308 3\n300-400-level Electives\n3 \n3\nElectives\n3 \n6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHINESE 306, 307, or 308 3\nChinese Area Studies Elective\n4 \n3\n300-400-level Electives\n3 \n9\nSecond Term Hours\nCHINESE 361, 363, 364, or 450 3\nChinese Area Studies Elective\n4 \n3\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\n300-400-level Electives\n3 \n6\nExit Proficiency Exam\n_______\n1 \nStudent must meet proficiency requirement\nto enroll in CHINESE 204. Study abroad in an\nimmersion program in China or Taiwan is strongly\nrecommended.\n2 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n3 \nElectives must be represented by an approved\nuniversity minor in a second foreign language; 16\ncredits in a concentrated related field; or a second\nmajor in another field. Electives should include\nsufficient 300-400 level coursework to meet\nUniversity requirement of 40 upper division credits.\n4 \nChinese Area Studies (9 credits): Approved courses\ninclude ASIA 302 [M], 314, 315 [M], 476 [M], CES\n314 [M], 315 [M], and POL S 333, or as approved by\nadvisor. University requirements include a total of\ntwo [M] courses.\nCOMPARATIVE ETHNIC STUDIES\n(120 HOURS)\nThe BA in Comparative Ethnic Studies offers a\nunique opportunity to study the social, economic,\nand political forces that have shaped the historic\nexperience of diverse ethnic communities in the\nUnited States over the past 500 years and that\ncontinue to determine our future. CES embraces\ninterdisciplinary, comparative, and transnational\napproaches to studying race relations and the\nintersectionality of race, gender, class, sexuality, and\nglobalization. The program offers a major and two\nminors; it is preparatory for careers and future study\nin teaching, social work, law school, community\ndevelopment and nonprofit work.\nStudents must complete a minimum of 36 credits in\nthe major, as outlined in the program of studies. An\noverall 2.0 major GPA is required. A list of approved\nCES Sub-core and CES Electives are outlined below.\nStudents must also satisfy the UCORE, College of\nArts and Sciences graduation requirements, and take\nat least 40 of the total 120 semester credits in 300\n– 400 level courses. Students are admitted to the\nComparative Ethnic Studies major upon making\ntheir intentions known to the School of Languages,\nCultures, and Race.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCES 201 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nCES Elective \n2 \n3\nForeign Language and/or Electives 6\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\n\n267\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nCES Elective\n2 \n3\nForeign Language and/or Electives 6\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCES 301 [M] 3\n300-400-level CES Elective\n2 \n3\nCES Sub-core\n3 \n6\nElectives 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCES Sub-core\n3 \n3\n300-400-level CES Electives\n2 \n6\n300-400-level Electives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400-level CES Elective\n2 \n3\nElectives 12\nSecond Term Hours\nCES 489 [CAPS] 3\n300-400-level Electives 12\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nCES Electives: 18 credits including 12 credits\nof 300-400-level course work. CES Electives and\nsub-core must include course work to meet the\nUniversity requirement of 2 [M] courses. Approved\ncourses include AMER ST 475; CES 111, 131, 151,\n171, 209, 220, 240, 244, 254, 255, 260, 271, 280,\n308, 313, 314 [M], 325, 331, 332 [M], 335, 336, 338,\n353 [M], 357, 358 [M], 373 [M], 379, 380, 405, 406,\n407, 413, 426, 440, 444, 446, 454, 465, 470, 491 [M];\nCES 372/ANTH 312; CES /WOMEN ST 411.\n3 \nCES Sub-core courses are (9 Credits): CES 301\n[M], 325, 440, 446, and 491 [M]. CES Sub-core\nand Electives must include coursework to meet\nUniversity requirement of 2 [M] courses.\nFRENCH\n(120 HOURS)\nA minimum of 34 credits beyond the 203 level (or\nthe equivalent level in competence) in the major\nlanguage is required for a Bachelor of Arts degree\nin Foreign Languages and Cultures. FRENCH 101,\n102, and 203 do not count toward the major.\nStudents who place into 102 and receive a B or\nbetter qualify for an additional 4 departmental\nadvanced placement credits; students placing into\n203 or above and receiving a B or better qualify\nfor 8 departmental advanced placement credits. A\nmaximum of 8 departmental AP credits is possible.\nSee school for details.\nMajors must complete either a minor in a second\nforeign language, a concentration of at least 16\ncredits in a related field, or a second major.\nStudents are admitted to the French major upon\nmaking their intentions known to the School of\nLanguages, Cultures and Race. However, no course\nin which a C- or lower grade is earned will be\ncounted toward the major. 300-400-level courses\ntaken pass, fail may not be included for credit\ntoward the major. No course may be repeated for\ncredit toward the major unless thus designated in\nthe catalog. No course may count for both the major\nand the minor.\nMajors and prospective majors are strongly\nencouraged to spend at least one semester abroad,\nliving in the target culture and enhancing their\nfluency. Many accredited study abroad programs are\navailable; students should work with their advisers\nin the selection of a program.\nOf the 34 credits required for the major, a\nminimum of 15 must be taken in residence with 6\nof these credits at the 400 level. A maximum of 12\ncredits per semester or 18 credits per year earned in\na study abroad program may be applied toward the\nmajor. Credits for FRENCH 105, 205, 305, and 405\nmay not be applied toward the major.\nAll majors must complete an exit proficiency\nexamination during the semester in which they\ncomplete the last language course of their major.\nThere is a fee charged for the exam.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFOR LANG 101 [DIVR], 110 [DIVR],\n120 [DIVR], or 220 [DIVR] 3\nFRENCH 101, 102, 203, or Elective\n1 \n4\nFRENCH 105 or Elective 1\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSLCR Culture Course\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nFRENCH 102, 203, or Elective\n1 \n4\nFRENCH 105 or Elective 1\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSLCR Culture Course\n2 \n3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nFRENCH 203 or Elective\n1 \n4\nFRENCH 205 or Elective 1\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives\n4 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nFRENCH 110 [HUM] or 120 [HUM] 3\nFRENCH 204 4\nFRENCH 205 or Elective 1\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nElectives\n4 \n3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFRENCH 305 or Elective 1\nFRENCH 306, 307, or 308 [M] 3\nFRENCH 361 [COMM] 3\nElectives \n4 \n9\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nFRENCH 305 or Elective 1\nFRENCH 306, 307, or 308 [M] 3\nFRENCH 320 [HUM] 3\nElectives\n4 \n4\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFRENCH 306, 307, or 308 [M] 3\nFRENCH 310 or 410 [CAPS] 3\nFRENCH 405 or Elective 1\nElectives\n4 \n9\nSecond Term Hours\nFRENCH 350 or 450 [M] 3\nFRENCH 405 or Elective 1\nFRENCH 408 [M] 3\nFRENCH 420 [CAPS] 3\nElectives\n4 \n6\nExit Proficiency Exam\n_______\n1 \nStudent must meet proficiency requirement to\nenroll in FRENCH 204.\n2 \nSLCR Culture Course (6 credits): Choose from\nCHINESE 111, 120, 121, 131; GERMAN 110, 120;\nSPANISH 110, 111, 120, 121; JAPANESE 120, or 123.\n3 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n4 \nElectives must be represented by an approved\nuniversity minor in a second foreign language; Electives should include\nsufficient 300-400 level coursework to meet\nUniversity requirement of 40 upper division credits.\nFRENCH - SECONDARY EDUCATION\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents who wish to earn a teaching credential\nmust apply to the Teacher Preparation Program\nin the College of Education. They should consult\nwith an advisor in Teaching and Learning regarding\nthe education requirements and with an advisor in\nFrench regarding the French requirements.\nTo be admitted to the French Teaching option, a\nstudent must have earned at least a 2.50 cumulative\nGPA. A grade of C or better is required in all French\ncourses to fulfill the requirement of this degree.\nFRENCH 101 and 102 do not count toward the\nmajor, but students must complete these courses or\nshow equivalent proficiency to enroll in FRENCH\n203.\nDepartmental advanced placement credits:\nStudents who place into 102 and receive a B or\nbetter qualify for an additional 4 departmental\nadvanced placement credits; students placing into\n203 or above and receiving a B or better qualify\nfor 8 departmental advanced placement credits. A\nmaximum of 8 departmental AP credits is possible.\nSee school for details.\nNo course in which a C- or lower grade is earned\nwill be counted towards the major. 300-400-level\ncourses taken pass, fail may not be included for\ncredit toward the major. No course may be repeated\nfor credit toward the major unless thus designated\nin the catalog. No course may count for both the\nmajor and the minor.\nTeaching majors are strongly encouraged to spend\nat least a summer abroad, living in the target culture\nand enhancing their fluency. Many accredited study\nabroad programs are available. Students should work\nwith their advisors in the selection of a program or if\nwanting to consider alternate options to the study\nabroad requirement\nOf the 32 FRENCH credits required for the\nteaching major, a minimum of 15 must be taken in\nresidence with 6 of these credits at the 400 level. A\nmaximum of 12 credits per semester or 18 credits\nper academic or calendar year earned in a study\nabroad program may be applied toward the teaching\n\n268\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nmajor. Credits for FRENCH 105, 205, 305, and 405\nmay not be applied toward the major or minor.\nAll teaching majors must complete an exit\nproficiency examination during the semester in\nwhich they complete the last language course of\ntheir major. There is a fee charged for the exam.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nFOR LANG 101 [DIVR] or 110 [DIVR] 3\nFRENCH 120 [HUM] 3\nFRENCH 203\n1 \n4\nFRENCH 205 or Elective\n2 \n1\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 201 [WRTG] 3\nFRENCH 204 4\nFRENCH 205 or Elective \n2 \n1\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nFRENCH 306, 307, or 308 [M] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nFRENCH 306, 307, or 308 [M] 3\nFRENCH 310, 320 [M], 350, or 361 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nTCH LRN 301 3\nApply for certification into the\nSecondary Teacher Certificate Program\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Term Hours\nTCH LRN 317 Initial Practicum Experience\n(Summer) 2\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nFOR LANG 440 3\nFRENCH 306, 307, or 308 [M] 3\nFRENCH 310, 320 [M], 350, or 361 3\nSecond Term Hours\nFRENCH 408 [M] 3\nTCH LRN 464 3\nTCH LRN 465 3\nTCH LRN 466 3\nThird Term Hours\nFOR LANG 380, 480, or 495 (Summer abroad or\ninternship in Francophone country)\n4 \n6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nED PSYCH 468 3\nFRENCH 420 [CAPS] 3\nTCH LRN 467 3\nTCH LRN 469 3\nTCH LRN 470 3\nComplete FL proficiency Exit Exam\nPass Designated World Language WEST-E and\nAmerican Council on the Teaching of Foreign\nLanguages (ACTFL) at the advance-low level\nSecond Term Hours\nTCH LRN 415 Student Teaching 16\n_______\n1 \nStudent must meet proficiency requirement to\nenroll in FRENCH 203.\n2 \nFRENCH 205 is not required for degree. Davis, Coordinator\nThe BA in Humanities - International Area Studies\nmajor is for students who have interests that are\nboth international and interdisciplinary. Students\nmay choose between these major concentrations:\nLatin America Area Studies, German Area Studies,\nFrench and Francophone Area Studies, and\nEuropean Area Studies. (Please note that Asian\nArea Studies is described in the Asian Program\nsection of the catalog). Students who wish to earn\na Bachelor of Arts in Humanities with a focus in\nInternational Area Studies will devise an approved,\ncoherent program of study with the coordinator\nand a designated advisor who is a specialist in the\nstudent’s area of interest. The program of study\nmust fulfill an academic or career goal, include\nprerequisites consistent with the 300-400-level\nmajor coursework, satisfy the UCORE requirements\nand any additional requirements for the College of\nArts and Sciences, and include language proficiency\nappropriate to the cultural area. The area studies\nmajor will consist of a minimum of 40 credits. No\ncourse in which C- or lower is earned will be counted\ntoward the major. More details are available on the\nwebsites of WSU, the General Studies program,\nand the School of Languages, Cultures, and Race,\nat https://slcr.wsu.edu/.\nHUMANITIES - RELIGIOUS STUDIES\nMAJOR\n(120 HOURS)\nM. W. Myers, Coordinator\nThe BA in Humanities - Religious Studies major is\na cross-disciplinary program designed for students\nwho wish to develop an understanding of the nature\nof religion and its role in individual and social life.\nThe program enables students to analyze critically\nand evaluate western and non-western religions\nwithout a predisposition to defend or reject the\nclaims of any particular faith. The program offers\nboth a major and a minor; it is preparatory for\ncareers and future study in international affairs,\narts, humanities, social sciences, and intercultural\nstudies. Students who major in religious studies will\nearn a Bachelor of Arts in Humanities degree.\nStudents are admitted to the BA in Humanities\n– Religious Studies major upon making their\nintentions known to the School of Languages,\nCultures, and Race.\nA student may earn a major in Religious Studies\nby completing 39 credits of work from among\nthe designated courses in the several departments\ninvolved. Of these 39 credits, 12 must consist of\nthe core courses specified below for all majors.\nFurther courses are specified as required or elective\ndepending on the student’s focus: western religions,\nnon-western religions, or comparative religions.\nThere is also a language requirement.\nA student must also satisfy the UCORE\nand College of Arts and Sciences graduation\nrequirements and take at least 40 of the total\n120 credits in 300-400-level courses. For a minor\nin Religious Studies, a student must take at least\n18 credits of work, including the core (minus the\nSeminar in Religious Studies) and three courses from\nthe required list of comparative religion. Religious\nStudies also makes an ideal second major.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nForeign Language\n2 \n4\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nForeign Language \n2 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHUM 103 [HUM] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language or Elective\n2 \n4\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nForeign Language or Elective\n2 \n4\nPHIL 207 3\nElective Core\n3 \n3\nElectives 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\n--------------------------------------------------------\nTHIRD and FOURTH Years [See “OPTIONS”\nbelow] 60\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nStudents with two years high school foreign\nlanguage are required to complete 2 additional\nsemesters. Students without high school foreign\nlanguage are required to complete 4 semesters.\n3 \nElective Core courses: FOR LANG 102, HUMANITY\n101, or HUMANITY 335.\nOPTIONS\nThird and Fourth Years — Students must\ncomplete one of the following options. Options\n\n269\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nand Elective coursework must reflect University\nrequirements of 120 total credits, 40 credits of\n300-400-level coursework, two [M] courses, and a\n[CAPS] course.\nWestern Religions: HISTORY 272, 445, PHIL\n407, and seven courses from: ANTH 330, ENGLISH\n305, 306, 485, FINE ART 201, 202, HISTORY 341,\n423, 440, 441, HUMANITY 101, 302 [M], PHIL 320,\n322, 413, 420, or 446.\nNon-Western Religions: HISTORY 273, PHIL\n314 [M], 315 [M], 407, and six courses from: ANTH\n303, 330, FINE ART 201, 202, 302 [M], HISTORY\n270, 275, 308, 370, 373, 374, 472 [M], 473, or\nHUMANITY 350.\nComparative Religions: HISTORY 273, 407,\n445, PHIL 314 [M], 315 [M], and five courses from:\nANTH 303, ENGLISH 305, 306, 483, 485, FINE ART\n201, 202, 302 [M]; HISTORY 308, 341, 370, 373, 374,\n440, 441, 472 [M], 473, or HUMANITY 350.\nJAPANESE\n(120 HOURS)\nA minimum of 34 credits beyond the 203 level (or\nthe equivalent level in competence) in the major\nlanguage is required for a Bachelor of Arts degree\nin Foreign Languages and Cultures. 101, 102, and\n203 do not count toward the major. However, no course\nin which a C- or lower grade is earned will be\ncounted toward the major. 300-400-level courses\ntaken pass, fail may not be included for credit\ntoward the major. No course may be repeated for\ncredit toward the major unless thus designated in\nthe catalog. No course may count for both the major\nand the minor.\nMajors and prospective majors are strongly\nencouraged to spend at least one semester abroad,\nliving in the target culture and enhancing their\nfluency.
