The University requires a minimum of 40\ncredits of 300-400-level coursework.\nSOCIAL SCIENCES MAJOR - PERSONNEL\nPSYCHOLOGY/HUMAN RESOURCES\nOPTION (VANCOUVER-ONLY)\n(120 HOURS)\nThe Personnel Psychology/Human Resources (PP/\nHR) option for the BA in Social Sciences - Social\nSciences major is designed to provide human\nresource professionals, and those preparing for a\ncareer in human resources, the tools to be effective\nmanagers. 120 credit hours are required, including\ncompletion of WSU UCORE requirements, CAS\nrequirements, and a combination of social sciences\ncourses totaling 40 upper-division hours from three\nacademic areas (psychology, human development,\nand management). The GPA for the 40 hours\nmust be a 2.00 minimum. Students declare the\nGeneral Social Sciences major (Gen S) and receive a\nBachelor of Arts in Social Sciences with an Option\nin Personnel Psychology/Human Resources.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nPSYCH 306 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, and/or\nElectives 12\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nPSYCH 308 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, and/or\nElectives 6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\n\n270\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nH D 406 3\nMGMT 301 3\nPSYCH 311 4\nArea 1 Electives \n2 \n3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArea 1 Electives \n2 \n3\nArea 2 Electives \n3 \n3\nArea 3 Electives \n4 \n3\nElectives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArea 1 Electives \n2 \n3\nArea 2 Electives \n3 \n3\nArea 3 Electives \n4 \n3\nElectives 6\nSecond Term Hours\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nArea 3 Electives \n4 \n3\nElectives 9\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nArea 1 electives: PSYCH 309, 350, 412, 470, or 495.\n3 \nArea 2 electives: H D 301, 350, 385, 403, or 430.\n4 \nArea 3 electives: I BUS 453 [M], MGMT 401 [M],\n450, 455, 456 [M], 485 [M], 487, 496. Must include\ntwo [M] courses.\nSOCIAL SCIENCES OR HUMANITIES MAJOR\n- PLAN A OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA. Chow, Coordinator\nThis division of general studies is for students whose\nprimary interest in the humanities or social sciences\nrequires programs and course selections which\nare not possible within single academic units or\nestablished curricula. Students who wish to earn a\nBachelor of Arts in Humanities or a Bachelor of Arts\nin Social Sciences will devise an approved, coherent\nprogram of study which fulfills an academic or\ncareer goal and includes prerequisites consistent\nwith the 300-400-level course work. In addition,\neach student will satisfy the UCOREs and any\nadditional requirements of the College of Arts and\nSciences.\nStudents are admitted to the General Humanities\nmajor (Gen H) or General Social Sciences major\n(Gen S) upon making their intentions known to\nthe School of Languages, Cultures, and Race.\nPlan A—Primary/Secondary Concentration\nPrimary concentration: a minimum of 24 credits,\nincluding at least 15 300-400-level credits, must be\ncompleted in a single humanities or social sciences\ndepartment or published program with a minimum\n2.00 primary concentration GPA. The degree (Gen H\nor Gen S) will depend on the primary concentration.\nSecondary concentration: a minimum of\n15 credits, including at least 6 300-400-level\ncredits, must be completed in another academic\ndepartment, program or area published in the\ncatalog with a minimum 2.00 GPA.\nPer Academic Regulation 54, students may not\nbe admitted in or awarded an additional major\nor minor if it carries the same name as one of\nthe areas of study or options, concentrations or\nsub-plans within a major. In addition, students\npursuing a Business major or minor may not also\nbe admitted in an option, concentration or subplan\nof Administrative Studies.\nFor a list of approved Plan A areas, please contact\nthe Liberal Arts General Studies office.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, or Elective 3 or 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nPrimary Concentration 3\nSecondary Concentration 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, and/or Elective 6\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nPrimary Concentration 3\nSecondary Concentration 3\nElectives 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400-level Primary Concentration\n2 \n3\nPrimary Concentration 3\nSecondary Concentration 3\nElectives 6\nSecond Term Hours\n300-400-level Primary Concentration\n2 \n3\n300-400-level Secondary Concentration\n2 \n3\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nElectives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400-level Primary Concentration\n2 \n6\n300-400-level Secondary Concentration\n2 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\n300-400-level Primary Concentration\n2 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n12\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nStudents must take a total of 40 credits of upper-\ndivision (300-400 level). 21 upper-division credits\nmust be taken within the designated concentration\nareas. The UCORE requirements include 3 upper-\ndivision credits. The remaining 16 credits may be\ntaken in the electives, the UCOREs, or by electing\nto take more than the minimum required in the\nareas. Among the 300-400 level course work in the\nareas, two courses, each at 3 credits, must have a\n[M] designation. Only 6 credits of internship or\nP, F credits are allowed to count towards major\nrequirements.\nSOCIAL SCIENCES OR HUMANITIES MAJOR\n- PLAN B OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA. Chow, Coordinator\nHumanities: A combination of humanities courses\ntotaling at least 39 credits involving three academic\nareas with a minimum of 9 credits in each of the\nthree areas. At least 21 of the 39 credits must be at\nthe 300-400-level and the GPA for the 39 credits\nmust be a 2.0 minimum. Students are admitted\nto the General Humanities major (Gen H) upon\nmaking their intentions known to the School\nof Languages, Cultures, and Race, and receive a\nBachelor of Arts in Humanities.\nSocial Sciences: A combination of social sciences\ncourses totaling at least 39 credits involving three\nacademic areas with a minimum of 9 credits in\neach of the three areas. At least 21 of the 39 credits\nmust be at the 300-400-level and the GPA for the\n39 credits must be a 2.0 minimum. Students are\nadmitted to the General Social Sciences major\n(Gen S) upon making their intentions known to\nthe School of Languages, Cultures, and Race, and\nreceive a Bachelor of Arts in Social Sciences.\nPer Academic Regulation 54, students may not\nbe admitted in or awarded an additional major\nor minor if it carries the same name as one of\nthe areas of study or options, concentrations or\nsub-plans within a major. In addition, students\npursuing a Business major or minor may not also\nbe admitted in an option, concentration or subplan\nof Administrative Studies.\nFor a list of approved Plan B areas, please contact\nthe Liberal Arts General Studies office.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArea 1 3\nArea 2 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, and/or\nElectives 7\n\n271\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nSecond Term Hours\nArea 1 3\nArea 3 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, and/or\nElectives 6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400-level Area 1\n2 \n3\nArea 2 3\nArea 3 3\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\n300-400-level Area 2\n2 \n3\n300-400-level Area 3\n2 \n3\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nElectives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400 Any Area\n2 \n9\nElectives\n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\n300-400 Any Area\n2 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n12\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nStudents must take a total of 40 credits of upper-\ndivision (300-400 level). 21 upper-division credits\nmust be taken within the designated concentration\nareas. The UCORE requirements include 3 upper-\ndivision credits. The remaining 16 credits may be\ntaken in the electives, the UCOREs, or by electing\nto take more than the minimum required in the\nareas. Among the 300-400 level course work in the\nareas, two courses, each at 3 credits, must have a\n[M] designation. Only 6 credits of internship or\nP, F credits are allowed to count towards major\nrequirements.\nSPANISH\n(120 HOURS)\nA minimum of 34 credits beyond the 203 level (or\nthe equivalent level in competence) in the major\nlanguage is required for a Bachelor of Arts degree\nin Foreign Languages and Cultures. SPANISH\n101, 102, and 203 do not count toward the major.\nStudents who place into 102 and receive a B or\nbetter qualify for an additional 4 departmental\nadvanced placement credits; students placing into\n203 or above and receiving a B or better qualify\nfor 8 departmental advanced placement credits. A\nmaximum of 8 departmental AP credits is possible.\nSee school for details.\nMajors must complete either a minor in a second\nforeign language, a concentration of at least 16\ncredits in a related field, or a second major.\nStudents are admitted to the Spanish major upon\nmaking their intentions known to the School of\nLanguages, Cultures and Race. However, no course\nin which a C- or lower grade is earned will be\ncounted toward the major. 300-400-level courses\ntaken pass, fail may not be included for credit\ntoward the major. No course may be repeated for\ncredit toward the major unless thus designated in\nthe catalog. No course may count for both the\nmajor and the minor.\nMajors and prospective majors are strongly\nencouraged to spend at least one semester abroad,\nliving in the target culture and enhancing their\nfluency. Many accredited study abroad programs are\navailable; students should work with their advisers\nin the selection of a program.\nOf the 34 credits required for the major, a\nminimum of 15 must be taken in residence with 6\nof these credits at the 400 level. A maximum of 12\ncredits per semester or 18 credits per year earned in\na study abroad program may be applied toward the\nmajor. Credits for SPANISH 105, 205, 305, and 405\nmay not be applied toward the major.\nAll majors must complete an exit proficiency\nexamination during the semester in which they\ncomplete the last language course of their major.\nThere is a fee charged for the exam.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nFOR LANG 101, 110, 120, 130, or 220 3\nMATH 103 (if needed) or Electives\n1 HOURS)\nStudents who wish to earn a teaching credential\nmust apply to the Teacher Preparation Program\nin the College of Education. They should consult\nwith an advisor in Teaching and Learning regarding\nthe education requirements and with an advisor in\nSPANISH regarding the Spanish requirements.\nTo be admitted to the Spanish Teaching option, a\nstudent must have earned at least a 2.50 cumulative\nGPA. A grade of C or better is required in all SPANISH\ncourses to fulfill the requirement of this degree.\nSPANISH 101 and 102 do not count toward the\nmajor, but students must complete these courses or\nshow equivalent proficiency to enroll in SPANISH\n203.\nDepartmental advance placement credits:\nStudents who place into 102 and receive a B or\nbetter qualify for an additional 4 departmental\nadvanced placement credits; students placing into\n203 or above and receiving a B or better qualify\nfor 8 departmental advanced placement credits. A\nmaximum of 8 departmental AP credits is possible.\nSee school for details.\nNo course in which a C- or lower grade is earned\nwill be counted toward the major. 300-400-level\ncourses taken pass, fail may not be included for\ncredit toward the major. No course may be repeated\nfor credit toward the major unless thus designated\nin the catalog. No course may count for both the\nmajor and the minor.\nTeaching majors are strongly encouraged to spend\nat least a summer abroad, living in the target culture\nand enhancing their fluency. Many accredited study\nabroad programs are available. Students should work\nwith their advisors in the selection of a program or if\nwanting to consider alternate options to the study\nabroad requirement.\n\n272\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nOf the 35 SPANISH credits required for the\nteaching major, a minimum of 15 must be taken\nin residence at WSU with 6 of these credits at the\n400 level. A maximum of 12 credits per semester\nor 18 credits per academic or calendar year earned\nin a study abroad program may be applied toward\nthe teaching major. Credits for SPANISH 105, 205,\n305, and 405 may not be applied toward the major.\nAll teaching majors must complete an exit\nproficiency examination during the semester in\nwhich they complete the last language course of\ntheir major. There is a fee charged for the exam.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nFOR LANG 101 [DIVR] or 110 [DIVR] 3\nSPANISH 120 [HUM] 3\nSPANISH 203\n1 \n4\nSPANISH 205 or Elective\n2 \n1\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 201 [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSPANISH 204 4\nSPANISH 205 or Elective\n2 \n1\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSPANISH 306 3\nSPANISH 308 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nSPANISH 307 3\nSPANISH Film/Literature/Culture Elective\n4 \n3\nTCH LRN 301 3\nApply for certification into the\nSecondary Teacher Certificate Program\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Term Hours\nTCH LRN 317 Initial Practicum Experience\n(Summer) 2\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nFOR LANG 440 3\nSPANISH 407 or 408 [M] 3\nSPANISH 450 [M], 451 [M], 452 [M], or\n453 [M] 3\nSPANISH Film/Literature/Culture Elective\n4 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nSPANISH 407 or 408 [M] 3\nSPANISH 450 [M], 451 [M], 452 [M], or\n453 [M] 3\nTCH LRN 464 3\nTCH LRN 465 3\nTCH LRN 466 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nED PSYCH 468 3\nSPANISH 420 [CAPS] or FOR LANG 410 [CAPS] 3\nTCH LRN 467 3\nTCH LRN 469 3\nTCH LRN 470 3\nComplete FL proficiency Exit Exam\nPass Designated World Language WEST-E and\nAmerican Council on the Teaching of Foreign\nLanguages (ACTFL) at the advance-low level\nSecond Term Hours\nTCH LRN 415 Student Teaching 16\n_______\n1 \nStudent must meet proficiency requirement to\nenroll in SPANISH 203.\n2 \nSPANISH 205 is not required for degree. Students\nwho do not take SPANISH 205 may need elective\ncredits to meet University graduation requirement\nof 120 credits.\n3 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n4 \nSPANISH Film/Literature/Culture Electives:\nApproved courses include SPANISH 310, 311,\n320, 321, 350, 351, 361, 362, 363, 364, 365, or as\napproved by advisor.\nAdditional Majors\nAdditional Major – French for the\nProfessions\nStudents who are admitted in a major may seek an\nadditional major in French for the Professions. This\nadditional major does not lead to a degree. The\nadditional major requires 38 credits, as follows: 1)\nLanguage Foundation (14 credits) -- FRENCH\n101, 102, 203, and 261. Note that most students\nentering WSU will have already fulfilled the\nequivalent of the 101 and 102 courses, if they\nchoose to pursue the same foreign language for\nthis major; 2) Intermediate Language (6 credits)\n-- Two courses from FRENCH 306, 307, or 308; 3)\nLanguage for Specific Purposes (6 credits) -- FRENCH\n320 [HUM] and 361 [COMM]; and 4) Upper-level\nExperience (12 credits) -- FRENCH 420 [CAPS];\ntwo Writing in the Major courses (see school);\nand FOR LANG 495, Internship / Service Learning\n/ Undergraduate Research / Study Abroad (for\n8 weeks minimum). No course in which a C- or\nlower grade is earned will be counted toward the\nadditional major. No course taken pass/fail may\nbe included for credit toward the major. No course\nmay be repeated for credit toward the major unless\nthus designated in the catalog. No course may count\nfor both the major and the minor. The STAMP 4S\n(Standards-based Measurement of Proficiency) web-\nbased assessment of foreign language proficiency in\nreading, writing, speaking, and listening and will be\ntaken during the semester in which the student is\ncompleting the final course for the major taught in\nthe target language.\nAdditional Major – German for\nthe Professions\nStudents who are admitted in a major may seek an\nadditional major in German for the Professions.\nThis additional major does not lead to a degree. The\nadditional major requires 39 credits, as follows: 1)\nLanguage Foundation (15 credits) -- GERMAN 101,\n102, 203, and 204. Note that most students entering\nWSU will have already fulfilled the equivalent\nof the 101 and 102 courses, if they choose to\npursue the same foreign language for this major;\n2) Intermediate Language (6 credits) -- GERMAN\n307 and 308; 3) Language for Specific Purposes (6\ncredits) -- GERMAN 320 and 361 [COMM]; and 4)\nUpper-level Experience (12 credits) -- GERMAN\n420 [CAPS]; two Writing in the Major courses (see\nschool); and FOR LANG 495, Internship / Service\nLearning / Undergraduate Research / Study Abroad\n(for 8 weeks minimum). No course in which a C- or\nlower grade is earned will be counted toward the\nadditional major. No course taken pass/fail may\nbe included for credit toward the major. No course\nmay be repeated for credit toward the major unless\nthus designated in the catalog. No course may count\nfor both the major and the minor. The STAMP 4S\n(Standards-based Measurement of Proficiency) web-\nbased assessment of foreign language proficiency in\nreading, writing, speaking, and listening and will be\ntaken during the semester in which the student is\ncompleting the final course for the major taught in\nthe target language.\nAdditional Major – Japanese for\nthe Professions\nStudents who are admitted in a major may seek an\nadditional major in Japanese for the Professions.\nThis additional major does not lead to a degree. The\nadditional major requires 37 credits, as follows: 1)\nLanguage Foundation (16 credits) -- JAPANESE 101,\n102, 203, and 204; 2) Intermediate Language (9\ncredits) -- JAPANESE 306, 307, and 308; 3) Language\nfor Specific Purposes (3 credits) -- JAPANESE 361;\n4) Lower-level Culture/Literature course taught in\nEnglish (3 credits) -- one from JAPANESE 111, 120,\n123, and 131; 5) Upper-level Culture/Literature\ncourses taught in English (6 credits) -- two from\nCHINESE 311, JAPANESE 320, JAPANESE 322, and\nASIA 330; and 6) two Writing in the Major courses\n(see school). No course in which a C- or lower grade\nis earned will be counted toward the additional\nmajor. No course taken pass/fail may be included\nfor credit toward the major. No course may be\nrepeated for credit toward the major unless thus\ndesignated in the catalog. No course may count\nfor both the major and the minor. The STAMP 4S\n(Standards-based Measurement of Proficiency) web-\nbased assessment of foreign language proficiency in\nreading, writing, speaking, and listening and will be\ntaken during the semester in which the student is\ncompleting the final course for the major taught in\nthe target language.\nAdditional Major – Spanish for\nthe Professions\nStudents who are admitted in a major may seek an\nadditional major in Spanish for the Professions.\nThis additional major does not lead to a degree. The\nadditional major requires 38 credits, as follows: 1)\nLanguage Foundation (14 credits) -- SPANISH 101,\n102, 203, and 261. Note that most students entering\nWSU will have already fulfilled the equivalent of\nthe 101 and 102 courses, if they choose to pursue\nthe same foreign language for this major; 2)\nIntermediate Language (6 credits) -- Two courses\nfrom SPANISH 306, 307, or 308; 3) Language for\nSpecific Purposes (6 credits) -- SPANISH 320 or\n321 [DIVR]; and 361, 362, 363, 364, or 365; and\n4) Upper-level Experience (12 credits) -- Integrative\nCapstone [CAPS]; two Writing in the Major courses\n\n273\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\n(see school); and FOR LANG 495, Internship /\nService Learning / Undergraduate Research / Study\nAbroad (for 8 weeks minimum). No course in which\na C- or lower grade is earned will be counted toward\nthe additional major. No course taken pass/fail may\nbe included for credit toward the major. No course\nmay be repeated for credit toward the major unless\nthus designated in the catalog. No course may count\nfor both the major and the minor. The STAMP 4S\n(Standards-based Measurement of Proficiency) web-\nbased assessment of foreign language proficiency in\nreading, writing, speaking, and listening and will be\ntaken during the semester in which the student is\ncompleting the final course for the major taught in\nthe target language.\nMinors\nAmerican Indian Studies\nM. Holloman, Coordinator\nThe minor in American Indian Studies requires 18\nsemester hours which shall include a required 9 hour\ncore (3 of the following 4 courses: ANTH 320, CES\n171, HISTORY 308, or HISTORY 410) and 9 hours\nof electives (ANTH 327, 331, 334, 535, CES 372,\n373, 379, 470, 475, FINE ART 301, HISTORY 410,\nor MUS 265). At least 9 of the credits must be taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses,\nand at least 9 hours must be at the 300-400 level.\nA minimum of 12 credits must be taken for a letter\ngrade and a minimum GPA of 2.00 is required in the\nminor coursework.\nChinese, French, German,\nJapanese, or Spanish\nTo fulfill requirements for a minor in Chinese,\nFrench, German, Japanese, or Spanish, a student\nmust complete a minimum of 17 credits of course\nwork in one language area. A foundation of the\ntarget language, 203 and 204 (8 credits), is required.\nThe remaining 9 credits must be 300-400-level\ncourse work in the target language, of which 3\ncredits must be taken in residence at WSU, while\nthe remaining 6 credits must be taken either in\nresidence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad, educational exchange courses,\nor equivalent transfer coursework. All courses must\nbe passed with a grade of C or better. Only courses\nthus designated in the Catalog may be repeated for\ncredit toward the minor. Courses counting towards\na minor in the language may not be counted\ntowards a major in International Area Studies (i.e.,\nAsian Studies, Latin America Area Studies, German\nArea Studies, or French and Francophone Area\nStudies). 105, 205, 305, 405 may not count towards\nthe minor. For courses taken in Study Abroad\nPrograms or as other transfer credits, please check\nwith your advisor. All Chinese, French, German,\nJapanese, and Spanish language minors must also\ncomplete an exit proficiency examination interview\nduring the semester in which they complete the\nlast language course of their minor. There is a fee\ncharged for the exam\nComparative Ethnic Studies\nFor the minor in Comparative Ethnic Studies (CES),\nstudents must complete either CES 101 or 201, as\nwell as an additional 15 hours of coursework in\nCES, nine hours of which must be 300-400 level\ncourses taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses.\nFilm Studies\nAna M. Rodriguez-Vivaldi, (Faculty Coordinator) and\nL. Heustis (Advisor)\nhttps://forlang.wsu.edu/academics/film-studies/\n509-335-4136\nThe Film Studies Minor introduces students to\nthe critical study of cinema and media studies. It\nexplores how cinema both reflects and influences\nthe facts, ideas, and activities of any given society,\nand how film allows us to travel to most places\nin the world and become familiar with diverse\ncultures, traditions, and ways of thinking. The\nfilm studies minor also teaches students how to\ndiscern the cinematic and narrative features that\nare used in cinematography and how culture can\ninfluence them. The study of film encourages critical\nthinking, respect for cultural diversity, and detailed\nknowledge of film as a text of facts and ideas.\nThe minor’s program of studies is designed by the\nstudent in collaboration with the coordinator and /\nor the advisor. A minimum of 18 credits is required\nand must include 9 hours of upper-division work\ntaken in residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\n9 credits must be chosen from COM 471, ENGLISH\n150, 339, FOR LANG 110, 410, MUS 266, PHIL 210,\nand SOC 372 or 373. An additional 9 elective credits\ngeared toward social, cultural, or applied skills are\nrequired. Approved courses include CES 222, 338, 358\n[M], 379, CHINESE/ASIA/JAPANESE 111, CHINESE\n311 [M], COM 210, COMJOUR 360, 390, 466, CRM\nJ/POL S 381, DTC 335, 338, DTC/ENGLISH 336, 354,\n355, DTC/AMER ST/ENGLISH 475, ENGLISH 205,\n316, 340, 342, ENGLISH/FINE ART 337, FINE ART\n333, 363, 380, 381, 385, 434, 435, FRENCH 110, 310,\n410, GERMAN 110, 310, HISTORY 400, MUS 162,\nRUSSIAN 410, SOC 373, SPANISH 110, 111, 310,\n311, and WOMEN ST 340. No more than two courses\nwith the same subject (or content, as in cross-listed\ncourses) may be applied towards the minor. All core\ncourses must be taken at WSU. After consultation with\nthe film studies coordinator or advisor, two elective\ncourses may be transferred to the film studies minor\nfrom accredited study abroad and other university/\ncollege programs. A maximum of 3 internship credits\nmay count towards the minor’s electives.\nLearning Goals\n• To enhance knowledge of the history and practice\nof film production\n• To analyze the nature, history, and function of\nfilm in an interdisciplinary manner that broadens\nand enhances critical thought\n• To enhance the perception of and respect for the\ndiversity of cultures in this country and around the\nworld as exposed through this medium\n• To enhance technical understanding of how film\nand related-media work\n• To enhance understanding of the societal and\ncultural roles and impact of film and other media\n• To enhance media literacy skills\nFrench Area and Culture Studies\nA minimum of 16 credits is required (options in\nFrench or Francophone Studies). A foundation\nof the target language, French 203 (4 credits), is\nrequired; in addition, 4 courses (12 credits) of\nfurther knowledge must be taken other than 203\nas: EITHER one lower level and two upper-level\ncourses in FLC plus one approved course in another\ndepartment; OR one lower-level and one upper-level\ncourse in FLC plus two approved courses in another\ndepartment. See the school for a list of acceptable\ncourses. For special requirements concerning\nFrench and Francophone options in the French\nArea Studies Minor, please see your advisor. A\nminimum of 9 credits with a letter grade must be\ntaken in residency at WSU at the 300-400 level. All\ncourses must be passed with a grade of C or better.\nOnly courses thus designated in the Catalog may\nbe repeated for credit toward the minor. Courses\ncounting towards a minor in the language may not\nbe counted towards a major in International Area\nStudies (i.e., Latin America Area Studies, German\nArea Studies, French and Francophone Area Studies,\nor Russian Area Studies). 105, 205, and 305 may\nnot count towards the minor. For courses taken in\nStudy Abroad Programs or as other transfer credits,\nplease check with your advisor.\nFrench for Design and\nMerchandising\nThe minor in French for Design and Merchandising\nrequires a minimum of 16 credits, 9 of which must\nbe in 300-400-level courses taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. Required courses\nfor the foundation of the target language include\nFRENCH 203 and FRENCH 204 or 261 (7-8 credits).\nAn additional 3 courses (9 credits) must be selected\nfrom the following: FRENCH 361, FRENCH 362,\nand FRENCH 306 or FRENCH 320, or equivalent\n(if taken abroad). All courses must be passed with\na grade of C or better. Courses counting towards\nthis minor may not be counted toward a major\nin International Area Studies (i.e., French and\nFrancophone Area Studies). FRENCH 105, 205,\nand 305 may not count towards this minor. For\ncourses/course equivalencies taken in Study Abroad\nPrograms or as other transfer credits, please check\nwith your advisor. An exit proficiency examination\nis required and will be taken during the semester\nin which the student is completing the final target\nlanguage course for the semester.\nGerman Area and Culture Studies\nA minimum of 16 credits is required. A foundation\nof the target language, GERMAN 203 (4 credits),\nis required; in addition, 4 courses (12 credits) of\nfurther knowledge must be taken other than 203\nas: EITHER one lower level and two upper-level\ncourses in FLC plus one approved course in another\ndepartment; OR one lower-level and one upper-level\ncourse in FLC plus two approved courses in another\ndepartment. See the school for a list of acceptable\ncourses. A minimum of 9 credits with a letter grade\nmust be taken in residency at WSU at the 300-400\nlevel. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or\nbetter. Only courses thus designated in the Catalog\nmay be repeated for credit toward the minor. Courses\ncounting towards a minor in the language may not\nbe counted towards a major in International Area\nStudies (i.e., Latin America Area Studies, German\nArea Studies, French and Francophone Area Studies,\nor Russian Area Studies). 105, 205, and 305 may\n\n274\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\nnot count towards the minor. For courses taken in\nStudy Abroad Programs or as other transfer credits,\nplease check with your advisor.\nGlobal and Ethnic Narrative\nTraditions\nA systematic approach to the study of a variety\nof regional myths, and global, ethnic, and racial\nnarrative traditions in their original context as\nwell as in more contemporary reinterpretations\nthrough literature and film and other cultural\narenas, with the aim to challenge and resituate\ndominant views about race and ethnicity, gender,\nsocial classes, and different political practices. When\nwe consider how contemporary writers, filmmakers,\npoets, playwrights, painters, music composers,\nand other cultural producers use the forms and\nelements of these storytelling practices we can more\neffectively analyze how these narratives have the\npower to articulate political ideas as well as social\nand cultural transformations. In this manner, the\nprogram develops our students’ critical thinking\nand encourages them to re-interpret the place of the\nself as an identity culturally situated. Narratives to\nbe studied address specific topics related to gender\n(representations of women, men, homosexuality,\netc.), age (representations of childhood, youth,\nthe elderly, etc.), history (representations of war,\nrevolutions, dictatorships, democratization, etc.),\nculture and society (gendered roles, race, nature,\nreligion, social classes, immigration, etc.), to\nmention a few.\nCompletion of the minor requires 18 credits\nincluding a required core (6 credits) and 12 credits of\nelectives. At least 9 credits of approved coursework\nmust be taken at the 300-400 level. No courses\ntaken Pass/Fail will count towards the 18-credit\nrequirement.\nRequired courses (6 credits): Two course from CES/\nENGLISH 220 or FOR LANG 130; FOR LANG 110 or\n410; FOR LANG 120.\nElective courses (12 credits): Four courses from\nthree categories below.\nCategory 1 - Literature and Mythology, 2 courses\nfrom: ASIA/CHINESE/JAPANESE 131, CES 313/\nENGLISH 311, CES/ENGLISH 314, CES 331/\nENGLISH 321, CES 332/ENGLISH 322, CES 353/\nENGLISH 345, CES 373/ENGLISH 341, FOR LANG\n370, 371, 373, one from FRENCH 350 or 430, one\nfrom GERMAN 350 or 450 or 451 or 452, one from\nSPANISH 350 or 351 or 430 or 450 or 451 or 452.\nCategory 2 - Culture and Film, one course from:\nASIA/CHINESE/JAPANESE 111, ASIA/CHINESE 330,\nASIA/JAPANESE 122, 123, CES 254, CHINESE 120,\n121, 311, FRENCH 110, 120, 310, 320, 410, 420,\nGERMAN 110, 120, 310, 320, SPANISH 110, 111,\n120, 121, 310, 311, 320, 321, 420.\nCategory 3 - History and Society, one course from:\nCES 111, 131, 151, 171, 255, CES 211/HISTORY 201,\nCES/HISTORY 235.\n15 of the credits must be taken at WSU. A grade\nof C or better must be earned in each of the courses\napplied to the minor. No course may be repeated\nfor credit. No more than 6 credits may apply toward\ncompletion of a different minor. Other courses\nmay be added to the list of acceptable electives. To\ndiscuss any course equivalencies, please contact the\nminor coordinator.\nGlobal Studies\nA. M. Rodriguez-Vivaldi, (Faculty Coordinator) and L.\nHeustis (Advisor)\nhttp://libarts.wsu.edu/genstudies/\n509-335-0397\nGlobal studies examine economic, political, social,\ncultural, and scientific practices in a transnational and\ncross-cultural perspective. The Global Studies minor\nis designed to provide students with an integrated\nexposure to globally related scholarship across the\ndisciplines, and encourages a student in any major\ndiscipline to think in terms of the globalization that\nmarks the contemporary world. The program of study\nis designed to provide an exciting interdisciplinary\nglobal perspective on the arts, humanities, social\nsciences, and sciences. The minor is flexible and\ncomplements majors from across the University,\naffording students the opportunity to reach beyond\ntheir majors, or to take courses related to their majors\noutside of the context of the United States.\nIn order to be admitted to the minor, students\nmust have completed at least 60 credits with a 2.0\nGPA or above. To earn the minor, students must\ncomplete a minimum of 18-19 credits:1 core course\nin each student learning outcome category (12-13\ncredits), and 2 course electives (6 credits) in any of the\nthematic categories listed in the program of studies,\nbut targeting two different learning outcomes. At\nleast 9 credits of approved coursework must be taken\nat the 300-400 level, and no courses taken Pass/Fail\nwill count towards the 18-19 credit requirement. Six\ncredits of approved transfer work may be counted\ntowards the minor; the remaining 12-13 credits\nmust be taken in residence at WSU or through WSU-\napproved education abroad or educational exchange\ncourses. No more than two courses with the same\nsubject (or content, as in cross-listed courses) can\nbe applied to the minor. Some courses may be\nsubstituted with the approval of the Global Studies\nMinor advisor. Additional courses may be included\nwithin the minor as developed in the university\ncurriculum.\nStudent Learning Outcomes: The minor\ngives students a competitive edge in the global job\nmarket. Students earning the minor will be prepared\nto 1) understand connections that can be made from\nhistorical, cultural, economic, and political contexts\nthat shape society and reflect global systems; 2)\ndemonstrate knowledge of and be sensitive to\nothers’ differing identities and values across cultures;\n3) apply intercultural communication skills to\ninteract effectively with individuals and in groups;\nand 4) interact respectfully and responsibly across\nboundaries in diverse environments.\nProgram of Studies:\nCore Courses: Choose one from ANTH 203,\nCES 244, ECONS 101, 198, POL S 103, or SOC 415.\nChoose one from ANTH 316, FINE ART 202, or POL\nS 428. Choose one from: COM 105, COMSOC 321,\nor FOR LANG 120. PLUS, complete one semester of\nforeign language study at WSU beyond the WSU\nadmissions requirement. Foreign language courses\ntaken at WSU to fulfill the admissions requirement\nare not eligible to be applied to the minor.\nElectives: Six credits required. Choose two courses\ntargeting two different learning outcomes (SLOs):\nSLO 1 Connections among contexts: ANTH 260,\nCES 380, CROP SCI 360, ENGLISH 373, FINE ART\n301, HISTORY 494 or 495 or approved upper-level\nWorld History course, HONORS 370, 380, 390, I BUS\n380 or 470, POL S 429, SOC 334 or 430, SOE 390.\nSLO 2 Knowledge about identities and values:\nANTH 301 or 404, BIOLOGY 407, ENTOM 150, FOR\nLANG 110, HUMANITY 350, MUS 163 or 265, POL\nS 435, SOE 110.\nSLO 3 Communication skills: Additional semester\nof same foreign language as used for the Core\nrequirement or additional foreign language course\ntaught in the foreign language at WSU.\nSLO 4 Respectful interaction: ANTH 418, BIOLOGY\n110, COMSOC 421, HISTORY 491, SOE 312.\nLatin American and Spanish Area\nStudies\nA minimum of 16 credits is required. A foundation\nof the target language, SPANISH 203 (4 credits),\nis required; in addition, 4 courses (12 credits) of\nfurther knowledge must be taken other than 203\nas: EITHER one lower level and two upper-level\ncourses in FLC plus one approved course in another\ndepartment; OR one lower-level and one upper-level\ncourse in FLC plus two approved courses in another\ndepartment. See the school for a list of acceptable\ncourses. A minimum of 9 credits with a letter grade\nmust be taken in residency at WSU at the 300-400\nlevel. All courses must be passed with a grade of C or\nbetter. Only courses thus designated in the Catalog\nmay be repeated for credit toward the minor. Courses\ncounting towards a minor in the language may not\nbe counted towards a major in International Area\nStudies (i.e., Latin America Area Studies, German\nArea Studies, French and Francophone Area Studies,\nor Russian Area Studies). 105, 205, and 305 may not\ncount towards the minor. For courses taken in Study\nAbroad Programs or as other transfer credits, please\ncheck with your advisor.\nPopular Culture\nFor the minor in Popular Culture students must\ncomplete a minimum of 21 credit hours, 9 of which\nmust be upper-division course work and taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nRequired core courses (12 credit hours): AMER ST\n216, CES 101 or 201, 260, and 325. Electives (9\ncredit hours): AMER ST 475, CES 209, 222, 308, 336,\n338, 357, 358, 379, or 413.\nReligious Studies\nM. Myers, Coordinator\nFor a minor in religious studies, a student must\ntake at least 18 semester hours of work, of which at\nleast half must be 300-400-level taken in residence\nat WSU or through WSU-approved education\nabroad or educational exchange courses. The minor\nincludes the core (minus the Seminar in Religious\nStudies) and three courses from the required list of\ncomparative religion.\nCertificates\nAmerican Indian Studies\nMichael. Holloman, Coordinator.\nThe certificate in American Indian Studies requires\n18 semester hours which shall include a required\ncore (9 hours) and 9 hours of electives. 15 of the\n\n275\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\ncredits must be taken at WSU, and 9 hours must\nbe at the 300-400-level. A minimum of 12 credits\nmust be taken for a letter grade and a grade of C\nor better must be earned in each of the required\nand recommended courses in order to qualify for\nthe certificate. Any currently enrolled degree-\nseeking student is eligible to enroll in the certificate\nprogram. Other students must meet the existing\nadmissions standards for non-degree seeking\nstudents. The university undergraduate certificate\nfee will apply. Students must complete 3 of the\nfollowing 4 courses: ANTH 320, CES 171, HISTORY\n308, or HISTORY 410. The remaining 9 hours are\nchosen from the following elective courses: ANTH\n327, 331, 334, 535, CES 372, 373, 379, 470, 475,\nFINE ART 301, HISTORY 410, or MUS 265. Other\ncourses in American Indian studies may be added\nto the elective pool as they become available.\nContact Michael Holloman, coordinator, for more\ninformation.\nCore Competencies in Spanish\nLanguage and Culture\nWSU’s online Core Competencies in Spanish\nLanguage and Culture certificate program is the\nstudy of Spanish language and culture from the\nnovice through intermediate language level.\nThe Spanish-speaking world is a diverse cultural\nlandscape covering nationalities from Europe,\nthe Caribbean, Central America, South America,\nand beyond and is very valuable in today’s global\neconomy.\nThe program leverages ever-expanding technol-\nogy in online learning developed by one of the\nleading textbook publishers in the discipline.\nThe certificate program can be its own stand-alone\nprogram or it can allow students entry into a Span-\nish minor or major at WSU. Core Competencies is\nperfect for businesses or individuals with the need\nto learn the Spanish language and to gain insight\ninto Hispanic cultures. The University undergradu-\nate certificate fee will apply.\nRequired Courses: Spanish 101, Spanish\n102, Spanish 203, Spanish 204 (16 total credits).\nStudents must pass all classes with a C or better.\nProficiency Exam Requirement\nStudents who earn this certificate are also required\nto take an exit proficiency exam at the end of the\nacademic term in which they complete the last\ncourse of the certificate. Students must pass the\nSTAMP exam at the intermediate level in order to\nearn the certificate. This exam requires a fee.\nItalian Language Certificate\nThe Italian Language Certificate comprises four\nin-depth courses of basic communication skills in\nItalian by developing competency in basic to low-\nintermediate skills of speaking, listening, reading,\nwriting, and culture. To earn this certificate, students\nmust complete a total of 16 hours by taking each\nof these courses: ITALIAN 101, 102, 203, and 204.\nThis certificate is designed for non-native speakers\nof Italian and is offered at the level of attaining a\nbasic expertise and knowledge in Italian language\nskills and culture.\nNo more than 4 hours earned at other institutions\nmay apply towards the certificate and no more than\n4 hours may be pass/fail. Courses earned at another\ninstitution or by AP credit will be determined by\nthe school regarding course equivalencies and\nallowance in the certificate. All courses must be\nearned with a grade of C or better. The University\nundergraduate certificate fee will apply.\nProficiency Exam Requirement\nStudents who earn this certificate are also required\nto take an exit proficiency exam at the end of the\nacademic term in which they complete the last\ncourse of the certificate. Students must pass the\nSTAMP exam at the intermediate level in order to\nearn the certificate. This exam requires a fee.\nDescription of Courses\nAMERICAN STUDIES\nAMER ST\n216 Introduction to American Cultural\nStudies 3 Introduction to the interdisciplinary\nstudy of American cultures and the field of\nAmerican studies. (Crosslisted course offered\nas AMER ST 216, CES 216, ENGLISH 216,\nHISTORY 216, WOMEN ST 216).\n471 Cultural Politics Since World War II 3\nAmerican popular culture, politics and culture\nof the 1960s, or topics in recent cultural\npolitics.\n472 E c o l o g i c a l I s s u e s a n d A m e r i c a n\nNature Writing 3 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. education.\n520 Colonization, Globalization and\nDecolonization 3 Topics in the critical study\nof colonialism, neo-colonialism, imperialism,\nglobalization and resistance to these forces.\n524 within and\nacross an array of identity categories.\n553 Latino/a and Latin American Literatures\nand Cultures 3 Autobiographies, journals,\nand memoirs of Latino/a authors as a means of\nexploring subtle indoctrination\nthrough popular culture.\n560 Critical Studies in Race and Popular\nCulture 3 Foundational and contemporary\ntexts in popular culture studies that address\nthe significance of race in our understanding\nand consumption of popular culture.\n580 Immigration and Citizenship 3 Current\nresearch around the historic, social, economic,\nand political conditions that have influenced\nthe flow of immigrants, their status as citizens,\nand their national/international identity.\n590 Seminar in American Studies 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 9\nhours. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CES 211, HISTORY 201).\n216 Introduction to American Cultural\nStudies 3 Introduction to the interdisciplinary\nstudy of American cultures and the field of\nAmerican studies. (Crosslisted course offered\nas AMER ST 216, CES 216, ENGLISH 216,\nHISTORY 216, WOMEN ST 216).\n220 [HUM] Introduction to Multicultural\nLiterature 3 Survey of multicultural literature\nincluding European American, African\nAmerican, Asian American, Chicana/o, and\nNative American authors. (Crosslisted course\noffered as CES 220, ENGLISH 220).\n222 Race in Sport Films 3 (2-2) Examination of\nracial politics through critical discussions of\nsport film.\n235 [HUM] African American History 3\nHistory of African Americans in the US with\nemphasis upon major themes of the Black\nexperience. (Crosslisted course offered as CES\n235, HISTORY 235).\n240 Global Indigenous Issues 3 Critical\nexamination of global indigenous politics in\na historical perspective.\n244 [SSCI] Critical Globalizations 3 Critical\nexamination of the historical trajectory and\ncontemporary practices, institutions and\npolicies that make up globalization.\n254 [SSCI] Comparative Latino/a Cultures\n3 Comparison of the contemporary and\nhistorical experiences of Latinos and Latinas\nin the United States, and their relations with\nother ethnic minority groups and the majority\npopulations.\n255 Latina/o Diasporic Communities in the\nU.S. 3 Exploration of historical movements,\nsettlement, and interactions within the United\nStates of different Latina/o groups.\n260 [HUM] Race and Racism in US Popular\nCulture 3 Examines images, ideologies,\nand identities; introduces key concepts and\nmethods; focuses on race, gender, sexuality\nand class.\n271 [HUM] Native Music of North America\n3 Music and ceremonialism as a reflection of\nrealities in North American native cultures,\npast and present. (Crosslisted course offered\nas MUS 265, CES 271).\n280 Race and the Law in American History 3\nIntroduction to the role of the law in American\nrace-relations since 1750. (Crosslisted course\noffered as CES 280, HISTORY 280).\n291 [DIVR] Anti-Semitism 3 Historical, social,\ntheological, and ideological dimensions of\nanti-Semitism.\n301 [M] Race and Global Inequality 3\nExamination of nationalism, colonization,\nempire-building, racism, ethnic conflict, and\nclass inequality in a global context.\n302 Social Psychology of Prejudice 3\nCauses and nature of prejudice from social,\npsychological, and cultural theoretical\nperspectives.\n308 [SSCI] Cultural Politics of Sport 3 A\ncritical examination of US sports through\nclass, race, gender, sexuality, nationalism and\ncriminality.\n313 [HUM] Asian Pacific American Literature\n3 Asian American fiction, drama, poetry, and\nother arts, 1900 to present; impact of Asian/\nPacific American culture and experience upon\nthese works. (Crosslisted course offered as CES\n313, ENGLISH 311).\n\n277\nLanguages, Cultures, and Race\nWashington State University, 2021\n314 [M] Topics in Asian Pacific American\nLiterature 3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 6 hours. Trends, themes,\nmajor writers. Trends and\nmajor writers. (Crosslisted course offered as\nENGLISH 322, CES 332).\n335 [SSCI] Black Freedom Struggle 3 Historic\nexploration of black resistance focusing\non nationwide movement that developed\nfollowing World War II. (Crosslisted course\noffered as CES 335, HISTORY 313).\n336 Black Popular Culture 3 Histories of African\nAmerican pop culture; examines how African\nAmerican cultural specificities emerge and\ntransform American popular imaginations.\n338 Cinematic Images of Blackness 3 Critical\nperspectives on the history of cinematic images\nof blackness; traces experiences of blacks\nwithin Hollywood as actor or artist, subject or\nimage.\n353 [M] Contemporary Latina/o Literatures\n3 Latina/o literature, narrative, novel,\nautobiography, poetry, short story, and\ndrama. (Crosslisted course offered as CES 353,\nENGLISH 345).\n357 Latinas/os and U.S. Popular Culture\n3 Examination of the participation and\nrepresentation of Latina/o bodies in different\naspects of U.S. popular culture.\n358 [M] US Latino/as in Film 3 (2-3) Critical\nanalysis of Latinas and Latinos in contemporary\nUS mainstream movies and independent films.\n359 Chicana/o and Latina/o Politics 3\nCharacter, role, and goals of Chicano/Latino\npolitics; contemporary Chicano/Latino issues.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CES 359, POL S\n375).\n372 Indigenous Women in Traditional\nand Contemporary Societies 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ANTH 101, 214, CES 101, or 171.\nExploration of roles and activities of women in\nindigenous societies; how traditional gender\nroles have developed and changed.\n373 [M] Native American Literature 3 Native\nAmerican literature, by and about the original\ninhabitants, image and counter-image, with\nemphasis on the 20th century. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CES 373, ENGLISH 341).\n379 Indigenous Film 3 Critical examination of\nfilms and videos featuring and by indigenous\npeoples; traces the history of the indigenous\npeoples as subjects of films and as filmmakers.\n380 Immigration and Citizenship in the\nGlobal Economy 3 Examination of past and\ncurrent notions of immigration and citizenship\nin North American, Asian, and European\ncountries as defined by government officials,\npolitical organizations, community groups,\nand popular culture.\n401 Seminar in Culture and Power 3 Complex\npower relations that develop among competing\nlocal, regional, national, and global culture(s).\n405 [CAPS] Cultural Criticism and Theory\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing. Major\ncritiques and theories of colonialist and\nimperialist formations of culture. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CES 405, ENGLISH 410).\n406 Philosophy and Race 3 Course Prerequisite:\n3 hours in PHIL or CES 201. Examination of\nrace within western philosophy including\nwork of philosophers of color and analysis of\nthe category race. (Crosslisted course offered as\nCES 406, PHIL 406).\n407 Race, Gender and the Prison Industrial\nComplex 3 Race, gender and nationality\nand how they affect the organization and\nmaintenance of the prison industrial complex.\n411 Asian Pacific American Women 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CES or WOMEN ST course; junior\nstanding. Intersection of ethnicity, race, class,\ngender and sexuality in the lives of Asian\nPacific American women. (Crosslisted course\noffered as CES 411, WOMEN ST 411).\n413 Asian Pacific Americans and Popular\nCulture 3 Course Prerequisite: CES 101 or\n111. Examines the racial politics that have\ndeveloped around the representation of Asian\nPacific Americans in US popular culture.\n426 Workers Across North America 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. International\ninteractions between workers and labor unions\nin Mexico, Canada and the US. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as CES 426, HISTORY 426).\n435 African American Women in US Society\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing.\nCritical terms and models for understanding\nthe experiences of African American women\nin antebellum America to the present; an\ninterdisciplinary forum concerned with the\nnational experience of the African American\nwoman experience.\n436 Black Masculinities 3 Historical, political\nand cultural constructions of images of black\nmanhood and the effects on black male\nsubjectivity.\n440 [CAPS] Global Social Justice 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Examination of\nsocial justice issues in the United States and\ntransnationally.\n442 Nation, Ethnicity, and Modernity 3\nRelationship between modernity and nation-\nmaking in relation to dominant constructions\nof race and ethnicity and histories of\ncolonialism.\n444 White Power Movements and Ideologies\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing.\nCritical assessment of white supremacist and\nnationalist movements and ideologies around\nthe globe.\n446 Racism and Anti-Racism in Global\nContext 3 Theory and practice of anti-racism;\nhistory and scope; strategies to transform racist\nsystems.\n454 Latinas in U.S. Culture and Society\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing.\nIntersections of race, class, gender and sexual\norientation in the experience of a marginalized\ngroup - Chicanas.\n465 Race, Science, and Society 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Racial thinking\nin science tracing the impact of scientific\nracism on policy, popular thought and social\nmovements.\n470 Indigenous Politics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. An overview of the struggles\nof indigenous people; issues include rights,\nrecognition, identity, natural resources,\nintellectual property, and repatriation globally.\n475 Indians of the Northwest 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ANTH 320, CES 171, 375, 377,\nor HIST 308; junior standing. History and\nethnography of Native Americans of the\nCoast and Plateau; historic relationship with\nEuropeans and Euro-Americans, and other\nNative Americans, Asian Americans, and\nChicanas/os.\n485 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n489 [CAPS] Everyday Struggles for Justice\nand Equality 3 Course Prerequisite: CES\n201; junior standing. Investigation of everyday\nrealities of racism, sexism, and heterosexism;\napplied research; communication of findings\nthrough new and/or creative media.\n491 [M] Theories of Racism and Ethnic\nConflicts 3 Provides general knowledge of the\nhistory of racist ideas and the social, political,\nand cultural contexts underlying ethnic\nconflicts.\n494 Advanced Topics in Ethnic Studies 3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n9 hours. Course Prerequisite: 3 credits in CES.\nA reading and discussion course that explores\nspecial topics in ethnic studies.\n495 Special Topics in Comparative Ethnic\nStudies 3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 6 hours. Cross-cultural\nstudies on Asian Pacific Americans, Blacks,\nChicanas/os, and Native Americans.\n498 Internship in Comparative Ethnic\nStudies V 1-3 Course Prerequisite: 12 hours\nof CES; junior standing. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 702 credit. S, U\ngrading.\n\n285\nMathematics and Statistics\nWashington State University, 2021\nProgram in Materials\nScience and Engineering\nmaterials.wsu.edu\nFrench Administration, Room 324\n509-335-8231\nProfessors, A. Bandyopadhyay, S. Bose, A. E. Clark, G.\nS. Collins, I. Dutta, D. P. Field, Y. Gupta, K. W. Hipps,\nY. Lin, U. Mazur, J. McCloy, M. D. McCluskey, M.\nMcLarty, M. S. Mesarovic, M. G. Norton, M. P. Wolcott,\nC. S. Yoo, J. W. Zhang, W. Zhong; Associate Professors,\nS. Banerjee, S. Beckman, J. A. Brozik, S. L. Dexheimer,\nK. Englund, Y. Gu, J. Leachman, Q. Li, L. Scudiero, V.\nYadama; Assistant Professors, N. Boddeti, B. Collins,\nA. Gozen, X. Guo, D. Lee, M. Song, D. Wu, Q. Zhang.\nMaterials science includes the principles and\npractice of designing, synthesizing, characterizing,\npreparing, and fabricating useful materials. The\nMaterials Science and Engineering Program\naccepts qualified bachelor’s and master’s graduates\nin the sciences and engineering who now wish to\npursue graduate research for a Ph.D. in the area\nwhere the disciplines overlap. Materials science\nis an interdisciplinary program and this feature is\nemphasized in the research activities.\nRequirements for the Materials Science Ph.D.\ninclude a minimum of 72 credit hours of which\nat least 21 hours are graded course work. The\ncommon ground for all participants in materials\nscience is covered by the core of courses (15 credits)\nrequired of all students. The core provides a general\noverview to the field as well as advanced courses\nin thermodynamics, solid state physics, applied\nmathematics, and materials characterization.\nAll students must attend the materials science\nseminar series (at least 6 credits), which provides an\nopportunity to find out the current research activities\nin the program and associated departments. After\ncompletion of the core of courses, students then\nselect additional courses (a minimum of 6 credit\nhours) in areas that are applicable to their research\nprogram. These courses can come from any area of\nphysical science, engineering, and mathematics.\nAll students complete an original research\ndissertation (MATSE 800). Minimum 20 credits.\nAfter admission to candidacy for the degree,\nstudents select a research supervisor from the\nmaterials science faculty. A broad spectrum of\ncontemporary research areas is available.\nDescription of Courses\nMATERIALS SCIENCE\nMATSE\n503 Current Topics in Materials Science V 1-3\nMay be repeated for credit. Recent advances\nand current research at the forefront of\nmaterials science.\n505 Advanced Materials Science 3 Broad\nbaseline in materials science including\nrelationships between structure and properties.\n(Crosslisted course offered as MSE 505, MATSE\n505). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n506 Biomaterials 3 Overview of the different\ntypes of materials used in biomedical\napplications such as implants and medical\ndevices. Credit not granted for both MSE 406\nand MSE 506. (Crosslisted course offered as\nMSE 506 and MATSE 506.)\n513 Theory of Plasticity and its Physical\nFoundations 3 Phenomenological plasticity\nand viscoplasticity of polycrystalline metals\nand alloys, polymers and granular media;\ndeformation mechanisms; dislocation\nmechanics and interactions; dislocation\nmotion; slip and climb; crystal plasticity;\nsize effects and gradient models. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as MSE 513, ME 513, MATSE\n513). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n516 Phase Transformations 3 Thermodynamics,\nnucleation, interface motion, mechanisms and\nkinetics of chemical reactions between solid\nmetals and their environment. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as MSE 516, MATSE 516).\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n521 Statistics of Microstructures 3 Stereology,\norientation and spatial distributions,\npercolation, measurement techniques and\napplication to modeling of microstructures.\n(Crosslisted course offered as MSE 521, MATSE\n521). Recommended preparation: MATH\n540. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n524 Glass Science and Technology 3 Glass\ncomposition design, processing, and properties;\nengineering and technology related to glasses\nand glass-ceramics; case studies in applied\nglass science and characterization. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as MSE 524, MATSE 524.)\nRecommended preparation: Basic knowledge\nin materials science and manufacturing.\n531 Nanoscience and Nanotechnology 3\nOverview of nanoscience and nanotechnology\na n d t h e i r b i o m e d i c a l , e n e r g y, a n d\nenvironmental applications; structures,\nproperties, synthesis of nanoscale materials\nand fabrication of nanostructured devices.\n(Crosslisted course offered as MSE 531, MATSE\n531, ME 531.) Recommended preparation:\nBasic knowledge of materials, engineering,\nchemistry.\n538 Special Topics V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit. Selected topics of current interest in\nadvanced materials science.\n571 Microscopic Analysis of Solid Surfaces 3\nModern spectroscopic methods for microscopic\nanalysis of solid surfaces; emphasizes electron,\nion, laser, and x-ray techniques.\n593 Seminar in Materials Science 1 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Presentation and discussion of topics\nin materials science taken from research in\nprogress or current literature.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe Materials Science or the Materials Science\nand Engineering PhD program. Independent\nresearch and advanced study for students\nworking on their doctoral research, dissertation\nand/or final examination. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nDepartment of Mathematics\nand Statistics\nmath.wsu.edu\nNeill 103\n509-335-3926\nDepartment Chair and Professor, C. N. Moore;\nProfessors, N. Dasgupta, R. H. Dillon, V. K.\nJandhyala, A. Khapalov, B. Krishnamoorthy, H. Li,\nV. S. Manoranjan, J. McDonald, A. Panchenko, D. B.\nSlavit, M. Tsatsomeros, H. Yin; Associate Professors,\nT. Asaki, A. Dimitrov, M. G. Hudelson, S. Liu, F. G.\nPascual, L. Schreyer, M. F. Schumaker, E. Schwartz, N.\nStrigul, K. Vixie, N. Voulgarakis, X. Wang; Assistant\nProfessors, X. Chen, D. DeFord, W. Hall, A. Kaul, L. F.\nNew, Y. Wang; Adjunct Professor, K. D. Cooper; Clinical\nProfessor, S. Lapin; Clinical Associate Professors, H.\nD. Johnson, K. Vincent; Clinical Assistant Professors,\nK. Fiedler, C. Kogan, D. Mitchell, D. Reiss, S. Selmi;\nSenior Instructors, P. Krouss, J. Martin, E. Remaley,\nL. R. Sotomayor, D. Zhang; Professors Emeriti, J. R.\nAlldredge, K. A. Ariyawansa, D. C. Barnes, S. Cooper,\nD. W. DeTemple, M. Evans, A. C. Genz, M. A. Jacroux,\nR. A. Johnson, M. J. Kallaher, D. C. Kent, L. Knott, J.\nE. Kucera, C. Long, R. Mifflin, C. B. Millham, S. C.\nSaunders, D. S. Watkins, W. A. Webb, H. C. Wiser,\nD. J. Wollkind.\nT h e D e p a r t m e n t o f M a t h e m a t i c s a n d\nStatistics provides undergraduate instruction and\ntraining in all major fields of mathematics and\nstatistics. The numerous service courses taught by\nthe department reflect the growing importance of\nmathematics and statistics in an increasing number\nof other disciplines.\nUndergraduate training for mathematics majors\nis provided at WSU in the following six options:\nactuarial science, applied mathematics, secondary\nmathematics teaching with certification, secondary\nmathematics teaching without certification,\ntheoretical mathematics, and statistics. The\noptions prepare students for careers related to\nthe respective fields. The mathematics major also\nprepares students for graduate study in such fields\nas business, economics, management science\nand computer science, as well as mathematics\nand statistics. Talented undergraduate majors in\n\n286\nMathematics and Statistics\nWashington State University, 2021\nmathematics are given individual and small group\ninstruction outside of class, sometimes resulting\nin research publications. A new, interdisciplinary\nundergraduate degree in data analytics is also\navailable.\nWe expect that students graduating with a\nmathematics degree will be able to: 1) use their\nmathematics and statistics skills within the context\nof a strong, fundamental general education, 2)\nuse the fundamentals of the life and physical\nsciences, 3) apply a fundamental knowledge and\npractical understanding of mathematics and\nstatistics, 4) continue learning in both traditional\nand non-traditional educational settings, and 5)\ncommunicate effectively.\nAll students who enroll in mathematics courses are\nresponsible for satisfying the prerequisite(s). With\nonly a few exceptions, WSU undergraduate students\nare required to take the WSU Math Placement\nAssessment (MPA) prior to enrolling in their first\ncollege-level mathematics course. See http://www.\nmath.wsu.edu/placement/welcome.php placement\nfor more information.\nGraduate study and specialization are offered\nby the department in both classical and modern\nareas of mathematics and statistics. A PhD student\nhas four choices: a PhD in Mathematics, PhD in\nMathematics-Applied Mathematics option, a PhD\nin Mathematics with an Education Emphasis, or a\nPhD in Statistical Science. The first involves doing\nmathematical research, the Applied Mathematics\noption focuses on applied mathematical research,\nthe Education Emphasis option involves research\non the teaching and learning of mathematics, and\nthe Statistics option involves statistical research.\nAt the masters level the department offers the\nfollowing degrees: a MS in Mathematics, MS in\nMathematics–Applied Mathematics Option, MS\nin Mathematics-Computational Finance Option,\nMS Mathematics – Teaching Option, and a MS in\nStatistics. A graduate certificate in Teaching College\nMathematics is also available.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nAs preparation for work toward an advanced\ndegree in mathematics or statistics, a student should\nhave completed the equivalent of an undergraduate\ndegree in mathematics, statistics, or a related field.\nAdequate opportunities are provided for removing\ndeficiencies through the taking of appropriate\ncourses. Students who contemplate undertaking\nstudies leading to a doctoral degree should contact\nthe Graduate Coordinator (gradinfo@math.wsu.\nedu) for advice and assistance in the development\nof their plans.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nACTUARIAL SCIENCE OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nMathematics Major Core Requirements\nIn addition to the UCORE requirements and\nthe College of Arts and Sciences requirements,\na mathematics major is required to take 13\ncore courses and a minimum of 4 additional\n300-400-level MATH courses specified by a chosen\noption. Options include: Actuarial Science, Applied\nMathematics, Theoretical Mathematics. Courses\nrequired for the major may not be taken pass/fail,\nand a 2.0 minimum GPA is required.\nAdmission to the Major Requirements\n• Applications for admission to the major are\naccepted at any time during fall and spring\nsemesters. Decisions are made within ten working\ndays of receipt of application. Application forms are\navailable in the Mathematics Department office.\n• Applications are evaluated, and admission\ndecided, by a faculty committee.\n• Applicants must have a cumulative GPA of at\nleast 2.0.\n• The mathematics core consists of MATH 171,\n172, and 220. These courses (or their equivalent\nfor transfer students) must be completed before\napplication.\n• Students with at least a 2.5 GPA in the\nmathematics core will be admitted automatically.\nThose with less than a 2.0 GPA in the mathematics\ncore will normally not be admitted. Others will be\nconsidered on a case-by-case basis.\n• Appeals related to admission decisions are\nconsidered by the department chairperson.\n• Students who are denied admission may reapply\nafter completing at least 12 more credits, whereupon\ndecisions are based on grades in mathematics,\nscience, and computer science courses; cumulative\nGPA and grade patterns; and a personal interview.\n• Admitted students whose cumulative GPA or GPA\nin MATH courses numbered 171 and above falls\nbelow 2.0 for two consecutive semesters, or who\nare academically deficient, are subject to release\nfrom the major.\n• Applications for readmission are handled in the\nsame manner as admission applications for those\npreviously denied.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCPT S 121 4\nECONS 101 [SSCI] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 172 or 182 4\nMATH 220 or 230 2 or 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 273 or 283 2\nMATH 301 3\nMATH 405 3\nPHYSICS 201 [PSCI] 3\nPHYSICS 211 [PSCI] 1\nSecond Term Hours\nECONS 102 [SSCI] 3\nMATH 315 3\nSTAT 360 3\nElectives\n1 \n6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMATH 300 [M] 3\nMATH 420 3\nSTAT 443 3\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or Electives\n1 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] [M] 3\nSTAT 412 or 423 3\nSTAT 446 3\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or Electives\n1 \n6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMATH 401 [M] 3\nMATH 416 3\nElectives\n1 \n9\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMATH 464 [CAPS] 3\nSTAT 447 3\nElectives\n1 \n6\nExit Interview\n_______\n1 \nSuggested elective courses for students pursuing\nActuarial Science Option include ACCTG 230\nand 231, FIN 325 and 350, and MATH 448, which\nprovide additional background for actuarial exams.\nNote: A minor in Business Administration is\nrequired to take FIN 325 and 350.\nAPPLIED OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nMathematics Major Core Requirements\nIn addition to the UCORE requirements and\nthe College of Arts and Sciences requirements,\na mathematics major is required to take 13\ncore courses and a minimum of 4 additional\n300-400-level MATH courses specified by a chosen\noption.
