Options include: Actuarial Science, Applied\nMathematics, Theoretical Mathematics. Courses\n\n289\nMathematics and Statistics\nWashington State University, 2021\nrequired for the major may not be taken pass/fail,\nand a 2.0 minimum GPA is required.\nAdmission to the Major Requirements\n• Applications for admission to the major are\naccepted at any time during fall and spring\nsemesters. Decisions are made within ten working\ndays of receipt of application. Application forms are\navailable in the Mathematics Department office.\n• Applications are evaluated, and admission\ndecided, by a faculty committee.\n• Applicants must have a cumulative GPA of at\nleast 2.0.\n• The mathematics core consists of MATH 171,\n172, and 220. These courses (or their equivalent\nfor transfer students) must be completed before\napplication.\n• Students with at least a 2.5 GPA in the\nmathematics core will be admitted automatically.\nThose with less than a 2.0 GPA in the mathematics\ncore will normally not be admitted. Others will be\nconsidered on a case-by-case basis.\n• Appeals related to admission decisions are\nconsidered by the department chairperson.\n• Students who are denied admission may reapply\nafter completing at least 12 more credits, whereupon\ndecisions are based on grades in mathematics,\nscience, and computer science courses; cumulative\nGPA and grade patterns; and a personal interview.\n• Admitted students whose cumulative GPA or GPA\nin MATH courses numbered 171 and above falls\nbelow 2.0 for two consecutive semesters, or who\nare academically deficient, are subject to release\nfrom the major.\n• Applications for readmission are handled in the\nsame manner as admission applications for those\npreviously denied.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCPT S 121 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 172 or 182 4\nMATH 220 or 230 2 or 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nForeign Language, if needed, or Electives 4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 273 or 283 2\nMATH 301 3\nPHYSICS 201 [PSCI] 3\nPHYSICS 211 [PSCI] 1\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nMATH 315 3\nMATH 398 1\nSTAT 360 3\nForeign Language, if needed, or Electives 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMATH 300 [M] 3\nMATH 420 3\nTheoretical Mathematics Option Course\n1 \n3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] [M] 3\nMATH 421 [M] 3\nTheoretical Mathematics Option Course\n1 \n3\nElectives 6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMATH 401 [M] 3\nTheoretical Mathematics Option Course\n1 \n3\nElectives 9\nSecond Term Hours\nMATH 402 [M] 3\nMATH 464 [CAPS] 3\nElectives 9\nExit Interview\n_______\n1 \nTheoretical Mathematics Required Option Courses:\nThree courses from MATH 302, 325, 403, 415, 441,\nor 453.\nMinors\nMathematics\nA mathematics minor requires a minimum of 19\nhours including MATH 171, 172, and one of 220 or\n273. An additional 9 hours from a combination of\n300-400-level mathematics credits or STAT 360, 370,\n423, 443, 446, and 447 must be taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. Courses required\nfor the minor may not be taken pass/fail and a\nminimum 2.0 GPA is required in all courses taken\nfor the minor. MATH 303, 330, 351, 398, 425, and\n431 do not count toward the minor.\nStatistics\nThe minor in statistics requires a minimum of 18\ncredit hours. 9 hours of upper-division work must\nbe 300-400-level and be taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses. Courses required for\nthe minor may not be taken pass/fail and a minimum\n2.0 GPA is required in all courses. Required courses\ninclude STAT 360 or 370, STAT 412, 423 or 430; STAT\n443, and 9 additional hours selected from STAT 410,\n419, 422 (UIdaho), 428 (UIdaho), 436, 446, 447,\nand 456. Students majoring in mathematics under\nthe Actuarial Sciences Option must take STAT 456.\nCertificates\nCertificate in Quantitative\nBiology\nThe certificate in Quantitative Biology requires 17\ncredits. Students must earn a grade of C or higher in\neach course and no P, F or S, F graded course work\nmay be applied to the certificate.\nRequirements: MATH/BIOLOGY 340; 6 credits of\nmathematics (MATH 172 or higher) and/or statistics\n(300-400-level), of which 3 credits must be taken in\nresidence at Washington State University; 8 credits\nof 300-400-level BIOLOGY courses of which 3\ncredits must be taken in residence at Washington\nState University.\nDescription of Courses\nMATHEMATICS\nMATH\n100 Basic Mathematics 2 Course Prerequisite:\nA minimum ALEKS math placement score of\n1%. Review of basic arithmetic and elementary\nalgebra. No credit earned toward degree. S, F\ngrading.\n101 Intermediate Algebra 3 Fundamental\nalgebraic operations and concepts. No credit\nearned toward degree.\n103 Algebra Methods and Introduction to\nFunctions 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 100\nwith an S, MATH 101 with a C or better, or\na minimum ALEKS math placement score of\n40%. Fundamental algebraic operations and\nconcepts, linear systems and inequalities,\np o l y n o m i a l a n d r a t i o n a l f u n c t i o n s ,\nintroduction to exponential and logarithmic\nfunctions.\n105 [QUAN] Exploring Mathematics 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 101, 103, or 251, each\nwith a C or better, or STAT 212 with a C or\nbetter, or a minimum ALEKS math placement\nscore of 45%. Nature and scope of modern\nmathematics, and its relationships to other\ndisciplines.\n106 College Algebra 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 101 with a C or better, or MATH 103\nwith a C or better, or a minimum ALEKS math\nplacement score of 70%. Graphs, properties\nand applications of polynomial, rational,\nexponential and logarithmic functions.\n108 Trigonometry 2 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n106 with a C or better. Graphs, properties and\napplications of trigonometric functions. Credit\nnot normally granted for both MATH 108 and\n107.\n110 Mathematics Acceleration 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: A minimum ALEKS math\nplacement score of 25%. Individualized\ninstruction on mathematical skills to enhance\nthe mathematical background necessary for\nsuccess in one of MATH 103, 106, or 171. S, F\ngrading.\n111 Mathematics Tutorial for MATH 201 1\nCourse Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment\nMATH 107. Student-centered group tutorial\nfocusing on skill improvement for success in\nMATH 201. S, F grading.\n115 Math 105 Tutorial 2 Tutorial for MATH\n105 focusing on concept development and\nmastery; skill proficiency. S, F grading.\n\n290\nMathematics and Statistics\nWashington State University, 2021\n116 Math 106 Tutorial 2 Tutorial for MATH\n106 focusing on concept development and\nmastery; skill proficiency. S, F grading.\n140 [QUAN] Calculus for Life Scientists 4 (3-\n3) Course Prerequisite: MATH 106 with a C\nor better and MATH 108 with a C or better,\nor a minimum ALEKS math placement score\nof 80%. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for MATH 171 or 202 except\nby department consent. Differential and\nintegral calculus with emphasis on life science\napplications. By department consent, credit\nmay be allowed for two of MATH 140, 171, or\n202.\n171 [ Q U A N ] C a l c u l u s I 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 106 with a C or better and\nMATH 108 with a C or better, or a minimum\nALEKS math placement score of 83%.\nEnrollment not allowed if credit already earned\nfor MATH 140 or 202 except by department\nconsent. Differential and integral calculus of\none variable with associated analytic geometry.\nBy department consent, credit may be allowed\nfor two of MATH 140, 171, or 202.\n172 Calculus II 4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 171 with a C or better. Techniques\nand applications of one-variable calculus;\nestimations; series, derivative of a vector\nfunction. Credit not granted for both MATH\n172 and 182.\n182 Honors Calculus II 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 171 with a C or better; by\ndepartment permission only. Single variable\ncalculus, series, with emphasis on conceptual\ndevelopment and problem solving. Credit not\ngranted for both MATH 172 and 182.\n201 M a t h e m a t i c s f o r B u s i n e s s a n d\nEconomics 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 101\nwith a C or better, MATH 103 with a C or better,\nor a minimum ALEKS math placement score of\n65%. Mathematical analysis using polynomial,\nexponential, and logarithmic functions; linear\nsystems, linear programming and mathematics\nof finance, for business/economic applications\nand modeling.\n202 [QUAN] Calculus for Business and\nEconomics 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n106 with a C or better, MATH 201 with a C or\nbetter, or a minimum ALEKS math placement\nscore of 80%. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for MATH 140 or 171 except by\ndepartment consent. Differential calculus of\nthe polynomial, exponential, and logarithmic\nfunctions; focus on unconstrained and\nconstrained optimization, single and partial\ndifferentiation. By department consent, credit\nmay be allowed for two of MATH 140, 171, or\n202.\n216 Discrete Structures 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 108 with a C or better, or MATH 140,\n171, 172, 182, or MATH 202 or concurrent\nenrollment. Discrete mathematics, trees,\ngraphs, elementary logic, and combinatorics\nwith application to computer science.\nRecommended preparation: Programming\ncourse.\n220 Introductory Linear Algebra 2 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 171 or concurrent\nenrollment. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for MATH 225 or 230. Solving\nlinear systems, matrices, determinants,\nsubspaces, eigenvalues, orthogonality. Credit\nnot granted for more than one of MATH 220,\n225, and 230.\n225 L i n e a r A l g e b r a w i t h M o d e r n\nApplications 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n106 or higher. Enrollment not allowed if\ncredit already earned for MATH 220 or 230.\nSolving linear systems, matrices, determinants,\nsubspaces, eigenvalues, orthogonality,\nmachine learning, AI, computer graphics, and\neconomic models. Credit not granted for more\nthan one of MATH 220, 225, and 230.\n230 Honors Introductory Linear Algebra 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MATH 171 or concurrent\nenrollment. Enrollment not allowed if\ncredit already earned for MATH 220 or 225.\nAn introduction to linear algebra with an\nemphasis on conceptual development. Credit\nnot granted for more than one of MATH 220,\n225, and 230.\n251 F u n d a m e n t a l s o f E l e m e n t a r y\nMathematics I 3 (2-2) Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 101, 103, 105, or 106, each with a C\nor better, or STAT 212 with a C or better, or\na minimum ALEKS math placement score of\n45%. Comprehensive development of number\nsystems emphasizing place-value, integers,\nrational numbers, and associated algorithms;\nmethods of problem solving.\n252 [QUAN] Fundamentals of Elementary\nMathematics II 3 (2-2) Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 251 with a C or better. Inquiry-\nbased approach to fundamental concepts:\nmeasurement, geometrical constructions,\nsimilarity, congruence, symmetry, probability,\ncounting principles, measures of central\ntendency, and distributions. Required\npreparation: One year of high school geometry.\n273 Calculus III 2 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n172 with a C or better, or MATH 182 with a\nC or better. Calculus of functions of several\nvariables. Credit not granted for both MATH\n273 and 283.\n283 Honors Calculus III 2 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 182 or by department permission.\nMultivariable calculus with emphasis on\nconceptual development and problem solving.\nCredit not granted for both MATH 273 and\n283.\n300 Mathematical Computing 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 220 or MATH 230.\nExamination of some current computer\nsoftware for solving mathematical problems.\nRecommended preparation: MATH 315.\n301 I n t r o d u c t i o n t o M a t h e m a t i c a l\nReasoning 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n220 with a C or better, or MATH 230 with a\nC or better. Mathematical arguments and the\nwriting of proofs.\n302 Theory of Numbers 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 172 with a C or better, or MATH 182\nwith a C or better; MATH 301 with a C or better.\nDivisibility properties of integers; congruences;\nDiophantine equations; quadratic residues.\n303 [M] Geometry for the Middle School\nTeacher 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 252.\nTopics in 2D and 3D geometry including\ntechnology-based reasoning and exploration,\ndeductive arguments, transformational and\nproportional reasoning, and non-Euclidean\ngeometries.\n315 D i f f e r e n t i a l E q u a t i o n s 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: MATH 273 with a C or better or\nMath 283 with a C or better; and MATH 220\nwith a C or better or concurrent enrollment,\nor MATH 230 with a C or better or concurrent\nenrollment. Linear differential equations and\nsystems; series, numerical and qualitative\napproaches; applications.\n320 [M] Elementary Modern Algebra 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 220 with a C or better or\nMATH 230 with a C or better. Algebra as a\ndeductive system; number systems; groups,\nrings, and fields.\n325 Elementary Combinatorics 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 220 with a C or better or\nMATH 230 with a C or better. Introduction\nto combinatorial theory: counting methods,\nbinomial coefficients and identities, generating\nfunctions, occurrence relations, inclusion-\nexclusion methods.\n330 Methods of Teaching Secondary School\nMathematics 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n301 or concurrent enrollment. New curricula\nand pedagogical techniques for secondary\nschool mathematics.\n340 Introduction to Mathematical Biology\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 140 with a C\nor better, or MATH 172 with a C or better, or\nMATH 182 with a C or better; BIOLOGY 101,\nBIOLOGY 102, BIOLOGY 106, or BIOLOGY\n107. Mathematical biology and development\nof mathematical modeling for solutions to\nproblems in the life sciences. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as MATH 340, BIOLOGY 340).\n351 Algebraic Thinking for the Middle\nSchool Teacher 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n252 with a C or better. Algebraic reasoning,\nclasses of functions, translation among models,\nanalytical rule, tables of data, context and\ncoordinate graphs.\n352 Probability and Data Analysis for Middle\nSchool Teachers 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n251; MATH 252. Probability and statistics in\nrelation to middle school mathematics and real\nworld problems through visualization, hands-\non activities, and technology.\n364 Principles of Optimization 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 202, MATH 220, or\nMATH 230. Algebra of linear inequalities;\nduality; graphs, transport networks; linear\nprogramming; special algorithms; nonlinear\nprogramming; selected applications.\n375 Vector Analysis 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n315. Line integrals, gradient, curl, divergence;\nStokes’ theorem, potential functions.\n398 Mathematical Snapshots 1 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 172 or MATH 182.\nCharacter, life work, and historical importance\nof mathematicians from various eras and\nbranches of mathematics.\n\n291\nMathematics and Statistics\nWashington State University, 2021\n401 [M] Introduction to Analysis I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 301 with a C or better.\nProperties of sets and sequences of real\nnumbers; limits, continuity, differentiation\nand integration of functions; metric spaces.\n402 [M] Introduction to Analysis II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 401. Sequences of\nfunctions, power series, multivariable calculus,\ninverse and implicit function theorems,\nLagrange multipliers, change of variable in\nmultiple integrations.\n403 Euclidean and Non-Euclidean Geometry\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 301 with a C or\nbetter. Geometry as a deductive system of logic;\npostulational systems; projective and non-\nEuclidian geometries.\n405 Introduction to Financial Mathematics\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 172 or 182.\nIntroduction to financial mathematics\nincluding the basics of annuities, stocks,\nbonds, and financial derivatives.\n415 Intermediate Differential Equations\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 315. Linear\nsystems; qualitative theory (existence,\nuniqueness, stability, periodicity); boundary\nvalue problems; applications.\n416 Numerical Simulations for Probabilistic\nModels 3 Course Prerequisite: STAT 360; CPT\nS 121, CPT S 251, or MATH 300. Efficient\ngeneration of random variables; statistical\nanalysis and validation techniques; variance\nreduction; Markov Chain Monte Carlo\nmethods; applications include complex\nsystems, financial models, and Bayesian\ncomputation. Credit not granted for both\nMATH 416 and MATH 516. Required\npreparation must include probability and\nstatistics and programming experience.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n420 Linear Algebra 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 220 with a C or better, or MATH 230\nwith a C or better; MATH 301 with a C or\nbetter. Vector spaces, linear transformations,\ndiagonalizability, normal matrices, inner\nproduct spaces, orthogonality, orthogonal\nprojections, least-squares, SVD.\n421 [M] Algebraic Structures 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 301 with a C or better.\nProperties of algebraic structures and their\nhomomorphisms, semi-groups, groups, rings,\nunique factorization domains, fields.\n425 Conceptual Aspects of Mathematics 3\nCourse Prerequisite: By instructor permission.\nExploration of conceptual models for thinking\nabout mathematical ideas; activities and\ndiscussions of mathematical thinking and\ninstruction. (Crosslisted course offered as TCH\nLRN 425, MATH 425).\n431 I n t e r s e c t i o n s o f C u l t u r e a n d\nMathematics 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n301 with a C or better. Gender/race/ethnicity\ndifferences; social consequences; cultural\ninfluences on development and learning of\nmathematics; role of women, people of color\nin mathematics. Credit not granted for both\nMATH 431 and 531. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n432 [CAPS] Mathematics for College and\nSecondary Teachers 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 301 with a C or better. Pre-algebra,\nalgebra functions and geometry examined\nfrom an advanced perspective, for secondary\nand lower level college teachers.\n440 Applied Mathematics I: PDEs 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 315. Applied partial\ndifferential equations; Fourier series; Bessel\nfunctions and Legendre polynomials as\nharmonics for disks and balls; Laplace, heat,\nand wave equations; separation of variables\nand D’Alambert’s formula. Credit not\ngranted for both MATH 440 and MATH 540.\nRequired preparation must include differential\nequations. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n441 Applied Mathematics II: Complex\nVariables 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n315. Complex numbers and complex-valued\nfunctions of one complex variable; analytic\nfunctions and Cauchy-Riemann equations;\ndifferentiation and contour integration;\nCauchy integral theorem; Taylor and\nLaurent series; residues; conformal mapping;\napplications to potential theory. Credit not\ngranted for both MATH 441 and MATH 541.\nRequired preparation must include differential\nequations. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n448 Numerical Analysis 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 315 with a C or better; one of CPT S\n121, 131, or MATH 300, with a C or better.\nFundamentals of numerical computation;\nfinding zeroes of functions, approximation\nand interpolation; numerical integration\n(quadrature); numerical solution of ordinary\ndifferential equations. (Crosslisted course\noffered as MATH 448, MATH 548, CPT S 430,\nCPT S 530). Required preparation must include\ndifferential equations and a programming\ncourse.\n453 Graph Theory 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 220 or MATH 230. Graphs and their\napplications, directed graphs, trees, networks,\nEulerian and Hamiltonian paths, matrix\nrepresentations, construction of algorithms.\n(Crosslisted course offered as MATH 453,\nMATH 553, CPT S 453, CPT S 553). Required\npreparation must include linear algebra.\nRecommended preparation: MATH 301.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n456 Introduction to Statistical Theory\n3 Course Prerequisite: STAT 430 or 443.\nSampling distributions; hypothesis testing\nand estimation; maximum likelihood;\nlikelihood ratio tests; theory of least squares;\nnonparametrics. (Crosslisted course offered\nas STAT 456, MATH 456). Credit not granted\nfor more than one of STAT/MATH 456 or STAT\n556. Recommended preparation: One 3-credit\n400-level STAT or probability course.\n464 [CAPS] Linear Optimization 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 273 or MATH 283. Linear\nand integer programming; optimization\nproblems; applications to economic and\nmilitary strategies; rectangular games;\nminimax theory. Recommended preparation:\nMATH 301.\n466 Optimization in Networks 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 364. Formulation and\nsolution of network optimization problems\nincluding shortest path, maximal flow,\nminimum cost flow, assignment, covering,\npostman, and salesman. Credit not granted\nfor both MATH 466 and MATH 566. Required\npreparation must include linear programming.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n486 Mathematical Methods in Natural\nSciences 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 315.\nIntroduction to mathematical modeling\nof natural processes; methods include\ndimensional and scaling analysis, perturbation\ntheory, field theory of continuum mechanics,\ncalculus of variations, and Markov chains;\napplications to physics, chemistry, biology, and\nengineering. Credit not granted for both MATH\n486 and MATH 586. Required preparation must\ninclude differential equations. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n490 Topics in Mathematics V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n9 hours. Course Prerequisite: By instructor\npermission. Special topics in mathematics.\n494 Seminar in Mathematical Biology 1 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum 4\nhours. Course Prerequisite: MATH 140 with a\nC or better, or MATH 172 with a C or better, or\nMATH 182 with a C or better; BIOLOGY 101,\nBIOLOGY 102, BIOLOGY 106, or BIOLOGY\n107. Oral presentation of research approaches,\nresearch results and literature review of\nmathematical biology including mathematical\nmodeling of biological systems. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as MATH 494, BIOLOGY 494).\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents. S, F grading.\n497 Instructional Practicum V 1-2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n2 hours. Course Prerequisite: By instructor\npermission. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n500 Proseminar 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 2 hours. S, F grading.\n501 Real Analysis 3 Metric spaces, convergence,\ncontinuous functions, infinite series,\ndifferentiation and integration of functions of\none and several variables. Required preparation\nmust include advanced calculus or real analysis.\n502 Introduction to Functional Analysis 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MATH 501. Normed linear\nspaces, Banach spaces, introduction to Hilbert\nspace, linear operators. Required preparation:\nAdvanced linear algebra.\n503 Complex Analysis 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 501. Analytic functions, complex\nintegration, Taylor and Laurent series,\nconformal mapping, Riemann surfaces and\nanalytic continuation. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n\n292\nMathematics and Statistics\nWashington State University, 2021\n504 Measure and Integration 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 501. Lebesque measure,\nLebesque integration, differentiation, L\nspaces, general measure and integration,\nRadon-Nikodym Theorem, outer measure and\nproduct measures. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n505 Abstract Algebra 3 Groups, rings, fields,\nand homological algebra. Required preparation\nmust include abstract algebra. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n507 Advanced Theory of Numbers 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Analytic and algebraic number theory.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n508 Advanced Mathematical Methods for\nPhysics and Engineering 3 Advanced\ntreatment of applications using techniques\nfrom fundamental analysis, convexity, analytic\nfunction theory, asymptotics, and differential\nequations. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n511 Advanced Linear Algebra 3 Spectral theory,\nSchur’s theorem, normality, Jordan canonical\nforms, hermitian matrices, variational\ninequalities, matrix norms, eigenvalue\nlocalization, matrix perturbation theory.\nRequired preparation must include second level\nundergraduate linear algebra. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n512 Ordinar y Differential Equations\n3 Existence of solutions; linear systems;\nqualitative behavior, especially stability;\nperiodic solutions. Required preparation\nmust include a year-long sequence in advanced\ncalculus or real analysis. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n516 Numerical Simulations for Probabilistic\nModels 3 Efficient generation of random\nvariables; statistical analysis and validation\ntechniques; variance reduction; Markov\nChain Monte Carlo methods; applications\ninclude complex systems, financial models,\nand Bayesian computation. Credit not\ngranted for both MATH 416 and MATH 516.\nRequired preparation must include probability\nand statistics and programming experience.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n524 Algebraic Topology 3 Algebraic techniques\n(groups, homomorphisms, etc) to study\nconnectivity of spaces; topics include simplicial\ncomplexes, homology, relative homology,\nMeyer-Vietoris sequences, categories and\nfunctors, cohomology, and duality in\nmanifolds. Recommended preparation: real\nanalysis and abstract algebra.\n525 General Topology 3 Sets, metric spaces,\ntopological spaces; continuous mappings,\ncompactness, connectedness, local properties,\nfunction spaces, and fundamental groups.\nRequired preparation must include a year-\nlong sequence in advanced calculus or real\nanalysis. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n529 Computational Topology 3 Topological\ntechniques combined with algorithms to find\nstructure in data; simplicial complexes from\npoint clouds, algorithms for homology and\npersistent homology, mapper and topological\ndata analysis, optimal homology problems.\nRecommended preparation: mathematical\nmaturity at senior undergraduate level and\nsome experience with computer programming.\n531 I n t e r s e c t i o n s o f C u l t u r e a n d\nMathematics 3 Gender/race/ethnicity\ndifferences; social consequences; cultural\ninfluences on development and learning of\nmathematics; role of women, people of color\nin mathematics. Credit not granted for both\nMATH 431 and 531. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n532 Advanced Mathematical Thinking 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Graduate standing in\nmathematics. Current theories about how\nhumans learn to think mathematically at\nthe advanced level. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n533 Teaching College Mathematics 1 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 3\nhours. Course Prerequisite: Graduate standing\nin Mathematics or Statistical Science. Theory\nand practice of mathematics instruction at the\ncollegiate level.\n534 Theories of Learning in Mathematics 3\nMath learning theories, including behaviorism,\ninformation processing, constructivism,\ns i t u a t e d c o g n i t i o n , c o m m u n i t i e s o f\npractice; influence on teaching and learning\nmathematics. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n535 Research Paradigms in Mathematics\nEducation 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 534.\nCurrent research paradigms in math education\nresearch; critique research designs used in\ncurrent mathematics education research\narticle; design and carry out a research project.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n536 Statistical Computing 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: STAT 556. Generation of random\nvariables, Monte Carlo simulation, bootstrap\nand jackknife methods, EM algorithm,\nMarkov chain Monte Carlo methods.\n(Crosslisted course offered as STAT 536,\nMATH 536). Recommended preparation: One\n3-credit 400-level probability or STAT course.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n540 Applied Mathematics I: PDEs 3 Applied\npartial differential equations; Fourier series;\nBessel functions and Legendre polynomials as\nharmonics for disks and balls; Laplace, heat,\nand wave equations; separation of variables\nand D’Alambert’s formula. Credit not\ngranted for both MATH 440 and MATH 540.\nRequired preparation must include differential\nequations. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n541 Applied Mathematics II: Complex\nVariables 3 Complex numbers and complex-\nvalued functions of one complex variable;\nanalytic functions and Cauchy-Riemann\nequations; differentiation and contour\nintegration; Cauchy integral theorem; Taylor\nand Laurent series; residues; conformal\nmapping; applications to potential theory.\nCredit not granted for both MATH 441 and\nMATH 541. Required preparation must include\ndifferential equations. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n543 Stable Numerical Methods Using\nOrthogonality 3 Computational methods\nfor stabilizing difficult and ill-posed differential\nand integral equations problems by using\nsystems of functions and regularization\ntechniques; applications to forward and\ninverse problems; techniques include the\nuse of wavelets and orthogonal polynomials.\nRequired preparation must include numerical\nanalysis. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n544 Advanced Matrix Computations 3\nAdvanced topics in the solution of linear\nsystems, singular value decomposition, and\ncomputation of eigenvalues and eigenvectors\n(Francis’s algorithm). (Crosslisted course\noffered as MATH 544, CPT S 531). Required\npreparation must include numerical analysis.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n545 Numerical Analysis of Parabolic and\nHyperbolic PDEs 3 Numerical solutions of\nparabolic and hyperbolic partial differential\nequations with emphasis on finite difference\nmethods; topics include: finite difference;\nstability, consistency, and convergence; shocks;\nconservation of forms. Required preparation\nmust include numerical analysis. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n546 Numerical Analysis of Elliptic PDEs\n3 Numerical solutions of elliptic partial\ndifferential equations with emphasis on finite\nelement methods; finite difference; error\nanalysis. Required preparation must include\nnumerical analysis. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n548 Numerical Analysis 3 Fundamentals of\nnumerical computation; finding zeroes of\nfunctions, approximation and interpolation;\nnumerical integration (quadrature); numerical\nsolution of ordinary differential equations.\n(Crosslisted course offered as MATH 448,\nMATH 548, CPT S 430, CPT S 530). Required\npreparation must include differential equations\nand a programming course.\n553 G r a p h T h e o r y 3 Graphs and their\napplications, directed graphs, trees, networks,\nEulerian and Hamiltonian paths, matrix\nrepresentations, construction of algorithms.\n(Crosslisted course offered as MATH 453,\nMATH 553, CPT S 453, CPT S 553). Required\npreparation must include linear algebra.\nRecommended preparation: MATH 301.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n\n293\nMathematics and Statistics\nWashington State University, 2021\n555 Topics in Combinatorics 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Combinatorics, generating functions,\nrecurrence relations, inclusion-exclusion,\ncoding theory; experimental design, graph\ntheory. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n560 Partial Differential Equations I 3 Partial\ndifferential equations and other functional\nequations: general theory, methods of solution,\napplications. Required preparation\nmust include real analysis and command of a\nprogramming language. Dutta, D. P.\nField, Y. Lin, K. Matveev, J. S. McCloy, S. Mesarovic,\nM. G. Norton, C. Pezeshki, C. D. Richards, R. F.\nRichards, L. V. Smith, J. Zhang, W. Zhong; Associate\nProfessors, S. Banerjee, S. P. Beckman, B. A. Gozen, J.\nW. Leachman, Q. Li, J. Liu; Assistant Professors, K.\n\n296\nMechanical and Materials Engineering\nWashington State University, 2021\nR. Chen, M. Luo, D. F. McLarty, K. Qiu, M. K. Song,\nJ. P. Swensen; Clinical Assistant Professor, N. Biswas;\nInstructor, D. A. Torick; Bremerton: Clinical Professor,\nM. J. Pitts; Clinical Associate Professor, B. Asgharian;\nInstructor, P. M. Dodge; Everett: Clinical Professor, X.\nBi; Clinical Assistant Professors, G. N. Taub, Z. Shu;\nInstructor, D. Strong; Tri Cities: Associate Professor,\nC. Mo.\nThe School of Mechanical and Materials Engineering\noffers programs in Mechanical Engineering\n(Pullman, Bremerton, and Everett campuses), and\nMaterials Science and Engineering (Pullman). Each\nprogram is detailed as follows.\nMECHANICAL ENGINEERING\nMechanical engineering is concerned with (a)\nthe use and economical conversion of energy from\nnatural sources into other useful energy to provide\npower, light, heat, cooling and transportation,\n(b) the design and production of machines to\nlighten the burden of human work, (c) the creative\nplanning, development and operation of systems\nfor using energy, machines and resources, (d)\nthe processing of materials into products useful\nto people, and (e) developing machines and\nalgorithms for autonomous systems. Employment\nopportunities for graduates exist in the areas of\nmechanical design, systems design, equipment\ndevelopment, manufacturing, CAD/CAM,\nalgorithm development, project engineering,\nproduction management, applied research, and\nsales and service.\nThe program leading to the Bachelor of Science\ndegree in Mechanical Engineering is accredited by\nthe Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET,\nhttp://www.abet.org.\nThe mission of the mechanical engineering\nprogram is to provide a broad education in\nmechanical engineering that prepares our students\nfor being successful in professional practice and\nadvanced studies. The educational objectives of the\nundergraduate mechanical engineering program are\nas follows: (1) Graduates will meet or exceed the\nexpectations of employers of mechanical engineers;\n(2) Qualified graduates will pursue advanced study\nif they so desire; and (3) Graduates will pursue\nleadership positions in their profession and/or\ncommunities.\nThe undergraduate curriculum emphasizes\nfoundation courses at the third year which\nare fundamental to all aspects of mechanical\nengineering. These courses emphasize both\nanalysis and design while accompanying\nlaboratory courses provide opportunities for\nhands-on experiences. Computer applications are\ninterwoven throughout the program. The courses\nin the fourth year emphasize the integration of\nfundamental engineering principles into various\napplications in mechanical engineering. Students\nhave an opportunity to complete a sequence of\nelectives in one of three concentrations or follow\na general path taking technical electives of their\nchoice. The concentrations include Thermo-fluids,\nManufacturing, and Autonomous Systems. By\ncompleting a concentration, students will have\ndeeper knowledge in a specific area of mechanical\nengineering they would like to pursue in their future\ncareers. The undergraduate program culminates in\na capstone laboratory course.\nGraduates are prepared to enter the field as\nengineers or to continue into a graduate program.\nAn engineering internship program is available for\nstudents to gain industrial experience during their\nacademic careers.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe learning outcomes of the mechanical\nengineering undergraduate program are the\nfollowing:\n• Ability to identify, formulate, and solve complex\nengineering problems by applying principles of\nengineering, science, and mathematics.\n• Ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions.\n• Ability to apply engineering design to\nproduce solutions that meet specified needs with\nconsideration of public health, safety, and welfare,\nas well as global, cultural, social, environmental,\nand economic factors.\n• Ability to function effectively on a team whose\nmembers together provide leadership, create a\ncollaborative and inclusive environment, establish\ngoals, plan tasks, and meet objectives.\n• Ability to recognize ethical and professional\nresponsibilities in engineering situations and\nmake informed judgments, which must consider\nthe impact of engineering solutions in global,\neconomic, environmental, and societal contexts.\n• Ability to communicate effectively with a range\nof audiences.\n• Ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\nThe School offers courses of study leading to\nthe degrees of Bachelor of Science in Mechanical\nEngineering (accredited by the Engineering\nAccreditation Commission of ABET, www.abet.org),\nMaster of Science in Mechanical Engineering, and\nDoctor of Philosophy (Mechanical Engineering).\nThe school participates in the interdisciplinary\nprograms leading to the Master of Science in\nEngineering and Doctor of Philosophy (Engineering\nScience).\nMATERIALS SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING\nThe program leading to the Bachelor of Science\ndegree in Materials Science and Engineering\nis accredited by the Engineering Accreditation\nCommission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.\nThe mission of the materials science and\nengineering program is to provide excellence\nin education, research, and service in the field\nof Materials Science and Engineering through\neducational programs that graduate students with\nstrong backgrounds in scientific and engineering\nproblem-solving methods. Materials science\nand engineering is the application of methods\nand principles of the pure sciences to study\nengineering materials. The undergraduate program\nfocuses on (a) the relationship of the microscopic\nstructure, e.g. crystal structure and defects to the\nmacroscopic properties of materials, e.g. strength;\n(b) experimental techniques for characterizing\nphysical, chemical and structural properties of\nmaterials; (c) Design and selection of appropriate\nmaterials for given engineering applications.\nThe specific fields of application covered by\nresearch and instruction programs can be expressed\nby the nominal designations of metals (metallurgy),\npolymers, ceramics, electronic materials,\nbiomaterials, and composites. Due to the diversity\nof useful properties encountered in materials\nengineering, attention must be given to application\nand peculiarities of these specific types of materials.\nWhere possible, however, a generalized approach\ntoward the study of materials, their properties, their\nselection, and their utilization is fostered. The broad-\nbased instructional approach prepares graduates for\ncareers in a wide range of industrial settings, from\naerospace companies to corporations specializing in\nthe production of solid state electronics. In addition,\nthe undergraduate curriculum prepares students for\ncontinued education at the graduate level.\nThe educational objectives of the undergraduate\nmaterials science and engineering program are\nas follows: (1) Graduates will meet or exceed the\nexpectations of employers of materials engineers;\n(2) Qualified graduates will pursue advanced study\nif they so desire; and (3) Graduates will pursue\nleadership positions in their profession and/or\ncommunities.\nThe School offers courses of study leading to the\ndegrees of Bachelor of Science in Materials Science\nand Engineering (accredited by the Engineering\nAccreditation Commission of ABET, www.abet.\norg) and the Master of Science in Materials Science\nand Engineering. The school participates in the\ninterdisciplinary programs leading to the Doctor of\nPhilosophy (Engineering Science, Materials Science\nand Engineering).\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nThe learning outcomes of the materials science\nand engineering undergraduate program are the\nfollowing:\n• An ability to identify, formulate, and solve\ncomplex engineering problems by applying\nprinciples of engineering, science, and mathematics.\n• An ability to apply engineering design to\nproduce solutions that meet specified needs with\nconsideration of public health, safety, and welfare,\nas well as global, cultural, social, environmental,\nand economic factors.\n• An ability to communicate effectively with a\nrange of audiences.\n• An ability to recognize ethical and professional\nresponsibilities in engineering situations and\nmake informed judgments, which must consider\nthe impact of engineering solutions in global,\neconomic, environmental, and societal contexts.\n• An ability to function effectively on a team\nwhose members together provide leadership, create\na collaborative and inclusive environment, establish\ngoals, plan tasks, and meet objectives.\n• An ability to develop and conduct appropriate\nexperimentation, analyze and interpret data, and\nuse engineering judgment to draw conclusions.\n• An ability to acquire and apply new knowledge as\nneeded, using appropriate learning strategies.\n• Ability to apply advanced science (such as\nchemistry and physics) and engineering principles\nto materials systems.\n• Integrated understanding of the scientific and\nengineering principles underlying the above\nfor major elements of the field, viz. structure,\nproperties, processing and performance related to\nmaterials systems appropriate to the field.\n• Ability to apply and integrate knowledge from\neach of the above four elements of the field to solve\nmaterials selection and design problems.\n• Ability to utilize experimental, statistical, and\ncomputational methods consistent with the goals\nof the program.\n\n297\nMechanical and Materials Engineering\nWashington State University, 2021\nADMISSION\nAdmission to the Mechanical Engineering\nprogram or Materials Science and Engineering\nprogram is processed by the School. The admission\nrequirements, including requirements for transfer\nstudents, are described in the WSU catalog in the\nschedules of studies for each major. Details for\nadmission can also be obtained by contacting the\nSchool directly.\nTRANSFER STUDENTS\nThe School of Mechanical and Materials\nEngineering cooperates with the community\ncolleges in Washington to minimize problems\nassociated with transfer. Inquiries are welcome. A\nstrong preparation in mathematics, physics, and\nchemistry is strongly recommended prior to transfer\nto minimize the time required at Washington\nState University to complete the bachelor’s degree\nrequirements.\nGRADUATE STUDY\nA p p l i c a n t s s h o u l d h a v e a B a c h e l o r o f\nScience degree from an accredited program in\nmechanical engineering or materials science and\nengineering. Students with bachelor degrees in\nother engineering disciplines, mathematics, and the\nphysical sciences are routinely admitted but may be\nrequired to meet additional course requirements.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nMATERIALS SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING\n(123 HOURS)\nAdmission Requirements\nTo be admitted into Materials Science and\nEngineering major, students must have 83%\nor higher ALEKS placement score (MATH) or\nCompletion of Math 106 and 108, 171 or higher\ncalculus course with “C” or better or Calc AP score\nof 2.\nTransferring students must satisfy all of the above\nadmission requirements. Students must earn a 2.6\nGPA in transferred major courses and have earned\na “C” or better in all transferred courses required\nfor the MSE degree.\nBenchmarks to Maintain Major in MSE\nStatus\nTo keep their status as Materials Science\nEngineering majors, students must: (1) maintain\n2.6 average GPA in major courses required for MSE\ndegree, (2) obtain grade “C” of better in all courses\nrequired for MSE degree. No more than one repeat\nper course is allowed in all ME and MSE courses\nrequired for MSE degree.\nMajor courses required for MSE degree include\nall ME, MSE, physics, chemistry, and math courses\nlisted in the schedule of studies.\nAny further questions should be addressed to\nthe Undergraduate Student Services office located\nin Sloan 205 or contact an MME academic advisor.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nME 116 2\nMSE 201 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 106 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 172 4\nMSE 202 3\nTechnical Elective\n1 \n3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nMATH 220 2\nMATH 273 2\nME 220 1\nMSE 316 3\nPHYSICS 201 3\nPHYSICS 211 1\nSecond Term Hours\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMATH 315 3\nMSE 241 3\nMSE 33X\n2 \n3\nPHYSICS 202 3\nPHYSICS 212 1\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nECONS 102 [SSCI] 3\nMSE 302 3\nMSE 321 3\nMSE 323 2\nMSE 413 3\nSTAT 370 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBiological Science [BSCI] 3\nMSE 318 3\nMSE 320 [M] 3\nMSE 33X\n2 \n3\nTechnical Elective\n1 \n3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 402 [WRTG] [M] 3\nME 312 3\nME 416 [CAPS] 3\nMSE Electives\n3 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMSE 425; or MSE 488 and ENGR 489 3\nMSE Elective\n3 \n3\nTechnical Elective\n1 \n3\nComplete Exit Survey\n_______\n1 \nTechnical Elective (Minimum of 9 credits, of which\n3 must be upper-division or 500 level): Any upper-\ndivision CE, CH E, CHEM, CPT S, E E, MATH, ME,\nMSE, or PHYSICS course not used to fulfill other\nrequirements (excluding ME 416), CE 211, and 215,\nEE 261, and 262, ME 212 and 216.\n2 \nMSE 33X (6 credits): Choose from MSE 331, 332,\nor 333.\n3 \nMSE Elective (9 credits): Any 300, 400, or 500-level\nMSE course except MSE 499 not used to fulfill other\nrequirements.\nMECHANICAL ENGINEERING\n(124 HOURS)\nAdmission Requirements\nTo be admitted into the Mechanical Engineering\nmajor, students must have earned an 83% or higher\nALEKS placement score (MATH), or completed\nMATH 106 and 108, 171 or higher calculus course\nwith “C” or better, or Calc AP score of 2.\nTransferring students must satisfy all of the above\nadmission requirements. Students must earn a 2.6\nGPA in transferred major courses and have earned\na “C” or better in all transferred courses required\nfor the ME degree.\nStudents transferring to degree-completion\nprograms in Bremerton and Everett branches must\nhave 2.6 average GPA in the following or equivalent\ncourses, each completed with grade “C” or better:\nCE 211, CE 215, CHEM 105, CPT S 121 or 131, E E\n221, ENGLISH 101, MATH 171, MATH 172, MATH\n220, MATH 273, MATH 315, ME 116, ME 212, ME\n241, PHYSICS 201 and 211, PHYSICS 202 and 212.\nBenchmarks to Maintain Major in ME\nStatus\nTo keep their status as Mechanical Engineering\nmajors, students must: (1) maintain a 2.6 average\nGPA in major courses required for ME degree, (2)\nobtain a grade of C of better in all courses required\nfor the ME degree. No more than one repeat per\ncourse is allowed in all ME and MSE courses required\nfor the ME degree.\nMajor courses required for the ME degree include\nall ME, MSE, physics, chemistry, and math courses\nlisted in the schedule of studies.\nGraduation Requirement\nMaintain a minimum 2.6 average GPA in major\ncourses required for the ME degree.\nConcentrations for BS in Mechanical\nEngineering\nStudents follow a General Path, or seek a\nconcentration in Thermo-fluids, Manufacturing,\nor Autonomous Systems.\nStudents are encouraged to consult with their\nadvisor at their campus of residence for approved\nalternative course sequences as well as allowed\nsubstitutions to the schedule studies.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGR Fundamentals of Engineering Exam\n_______\n1 \nRestricted Electives (at least 6 credits): Choose from\nME 310 and 311 or ME 312, ME 401, ME 405.\n2 \nConcentration Paths (9 credits): General\nConcentration: Three technical electives which may\ninclude the remaining restricted elective. Thermo\nFluids Concentration: Must take ME 405, and\neither ME 312 or 401 from the restrictive electives;\ntwo courses from ME 419, 431, 436, and 439; and\none additional technical elective. Manufacturing\nConcentration: Must take ME 312, and either ME\n401 or 405 from the restrictive electives; ME 474 and\n475; and one more technical elective. Autonomous\nSystems Concentration (must complete CPT\nS 121, 131, or ME 241 prior to beginning this\nconcentration): Must take ME 401, and either\nME 312 or 405 from the restrictive electives; two\ncourses from CPT S 122 or 132, and ME 481; and\none technical elective.\n3 \nTechnical Electives for concentrations: Any\n400-500-level ME, MSE, or EECS course not listed\nas a major requirement, and BIO ENGR 425.\nMinors\nMaterials Science and Engineering\nA minor in materials science and engineering\nrequires 16 credits which must include ME 220 and\nMSE 201. An additional 12 credits must be chosen\nfrom MSE 302, 316, 321, 401, 402, 403, 404, 406,\n413, ME 310, ME 311, or E E 496. 9 hours of upper-\ndivision work must be taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses.\nMechanical Engineering\nA minor in mechanical engineering requires 16\ncredits of 300-400-level ME courses, including two\nof the following four courses: ME 303, 304, 316,\n348. 9 hours of upper-division work must be taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nDescription of Courses\nMECHANICAL ENGINEERING\nME\n116 Engineering Computer-aided Design and\nVisualization 2 (0-6) Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 171 or concurrent enrollment.\nIntroduction to 3-D solid modeling, parts,\ndrawings, assemblies, multi-body parts, sketch\nediting, sheet metal, weldments, surface and\nmold tools.\n212 Dynamics 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 172\nor 182 with a grade of C or better; CE 211 with\na grade C or better. Kinematics and kinetics\nof particles and rigid bodies; introduction to\nmechanical vibration. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n216 Integrated CAD Design 2 (0-6) Course\nPrerequisite: ME 116 with a C or better; CE\n215 or concurrent enrollment. CAD based\nanalysis for engineering design, the application\nof motion, FEA and CFD, CAD simulations to\nthe engineering design process.\n220 Materials Laboratory 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: CE 215 or concurrent enrollment,\nor MSE 202 or concurrent enrollment.\nMechanical behavior of materials and\napplication to engineering structures.\n241 Engineering Computations 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 273 or concurrent\nenrollment; 4 credits of PHYSICS 201 or\nconcurrent enrollment, or PHYSICS 201 and\n211, or both with concurrent enrollment.\nIntroduction to the computational methods\nused for solving numerical problems in\nengineering. (Crosslisted course offered as ME\n241, MSE 241.)\n301 Fundamentals of Thermodynamics 3\nCourse Prerequisite: 4 credits of PHYSICS 201\nwith a grade of C or better, or PHYSICS 201 and\n211, both with a C or better. Thermodynamic\nproperties of matter, ideal and real gases,\nwork and heat, first and second laws and\ntheir application to engineering systems.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n303 Fluid Mechanics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nME 212. Fluid statics, laminar and turbulent\nflow, similitude, pipe flow, boundary layers,\nlift and drag and measurement techniques.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n304 Heat Transfer 3 Course Prerequisite: ME 301;\nME 303; admitted to the major in Mechanical\nEngineering. Conduction, radiation, and\nconvection heat transfer; analytical, numerical,\nexperimental results for solids, liquids, and\ngases; heat exchanger design. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n306 Thermal and Fluids Laboratory 2 (1-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: ME 301; ME 303; STAT\n370 or concurrent enrollment; admitted\nto the major in Mechanical Engineering.\nInstrumentation, data acquisition, and theory\nverification in the thermal and fluid sciences.\n310 Manufacturing Processes 2 Course\nPrerequisite: MSE 201; admitted to the major\nin Mechanical Engineering or Materials Science\nand Engineering. Manufacturing processes,\nmaterial fabrication, and nontraditional\nprocessing.\n311 Manufacturing Processes Laboratory\n1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: ME 310 or\nconcurrent enrollment; admitted to the major\nin Mechanical Engineering. Manufacturing\nprocesses laboratory in machining, welding,\nforming; manufacturing project.\n312 Manufacturing Engineering 3 (2-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: MSE 201; admitted to the\nmajor in Mechanical Engineering or Material\nScience Engineering.. Traditional and advanced\nmanufacturing processes for metals, plastics,\nand ceramics.\n313 Engineering Analysis 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 315 or concurrent\nenrollment; CE 215; ME 116; E E 221, CPT S\n121, CPT S 131, CPT S 251, ME 241, or MSE\n241. Analysis and modeling of engineering\nproblems utilizing numerical and mathematical\ntechniques and computers. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n316 Mechanical Component Analysis and\nDesign 3 Course Prerequisite: CE 215; ME\n216 or concurrent enrollment; ME 220 or\nconcurrent enrollment; admitted to the major\nin Mechanical Engineering. Optimal design of\nmachinery; analysis for prevention of machine\nelements failure.\n348 Dynamics Systems 3 Course Prerequisite:\nME 212; ME 313; admitted to the major in\nMechanical Engineering. Fundamentals of\nvibration analysis, control systems, system\nmodeling and dynamics analysis.\n\n299\nMechanical and Materials Engineering\nWashington State University, 2021\n401 Mechatronics 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nE E 262; ME 348; admitted to the major\nin Mechanical Engineering. Integration of\nmechanical and microprocessor-based systems;\ncontrol theory implemented with data\nacquisition systems; sensors; actuators, signal\nconditioning, programmable logic controllers.\n405 Thermal Systems Design 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ME 304; admitted to the major in\nMechanical Engineering. Design and analysis\nof thermofluid systems using principles of\nthermodynamics, fluid mechanics and heat\ntransfer.\n406 [M] Experimental Design 3 (1-6) Course\nPrerequisite: ME 220; ME 304; ME 306; ME\n348; admitted to the major in Mechanical\nEngineering. Designing, conducting, and\nreporting of experimental investigations\ninvolving mechanical equipment.\n407 Computational Fluid Dynamics 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ME 303. Basic concepts and\napplications of computational fluid dynamics\nto the analysis and design of fluid systems and\ncomponents.\n413 Mechanical Behavior of Materials 3\nCourse Prerequisite: CE 215 and MSE 201; OR\nMSE 202. Elasticity, elastic stress distributions;\nplastic deformation of single and polycrystals;\nintroduction to dislocation theory and its\napplications; creep, fracture, fatigue. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as MSE 413, ME 413).\n415 [M] Engineering Design 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ME 304 or concurrent enrollment;\nME 316 or concurrent enrollment and ME 348\nor concurrent enrollment; admitted to the\nmajor in Mechanical Engineering. Systems and\ncomponent design; product development from\nspecifications to manufacturing; team-based\nCAD design projects; engineering economics;\nengineering professional skills.\n416 [CAPS] Mechanical Systems Design 3\n(1-6) Course Prerequisite: Admitted major\nin Mechanical Engineering; ME 415; senior\nstanding; OR admitted major in Materials\nScience Engineering; MSE MSE 320; MSE 413\nor concurrent enrollment; one of MSE 401,\n402, or 403; OR admitted major in Materials\nScience Engineering; MSE 202 with a C or\nbetter; MSE 318 with a C or better; MSE 413\nor concurrent enrollment. Integrative design\nin mechanical engineering; multidisciplinary\ndesign project considering both technical\nand non-technical contexts; organizational\ndynamics and communications.\n419 Air Conditioning 3 Course Prerequisite: ME\n304. Principles of heat and moisture transfer;\nair motion and purity in buildings; design\nof systems. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n431 Design of Solar Thermal Systems 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ME 301; ME 303; ME\n304; admitted to the major in Mechanical\nEngineering. Design of solar thermal systems\nfor heating and cooling of buildings, heating\nof water, electrical generation, industrial\nprocesses and distillation.\n436 Combustion Engines 3 Course Prerequisite:\nME 301; ME 303. Internal combustion engines;\nspark ignition engines, diesels, and gas\nturbines.\n439 A p p l i e d A e r o d y n a m i c s 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: ME 303. Aerodynamic lift and\ndrag; circulation; boundary layers, application\nto subsonic aircraft wing design.\n449 M e c h a n i c a l V i b r a t i o n 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: ME 348. Vibrating systems and\nnoise producing mechanisms; design for noise\nand vibration control. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n461 Introduction to Nuclear Engineering 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MATH 315; admitted to\na major in engineering or physical sciences;\nsenior standing. Applied nuclear physics;\napplication to the nuclear fuel cycle and\nnuclear reactor core design; nuclear reactor\nsystems and safety. (Crosslisted course offered\nas ME 461, CHE 461).\n462 Introduction to Nuclear Engineering II\n3 Fundamentals of nuclear engineering, heat\ndeposition and removal from nuclear reactors,\nradiation protection, radiation shielding, and\nlicensing, safety, and environmental aspects of\nnuclear reactor operation.\n466 F u n d a m e n t a l s o f E n g i n e e r i n g\nExamination Review 1 Course prerequisite:\nAdmitted to a major in engineering or\ncomputer science. Review of engineering\nfundamentals and mechanical engineering\ndiscipline specific topics to prepare for the\nFundamentals of Engineering Examination. S,\nF grading.\n472 Finite Element Methods in Design 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ME 414. Design of selected\nmechanical systems components using finite\nelement analysis.\n473 Advanced CAD and Geometric Modeling\n3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite: ME 316. Parametric\nand feature based CAD/CAM; geometric\nmodeling and its mathematical basis;\nintegration of CAD with design processes and\nother software.\n474 Design for Manufacture and Modern\nManufacturing Strategies 3 Course\nPrerequisite: ME 310 or 312. Design for\nm a n u f a c t u r e a n d a s s e m b l y ; m o d e r n\nmanufacturing philosophies and practices;\nlean manufacturing; manufacturing cost and\ntime analysis; quality control. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n475 Manufacturing Enterprise Systems --\nAutomation and Product Realization\n3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite: ME 310 and 311,\nor ME 312. Manufacturing automation and\nproduct realization; information technology\nand electronic data in manufacturing enterprise\nsystems; product life-cycle management (PLM);\nsustainable and green manufacturing. Field trip\nto manufacturing industries required.\n481 Control Systems 3 Course Prerequisite: ME\n348. Analysis and design of feedback control\nsystems. Credit not granted for both ME 481\nand 581. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n483 Topics in Mechanical Engineering V 1\n(0-4) to 4 (0-16) May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 7 hours. An exploration\nof the Robot Operating System (ROS) and\nsolutions to simple AI problems using existing\nmachine learning frameworks.\n488 Professional Practice Coop/Internship\nI V 1-2 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. S, F\ngrading.\n495 Internship in Mechanical Industry V\n3-6 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 12 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Mechanical\nEngineering. By interview only. Students\nwork full time on engineering assignment in\napproved industries with industrial and faculty\nsupervision. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n501 C o n t i n u u m M e c h a n i c s 3 U n i f i e d\npresentation of principles common to all\nbranches of solid and fluid mechanics; viscous\nfluids, elasticity, viscoelasticity, and plasticity.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ME 501, MATH\n570.) Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n502 S u s t a i n a b i l i t y A s s e s s m e n t f o r\nEngineering Design 3 Sustainability\nassessment, including environmental,\nsocietal, and economic assessment, in design\nand planning for entire product life cycle.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n503 S y s t e m s D e s i g n A p p r o a c h e s f o r\nSustainability 3 Sustainability in systems\ndesign methodologies; systems modeling\nand decision-making for sustainability;\nmultidisciplinary design optimization; research\ntopics. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n507 Additive Manufacturing 3 Additive\nmanufacturing processes and their applications\nin ceramic, metallic, polymeric, and composite\nmaterials. Recommended preparation:\nBasic knowledge in materials science and\nmanufacturing. (Crosslisted course offered as\nMSE 507, ME 507). Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n509 MEMS Engineering 3 (2-3) Introduction\nto the design, fabrication and application\no f m i c r o e l e c t r o m e c h a n i c a l s y s t e m s .\n(Crosslisted course offered as ME 509, MSE\n509). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n\n300\nMechanical and Materials Engineering\nWashington State University, 2021\n513 Theory of Plasticity and its Physical\nFoundations 3 Phenomenological plasticity\nand viscoplasticity of polycrystalline metals\nand alloys, polymers and granular media;\ndeformation mechanisms; dislocation\nmechanics and interactions; dislocation\nmotion; slip and climb; crystal plasticity;\nsize effects and gradient models. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as MSE 513, ME 513, MATSE\n513). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n514 T h e r m o d y n a m i c s o f S o l i d s 3\nThermodynamic properties of solid solutions;\nmodels for substitutional and interstitial\ns o l u t i o n s ; c o n f i g u r a t i o n a l a n d n o n -\nconfigurational contributions; calculation of\nphase diagrams. (Crosslisted course offered as\nMSE 514, ME 514). Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n515 Convective Heat Transfer 3 Derivation of\nthe energy conservation equation; laminar and\nturbulent forced convection heat transfer with\ninternal and external flow; free convection.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n516 Conduction and Radiation Heat Transfer\n3 Principles of conduction and radiation heat\ntransfer with focus on solving conduction and\nradiation problems of engineering interest.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n517 Thin Films 3 Materials science aspect of thin\nfilms, including growth, characterization, and\nproperties for electrical, mechanical, corrosion,\nand optical behavior. (Crosslisted course\noffered as MSE 517, ME 517). Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n520 M u l t i s c a l e M o d e l i n g i n\nThermomechanics of Materials 3\nMultiscale problems in thermomechanics\nof materials; practical and computational\naspects of homogenization, granular materials,\ndislocation plasticity and atomistic methods.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ME 520, MSE\n520). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n521 Fundamentals of Fluids I 3 Governing\nequations of fluid mechanics accompanied\nby applications of Navier-Stokes equation to\nsimple flow situations, boundary layer analysis.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n525 Biomechanics 3 Methods for analysis of rigid\nbody and deformable mechanics; application\nto biological tissue, especially bone, cartilage,\nligaments, tendon and muscle. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as BIO ENG 425/525, ME 525).\nCredit not granted for more than one of BIO\nENG 425, BIO ENG 525, or ME 525.\n526 S t a t i s t i c a l T h e r m o d y n a m i c s 3\nMicroscopic development of equilibrium;\nclassical and quantum particle statistics;\nstatistical description of real and ideal gases,\nsolids, and liquids. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n527 M a c r o s c o p i c T h e r m o d y n a m i c s 3\nAdvanced thermodynamics from macroscopic\nviewpoint; basic postulates, equilibrium,\nstability, property relations; application to\nthermal-fluid and solid mechanics; irreversible\nthermodynamics. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n530 Elasticity 3 Theory of kinematics of solid\ndeformable bodies; conservation laws applied\nto an elastic continuum; generalized linear\nstress-strain behavior with applications.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ME 530, MSE\n530). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n531 Nanoscience and Nanotechnology 3\nOverview of nanoscience and nanotechnology\na n d t h e i r b i o m e d i c a l , e n e r g y, a n d\nenvironmental applications; structures,\nproperties, synthesis of nanoscale materials\nand fabrication of nanostructured devices.\n(Crosslisted course offered as MSE 531, MATSE\n531, ME 531.) Recommended preparation:\nBasic knowledge of materials, engineering,\nchemistry.\n532 Finite Elements 3 Theory of finite elements;\napplications to general engineering systems\nconsidered as assemblages of discrete elements.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CE 532, ME\n532). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n534 Mechanics of Composite Materials\n3 A n a l y s i s o f m i c r o m e c h a n i c a l a n d\nmacromechanical behavior of composite\nmaterials with emphasis on fiber-reinforced\ncomposite; prediction of properties; stiffness\nand strength theories; laminated beams and\nplates; dynamic behavior; environmental\neffects. (Crosslisted course offered as ME 534,\nMSE 534). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n537 Fracture Mechanics and Mechanisms 3\nFracture mechanics and mechanisms and the\nmicrostructural origins of toughness in metals,\npolymers and composites. (Crosslisted course\noffered as MSE 537, ME 537). Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n540 Advanced Dynamics of Physical Systems\n3 Newtonian dynamics, rotating coordinate\nsystems; Lagrangian and Hamiltonian\nmechanics; gyroscopic mechanics, other\napplications. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n556 Numerical Modeling in Fluid Mechanics\n3 Fundamental concepts in development\nof numerical models for fluid flow with\napplications to steady and unsteady flows.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n565 Nuclear Reactor Engineering 3 Reactor\npower distribution; thermal and exposure\nlimits; critical heat flux and pressure design;\nneutronic/thermal hydraulic relationships;\ntransient/accident analysis. Floyd College of\nMedicine\nmedicine.wsu.edu/\n412 E. Spokane Falls Blvd, Spokane, WA\n99202\n509-358-7944\nFounding Dean, J. Tomkowiak; Vice Dean for Research\nand Interim Chair, Department of Community and\nBehavioral Health, J. Roll; Vice Dean of Administration,\nAccreditation, and Finance (Chief Operating Officer), J.\nZimmerman; Special Advisor to the Dean, M. A. Clemens;\nSenior Associate Dean, Center for Interprofessional\nHealth Education Research & Scholarship (CIPHERS),\nD. DeWitt; Senior Associate Dean for Admissions\nand Student Affairs, L. E. Harrison; Senior Associate\nDean for Policy and Compliane, J. Hupp; Associate\nDean for Curriculum and Interim Associate Dean for\nFaculty Development, J. Espenschied; Associate\nDean for Clinical Education Everett, L. Schecter;\n\n303\nMedical Education and Clinical Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nAssociate Dean for Clinical Education Spokane and\nClinical Education Director, Mind, Brain and Behavior,\nM. Layton; Associate Dean for Clinical Education\nTri-Cities, F. Williams; Associate Dean for Clinical\nEducation Vancouver, J. Marcin; Assistant Dean for\nStudent Affairs, L. Burch-Windrem; Assistant Dean for\nCommunity Engagement, L. Francis; Assistant Dean for\nHealth Equity and Inclusion, D. Garcia; Assistant Dean\nfor Career Advising and Student Programs, K. Lindquist;\nAssistant Dean for Research, S. McPherson; Chair and\nProfessor, Department of Translational Medicine and\nPhysiology, K. Roberts; Interim Chair, Department of\nMedical Education and Clinical Sciences and Clinical\nEducation Director, Family Medicine, J. Haney; Chair\nand Professor, Nutrition and Exercise Physiology, G.\nDuncan; Intermim Chair and Professor, Department of\nSpeech and Hearing Sciences, A. Meredith.\nThe Elson S. Floyd College of Medicine is\nWashington’s community-based medical school.\nNamed after the University’s late president, Elson\nS. Floyd, the college was created to expand medical\neducation and health care access in communities\nacross the state of Washington. Under the direction\nof Founding Dean Dr. John Tomkowiak, the College\nof Medicine aims to meet its mission to solve\nproblems in challenging health care environments\nacross the state of Washington, all with a vision\nof Washingtonians living longer, better. Through\na culture based on valuing the individual, we are\nresourceful, agile, inventive and generous in serving\nthe people of the state and beyond, to develop\nhealthier populations through research, innovation,\ninterprofessional education and patient-centered\ncare.\nThe College of Medicine administration is\nlocated on the WSU Health Sciences Campus\nin Spokane with clinical campuses in Everett,\nSpokane, Tri-Cities and Vancouver. Employing a\ncommunity-based model in which students gain\nclinical experiences in hospital and health care\nsettings near the four campus locations, the college\nemphasizes training in the kind of environments\nwhere students will ultimately settle to practice as\nhealth care professionals. All campuses foster active\nlearning environments, interdisciplinary teaching,\nresearch, outreach, and clinical services.\nThe College consists of the Departments of\nTranslational Medicine and Physiology, Community\nand Behavioral Health, Medical Education and\nClinical Sciences, Nutrition and Exercise Physiology,\nand Speech and Hearing Sciences.\nThe Department of Translational Medicine and\nPhysiology is the central hub of foundational, and\ntranslational biomedical research at the Elson S.\nFloyd College of Medicine. Our faculty represent\na diverse set of interests, ranging from the\nneuroscience of sleep to cancer. Their work extends\nfrom cell and molecular physiology to behavioral\nstudies, and they employ a full range of model\nsystem as well as human subjects. The Department\nprovides research opportunities to graduate\nstudents in participating Ph.D. programs and to\nmedical students.\nThe Department of Community and Behavioral\nHealth focuses on addressing health at the\ncommunity level through research, patient care\nand degree programs, all of which align with\nthe University’s land-grant mission and extend\nthe College of Medicine’s reach. The department\nenables the college’s research enterprise to hone\ntheir focus in these areas and emphasize their\nbehavioral health work.\nThe Department of Medical Education and\nClinical Sciences delivers the MD program, training\nmedical students to be insightful and compassionate\nphysicians. It immerses students in a variety of\nreal-world and simulated learning environments\nthat provide them with the clinical and behavioral\ncompetencies to be successful in the future practice\nof medicine. In addition to preparing students to\ncare for individual patients, it readies them to take\nthe lead in addressing community healthcare issues.\nStudents learn to recognize problems in health care\ndelivery, innovate solutions, and mobilize change\nthat improves the health of entire populations.\nThe department also delivers two professional\ncertificates, the Certificate in Healthcare Leadership\nand the Certificate in Medical Ethics.\nThe Department of Nutrition and Exercise\nPhysiology focuses on the effects of nutrition\nand physical activity on human health. The\ninterdisciplinary program combines study in human\nnutrition, exercise physiology, and biological\nsciences, along with population, social and\npsychological sciences. Opportunities for research\nand applied, practical experiences are the core of\nthe instructional methods for both undergraduate\nand graduate students. The academic programs offer\ndegrees at the B.S., M.S. and Ph.D. levels.\nThe Department of Speech and Hearing Sciences\noffers programs leading to a Bachelor of Arts in\nSpeech and Hearing Sciences and a Master of\nScience in Speech and Hearing Sciences in speech-\nlanguage pathology. Training in speech and\nhearing sciences through the bachelor’s degree\nprepares students for a range of careers in health\nprofessions, education and social services, among\nothers. State and national clinical and educational\nlicensure and certification require completion of the\nmaster’s degree. Graduate students are prepared as\nspeech-language pathologists to provide direct and\nconsultative services in medical and educational\nsettings. The faculty’s research contributes to the\nevidence base of the profession, ensuring that future\ngenerations of professionals are prepared to provide\nthe best possible health care.\nDepartment of Medical\nEducation and Clinical\nSciences\nmedicine.wsu.edu/research/dcp/clinical-\nsciences/\nSpokane Academic Center, Room 401\n509-368-6578\nChair, Clinical Education Director, Family Medicine,\nand Clinical Associate Professor, J. Haney. WSU\nSpokane: Professors, J. Kennedy, M. G. McDonell, J.\nWisor; Associate Professors, N. Chaytor, S. McPherson;\nAssistant Professors, O. Oluwoye, L. Wood; Clinical\nProfessors, H. F. Andersen, B. Bray, H. Kaya; Clinical\nAssociate Professors, C. Anderson, J. Bowman, T.\nChauvin, M. Clemens, D. Conley, D. Cooper, C. Davis,\nW. Dittman, P. Dygert, J. Espenschied, R. Gersh, J.\nHaney, C. Heine, B. Hsu, D. Jackson, S. Joseph, A. Kim,\nA. Kumar, S. Logani, R. Nandagopal, S. Toro-Posada, B.\nWashington; Clinical Assistant Professors, S. Ahmad,\nK. Beine, S.
