Schneider, B. Sestero, S. Siddiqui,\nL. Sood, J. Troiano, J. M. Walker, S. Weeks, M. Zhang;\nResearch Assistant Professors, K. Hirchak, L. Kreigel, A.\nLamp, A. Miguel; Clinical Research Professor, T. May;\nAssociate Instructors, G. Ferguson, G. Kordas, A. Petras;\nAffiliate Associate Professors, W. Kabasenche; Affiliate\nAssistant Professor, D. DePriest. WSU Everett Clinical\nCampus: Associate Chair and Clinical Professor, L.\nSchecter; Clinical Assistant Professors, R. Beckley, S.\nQuade, K. Wyrick. WSU Pullman: Clinical Assistant\nProfessor, S. Lampa. Seattle: Associate Professor, P.\nJohansson; Assistant Professor, A. Fyfe-Johnson, C.\nMiller, A. Such-Dicey, A. Zamora-Kapoor; Research\nAssistant Professors, C. Carty, L. Hebert. WSU Spokane\nClinical Campus: Associate Chair TBD; Clinical\nAssociate Professors, R. Moon, H. Mroch; Clinical\nAssistant Professors, E. Burns, L. Gates. WSU Tri-\nCities Clinical Campus: Associate Chair and Clinical\nProfessor, F. Williams; Clinical Assistant Professors,\nK. Berger, P. Carrera, K. Kakumba. WSU Vancouver\nClinical Campus: Associate Chair and Clinical\nProfessor, J. Marcin; Clinical Assistant Professors, R.\nGreen, J. Hartinger, J. Sandhu.\nThe Department of Medical Education and Clinical\nSciences (DMECS) delivers the MD program and\nadministers two professional certificates, the\nCertificate in Leadership and the Certificate in\nMedical Ethics for the Elson S. Floyd College of\nMedicine. The department collaborates across\ndisciplines to prepare tomorrow’s physicians as\ncompassionate, community-engaged leaders,\ninnovators and change agents and to conduct\nresearch that advances the delivery of care. It unites\nfaculty members in a range of clinical disciplines\nand specialties. Together with the Dean and\nAdministration, and in collaboration with sister\nschools, colleges, and departments, the department\nworks to establish educational goals, plan course\ncontent, teach and conduct research.\nInvestigations conducted within the department\nare numerous and include the following (partial\nlist):\n• Population-based interventions to improve\nhealth care delivery\n• Clinical studies related to the delivery of\npersonalized care\n• Transdisciplinary investigations to address\nchallenges that span science, technology, and\nmedicine\n• Training medical students in research methods\nto improve clinical care\n• Medical education studies that lead to\ninnovations in physician training\nThe MD program is accredited by Northwest\nCommission on Colleges and Universities and by\nthe Liaison Committee on Medical Education.\nWashington State Licensure Requirements\nLicensure requirements vary by state. To obtain a\nmedical license in Washington state applicants are\nrequired to have graduated from an accredited or\napproved medical school and completed adequate\ntime in residency training. Applicants must pass all\nthree steps of the United States Medical Licensing\nExamination. A list of additional requirements for\nlicensure is available from the Washington State\nDepartment of Health website: www.doh.wa.gov.\n\n304\nMedical Education and Clinical Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nCollege of Medicine Program Core\nCompetencies\nThe College of Medicine program incorporates\ncore competencies that our faculty commits to\nteaching, and our students are expected to learn,\nwhich will be evaluated to ensure that all graduating\nstudents attain the appropriate level of mastery to\nsucceed in their careers.\nCore Competencies\nAll competencies must be achieved at a level\nsufficient for entry into graduate medical education,\nenabling students to lead, innovate, and solve\nproblems in challenging health care environments.\nMedical and Scientific Knowledge:\n• Demonstrates knowledge of established\nand evolving concepts in medicine including\nbiomedical, clinical, epidemiological, health\nsystems, and social-behavioral perspectives in the\ncare of patients and communities.\nPatient Care and Health Promotion:\n• P r o v i d e s e v i d e n c e - b a s e d c a r e t h a t i s\ncompassionate, culturally-appropriate, and\neffective for illness prevention, health promotion,\nmanagement, and treatment of disease, and\nimprovement in quality of life, including end-of-\nlife care.\nProfessionalism and Self-Awareness:\n• Demonstrates commitment and adherence to\nprinciples of the profession, and awareness of how\none’s own interests, personal biases, vulnerabilities,\nand limitation of knowledge.\nPractice-Based and Life-Long Learning:\n• Demonstrates the ability to appraise, assimilate,\nand incorporate scientific evidence and innovate,\nas needed, to evaluate and improve patient care\npractices based on continuous self-evaluation and\nlife-long learning.\nSystems-Based and Inter-Professional Practice:\n• Demonstrates awareness of and responsiveness\nto the larger context of health care, and the ability\nto call on system resources, including other health\ncare professionals, to provide optimal care.\nInterpersonal and Communication Skills:\n• Demonstrates effective information exchange\nand collaboration with patients, patients’\nfamilies, peers, other health professionals, and the\ncommunity to enhance care.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nDOCTOR OF MEDICINE (MD) CURRICULUM\n(178 HOURS)\nSPECIFICATION OF DEGREE REQUIREMENTS FOR\nGRADUATION WITH THE MD DEGREE\nThe requirements for the MD degree are established\nby the Elson S Floyd College of Medicine Faculty\nSenate. Those requirements are as follows:\nThe degree of Doctor of Medicine is awarded by the\nWashington State University Board of Regents upon\na student’s successful completion of the graduation\nrequirements, including recommendation of the\nchair of the Student Evaluation, Promotion &\nAwards Committee (SEPAC) to the Dean of the\nESFCOM. To graduate with the Doctor of Medicine\ndegree, ESFCOM students must meet the following:\n1. Be at least 21 years of age at the time the degree\nis awarded.\n2. Pass all required first year Foundations of\nMedical Science courses (MED FMS 501, MED FMS\n502, and MED FMS 503).\n3. Pass all required second year Foundations of\nMedical Science (MED FMS 511, MED FMS 512, and\nMED FMS 513).\n4. Pass all components of the Longitudinal\nIntegrated Clerkships (MED CLIN 521, MED CLIN\n522, MED CLIN 523, and MED CLIN 524).\n5. Pass one sub internship clinical rotation (MED\nCLIN 531, MED CLIN 532, MED CLIN 533, MED\nCLIN 534, MED CLIN 535, or MED CLIN 536).\n6. Pass the clinical rotation in Emergency\nMedicine (MED CLIN 537) and pass either the\nclinical rotation in Rural Medicine (MED CLIN 538)\nor the clinical rotation in Underserved Medicine\n(MED CLIN 539).\n7. Pass 24 additional elective credits (MED CLIN\n531-699).\n8. Take and pass United States Medical Licensing\nExams (USMLE) Step 1, Step 2(CS) Clinical Skills,\nStep 2(CK) Clinical Knowledge within the allotted\nnumber of attempts for each.\n9. Complete the ESFCOM Leadership in Medicine\nand Healthcare Certificate.\n10. Pass all Foundations of Scholarship and\nDiscovery courses (MEDSCHLR 500, MEDSCHLR\n520, and MEDSCHLR 540).\n11. Complete all requirements within six\nconsecutive academic years.\n12. Receive the SEPAC’s and Dean of the ESFCOM\nrecommendations for graduation and receipt of the\nMD degree.\nStudents must be in compliance with these\nconditions throughout the MD program and in\norder to complete the MD degree:\n1 . M e d i c a l H e a l t h R e q u i r e m e n t s a n d\nImmunizations: MD degree candidates must be in\ncompliance with health requirements at all times.\nEntering medical students must complete certain\nhealth-related forms, immunizations, and tests\nbefore beginning studies at the ESFCOM and, for\nsome of these, annually thereafter.\n2. Data Security and Privacy (HIPAA) Training:\nMD degree candidates must remain in compliance\nwith Elson S. Floyd College of Medicine’s HIPAA\ntraining requirement and information security\nrequirements.\n3. Demonstrate consistent evidence of\nprofessionalism as assessed by the SEPAC.\nSatisfaction of Technical Standards: To graduate,\nstudents must meet the requirements set forth in\nthe College of Medicine Technical, Non-Academic\nStandards. These Technical Standards include:\nObservation, Communication, Motor, Intellectual\n(Conceptual, Integrative and Quantitative Abilities),\nBehavioral/Social, and Task Completion.\nDegrees will be conferred once a year on\nCommencement Day in the spring. Students\ncompleting requirements for a degree prior to their\nscheduled degree conferral date will be conferred\nthe degree on the official Commencement Day, but\nmay request that the SEPAC Committee provides a\nwritten confirmation that the student has met all\ngraduation requirements.\nNote on licensure: Meeting the graduation\nrequirements for the MD degree at Elson S Floyd\nCollege of Medicine does not guarantee eligibility\nfor state licensure. Some states have specialized\ncurricular requirements for licensure, and students\nare advised to check with the Medical Board in states\nof possible residency for licensure requirements.\nThese requirements may be changed at any time\nto ensure that all graduates meet the required\nqualifications of a practicing physician.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMED FMS 501 14\nMED LMH 501 1\nSecond Term Hours\nMED FMS 502 13\nMED LMH 502 1\nMEDSCHLR 500 1\nThird Term Hours\nMED FMS 503 12\nMED LMH 503 1\nMEDSCHLR 500 1\nFourth Term Hours\nMEDSCHLR 520\n1 \n3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMED FMS 511 13\nMED LMH 511 1\nSecond Term Hours\nMED FMS 512 13\nMED LMH 512 1\nThird Term Hours\nMED FMS 513 11\nMED LMH 513 1\nFourth Term Hours\nMED CLIN 521 8\nMEDSCHLR 540\n1 \n3\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMED CLIN 522 14\nMED LMH 521 1\nSecond Term Hours\nMED CLIN 523 14\nMED LMH 522 1\nThird Term Hours\nClinical Rotation\n2 \n4\nMED CLIN 524 10\nMED LMH 523 1\nFourth Term Hours\nClinical Rotations\n2 \n8\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nClinical Rotations\n2 \n12\nMED LMH 531 1\nSecond Term Hours\nClinical Rotations\n2 \n8-12\nMED LMH 532 1\n\n305\nMedical Education and Clinical Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nThird Term Hours\nClinical Rotation\n2 \n4\nMED LMH 533 1\n_______\n1 \nThe listed pathway is one example of the\nsequencing of MEDSCHLR courses for 520 and\n540. Students need to take MED SCHLR 520 by the\nend of their third year. MED SCHLR 540 must be\ncompleted by the end of Winter term of their fourth\nyear (extensions past Winter term require approval).\nThe timing of enrollment in these courses is up to\nthe student’s discretion.\n2 \nThe Clinical Rotations must include one course\nfrom the series MED CLIN 531-536, and MED\nCLIN 537, and either MED CLIN 538 or MED CLIN\n539, and 24 credits from MED CLIN 531-699. The\nstudents have 10 time slots to complete these 36\ncredits. Students are required to take no fewer than\n8 credits of MED CLIN courses in the 4th year, First\nTerm and Second Term and no fewer than 4 credits\nof MED CLIN courses in 4th year, Third Term.\nCertificates\nMedical Ethics\nThe Certificate in Medical Ethics, in the Elson\nS. Floyd College of Medicine, is designed to\nprepare medical clinicians and ethics committee\nmembers to perform competent clinical ethics case\nconsultation in a hospital, long-term care, or clinic\nsetting. The Certificate consists of 12 credits divided\nbetween four courses, which are meant to be taken\nin sets of two concurrent 3-credits courses over one\nacademic year. One course per concurrent set is\ntaken entirely on-line, and the second is a seminar-\nstyle course taken both on-line and through live\ninteractive discussion either in-person or via web-\nconferencing. Fall semester courses consist of MED\nETH 500 Conceptual Foundations of Bioethics and\nMED ETH 510 Seminar in Conceptual Foundations\nof Bioethics. These courses take students through\nbasic tools of moral reasoning, including basic\nconcepts in logic (fallacies, validity and soundness,\netc.); descriptive and normative reasoning,\npositive and negative rights, basic approaches\nto morality (deontology and consequentialism,\npluralism, etc.) and definitions of equality, and\njustice. Spring Semester courses consist of MED\nETH 530 The Practice of Clinical Ethics and MED\nETH 540 Seminar in Clinical Ethics: Methods,\nProcess, Skills & Traits. These courses delve into\nthe practical aspects of case analysis and the practice\nof ethics consultation in the clinical setting, with\nparticular focus on the traditional range of topics\nin this emerging field of study (informed consent;\nsurrogate decision making; professional rights of\nconscience; concepts of welfare and quality of life,\netc.). During the seminar portion of this concurrent\nset of courses, students are taught the basic tools of\nchart writing, information gathering, and conflict\nresolution techniques essential to the conduct of\nethics case consultation in a clinical setting.\nHealthcare Leadership\nAcademic Requirements:\nPre-clerkship Curriculum: Students must\nsuccessfully complete all required courses in the\npre-clerkship curriculum (6 credits), MED LMH 501,\n502, 503, 511, 512, and 513. Clinical Curriculum:\nStudents must successfully complete all required\ncourses in the clinical clerkships (6 credits), MED\nLMH 521, 522, 523, 531, 532, and 533.\nAdditional Requirements:\nESFCOM Year 4: Capstone Leadership Paper/Project:\nStudents are required to complete a 10-page paper\nduring the 4th year (with a mentor/advisor). The\npaper must focus on lessons learned during the\nleadership certificate courses, medical school\nclerkships, research and/or healthcare-related\nvolunteer activities.\nIf combined with a student’s scholarly project,\nthe leadership portion must comprise a related,\nadditional 10-page analysis - i.e. this has to be a\nseparate paper or portion of the scholarly project.\nStudents wishing to combine their leadership\ncapstone paper with their scholarly project must\nreceive formal approval signed off by both the\nAssistant Dean for Medical Student Scholarship and\nthe Leadership in Medicine and Healthcare Course\nDirector.\nDescription of Courses\nFOUNDATIONS OF MEDICAL SCIENCE\nMED FMS\n501 Foundations of Medical Science I 14\n(5-18) Course Prerequisite: Admission to the\nMD Degree Program. Foundational anatomy,\nhistology, and introductory pathology;\nphysical exam, population health, clinical\nskills and ethics. S, F grading.\n502 Foundations of Medical Science II 13\n(7-12) Course Prerequisite: MED FMS 501.\nFoundational cell and molecular sciences,\nhematology and oncology; clinical skills. S, F\ngrading.\n503 Foundations of Medical Science III 12\n(7-10) Course Prerequisite: MED FMS 502.\nFoundational microbiology, infectious disease,\nand cardiovascular systems; clinical skills. S, F\ngrading.\n509 Special Topics in Medicine V 1-4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Course Prerequisite: By permission only.\nS, F grading.\n511 Foundations of Medical Science IV 13\n(7-12) Course Prerequisite: MED FMS 503.\nFoundational cardiovascular, respiratory,\ngastrointestinal, and renal systems; nutritional\nsciences; clinical skills. S, F grading.\n512 Foundations of Medical Science V 13\n(7-12) Course Prerequisite: MED FMS 511.\nFoundational nervous system, psychiatry, and\nbehavioral sciences; endocrine system; human\nreproduction; clinical skills. S, F grading.\n513 Foundations of Medical Science VI 11\n(5-12) Course Prerequisite: MED FMS 512.\nFoundational rheumatology; skin system;\nmusculoskeletal system; clinical immunology;\nclinical skills. S, F grading.\n514 Community Organizing for Health\nEquity 1 Course Prerequisite: By permission\nonly. Development of community organizing\nskills for social justice through participatory\nexercises, discussion, and short lectures. S, F\ngrading.\nMEDICAL CLINICAL TRAINING\nMED CLIN\n521 Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship I 8\nCourse Prerequisite: MED FMS 513. Covers\nthe seven core disciplines in medicine:\nfamily medicine, internal medicine, general\nsurgery, pediatrics, psychiatry, obstetrics\nand gynecology, and neurology; clinical\nexperiences will be interleaved throughout the\nentire sequence of LIC courses and will focus\non working with a small number of preceptors\nin each discipline for a continuity experience\nbetween teacher and learner.\n522 Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship\nII 14 Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 521.\nCovers the seven core disciplines in medicine:\nfamily medicine, internal medicine, general\nsurgery, pediatrics, psychiatry, obstetrics\nand gynecology, and neurology; clinical\nexperiences will be interleaved throughout the\nentire sequence of LIC courses and will focus\non working with a small number of preceptors\nin each discipline for a continuity experience\nbetween teacher and learner.\n523 Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship\nIII 14 Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 522.\nCovers the seven core disciplines in medicine:\nfamily medicine, internal medicine, general\nsurgery, pediatrics, psychiatry, obstetrics\nand gynecology, and neurology; clinical\nexperiences will be interleaved throughout the\nentire sequence of LIC courses and will focus\non working with a small number of preceptors\nin each discipline for a continuity experience\nbetween teacher and learner.\n524 Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship\nIV 10 Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 523.\nCovers the seven core disciplines in medicine:\nfamily medicine, internal medicine, general\nsurgery, pediatrics, psychiatry, obstetrics\nand gynecology, and neurology; clinical\nexperiences will be interleaved throughout the\nentire sequence of LIC courses and will focus\non working with a small number of preceptors\nin each discipline for a continuity experience\nbetween teacher and learner.\n530 Virtual - Clinical Cases 2 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 12 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524. A self-\ndirected online course involving review of\ncases selected by faculty in a specified specialty.\n531 Family Medicine - Subinternship 4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN\n524. Extension of knowledge and skills in\nthe evaluation and management of acute and\nchronic medical conditions treated by family\nphysicians. May include attendance at medical\nconferences.\n\n306\nMedical Education and Clinical Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n532 Internal Medicine - Subinternship 4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524.\nExtension of knowledge, skills, and range of\nmedical problems evaluated and managed in\na hospital or ambulatory setting.\n533 Surgery - Subinternship 4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN\n524. Knowledge, skills, and range of medical\nproblems related to common surgical issues in\nvarious surgical specialties.\n534 Pediatrics - Subinternship 4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 12\nhours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524 and\nat least 2 credits of MED CLIN 568; exceptions\ngranted by the Associate Dean for Curriculum\nor designee. Knowledge and skills in caring for\npediatric patients admitted to the hospital or\nambulatory setting; exposure to the wide range\nof medical diagnoses that lead to the admission\nof pediatric patients.\n535 Psychiatry - Subinternship 4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 12\nhours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524.\nKnowledge, skills, and attitudes necessary to\ndiagnose and treat a wide range of routine\npsychiatric, medical, and behavioral problems;\nexposure to the breadth of undifferentiated\npatient complaints presenting in both acute\nand chronic treatment settings.\n536 O b s t e t r i c s a n d G y n e c o l o g y -\nSubinternship 4 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 12 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: MED CLIN 524. Knowledge,\nskills, and range of women’s health issues\nwith concentration on common obstetrical\nand gynecological conditions; introduction\nto serious, less common conditions.\n537 Emergency Medicine - Emergency\nMedicine 4 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 12 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: MED CLIN 524. Knowledge,\nskills, and range of medical problems\ntreated by emergency physicians; breadth of\nundifferentiated patient complaints presenting\nin an acute setting.\n538 Core - Rural Medicine 4 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 12 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524. Caring for\npatients in communities with limited medical\nfacilities; issues related to referrals and transfers\nto tertiary care centers for more complex\nmedical problems and care coordination with\nlocal resources.\n539 Core - Underserved Medicine 4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 12\nhours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524. The\nhealth care issues of underserved populations\nand the complexities of providing for their\nmedical needs in challenging social situations;\ndisparities in the American health care system\nand challenges under-resourced patients face\nin meeting their medical needs.\n540 Virtual - Advanced Multi-Specialty\nClinical Cases 2 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 12 hours. A self-directed online course\ninvolving review of selected clinical cases and\nclinical skills modules across specialties.\n541 Clinical Rotation - Radiology V 2-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524;\nexceptions granted by the Associate Dean for\nCurriculum or designee. Medical imaging\nmodalities and imaging-guided treatments,\nincluding patient preparation, risks, costs, and\naccuracies.\n542 Clinical Rotation - Dermatology V\n2-4 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 12 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nMED CLIN 524. Disorders of the skin, mucous\nmembranes, hair, and nails, including\ncommon skin problems such as acne, atopic\ndermatitis, contact dermatitis, psoriasis,\ncutaneous infections, benign skin lesions, and\nmalignant lesions.\n543 Clinical Rotation - Physical Medicine\nand Rehabilitation V 2-4 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 12 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524. Diagnosis\nand treatment of patients with acute or chronic\npathology of the neuromusculoskeletal\nsystems.\n544 Internal Medicine - Nephrology V 2-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524.\nBreadth of nephrologic disorders as related to\nacute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease,\nhematuria, proteinuria, hyperparathyroidism,\nhypertension, electrolyte disorders, metabolic/\nacid-base disorders, and poisoning.\n545 Internal Medicine - Critical Care 4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN\n524. Breadth of complex patient conditions\npresenting acutely and throughout an\nintensive care stay.\n546 Surgery - Vascular Surgery V 2-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN\n524. Etiologies, pathophysiology, evaluation,\ntreatment, and follow-up care of commonly\nencountered vascular diseases; participation in\nsupervised patient care and learning activities\nin various environments.\n547 Internal Medicine - Cardiology V 2-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN 524.\nCardiac problems and pathology, including,\nbut not limited to, angina and other forms\nof chest pain, ischemic heart disease, chronic\nheart failure, other myocardial diseases and\narrhythmias.\n548 Surgery - Orthopaedic Surgery V 2-4 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Course Prerequisite: MED CLIN\n524. Basic tools of\nmoral reasoning, including basic concepts in\nlogic (fallacies, validity, and soundness, etc.);\ndescriptive and normative reasoning, positive\nand negative rights, basic approaches to\nmorality (deontology and consequentialism,\npluralism, etc.) and definitions of equality and\njustice.\n510 Seminar in Conceptual Bioethics 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admission to the Medical\nEthics Certificate Program. The traditional\nrange of bioethics topics (informed consent;\nsurrogate decision-making; professional rights\nof conscience; concepts of welfare and quality\nof life, etc.); basic tools of moral reasoning to\nanalyze these topics.\n530 The Practice of Clinical Ethics 3\nC o u r s e P r e r e q u i s i t e : M E D E T H 5 0 0 ;\nadmission to the Medical Ethics Certificate\nProgram Core competencies for healthcare\nethics consultation and the skills, knowledge,\nand background necessary for the effective\napplication of ethics to clinical cases; classic\ncases that have formed the cannon for\nbioethics, skills in negotiation, and conflict\nresolution, as well as communication, note\ntaking and charting skills.\n540 Seminar in Clinical Ethics: Methods,\nProcess, Skills & Traits 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to the Medical Ethics\nCertificate Program. Investigates the history\nof clinical ethics including the evolution of\nmedical ethics committees; introduction to\nsignificant medical legislation and the canon\nof case law in clinical ethics; moral reasoning,\nmediation, and negotiation skills will be\nhoned around sensitive, often controversial\nissues; several opportunities offered to practice\ncore sills and culminates in a clinical ethics\nsimulation.\n\n310\nMedical Education and Clinical Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nLEADERSHIP IN MEDICINE AND\nHEALTHCARE\nMED LMH\n501 Understanding Yourself as a Physician\nLeader 1 Course Prerequisite: Admission\nto the MD Degree Program. S, F grading.\nDepartment of\nTranslational Medicine and\nPhysiology\nm e d i c i n e . w s u . e d u / r e s e a r c h / d c p /\nbiomedical-sciences/\nP.O. Box 1495, Spokane, WA 99210\n509-368-6791\nChair and Professor, K. Roberts; Professors, M. G.\nFrank, J. Wisor; Associate Professors, L. Kapas, W. Li,\nJ. Sun, E. Szentirmai; Clinical Associate Professors, T.\nChauvin, C. J. Davis; Assistant Professors, J. Gerstner,\nD. Hansen, K. Honn, Y. Lee, Y. Liu, L. Peixoto; Clinical\nAssistant Professor, W. Vanderheyden; Research\nAssistant Professor, C. Hayworth; Scholarly Assistant\nProfessors, K. Courtney, B. Satterfield.\nThe Department of Translational Medicine and\nPhysiology is the central hub of foundational,\nand translational biomedical research at the\nElson S. Floyd College of Medicine. Our faculty\nrepresent a diverse set of interests, ranging from the\nneuroscience of sleep to cancer. Their work extends\nfrom cell and molecular physiology to behavioral\nstudies, and they employ a full range of model\nsystem as well as human subjects.\nThe Department provides research opportunities\nto graduate students in participating Ph.D. programs\nand to medical students.\nOur mission is to promote and support basic and\ntranslational research in biomedical sciences at the\nhighest level. To this end, we recruit talented and\ncollaborative scientists to our faculty and provide\nthem with state-of-the-art laboratories and core\nfacilities. We strive for discovery in the function\nof basic physiologic systems and their associated\ndisease states with an intent to translate our findings\nto improve human health.\nDescription of Courses\nBiomedical Sciences\nBIOMED\n550 Biochemistry for the Health Sciences\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to a WSU\ngraduate program in Health Sciences. Human\nhealth and health-related principles taught at\nthe biochemical level, including intermediary\nmetabolism, proteins, medical nutrition, and\ngene expression.\nDepartment of Military\nScience\nrotc.wsu.edu\nAvery 405\n509-335-7394\nDepartment Chair and Professor, LTC Matthew R.\nSheftic; Military Science MS1 Instructor, CPT Michelle\nM. Kelly; Military Science MS2 Instructor, CPT Adam P.\nMcWade; Military Science MS3 Instructor, SFC Michael\nC. Whittick; Assistant PMS/Instructor, CPT Lucas C.\nReece.\nThe Department of Military Science is the formal\ndesignation of the Army ROTC program at\nWashington State University. It is designed to\neducate, train, and motivate qualified students to\nserve as commissioned officers in the U.S. Army\nupon graduation. The military science department\noffers academic, professional, and technical\neducation and training that complements the\neducational programs and goals at WSU.\nThe military science curriculum comprises a two-\nyear basic course (freshman and sophomore years)\nand a two-year advanced course (junior and senior\nyears). The basic course is open to all WSU students.\nEnrollment in the advanced course is offered only\nwith the approval of the department chair and upon\ncompletion of basic courses.\nAt WSU, military science courses emphasize\ntraining in a practical environment. Students learn\nleadership skills through classroom instruction,\non-campus leadership labs, and summer training\nopportunities. The goal of this training is to develop\nleadership skills applicable in both military and\ncivilian occupations. During the summer, usually\nbetween the junior and senior year of academic\n\n311\nMolecular Biosciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nstudy, cadets must attend Advanced Camp at Fort\nKnox, KY. This is a 43-day leadership practicum\nadministered by Officers and NCOs of the U.S.\nArmy that develops and assesses the leadership\ncapabilities of the cadets.\nCompetitive, merit-based scholarships are\navailable to deserving individuals. These\nscholarships pay either Tuition and associated\nfees, or Room and Board. Scholarship winners\nalso receive $1200/year for books ($600 each\nsemester). Contracted cadets receive a monthly\nstipend of $420 per month. High school juniors\nmay apply for a four-year Army ROTC scholarship\nbeginning June 12th after their junior year, with a\ndeadline of January 10th of their senior year of high\nschool. Students at WSU may apply for campus-\nbased scholarships if they meet GPA, medical and\nphysical requirements.\nHigh school students may also join ROTC by\nenlisting into the Army National Guard or Army\nReserves and simultaneously serving as a cadet in\nthe Simultaneous Membership Program (SMP) while\nenjoying all of the financial benefits that accompany\nthe program. Additionally, special scholarships are\navailable for SMP Cadets who pursue a commission\ninto the Army Reserves through Guaranteed Reserve\nForces Duty (GRFD) scholarship. Prospective cadets\ninterested in the SMP Program should also inquire\nabout the tremendous benefits of yet another type\nof scholarship called the Minuteman Scholarship.\nUpon successful completion of the advanced\ncourse and graduation from WSU, cadets are\ncommissioned as U.S. Army officers and serve in\nthe Active Duty Army, the Army Reserves, or the\nArmy National Guard. For more information, please\ncontact Mr. Timothy A. Tate at (509)-308-9676 or\ntim-tate@wsu.edu.\nMinors\nMilitary Science\nA Military Science minor requires 18 hours of\napproved Military Science courses, with at least 9\nhours of 300-400-level credits taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. Students must\ntake the following courses to complete this minor:\nMIL SCI 101, 102, 201, 202, 301, 302, 401, and 402.\nDescription of Courses\nMILITARY SCIENCE\nMIL SCI\n101 The United States Army 1 Role of the Army\nin contemporary society.\n102 National and International Role of\nthe Army 1 Role of the Army in today’s\ninternational affairs.\n110 Cougar Rangers I 1 Military adventure\ntraining, pioneering activities, military skills\nand small unit tactics. Field trip required.\n111 Cougar Rangers II 1 Military adventure\ntraining, pioneering activities, military skills\nand small unit tactics. Field trip required.\n201 I n t r o d u c t i o n t o L e a d e r s h i p 2\nMultidisciplinary approach to military\nleadership.\n202 The Officer as a Professional 2 U.S. Army\nOfficer Corps as a profession; the U.S. Army\nOfficer as a professional.\n301 Applied Leadership and Management 3\nCourse Prerequisite: By instructor permission.\nTroop leadership procedures emphasizing\ninstruction in military professionalism\nand ethics; practical aspects of tactics and\nleadership practicum.\n302 Small Unit Tactics and Militar y\nLeadership 3 Course Prerequisite: By\ninstructor permission. Preparation, delivery,\nand critique of practical oral presentations;\nleadership of small units; offensive and\ndefensive operations.\n320 Leadership Development Assessment 6\n(0-18) Course Prerequisite: MIL SCI 301; MIL\nSCI 302. By interview only. Intensive study and\ninternship in military tactics, command and\nleadership; held at Fort Lewis, WA. S, F grading.\n396 Leader Internship 6 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. By interview only. Fully\nfunded non-committal leader internship and\nArmy orientation; provides leader training\nand assessment. May be taken as MGTOP 498,\nPOL S 497, PE ACTIV 201, or ED AD 499 with\npermission. S, F grading.\n401 Advanced Military Leadership 3 Course\nPrerequisite: By instructor permission.\nHistorical and legal basis of military\njustice; small unit management; military\nprofessionalism and ethics.\n402 Advanced Military Management and\nPracticum 3 Course Prerequisite: By\ninstructor permission. Theory and practice\nof Army administration/management;\nstaff planning and correspondence; pre-\ncommission orientation; unit management/\nresources application.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\nSchool of Molecular\nBiosciences\nsmb.wsu.edu\nBiotechnology-Life Sciences 102\n509-335-1276\nDirector and Regents Professor, M. Griswold; Senior\nAssociate Director and Professor, M. Konkel; Associate\nDirector for Graduate Program and Associate Professor,\nJ. Watts; Associate Director for Undergraduate Programs\nand Associate Professor, E. Offerdahl; Associate Director\nfor Alumni Relations and Clinical Associate Professor, P.\nMixter; Director of PSM Program and Clinical Professor,\nN. McCabe; Assistant Director for Undergraduate\nLaboratories and Clinical Associate Professor, C.\nHelmick; Regents Professor, M. Smerdon; Professors,\nJ. Alderete, R. Brosemer, T. Hassold, P. Hunt, M. Klotz\n(Tri-Cities), J. Oatley, J. Wyrick, L. Xun; Associate\nProfessors, C. Cooper (Vancouver), W. Davis, L. Gloss,\nA. Goodman, C. Haseltine, C. Her, S. Roberts, E.\nShelden, S. Sylvester (Vancouver); Assistant Professors,\nR. Driskell, W. Winuthayanon; Clinical Professor, M.\nSanchez-Lanier; Clinical Assistant Professors, J. Hinz,\nM. Rolfsmeier; Instructor, J. Arneson.\nMolecular biosciences can be viewed as a dynamic\ncontinuum in which approaches derived from\nbiology, chemistry, and physics are utilized to\naddress the fundamental mechanisms of living\nthings. The School of Molecular Biosciences (SMB)\noffers undergraduate majors in biochemistry,\ngenetics and cell biology, and microbiology.\nThe School of Molecular Biosciences also offers\nundergraduate minors in biochemistry, genetics\nand cell biology, microbiology, molecular biology,\nand pre-genetic counseling. Requirements for these\nmajors and minors are detailed below.\nAt the graduate level, the school offers programs\nleading to the degrees of Master of Science and\nDoctor of Philosophy in Molecular Biosciences. The\nSchool also offers a Professional Science Master’s\ndegree in Molecular Biosciences that can be earned\neither on the Pullman Campus or through WSU\nGlobal Campus. In addition the school offers a\ncombined undergraduate degree in Genetics and\nCell Biology and PSM in Molecular Biosciences.\nAt the undergraduate level, we expect that\nour graduating students will possess: 1) an\nunderstanding of the major concepts in the\nmolecular biosciences and an awareness of how these\nconcepts are integrated from the molecular to the\norganismal level; 2) the necessary critical thinking\nand quantitative reasoning skills, and the ability to\napply those skills, to identify and solve biological\nproblems at the cellular, molecular, and structural\nlevels; 3) the oral and written communication\nskills necessary to effectively communicate key\nscientific findings in the molecular biosciences to\nboth non-scientific and professional audiences;\n4) the scientific literacy necessary to become an\ninformed citizen of a diverse, ever changing, global\nsociety, and to engage in a lifetime of scientific\nlearning; and 5) the relevant ethics education and\nexposure necessary to encourage the highest levels\nof professionalism and humanism.\nSTUDENTS PURSUING PRE-MEDICINE,\nPRE-DENTAL, PRE-PHARMACY, PRE-\nPHYSICIAN ASSISTANT OR PRE-\nVETERINARY MEDICINE\nThe majors in the School of Molecular Biosciences\nprovide a perfect home for the student who is\ninterested in pursuing professional education\nafter graduating from WSU. Our degrees have\nbeen designed to prepare students to succeed\nin these professional programs, as well as on the\nlatest versions of the standardized examinations\nfor admission to professional programs. Pre-\nprofessional students majoring in SMB are advised\nby a faculty member or professional advisor in the\nSchool and additionally work with a professional\nspecialist from the Health Professions Student\nCenter.\nStudents from all three SMB undergraduate majors\nhave been successfully admitted to professional\nprograms in human medicine, veterinary medicine,\nphysician assistant, pharmacy, and dentistry.\n\n312\nMolecular Biosciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nThe Biochemistry degree is a perfect match for\npre-pharmacy students and highly motivated\nstudents should consider our 7-year Fast track\nB.S. Biochemistry-PharmD program offered in\ncooperation with the WSU College of Pharmacy and\nPharmaceutical Sciences. Pre-veterinary medicine\nstudents can elect to pursue any SMB major, and\nhigh-achieving students should consider the 7-year\nHonors Fast track B.S. Microbiology to DVM\nprogram. Students interested in either of these fast\ntrack programs should contact the School for more\ninformation.\nBIOCHEMISTRY\nBiochemistry is an interdisciplinary science\nthat applies the methods and theories of chemistry\nto understand chemical reactions in living\norganisms. Biochemists seek to understand life at\nall levels, from individual molecules inside cells\nto complex interactions within ecosystems. An\nundergraduate major in biochemistry will prepare\nyou for a variety of careers including biotechnology,\ndrug design, science policy, bioinformatics, forensics,\ngenetic counseling, health professions, science\ncommunication, and so many more! Biochemistry\nmajors will be able to apply the principles of\nbiochemistry, biophysics, and molecular biology\nto answer questions in a wide range of research areas\nincluding protein biochemistry, molecular biology\nof gene regulation, enzymatic reaction mechanisms,\nsignal transduction, DNA repair, reproductive\nbiology, DNA-protein interactions, plant and\nnatural product biochemistry, and structural\nbiology including nuclear magnetic resonance\n(NMR) spectroscopy and x-ray crystallography.\nThe program offers two curricular options leading\nto the Bachelor of Science in Biochemistry. The\nbiochemistry/biophysics option provides increased\nemphasis on chemistry, physics, mathematics,\nand physical biochemistry, and yields a minor in\nchemistry. The biochemistry/molecular biology\noption provides increased emphasis on molecular\nand cell biology.\nGENETICS AND CELL BIOLOGY\nGenetics and cell biology are interrelated sciences\nthat are fundamental to all fields of modern\nbiology. Undergraduates who major in genetics\nand cell biology will be well versed in aspects of\nthe rapidly emerging fields of genomics, epigenetics,\nproteomics, bioinformatics and molecular signaling.\nThe program affords students the opportunity to\nlearn from and interact with scientists whose diverse\nresearch programs include the genetics of cancer\nand development, chromosome abnormalities,\nDNA repair mechanisms, stem cell biology and the\nbiology of reproduction. Our faculty work with\na diverse group of model organisms including C.\nelegans, Drosophila, zebrafish, mice and rats, as\nwell as using cell culture, plants, and microbial\nexperimental systems. Graduates of the degree\nwill be prepared to work in careers that traditionally\nmay not have required science training including:\nscience communication, forensics, law enforcement,\ncommunity outreach science organizations and\nscience policy development. In addition, students\nwill be trained for positions as researchers in\nbiotechnology companies, within healthcare and\nin academic institutions. This degree also prepares\nstudents for entry into graduate programs leading\nto Master’s, Professional Science Master’s and PhD\ndegrees in a variety of disciplines including the\nbroad areas of molecular biology, molecular genetics\nand cell biology. In addition, students will also be\nwell prepared to enter the professions of medicine,\ndentistry, veterinary medicine, physician assistant,\ngenetic counseling and education.\nMICROBIOLOGY\nMicrobiology is both a basic and an applied science\nthat studies microorganisms and their activities. It is\nconcerned with their form, structure, reproduction,\nphysiology, and identification. It includes the study\nof their distribution in nature, their relationship\nto each other and to other living things, their\nbeneficial and detrimental effects on human beings,\nand the physical and chemical changes they make\nin their environment. Employment opportunities\nin industrial, government, hospital, and private\nlaboratories and agencies are excellent for qualified\ngraduates. Areas in which the unit is prepared to\ndirect research include bioremediation, molecular\ngenetics, molecular basis of cell-cell interactions\nand pathogen virulence, microbial differentiation,\ncellular immunology and the regulation of the\nimmune response.\nThe Microbiology degree program offers options\nin either molecular biology or medical technology,\nleading to the Bachelor of Science degree in\nMicrobiology. An additional year in an accredited\nschool of clinical laboratory sciences is required\nafter graduation for those interested in becoming\ncertified clinical laboratory scientists.\nADMISSION TO THE MAJOR\nREQUIREMENTS:\nA student may be admitted to a School of\nMolecular Biosciences major (biochemistry, genetics\nand cell biology, or microbiology) upon making\ntheir intention known to the department. Please\nreference the schedule of studies for additional\ninformation on maintaining good standing for\neach major.\nGRADUATION REQUIREMENTS:\nA grade of C or better is required in all MBIOS\ncourses taken to meet graduation requirements.\nNone of these courses may be taken pass/fail.\nSTUDENT LEARNING OUTCOMES\nFor the Biochemistry, Genetics and Cell Biology, and\nMicrobiology Degree Programs:\nBefore Graduating with a degree from SMB, a\nstudent will achieve these learning outcomes:\nGlobal\n• Be competitive for professional and graduate\nstudies and/or employment.\nKnowledge\n• Identify the modern foundational knowledge\nunderlying Biochemistry, Cell Biology, Genetics,\nand Microbiology.\n• Recognize relevant ethical concepts related to\nscientific publication and research conduct.\nSkills\n• Perform basic laboratory techniques used in\nmolecular bioscience research (e.g. light microscopy,\ngel electrophoresis, PCR, and protein analysis).\n• Design, perform, and quantitatively/qualitatively\nevaluate the results of laboratory experiments.\n• Locate, retrieve, and evaluate scientific\ninformation, especially primary literature, with\nregards to its adequacy, value, and logic.\n• Prepare oral and written reports in standard\nscientific formats.\nAttitudes\n• Decide that studying the molecular biosciences is\nrewarding and relevant to everyday life experiences.\n• Appreciate the importance of the ethical\nimplications of scientific issues in society.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBIOCHEMISTRY - BIOPHYSICS OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to a School of Molecular\nBiosciences Biochemistry major upon making their\nintention known to the department. To remain in\ngood standing, a student must meet the following\ntwo requirements:\n• Complete BIOLOGY 106, BIOLOGY 107, CHEM\n105 and CHEM 106, MBIOS 301, MBIOS 303, MBIOS\n305, or transfer equivalents, with a minimum grade\nof C.\n• After 30 credits, maintain a minimum cumulative\nGPA of at least 2.5.\nA Biochemistry major who falls below the\nminimum requirements will be released from the\nprogram according to Academic Regulation 53.\nA grade of C or better is required in all MBIOS\ncourses taken to meet graduation requirements.\nNone of these courses may be taken pass/fail.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] or 107 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 106 (accelerated) or Elective\n1 \n3\nMATH 108 (accelerated) or Elective\n1 \n2\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 or 107 4\nCHEM 106 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 345 4\nMATH 172 4\nMBIOS 201 [COMM] 3\nMBIOS 301 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 348 4\nMBIOS 303 4\nPHYSICS 201 3\nPHYSICS 211 1\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\n\n313\nMolecular Biosciences\nWashington State University, 2021\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nPHYSICS 202 3\nPHYSICS 212 1\nMBIOS 305 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 347 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMBIOS 304 3\nMBIOS 401 3\nMBIOS 465 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 220 2\nCHEM 222 2\nMBIOS 413 3\nMBIOS 466 or PHYSICS 466 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nMBIOS 414 3\nMBIOS 454 [M] 3\nMBIOS 494 [M] [CAPS] 3\nElectives 9\nExit Survey\n_______\n1 \nIf required - consult advisor.\nBIOCHEMISTRY - MOLECULAR BIOLOGY\nOPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to a School of Molecular\nBiosciences Biochemistry major upon making their\nintention known to the department. PHYSICS 466.\nBIOCHEMISTRY – ACCELERATED PRE-\nPHARMACY OPTION\n(133 HOURS)\nThis option has been established for admission\nof highly academically qualified students to the\nDoctor of Pharmacy (PharmD) program in the\nWashington State University College of Pharmacy.\nThe program of study consists of three years of\nundergraduate coursework that fulfills the pre-\npharmacy Biochemistry requirements followed\nby the four-year PharmD Program. Satisfactory\ncompletion of this 7-year curriculum leads to the\nBachelor of Science (B.S.) in Biochemistry and\nDoctor of Pharmacy (PharmD) degrees.\nEarly admission to the PharmD program requires\napproval of the WSU Pharmacy Admissions\nCommittee.\nAdmission requirements for the Biochemistry –\nAccelerated Pre-Pharmacy option include:\n• Completion of BIOLOGY 106, BIOLOGY 107,\nCHEM 105, and CHEM 106 or 116 with a minimum\ngrade of C\n• A minimum cumulative GPA of 2.50 A minimum\nof 24 credits at WSU\n• Students must complete a minimum of 90\nundergraduate credits including 30 credits of upper-\ndivision coursework, and 30 credits (1st year) of\nthe PharmD coursework, as specified, to earn the\nBachelor of Science in Biochemistry.\nA grade of C or better is required in all MBIOS\ncourses taken to meet graduation requirements.\nNone of these courses may be taken pass/fail.\nCompleted core requirements may not be used to\nsatisfy lecture or lab electives.\nFirst MBIOS 410, 413, 426, 440, 442, 450, 503.\nMICROBIOLOGY – HONORS ACCELERATED\nPRE-VETERINARY OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nThis option has been established for admission\nof highly academically qualified students to the\nDoctor of Veterinary Medicine (D.V.M.) program\nat the Washington State University College of\nVeterinary Medicine (CVM). The program of study\nconsists of three years of undergraduate coursework\nthat fulfills the pre-veterinary microbiology\nrequirements followed by the four-year D.V.M.\nProgram. Satisfactory completion of this 7-year\ncurriculum leads to the Bachelor of Science (B.S.)\nin Microbiology and Doctor of Veterinary Medicine\n(D.V.M.) degrees.\nAll students who qualify for admission to\nthe WSU Honors College are eligible to apply\nfor pre-admission to the College of Veterinary\nMedicine after one year of Honors pre-veterinary\nmicrobiology curriculum. Interested applicants\nshould identify themselves to the Honors College\nas soon as they decide to enroll at the University\nbecause the number of available seats in the B.S./\nD.V.M. Program is limited. Early admission to the\nD.V.M. Program requires approval of the CVM\nAdmissions Committee. Accepted students are\npre-admitted directly to the D.V.M. program. To\nmaintain pre-admission into the D.V.M. Program,\naccepted students must achieve an overall grade\npoint average of 3.50 or better in all undergraduate\ncoursework.\nStudents may be admitted to the Microbiology –\nAccelerated Pre-Veterinary option after completing\na minimum of 30 semester credits in residence\nat WSU with a 2.5 cumulative GPA, and a grade\nof C or better in each of the following courses:\nBIOLOGY 106; BIOLOGY 107; CHEM 105; CHEM\n106 or 116. Completion of the degree requires\ncompletion of Honors curriculum; a minimum of 90\nundergraduate credits including 30 upper-division\ncredits; and one year of DVM coursework.\nA grade of C or better is required in all MBIOS\ncourses taken to meet graduation requirements.\nNone of these courses may be taken pass/fail.\nCompleted core requirements may not be used to\nsatisfy lecture or lab electives.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 4\nCHEM 105 4\nENGLISH 298 4\nForeign Language (if needed)\n1 \n0-4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 106 or 116\n2 \n4\nHONORS 270 To remain in\ngood standing, a student must meet the following\ntwo requirements:\n• Complete BIOLOGY 106, BIOLOGY 107, CHEM\n105 and CHEM 106, MBIOS 301, MBIOS 303, MBIOS\n305, or transfer equivalents, with a minimum grade\nof C.\n• After 30 credits, maintain a minimum cumulative\nGPA of at least 2.5.\nA Microbiology major who falls below the\nminimum requirements will be released from the\nprogram according to Academic Regulation 53.\nA grade of C or better is required in all MBIOS\ncourses taken to meet graduation requirements.\nNone of these courses may be taken pass/fail.\nCompleted core requirements may not be used to\nsatisfy lecture or lab electives.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] or 107 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 106 (accelerated) or Elective\n1 \n3\nMATH 108 (accelerated) or Elective\n1 \n2\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 or 107 4\nCHEM 106 4\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 140 [QUAN] or 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 345\n2 \n4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMBIOS 301 4\nSecond Term Hours\nMBIOS 303 4\nMBIOS 305 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nMBIOS 304 3\nPHYSICS 101 or 201 3\nPHYSICS 111 or 211 1\nSTAT 212 or 412 3 or 4\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nMBIOS 410 3\nMBIOS 450 3\nPHYSICS 102 or 202 3\nPHYSICS 112 or 212 1\nElectives 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 418 4\nMBIOS 404 3\nMBIOS 430 [M] 3\nMBIOS 440 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nMBIOS 411 [M] 3\nMBIOS 442 3\nMBIOS 494 [M] [CAPS] 3\nElectives 5\nExit Survey\n_______\n1 \nIf required - consult advisor.\n2 \nCHEM 345 and 348 recommended for professional\nor graduate degrees.\nMICROBIOLOGY – MOLECULAR BIOLOGY\nOPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to a School of Molecular\nBiosciences Microbiology major upon making their\nintention known to the department. BIOLOGY 418, ENTOM 343, FS 416.\nMinors\nBiochemistry\nA minor in biochemistry requires 17 hours including\nCHEM 348; MBIOS 303, 304, 413; MBIOS 414, 465,\nor CHEM 331. A grade of C or better is required in\nall courses used in the minor. None of these courses\nmay be taken pass/fail. Credit hours for the minor\nmust include 9 hours of upper-division work taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nGenetics and Cell Biology\nA minor in genetics and cell biology requires\n16 credits under the genetics and cell biology degree\nprogram at the 300-400-level, including MBIOS 301,\n401, and 478. Additional credits may be selected\nfrom MBIOS 402, 404, 423, and no more than one\nfrom ANIM SCI 330, BIOLOGY 321, 335, CROP SCI/\nHORT 445, NEUROSCI 305, or PHIL 365. 9 credits\nof upper-division work must be taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses. A grade of C or\nbetter is required in all course work for the minor.\nMicrobiology\nA minor in microbiology requires a minimum of 16\ncredit hours including MBIOS 305, 304 or 306, and\nthe remaining selected from: MBIOS 342, 404,\n410, 411, 426, 430, 440, 442, 446, 450, 548, FS\n416. 9 hours of upper-division work must be taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nA grade of C or better is required in all course work\nfor the minor.\nMolecular Biology\nA minor in molecular biology requires 20 hours\nincluding the following courses: MBIOS 301, 305,\n303, 304; MBIOS 401 or 450; MBIOS 404, 413, or\n440. A grade of C or better is required in all course\nwork for the minor. Credit hours for the minor\nmust include 9 hours of upper-division work taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nA student whose major is in the School of Molecular\nBiosciences cannot be granted a minor in molecular\nbiology.\nPre-Genetic Counseling\nA minor in pre-genetic counseling requires 19 - 23\nhours including MBIOS 301, 423, PHIL 365, PSYCH\n321 or 333, 440 or 444, 445, one of PSYCH 311,\nSTAT 212, 360, or 412. A grade of C or better is\nrequired in all course work for the minor. Credit\nhours for the minor must include 9 hours of upper-\ndivision work taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses.\nCertificates\nMolecular Biosciences\nThe Certificate in Molecular Biosciences requires\na minimum of 18 hours. Students are expected to\nhave already completed courses equivalent to one\nyear of freshman chemistry for science majors; one\nyear of freshman biology for science majors; and\none semester of organic chemistry; all through an\naccredited institution of higher education before\nworking towards this certificate. The 15 hour core\nis: MBIOS 101 or 305 and 306, or 304 and 305;\nMBIOS 301; MBIOS 303; and MBIOS 320. 3 hours\nof electives are selected from: ANTH 468, BIOLOGY\n140, BIOLOGY 330, CRM J 320, MBIOS 342, PHIL\n103, or 365. A grade of C or better must be earned\nin all classes that apply towards this certificate.\nMost of the courses required for this certificate\nhave prerequisites. Please consult the catalog to\nassure that these prerequisites have been met prior\nto registering for courses.\nDescription of Courses\nMOLECULAR BIOSCIENCES\nMBIOS\n101 [BSCI] Introductory Microbiology 4\n(3-3) Course Prerequisite: Not intended for\nmajors in the School of Molecular Biosciences.\nMicrobiology for the informed citizen as it\nimpacts humans and their environment. Basic\nprinciples of modern and classical genetics\nutilizing several species.\n404 Molecular Biology 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMBIOS 301; MBIOS 303; MBIOS 305 or\nconcurrent enrollment. Credit not granted for\nboth MBIOS 405 and 505.\n410 Medical Microbiology 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMBIOS 305; MBIOS 404 or concurrent\nenrollment. Microbial pathogens and their\nrelationship to disease.\n\n317\nMolecular Biosciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n411 [M] Diagnostic Medical Bacteriology 3\n(1-6) Course Prerequisite: MBIOS 304; MBIOS\n410 or concurrent enrollment. S, U grading.\nProgram in Molecular Plant\nSciences\nmps.wsu.edu\n324 French Administration Bldg.\n509-335-7619\nChair and Professor, M. M. Neff; Professors, J. A.\nBrowse, R. S. Brueggeman, I. C. Burke, A. B. Cousins,\nA. Dhingra, D. R. Gang, K. S. Gill, S. H. Hulbert, M. L.\nKahn, A. Kalyanaraman, C. H. Kang, M. Knoblauch,\nN. R. Knowles, B. M. Lange, N. G. Lewis, T. W. Okita,\nH. Pappu, J. Peters, B. W. Poovaiah, E. Roalson, M.\nTegeder; Associate Professors, J. W. Busch, A. H. Carter,\nH. A. Hellmann, H. Kirchhoff, A. J. McCubbin, M.\nPumphrey, S. Roje, A. Smertenko, J. J. Wyrick; Assistant\nProfessors, S. P. Ficklin, M. Friesen, C. Gleason, H. H.\nKunz, K. Sanguinet, K. Tanaka, Z. Zhang; Adjunct\nProfessors, K. G. Campbell, W. Chen, D. W. Crowder,\nP. A. Okubara, C. M. Steber, L. S. Thomashow.\nGraduate study leading to the Doctor of Philosophy\ndegree is offered as an interdepartmental curriculum\nby graduate faculty from the Departments of\nCrop and Soil Science, Electrical Engineering and\nComputer Science, Horticulture and Landscape\nArchitecture, Molecular Biosciences, Plant\nPathology, Biological Sciences, and the Institute\nof Biological Chemistry. The objectives of the\nprogram are to provide the graduate student with\na broad knowledge in molecular plant sciences\nand with research experience in a chosen area\nwithin this discipline. Specialization includes\ncellular and subcellular physiology, the molecular\nbiology and biochemistry of plant-related processes,\nphotosynthesis and photorespiration, nitrogen\nfixation, phytochemistry, the physiology of vascular\nplants, metabolism, plant pathogen interactions,\nhormonal interactions and regulation of growth,\ncrop production physiology, and physiological\necology as well as related areas in agriculture and\nbiology.\nStudents entering the program must have\ncompleted their baccalaureate degree with training\nin one year each of elementary biology or botany,\nand physics, chemistry through one semester of\norganic chemistry and biochemistry, one semester\n\n319\nMusic\nWashington State University, 2021\neach of molecular plant sciences and genetics,\nand mathematics (through calculus). Limited\nundergraduate deficiencies may be remedied by\ntaking the appropriate courses upon enrollment\nin the graduate program on a provisional basis.\nDegree requirements include courses in molecular\nbiology, advanced molecular plant sciences, plant\nmorphology and anatomy, and metabolism. To\nmeet the minimum requirements of core course\ncredit in the Graduate School, elective courses are\nchosen as approved by the student’s advisor and the\nsupervising committee of graduate faculty. There is\nno foreign language requirement.\nPolicies and procedures of the Graduate School\napply to all admissions. Interested students may\ndirect their inquiries to molecular plant sciences\nor to any participating faculty member. Should the\nlatter route be followed, preference for the Program\nin Molecular Plant Sciences must be indicated and,\nif possible, the research area of interest identified.\nThe program offers flexibility for students with\nvaried backgrounds in chemistry, biochemistry,\nmolecular plant sciences, molecular biology,\nbotany, genetics, biology, and the agricultural\nsciences to pursue advanced training in molecular\nplant sciences, with independent study and original\nresearch in areas of the student’s own interests\nas the single most important component. The\ninterdisciplinary nature of the program assures\nthe student of interaction with molecular plant\nscientists representing a wide range of research\ninterests and provides the student with a broad\nchoice of specialized facilities which are available\nin the cooperating academic units.\nStudents are typically supported by the program\nduring the first academic year. Financial support\nduring subsequent years will be managed by the\nadministering academic unit. Participating faculty\nmay provide support through individual grants\nand contracts. Every effort will be made to inform\napplicants of these opportunities.\nCourse requirements are drawn from existing\ncourses offered by MPS and cooperating departments\nand programs. In addition, a seminar is held weekly\nduring each semester.\nThe Objectives and Outcomes of the\nProgram\nTo enable students to develop as successful\nprofessionals in a collaborative, interdisciplinary\nenvironment as preparation for highly competitive\npositions in industry, government, and academia,\nthe program aims to provide a variety of experiences\nthat help students to:\n• Achieve mastery of knowledge in the general\nfield of molecular plant sciences and the highest\nlevel of expertise in a specific, defined area of this\nfield\n• Develop the expertise to use molecular\ntechnology to solve novel and emerging problems\nrelated to plant and agricultural sciences\n• Present research to local, regional, national,\nand international audiences through publications\nin professional journals and conference papers\ngiven in a range of venues and to a diverse type\nof audience\n• Participate in professional organizations,\nbecoming members, attending meetings, and taking\nleadership roles where appropriate\n• Broaden their professional foundations through\nactivities such as teaching, internships, fellowships,\nand grant applications\nTo prepare students to be effective and innovative\nresearchers in the field of molecular plant sciences,\nthe program aims to provide a variety of experiences\nthat help students to:\n• Become independent, self-motivated researchers\nwith the ability to recognize problems in their field\nof expertise and formulate solutions to the problems\n• Develop a comprehensive knowledge of previous\nand current research in their field of expertise and\nbe able to demonstrate that knowledge capably in\na review of the literature\n• Generate viable questions within their field of\nexpertise and pose problems or hypotheses related\nto those questions\n• Apply sound research methods to problems in\nmolecular plant sciences and describe the methods\neffectively\n• Perform statistical analyses of research data and\npresent the results in a way that makes clear sense\nof the data\n• Discuss the solution to the research problem or\nthe support or lack of support for the hypothesis in\na way that effectively documents the contribution\nof the research to the area of study\nTo enhance visibility of the doctoral program\nin molecular plant sciences nationally and\ninternationally, the program aims to:\n• Attract and retain high-quality students\n• Provide effective mentoring that encourages\nstudents to graduate in a timely manner\n• Place graduates in positions in academia,\nindustry, and government\n• To attract, retain, and support nationally-\nrecognized research-active faculty actively involved\nin the molecular plant sciences graduate program\nDescription of Courses\nMOLECULAR PLANT SCIENCES\nMPS\n515 Seminar in Molecular Plant Sciences\n1 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 4 hours. A cross-discipline seminar,\nincluding botany, crop and soils sciences,\nhorticulture, plant pathology, and molecular\nplant sciences. S, F grading.\n525 Plant Molecular Genetics 3 Introduction\nto plant genome organization and gene\nexpression while acquiring knowledge\nof modern molecular techniques and\nexperimental approaches.\n561 Biochemical Signaling in Plants,\nAnimals and Microorganisms 3 Course\nPrerequisite: MBIOS 513. New research on\nintra and extra cellular biochemical signaling,\nincluding communication in plants and\nhormone action in animals. (Crosslisted course\noffered as MBIOS 561, MPS 561).\n570 Advanced Topics in Molecular Plant\nSciences 1 May be repeated for credit;\nc u m u l a t i v e m a x i m u m 3 h o u r s . O r a l\npresentation of a current research paper. S, F\ngrading.\n574 Protein Biotechnology 3 Biotechnology\nrelated to the isolation, modification and large\nscale commercial production, patenting and\nmarketing of useful recombinant proteins and\nproducts. (Crosslisted course offered as MPS\n574, CHE 574, MBIOS 574). Recommended\npreparation: MBIOS 513.\n587 Advanced Topics in Plant Biochemistry\n1 Methods of plant phenotyping.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Dissertation and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe Molecular Plant Science PhD program.\nIndependent research and advanced study for\nstudents working on their doctoral research,\ndissertation and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n800 credit. S, U grading.\nSchool of Music\nmusic.wsu.edu\nKimbrough 260\n509-335-3898\nDirector of the School of Music and Associate Professor,\nD. Luethi; Regents Professor, G. Yasinitsky; Professors,\nK. McCarthy, D. Turnbull; Associate Professors, T.\nBennefield, S. Blasco, R. Boden, D. Pham, S. Scott, J.\nWieck, H. A. Young; Assistant Professors, C. Dickey,\nF. Menchetti, M. Myers, C. Rodriques, D. Singleton,\nJ. Wilson; Clinical Associate Professor, B. Edwards,\nM. King, S. Miller, M. Parkhurst; Clinical Assistant\nProfessors, A. Agulay, A. Miller, Y. Roh, D. Snider, J.\nSvendsen, S. Tegart.\nThe School of Music prepares students for careers\nin music with degrees in performance, composition,\nand music education. It is accredited by the National\nAssociation of Schools of Music.\nThe School of Music at Washington State\nUniversity prepares its students to be successful,\ninnovative, and employable musicians in a 21st-\ncentury career field.\nActing as local and global ambassadors, our\nstudents and faculty embrace the WSU land-grant\nmission by promoting musical curiosity, cultural\nawareness, and critical engagement through artistic\ncreation, pedagogy, and scholarship.\n\n320\nMusic\nWashington State University, 2021\nWe serve diverse communities across the wide\nreach of the WSU institution, through a musical\npractice that is fundamental to emotional wellness,\nconstructive dialogue, and self-reflection.\nPerformance Studies in Music\nPerformance studies are offered on several levels\nto meet the needs of music majors as well as those\nof students from the general university community.\nThere are no additional fees or tuition charges\nfor the use of practice facilities. The 100-level\nperformance studies are open to any student\nwithout audition through class instruction. The\n200-level denotes group or private instruction for\nadvanced non-music majors by special permission\nof the department chair (audition required).\nIndividual instruction in performance studies is\noffered at the 300- and 400-level for music majors\nand, by special permission of the department\nchair, to advanced non-music majors who meet\nall requirements for music majors as listed below.\nAll students enrolled in 200-400-level performance\ninstruction are required to attend weekly\nconvocation (student recital), attend recitals as\nrequired, participate in at least one approved\nmusic department ensemble, and take applied\njury examinations at the end of each term. A small\ntuition charge is assessed per 200-400-level course,\nnot dependent on total credits. Students enrolled in\n300- and 400-level performance study must enroll\nin a music theory or music history course each\nsemester until music core requirements have been\ncompleted. No student will be permitted to enroll\nin 300-400-level performance studies unless these\ncriteria are met. In addition, each music major must\npass the piano proficiency exam, as a precondition\nto upper-division standing.\nPerformance studies may not be taken on a pass-\nfail basis.\nBachelor of Arts\nThis program is designed to offer a broad musical\nunderstanding within a liberal arts background.\nWe expect that our graduating students be able\nto: 1) demonstrate mastery of music theory (an\nunderstanding of organizational patterns of\nmusic and their interaction, and of musical forms\nand structures and the ability to employ this\nunderstanding in aural, verbal, and visual analyses);\n2) competently perform on an instrument of choice\n(including voice) and effectively communicate on\nthe literature for that instrument and for appropriate\nensembles, and demonstrate a basic performance\nproficiency on the piano; 3) critically evaluate the\nhistory and development of music through the\npresent time and place music in historical, cultural\nand stylistic contexts; 4) comprehend the basics of\nnon-Western music and/or jazz, and demonstrate a\nrudimentary capacity to create derivative or original\nmusic both extemporaneously and in written\nform; and 5) work independently on a variety of\nmusical problems by combining their capabilities\nin performance, analysis, composition and\nimprovisation, and history and repertory. Students\noften elect a minor in another field.\nBachelor of Music\nThis program offers majors for specialization in\nperformance, composition and music education.\nThe curriculum is designed to prepare students as\nprofessional musicians, teachers, and practitioners\nof music. We expect that our graduating students\nbe able to: 1) demonstrate mastery of music theory\n(an understanding of organizational patterns of\nmusic and their interaction, and of musical forms\nand structures and the ability to employ this\nunderstanding in aural, verbal, and visual analyses);\n2) competently perform on an instrument of choice\n(including voice) and effectively communicate on\nthe literature for that instrument and for appropriate\nensembles, and demonstrate a basic performance\nproficiency on the piano; 3) critically evaluate the\nhistory and development of music through the\npresent time and place music in historical, cultural\nand stylistic contexts; 4) comprehend the basics of\nnon-Western music and/or jazz, and demonstrate\na rudimentary capacity to create derivative or\noriginal music both extemporaneously and in\nwritten form; and 5) work independently on a\nvariety of musical problems by combining their\ncapabilities in performance, analysis, composition\nand improvisation, and history and repertory.\nMusic Performance and Composition\nThis major offers professional preparation\nin music with specialization in performance\nor composition. The curriculum is designed to\nprepare students to become professional performers\nin their respective major instrument or voice, or\nprofessional composers. Students following options\nin performance or composition are required to\npresent an acceptable senior recital in the major\nperformance medium, or compositions for\ncomposition majors. Students following options\nin performance are also required to present an\nacceptable junior recital in the major performance\nmedium. Students pursuing Performance in Jazz\nStudies are limited to specific major performance\ninstruments as stated in the degree description.\nMusic Education\nThis program offers professional preparation\nin music with specialization in music education.\nThe curriculum is designed to prepare students as\nprofessional teachers of music. Students following\nany of the music education or elective studies\noptions are required to present an acceptable senior\nhalf recital in the major performance medium.\nStudents following any of the music education\noptions must have a minimum GPA of 2.5 in all of\nthe following areas: cumulative GPA, Professional\nEducation Core with a C or better in each course,\nand academic major (and minor if any) with a C or\nbetter in each course. Students admitted as majors\nin any of the music education options must also\nbe admitted as majors in the College of Education.\nBachelor of Music in Music Education,\noption without endorsement\nThis degree provides valuable, current, and\nmarketable options for students seeking pre-\nprofessional training in music, and in music\neducation. Students in this option may opt to\napply for the MA program of study in music at WSU\nwhere they may elect to complete courses required\nfor a teaching endorsement and state certification.\nAdmission to graduate school and the School of\nMusic graduate program following completion\nof this degree is determined by application on an\nindividual basis.\nMaster of Arts in Music\nPlease consult the current WSU Graduate Study\nBulletin. For students pursuing the combined BM/\nMA with teacher certification in Music, please\nconsult the department.\nSchedule of Studies\nNormal progress in all music degree curricula\nrequires enrollment during the freshman year in\n300-level performance studies. Such enrollment\nrequires an audition which is best completed\nduring the semester (usually spring) prior to the\nstudent’s matriculating in the university. Students\nwho do not audition early must do so during the\nfirst week of classes in the term. Normal progress\nalso assumes placement in 200-level music theory.\nTheory placement tests will be administered as\npart of the performance audition. Students who do\nnot qualify for 300-level performance studies and\n200-level theory studies as freshmen will usually\nrequire more semesters and credits of performance\nstudies to complete a degree than listed in this\nschedule of studies.\nTo be admitted as a major pursuing any degree in\nmusic, students must meet the following criteria:\nCompletion of 24 credits; cumulative GPA of 2.0;\ncompletion of 10 credits with a cumulative GPA\nof 2.0 and a grade of C or better in those courses\nselected: MUS 151, 181, 182, 251, 252, 253, 254,\nand up to four credits of applied study; approval\nof the appropriate applied study area coordinator;\n[approval requires two semesters’ study as specified\nby each area: Keyboard at 300 level with grade of\nB- or better, Brass and Percussion at 300 level with\ngrade of B- or better, Woodwinds at 300 level with\ngrade of B- or better, and Voice at 200 level with\ngrade of B- or better]; completion of application\navailable from department. Students not passing\nthe upper-division exam after the second attempt\nmay not continue as music majors.\nIn addition the College of Education requires\n2.5 GPA and C or better in each course listed for\nthe major, minor and professional core, plus a 2.5\ncumulative GPA, of students advancing in any of\nthe Bachelor of Music in Music Education curricula.\nAs indicated in the requirements listed under\nthe various majors and options for the Bachelor\nof Music degree and the Bachelor of Arts degree in\nMusic, each student must satisfactorily complete all\nmusic courses with a minimum 2.5 GPA and a grade\nof C or better in each music course. Each student\nis required to pass the piano proficiency exam and\nthe junior and/or senior qualifying exam, with the\nexception of those students enrolled in the Bachelor\nof Arts degree (the B.A. degree requires completion\nof MUS 182 with a C or better). Students must also\ncomplete the UCOREs plus those for the College of\nArts and Sciences.\nStudent Learning outcomes\n• Critical, Creative and Musical Reasoning: This\nincludes learning to analyze and interpret music, to\nexpress the composer’s intention, the character of\nthe music and to convey the emotion of the work.\n• Quantitative and Symbolic Reasoning: This\ninvolves taking the abstract symbols on the page\nand making musical sense of them, interpreting\nthe rhythmic and pitch elements of the music and\nmaking expressive choices based on the notation\non the page.\n• I n f o r m a t i o n L i t e r a c y : M u s i c i a n s m u s t\n\n321\nMusic\nWashington State University, 2021\nunderstand the historical and cultural aspects of\nthe music that they are performing to present a\nmusically and artistically convincing performance.\nAlso, students must become familiar with a wide\nrange of important works from the musical canon.\n• Communication: A musical performance is not\nsuccessful unless there is communication with the\naudience.\n• Diversity: To perform music of different styles\nand genres, it is essential to understand diverse\ncultures and musical views. This is related to\ninformation literacy.\n• Integration of Learning: For a musical\nperformance to be truly successful, all of these\nLearning Outcomes—creative thinking, symbolic\nreasoning, information literacy, communication\nand diversity must be integrated by the performer.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBACHELOR OF ARTS IN MUSIC\n(120 HOURS)\nThis four-year program is designed to meet the\nneeds of students wishing a broad liberal arts\nbackground with a major in music. Of the total\n120 credits required for a degree in this program,\n50 credits are in music and 70 credits are devoted\nto courses outside music, including the University\nCommon Requirements (UCOREs). Non-music\ncourses other than those used for the UCOREs must\nbe at the 200-level or above. 40 credits of the 120\nrequired for the degree must be in 300-400-level.\nOther requirements include: achieve a cumulative\n2.5 GPA and a grade of C or better in all music\nclasses; senior qualifying exam; piano proficiency\nexam or grade of C or better in MUS 182.\nOnly 9 credits of MUS courses can be used to fulfill\nUCORE requirements.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMUS 164 1\nMUS 181\n2 \n0 or 1\nMUS 251\n3 \n3\nMUS 252\n3 \n1\nMUS Ensemble\n4 preparation\noption must have a minimum GPA of 2.5 in all of\nthe following areas: cumulative GPA, Professional\nEducation Core with a C or better in each course,\nand academic major (and minor if any) with a C\nor better in each course. groups\n(MUS 429, 430, 431).\nOnly 9 credits of MUS courses can be used to fulfill\nUCORE requirements.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nForeign Language, if
