282 1\nTCH LRN 467 [M] 3\nTCH LRN 469 2\nTCH LRN 470 3\nSenior Half Recital\nFifth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMUS 497 4\nTCH LRN 415 12\n_______\n1 \nApplied Music: 14 credits required with a\nminimum of 2 credits at the 400 level. Approved\ncourses include MUS 301-318, 320, 401-418, 420.\n2 \nClass piano credits not required in degree.\n3 \nFall only.\n4 \nMusic Ensemble: 6 credits of MUS 428-444 with a\nminimum of 4 credits choral (MUS 429, 430, 431).\n5 \nOne from ENGLISH 201, 301, 302, or 402 is\nrequired for admission to the Teacher Education\nProgram. Students who take ENGLISH 302 will need\nto take an additional [WRTG] or [COMM] course.\n6 \nSpring only.\n7 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n8 \nCourse taught alternate years.\nMUSIC EDUCATION - CHORAL/\nINSTRUMENTAL/GENERAL ENDORSEMENT\nOPTION\n(140 HOURS)\nStudents following any teacher preparation option\nare required to present an acceptable senior half\nrecital in the major performance medium.\nStudents following any teacher preparation\noption must have a minimum GPA of 2.5 in all of\nthe following areas: cumulative GPA, Professional\nEducation Core with a C or better in each course,\nand academic major (and minor if any) with a C\nor better in each course. Students must also be\nadmitted into the College of Education.\nStudents must pass the Piano Proficiency\nExam, pass the senior qualifying exam, achieve a\ncumulative 2.5 GPA and a grade of C or better in\nall music classes, and a 2.5 GPA and a grade of C or\nbetter in all College of Education Professional Core\ncourses. Class piano credits are not required for the\ndegree. Instrumentalists must complete 4 credits in\nvocal performance studies (private lessons and/or\nensemble) and vocalists must complete 4 credits of\ninstrumental performance studies.\nThis option provides teacher certification in\ndesignated arts: music (choral, instrumental, and\ngeneral). Requirements include: C or better in all\nmusic and education courses; 2.5 music average;\n2.5 education average; 2.5 overall average; 4 credits\nvocal performance for instrumentalists; 4 credits\ninstrumental performance for vocalists; senior\nqualifying exam, piano proficiency, solo half-\n\n323\nMusic\nWashington State University, 2021\nrecital. Approved performing groups: a minimum\nof 1 credit during each of 7 semesters, to include at\nleast one semester of MUS 435 for instrumentalists\nand 428, 433, or 439 for vocalists. Within the 7\nsemesters/credits, a minimum of 2 credits in choral\nensembles (MUS 429, 430, or 431) and 2 credits in\ninstrumental ensembles (MUS 434, 436, 437, or\n438).\nOnly 9 credits of MUS courses can be used to fulfill\nUCORE requirements.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nForeign Language, if needed 0-4\nMUS 164 1\nMUS 181\n2 \n0 or 1\nMUS LRN 415 12\n_______\n1 \nApplied Music: 14 credits required with a\nminimum of 2 credits at the 400 level. Approved\ncourses include MUS 301-318, 320, 401-418, 420.\n2 \nClass piano credits not required in degree.\n3 \nFall only.\n4 \nMusic Ensemble: 6 credits required from MUSIC\n428-444 with a minimum of 2 credits choral (MUSIC\n429, 430, 431) and 2 credits instrumental (MUSIC\n434, 436, 437, 438)\n5 \nOne from ENGLISH 201, 301, 302, or 402 is\nrequired for admission to the Teacher Education\nProgram. Students who take ENGLISH 302 will need\nto take an additional [WRTG] or [COMM] course.\n6 \nSpring only.\n7 \nCourse taught alternate years.\n8 \nStudents are not required to take the second-level\ntechniques course of their major instrument.\n9 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\nMUSIC EDUCATION - ELECTIVE STUDIES\nIN EDUCATION OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nStudents following any teacher preparation option\nare required to present an acceptable senior half\nrecital in the major performance medium.\nStudents following any teacher preparation\noption must have a minimum GPA of 2.5 in all of\nthe following areas: cumulative GPA, Professional\nEducation Core with a C or better in each course,\nand academic major (and minor if any) with a C\nor better in each course. Students must also be\nadmitted into the College of Education. Since this\noption is likely to lead to enrollment in the MA\nin Music, students are advised that admission to\ngraduate study requires a 3.0 cumulative GPA.\nStudents must pass the Piano Proficiency\nExam, pass the senior qualifying exam, achieve a\ncumulative 2.5 GPA and a grade of C or better in\nall music classes, and a 2.5 GPA and a grade of C or\nbetter in all College of Education Professional Core\ncourses. Class piano credits are not required for the\ndegree. Instrumentalists must complete 4 credits\nin vocal performance studies (private lessons and/\nor ensemble) and vocalists must complete 4 credits\nof instrumental performance studies. Approved\nPerforming Ensembles: See degree requirements\nfor applicable (desired) endorsement.\nThis option provides professional preparation in\nmusic combined with studies in education. Students\nmay complete teacher certification requirements\nafter completion of this degree through further\nenrollment as undergraduate second degree\ncandidates, enrollment as post-baccalaureate non-\ndegree students, or as graduate students, each of\nwhich requires application for admission. Students\nplanning to seek admission and enroll as graduate\nstudents should, at the beginning of their last\nsemester of undergraduate study, complete the\nnecessary form to count selected courses in the final\nundergraduate semester toward the graduate degree,\nup to a maximum of 6 credits.\nAs stated above, this option may lead to one\nof three paths to achieve teacher certification\nin designated arts: Music (choral, instrumental,\nand general). If a student elects to pursue teacher\ncertification, requirements include: C or better in\nall music and education courses; 2.5 music average;\n2.5 education average; 2.5 overall average; 4 credits\nvocal performance for instrumentalists; 4 credits\ninstrumental performance for vocalists; upper-\ndivision exam, piano proficiency, solo half-recital.\nApproved performing groups: a minimum of 1\ncredit during each of 7 semesters, to include at least\none semester of MUS 435 for instrumentalists and\n428 for vocalists. Include a minimum of 2 credits\nin choral and 2 credits in instrumental performing\ngroups. Note that during the second term of the\nsenior year, only 10 credits are taken toward the\ndegree. Students must enroll in 12 credits to be full\ntime and may enroll in graduate credits if preparing\nto enroll in the MA degree program.\nOnly 9 credits of MUS courses can be used to fulfill\nUCORE requirements.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n2 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMUS 164 1\nMUS 181\n3 \n0 or 1\nMUS 251\n4 \n3\nMUS 252\n4 \n1\nMUS Ensemble \n5 \n1\nSecond Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\n\n324\nMusic\nWashington State University, 2021\nMUS 182\n3 \n0 or 1\nMUS 190 1\nMUS 253\n6 \n3\nMUS 254\n6 \n1\nMUS Ensemble \n5 \n1\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n2 \n4\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nMUS 103 or 319 2\nMUS 281 0 or 1\nMUS 351\n4 \n3\nMUS 352\n4 \n1\nMUS 491\n4 \n2\nMUS Ensemble\n5 \n1\nTCH LRN 301 3\nSecond Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nMUS 353\n6 \n3\nMUS 354\n6 \n1\nMUS 359 [HUM] [M]\n6 \n3\nMUS 490\n6 \n3\nMUS Ensemble \n5 \n1\nTCH LRN 317 2\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nPass Piano Proficiency\nMay Field Experience\nAdmitted into Major, Admitted into TCH LRN\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nDiversity [DIVR] (Non-MUS) 3\nENGLISH 201 [WRTG]\n7 \n3\nMUS 258\n4 \n2\nMUS 360 [HUM] [M]\n4 \n3\nMUS 455\n4 \n2\nMUS Ensemble \n5 \n1\nSecond Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nArts [ARTS] (Non-MUS) 3\nMUS 428 or 435 1\nMUS 461 [CAPS]\n6 \n3\nMUS Electives 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nApplied MUS \n1 \n2\nForeign Language, if needed 0-4\nMUS Endorsement Electives\n8 \n4\nMUS Ensemble \n5 \n1\nTCH LRN 464 3\nTCH LRN 465 3\nSenior Qualifying Exam\nReserve Credit for MA recommended\nSecond Term Hours\nED PSYCH 468 3\nForeign Language, if needed 0-4\nMUS 482 or 483 1\nMUS Endorsement Electives\n8 \n4\nTCH LRN 467 [M] 3\nTCH LRN 470 3\nSenior Half-Recital\nReserve Credit for MA recommended\n_______\n1 \nApplied Music: 14 credits required with a\nminimum of 2 credits at the 400 level. (32 credits required with a\nminimum of 4 credits at the 400-level): MUS 202,\n205, 209, 213, 218, 220, 302, 305, 309, 313, 318,\n320, 402, 405, 409, 413, 418, and 420.\n2 \nFall only.\n3 \nMusic Ensembles: a minimum of one credit per\nsemester.\n4 \nClass piano credits not required in degree.\n5 \nSpring only.\n6 \nCourse taught alternate years.\n7 \nStudents must complete a minimum of 6 credits of\nelectives outside of MUS and UCORE requirements.\nPlease consult with advisor for elective selection.\n8 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\nMUSIC PERFORMANCE - VOICE OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nRequirements include: junior and senior qualifying\nexams; piano proficiency exam; achieve a\ncumulative 2.5 GPA and a grade of C or better in all\nmusic classes; junior and senior recitals.\nOnly 9 credits of MUS courses can be used to fulfill\nUCORE requirements.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term 1\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or\nNon-MUS Electives 7\nSenior Full Recital\n_______\n1 \nApplied Music: 32 credits of MUS 303 and 403\nrequired with a minimum of 4 credits of MUS 403.\n2 \nClass piano credits not required.\n3 \nFall only.\n4 \nSpring only.\n5 \nCourse taught alternate years.\n6 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n7 \nStudents must complete a minimum of 6 credits of\nelectives outside of MUS and UCORE requirements.\nPlease consult with advisor for elective selection.\nMinors\nJazz Studies\nRequired courses: MUS 257, 258, 362, 457, 458, and\none 3-credit MUS course; four credits from 438, 439,\n440. Credit hours for the minor must include 9\nhours of upper-division work taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses.\nMusic Minor and Supporting\nTeaching Endorsements\nChoose one of the following options: Option 1\nincludes MUS 151 and 2 credits from MUS 181, 182,\n281 or 2 credits from MUS 102, 202, 302. Option\n2 includes MUS 251 and 252. Both options also\ninclude MUS 160 and one course from MUS 262,\n265, 362, MUS 163 or 363; 4 credits of performance\nstudies, 4 credits performing groups; and 4 credits\n300-400-level music electives. Also available are\nsupporting teaching endorsements in music for\nstudents whose primary teaching endorsements\nare in other majors. Credit hours for the minor\nmust include 9 hours of upper-division work taken\nin residence at WSU or through WSU-approved\neducation abroad or educational exchange courses.\nMusic Technology\nThe minor in Music Technology is designed to offer\na foundation for music recording, production, and\nperformance. Students will be able to: 1) navigate,\nset up, and operate common hardware and software\nconfigurations found in professional recording\nstudios; 2) set up and operate equipment for live\nsound reinforcement; and 3) make use of MIDI,\nsequencing, notation, and other technologies\nrelevant to music performance and composition\nin a variety of genres and styles. Completion\nof the minor requires a minimum GPA of 2.0.\nAdditionally, students must earn a C or better\ngrade and a minimum GPA of 2.5 in all music\ncourses. Nine hours of upper-division work must\nbe taken in residence at WSU or through WSU-\napproved education abroad or educational exchange\ncourses. Required courses include: MUS 153 (151 or\n251 may substitute), 164, 264, 364, and 464. An\nadditional 9 credits must be chosen from: MUS 201-\n220 (maximum 2 credits), MUS 256, 435, 452, 496,\n499; DTC 201, 208, 336; FINE ART 333, 435.\nDescription of Courses\nMUSIC\nMUS\n102 Piano 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n103 Voice 2 (0-6)\n\n328\nMusic\nWashington State University, 2021\n120 [ARTS] Class Guitar 3 Class instruction on\nbasic guitar; repertoire will be selected from\nclassical, jazz, rock, pop, fusion, and world\nmusic.\n151 Music Fundamentals I 3 Notation and\nperformance of music fundamentals: pitch,\nrhythm, scales, key signatures, and intervals.\n152 Music Fundamentals II 3 Notation and\nperformance of music fundamentals: melody,\nrhythm, scales, intervals, key signatures, triads;\npreparatory for MUS 251.\n153 [ARTS] Musical Style in Composition 3\nIntroduction to musical style in composition,\nhistory, and analysis including theory\nfundamentals, history survey, and beginning\ncomposition.\n160 [ARTS] Survey of Music Literature 3\nExploration of predominantly western music\nthrough demonstrations, performances,\nlectures, concerts, and discussions.\n163 [ARTS] World Music 3 Exploration of\nmusic from a global perspective through\ndemonstrations, performances, lectures and\ndiscussion.\n164 Introduction to Music Technology 1\nCourse Prerequisite: MUS 151; MUS 251\nor concurrent enrollment. Music notation\nsoftware, audio recording and editing, and\nmusic specific web design.\n181 Class Piano I 1 (0-3) May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 2 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By permission only. Pedal, sight\nreading, transposition, playing by ear, chord\nprogressions, melody harmonization and\nimprovisation.\n182 Class Piano II 1 (0-3) May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 2 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 181. Scales, arpeggios,\nblocked and broken chords; repertoire to\ncomplement individual skills, theoretical\nknowledge and improvisation.\n190 Foundations of Music Education 1\nMethods and materials for becoming an\neffective music educator; includes observations\nand classroom teaching.\n201 Organ 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit. By\naudition only.\n202 Piano 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit. By\naudition only.\n203 Voice 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\nRecommended preparation: Concurrent\nenrollment in MUS 431, 432, 433, 428 or 439.\n204 Horn 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n205 Trumpet 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n206 Trombone 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n207 Euphonium 2 (0-6) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n208 Tuba 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n209 Percussion 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n210 Violin 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n211 Viola 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n212 Violoncello 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n213 Contrabass 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n214 Flute 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n215 Oboe 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n216 Clarinet 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n217 Bassoon 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n218 Saxophone 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\n220 Guitar 2 (0-6) May be repeated for credit.\nCourse Prerequisite: MUS 120. Reading and\ninterpreting music on the guitar.\n251 Materials and Structures of Music I 3\nCourse Prerequisite: By examination only.\nSee music.wsu.edu for placement exam\ninformation. Music theory fundamentals;\nanalysis and composition of two-voice\ncounterpoint, diatonic harmony in choral and\nkeyboard texture, and melodic form.\n252 Applied Theory I 1 (0-3) By examination. Ear\ntraining, conducting, rhythmic reading, sight\nsinging, keyboard, dictation.\n253 Materials and Structures of Music II\n3 Course Prerequisite: MUS 251 with a C or\nbetter; MUS 252. Analysis and composition of:\nfigured bass, Alberti figures, and choral diatonic\nand initial chromatic harmony; modulation;\nalternation and binary forms.\n254 Applied Theory II 1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite:\nMUS 251 with a C or better; MUS 252 with a C\nor better. Ear training, sight singing, keyboard.\n256 Seminar in Composition 2 (0-6) May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n8 hours. Course Prerequisite: MUS 251 or\nconcurrent enrollment. By Interview Only.\nOriginal writings in small forms.\n257 Jazz Theory 2 Introduction to jazz theory;\nchord symbols, extended harmony, scales and\nmodes, voicing, bass lines and substitutions.\n258 Introduction to Jazz Improvisation 2 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum 4\nhours. Introduction to jazz improvisation.\n262 [ARTS] Rock Music: History and Social\nAnalysis 3 History and analysis of rock music\nrelated to its African American origins, its\nsocietal role, and its diverse development and\nimpact.\n264 Music Technology I 2 Course Prerequisite:\nMUS 164. MIDI hardware/software and related\ntechnologies used in music production.\nSequencing, orchestration, virtual instruments,\nsample control, interactivity, performance.\n265 [HUM] Native Music of North America\n3 Music and ceremonialism as a reflection of\nrealities in North American native cultures,\npast and present. (Crosslisted course offered\nas MUS 265, CES 271).\n266 [ARTS] Film Music 3 The evolution of\nfilm music; discussions/lectures will address\naesthetics of film music and how they influence\nperception, communication, and drama.\n281 Class Piano III 1 (0-3) May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 2 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 182. Principles, functional\nkeyboard and improvisation.\n282 Class Piano IV 1 (0-3) May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 2 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 281 or Piano Proficiency\nExam. Advanced skills, particularly for music\neducation majors; score reading, transposition,\nsight-reading, and reduction of scores;\nensemble skills.\n301 Organ V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n302 Piano V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n303 Voice V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit. Recommended preparation:\nConcurrent enrollment in MUS 431 or 432.\n304 Horn V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n305 Trumpet V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n306 Trombone V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n307 Euphonium V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n308 Tuba V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n309 Percussion V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n310 Violin V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n311 Viola V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n312 Violoncello V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n313 Contrabass V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n314 Flute V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n315 Oboe V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n316 Clarinet V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n317 Bassoon V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n318 Saxophone V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n319 Secondary Performance Study 2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 16\nhours. Course Prerequisite: By permission only.\nInstruction on instruments or voice other than\nmajor performing medium.\n320 Guitar V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit. Guitar.\n351 Materials and Structures of Music III\n3 Course Prerequisite: MUS 164 with a C or\nbetter; MUS 253 with a C or better; MUS 254\nwith a C or better. Voice leading and analysis\nof functional chromatic harmony; study of\ncommon large forms in the 17th, 18th, and\n19th century.\n352 Applied Theor y III 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 164 with a C or better;\nMUS 253 with a C or better; MUS 254 with a\nC or better. Continued musical development\nin ear training, sight singing, applied theory,\nkeyboard dictation.\n\n329\nMusic\nWashington State University, 2021\n353 Materials and Structures of Music IV\n3 Course Prerequisite: MUS 351 with a C or\nbetter; MUS 352 with a C or better. Vertical,\nlinear and formal relationships of 20th century\nmusic; writing, analysis, listening.\n354 Applied Theor y IV 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 351 with a C or better; MUS\n352 with a C or better. Continued development\nin ear training, sight singing, keyboard and\ndictation, emphasizing 20th century music.\n359 [HUM] [M] History of Music: Antiquity\nto 1650 3 Course Prerequisite: MUS 251 with\na C or better; MUS 252 with a C or better;\nENGLISH 101 with a C or better. History and\nstyle of western art music from Antiquity to\n1650; introduction to and selected topics in\nethnomusicology.\n360 [HUM] [M] History of Music: 1650 -\n1850 3 Course Prerequisite: MUS 359 with a\nC or better. History and style of western art\nmusic from 1650 to 1850; selected topics in\nethnomusicology.\n362 [DIVR] History of Jazz 3 History of jazz in\nchronological sequence; social and political\ncontexts of the African-American origins of\njazz; stylistic developments.\n363 [DIVR] Women in Music 3 Intersections of\ngender, class, race, and culture with popular\nand country music. (Crosslisted course offered\nas MUS 363, WOMEN ST 363).\n364 Audio Engineering I 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMUS 164. Software, equipment, and\ntechniques used in studio recording and live\nsound reinforcement; includes both theoretical\nfoundations and practical application.\n371 Diction for Singers I 2 Italian and English;\nInternational Phonetic Alphabet; fundamental\ndiction principles, applied to each language\nand oriented to needs of the singer.\n372 Diction for Singers II 2 Course Prerequisite:\nMUS 371. French and German; International\nPhonetic Alphabet; fundamental diction\nprinciples, applied to each language and\noriented to needs of the singer.\n388 Music for the Classroom Teacher 2 Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 153; admitted to the major\nin Elementary Education. Singing, movement,\nlistening and instrumental methods/resources\nfor K-8 grades.\n401 Organ V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n402 Piano V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n403 Voice V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit. Recommended preparation:\nConcurrent enrollment in MUS 431 or 432.\n404 Horn V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n405 Trumpet V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n406 Trombone V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n407 Euphonium V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n408 Tuba V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n409 Percussion V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n410 Violin V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n411 Viola V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n412 Violoncello V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n413 Contrabass V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n414 Flute V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n415 Oboe V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n416 Clarinet V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n417 Bassoon V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n418 Saxophone V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be\nrepeated for credit.\n420 Guitar V 2 (0-6) to 4 (0-12) May be repeated\nfor credit.\n428 [ARTS] Opera Workshop 1 (0-4) May be\nrepeated for credit. Course Prerequisite: By\naudition only; see music.wsu.edu for details.\nPublic performance may be required. Credit\nnot granted for both MUS 428 and MUS 528.\n429 [ARTS] Tenor/Bass Choir 1 (0-2) May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 12\nhours. Vocal ensemble whose membership\nsings tenor or bass; no audition required; all\nstudents welcome; placement assessments will\nbe administered first week of classes.\n430 [ARTS] Treble Choir 1 (0-2) May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 12 hours.\nVocal ensemble whose membership sings\nsoprano or alto; no audition required; all\nstudents welcome; placement assessments will\nbe administered first week of classes.\n431 [ARTS] Concert Choir 1 (0-4) May be\nrepeated for credit. Course Prerequisite: By\naudition only; see music.wsu.edu for details.\nAuditioned choral ensemble studying and\nperforming global music of varying cultures,\nlanguage, period, style, and tradition. Credit\nnot granted for both MUS 431 and MUS 531.\n432 [ARTS] University Singers 1 (0-4) May be\nrepeated for credit. Public performance may be\nrequired. Non-auditioned choir consisting of\n70+ singers. The majority of this group is made\nup of non-music majors.\n433 [ARTS] Madrigal/Chamber Singers\n1 (0-4) May be repeated for credit. Course\nPrerequisite: By audition only; see music.wsu.\nedu for details. Study, rehearse, perform, and\nreview original works and transcriptions for\nsymphony orchestra; public performance each\nsemester. Credit not granted for both MUS 433\nand MUS 533.\n434 [ARTS] Symphony Orchestra 1 (0-4) May\nbe repeated for credit. Study, rehearse, perform\nand review original works and transcriptions\nfor symphony orchestra; public performance\neach semester.\n435 Chamber Ensembles 1 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: By audition\nonly; see music.wsu.edu for details. Public\nperformance may be required. Credit not\ngranted for both MUS 435 and MUS 535.\n436 [ARTS] Symphonic Band 1 (0-4) May\nbe repeated for credit. Large ensemble\nperformance of repertoire for band. Public\nperformances.\n437 [ARTS] Symphonic Wind Ensemble 1 (0-4)\nMay be repeated for credit. Course Prerequisite:\nBy audition only; see music.wsu.edu for details.\nLarge ensemble; public performances each\nsemester. Credit not granted for both MUS 437\nand MUS 537.\n438 [ARTS] Jazz-Lab Band 1 (0-4) May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 8\nhours. Course Prerequisite: By audition only;\nsee music.wsu.edu for details. Jazz big band.\nPublic performances each semester. Credit not\ngranted for both MUS 438 and MUS 538.\n439 [ARTS] Vocal Jazz Ensemble 1 (0-4) May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum 8\nhours. Course Prerequisite: By audition only;\nsee music.wsu.edu for details. The majority of\nthis group is made up of non-music majors.\nPublic performances each semester. Credit not\ngranted for both MUS 439 and MUS 539.\n440 Jazz Combos 1 (0-4) May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 8 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By audition only; see music.\nwsu.edu for details. Public performances each\nsemester. Credit not granted for both MUS 440\nand MUS 540.\n441 Accompanying 1 (0-4) May be repeated for\ncredit.\n444 Marching Band/Varsity Band 1 (0-4) May\nbe repeated for credit.\n451 Seminar in Counterpoint 2 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 4 hours.\nCourse Prerequisite: MUS 351 or concurrent\nenrollment. Contrapuntal techniques of the\n16th and 18th century with original stylistic\nwriting.\n452 Electronic Music Techniques 2 Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 264. Composition and\nperformance using computer-controlled\ndigital, analog, and sampling synthesis; topics\ninclude sequencing, waveform editing, signal\nprocessing, spatialization, and performance.\n455 Seminar in Instrumentation 2 May be\nrepeated for credit. Course Prerequisite: MUS\n351 or concurrent enrollment. Scoring for\nvarious instrumental combinations.\n456 Seminar in Advanced Composition 4\nMay be repeated for credit. Course Prerequisite:\nMUS 351. By Interview Only. Original writing\nin small and large forms (traditional and\nexperimental).\n457 Seminar in Jazz Arranging/Composition\n2 Course Prerequisite: MUS 257. Arranging and\ncomposing for instrumental jazz ensembles.\n458 Advanced Jazz Improvisation 2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n4 hours. Course Prerequisite: MUS 258.\nAdvanced concepts in jazz improvisation.\n\n330\nMusic\nWashington State University, 2021\n459 Seminar in Advanced Jazz Composition\nV 1 (0-2) to 3 (0-6) May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 12 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 457. Creation of works for\nJazz Ensembles. Credit not granted for both\nMUS 459 and MUS 559.\n461 [CAPS] The Musician in Society:\nPhilosophies and Practices, 1850 -\nPresent 3 Course Prerequisite: MUS 360 with\na C or better; admitted to the major in Music;\njunior standing. History and style of western\nart music from the late romantic period to the\npresent, combining theories of history, theory,\nethnomusicology, performance, pedagogy, and\nadvocacy.\n464 Audio Engineering II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nMUS 364. Continued training in software,\nequipment, and techniques used in studio\nrecording and live sound reinforcement;\ntheory and practical application.\n465 S e m i n a r i n M a j o r P e r f o r m a n c e\nLiterature 2 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 6 hours. Survey/\nperformance of solo and chamber literature\nfor voice, keyboard, strings, winds, brass,\npercussion.\n470 Marketing and Promotion for the\nPerforming Arts 2 (1-3) Components\nand techniques used in the marketing and\npromotion of the performing arts and the\nentertainment industry.\n480 Instrumental Music Education 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in Music.\nPhilosophies, administration, organization,\nmaterials and methods for instrumental music\neducation K-12. Credit not granted for both\nMUS 480 and MUS 580.\n482 Instr umental Conducting 1 (0-3)\nTechniques and patterns in conducting as\napplied to orchestra and band literature; score\npreparation and rehearsal techniques for\ninstrumental ensembles.\n483 Choral Conducting 1 (0-3) Techniques and\npatterns in conducting as applied to choral\nliterature; score preparation and rehearsal\ntechniques for choral ensembles.\n484 Woodwind Techniques I 1 (0-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 190. Performance and\npedagogy of woodwind instruments for music\neducators.\n485 Woodwind Techniques II 1 (0-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 190; MUS 484. Second level\nof performance and pedagogy of woodwind\ninstruments for music educators.\n486 String Techniques I 1 (0-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 190. Performance and\npedagogy of string instruments for music\neducators.\n487 String Techniques II 1 (0-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 190; MUS 486. Second\nlevel of performance and pedagogy of string\ninstruments for music educators.\n488 Choral Methods and Materials I 2 (0-6)\nPreparation in the administration of choral\nprograms from auditions to the selection\nand rehearsal of choral literature. Credit not\ngranted for both MUS 488 and MUS 588.\n489 Choral Methods and Materials II 2 Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 488. Development of skills\nin choral arranging, curriculum construction,\nresearch, and job placement. Credit not\ngranted for both MUS 489 and MUS 589.\n490 General Music Material/Methods 3\nCourse Prerequisite: MUS 491. Materials\nand methods for general music education\nmajors; multiculturalism, collaboration,\ndevelopmental curriculum and research issues;\naddressing national standards; observations.\nCredit not granted for both MUS 490 and MUS\n590.\n491 Voice Pedagogy 2 (1-3) Anatomy of the\nsinging process; methodology of teaching\nvoices in various learning and teaching styles.\nCredit not granted for both MUS 491 and MUS\n591.\n492 Brass Techniques I 1 (0-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 190. Performance and\npedagogy of brass instruments for music\neducators.\n493 Brass Techniques II 1 (0-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 190; MUS 492. Second\nlevel of performance and pedagogy of brass\ninstruments for music educators.\n494 Percussion Techniques I 1 (0-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 190. Performance and\npedagogy of percussion instruments for music\neducators.\n495 Percussion Techniques II 1 (0-2) Course\nPrerequisite: MUS 190; MUS 494. Second level\nof performance and pedagogy of percussion\ninstruments for music educators.\n496 Topics in Music V 1-3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nAdvanced seminar with required projects in\nmusic history, literature, pedagogy, theory,\ncomposition or performance.\n497 Directed Student Teaching in Music\nV 4-16 Course Prerequisite: By permission\nonly. Supervised teaching in public schools,\nincluding seminars reflecting on effective\nteaching. S, F grading.\n498 Piano Pedagogy Practicum 2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Course Prerequisite: MUS 202, 302, or\n402. Supervised teaching in Piano Preparatory\nLab School, including lesson planning and\nmeetings with coordinator for critiques and\nsuggestions. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. S, U grading.\nProgram in Naval Science\nwww.uidaho.edu/navyrotc/\n2nd Floor, Hays Hall; University of Idaho\n208-885-6333\nThe Navy-Marine Corps Officer Education Program,\nadministered and taught by the NROTC staff at the\nUniversity of Idaho, is open to qualified persons and\noffers scholarships leading to commissions in the\nUnited States Navy and Marine Corps. Normally,\nstudents enter the program at the beginning of their\nfreshman year. However, selected students may enter\nup to the end of the sophomore year. During the four\nyears students take up to 24 credits of professional\ncourses taught by the NROTC staff officers. In\naddition to professional courses, NROTC students\nmust participate in close order drill and physical\ntraining each semester. Following graduation and\ncommissioning, new officers are offered a broad\nvariety of duty assignments including duty on\nsurface ships, nuclear submarines, cyber warfare\nengineering, naval aviation, special operations\nunits, law, ground or aviation assignments in the\nMarine Corps.\nCollege Program\nApplication for this non-scholarship program is\nmade through the Department of Naval Science.\nStudents receive their uniforms and naval science\ntextbooks at no cost. At the end of their sophomore\nyear, students are eligible to be selected for Advanced\nStanding and will begin receiving a monthly stipend\nof $350 per month, which will increase to $400 per\nmonth as seniors. College Program students may\nbe nominated by the Professor of Naval Science\nfor a two- or three-year scholarship as freshmen or\nsophomores, if their academic and military aptitude\nmarks are sufficient to warrant such nomination.\nThe program requires one training cruise during\nthe summer following the junior year to meet\ncommissioning requirements.\nScholarship Program\nNaval Science (Navy or Marine-Option)\nScholarship students’ benefits include tuition, fees,\na $750 book allowance, and a monthly stipend of up\nto $400. Application for this program is normally\nmade during the early fall of the student’s senior\nyear of high school. Initial selections are based on\ncollege entrance examination scores (SAT or ACT),\nhigh school academic performance, and extra-\ncurricular activities.\nA student on scholarship participates in at least\nthree summer training cruises of three to six weeks\nduration. During the first summer, students are\nintroduced to the Surface Warfare, Submarine,\nMarine Corps, and Aviation communities. The\nsecond and third summers are spent aboard ships\nof the Pacific or Atlantic fleets and often include\n\n332\nNaval Science\nWashington State University, 2021\ntravel to foreign ports. During summer cruises, the\nstudents receive Active Duty E-5 pay, in addition to\nroom and board.\nMarine Corps Option\nScholarship and College Program students who\ndesire a Marine Corps commission may apply for\nthe Marine Corps option during their first two years\nin college. Students taking this option enroll in\nspecialized classes on Marine Corps subjects during\ntheir junior year and participate in summer training\nat Officer Candidate School, Quantico, Virginia\nduring the summer following their junior year.\nMinors\nNaval Science\nNAV SCI 101, 102, 201, 202; four to six courses from\nthe following: NAV SCI 301, 302, 311, 401, 402,\n412. Credit hours for the minor must include 9\nhours of upper-division work taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses.\nDescription of Courses\nNAVAL SCIENCE\nNAV SCI\n101 Introduction to the Naval Science 2\nIntroduction to the Naval Service: customs,\ntraditions, structure, career paths, basic\nleadership, ethics and character development,\nduties of a junior officer, ships/aircraft of the\nU.S. Navy Fleet.\n103 I n t r o d u c t i o n t o N a v a l S c i e n c e\nLaboratory 1 Practical instruction for\nintroduction to Naval Science. S, F grading.\n104 Seapower and Maritime Affairs 3 An\noverview of U.S. naval history; seapower\nand maritime affairs beginning with the\nContinental Navy to present-day naval history.\n200 Seminar V 1-16 May be repeated for credit.\n203 Workshop V 1-16 May be repeated for credit.\n204 Special Topics V 1-16 May be repeated for\ncredit.\n205 Navigation 3 Theory, principles, and\nprocedures of terrestrial and electronic\nnavigation, and rules of the nautical road.\n206 Naval Leadership and Management 3\nTheories of management and management\nresources, motivational theories, and\nleadership.\n299 Directed Study V 1-16 May be repeated for\ncredit.\n303 S h ips Systems I 3 Introduction to\nNaval shipboard engineering systems;\npropulsion systems; nuclear, gas turbine, and\nconventional; auxiliary systems and shipboard\ndamage control; basic concepts in ship design.\n304 Ships Systems II 3 Naval weapons;\ntheory and process of detection (radar and\nsonar), evaluation; delivery, guidance, and\nexplosives; integration of weapons systems\nwith command, control, and communications\nsystems.\n311 Evolution of Warfare 3 Evolution of war\nthrough tactics; strategy from Sun Tzu to J.F.C.\nFuller. Recommended preparation: NAV SCI\n101, NAV SCI 104.\n402 Naval Leadership and Ethics 3 An intellectual\nexploration of Western moral traditions and\nethical philosophy within a military context.\nTopics will include military leadership, core\nvalues, professional ethics, and conduct of\nwarfare with applications appropriate for future\nNavy and Marine Corps officers. Recommended\npreparation: NAV SCI 206.\n403 Workshop V 1-16 May be repeated for credit.\n404 Special Topics V 1-16 May be repeated for\ncredit.\n406 Naval Operations 3 Course Prerequisite:\nNAV SCI 205. Naval operations and tactics,\nrelative motion, and Maneuvering Boards.\n412 Fundamentals of Maneuver Warfare\n3 Amphibious doctrine and its relation to\nmaneuver warfare. Recommended preparation:\nNAV SCI 311.\n499 Directed Study V 1-16 May be repeated for\ncredit.\nProgram in Neuroscience\nipn.vetmed.wsu.edu/neuroscience/\nVeterinary and Biomedical Research Bldg\n(VBR) 207\n509-335-6624\nDirector, Chair, and Professor, S. Simasko; Associate\nDirector of Graduate Program and Professor, S.\nAppleyard; Associate Director of Undergraduate Program\nand Associate Professor, S. Gizerian; Regents Professor,\nJ. M. Krueger; Professors, G. Belenky (Spokane), M.\nChandra, R. M. Craft, M. Frank (Spokane), R. Fuchs,\nJ. W. Harding, J. Hinson, M. Morgan (Vancouver),\nC. Portfors (Vancouver), R. Quock, R. C. Ritter, M.\nSchmitter-Edgecombe, H. Van Dongen (Spokane), P.\nWhitney; Associate Professors, R. L. Brown, T. Brown,\nA. Coffin (Vancouver), C. Davis (Spokane), A. Dimitrov\n(Vancouver), W. Dong, D. Jackson, L. Kapas (Spokane),\nM. Layton (Spokane), D. Lin, R. McLaughlin, P.\nMeighan, J. Peters, D. Rossi, L. Sprunger, E. Szentirmai\n(Spokane), B. Tanner, M. Varnum, A. Vasavada, G.\nWayman, J. Wisor (Spokane); Assistant Professors, R.\nCatena, K. Delevich, K. Honn, L. Peixoto (Spokane),\nE. Qualls-Creekmore; Additional Graduate Faculty, C.\nBurgoyne, S. Demirel, B. Fortune, H. Shen, B. Sorg, D.\nStenkamp, L. Wang.\nNeuroscience is the study of how the nervous\nsystem impacts physiology, behavior, and health. It\nseeks to answer questions at the molecular, cellular,\nsystems, behavioral, cognitive, and societal levels\nthrough application of a wide array of approaches\nand techniques. Neuroscience research is critical not\nonly to improving learning and performance, but\nalso addresses some of the most vexing problems\nthat prevent good health, as well as impacts the\nvery nature on how we view ourselves as sentient\nbeings. WSU has a neuroscience faculty engaged in\nnumerous focuses with particular strengths in the\nareas of energy homeostasis, sleep, circadian biology,\naddiction, emotions and well-being, sensory\nprocesses, neuronal function, electrophysiology,\nand movement. The Program sponsors Bachelor\nof Science, Master of Science, and Doctor of\nPhilosophy degrees, in addition to minors at the\nundergraduate level.\nThe undergraduate program for majors is designed\nfor students interested in preparing for professional\nstudy in the health sciences (such as medical\ndoctor or doctor of veterinary medicine), graduate\nschool, or for those who wish to use their training\nin laboratory settings in universities, government\norganizations, or industry.\nComputational neuroscience is an option\nwithin the undergraduate neuroscience major and\nlinks the information processing features of the\nnervous system with information processing of\ncomputer systems. Accordingly, the computational\nneuroscience track supplements the neuroscience\ncore curriculum with information technology\ncourses. In this way students learn not only of the\nbrain and its information processing mechanisms,\nbut also of modern computer hardware and\nsoftware technologies. Upon completion of the\nfour-year curriculum, a BS in Neuroscience will be\nawarded. Furthermore, the program is designed to\nallow students to acquire breadth in computation\nsubjects or, alternatively, to focus on either software\nor hardware aspects of computation. Students\nchoosing to acquire breadth in computational\nsubjects will be well prepared for graduate study\nin most areas of neural and biomedical science,\nincluding bioengineering. Students choosing a\nsoftware or hardware focus may obtain a minor in\neither computer science or computer engineering.\nStudent Learning Outcomes for BS\nneuroscience majors\nKnowledge:\n• Demonstrate knowledge of, and recognize the\nrelationships between, the structure and function\nof molecules and tissues involved in neurobiological\nsystems at all levels: molecular, cellular, and\norganismal.\n• Recognize the impact that science has on culture,\nand vice versa.\nSkills:\n• Perform basic laboratory techniques used in\nneuroscience research and understand and apply\nprinciples of laboratory safety.\n• Locate and retrieve scientific information and\nread, understand, and critically evaluate primary\nliterature.\n• Prepare oral and written reports in a standard\nscientific format.\n• Apply the scientific process, including designing,\nconducting, and evaluating experiments and testing\nof hypotheses.\n• Use mathematics and statistics to evaluate\nscientific evidence and interpret graphs and tables.\nAttitudes:\n• Recognize that all areas of science are integrated\nand interconnected.\n• Appreciate scientific knowledge as something\nthat is not static, but constantly expanding through\nthe ongoing work of researchers.\n• Value ethical conduct in science.\n• Recognize that the best decision-making and\npolicies are based on evidence.\n\n333\nNeuroscience\nWashington State University, 2021\nTransfer Students\nTransfer students must satisfy the program\nrequirements for graduation. Science courses\ntaken at other institutions will be evaluated and\ncredits accepted where possible. Transfer students\nare strongly encouraged to enroll in math and\nchemistry classes at the appropriate level to meet\nthe program requirements prior ro transferring.\nInquiries should be directed to the Associate\nDirector of Undergraduate Program.\n7-Year Honors Neuroscience/Veterinary\nMedicine Degree Program\nAcademically qualified undergraduate students\nwho meet the highly selective criteria for admission\nto WSU’s Veterinary Medical Program may apply to\nthe 7-year BS/DVM degree program in neuroscience\nafter completion of one year of Honors College\ncoursework at WSU. If accepted into the program,\nthe student will work toward a bachelor of science in\nneuroscience in the first three years of the program\nand work toward the doctor of veterinary medicine\ndegree in the following four years. The first three\nyears are a combination of WSU Honors College\ncourses and regular university undergraduate courses\nthat fulfill the pre-veterinary and Neuroscience\nmajor requirements. The last four years are the\ntraditional doctor of veterinary medicine program,\nplus completion of an honors thesis. Prospective\napplicants must be admitted to the WSU Honors\nCollege and enrolled in Honors courses. See the\nHonors College for additional information.\nPreparation for Graduate Study in\nNeuroscience\nThe graduate program prepares students for\ncareers in academia, industry, and government\nservice. Students work closely with faculty members\nwho are internationally known for their research\naccomplishments in energy homeostasis, sleep,\ncircadian biology, addiction, emotions and well-\nbeing, sensory processes, neuronal function,\nelectrophysiology, and movement. Upon\ngraduation, students with a doctoral degree are\ncredible international experts in the area of their\nthesis research. They will have developed cutting\nedge technical research skills, be capable of\nindependently organizing and writing publishable\nresearch manuscripts, know the fundamentals on\nhow to write competitive research proposals, have a\nbreadth of knowledge that enables them to critically\nevaluate neuroscience research, and finally, develop\ninsights that help them identify areas ripe for future\ninvestigation. These skills are not only appropriate\nfor basic research, but the ability to organize a set\nof sophisticated goals, identify a plan to accomplish\nthose goals, and then successfully complete the plan\nare skills transferable to many jobs. Our graduates\nhave gone on to excellent positions in tier-one\nresearch universities, teaching colleges, industry\n(e.g., biotechnology, pharmaceutical, and medical\ndevice), as well as professional schools (e.g., medical,\nveterinary, optometry).\nTo be eligible for admission, candidates must meet\ngeneral Washington State University requirements\noutlined at the Graduate School website: http://\ngradschool.wsu.edu/ in effect at the time of\ntheir admission, as well as the current graduate\nneuroscience program requirements.\nApplicants to the Ph.D. or M.S. program are\nrequired to have a Bachelor’s degree from an\naccredited higher education institution. Applicants\nmust have a minimum grade point average of 3.0\n(A=4.0). Applicants will have completed courses\nin inorganic and organic chemistry, biochemistry,\ncalculus, physics and a minimum of three courses\nin different areas of the biological sciences. It is\nadvisable that applicants have a basic statistics\ncourse prior to entering the neuroscience program.\nApplication documents must include the following:\n• College transcripts (unofficial acceptable for\ninitial review–upon admittance official transcripts\nare required)\n• Three (3) letters of reference\n• Resume or curriculum vita\n• Personal statement describing why you are\ninterested in studying neuroscience (clearly define\nwhich faculty mentor (minimum of 3) you are\ninterested in working with and explain why).\nIf admitted to WSU you will have the ability to\nrefine your choice of faculty mentors while doing\nlab rotations. Included in the personal statement\ndescribe an achievement that you are proud of and\ndiscuss how you reached your goal, and any obstacles\nyou had to overcome to reach it. Conversely, tell us\nabout a time when you didn’t achieve a goal and\nwhat you learned from the experience (maximum\nword length is 350 words).\n• Writing Statement: Describe a major finding\nin neuroscience and/or biomedicine over the past\nfive (5) years, and explain why you think it was\nimportant (maximum word length is 350 words for\nstatement). Be sure to cite references used after the\nwriting statement. An additional maximum length\nof 350 words is given for the cite references.\n• Turning in a document over the maximum word\nlength may cause your application to be disqualified\nfrom consideration.\n• TOEFL scores (minimum score 100) required for\napplicants whose native language is not English\nInquiries should be directed to the Program in\nNeuroscience, Department of Integrative Physiology\nand Neuroscience; Washington State University,\nPullman, WA 99164-7620 or email grad.neuro@\nwsu.edu.\nStudents normally begin their studies in the fall\nsemester, which starts the latter part of August.\nApplicants are offered admission on a rolling\nbasis, but may be notified of acceptance as late as\nApril 15. Students may still apply for admission\nafter December, but graduate stipends may not be\navailable for late applicants.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nCOMPUTATIONAL BREADTH OF FIELD\nOPTION\n(124 HOURS)\nStudents may be admitted to the Neuroscience\nComputational Breadth of Field Option upon\nmaking their intention known to the department\nand enrollment in or credit for MATH 106 (or\nhigher). To maintain admission to the major,\nstudents who have completed a minimum of 30\ncredits at WSU must maintain a 3.0 minimum\nGPA overall, and a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA\nin BIOLOGY 107, CHEM 105, CHEM 106 or 116,\nMATH 171, MATH 172, NEUROSCI 301, NEUROSCI\n302, and PHYSICS 201/211 or 205. Students must\nreceive a grade of C or better in these courses and\nmay repeat a maximum of three of these courses to\nmaintain admission to the major.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 106 4\nCPT S 121 4\nMATH 172 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 4\nMATH 273 2\nNEUROSCI 301\n1 \n3\nPHYSICS 201 3\nPHYSICS 211 1\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 345 4\nCPT S 122 4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nNEUROSCI 302 3\nPHYSICS 202 3\nPHYSICS 212 1\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nE E 214 4\nMATH 216 3\nMATH 220 2\nMBIOS / BIOLOGY 301 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG]\n2 \n3\nMATH 315 3\nNEUROSCI 404 4\nComputational Neuroscience Electives\n3 \n3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nE E 261 3\nE E 262 1\nNEUROSCI 425 3\nNEUROSCI 426 1\nNEUROSCI 430 [M] 4\nComputational Neuroscience Electives \n3 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIO ENG 340 4\nNEUROSCI 403 [M] 3\nNEUROSCI 490 [CAPS] 3\nComputational Neuroscience Electives \n3 \n3\n_______\n1 \nPSYCH 372 may be taken in place of NEUROSCI\n\n334\nWashington State University, 2021\nNeuroscience\n301 with department permission.\n2 \nProfessional or Technical Writing is recommended\n(e.g. ENGLISH 201 or 402)\n3 \nComputational Neuroscience Electives (the\nBreadth of Field emphasis requires a minimum of\n9 credits): At least 3 credits must be 300-400-level\nE E or CPT S courses. Approved courses include\nBIOLOGY 315, 321, 340, 438, 456; BIO ENG 481;\nCPT S 322, 434, 440, 443; E E 311, 321, 324, 341,\n451, 464; MBIOS 303, 305, 401, 404, 413, 478;\nNEUROSCI 305, 333, 409; Psych 470, 490, 491;\nPHYSICS 466. Courses may not be used to fulfill\nmore than one requirement. Other courses may be\nallowed by department consent. Please consult your\nadvisor.\nCOMPUTATIONAL HARDWARE OPTION\n(124 HOURS)\nStudents may be admitted to the Neuroscience -\nComputational Hardware Option upon making\ntheir intention known to the department and\nenrollment in or credit for MATH 106 (or higher).\nTo maintain admission to the major, students\nwho have completed a minimum of 30 credits at\nWSU must maintain a 3.0 minimum GPA overall,\nand a minimum 3.0 cumulative GPA in BIOLOGY\n107, CHEM 105, CHEM 106 or 116, MATH 171,\nMATH 172, NEUROSCI 301, NEUROSCI 302, and\nPHYSICS 201/211 or 205.
