Consult\nyour advisor regarding elective courses that may be\nrequired or recommended for admission to a DVM\nprogram.\nHONORS ACCELERATED PRE-VETERINARY\nOPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nThis option has been established for admission\nof highly academically qualified students to the\nDoctor of Veterinary Medicine (D.V.M.) program\nat the Washington State University College of\nVeterinary Medicine (CVM). The program of study\nconsists of three years of undergraduate coursework\nthat fulfills the pre-veterinary neuroscience\nrequirements followed by the four-year D.V.M.\nprogram. Satisfactory completion of this 7-year\ncurriculum leads to the Bachelor of Science (B.S.)\nin Neuroscience and Doctor of Veterinary Medicine\n(D.V.M.).\nAll students who qualify for admission to the\nWSU Honors College are eligible to apply for pre-\nadmission to the College of Veterinary Medicine\nafter completion of one year in the pre-veterinary\nneuroscience curriculum. Interested applicants\nshould identify themselves to the Honors College\nas soon as they decide to enroll at the University\nbecause the number of available seats in the B.S./\nD.V.M. program is limited. Early admission to the\nD.V.M. program requires approval of the CVM\nAdmissions Committee. Accepted students are\npre-admitted directly to the D.V.M. program. To\nmaintain pre-admission into the D.V.M. program,\naccepted students must achieve an overall grade\npoint average of 3.5 or better in all undergraduate\ncoursework.\nStudents may be admitted to the Neuroscience\nHonors Accelerated Pre-Veterinary Option upon\nmaking their intention known to the department\nand enrollment in, or credit for, MATH 106 (or\nhigher). To maintain admission to the major,\nstudents who have completed a minimum of 30\ncredits at WSU must maintain a 3.0 minimum GPA\noverall, and a 3.0 minimum cumulative GPA in each\nof the following courses: BIOLOGY 107; CHEM 105;\nCHEM 106 or 116; MATH 140 or 171; NEUROSCI\n301, NEUROSCI 302; PHYSICS 101/111, 201/211 or\n205; and PHYSICS 102/112, 202/212, 206, or CHEM\n345. Students must receive a grade of C or better in\nthese courses and may repeat a maximum of three\nof these courses to maintain admission to the major.\nCompletion of the degree requires completion\nof the HONORS Curriculum; a minimum of 90\nundergraduate credits, including 30 upper-division\ncredits; and one year of DVM coursework.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 105 4\nMATH 140 or 171 4\nForeign Language (if needed)\n1 \n0-4\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 106 or 116\n2 \n4\nENGLISH 298 3\nHONORS 270\n3 \n3\nPHYSICS 101 3\nPHYSICS 111 1\nForeign Language (if needed)\n1 \n0-4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 106 4\nHONORS 280 3\nHONORS 290\n2 \n3\nNEUROSCI 301\n4 \n3\nPSYCH 105\n3 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nCHEM 345 4\nNEUROSCI 302 3\nPHYSICS 102 3\nPHYSICS 112 1\nBehavior Requirement\n5 \n3 or 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY/MBIOS 301 4\nHONORS 370 3\nHONORS 398\n6 \n0 or 1\nMBIOS 303 4\nNEUROSCI 430 [M] 4\nNEUROSCI 450\n7 \n2\nSecond Term Hours\nHONORS 380 3\nHONORS 390 3\nHONORS 450\n7 \n1\nNEUROSCI 403 [M] 3\nNEUROSCI 490 [CAPS] 3\nStatistics Course\n8 \n4\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nVET MED 511 5\nAdditional D.V.M. Coursework\n9 \n10\nSecond Term Hours\nVET MED 520 5\nVET MED 521\n10 \n3\nAdditional D.V.M. Coursework\n9 \n7\n_______\n1 \nStudents must meet the Honors College Foreign\nLanguage requirement.\n2 \nStudents who complete CHEM 116 fulfill the\nHonors College HONORS 290 requirement and\nanother 3-credit course can be substituted.\n3 \nIf HONORS 270 is taught by a member of the\nPsychology faculty, students may waive PSYCH\n105. If PSYCH 105 is waived, students may need to\ntake additional coursework to meet the 90-credit\nundergraduate minimum.\n4 \nPSYCH 372 may be taken in place of NEUROSCI\n301 with department permission.\n5 \nBehavior Course: Choose one course from\nNEUROSCI 305, 333, or 409. Other courses may be\nallowed by department consent.\n6 \nHONORS 398 is an optional thesis-preparation\ncourse.\n7 \nNEUROSCI 450 is applied to the 3 credit HONORS\n450 requirement.\n8 \nStatistics Course: Choose one course from PSYCH\n311, STAT 212, 360, 370, or 412.\n9 \nAdditional D.V.M. courses required in the first year\nof the D.V.M. program to satisfy the Neuroscience\n\n337 \nWashington State University, 2021\nNeuroscience\nelective requirement for the B.S. in Neuroscience.\n10 \nVET MED 521 satisfies the Neuroanatomy\n(NEUROSCI 404) requirement for the B.S. in\nNeuroscience.\nMinors\nNeuroscience\nStudents may apply for the minor in Neuroscience\nonce they have completed 60 credits and have\na 2.75 GPA. However, they may take minor\ncoursework at any time as long as they meet the\nprerequisites. The minor in Neuroscience requires\n16 credits with at least 13 credits at or above the\n300-level. Courses needed to satisfy the minor must\ninclude NEUROSCI 301; three credits selected from\nNEUROSCI 305, 333, or 409; at least six credits\nselected from the following: NEUROSCI 403, 404,\nand 430; and up to four credits of neuroscience\nrelated elective coursework. Approved Neuroscience\nelectives include: BIOLOGY 301, 315, 321, 340,\n352, 353, 354, 438, 456; MATH 340; MBIOS 301,\n304, 305, 401, 404, 413; NEUROSCI 305, 409,\n425, 426; PSYCH 265, 312, 333, 350, 361, 372,\n384, 464, 470, 490, 491; PHYSICS 466; VET PH\n308. Upon the approval of the student’s advisor, a\nstudent with a minor in neuroscience may include\n500-level courses in the minor program, provided\nthe student meets the graduate study requirements\nand, prior to registration, obtains the consent of the\nfaculty Neuroscience minor. Credits for the minor\nmust include a minimum of 9 credits of upper-\ndivision work taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses.\nDescription of Courses\nNEUROSCIENCE\nNEUROSCI\n105 [BSCI] Meet Your Brain 3 Introduction to\nthe brain and nervous system and how they\nare affected by your environment and everyday\nactivities.\n138 Neuroscience Seminar 1 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 2 hours.\nIntroduces new students to individual faculty\nresearch interests and helps students link\npersonal interests to academic majors. S, F\ngrading.\n150 [BSCI] Art and the Brain 3 Explore networks\ninvolved in sensory perception; learn how art\nintegrates perceptual experiences into works\nthat affect our understanding of ourselves.\n201 [COMM] Introduction to Communication\nin the Molecular Life Sciences 3 (1-4)\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 106 with a\nC or better or BIOLOGY 107 with a C or\nbetter. Analysis of primary literature and an\nintroduction to scientific communication\nskills in the molecular life sciences. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as NEUROSCI 201, MBIOS 201).\nRecommended preparation: Pre-admitted or\nadmitted major in Biochemistry, Genetics &\nCell Biology, Microbiology, or Neuroscience.\n275 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n301 Foundations of Neuroscience I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 107, CHEM 105, or\nNEUROSCI 138. Enrollment in NEUROSCI 301\nnot allowed if credit already earned for PSYCH\n372. Structure and function of the nervous\nsystem from single neurons to behavior.\n302 Foundations of Neuroscience II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CHEM 106; BIOLOGY 107;\nNEUROSCI 301 or PSYCH 372. In-depth\nconcepts, analysis, and discussion of the\nexperimental foundations for understanding\nnervous system function.\n305 Neurons, Genes, and Behavior 3 Course\nPrerequisite: NEUROSCI 301, 302, MBIOS\n301, or PSYCH 372. In-depth exploration of\nthe organization of the brain, and how this\norganization underlies behavior.\n333 Techniques and Experimental Design\nin Neuroscience Research 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: NEUROSCI 301 or PSYCH 372;\nMATH 140, 171, PSYCH 311, STAT 212,\n360, 370, or 412. Representative modern\nneuroscience experiments are explored from a\nconceptual, technical, and design perspective.\n403 [M] Cellular Neurobiology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: NEUROSCI 302; MBIOS 301;\nadmitted to the major or minor in Neuroscience.\nCellular and molecular interactions occurring\nwithin the nervous system. Recommended\npreparation: NEUROSCI 430.\n404 Neuroanatomy 4 (3-3) Course Prerequisite:\nNEUROSCI 302. Fundamental principles of\nthe organization and plans of circuitry of the\nnervous system.\n409 A f f e c t i v e N e u r o s c i e n c e 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: NEUROSCI 302 or PSYCH 372.\nBrain mechanisms of human and animal\nemotions. Credit not granted for both\nNEUROSCI 409 and NEUROSCI 509.\n425 Foundations of Medical Physiology 3\nCourse Prerequisite: BIO ENG 210, MBIOS 301,\nMBIOS 303, NEUROSCI 301, NEUROSCI 302,\nor PSYCH 372. Integrated functioning of organ\nsystems, focusing on mechanisms of disease,\norgan dysfunction, and disturbances to whole-\nanimal homeostasis and health. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as NEUROSCI 425, VET PH 425).\n426 Foundations of Medical Physiology\nLab 1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: Concurrent\nenrollment in NEUROSCI 425. Optional\nlaboratory component of NEUROSCI/VET PH\n425. Practical analysis of organ function and\nhealth using medical diagnostic equipment\nand clinical cases. (Crosslisted course offered\nas NEUROSCI 426,VET PH 426).\n430 [M] Principles of Neurophysiology 4 (3-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: NEUROSCI 302; 4 credits\nof PHYSICS 102 or 202, or PHYSICS 102 and\n112, or PHYSICS 202 and 212, or PHYSICS\n206. Advanced exploration of the principles\nunderlying cellular, sensory, motor and\nintegrative functions of the nervous system.\nRecommended preparation: MBIOS 303.\n450 Honors Thesis Research V 1-3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNeuroscience; admitted to Honors College.\nLaboratory research with emphasis on honors\nthesis or project directed by faculty.\n480 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n490 [CAPS] Senior Project 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Neuroscience; senior\nstanding. Senior capstone course for students\nmajoring in Neuroscience.\n491 Senior Project-Poster 1 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Neuroscience; senior\nstanding. Research project poster or oral\npresentation. S, F grading.\n495 Directed Research V 1-3 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nmajor or minor in Neuroscience. Introduction\nto neuroscience research literature.\n499 Special Problems V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major or minor in\nNeuroscience. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n509 Affective Neuroscience 3 Brain mechanisms\nof human and animal emotions. Credit\nnot granted for both NEUROSCI 409 and\nNEUROSCI 509.\n520 Fundamentals of Neuroscience 4 (3-\n3) Functional aspects of the brain from cell\nmembrane to higher integrative processes.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n529 I n t e g r a t i v e N e u r o s c i e n c e 3 Basic\nbiochemical processes in the nervous system\nand their significance for normal and abnormal\nfunction.\n531 Neuroscience Laboratory Rotation 1\n(0-3) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 2 hours. Fourteen-week rotation\nthrough each of two research laboratories;\nlearning procedures and techniques in\nneuroscience. S, F grading.\n540 S p e c i a l To p i c s i n I n t e g r a t i v e\nNeuroscience V 1-3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nConcepts and controversies in neuroscience\ninvolving integrative properties of cell systems.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n541 Special Topics in Cellular and Molecular\nNeuroscience V 1-3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nConcepts and controversies in neuroscience\nthat involve nerve cell function and regulation.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n\n338\nWashington State University, 2021\nNeuroscience\n542 Special Topics in Interdisciplinary\nNeuroscience V 1-3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nConcepts and controversies in neuroscience\nthat revolve around traditional approaches to\nnervous system study. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n543 Special Topics in Behavioral/Clinical\nNeuroscience V 1-3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nConcepts and controversies in neuroscience\nthat involve normal and pathological aspects\nof behavior. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n563 Deconstruction of Research 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Graduate standing in a WSU\nbiomedical based graduate program. Nature\nand development of scientific investigation\nthrough oral and written avenues, and\nmethods of critical analyses applied to\nquestions of biomedical interest. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as NEUROSCI 563, GLANHLTH\n563, MBIOS 563, VET MICR 563, VET PATH\n563, VET PH 563).\n564 Topics in Biomedical Experimentation\nV 1-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Examination of the\nphilosophy of experimental design and\npractical application and analysis of various\nexperimental approaches in biomedical\nresearch. Recommended preparation: graduate\nstanding in a WSU biomedical-based program,\nand an advanced undergraduate or graduate\nstatistics course. (Crosslisted course offered as\nNEUROSCI 564, GLANHLTH 564, MBIOS 564,\nPHIL 564, VET MICR 564, VET PATH 564, VET\nPH 564).\n590 Seminar 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 7 hours. Presented by\nadvanced graduate students and faculty (both\nin INP and around WSU) on their research\nareas. (Crosslisted course offered as NEUROSCI\n590, VET PH 590.) S, F grading.\n592 Research Writing and Seminar 2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Course Prerequisite: Graduate student\nin Neuroscience program. Essentials of oral and\nwritten scientific communication.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe Neuroscience PhD program. Independent\nresearch and advanced study for students\nworking on their doctoral research, dissertation\nand/or final examination. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nCollege of Nursing\nnursing.wsu.edu\nSpokane\n509-324-7360\nDean and Professor, M. Koithan; Associate Dean for\nAcademics and Clinical Associate Professor, A. Mason;\nAssociate Dean for Research and Professor, J. Postma;\nAssociate Dean for Faculty Affairs and Professor,\nD. Smart; Associate Dean and Academic Director–\nVancouver and Professor, L. Eddy; Academic Director-\nTri-Cities and Clinical Assistant Professor, B. Briggs;\nCampus Coordinator-Yakima and Associate Teaching\nProfessor, L. Vickers.\nThe Washington State University College\nof Nursing was established in 1968. Since its\ninception, the College has delivered excellent\nacademic programs, engaged in research and\nservice, and maintained strong partnerships\nwith educational institutions and community\nhealthcare organizations. The College functions\nas an integrated multi-campus system to develop\nand implement educational, research, and service\ninitiatives.\nUNDERGRADUATE PROGRAMS\nThe College of Nursing offers two pre-professional\nbaccalaureate programs. The Bachelor of Science in\nNursing (BSN) pre-licensure undergraduate program\nis open to students beginning a nursing career.\nStudents in this program complete approximately\nfour academic years of full-time study. The RN-BSN\nundergraduate program is open to registered nurses\nwho completed an Associate Degree in nursing and\nwho wish to obtain a degree in nursing. Students\nin this program complete approximately one year\nof full-time study.\nThe program of study for both types of students\nleads to the degree of Bachelor of Science in Nursing\n(BSN). Undergraduate nursing programs at WSU are\napproved by the Washington State Nursing Care\nQuality Assurance Commission and nationally\naccredited by the Commission on Collegiate\nNursing Education.\nBSN Students\nStudents with no previous preparation in nursing\nmay complete pre-nursing course work (freshman\nand sophomore years) at Washington State\nUniversity (Pullman or Tri-Cities campus locations),\nEastern Washington University, Whitworth\nUniversity, or another college or university. Pre-\nnursing coursework provides the student with a\nfoundation in the natural and social sciences and the\nhumanities. To apply for admission to the college,\nstudents must have at least 60 semester hours and\nall courses prerequisite to nursing completed the\nterm prior to enrollment in the upper division.\nThe 300-400-level courses in the nursing major\n(junior and senior years) are offered at the College\nof Nursing in Spokane, Tri-Cities, and Yakima.\nThese courses provide professional preparation in\nnursing, balancing course work with supervised\nclinical practice experiences in hospitals, healthcare\norganizations, and community settings. Upon\nsuccessful completion of the BSN program,\ngraduates are eligible to take the National Council\nLicensure Examination (NCLEX®) to become\neligible for licensure as Registered Nurses.\nRN – BSN Students\nStudents who are Registered Nurses may apply\nto the RN – BSN program at any time following\nthe completion of their basic Registered Nursing\neducation. The RN – BSN is offered at Spokane, Tri-\nCities, Vancouver, and Yakima WSU campuses. The\nprogram builds on pre-licensure RN competencies\nand is focused on additional pre-professional nursing\ncompetencies that include, research, leadership,\npatient care quality and safety, informatics, and\npopulation health. Practice experiences are focused\non leadership and population health. The program\nis flexible, offering hybrid course delivery. A current,\nunencumbered Washington State RN License or\neligibility for licensure is required. Applicants\nmust be at junior standing (60 semester hours/90\nquarter hours), have completed College of Nursing\nprerequisite courses and WSU’s University Common\nRequirements (UCORE) or equivalent course work.\nTo apply for admission, consultation with a nursing\nacademic advisor is required.\nTransfer Students\nAll students who plan to transfer to nursing at\nWashington State University from other institutions\nshould discuss their plans early with their academic\nadvisor so that the pre-transfer program of study will\nbe appropriate to nursing degree requirements. The\nCollege of Nursing offers pre-enrollment advising at\ncampus locations in Spokane, Tri-Cities, Vancouver,\nand Yakima for Registered Nurses who plan to\nobtain the BSN from Washington State University.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nWe expect our graduating students will be able to\ndemonstrate competence in the provision of care,\ndevelop and apply professional values, develop\nin the role of the Registered Nurse, and serve as\ndesigners, managers, and coordinators of care.\nStudent learning outcomes for our BSN Programs\nare: 1) Formulate nursing practice decisions using\nthe foundation of a liberal education and evolving\nknowledge from nursing science, the biological and\nbehavioral sciences, and the humanities. 2) Apply\nleadership concepts, skills, and decision-making\nin the provision of high-quality nursing care,\nhealthcare team coordination, and the oversight and\naccountability for safe care delivery in a variety of\nsettings. 3) Integrate reliable evidence from multiple\ncredible sources of knowledge including basic\nand health sciences to inform practice and make\nclinical judgments. 4) Demonstrate skills in using\npatient care technologies, information systems,\nand communication devices that support safety\nand quality nursing practice. 5) Demonstrate basic\nunderstanding of the role of nurses in advocating\nfor patients, communities and populations in\n\n339 \nWashington State University, 2021\nNursing\ndiscussions related to healthcare policy, finance,\nand regulations. 6) Use inter-and intra-professional\ncommunication and collaborative skills to advocate\nfor safe, evidence-based, high quality patient-\ncentered care. 7) Demonstrate basic understanding\nof the role of health promotion, and disease/injury\nprevention in improving population health across\nthe lifespan. 8) Demonstrate the values central to\nnursing practice including altruism, autonomy,\nhuman dignity, integrity, advocacy, social justice\nand life-long learning. 9) Provide safe, competent,\ncompassionate, ethical, culturally sensitive, and\nevidence based nursing care to individuals, families,\ngroups, communities and populations through\npromotion, maintenance and restoration of health;\nprevention of illness, and physical, emotional, and\nspiritual support throughout the life span including\nend of life, and across the continuum of health care\nenvironments.\nMASTER OF NURSING (MN) PROGRAM\nThe Master of Nursing (MN)-Population Health\nprogram prepares students for advanced nursing\npractice in population health with an opportunity\nto earn Graduate Certificates in education, public\nhealth, and systems leadership. MN students\ncomplete practica and capstone projects to\ndemonstrate mastery of essential competencies,\nincluding systems leadership, quality and safety,\nevidence-based practice, informatics, health policy,\ninterprofessional practice, and population health\nadvanced practice. Students may be admitted\nto the post-baccalaureate Master’s in Nursing\nprogram after completing a bachelor’s degree in\nnursing, or may enroll in the RN-to-Master’s in\nNursing program after earning an Associate Degree\nin Nursing (ADN) and a bachelor’s degree in a field\nrelated to nursing. Courses are offered in a hybrid\nformat. The MN program is offered at the Spokane,\nTri-Cities, Yakima, and Vancouver WSU campuses.\nMost students complete the program in two to three\nyears.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nStudent learning outcomes for our MN program\nare 1) integrate scientific findings from nursing,\nbiopsychosocial fields, genetics/genomics, public\nhealth, quality improvement, and organizational\nsciences for the continual improvement of\nnursing care across diverse settings; 2) implement\norganizational and system leadership skills to\npromote high quality, safe patient care that\nemphasizes ethical and critical decision making\nand effective working relationships within a\nsystems perspective; 3) articulate multiple elements\nof quality, including methods, tools, performance\nmeasures, and quality standards, and apply\nthese within an organization; 4) apply research\noutcomes within the practice setting to resolve\npractice problems, and work as a change agent\nto disseminate these results; 5) use patient-care\ntechnologies to deliver and enhance care, including\ncommunications technologies to integrate and\ncoordinate care; 6) intervene at the systems level\nthrough policy development, and employ advocacy\nstrategies to influence health and health care; 7)\ncommunicate, collaborate, and consult with other\nhealth care professionals as a member or leader of\ninter-professional teams to manage and coordinate\ncare; 8) apply and integrate broad organizational,\nclient-centered culturally appropriate concepts\nwhen planning, delivering, managing, and\nevaluating evidence for clinical prevention and\npopulation care, including services to individuals,\nfamilies, and aggregates/identified populations; and\n9) articulate a broadly defined understanding of\nnursing practice as any form of nursing intervention\nthat influences health care at the direct and indirect\ncare levels for individuals, populations, and systems,\ncoupled with an advanced level of understanding of\nnursing and relevant sciences that is integrated into\ndirect and indirect nursing practice.\nDOCTOR OF NURSING PRACTICE (DNP)\nPROGRAM\nThe Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) program\nprepares students to be leaders in clinical practice\nand allows graduates to engage in advanced nursing\npractice. The DNP program provides students with\nopportunities to work in various health care settings\nunder the guidance of experienced faculty mentors\nand community experts. An integral part of the\nprogram is the completion of the Doctor of Nursing\nPractice (DNP) Project, which provides students\nwith the knowledge and skills to use evidence and\nlead innovations in practice. DNP graduates are\nprepared to translate research and evidence into\npractice, lead interdisciplinary care teams, measure\nhealth-related outcomes, and improve the health\nof individual patients, groups, populations, and\ncommunities.\nProspective students who have earned the\nBachelor of Science in Nursing degree select one\nof three areas of emphasis in the DNP Program:\nFamily Nurse Practitioner (FNP), Psychiatric Mental\nHealth Nurse Practitioner (PMHNP), or Advanced\nPopulation Health (APH). Along with completing\nrequired didactic coursework, students complete\na minimum of 1,000 practicum hours. Graduates\nof the FNP and PMHNP programs are eligible to\ncomplete a national certification examination\nleading to state licensure as Advanced Registered\nNurse Practitioners.\nProspective students who have earned the Master’s\ndegree in Nursing who wish to add an additional\nspecialty (FNP, PMHNP, APH) can work with an\nadviser for an individualized plan of study. Courses\nare offered on the Spokane, Tri-Cities, Yakima, and\nVancouver WSU campuses.\nAdmission to the DNP program is granted based\non 1) admission to the WSU Graduate School; 2)\nundergraduate and, if applicable, graduate GPA\n3.0; 3) written interview responses. Eligibility for\nGraduate School admission includes: 1) Cumulative\nGPA 3.0; 2) three professional references; 3)\nwritten goal statement congruent with program’s\nphilosophy and focus. All applicants to the DNP\nprogram must be licensed as a registered nurse in\nWashington state (or, for international students,\neligibility for licensure on admission with\ncompletion of process before first clinical/practicum\ncourse enrollment).\nThe Graduate Program Office in the College\nof Nursing provides program information to\nprospective students and support for current\nstudents, including assignment of faculty advisors\nand support for enrollment and progression.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nWe expect that DNP graduates: 1) Apply\nb i o p h y s i c a l , p s y c h o s o c i a l , b e h a v i o r a l ,\nsociopolitical, cultural, economic, and nursing\nscience to improve health care practice and delivery\nsystems (DNP Essentials I, V, and VIII); 2) Analyze\norganizational structure, functions and resources\nto improve the delivery of care (DNP Essential II);\n3) Translate evidence-based research into practice\nto improve health care delivery and outcomes for\nall (DNP Essential III); 4) Use information systems/\ntechnology to support and improve patient care\nand healthcare systems (DNP Essential IV); 5)\nAdvocate for the nursing profession through the\ndevelopment, implementation and evaluation of\nhealthcare policy (DNP Essential V); 6) Collaborate\nwith other health professionals to improve health\ncare access and health outcomes for individuals and\npopulations (DNP Essential VI); 7) Advocate for\nethical policies and practice which prevent illness,\npromote health and social justice, and reduce\ndisparities for patient populations in urban, rural,\nand global settings (DNP Essential V, VII); 8) Apply\nadvanced knowledge and skills within an area of\nspecialized nursing practice (DNP Essential VIII).\nPH.D. IN NURSING PROGRAM\nThe Ph.D. in Nursing program prepares nurse\nscientists who engage in research, scholarship, and\ndiscovery to advance the discipline of nursing.\nGraduates are equipped to become leaders in\nnursing education and research, critical roles in\ntoday’s health care environment.\nStudents complete required coursework over 7\nsemesters using a hybrid approach to teaching/\nlearning. All students prepare a dissertation research\nproposal to meet requirements for the preliminary\nexamination, and complete an independent\nresearch study. Courses are offered through the\nSpokane campus.\nThe baccalaureate to Ph.D. program includes\na “bridge year” consisting of two semesters of\npreparatory (Master’s level) coursework before\nbeginning the traditional Ph.D. program with the\nnext incoming cohort. The required 85 credits can\nbe completed in 9 semesters of full-time study.\nPart-time programs of study are also available. All\nPh.D. students are assigned advisors who will help\nto individualize their programs of study and refine\nresearch interests. BSN-Ph.D. students will also\nbe closely advised during Year 1 by the program\ndirector to help them transition successfully to\ndoctoral study. International students are welcome\nin our Ph.D. program; please see https://gradschool.\nwsu.edu/international-requirements.\nAdmission to the Ph.D. program is granted\nbased on: 1) admission to the WSU Graduate\nSchool; 2) graduate GPA 3.5*; 3) submission of\nscholarly work; and 4) phone interview responses\n(*mitigating circumstances resulting in GPA below\n3.5 are considered). Eligibility for Graduate School\nadmission includes: 1) Cumulative GPA 3.0; 2) 3\nprofessional references; 3) written goal statement\ncongruent with program’s philosophy and focus. All\napplicants to the Ph.D. program must be licensed\nas a registered nurse in Washington state (or, for\ninternational students, eligibility for licensure on\nadmission with completion of process before first\nclinical/practicum course enrollment).\nThe Graduate Program Office in the College\nof Nursing provides program information to\nprospective students and support for current\nstudents, including assignment of faculty advisors\nand support for enrollment and progression.\n\n340\nWashington State University, 2021\nNursing\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nWe expect graduates of the Ph.D. in Nursing\nprogram to: 1) contribute to advancing nursing\nscience and practice through clinical research; 2)\nanalyze, construct, and test theoretical frameworks\nthat guide nursing research design, methodology,\ndata analyses, and the transfer of new knowledge\ninto practice; 3) create effective interdisciplinary\ncollaborations to foster research and the transfer\nof evidence-based knowledge into best clinical\npractices; 4) synthesize knowledge from a variety\nof disciplines to create research designs and\nmethods for nursing science and to address ethical,\nsocial, cultural, political, and professional issues;\n5) implement proven and emerging technologies\nto enhance nursing research and education;\nand 6) implement innovative research designs,\nmethodologies, leadership skills, health education,\nand/or life style modification techniques to address\nthe health care needs of vulnerable populations and\ndisparities in the access to or delivery of health care.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nNURSING\n(121 HOURS)\nA grade of C or better is required in all prerequisite\ncourses and nursing courses.\nCriteria for admission to the 300-400-level\nnursing major include an overall cumulative GPA\nof 3.00 or higher and a cumulative GPA of 3.00\nor higher in prerequisite courses. Achievement\nat a “proficient” level or above on the Test of\nEssential Academic Skills (TEAS) is required for all\nPre-licensure applicants. Responses to personal\ninterview questions may be used as additional\nadmission criteria. All pre-licensure applicants are\nrequired to have at least 50 hours of volunteer/work\nhealth experience and provide a proctored writing\nsample at interview time.\nPart-time schedule of study is available; see\nadvisor.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nCHEM 101 [PSCI] 4\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 102 [BSCI], 106 [BSCI], or\n107 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 102 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSOC 101 or 102 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 251 4\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nMBIOS 101 4\nSTAT 212 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 140 or 333 3\nBIOLOGY 315 4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nH D 101 3\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nNURS 308 3\nNURS 311 4\nNURS 315 4\nNURS 316 2\nNURS 317 3\nNURS 328 2\nSecond Term Hours\nNURS 309 [M] 3\nNURS 322 2\nNURS 323 2\nNURS 324 4\nNURS 325 5\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nNURS 408 3\nNURS 412 1\nNURS 414 3\nNURS 415 2\nNURS 416 3\nNURS 417 2\nSecond Term Hours\nNURS 409 2\nNURS 424 3\nNURS 425 2\nNURS 426 [M] 2\nNURS 427 3\nNURS 430 [CAPS] 3\nNURSING - REGISTERED NURSES OPTION\nCriteria for admission to the RN-BSN Program:\n• Current, unencumbered, Washington State RN\nlicense or eligibility for licensure is required.\n• Applicants must be junior standing (60 semester\nhours/90 quarter hours), have a direct transferable\nAA/AS degree, or have a bachelor’s degree.\n• Must complete College of Nursing prerequisite\nc o u r s e s a n d W S U ’s U n i v e r s i t y C o m m o n\nRequirements (UCORE) or equivalent course work.\nSome associate of arts, associate of science, or\nbachelor’s degrees may satisfy these requirements.\nCheck with your academic advisor or compare\nyour completed courses at the Transfer Credit\nEquivalencies website. Minimum grade for each\nprerequisite course is 2.0 (Pass/Satisfactory grades\nand CLEP scores are not accepted).\n• Cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher in all college\nwork.\nBachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) Option for\nRegistered Nurses: Required courses: NURS 360,\n400, 405, 406, 413, 440, 463, 465, 495, Integrated\nCapstone/upper-division elective.\nDescription of Courses\nNURSING\nNURS\n308 P r o f e s s i o n a l D e v e l o p m e n t I :\nProfessional Roles and Responsibilities\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the major\nin Nursing. First of professional development\nseries; roles of nurses as professional caregivers\nand advocates, based on core values of nursing,\nincorporating therapeutic use of self, ethical\ncomportment, and scope of practice.\n309 [M] Professional Development II:\nEthical Reasoning and Decision Making\nProcesses in Nursing 3 Course Prerequisite:\nNURS 308; NURS 315 or concurrent\nenrollment. Continuation of professional\ndevelopment series; moral/ethical reasoning\nmodels, decision processes, and philosophical\nbasis of nursing as a discipline.\n311 Pathophysiology and Pharmacology\ni n N u r s i n g 4 C o u r s e P r e r e q u i s i t e :\nAdmitted to the major in Nursing. Etiology,\npathogenesis, clinical manifestations of\ncommon human dysfunction; nursing\nimplications for prevention and therapeutic\napproaches including pharmacologic and non-\npharmacologic therapies.\n315 Nursing Practice: Health and Illness 4 (0-\n12) Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the major\nin Nursing. Introduction to nursing practice\nand health assessment: professional values,\ncore competencies, core knowledge and role\ndevelopment. S, F grading.\n316 Introduction to Nursing Practice in\nHealth and Illness: Theory 2 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in Nursing.\nIntroduction to nursing concepts and holistic\nassessment including core professional values,\nknowledge and competencies for nursing\npractice.\n317 H e a l t h A s s e s s m e n t 3 (2-2) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in Nursing.\nSystematic approach to health assessment of\nadults emphasizing and incorporating use of\nnursing process and scientific rationale.\n318 Growth and Development Across the\nLife Span 3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted\nto the major in Nursing. Theoretical and\nconceptual perspectives on human growth\nand development across the life span.\n322 The Human Experience of Diversity and\nHealth 2 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe major in Nursing. Explorations of regional,\nnational, and global expressions of health\nand illness and implications for health care\nprofessionals.\n323 Nursing in the Genome Era 2 Genome\nscience and application of genetic and genomic\nconcepts to nursing care.\n324 Nursing Concepts in Acute and Chronic\nIllness in the Adult 4 Course Prerequisite:\nNURS 311; NURS 315; NURS 316; NURS 317.\nTheoretical concepts of acute and chronic\nillness in the adult as a basis for critical\nthinking and decision-making in nursing.\n\n341 \nWashington State University, 2021\nNursing\n325 Nursing Practice in Acute and Chronic\nIllness in Adults 5 (0-15) Course Prerequisite:\nNURS 311; NURS 315; NURS 316; NURS\n317; concurrent enrollment in NURS 324.\nApplication of acute/chronic illness concepts\nin adults as a basis for critical thinking and\ndecision-making in nursing. S, F grading.\n328 Introduction to Gerontological Nursing\n2 Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNursing. Professional values, communication,\nand functional assessment in care of elders;\ncore knowledge and role development of the\ngerontological nurse.\n360 C o n t e m p o r a r y N u r s i n g 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in Nursing.\nIntegration of foundational nursing theory\ninto an exploration of historical, ethical/legal,\nand current issues, to further develop the\nprofessional nurse.\n365 Nursing Concepts: Assessment and\nApplication of Physiological Concepts\nto Nursing Practice I 2 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Nursing. Integration\no f p a t h o p h y s i o l o g i c a l , a s s e s s m e n t ,\npharmacological nursing concepts with diverse\nclient populations; emphasizing neurological,\nEENT, skin, musculoskeletal, endocrine, and\nrespiratory systems.\n366 Nursing Concepts: Assessment and\nApplication of Physiological Concepts\nto Nursing Practice II 2 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Nursing. Integration\no f p a t h o p h y s i o l o g i c a l , a s s e s s m e n t ,\npharmacological nursing concepts with\ndiverse client populations; emphasizing fluid/\nelectrolytes, oncology, GI/GU; cardiovascular;\nimmune system, renal.\n392 Therapeutic Touch: A Nursing Modality\nof Caring and Healing 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNursing. Explores the broad arena of touch as\na means of interpersonal communication and\nas a mechanism for healing using Krieger-Kunz\nmethod.\n398 Special Topics V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\n399 RN-BSN EXAM 32 S,F Grading. S, F grading.\n400 [M] Nursing Research and Evidence-\nBased Practice 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Nursing. Develops\nclinical questions, finds and critically appraises\npublished evidence, and translates research\ninto clinical practice.\n405 Nursing Leadership 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Nursing. Explores\nleadership theory to critically analyze group\nbehaviors and their effects on health care\noutcomes.\n406 Nursing Management of the Healthcare\nEnvironment 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Nursing. Critically\nanalyzes management strategies in diverse\nsettings with a focus on quality safety and fiscal\naccountability of the changing healthcare\nsystem.\n408 P r o f e s s i o n a l D e v e l o p m e n t I I I :\nLeadership and Management 3 Course\nPrerequisite: NURS 309. Continuation of\nprofessional development series; focus on\nimpact of leadership, management, and\nresource allocation on patient outcomes.\n409 Professional Development IV: Transition\nto Practice 2 Course Prerequisite: NURS 408;\nNURS 414; NURS 415; NURS 416; NURS 417.\nContinuation of professional development\nseries; focus on transition to practice and\nnursing across health care systems/delivery\nwithin global arena.\n412 Family and Community as a Context\nof Care 1 (0-2) Concepts of family-\nfocused nursing assessment, planning, and\ninterventions with emphasis on referral to\nappropriate community resources.\n413 Informatics in Healthcare 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNursing. Leveraging technology, tools, and\ndata to provide more efficient patient-centered\ncare to improve health outcomes.\n414 Child and Family Health: Theory 3\nCourse Prerequisite: NURS 324; NURS 325;\nconcurrent enrollment in NURS 328. Analysis\nand evaluation of scientific and theory base for\nnursing care of children and families.\n415 Children and Families as the Focus of\nNursing Care 2 (0-6) Course Prerequisite:\nNURS 324; NURS 325. Synthesis and\napplication of underlying science and nursing\nprocess with the unique population of children\nand families. S, F grading.\n416 Childbearing Health of the Family 3\nCourse Prerequisite: NURS 324; NURS 325;\nconcurrent enrollment in NURS 328. Care of\nchildbearing families within the context of\ncommunity; newborn health, and men’s and\nwomen’s reproductive health addressed.\n417 Nursing Care of Childbearing Families\n2 (0-6) Course Prerequisite: NURS 324; NURS\n325. Nursing care of families during the\nchildbearing continuum and/or acute care\nsettings; combination of clinical and seminar.\nS, F grading.\n424 Psychiatric/Mental Health Nursing\nConcepts 3 Course Prerequisite: NURS 414;\nNURS 415; NURS 416; NURS 417. Healthy to\npsychopathological states studied within a\nnursing framework; includes history, theories,\nlegal/ethical issues of psychiatric/mental\nhealth nursing.\n425 Nursing Practice: Psychiatric/Mental\nHealth 2 (0-6) Course Prerequisite: NURS\n414; NURS 415; NURS 416; NURS 417;\nconcurrent enrollment in NURS 424. Clinical\napplication of the nursing process with clients\nexperiencing acute and chronic psychiatric/\nmental health disruptions. S, F grading.\n426 [M] Community Health Nursing Theory\n2 Course Prerequisite: NURS 414; NURS 415;\nNURS 416; NURS 417. Synthesis of nursing\nand public health concepts with emphasis on\ncommunity as partner and population-focused\npractice.\n427 Community Health Nursing Practice 3 (0-\n9) Course Prerequisite: NURS 414; NURS 415;\nNURS 416; NURS 417; concurrent enrollment\nin NURS 426. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Nutrition\nand Exercise Physiology\nmedicine.wsu.edu/nutrition-and-exercise-\nphysiology-degree-program/\n665 N. Riverpoint Blvd. #318\n509-358-7811\nChair and Professor, G. Duncan; Associate Professors,\nH. Haverkamp, P. Monsivais; Assistant Professors,\nO. Amram, F. Carbonero, L. Miller, M. Perrigue,\nP. Solverson; Clinical Associate Professor, A. Davis;\nClinical Assistant Professors, S. Niehuser; Teaching\nAssistant Professor, J. Larsen.\nThe Department of Nutrition and Exercise\nPhysiology (NEP) offers the only academic program\nin the state of Washington, and one of few across\nthe nation, that integrates instruction and research\nin both human nutrition and exercise physiology.\nThe department is also unique in that it is housed\nwithin the Elson S. Floyd College of Medicine,\nfacilitating seamless integration with medical\neducation to ensure that future physicians are\nwell grounded in the importance of nutrition and\nexercise as preventative and therapeutic medicine.\nThe Bachelor of Science in NEP is a unique,\ninterdisciplinary undergraduate degree in the health\nsciences that focuses on the effects of nutrition\nand exercise on the health of individuals. Supporting\nprerequisite coursework, detailed in the Program of\nStudy (below), provides a broad knowledge base in\nhuman anatomy, physiology, nutrition, chemistry,\nbiochemistry, and microbiology; however, the\nprimary focus of the upper division major is\non applied nutrition and exercise physiology.\nThe program is accredited by the Committee on\nAccreditation for the Exercise Sciences (CoAES).\nThe degree offers an integrative curricular approach\nin which students gain a unique perspective on\nhow and why the human body responds to various\nnutritional and exercise stimuli through didactic\nand experiential assessment of molecular, genetic,\nclinical, social/psychological, and environmental\nfactors. Students gain experiential learning through\nlaboratories and a senior practicum, followed by a\nsemester-long internship.\nAt the completion of their undergraduate BS\nprogram, students will be expected to demonstrate\neffective written, oral, and visual communication\nskills in a variety of settings and environments\nfor target audiences; apply knowledge of physical,\nchemical, and biological sciences to nutrition\nand exercise sciences; apply knowledge of\nbehavioral and social sciences to nutrition and\nactivity habits of diverse populations; demonstrate\nthe ability to use, interpret, evaluate, and apply\nresearch principles to nutrition and physical\nactivity interventions; demonstrate the application\nof nutrition recommendations and activity\nprogramming for the prevention and management\nof chronic disease; demonstrate their understanding\nof the role of healthcare systems and public\npolicy in the maintenance and achievement of\nhealth; demonstrate critical thinking skills gained\nthroughout the NEP curriculum by utilizing\nproblem-solving activities and assignments;\nperform nutrition and exercise programming and\nwork effectively as a team member in a variety of\nsettings such as acute care, rehabilitation facilities,\nand community health facilities; be well informed\nregarding the characteristics of various health\nand fitness settings and factors that impact their\noperation such as policies, regulatory agencies,\nreimbursement/funding, and legislative issues;\nand model professional skills and behaviors,\nincluding social responsibility, ethical practice, and\na commitment to lifelong learning.\nGraduates will be prepared for successful and\nrewarding careers and job opportunities, including\ncardiac and pulmonary rehabilitation clinical\nprograms; community health centers; university\nand worksite wellness programs; exercise and health\npromotion; and commercial fitness centers, among\nothers. Graduates will be qualified to test for Health\nFitness and Specialty Certifications through the\nAmerican College of Sports Medicine. In addition,\ngraduates may seek admission to graduate programs\nin nutrition and exercise physiology and other\nhealth sciences programs.\nApplications are required for entry into the final\n\n345 \nWashington State University, 2021\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology\ntwo years of the BS NEP. To be a qualified applicant,\nWSU general education requirements, and a specific\nset of BS NEP prerequisites must be complete.\nStudents must have a cumulative GPA of 2.7 or\nbetter, as well as a 3.0 average in all the BS NEP\nprerequisite courses. No grade less than a C will be\naccepted in the BS NEP prerequisites. WSU students\nbased in Pullman are best served by working with an\nacademic advisor in the Health Professions Student\nCenter, https://healthprofessions.wsu.edu/, or 509-\n335-4549. Students from colleges or universities\nother than WSU Pullman will need to contact\nthe Academic Coordinator in the Department of\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology to determine\nappropriate prerequisites: nep@wsu.edu; 509-358-\n7811.\nThe non-thesis Master of Science Coordinated\nProgram in Dietetics, Nutrition, and Exercise\nPhysiology (CPD NEP), is a coordinated program in\ndietetics with an exercise emphasis. The CPD NEP\nis a professional masters degree and is accredited\nby the Accreditation Council for Education in\nNutrition and Dietetics (ACEND), the accrediting\nagency for the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics\n(AND). Successful completion of this MS program\nprepares students to test for the Registered Dietitian\nNutritionist (RDN) credential.\nThe department also offers an MS NEP thesis option\nand the Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) in NEP degrees.\nThese research tracks offer unique opportunities to\npursue research interests in nutrition and exercise\nphysiology, applied to clinical, community, and\npopulation-level settings.\nThe research interests of the faculty include\nn u t r i t i o n e d u c a t i o n , c l i n i c a l n u t r i t i o n\ntherapy, sociocultural factors that influence\ndietary and activity behaviors, clinical and applied\nexercise physiology and nutrition, health benefits\nof new crop varietals, community nutrition and\nactivity programming, environmental and policy-\nlevel influences on diet and activity, and gene by\nenvironment interactions.\nApplications for admission to the graduate\nprograms must include: Official GRE scores, official\ntranscripts for all college-level work, three letters of\nrecommendation, resume, and a purpose statement\ndiscussing career goals and research interests. For\nstudents whose native language is not English,\nTOEFL scores above 100 (Internet based) are\nrequired.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nBACHELOR OF SCIENCE IN NUTRITION\nAND EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY\n(125 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the nutrition and\nexercise physiology major upon completing the\nWSU UCORE courses (or equivalents), B.S. NEP\nprerequisites, a minimum GPA of 3.0 or better,\nand successful formal application to the program.\nApplication is due January 31 each year, to start\ncourses in the Fall semester at WSU Spokane.\nCompletion of the B.S. in Nutrition and Exercise\nPhysiology (NEP) requires a C or higher grade in all\nNEP courses required for the major and a minimum\ncumulative GPA of 2.5 in all required 300-400-level\nNEP courses completed at WSU.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nBIOLOGY 106 [BSCI] 4\nCHEM 101 [PSCI] or 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nSTAT 205 [QUAN] or 212 [QUAN] 3 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 107 4\nCHEM 102 or 106 4\nCOM 102 [COMM] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 333 3\nCHEM 345 4\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nKINES 262 or BIOLOGY 315 4\nPHYSICS 101 and 111 (if needed)\n1 \n0 or 4\nSecond Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 251 or 353 4\nMBIOS 303 4\nMBIOS 305 3\nPHIL 103 [HUM] or 365 [HUM] 3\nPHYSICS 102 and 112 (if needed)\n1 \n0 or 4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nWSU Spokane\nNEP 320 3\nNEP 340 3\nNEP 362 3\nNEP 400 3\nNEP 463 4\nSecond Term Hours\nWSU Spokane\nNEP 402 3\nNEP 427 [M] 3\nNEP 435 4\nNEP 476 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nWSU Spokane\nNEP 458 3\nNEP 477 or 478\n2 \n3\nNEP 479 3\nNEP 489 3\nSecond Term Hours\nWSU Spokane\nNEP 450 3\nNEP 480 or 481\n2 \n3 or 4\nNEP 482 3\nNEP 495 [CAPS] [M] 3\nThird Term Hours\nNEP 490 10\n_______\n1 \nBoth PHYSICS 101/111 and PHYSICS 102/112 are\nrequired for pre-health professional majors (e.g., pre-\nmed). These courses are not required for admission\ninto NEP, but should be taken by those students\nwishing to follow the pre-health professions tracks.\n2 \nStudents completing the Exercise Physiology\ntrack must complete NEP 478 and 480. Students\ncompleting the Community and Public Health track\nmust complete NEP 477 and 481.\nDescription of Courses\nNUTRITION AND EXERCISE PHYSIOLOGY\nNEP\n200 [SSCI] Place and Health 3 Critical review\nof theories and methods to determine how the\nnatural, built, and social environments shape\nindividual and population-level health.\n310 Principles of Strength Training and\nConditioning for Health Professions 2\nCourse Prerequisite: BIOLOGY 251; BIOLOGY\n315. Foundations of strength training and\nconditioning for the general population.\n320 Strength Training and Conditioning;\nTheory and Application 3 (2-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology, or the\nMaster of Science in Coordinated Program in\nDietetics, Nutrition, and Exercise Physiology.\nApplication of scientific principles of strength\nand conditioning as they relate to exercise\ntraining.\n340 Essentials of Food Preparation for\nHealth Sciences 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to the major in Nutrition and\nExercise Physiology, or the Master of Science in\nCoordinated Program in Dietetics, Nutrition,\nand Exercise Physiology. Experimental\napproach to physical, chemical and sensory\nproperties of foods; overview of culinary\ntechniques, technology and application to\nphysical activity.\n362 Biomechanical Analysis 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology. Applied\nsport, clinical, and occupational biomechanics.\n400 Macronutrient Metabolism 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology, or the\nMaster of Science in Coordinated Program in\nDietetics, Nutrition, and Exercise Physiology.\nDigestion, absorption, and metabolism of\ncarbohydrates, protein and fats, and their\nutilization for energy.\n402 Vitamin and Mineral Metabolism 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admitted to the major\nin Nutrition and Exercise Physiology, or the\nMaster of Science in Coordinated Program in\nDietetics, Nutrition, and Exercise Physiology.\nAbsorption and metabolism of vitamins and\nminerals and their role in macronutrient\nmetabolism and nutritional requirements for\nmaintenance of health.\n\n346\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology\nWashington State University, 2021\n427 [M] Nutritional Assessment and Lifestyle\nCounseling 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nConcurrent enrollment required in NEP 402\nand NEP 435; NEP 340; NEP 400; admitted\nto the major in Nutrition and Exercise\nPhysiology. Basic skills and concepts of\nnutrition assessment and lifestyle counseling\nof ambulatory adults using dietary intakes,\nmenu planning and communication skills.\n435 Applied Pathophysiology 4 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology, or the\nMaster of Science Coordinated Program in\nDietetics, Nutrition, and Exercise Physiology.\nPathophysiology of disease and implications\nfor dietary and exercise interventions.\n450 Management and Facilities 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in Nutrition\nand Exercise Physiology. Essential skills and\nguidelines for those in the health facility\nindustry in establishing and maintaining a\nsafe and proper facility.\n458 Nutrition Throughout the Life Cycle 3\nCourse Prerequisite: NEP 400; NEP 402; NEP\n435; admitted to the major in Nutrition and\nExercise Physiology. Physical activity relating\nto nutritional needs and dietary patterns\nfrom infancy through old age and including\nmaternal nutrition.\n460 E x e r c i s e P h y s i o l o g y f o r H e a l t h\nProfessions 3 Course Prerequisite: BIOLOGY\n251; BIOLOGY 315 or KINES 262. Acute and\nchronic physiological responses to exercise;\nemphasis is placed upon energy systems,\nskeletal muscle, nervous system cardiovascular\nsystem, respiratory system, and the endocrine\nsystem.\n463 Exercise Physiology 4 (3-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology. Advanced\nundergraduate exercise physiology with\nemphasis on mechanisms regulating\nphysiological responses to acute and chronic\nexercise.\n476 Exercise Testing and Prescription 3\n(2-3) Course Prerequisite: NEP 320; NEP\n463; admitted to the major in Nutrition and\nExercise Physiology. Principles of exercise\ntesting and prescription based on current\npractices in physical education, physiology,\nand rehabilitation.\n477 Human Health Behavior and Behavioral\nInterventions 3 Analysis of health-related\nbehaviors and the social, cultural, and\nenvironmental context in which they occur;\nexamines how psychological and behavioral\ntraits shape individual-level patterns of\nphysical activity, diet, and health; explores\nhow behavior change theories are used to\ndevelop health interventions for individuals\nand application in clinical and community\nsettings.\n478 Cardiopulmonary Physiology 3 (2-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: NEP 463; admitted to the\nmajor in Nutrition and Exercise Physiology.\nComprehensive analysis of cardiopulmonary\nfunction in healthy humans; students will\nconduct activities related to cardiopulmonary\nfunction during rest and exercise. Required\npreparation: previous course in Anatomy and\nPhysiology.\n479 Nutrition and Exercise Practicum I 3\n(1-6) Course Prerequisite: NEP 427; NEP 435;\nNEP 476; admitted to the major in Nutrition\nand Exercise Physiology. Supervised experience\nin applying exercise and nutrition assessment\ntechniques and developing exercise and\nnutrition prescription for normal and diseased\nsubjects.\n480 Cardiopulmonary Rehabilitation 4 (3-\n3) Course Prerequisite: NEP 435; NEP 463;\nNEP 476; NEP 478; admitted to the major in\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology. Principles\nand applications of exercise assessment/\nprescription and nutrition recommendations\nand program management to cardiopulmonary\nand rehabilitation situations and populations.\n481 Principles of Population Health 3\nCourse Prerequisite: NEP 477. Foundation of\npopulation health including an understanding\nof the difference between population and\nindividual heath, and the history, role, and\npractice of public health; epidemiological\ntheories, concepts, and measures; social\ndeterminants of health and inequalities in\nhealth; population-based approaches to\nimprove health; draws on a wide range of\nhealth research, aiming to apply principles\nand use examples related to obesity, chronic\ndisease, diet, and physical activity.\n482 Nutrition and Exercise Practicum II 3\n(1-6) Course Prerequisite: NEP 479; admitted to\nthe major in Nutrition and Exercise Physiology.\nSupervised experience in applying exercise and\nnutrition assessment techniques for normal\nand diseased subjects.\n489 NEP Internship and Professional\nD e v e l o p m e n t S e m i n a r 3 C o u r s e\nprerequisite: NEP 463; NEP 476; admitted\nto the major in Nutrition and Exercise\nPhysiology. Preparatory activities for students\nto successfully apply for and complete an\ninternship; activities to enhance professional\ndevelopment and group-level and/or one-on-\none advising; delivered in a seminar format. S,\nF grading.\n490 Exercise and Nutrition Internship V 1\n(0-3) to 15 (0-45) Course Prerequisite: NEP\n489; admitted to the major in Nutrition and\nExercise Physiology. Supervised offsite exercise\nfield experience to assess normal and diseased\npopulations and develop/apply exercise\nprescriptions and nutrition recommendations.\nS, F grading.\n495 [CAPS] [M] Interprofessional Capstone\nin Nutrition and Exercise Physiology 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admitted to the major in\nNutrition and Exercise Physiology, Nursing, or\nSpeech and Hearing Sciences at WSU Spokane;\nsenior standing. Culminating experience for\nsenior undergraduates in NEP and health\nscience fields; interprofessional approach\nto address the prevention, diagnosis, and\ntreatment of a variety of health conditions.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n501 Community Supervised Practice 5 (1-\n12) Course Prerequisite: Admission to the\nCoordinated Program in Dietetics. Review\nof literature in dietetic education and health\npromotion including supervised practice in\ncommunity facilities.\n505 Graduate Seminar 1 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 2 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to NEP Graduate\nProgram. Weekly presentations by experts\ncentered around a theme that addresses current\nissues and controversies in the broad fields of\nnutrition and exercise physiology. S, F grading.\n520 Research Methods in Nutrition and\nExercise Physiology 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to NEP Graduate Program. Current\nresearch designs and methods in nutrition and\nexercise physiology including behavioral and\nbasic sciences emphasizing chronic disease\nprevention.\n525 Advanced Human Nutrition 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to NEP Graduate\nProgram. Topics in applied human nutrition\nwith an in-depth study of contemporary\nnutrition research and applications in public\nhealth.\n526 Nutritional Epidemiology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to NEP Graduate\nProgram. The relationship between nutritional\nstatus, diet, and disease at the community and\npopulation level.\n537 Medical Nutrition Therapy I 4 (3-\n3) Course Prerequisite: Admission to the\nCoordinated Program in Dietetics. Theory\nand practical application of medical nutrition\ntherapy for a variety of disease states. Required\npreparation: previous college-level courses in\npathophysiology and nutrition assessment.\n540 Clinical Supervised Practice 11 Course\nPrerequisite: NEP 537; admission to the\nCoordinated Program in Dietetics. Clinical\nsupervised practical experience for graduate\nstudents in coordinated program in dietetics.\n542 Medical Nutrition Therapy II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: NEP 537; admission to the\nCoordinated Program in Dietetics. Theoretical\nand practical application of advanced medical\nnutrition therapy principles to complex disease\nstates.\n\n347 \nWashington State University, 2021\nPharmaceutical Sciences and Molecular Medicine\n551 Management Practices in Food Service\n5 (1-12) Course Prerequisite: Admission to the\nCoordinated Program in Dietetics. Advanced\nprinciples and supervised experience in\nfood systems, institutional food service\nmanagement, school food service and\ncommunity feeding programs.\n560 Geographic Information Systems in\nHealth and Social Sciences 3 Utilizing\nGeographical Information Systems (GIS)\nand mapping tools to examine and visualize\nepidemiological and social science data;\nassess public health, social, and policy issues\nincluding obesity, cardiovascular disease,\nand drug use; explore how this work can be\napplied to interventions. Public health from a nutrition\nperspective including current issues in\nnutrition healthcare, overview of existing\nprograms and assessment of program planning.\n580 Advanced Topics in Exercise Physiology\nand Nutrition 3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 12 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to NEP Graduate\nProgram. In-depth evaluation of current\nresearch in the fields of exercise physiology\nand nutrition; exploration of different topics\nby different instructors on a rotating basis.\n582 Advanced Exercise Physiology 3 (2-\n3) Systematic study of energy metabolism\nand acute and chronic adaptations of\nphysical activity at the whole systems level.\nRecommended preparation: Undergraduate\ncoursework in anatomy and physiology,\nbiochemistry, and exercise physiology.\n585 Clinical Exercise Physiology 3 Exercise\nand nutrition assessment/prescription and\nprogram management in rehabilitation for\npopulations in various disease states.\n586 Physical Activity Epidemiology and\nPublic Health 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to NEP Graduate Program. An in-\ndepth evaluation of topics relevant to the study\nof physical activity and public health globally.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. S, U grading.\nThe Pharmaceutical\nSciences and Molecular\nMedicine Graduate Program\npharmacy.wsu.edu/ph-d-in-pharmaceutical-\nsciences/\n509-368-6607\nChair and Professor, P. Lazarus; Pharmaceutical\nSciences and Molecular Medicine Graduate Program\nDirector and Associate Professor, D. Jackson; Professors,\nS. Ahmed, K. Gibson, A. Lazarus, K. Meier, M. Paine,\nJ-B Roullet, S. Tolmachev, J. White, J. Zhu; Associate\nProfessors, G. Chen, S. Daoud, S. Gaddameedhi, W.\nLi, S. Marsh, B. Prasad, S. Wang, Z. Wang; Assistant\nProfessors, A. Ahmed, M. Avtandilashvili, Z. Cheng, J.\nClarke, T. Denton, S. Natesan, C. Remsberg, J. Sun, G.\nTabatadze, B. Wu, H. Zhang.\nThe mission of the Graduate Program in\nPharmaceutical Sciences and Molecular Medicine\nis to produce graduates for teaching, research, and\nclinical careers in academia, industry, health care,\nand other public and private institutions dedicated\nto the promotion of human health and wellness.\nWe utilize multi-disciplinary basic and translational\nresearch approaches to 1) understand mechanisms\nof disease, 2) identify novel therapeutic targets, 3)\ndevelop and optimize pharmaceutical treatment\napproaches, and 4) promote the prevention and\nmanagement of chronic diseases. Pharmacology,\npharmacotherapeutics, biopharmaceutics, and\npharmacogenomics are emphasized in the\ncurriculum. Particular areas of focus are: drug\ndiscovery, translational pharmacology, and cancer\nbiology. We strive to prepare students to become\nindependent and creative problem solvers who will\ndevelop into leaders in their respective fields.\nStudents entering the program should have\ncompleted undergraduate work that includes\nbiology, chemistry (including organic chemistry\nand biochemistry), mathematics (through calculus),\nand organ/mammalian physiology course. Students\nworking toward the PhD in Pharmaceutical\nScience and Molecular Medicine are expected\nto develop an area of research emphasis that is\nconsistent with the capabilities and interests of the\nfaculty.\nA PharmD/PhD combined degree option is\navailable to train clinician scientists. Interested\nstudents may apply for PhD admission during the\nfirst two years of their progression through the\nPharmD program.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n• Demonstrate mastery of knowledge in the\ngeneral fields of Pharmaceutical Sciences and\nMolecular Medicine.\n• Develop the expertise to use appropriate\nmethodologies to solve novel and emerging\nproblems related to Pharmaceutical Sciences and\nMolecular Medicine.\n• Disseminate research findings to local, regional,\nnational, and international audiences primarily\nthrough publication in peer-reviewed journals and\npresentations at conferences.\n• Participate in professional organizations,\nincluding becoming members, attending meetings,\nand taking leadership roles where appropriate.\n• Participate in teaching, internships, fellowships,\nworkshops, credentialing, and grant applications to\nenhance competitiveness for career opportunities\nas appropriate.\n• Develop critical, integrative, and evaluative\nthinking at the highest levels of rigor.\n• D e v e l o p a d v a n c e d w r i t t e n a n d o r a l\ncommunication skills.\n• Become independent, self-motivated researchers\nwith the ability to identify specific problems in their\nfield of expertise and to formulate solutions to these\nproblems.\n• Develop a comprehensive knowledge of previous\nand current research in their field of expertise and be\nable to demonstrate that knowledge capability in a\nreview of the literature at a level that is potentially\npublishable.\n• Generate innovative questions within their field\nof expertise and pose hypotheses related to those\nquestions.\n• Apply sound methodological approaches to test\nhypotheses related to specific research questions\nand describe the methods effectively.\n• Perform statistical analyses of research data and\npresent the results in a way that clearly describes\nthe data.\nApplications for admission to the graduate\nprogram must include: Official GRE scores, official\ntranscripts for all college level work, three letters\nof recommendation, and a letter discussing career\ngoals, previous research experience, and research\ninterests. For students whose native language is not\nEnglish, TOEFL scores are required. Inquiries should\nbe emailed to: gradprograms@pharmacy.wsu.edu.\n\n348\nDescription of Courses\nPHARMACEUTICAL SCIENCES GRADUATE\nPROGRAM\nPHARMSCI\n505 Principles and Methods of Toxicology\n3 Course Prerequisite: MBIOS 513. Basic\nconcepts in mammalian toxicology and\nthe methodology currently employed for\ntoxicological investigations. Required\npreparation: 300-level organ/mammalian\nphysiology course.\n512 Topics in Pharmacology V 1-4 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n12 hours. Topics of current interest in\npharmacology and closely related disciplines.\n520 Foundations of Molecular Regulation\nand Cellular Regulation 4 Cellular biology,\nmolecular biology, genetics, and biochemistry\nused to develop therapeutic approaches for the\ntreatment and prevention of human disease\nstates.\n540 Fundamentals of Chronopharmacology\n3 Role of the circadian clock in pharmacology\nas it relates to therapeutic efficacy; special\nemphasis on anti-cancer drug treatment.\n555 General and Cellular Physiology 4 (3-\n3) Physiochemical mechanisms of cellular\nfunction. (Crosslisted course offered as VET\nPH 555, PHARMSCI 555). Recommended\npreparation: Concurrent enrollment in MBIOS\n513.\n560 Molecular and Cellular Methods in\nBiomedical Sciences 3 Basic experimental\nmethods and approaches in cell and molecular\nbiology, with an emphasis on practical skills\nand their appropriate application.\n565 Drug Delivery 3 Comprehensive overview\nof drug delivery at the molecular, cellular,\nand organ levels; concepts and approaches as\napplied to multiple diseases.\n566 Fundamentals of Toxicology 3 Application\nof toxicology in the safety evaluation and risk\nassessment at the molecular, cellular, and organ\nlevels; special emphasis on the concepts and\napproaches applied to organ system toxicology.\n571 Computer-Aided Drug Design 3 (2-\n2) Course Prerequisite: Graduate standing\nin the Pharmaceutical Sciences graduate\nprogram and permission from the instructor.\nPrinciples and applications of ligand-based and\nstructure-based computational methods used\nin lead optimization in drug discovery and\ndevelopment processes.\n572 Fundamentals of Oncology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: By permission only. Thorough\noverview of cancer biology encompassing\nbasic cellular and molecular mechanisms\nof carcinogenesis and tumor progression,\ntreatment and prevention.\n573 Principles of Pharmacokinetics and\nTo x i c o k i n e t i c s 3 Pharmacokinetic,\npharmacodynamic, and toxicokinetic systems;\nmathematical model development utilizing\ncommon kinetic systems.\n575 R e c e p t o r - L i g a n d I n t e r a c t i o n s 3\nInteractions of drugs with biological\nm a c r o m o l e c u l e s c o n s t i t u t i n g t h e\nphysicochemical basis of drug action.\n576 Biophysical Methods 3 Biophysical methods\nseparating or detecting analytes based on their\nphysical interactions with a support matrix or\nenergy.\n577 Responsible Conduct in Biomedical\nResearch 3 Training in biomedical research\nethics consistent with NIH requirements;\nintroduction to literature searching and analysis,\nscientific writing, and oral presentations.\n578 Applied Biostatistics 3 Research process;\ntechniques for conducting health sciences\nresearch and evaluation; critique published\nhealth sciences research and collect, utilize,\nand evaluate primary and secondary data.\n579 Principles of Pharmacology 3 Key\nprinciples of drug pharmacodynamics,\np h a r m a c o k i n e t i c s , o r g a n s y s t e m\npharmacology, and cutting-edge biomedical\nresearch-based drug discovery.\n580 Gene and Stem Cell Therapies 3 Stem\ncell therapeutics, gene transfer vectors and\nmethods for isolating and generating stem\ncells; stem cell therapeutics, presentation skills\nand evaluation of primary literature.\n581 Stem Cell Biology, Therapeutics and\nRegenerative Medicine 3 Provides\ninformation on the latest cutting edge research\nin the areas of stem cell biology and tissue\nregeneration; covers stem cell therapeutics,\ngene transfer vectors and methods for isolating,\ncharacterizing, and generating stem cells. (Course\noffered as PHARMSCI 581, ANIM SCI 581).\n597 College of Pharmacy Graduate Seminar\n1 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 12 hours. (Crosslisted course offered\nas PHARMSCI 597, NEP 597.) S, F grading.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit.
