Course Prerequisite: Admitted to\nthe Pharmaceutical Sciences PhD program.\nIndependent research and advanced study for\nstudents working on their doctoral research,\ndissertation and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n800 credit. S, U grading.\nCollege of Pharmacy and\nPharmaceutical Sciences\nwww.pharmacy.wsu.edu\nSpokane\n509-368-6700\nCOLLEGE OF PHARMACY AND PHARMACEUTICAL\nSCIENCES: Dean and Professor, M. Leid; Vice Dean\nand Professor, L. Garrelts MacLean; Associate Dean and\nProfessor, A. Lazarus; Associate Dean and Professor,\nK. Meier; Associate Dean and Associate Professor, J.\nRobinson; Associate Dean and Associate Professor,\nA. Stewart. DEPARTMENT OF PHARMACEUTICAL\nSCIENCES: Chair and Professor, P. Lazarus; Professors,\nS. Ahmed, M. Paine, J. Zhu; Associate Professors, S.\nDaoud, D. Jackson, S. Marsh, B. Prasad, S. Wang, Z.\nWang; Assistant Professors, A. Ahmed, Z. Cheng, J.\nClarke, T. Denton, S. Gaddameedhi, S. Natesan, C.\nRemsberg, B. Wu, H. Zhang. DEPARTMENT OF\nPHARMACOTHERAPY: Chair and Professor, J. White;\nProfessors, D. Baker, B. Gates, K. Gibson, T. Levien, J-B\nRoullet; Associate Professors, J. Akers, R. Crutchley, K.\nMcKeirnan, J. Neumiller, M. Undeberg, M. Willson;\nAssistant Professors, T. Bertsch, D. Bowers, D. Brand,\nC. Buchman, J. Clark, M. Giruzzi, N. Giruzzi, A. Kim,\nL. MacCamy, L. Marcath, J. Miller, C. Newsome, N.\nPerea, M. Thomas.\nThe College of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical\nSciences (CPPS) offers a course of study leading\nto a Doctor of Pharmacy (PharmD) degree.\nThe PharmD curriculum is comprised of four\nprofessional years. The first three professional years\nare delivered at the WSU Health Sciences campus\nin Spokane, Washington and the Pacific Northwest\nUniversity of Health Sciences Campus in Yakima,\nWashington. During the first three years, student\npharmacists develop a foundation in biomedical\nand pharmaceutical sciences, engage in peer-to-\npeer role play and simulations of clinical scenarios,\nand eventually work with complicated patient\ncases and develop confidence in building patient\nspecific plans.\nDuring the fourth professional year, students gain\nexperience in a variety of health care environments,\nincluding community, institutional and long-term\ncare settings. The curriculum consists of 6 six-\nweek rotations of advanced experiential training,\nin which students will be assigned to one of the\nfollowing geographic locations: Spokane, Yakima,\nTri-Cities/Walla Walla, Wenatchee, Seattle/Tacoma,\nOlympia, Pullman, or northern California. Students\nhave the opportunity to preference their preferred\ngeographic locations to complete the majority of\nrotations.\nThe college offers an additional degree option,\nthe Doctor of Pharmacy with Research Honors.\nThe curriculum for this option includes additional\ncoursework: a course in responsible conduct\nof research, and research credits taken in both\nsemesters of the second and third professional years.\nInterested students may apply for admission to the\nResearch Honors program in their first professional\nyear.\nWe enroll approximately 170 students to the\nDoctor of Pharmacy program annually in the\nfall, 135 for the Spokane campus and 35 for the\nYakima PharmD Extension. The application period\neach academic year is from July to January. We\nrecommend students prepare and submit their\napplication one calendar year before they intend to\nPharmaceutical Sciences and Molecular Medicine\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n349\nbegin the pharmacy program. Although a bachelor\ndegree is not required for admission, pre-requisites\nfor admission require three years of pre-pharmacy\neducation.\nAs a college, we utilize a holistic application\nreview process. This process considers a range of\ncharacteristics beyond academic metrics such as\ngrades and test scores. While we will evaluate grades\nand prerequisite grade trends, we will also evaluate\nstudents on a case-by-case basis by reviewing letters\nof recommendation, personal statements, and\nour professional goal statements. After our initial\napplication review, you may be invited to a Doctor\nof Pharmacy interview. We encourage interviewees\nto be themselves and share stories throughout the\ninterview to help us better understand you and your\nmotivations.\nFor additional information regarding the Doctor\nof Pharmacy curriculum, please see the CPPS home\npage at https://pharmacy.wsu.edu or contact the\nCPPS Office of Student Services at 509-368-6605.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nWashington State University College of Pharmacy\nand Pharmaceutical Sciences (CPPS) PharmD\nCurriculum Outcomes are Standards 1, 2, 3, and\n4 of the Accreditation Council for Pharmacy\nEducation (ACPE) Standards 2016. The complete\nACPE Standards 2016 are available at https://\nacpe-accredit.org/. Curriculum committee assigns\nPharmD Curriculum Outcomes to each required\ncourse in the curriculum.\nPharmD Curriculum Outcomes\nIn the Doctor of Pharmacy program, students are\ntrained to provide patient-centered care as part of\nthe integrated health care team. Students learn to\nserve as the medication expert, working directly\nwith patients to optimize and personalize their\nmedicines to fit their needs and improve health.\nUpon graduation from the Doctor of Pharmacy\nprogram, all graduates will demonstrate competency\nin the following outcomes:\nStandard 1: Foundational Knowledge\nThe graduate is able to develop, integrate, and\napply knowledge from the foundational sciences\n(i.e., biomedical, pharmaceutical, social/behavioral/\nadministrative, and clinical sciences) to evaluate\nthe scientific literature, explain drug action, solve\ntherapeutic problems, and advance population\nhealth and patient-centered care.\nStandard 2: Essentials for Practice and Care\n2.A. Patient-centered care – The graduate is able\nto provide patient-centered care as the medication\nexpert (collect and interpret evidence, prioritize,\nformulate assessments and recommendations,\nimplement, monitor and adjust plans, and\ndocument activities).\n2.B. Medication use systems management – The\ngraduate is able to manage patient healthcare needs\nusing human, financial, technological, and physical\nresources to optimize the safety and efficacy of\nmedication use systems.\n2.C. Health and wellness – The graduate is able to\ndesign prevention, intervention, and educational\nstrategies for individuals and communities to\nmanage chronic disease and improve health and\nwellness.\n2.D. Population-based care – The graduate is able\nto describe how population-based care influences\npatient-centered care and the development of\npractice guidelines and evidence-based best\npractices.\nStandard 3: Approach to Practice and Care\n3.A. Problem solving – The graduate is able to\nidentify problems; explore and prioritize potential\nstrategies; and design, implement, and evaluate a\nviable solution.\n3.B. Education – The graduate is able to educate\nall audiences by determining the most effective and\nenduring ways to impart information and assess\nlearning.\n3.C. Patient advocacy – The graduate is able to\nrepresent the patient’s best interests.\n3.D. Interprofessional collaboration – The\ngraduate is able to actively participate and engage\nas a healthcare team member by demonstrating\nmutual respect, understanding, and values to meet\npatient care needs.\n3.E. Cultural sensitivity – The graduate is able to\nrecognize social determinants of health to diminish\ndisparities and inequities in access to quality care.\n3.F. Communication – The graduate is able to\neffectively communicate verbally and nonverbally\nwhen interacting with individuals, groups, and\norganizations.\nStandard 4: Personal and Professional Development\n4.A. Self-awareness – The graduate is able to\nexamine and reflect on personal knowledge,\nskills, abilities, beliefs, biases, motivation, and\nemotions that could enhance or limit personal and\nprofessional growth.\n4.B. Leadership – The graduate is able to\ndemonstrate responsibility for creating and\nachieving shared goals, regardless of position.\n4.C. Innovation and entrepreneurship – The\ngraduate is able to engage in innovative activities\nby using creative thinking to envision better ways\nof accomplishing professional goals.\n4.D. Professionalism – The graduate is able to\nexhibit behaviors and values that are consistent\nwith the trust given to the profession by patients,\nother healthcare providers, and society\nPharmacy Prerequisites for Admission to\nthe Professional Pharmacy Program\n(Students transferring from the quarter system\nwill have transferrable credits converted to semester\ncredits upon acceptance into the PharmD program.\nAll transfer credits will be evaluated by WSU\nUndergraduate Admissions office. Please refer to our\ninformation page on PharmCAS for the most up to\ndate information on pre-required coursework and\napplication requirements. The following courses\nare required for admission and represent acceptable\nWSU courses.)\n• Written Communication I (3 credits)\n• Written Communication II (3 credits)\n• Philosophy – Logic, Critical Thinking or Ethics\n(3 credits)\n• Microeconomics – ECONS 101 (3 credits)\n• Introductory Psychology – PSYCH 105 (3 credits)\n• Calculus – MATH 140, 171, or 202 (3 or 4 credits)\n• Statistics – STAT 212 (3 credits )\n• Introductory Biology – BIOLOGY 106 and 107\n(8 credits)\n• Principles of Chemistry – CHEM 105 and 106\n(8 credits)\n• Organic Chemistry – CHEM 345 and 348 (8\ncredits)\n• Microbiology – MBIOS 305 (3 credits)\n• Microbiology and Molecular Biology Laboratory\n– MBIOS 304 (3 credits)\n• Human Anatomy with lab – BIOLOGY 315 (4\ncredits)\n• Advanced Human Physiology – BIOLOGY 353 (4\ncredits)\n• Biochemistry – MBIOS 303 (4 credits)\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nDOCTOR OF PHARMACY (PHARMD)\nCURRICULUM\n(135 HOURS)\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nPHARDSCI 502 4\nPHARDSCI 504 1\nPHARDSCI 508 3\nPHARDSCI 528 3\nPHARMACY 506 1\nPHARMACY 507 1\nPHARMACY 509 1\nPHARMACY 516 2\nSecond Term Hours\nPHARDSCI 510 2\nPHARDSCI 512 4\nPHARDSCI 518 2\nPHARDSCI 519 1\nPHARMACY 501 1\nPHARMACY 513 1\nPHARMACY 514 4\nElectives\n1 \n3 - Students interested in\npursuing the Research Honors plan should attend\ninformational sessions and consult with the policies\nfor the Research Honors Program, and then apply\nfor entry to this program during the second term\nof their first year in the PharmD curriculum.\nProspective Research Honors students must enroll\nin PHARMACY or PHARDSCI 499 or 599 in the\nsecond term of their first professional year before\napplying to the Research Honors program. The\nprogram requires selection of a research mentor,\nongoing research work (PHARDSCI 598; total of\nat least 8 credits required) during the second and\nthird professional years, completion of PHARMSCI\n577 in the first term of the second professional\nyear, presentation of research plans in the second\nprofessional year, and submission of a culminating\npaper to the Research Honors Program in the third\nprofessional year.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nPHARDSCI 502 4\nPHARDSCI 504 1\nPHARDSCI 508 3\nPHARDSCI 528 3\nPHARMACY 506 1\nPHARMACY 507 1\nPHARMACY 509 1\nPHARMACY 516 2\nSecond Term Hours\nPHARDSCI 510 2\nPHARDSCI 512 4\nPHARDSCI 518 2\nPHARDSCI 519 1\nPHARMACY 501 1\nPHARMACY 513 1\nPHARMACY 514 4\nPHARMACY or PHARDSCI 499 or 599\n1 \n1 - 4\nElectives\n1 \n3 - 0\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nPHARDSCI 532 4\nPHARDSCI 598 1 - 4\nPHARMACY 530 2\nPHARMACY 531 1\nPHARMACY 533 3\nPHARMACY 534 4\nPHARMACY 536 1\nPHARMACY 545 3\nPHARMSCI 577 3\nElectives\n1 \n2 - 0\nSecond Term Hours\nPHARDSCI 542 4\nPHARDSCI 547 2\nPHARDSCI 598 1 - 4\nPHARMACY 541 1\nPHARMACY 543 1\nPHARMACY 544 4\nPHARMACY 558 2\nPHARMACY 559 2\nElectives\n1 \n3 - 0\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nPHARDSCI 598 1 - 4\nPHARMACY 551 2\nPHARMACY 553 3\nPHARMACY 554 4\nPHARMACY 556 1\nPHARMACY 566 3\nElectives\n1 \n2 - 0\nSecond Term Hours\nPHARDSCI 598 1 - 4\nPHARMACY 555 4\nPHARMACY 557 4\nPHARMACY 561 2\nPHARMACY 563 2\nPHARMACY 564 3\nElectives\n1 \n2 - 0\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAdvanced Pharmacy\nPractice Experiences (APPE)\n2 \n15\nSecond Term Hours\nAdvanced Pharmacy\nPractice Experiences (APPE)\n2 \n15\n_______\n1 \nElective Courses: 12 credits of electives involving\na minimum of 4 courses are required throughout\nthe first three years of the curriculum. H, S, F\ngrading.\n570 Pain: Processes and Treatment 2 Course\nPrerequisite: PHARDSCI 512. Skills, education,\nand awareness in topics related to pain processes,\npharmacological and nonpharmacological\ntreatments, legal processes and resources,\nand inter-professional communication for\nimproved patient outcomes. S, F grading.\n571 Creative Problem Solving - Advanced\nCompounding 2 Course Prerequisite:\nPHARDSCI 508; PHARDSCI 519. Development\nof strong problem-solving skills through\nthe application of prior knowledge of\npharmaceutics and compounding, as well\nas new information gained from pre-class\nmaterials and available literature; discuss,\npropose, develop, and test novel alternative\nformulations for compounded products in\norder to address a given problem encountered\nin compounding pharmacy; evaluate results\nfrom in-class experiments to make a conclusive\nrecommendation as to how to address the\nproposed issue. S, F grading.\n572 Physical Activity Prescription in the\nPharmacy 2 Course Prerequisite: Admission\nto Pharmacy program. Knowledge and skill\nset for student pharmacists to apply evidence-\nbased guidelines to recommend and promote\nphysical activity in their patients. S, F grading.\n573 Family Medicine and Pharmacy 2\nCourse Prerequisite: PHARMACY 544 or 554.\nWide range of both inpatient and outpatient\nfamily medicine topics including but\nnot limited to, anticoagulation, diabetes,\nhypertension, heart failure, polypharmacy,\natrial fibrillation, COPD and asthma; serves\nas a bridge between therapeutic courses and\nexperiential APPE rotations. S, F grading.\n574 Veterinary Pharmacy 2 Course Prerequisite:\nPHARMACY 534. Basic pathophysiology\nof diseases in small and large animals and\ncurrent treatments likely to be dispensed by\ncommunity pharmacists. S, F grading.\n577 Diseases, Complications, and Drug\nTherapy in Obstetrics 2 Course Prerequisite:\nPHARDSCI 532; admission to Pharmacy\nprogram. Medical and pharmacological issues\ncommon in obstetrics. S,\nF grading.\nDepartment of Physics and\nAstronomy\nphysics.wsu.edu\nWebster 1245\n509-335-1698\nChair and Professor, B. Saam; Regents Professors, Y. M.\nGupta, M. G. Kuzyk; Professors, S. Bose, G. S. Collins,\nP. Engels, Y. Gu, P. L. Marston, M.D. McCluskey, S.\nL. Tomsovic; Associate Professors, B. A. Collins, S. L.\nDexheimer, M. Duez, M. Forbes, G. Worthey; Assistant\nProfessors, V. Baldassare, R. Bisset, J. McMahon;\nScholarly Professor, F. Gittes; Scholarly Associate\nProfessors, M. Allen, N. Cerruti; Teaching Assistant\nProfessor, A. Rasmussen.\nPhysics is the study of nature at its most fundamental\nlevel. It is the science upon whose principles all\nother sciences and technologies are based. A major\nin physics is ideal preparation not only for further\nstudy in physics but also for advanced study in\nbiophysics, medicine, astrophysics, geophysics,\nchemical physics, engineering, meteorology, and\ncomputer science. All of these areas also offer\npotential careers for the physics major.\nCourses offered introduce the student to the major\nphysical theories: mechanics, thermodynamics and\nstatistical physics, electricity and magnetism, and\nquantum physics. Additional undergraduate courses\ncover optics, atomic physics, nuclear physics, solid\nstate physics, biological physics, and astrophysics.\nStudents test the theories in laboratories and\nlearn experimental techniques needed to work\nwith modern apparatus such as computers, high-\nvacuum equipment, lasers, and electronic and\noptical devices.\nActive research programs supported by federal\ngrants and contracts are pursued in the following\nfields: acoustics (scattering, nonlinear processes,\nand levitation); astrophysics (planetary, stellar,\nand galactic structure and evolution); astrophysical\ngeneration of gravitational waves, gravitational\nwave data analysis, cosmology; optical properties\nof semiconductors; biophysics; nanoscale physics\nand materials, Bose-Einstein condensates, cluster\nphysics; optical physics (femtosecond laser\nspectroscopy, scattering from doped polymers,\nnonlinear optics, quantum electronics, Fourier\nspectroscopy, diffraction catastrophes); physics\neducation (use of microcomputers in teaching\nand labs); nuclear solid state physics (MÖssbauer\neffect, perturbed angular correlation, positron\nannihilation studies of defects in solids); shock wave\nand high pressure physics (chemical and structural\nresponse of condensed materials to high dynamic\npressures, time-resolved optical spectroscopy,\nshock and detonation wave propagation, chemical\nreactions, dynamic mechanical failure); surface\nand chemical physics (synchrotron SAFS, diamond\nfilms, molecular interactions with surfaces,\nreactive etching of surfaces, photoelectric and\nthermal emission microscopy); theory (quantum\nchaos, nonlinear dynamics, mesoscopic systems,\nphase transitions and critical phenomena,\nquantum liquids and gases, atomic and molecular\nphysics (ultra-cold atoms, optical pumping,\nmagnetic resonance), classical and quantum gravity,\nblack hole thermodynamics, and low-temperature\nphysics). These research groups offer graduate\nstudents the opportunity to pursue original\ninvestigations required for advanced degrees.\nUndergraduate physics majors are encouraged to\nparticipate in research through the special-project\ncourse (PHYSICS 499) and through part-time jobs\nthat are sometimes available.\nThe department offers courses of study leading to\nthe degrees of Bachelor of Science in Physics, Master\nof Science in Physics, and Doctor of Philosophy\n(Physics).\nAstronomy courses at both the undergraduate and\ngraduate levels are administered by the department.\nInstruction in astronomy is enhanced by the use\nof a 12-inch telescope at the Jewett Observatory,\nthe Spitz planetarium, and faculty research at LIGO\ngravitational-wave observatory. Opportunities are\navailable for students to collaborate with faculty to\ndo research projects.\nPharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n353\nThe Department of Physics and Astronomy is a\nmajor participant in the Materials Science Program\nand offers courses and research opportunities\nleading to advanced degrees in this interdisciplinary\nprogram.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nA student who has completed the undergraduate\nprogram in physics will be able to use scientific\nreasoning to form and test hypotheses; think\nindependently and critically in acquiring,\nreproducing, and assessing information from\na variety of sources; understand the important\nconcepts in each of the four core areas of physics:\nmechanics, electricity and magnetism, modern\nand quantum physics, and thermal and statistical\nphysics; apply these concepts in mathematical\nmodels to solve theoretical and real-world problems;\ndesign and conduct scientific experiments which\ntest new ideas and theories; present concepts and\nresults clearly, both orally and in writing; and\nbe prepared for graduate study and/or careers in\nphysics and related fields.\nTransfer Students\nTransfer students receive credit for equivalent\ncourses taken elsewhere, but must meet the\nrequirements for graduation listed.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nUndergraduate students contemplating graduate\nwork in physics should consider enrolling in\nPHYSICS 443, 521, 571, and additional math\ncourses.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nAPPLIED PHYSICS OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nThe program of courses below is appropriate\nfor students who wish to enter industry upon\ngraduation. The program of courses below is\nappropriate for students who have had a good\nexperience with calculus in high school and wish\nto start physics in the first semester at WSU (even\nthough the student may be placed in MATH 171,\nif their high school grades for the year course\nwere B or better they can follow this schedule of\nstudy). Students who have placed in MATH 172\ncan accelerate the math sequence. Students who\nhave not had calculus in high school should defer\nPHYSICS 201/211 until they have completed MATH\n171. Upon consultation with the departmental\nadvisor, modifications can be made in the list\nof required courses to fit the needs of individual\nstudents. The schedule of studies below includes\nthe additional lab credit required for graduation by\nthe College of Arts and Sciences.\nAdmission to the Major requirements\nStudents may be admitted to the major upon\nmaking their intentions known to the department.\nGraduation Requirements\nA research experience is required of all students as\na PHYSICS 499 project; however, to gain valuable\nwork experience outside the university, students\nare strongly encouraged to participate in an\ninternship or research experience in industry or a\ngovernment lab outside of WSU. The summer after\nthe junior year is the most appropriate time for this\nexperience. All students are required to submit an\nundergraduate thesis to a committee of two physics\nfaculty members in the senior year. PHYSICS 490\nwill give credit for this effort. The student must earn\na C (2.0) or better grade in each of the required\nphysics courses.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nCHEM 105 [PSCI] 4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nMATH 171 [QUAN] 4\nMSE 110 2\nPHYSICS at least two hours from ASTRONOM\n390, PHYSICS 490, or 499; and at least 3 hours\nfrom ASTRONOM 135, HISTORY 381, or SOE 103.\nThe minor also requires MATH 273 and PHYSICS\n303. These courses have as prerequisites MATH\n171, 172, 220, and PHYSICS 201/211 and 202/212.\nThese prerequisites are often required as part of\nphysical science major programs (Chemistry,\nComputer Science, Earth and Environmental\nScience, Engineering, and Physics) so that students\nin these fields will find the astronomy minor more\naccessible than students in other fields. Credit\nhours for the minor must include 9 hours of upper-\ndivision work taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses.\nPhysics\nA Physics minor requires PHYSICS 201/211,\n202/212, 303, and 304 plus any two courses (6\ncredits) from the following list: PHYSICS 320, 330,\nPhysics and Astronomy\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n355\n341, 342, 410, 415 [M], 443, 450, 461, 463, or 465.\nThis makes a total of 20 credits in PHYSICS, of which\n12 are upper division. Credit hours must include 9\nhours of upper-division work taken in residence\nat WSU or through WSU-approved education\nabroad or educational exchange courses. Students\nfrom outside the College of Arts and Sciences (i.e.,\nCollege of Engineering) do not have to meet the\nextra graduation requirements of the College of Arts\nand Sciences.\nDescription of Courses\nASTRONOMY\nASTRONOM\n135 [PSCI] Astronomy 4 (3-2) Overview of\nthe solar system, stars, galaxies, cosmology,\nand the history of astronomy. Includes a lab\ncomponent with occasional evening meetings.\nCredit not granted for both ASTRONOM 135\nand 150.\n138 [PSCI] Planets and Planetary Systems 3\nFormation and dynamics of planetary systems;\nmajor planets: interiors, surfaces, atmospheres;\nminor planets: moons, asteroids, comets;\nscience missions; extrasolar planets.\n150 Science and the Universe 3 Basic structure\nand history of science and science reasoning\nwith emphasis on astronomy, observational\npractice, and data analysis. Credit not granted\nfor both ASTRONOM 135 and 150.\n345 Principles of Astronomy 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 4 credits of PHYSICS 202, or\nPHYSICS 202 and 212, or PHYSICS 206; MATH\n172 or 182. Planets, the sun, stars, and galaxies;\ncurrent topics in astrophysics and planetary\nresearch.\n390 [PSCI] The Night Sky 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: Science [BSCI] or [PSCI] UCORE\ncourse. Star names, magnitude scales,\nconstellation identification, astronomical\ncoordinates, solar, lunar and planetary\nmotions, practical astronomy. Some outdoor\nevening time required.\n435 Astronomy and Astrophysics I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 4 credits of PHYSICS 202, or\nPHYSICS 202 and 212, or PHYSICS 206; MATH\n172 or 182. Planets, solar systems, and stars.\n436 Astronomy and Astrophysics II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 4 credits of PHYSICS 202, or\nPHYSICS 202 and 212, or PHYSICS 206;\nMATH 172 or 182. Exotic objects, galaxies, and\ncosmology.\n450 [CAPS] Life in the Universe 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Mathematics [N] or [QUAN];\njunior standing. The natural history of life\non earth and prospects for life elsewhere;\nincludes chemistry, biology, geology, physics\nand astronomy. Recommended preparation:\nCompletion of physical and biological sciences\nGERs/UCOREs.\n581 Advanced Topics in Astronomy 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 12\nhours. Advanced topics of current interest in\nastronomy. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\nPHYSICS\nPHYSICS\n101 [ P S C I ] G e n e r a l P h y s i c s 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: PHYSICS 111 or concurrent\nenrollment; MATH 108 with a grade of C or\nbetter, a minimum ALEKS math placement\nscore 75%, or passing MATH 140, 171, 202,\nor 206. Algebra/trigonometry-based physics;\ntopics in mechanics, wave phenomena,\ntemperature, and heat; oriented toward non-\nphysical science majors.\n102 General Physics 3 Course Prerequisite: 4\ncredits of PHYSICS 101 with a C or better,\nor PHYSICS 101 and 111 with a C or better;\nPHYSICS 112 or concurrent enrollment; MATH\n108 with a grade of C or better, a minimum\nALEKS math score 75%, or passing MATH\n140, 171, or 202. Algebra/trigonometry-based\nphysics; topics in electricity, magnetism,\noptical phenomena, relativity, and quantum\ntheory; oriented toward non-physical science\nmajors.\n103 Problem Solving for Physics 101 1\nCourse Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in\nPHYSICS 101 and 111. Small class environment\nfor students who desire focused attention on\nproblem solving skills as applied to PHYSICS\n101 and 111 materials. S, F grading.\n104 Problem Solving for Physics 102 1\nCourse Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in\nPHYSICS 102 and 112. Small class environment\nfor students who desire focused attention on\nproblem solving skills as applied to PHYSICS\n102 materials. S, F grading.\n111 [PSCI] General Physics Lab 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 108 with a grade of C or\nbetter, a minimum ALEKS math placement\nscore 75%, or passing MATH 140, 171, 202, or\n206; PHYSICS 101 or concurrent enrollment.\nAlgebra/trigonometry-based physics labs;\ntopics in mechanics, wave phenomena,\ntemperature, and heat; oriented toward non-\nphysical science majors.\n112 General Physics Lab II 1 (0-3) Course\nPrerequisite: PHYSICS 102 or concurrent\nenrollment. Algebra/trigonometry-based\nphysics lab; topics in electricity, magnetism,\noptical phenomena, relativity, and quantum\ntheory; oriented toward non-physical science\nmajors.\n137 [PSCI] Physics and Society 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Minimum ALEKS math placement\nscore of 45% or MATH 103 or higher with a\nC or better. Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for PHYSICS 408. Interactions\nof physics with society; energy; air and water\npollution; recycling; communications and\ncomputers; physics and war; physics and art.\nCredit not allowed for students who have\nearned credit for PHYSICS 408. Recommended\npreparation: UCORE [QUAN].\n150 [PSCI] Physics and Your World 3 Survey\nof physics as found in everyday phenomena;\nincluding many hands-on activities and home\nexperiments.\n188 First-Year Seminar I 1 Faculty will present\ncurrent research interests and opportunities\nin physics; questions and discussion. Taught\nannually each fall. S, F grading.\n189 First-Year Seminar II 1 Course Prerequisite:\nPHYSICS 188. Continuation of PHYSICS 188;\nfaculty will present current research interests\nand opportunities in physics; questions and\ndiscussions. S, F grading.\n201 [PSCI] Physics for Scientists and\nEngineers I 3 Course Prerequisite: PHYSICS\n211 or concurrent enrollment; MATH 171\nwith a C or better, or credit for or concurrent\nenrollment in MATH 172, 182, 273, or 315.\nCalculus-based physics; topics in motion\nand dynamics of particles and rigid bodies,\nvibrations, wave phenomena, and the laws of\nthermodynamics.\n202 Physics for Scientists and Engineers II 3\nCourse Prerequisite: 4 credits of PHYSICS 201\nwith a C or better, or PHYSICS 201 and 211\nwith a C or better, or PHYSICS 205 with a C or\nbetter; PHYSICS 212 or concurrent enrollment;\nMATH 172 or 182 with a C or better. Calculus-\nbased physics, topics in electricity, magnetism,\nelectromagnetics, D/C and A/C circuits, optics,\nreflection, refraction, interference, diffraction,\npolarization.\n203 Problem Solving for Physics 201 1\nCourse Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in\nPHYSICS 201 and 211. Small class environment\nfor students who desire focused attention on\nproblem solving skills as applied to PHYSICS\n201 materials. S, F grading.\n204 Problem Solving for Physics 202 1\nCourse Prerequisite: Concurrent enrollment in\nPHYSICS 202 and 212. Small class environment\nfor students who desire focused attention on\nproblem solving skills as applied to PHYSICS\n202 materials. S, F grading.\n205 [PSCI] Physics for Scientists and\nEngineers I - Honors 5 (3-5) Course\nPrerequisite: MATH 171 with a C or better,\nMATH 172 or concurrent enrollment, MATH\n182 or concurrent enrollment, MATH 273\nor concurrent enrollment, or MATH 315\nor concurrent enrollment. Calculus-based\nphysics, honors section; mechanics, sound,\nand thermodynamics.\n206 Physics for Scientists and Engineers II -\nHonors 5 (3-5) Course Prerequisite: 4 credits\nof PHYSICS 201 with a C or better, or PHYSICS\n201 and 211 with a C or better, or PHYSICS 205\nwith a C or better; MATH 172 with a C or better\nor MATH 182 with a C or better. Calculus-based\nphysics, honors section; electricity, magnetism,\nlight, topics in modern physics.\n211 [PSCI] Physics Lab for Scientists and\nEngineers 1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite:\nMATH 171 with a C or better, MATH 172\nor concurrent enrollment, MATH 182 or\nconcurrent enrollment, MATH 273 or\nconcurrent enrollment, or MATH 315 or\nconcurrent enrollment; PHYSICS 201 or\nconcurrent enrollment. Calculus-based physics\nlab; topics in motion and dynamics of particles\nand rigid bodies, vibrations, wave phenomena,\nand the laws of thermodynamics.\nPhysics and Astronomy\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n356\n212 Physics Lab for Scientists and Engineers\nII 1 (0-3) Course Prerequisite: PHYSICS 202\nor concurrent enrollment; PHYSICS 201\nwith a C or better or PHYSICS 205 with a C\nor better; MATH 172 with a C or better or\nMATH 182 with a C or better. Calculus-based\nphysics labs, topics in electricity, magnetism,\nelectromagnetics, D/C and A/C circuits, optics,\nreflection, refraction, interference, diffraction,\npolarization.\n303 Modern Physics I 3 Course Prerequisite: 4\ncredits of PHYSICS 202, or PHYSICS 202 and\n212 or concurrent enrollment, or PHYSICS\n206 or concurrent enrollment; MATH 220\nor concurrent enrollment or MATH 230\nor concurrent enrollment. Quantum and\nrelativity theories with applications to atomic,\nsolid state, nuclear and elementary particle\nphysics.\n304 Modern Physics II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nPHYSICS 303. Continuation of PHYSICS 303.\n320 Mechanics 3 Course Prerequisite: MATH\n315 or concurrent enrollment; MATH 220\nor concurrent enrollment or MATH 230 or\nconcurrent enrollment; 4 credits of PHYSICS\n202, or PHYSICS 202 and 212, or PHYSICS\n206. Particle motion in one-, two-, and three-\ndimensions; motions of systems of particles;\nrigid body motion; Lagrange’s equations.\n322 [PSCI] Sound Waves and Music 4 (3-3)\nCourse Prerequisite: MATH 103 or higher\nwith a C or better or a minimum ALEKS math\nplacement score of 45%. Multi-disciplinary\nintroduction to the acoustics of musical sound\nwith a hands-on approach, including human\nhearing and perception.\n330 Thermal Physics 3 Course Prerequisite:\n4 credits of PHYSICS 202, or PHYSICS 202\nand 212, or PHYSICS 206; MATH 273 or\n283. Thermal behavior of systems; energy\nand entropy; equations of state; changes of\nphase; elements of continuum and statistical\napproaches.\n341 Electricity and Magnetism I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 4 credits of PHYSICS 202, or\nPHYSICS 202 and 212, or PHYSICS 206; MATH\n315 or concurrent enrollment. Electrostatic\nfields, magnetic fields, dielectric and magnetic\nmedia.\n342 Electricity and Magnetism II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: PHYSICS 341. Continuation\nof PHYSICS 341. Maxwell’s equations;\nelectromagnetic waves, special relativity.\n408 [CAPS] Physics and Society 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Interactions of\nphysics with society; energy; air and water\npollution; recycling; communications and\ncomputers; physics and war; physics and art.\n410 Electronics 4 (2-6) Course Prerequisite: 4\ncredits of PHYSICS 202, or PHYSICS 202 and\n212, or PHYSICS 206. Laboratory construction\nand investigation of electronic circuits\nemployed in research instruments.\n415 [M] Quantum Physics Laboratory 3 (2-\n3) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nPHYSICS 304. Experiments in modern and\nquantum physics, fundamental interactions\nof radiations with matter.\n443 Optics 3 Course Prerequisite: PHYSICS 341\nor concurrent enrollment. Polarization,\ninterference, coherence, and diffraction\nphenomena of the electromagnetic spectrum;\noptics of solids; laser resonators; gaussian\nbeams; ABCD matrices.\n450 Introduction to Quantum Mechanics\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 315; PHYSICS\n303. Introduction to quantum theory with\napplications to atomic physics. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n461 Introduction to Atomic and Molecular\nPhysics 3 Course Prerequisite: PHYSICS 304.\nIntroduction to atomic and molecular physics;\nspectroscopy.\n463 Introduction to Solid State and\nMaterials Physics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nPHYSICS 304. Introduction to the physics of\nsolids; crystal structures, lattice vibrations,\nand electron theory. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n465 Introductory Nuclear Physics 3 Course\nPrerequisite: PHYSICS 304. Nuclear systematics,\napparatus of nuclear research, radioactivity,\nnuclear-atomic interactions, nuclear reactions\nand scattering; introductory particle physics.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n466 Biological Physics 3 Course Prerequisite:\n4 credits of PHYSICS 202, or PHYSICS 202\nand 212, or PHYSICS 206; CHEM 106 or 116;\nMATH 172 or 182. Fundamental physics and\nthermodynamics of the cell; mechanics of\nbiomolecular machines. Credit not granted\nfor both PHYSICS 466 and PHYSICS 566.\n481 Advanced Topics V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Topics\nin scientific and technological areas that have\nrelative significance to physics and astronomy.\n490 [M] Undergraduate Thesis 1 Preliminary\nthesis draft of a laboratory or library research\nexperience, oral presentation, and final draft.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n501 Graduate Seminar 1 Introduction to\ngraduate and interdisciplinary research. S, F\ngrading.\n514 Optoelectronics Lab I 1 (0-3) May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n3 hours. Experiments with optical systems:\nImaging, interference, coherence, information\nstorage/processing, gas and solid state lasers,\noptical fibers, and communications systems.\n515 Optoelectronics Lab II V 1 (0-3) to 3 (0-\n9) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 3 hours. Experiments in optical\nphysics, physical properties of light, laser\nphysics, waveguides, quantum confined\nsemiconductor structures and ultrafast\ndynamics and nonlinear optics.\n521 Classical Mechanics I 3 Laws of motion as\ndeveloped by Newton, d’Alembert, Lagrange,\nand Hamilton; dynamics of particles and\nrigid bodies. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n522 Classical Mechanics II 3 Continuation of\nPHYSICS 521. Classical mechanics of liquids\nand deformable solids; stress, deformation and\nstrain, flow, oscillations and waves.\n533 Thermal and Statistical Physics I 3\nThermodynamic laws and potentials, kinetic\ntheory, hydrodynamics and transport\ncoefficients; introduction to statistical\nmechanics, ensembles, partition functions.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n534 Thermal and Statistical Physics II 3 Phase\ntransitions and critical phenomena, Ginzburg-\nLandau theory, Bose-Einstein condensation,\nsuperfluids, Fermi systems, low-temperature\nexpansions. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n541 Electromagnetic Theor y 3 Special\nrelativity and the classical electromagnetic\nfield; emission, propagation, and absorption\nof electromagnetic waves. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n542 Electrodynamics 3 Interaction of matter\nand electromagnetic radiation; classical and\nquantum electrodynamics. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n545 Nonlinear Optics 3 Nonlinear wave\npropagation theory applied to several\nnonlinear-optical phenomena; experimental\ntechniques that probe a material’s nonlinearity.\n546 Quantum Electronics 3 The physics of lasers\nand of coherent optical radiation generation\nand propagation.\n550 Quantum Theory I 3 Introduction to\nquantum theory; physical and mathematical\nfoundations; application to atomic systems.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n551 Quantum Theory II 3 Symmetry and\ninvariance; angular momentum theory;\napproximation methods. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n552 Quantum Theory III 3 Scattering theory;\nrelativistic wave mechanics; quantum field\ntheory. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n561 Atomic and Molecular Physics 3 Physics\nof atoms and molecules using quantum theory.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n563 Physics of the Solid State 3 Lattice\nvibrations and defects; ionic and electronic\nconductivities; band theory; magnetic\nproperties; luminescence. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n566 Biological Physics 3 Fundamental physics\nand thermodynamics of the cell; mechanics\nof biomolecular machines. Credit not granted\nfor both PHYSICS 466 and PHYSICS 566.\nPhysics and Astronomy\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n357\n571 Methods of Theoretical Physics 3\nMathematical methods for theoretical physics;\nlinear algebra, tensor analysis, complex\nvariables, differential equations, integral\nequations, variational calculus, and group\ntheory. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n575 Advanced Solid State Physics 3 Quantum\ntheory of solids; Green’s functions, correlation\nfunctions and other field-theoretic methods;\nmagnetism, superconductivity and transport\nproperties.\n581 Advanced Topics in Physics 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 12\nhours. Topics of current interest in advanced\nphysics. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n590 Seminar 1 May be repeated for credit. S, F\ngrading.\n592 Wave Propagation Seminar 2 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 4\nhours. Waves in the continuum; elastic, plastic,\nand hydrodynamic waves; shock waves. S, F\ngrading.\n598 Teaching Undergraduate Physics\nLaboratories 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 4 hours. Principles\nand practices of teaching, planning and\nmanagement of undergraduate physics\nlaboratories; choice and care of equipment. S,\nF grading.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee chair\nbefore enrolling for 702 credit. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Plant\nPathology\nplantpath.wsu.edu\nJohnson Hall 345\n509-335-9541\nProfessor and Chair, T. D. Murray; Professors, G. A.\nChastagner, L. J. duToit, G. G. Grove, S. H. Hulbert, H.\nR. Pappu, N. Rayapati; Assistant Professors, A. Amiri,\nM. L. Friesen, C. Gleason, S. Harper, K. Tanaka, D. L.\nWheeler; Adjunct ARS Plant Pathologists, W. Chen, X.\nM. Chen, N. Klopfenstein, R. Navarre, P. A. Okubara,\nT. C. Paulitz, D. See, L. S. Thomashow, G. Vandemark,\nD. M. Weller; Adjunct Plant Pathologists, G. Bangera,\nC. Hagerty, M. Moyer; Professors Emeriti, L. M. Carris,\nR. J. Cook, K. C. Eastwell, L. A. Hadwiger, D. A. Inglis,\nD. A. Johnson, J. W. Moyer, T. L. Peever, J. D. Rogers,\nS. H. Smith.\nPlant pathology is the study of plant diseases,\nincluding causes, economic consequences, spread,\nand control. Opportunities for graduates in plant\npathology include positions in research and\ndevelopment, teaching, extension, diagnostics, and\nsales. Plant pathologists are employed throughout\nthe world by industries, governments, educational\ninstitutions, and private foundations.\nMost opportunities in plant pathology require\nadvanced degrees. Students who intend to\nterminate university training with a baccalaureate\ndegree are encouraged to enroll in the Agricultural\nand Food Systems (Agriculture and Food Security\nmajor) or Integrated Plant Sciences curricula. For\nmore information on these baccalaureate degrees,\nplease visit https://cahnrs.wsu.edu/academics/\nmajors/.\nThe courses offered in this department are\ndesigned both to train students expecting to\nmake plant pathology their professional field\nof specialization and to provide supplementary\ntraining for students in other biological and\nagricultural fields, particularly botany, crop science,\ngenetics, horticulture, forestry, and entomology.\nStudents who expect to become professional\nplant pathologists are advised to include in their\nundergraduate studies fundamental courses in\nbotany, chemistry, genetics, microbiology, physics,\nand zoology.\nA professional career in plant pathology would\nbenefit from graduate training. Students often\nenter the graduate program in plant pathology\nfollowing a major in biology, botany, crop science,\ngenetics, horticulture, molecular biology, or similar\nareas as well as in plant pathology. Specialized\nareas of advanced study include bacteriology,\nmycology, nematology, virology, epidemiology,\nmolecular biology of host-parasite relationships,\necology of disease development, disease resistance,\nchemical control, and biological control. Research\nis conducted on diseases of grain crops, forage\ncrops, forest trees, tree fruits, grapes, vegetables,\nornamentals, and turf.\nThe department offers Master of Science in\nPlant Pathology, and Doctor of Philosophy in\nPlant Pathology and contributes to the degrees\nof Bachelor of Science in Agricultural and Food\nSystems, Bachelor of Science in Integrated Plant\nSciences, and the Master of Science in Agriculture\nonline degree.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nAs preparation for work toward an advanced\ndegree, a student should have completed a\nbachelor’s degree; at least one semester each of\ngeneral inorganic chemistry, botany, zoology,\nphysics; one semester each of systematic botany,\nplant physiology, general plant pathology,\nentomology, microbiology, precalculus, organic\nchemistry, genetics, and report writing or advanced\ncomposition.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nTo enable students earning the M.S. and Ph.D.\nin Plant Pathology to understand and apply the\nscientific method to plant pathological problems,\nto develop critical thinking and professional\nskills needed for successful careers in public and\nprivate sectors, the program provides training and\ncoursework to help students develop the following\nskills:\n• Understanding, interpretation and synthesis of\nscientific literature pertaining to plant pathology\nand related disciplines\n• F o r m u l a t i n g h y p o t h e s e s ; d e v e l o p i n g\nexperimental designs to test these hypotheses;\nestablishing and maintaining experiments\n• Collecting data in an objective way and\nconducting appropriate statistical analyses\n• Interpretation and presentation of research\nresults in oral and written formats\n• Presentation of research at professional meetings\nand local commodity meetings\n• Publication of research in peer-reviewed scientific\njournals and other discipline-appropriate outlets\nsuch as commodity newsletters\nTo maintain a leadership role in plant pathology\nand related disciplines at the state, national and\ninternational levels, the program aims to:\n• Attract, retain and train high quality graduate\nstudents\n• Place students earning the M.S. into positions\nincluding extension agents, state and federal plant\npathologists, instructors at the community college\nlevel, support scientists in public or private sector\nresearch programs, and PhD programs\n• Place students earning the Ph.D. as leaders of\nscientific research programs in the public or private\nsector including industry, and faculty positions at\nthe University level.\nDescription of Courses\nPLANT PATHOLOGY\nPL P\n150 [BSCI] Molds, Mildews, Mushrooms:\nThe Fifth Kingdom 3 A survey of the socio-\nhistorical impact of fungi and their role in\ndevelopment and application of the scientific\nmethod.\n300 Diseases of Fr uit Crops 2 Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 120, HORT 310, or\nHORT 313. Comprehensive understanding of\nthe diseases of fruit crops grown in the state of\nWashington.\nPlant Pathology\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n358\n301 Food Mycology 3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite:\nMBIOS 101 or concurrent enrollment, or\nMBIOS 304 and 305, either with concurrent\nenrollment. Survey of the fungi important\nin food production, storage, and spoilage.\n(Crosslisted course offered as FS 301, PL P\n301). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n403 Advanced Cropping Systems 3 Course\nPrerequisite: HORT 202. Understanding the\nmanagement of constraints to crop production\nand quality; biological, physical, and chemical\napproaches to crop health management. Field\ntrips required. Credit not granted for both CROP\nSCI 403 and 503, or PL P 403 and 503.\nRecommended preparation: CROP SCI 305; PL\nP 429. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n429 G e n e r a l P l a n t P a t h o l o g y 3 ( 2 -\n3) Classification, symptoms, causes,\nepidemiology, and control of plant diseases.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n501 Biology and Control of Plant Diseases\n3 (2-3) Course Prerequisite: Admission to the\nMaster of Science in Agriculture graduate\ndegree program. Introduction to the biology\nand control of plant diseases covering\ndisorders caused by fungi, viruses, bacteria,\nand nematodes.\n503 A d v a n c e d C r o p p i n g S y s t e m s 3\nUnderstanding the management of constraints\nto crop production and quality; biological,\nphysical, and chemical approaches to crop\nhealth management. Field trips required.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CROP SCI 403,\nCROP SCI 503, PL P 403, PL P 503.) Credit not\ngranted for both CROP SCI 403 and 503, or PL\nP 403 and 503. Concepts of plant pathogen interactions\nand disease management.\n513 Plant Nematology 3 Anatomy and\nmorphology of plant-parasitic nematodes,\nmolecular plant-nematode interactions,\ngenomics, symptoms, identification,\ntechniques and control. Cooperative: Open to\nUI degree-seeking students.\n515 Seminar 1 May be repeated for credit.\n521 General Mycology 3 The structure, life\nhistories, classification, and economic\nimportance of the fungi. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n525 Field Plant Pathology and Mycology\n3 Diverse plant diseases, disease diagnosis\nand management in fields, orchards,\nnurseries; interact directly with diverse\nagricultural stakeholders. Field trip required.\nRecommended preparation: PL P 429 or PL P\n521.\n526 Advanced Fungal Biology 4 (2-6) Advanced\ntopics in fungal biology, ecology, systematics,\nevolution and coevolution via discussions\nof literature and special laboratory projects.\nRecommended preparation: Introductory\nm y c o l o g y a n d g e n e t i c s c o u r s e w o r k .\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n535 Molecular Genetics of Plant and\nPathogen Interactions 3 Genetic and\nmolecular biological aspects of host-pathogen\ninteractions. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n545 Statistical Genomics 3 (2-3) Develop\nconcepts and analytical skills for modern\nbreeding by using Genome-Wide Association\nStudy and genomic prediction in framework of\nmixed linear models and Bayesian approaches.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CROP SCI 545,\nANIM SCI 545, BIOLOGY 545, HORT 545, PL\nP 545.) Recommended preparation: BIOLOGY\n474; MBIOS 478. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n551 Epidemiology and Management of\nPlant Diseases 3 Principles of plant disease\nepidemiology, control and ecology of\npathogens. Recommended preparation: PL P\n429. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n570 Techniques in Plant Pathology 3 (1-\n6) Laboratory techniques for isolating,\ncultivating, and identifying the major groups\nof plant pathogenic organisms. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nPlant Pathology PhD program. Independent\nresearch and advanced study for students\nworking on their doctoral research, dissertation\nand/or final examination. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nSchool of Politics,\nPhilosophy, and Public\nAffairs\npppa.wsu.edu/\nJohnson Twr 801\n509-335-2544\nPOLITICAL SCIENCE: Director and Professor, T.\nRidout; Professors, C. Clayton, A. Mazur, T. Preston;\nAssociate Professors, S. Hoard (Career Track), C. Leeb,\nC. Long, A. Lopez, M. Salamone, S. Stehr, M. Stephan,\nP. Thiers; Assistant Professor, R. Elgar (Career Track), J.\nLewis, M. Ritter (Career Track); Professors Emeriti; M.\nCottam, N. Lovrich, D. Nice. PHILOSOPHY: Professors,\nJ. K. Campbell, P. Glazebrook, W. Kabasenche (Career\nTrack); Associate Professors, M. Goldsby, D. L. Shier,\nM. Stichter; Assistant Professors, L. Hubbard-Mattix\n(Career Track), S. Noll; Professors Emeriti, D. M.\nHolbrook, M. W. Myers, H. S. Silverstein. PUBLIC\nAFFAIRS: Professors, S. Finley, C. Mosher; Associate\nProfessors, L. Drapela, K. DuBois, C. Long, A. Lopez,\nA. Maclean, M. Stephan, P. Thiers.\nPOLITICAL SCIENCE PROGRAM\nhttps://pppa.wsu.edu/undergraduate-studies/b-a-in-\npolitical-science/\nCourses in political science are offered in political\ninstitutions (presidency, congress, the courts,\npolitical parties, mass media), public policy\nformation and evaluation, public law, civil\nliberties, international relations (foreign policy,\nsecurity studies, conflict resolution), comparative\ngovernment (area studies, post-industrial societies,\ncross-national comparisons), political philosophy\nand methodology.\nThe School of Politics, Philosophy, and Public\nAffairs (PPPA) offers courses of study leading to\nthe degrees of Bachelor of Arts in Political Science,\nMaster of Arts in Political Science (General), Master\nof Arts in Political Science (with a Graduate\nCertificate in Global Justice and Security Studies),\nand Doctor of Philosophy.\nThe undergraduate programs in Political Science\nare designed to prepare students to be more\nthoughtful consumers and producers of information\nrelated to political phenomenon in the U.S. and in\nother nations.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nMore specifically, the school’s programs teach\nstudents to:\n• Identify important issues, problems, and\nchallenges in the discipline and how to develop\nstrategies and solutions to solve them;\nPlant Pathology\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n359\n• Recognize, construct, and evaluate arguments,\nand employ those arguments on relevant issues in\nthe discipline and more generally;\n• Use the specific methods of the discipline to\nconduct meaningful problem driven research;\n• Recognize and respond to alternative, diverse\nviewpoints, and discuss normative, theoretical, and\ndescriptive aspects of the issues, arguments, and/or\ncontexts appropriately.\nOptions within the B.A. in Political\nScience: General Option, Prelaw Option,\nand Global Politics Option\nGeneral: The General Option in the Political\nScience B.A. provides diverse training in American\npolitics, comparative and international politics,\npolicy and public administration, and a wide range\nof elective courses in political science.\nNo specific major is required to be eligible for law\nschool, but political science is widely recognized as\nan excellent academic preparation for law school.\nThe CAS Prelaw Advising Center assists all students\ninterested in law school regardless of their intended\nmajor.\nPre-Law: The Political Science Prelaw Option\nis designed to prepare students for law school and\neventual careers in law. This curriculum reflects\nrecommendations of the Association of American\nLaw Schools.\nGlobal Politics: This option emphasizes\ncomparative and international politics and includes\nan international experience that can be fulfilled\nthrough study abroad, an international internship,\na minor in a foreign language or global studies, or\nROTC.\nGovernment is the nation’s largest employer.\nMany public officials are political science graduates.\nThe school advises students concerning training\nand career opportunities in federal, state, and\nlocal governments, the Foreign Service, and\nrelated occupations. Its internship programs place\nstudents in public agencies, political parties, and\nsimilar organizations. The school also encourages\nand advises students on study abroad as part of\npreparing for careers in international affairs.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nhttps://pppa.wsu.edu/graduate-studies/\nStudents with some undergraduate course work\nin political science while majoring in such subjects\nas economics, business administration, history,\ncriminal justice or sociology may readily pursue\ngraduate study in political science. Undergraduates\nat other institutions or in other programs at this\ninstitution who contemplate graduate work in this\nprogram should acquire some training in political\nscience. For graduate study and its graduate degree\nprograms, our students currently choose from one\nmajor foundational training area within which they\nwill focus for their preliminary exams (Institutions\nand Processes; Behavior and Psychology; Theory\nand Philosophy), as well as a specialization field\n(American politics; Global politics; Public Policy/\nPublic Administration).\nPHILOSOPHY PROGRAM\nhttps://pppa.wsu.edu/undergraduate-studies/b-a-in-\nphilosophy/\nThe Philosophy program in the School of Politics,\nPhilosophy, and Public Affairs offers courses in\nwhich students discuss fundamental intellectual\nquestions and both classical and contemporary\nattempts to address them. What makes for a morally\nright act or a just society? What sorts of things can\nwe really claim to know? What is mind, and what\nis its relation to matter? Are we really capable of free\nchoice or is our every act determined by past events?\nThese are the kinds of questions that are addressed\nby philosophers.\nPhilosophy students acquire knowledge of ethics,\nlogic, political philosophy, philosophy of religion,\nepistemology, metaphysics, and other areas that\nprovide excellent intellectual foundations for\ncareers in law, government service, education,\nministry, and many other fields. This is reflected in\nthe fact that philosophy majors, on average, perform\nbetter than any other major on professional and\ngraduate school admission tests that are required for\nadmission to law school, medical school, business\nadministration programs, and graduate school.\nThe study of philosophy enables students to\nexplore critically a variety of systems of beliefs and\nvalues, to identify and challenge the foundations of\ntheir own beliefs and values, and to develop critical\nthinking and communication skills that are in high\ndemand and central to success in all professions.\nThe School of Politics, Philosophy, and Public\nAffairs offers programs of study leading to the\nBachelor of Arts in Philosophy (in either the General\nOption or the Pre-Law Option) and the Graduate\nCertificate in Bioethics.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nMore specifically, the school’s programs teach\nstudents to:\n• Identify important issues, problems, and\nchallenges in the discipline and how to develop\nstrategies and solutions to solve them;\n• Recognize, construct, and evaluate arguments,\nand employ those arguments on relevant issues in\nthe discipline and more generally;\n• Use the specific methods of the discipline to\nconduct meaningful problem driven research;\n• Recognize and respond to alternative, diverse\nviewpoints, and discuss normative, theoretical, and\ndescriptive aspects of the issues, arguments, and/or\ncontexts appropriately.\nOptions within the B.A. in Philosophy:\nGeneral Option and Prelaw Option\nGeneral: The General Option provides broad\ntraining in philosophy, including an emphasis on\nthe history of philosophical thought.\nPre-Law: The Philosophy Pre-Law Option is\ndesigned to prepare students for law school and\neventual careers in law. This curriculum emphasizes\nethics, political philosophy, and critical thinking,\nand it reflects recommendations of the Association\nof American Law Schools. Students choosing\nother school options are also eligible to attend law\nschool if they meet admission requirements, but\nphilosophy is widely recognized as an excellent\nacademic preparation for law school.\nPUBLIC AFFAIRS\nhttps://cas.vancouver.wsu.edu/public-affairs\nThe Public Affairs degree is offered at the\nundergraduate level exclusively on the WSU\nVancouver Campus. The Bachelor of Arts in Public\nAffairs (BAPA) seeks to develop critical thinking\nabout political and social values and develop the\nability to conduct objective analysis of public\ninfrastructures and bureaucratic processes. The\ndegree program is designed to educate people\nfor service in public and nonprofit agencies and\nto prepare students for graduate or law school.\nIn addition to core courses, students complete\na concentration in public policy and politics,\npublic administration and management, or justice\nstudies. The program’s multidisciplinary perspective\nprovides for the blending of theory, methodology,\nand experience in an academically rigorous degree\nformat.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nStudying Public Affairs enables students to become\nethical, engaged and competent professionals, in\npublic administration, public management and\npublic policy. Graduates from our programs are\nwell prepared for careers in public service at the\nlocal, state, national or global levels, or for pursuing\nfurther studies. The program offers an intersection\nbetween rigorous academic research and practical\napplication. Our goal is to foster evidence-based\nreasoning and practice on the part of those working\nfor the public good, including students, community\nmembers, legislators, practitioners, scholars, and\nissue stakeholders.\nStudents in public affairs are expected to\ndemonstrate learned capacity in the universally\nrequired competencies of the Network of Schools of\nPublic Policy, Affairs, and Administration (NASPAA)\nas appropriate for the student’s level of study (i.e.\nundergraduate or graduate). NASPAA’s universal\nrequired competencies include the following:\n• To lead and manage in public governance;\n• To participate in and contribute to the policy\nprocess;\n• To analyze, synthesize, think critically, solve\nproblems and make decisions;\n• To articulate and apply a public service\nperspective; and\n• To communicate and interact productively with a\ndiverse and changing workforce and citizenry.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nPHILOSOPHY - GENERAL OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Philosophy -\nGeneral option upon making their intention known\nto the department.\nThe student must complete thirty (30) credits\nof coursework in philosophy: 3 credits in an\nintroductory PHIL course (which generally counts\ntoward a UCORE requirement); 3 credits in PHIL 201\nto satisfy a logical requirement (which can count\ntoward the [QUAN] requirement); 9 credits toward\na breadth requirement (3 credits in each of History,\nValue Theory, and Metaphysics & Epistemology\n(M&E)); 6 credits in further study in any of the three\nmain areas; 6 credits in advanced study from 300-\n400 level PHIL courses; and 3 credits in a capstone\n[CAPS] course in philosophy.\nNo course with a grade of D+ or less and no course\ntaken pass/fail will be counted toward the major.\nThe overall GPA for courses in the major must be\nat least a 2.00.\nPolitics, Philosophy, and Public Affairs\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n360\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nIntroductory PHIL Course [HUM] or [WRTG]\n1 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM], Humanities [HUM],\nWritten Communication [WRTG]\n3 \n3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nPHIL 201 [QUAN] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives\n2 \n3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n4 \n4\nForeign Language, if necessary, or Elective\n5,2 \n4\nHistory of Philosophy Course (Group A)\n6,7 \n3\nValue Theory Course (Group B)\n7,8 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n2\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language, if needed, or Elective2\n5,2 \n4\nMetaphysics and Epistemology Course\n(Group C)\n9,2 \n3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n4 \n4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nFurther Study Requirement\n7,10 \n6\nElectives\n2 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nPHIL Integrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nElectives\n2 \n12\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nAdvanced Study Requirement\n7,11 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n12\nSecond Term Hours\nAdvanced Study Requirement\n7,11 \n3\nElectives\n2 \n12\n_______\n1 \nIntroductory PHIL Course (3 credits): Select one\nfrom PHIL 101 [HUM], PHIL 103 [HUM], PHIL 200\n[WRTG], PHIL 207 [HUM], and PHIL 210 [HUM].\n2 \nElectives: Students are encouraged to apply\nelectives toward completion of an additional\nmajor. Elective courses must include sufficient\n300-400 level coursework to fulfill the University\nrequirement of 40 upper division credits.\n3 \nStudents must meet UCORE requirements not\nsatisfied by Introductory Course and applicable\ncourse must be from a subject other than PHIL.\n4 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n5 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n6 \nHistory of Philosophy Course (Group A) (3 credits):\nChoose one from PHIL 314 [M], PHIL 315 [M], PHIL\n320 [M], PHIL 321, PHIL 322, PHIL 333, PHIL 390,\nPHIL 420, PHIL 421, and PHIL 437 [M] not used to\nfulfill other Philosophy major requirements.\n7 \nTo meet University requirements, students are\nrequired to complete at least two [M] courses.\n8 \nValue Theory Course (Group B) (3 credits): Choose\none from PHIL 220, PHIL 280, PHIL 333, PHIL 360,\nPHIL 365, PHIL 370, PHIL 390, PHIL 406, PHIL 413,\nPHIL 425, PHIL 431, PHIL 435, PHIL 437 [M], PHIL\n438 [M], PHIL 450, PHIL 460 [M], PHIL 462 [M],\nPHIL 470, PHIL 472 [M], PHIL 475 not used to fulfill\nother Philosophy major requirements.\n9 \nMetaphysics and Epistemology Course (Group C)\n(3 credits): Choose one from PHIL 207, PHIL 350,\nPHIL 390, PHIL 401, PHIL 406, PHIL 407, PHIL\n413, PHIL 425, PHIL 442 [M], PHIL 443 [M], PHIL\n446, PHIL 447, PHIL 475 not used to fulfill other\nPhilosophy major requirements.\n10 \nFurther Study Requirement (6 credits): Any course\nin groups A, B, and C not used to fulfill other\nrequirements.\n11 \nAdvanced Study Requirement (6 credits): Any\n300-400-level PHIL course not used to fulfill other\nrequirements.\nPHILOSOPHY - PRE-LAW OPTION\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Philosophy - Pre-\nLaw option upon making their intention known to\nthe department.\nThe student must complete thirty (30) credits of\ncoursework in Philosophy: 3 credits in PHIL 200; 3\ncredits in PHIL 201 to satisfy a logical requirement\n(which can count toward the [QUAN] requirement);\n9 credits toward a breadth requirement (3 credits in\neach of History, Value Theory, and Metaphysics &\nEpistemology (M&E)); 6 credits in further study in\nany of the three main areas; 3 credits in PHIL 470; 3\ncredits in advanced study from 300-400-level PHIL\ncourses, and 3 credits in a capstone [CAPS] course in\nphilosophy. The Pre-Law option also requires that\nthe student take POL S 300.\nNo course with a grade of D+ or less and no course\ntaken pass/fail will be counted toward the major.\nThe overall GPA for courses in the major must be\nat least a 2.00.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nPHIL 200 [WRTG] 3\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nElectives\n1 \n6\nSecond Term Hours\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM]\n2 \n3\nPHIL 201 [QUAN] 3\nElectives\n1 \n6\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nHistory of Philosophy Course (Group A)\n4,5 \n3\nForeign Language, if needed, and/or\nElectives\n6,1 \n6\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nMetaphysics and Epistemology Course\n(Group C)\n5,7 \n3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n3 \n4\nForeign Language, if needed, or Electives\n6,1 \n4\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nPOL S 300 3\nValue Theory Course (Group B)\n5,8 \n3\nElectives\n1 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nFurther Study Requirement\n5,9 \n3\nPHIL Integrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nElectives\n1 \n9\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nPHIL 470 3\nElectives\n1 \n12\nSecond Term Hours\nAdvanced Study Requirements\n5,10 \n3\nElectives\n1 \n12\n_______\n1 \nElectives: Students are encouraged to apply\nelectives toward completion of an additional\nmajor.
