3\nPHIL 470 3\n300-400-level Electives 8\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nPOL S Electives need to include an additional [M]\ncourse to fulfill University requirements.\nPUBLIC AFFAIRS (VANCOUVER ONLY)\n(120 HOURS)\nThe Bachelor of Arts in Public Affairs requires\nstudents to earn at least a C grade or higher in all\ncore courses and no core courses may be taken pass/\nfail. In addition, only 6 credits in the concentration\nmay be taken pass/fail. At least 40 of the 120 credits\nfor the degree must be at the 300-400-level.\nAdmission Requirements\nFor admission to the Public Affairs major, students\nmust have an overall GPA of 2.75 or higher. Once\nadmitted, all students must maintain a minimum\noverall GPA of 2.75 or they will be released from\nthe major.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, or Elective 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nPOL S 101 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, or Elective 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nPOL S 300 3\nPOL S 316 3\nElectives 6\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nPOL S 340 3\nElectives 7\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nMinor Elective\n2 \n3\nPA Elective\n3 \n6\nSOC 320 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nPA Elective\n3 \n6\nPOL S 432 [M] 3\nSOC 321 4\nElectives 2\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nMinor Elective\n2 \n6\nPA Elective\n3 \n3\nPOL S 442 [M] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nMinor Elective\n2 \n9\n300-400-level Electives 3\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nA minor is recommended, but not required. The\nminor must total 16 to 18 semester hours, including\nat least six credits of upper-division course work,\nand must be in an area other than criminal justice\nor political science.\n3 \nPA Electives – 15 semester hours required in one\nof three concentration options: 1) Justice Studies:\nTwo courses from CRM J 320, 330, and POL S 402;\none course from SOC 360, 361, 362, and 367; and\ntwo courses from CRM J 370, 400 [M], 403, 420 [M],\n424, 426, 428, 450 [M], 490, POL S 381, 404 [M],\n405, SOC 340, and 461; 2) Public Administration\n& Management: Two courses from POL S 443, 445,\nand 446; three courses from HISTORY 415, 418,\nPOL S 305, 400, 447 [M], 450 [M], 497 (Washington\nState Legislative Internship only), and SOC 343;\nor 3) Public Policy & Politics: Two courses from\nPOL S 416, 417, 420, and 497 (Washington State\nLegislative Internship only); three courses from\nHISTORY 409, 415, 418, 419, POL S 305, 314, 317,\n400, 404 [M], 410, 427, 430, 436, 448, 450 [M], 455,\n497, SOC 332, 340, and 384.\nMinors\nEthics\nThe minor in ethics consists of 18 credit hours,\nof which at least 15 must be from ethics courses\nwithin the department of philosophy, such as\nPHIL 360, 365, 370, 460 [M], 462, 470, and 472\n[M]. Three credit hours may, with approval of the\ndepartment of philosophy, be from an ethics course\nin the student’s major or in another department.\nNine of the 18 hours must be in upper-division\nwork and taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses.\nPhilosophy\nThe minor in philosophy consists of 18 hours\nof course work, at least 9 of which must be in\n300-400-level courses taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses. Courses are chosen\nby the student, in consultation with the department,\nbut will normally include PHIL 101 or 103 and will\nalways include PHIL 201.\nPolitical Science\n18 semester hours of political science coursework\nis required for the minor, 9 of which must be\n300-400-level courses. Students must successfully\ncomplete POL S 101, 102, and 103. At least 12\nsemester hours of political science must be earned\nat Washington State University. Three hours of\nPOL S 497 or 499 may be applied to the minor. A\nminimum GPA of 2.0 in the political science courses\nis required.\nDescription of Courses\nPHILOSOPHY\nPHIL\n101 [HUM] Introduction to Philosophy 3\nNature and place of philosophy in human\nthought; problems and achievements.\n103 [HUM] Introduction to Ethics 3 Ethics\nthrough analysis of contemporary moral and\nsocial issues.\n200 [WRTG] Critical Thinking and Writing\n3 Application of critical thinking skills to essay\nwriting.\n201 [QUAN] Introduction to Formal Logic\n3 Course Prerequisite: MATH 101 with a\nC or better, MATH 103 with a C or better, a\nminimum ALEKS math placement score of\n40%, or higher level MATH. Core logical\nconcepts and formal syntax, semantics and\nproof procedures for categorical, propositional,\nand basic predicate logic.\n207 [HUM] Philosophy of Religion 3 Critical\ninquiry into the existence and nature of God;\nthe problem of evil; the relation of faith and\nreason; immortality and miracles. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n210 [HUM] Philosophy in Film 3 The use of film\nas philosophical text.\n220 [HUM] Philosophy of Food 3 Philosophical\nissues concerning the nature, production,\nand distribution of food, including ethical,\naesthetic, metaphysical, and/or social/political\ndimensions of food.\n280 [HUM] Islam in Theory and Practice 3\nFundamental principles of Islam, including the\nrelation between faith and practice, and the\nsocial, economic, political, and judicial systems\nin Islam. (Crosslisted course offered as PHIL\n280, ASIA 280).\n314 [HUM] [M] Philosophies and Religions\nof India 3 Metaphysical, epistemological,\nethical, aesthetic, social, and political views\nof Hinduism, Buddhism, and Islam, and their\ninfluence on Indian civilization. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as PHIL 314, ASIA 314).\nPolitics, Philosophy, and Public Affairs\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n363\n315 [HUM] [M] Philosophies and Religions\nof China and Japan 3 The philosophies\nand religions of China and Japan, and their\nmetaphysical, epistemological, ethical, social,\nand political positions and views of God and\ngods. (Crosslisted course offered as PHIL 315,\nASIA 315).\n320 [M] History of Ancient and Medieval\nPhilosophy 3 Course Prerequisite: 3 hours\nPHIL. Pre-Socratics, Plato, Aristotle; post-\nAristotelian philosophy to the Renaissance.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n321 History of Modern Philosophy 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 3 hours PHIL. Renaissance, 17th\nand 18th century philosophers. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n322 Nineteenth-century Philosophy 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 3 hours PHIL. The Continental,\npost-Kantian tradition, with emphasis on\nthinkers such as Hegel, Schopenhauer,\nKierkegaard and Nietzsche. Cooperative: Open\nto UI degree-seeking students.\n333 Development of Marxist Thought 3\nMarxist theory from the original writing\nof Marx and Engels to contemporary\ndevelopments. (Crosslisted course offered as\nPOL S 333, PHIL 333).\n350 Philosophy of Science 3 Purpose and logical\nstructure of science; human implications.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n360 [HUM] Business Ethics 3 The principles\nof ethics as applied to specific problems in\nbusiness faced by individuals and corporate\ninstitutions.\n365 [HUM] Biomedical Ethics 3 Ethical\nproblems in medicine and biological research.\n370 [HUM] Environmental Ethics 3 Explores\nthe obligations we have regarding non-human\nparts of the environment and the justification\nfor those obligations.\n390 Topics in Philosophy 3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\n401 Advanced Formal Logic 3 First-order\npredicate logic plus some metatheory,\napplications and/or extensions. Credit not\ngranted for both PHIL 401 and PHIL 501.\nRecommended preparation: PHIL 201.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n406 Philosophy and Race 3 Course Prerequisite:\n3 hours in PHIL or CES 201. Examination of\nrace within western philosophy including\nwork of philosophers of color and analysis of\nthe category race. (Crosslisted course offered as\nCES 406, PHIL 406).\n407 Seminar in Philosophy of Religion 3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Advanced topic-driven seminar. Critical\nanalysis of traditional and contemporary\nreligions and religious phenomena. Credit\nnot granted for both PHIL 407 and PHIL\n507. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n413 [CAPS] Science and Religion 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 3 credits PHIL; 3 credits [BSCI]\nor [PSCI]; junior standing. Methodological\ncomparison and philosophical investigation\nof the relation between religion and natural\nscience and related issues.\n420 E x i s t e n t i a l i s m a n d C o n t i n e n t a l\nPhilosophy 3 Selected movements, figures,\nand issues in recent continental philosophy.\nRecommended preparation: PHIL 320, 321 or\n322. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n421 Kant 3 Course Prerequisite: 3 hours PHIL.\nExploration of Kant’s philosophy and the\nphilosophies heavily influenced by Kant.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n425 Philosophy and Feminism 3 Course\nPrerequisite: PHIL 101, WOMEN ST 101, or\nWOMEN ST 120. Feminist philosophy as\ncritique of Western philosophical tradition\nand as alternate framework for thought.\n(Crosslisted course offered as PHIL 425, POL S\n425, WOMEN ST 425).\n431 Aesthetics and Philosophy of Art 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 3 hours PHIL; junior standing.\nPhilosophical exploration of aesthetics\nexperience and any or all of the arts; emphasis\non value considerations and comparisons\nof differing media. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n435 East/West Philosophy of Architecture\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing. East/\nWest philosophies and their impact on\nunderstanding of nature and architecture.\n437 [M] Classical Political Thought 3 The\ndevelopment of political philosophy from\nthe pre-Socratics to Machiavelli. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as POL S 437, PHIL 437).\n438 [M] Contemporary Political Theory 3\nThe development of political thought since\nMachiavelli. (Crosslisted course offered as POL\nS 438, PHIL 438).\n442 [CAPS] [M] Philosophy of Mind 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 3 hours PHIL; junior standing.\nTheories of mind, self, mental acts, psychological\nstates and artificial intelligence. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n443 [M] Philosophy of Language 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 3 hours PHIL. Investigation of\nphilosophical issues concerning meaning,\nreference, truth, the nature of language, and\nthe relation between language and thought.\nCredit not granted for both PHIL 443 and PHIL\n543. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n446 Metaphysics 3 Course Prerequisite: 3 hours\nPHIL. Issues and theories concerning free will\nand determinism, the nature of truth, the\nexistence of God, space, time and identity.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n447 Theory of Knowledge 3 Course Prerequisite:\n3 hours PHIL. Problems and theories\nconcerning skepticism, the nature and scope of\nknowledge, a priori knowledge, and induction.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n450 Data Analytics Ethics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. Ethical issues concerning the\ncollection, use, and dissemination of data.\n460 [M] Ethical Theory 3 Course Prerequisite:\n3 hours PHIL. Problems of ethical theory\nas treated by historical and contemporary\nphilosophers. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n462 [M] Women and Ethics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nPHIL 101, WOMEN ST 101, or WOMEN ST 201.\nStudy of gender and feminism and their effect\non contemporary ethical theories and issues.\n(Crosslisted course offered as WOMEN ST 462,\nPHIL 462). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n470 Philosophy of Law 3 Course Prerequisite: 3\nhours PHIL or POL S. Selected topics pertaining\nto moral and philosophical evaluation of law.\nCredit not granted for both PHIL 470 and PHIL\n570. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n472 [M] Social and Political Philosophy 3\nCourse Prerequisite: 3 hours PHIL or POL S.\nProblems of normative social and political\ntheories; historical and contemporary\nphilosophers. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n475 [CAPS] Zombie Apocalypse 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Uses zombies\nto model responses to global pandemics and\ncritically assesses awareness of pandemic\nthreats in contemporary popular culture.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\n501 Advanced Formal Logic 3 First-order\npredicate logic plus some metatheory,\napplications and/or extensions. Credit not\ngranted for both PHIL 401 and PHIL 501.\nRecommended preparation: PHIL 201.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n504 Special Topics in Philosophy 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Intensive study of a special topic not\notherwise covered in depth in the curriculum.\nCooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n507 Seminar in Philosophy of Religion 3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-seeking\nstudents.\n510 Seminar in the History of Philosophy\n3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n522 Seminar in Metaphysics 3 The nature of\nreality, through study of key concepts such as\nGod, personhood, free will, causation, space,\ntime, and identity. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students.\n524 Seminar in Epistemology 3 Classical\nproblems, questions, and theories involving\nthe concept of knowledge. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n535 Advanced Biomedical Ethics 3 Current\nethical issues in medical practice, medical\nresearch and public policy relating to health\nissues. S, U grading.\nPOLITICAL SCIENCE\nPOL S\n101 [SSCI] American National Government\n3 Introduction to American politics exploring\nthe constitution, political institutions and\nactors, the policy making process, and various\npublic policies.\n102 [SSCI] Introduction to Comparative\nPolitics 3 Nature of the state; fundamental\nproblems of government and politics;\nideological and institutional comparison of\ndemocracies and dictatorships.\n103 [SSCI] International Politics 3 Operation\nand interaction of national, international,\nand supranational communities; major world\nproblems since 1945.\n201 Political Research Methods 3 Training\nin social science research methodologies as\napplied to political phenomena.\n206 State and Local Government 3 Institutions,\nprocesses, and problems, with special reference\nto the state of Washington.\n276 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, U\ngrading.\nPre-Dental Curriculum\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-dental students are assisted with their\npreparation for application to dental schools through\nthe Health Professions Student Center (HPSC). health.\nprofessions@wsu.edu.\nBecoming a dentist requires a program of graduate\nstudy in dental school as well as undergraduate\nprerequisite coursework. No particular major is\nrequired and students are more likely to excel in\nmajors they enjoy. Adequate latitude exists in the\ndental schools’ requirements so that the Health\nProfessions Specialist is able to suggest a schedule of\nstudies to meet the needs of the individual student.\nTypically the coursework in each of the following\nareas, will meet the requirements of almost all\ninstitutions and prepare students for the Dental\nAptitude Test (DAT).\nThe Health Professions Specialists in the Health\nProfessions Student Center assist all students\nregardless of major, who have an interest in a health\ncare profession in meeting their goal. The HPSC\nwill assist students in the selection of appropriate\nclasses and a plan of study to meet the requirements\nof the dental schools to which they intend to apply.\nAdmission to a school of dentistry is based on\nsatisfactory completion of the entrance requirements\nof that school, attainment of satisfactory scholastic\nrecord, satisfactory to exceptional scores on the\nDental Admission Test (DAT), the possession of\npersonal qualifications necessary for the study\nof dentistry, and exemplary letters of reference.\nMost schools also require applicants to appear\nfor a personal interview and demonstrate manual\ndexterity development.\nThe Learning Goals for the Pre-dental curriculum\nare based on the WSU Learning Goals of the\nBaccalaureate and can be identified as (1) acquire\nand assimilate the disciplinary knowledge that is\nessential to successful careers as dental students\nand dentists (2) reason critically (3) develop lifelong\nlearning skills (4) write and speak effectively and (5)\ndevelop a sense of self in society.\nAdditional information can be obtained from Lori\nEiland, MS, DPT, the Pre-Dental Health Professions\nSpecialist in the Health Professions Student Center,\nWashington State University, 502 Smith Center for\nUndergraduate Education, Pullman, WA 99164-\n4551.\nPre-Health Curriculum\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-health students are assisted with their preparation\nfor application to health professions schools through\nthe Health Professions Student Center (HPSC). health.\nprofessions@wsu.edu.\nEntering a health care professional program requires\nspecific undergraduate preparative coursework.\nTypically, there are additional requirements that\nmust be met for admission. The Health Professions\nSpecialists in the Health Professions Student Center\nassist all students, who have an interest in a health\ncare profession in meeting their goal, regardless of\nacademic major.\nHealth Professions Specialists guide students with\ninterest in pre-medical, pre-dental, pre-nutrition\nand exercise physiology, pre-speech and hearing\nsciences, pre-nursing, pre-pharmacy, pre-veterinary,\npre-physical therapy, pre-physician assistant, pre-\noccupational therapy, pre-optometry, and many\nothers.\nThe Learning Goals for the Pre-health curriculum\nare based on the WSU Learning Goals of the\nBaccalaureate and can be identified as (1) acquire\nand assimilate the disciplinary knowledge that is\nessential to successful careers as a health professions\nstudent and practitioner (2) reason critically (3)\ndevelop lifelong learning skills (4) write and speak\neffectively and (5) develop a sense of self in society.\nAdditional information on preparation for\nadmission to health profession programs can\nPolitics, Philosophy, and Public Affairs\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n367\nbe obtained from any of the Health Professions\nSpecialists in the Health Professions Student Center,\nWashington State University, 502 Smith Center for\nUndergraduate Education, Pullman, WA 99164-\n4551.\nPre-Law Curriculum\nprelaw.wsu.edu\nStudents interested in legal education may prepare\nfor entrance into the law field or law school from\nany major in any college at the University. The\nAmerican Bar Association recommends attaining\nas rich an undergraduate education as possible,\nand developing skills in reading, writing, critical\nthinking, oral communication, research, and task\nmanagement. In most cases, preparing for a career in\nlaw requires success on the Law School Admissions\nTest (LSAT), grade point average, personal\nstatement, letters of recommendation, community\ninvolvement and leadership, alongside rigorous\ncourse work. While no major is recommended and\nthere are no set requirements for your undergraduate\neducation, the field of Law and Law School\nAdmission is highly competitive and success in\nthese areas depends on careful preparation. Students\ninterested in considering the law field should make\nan appointment with a pre-law advisor through the\nPre-Law Resource Center (502 CUE; email: prelaw@\nwsu.edu). Students interested in law as an area of\nstudy, can pursue one of the three undergraduate\nprograms at the University which offer pre-law\ncurricula: History (301 Wilson Hall), Philosophy\n(801 Johnson Tower), and Political Science (801\nJohnson Tower). Additional information can be\nobtained from Rachel Christofferson (Washington\nState University, Smith Center for Undergraduate\nEducation (CUE) 502, Pullman, WA 99164-4551).\nPre-Medical Curriculum\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-medical students are assisted with their\npreparation for medical school through the Health\nProfessions Student Center (HPSC). health.professions@\nwsu.edu.\nThe preparation program at WSU is among the\nmost comprehensive in the nation and offers many\nopportunities for students to interact and succeed.\nBecause there are many ways to prepare for a career\nin medicine, Health Professions Student Center is\nhere to help you map out the path that is best for\nyou.\nBecoming a physician requires a program\nof graduate study in medical school as well as\nundergraduate preparative coursework. Students\nare free to choose the academic path best suited\nto their interests and strengths. Professional school\nadmission criteria is focused on core academic\ncoursework, character, and extracurricular effort,\nnot specific degrees earned. Students will meet with\na Pre-Med Specialist every semester who is able to\nsuggest a schedule of studies to meet the needs of\nthe individual student.\nAcceptance of a student by a medical school is\ncontingent on the satisfactory completion of at least\nthe minimum entrance requirements of that school,\nattainment of a superior scholastic record, good to\nexcellent scores on the MCAT, and possession of\npersonal qualifications appropriate to success in the\nmedical profession. Most schools require applicants\nto appear for a personal interview. In addition,\nletters of recommendation from several college\nteachers, physicians and other professionals must\nstrongly support the applicant.\nThe Learning Goals for the Pre-medical curriculum\nare based on the WSU Learning Goals of the\nBaccalaureate and can be identified as (1) acquire\nand assimilate the disciplinary knowledge that is\nessential to successful careers as medical students\nand physicians (2) reason critically (3) develop\nlifelong learning skills (4) write and speak effectively\nand (5) develop a sense of self in society.\nAdditional information can be obtained from\nLourdes Giordani, Ph.D., or Lori Eiland, MS, DPT,\nthe Pre-Medical Specialists at the Health Professions\nStudent Center, Washington State University,\n502 Smith Center for Undergraduate Education,\nPullman, WA 99164-4551.\nPre-Nursing Curriculum\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-nursing students are assisted with their\npreparation for application to nursing school through\nthe Health Professions Student Center (HPSC). health.\nprofessions@wsu.edu.\nStudents interested in nursing must meet the\nrequirements for admission. The requirements\nfor admission to the WSU College of Nursing\nprograms are listed in the WSU Spokane catalog\nunder Nursing. The direct BSN program is based\non the Spokane, Yakima and Tri-Cities locations of\nWSU. In Pullman, pre-nursing students typically\nspend their first two years fulfilling their core\ncurriculum and pre-nursing requirement courses,\nand if accepted, they then spend their junior and\nsenior years fulfilling their nursing program courses\nat the WSU College of Nursing or other nursing\nprogram of student choice. Additional admissions\nrequirements vary based on the nursing program\nof student interest.\nThe Learning Goals for the pre-nursing curriculum\nare based on the WSU Learning Goals of the\nBaccalaureate and can be identified as (1) acquire\nand assimilate the disciplinary knowledge that is\nessential to successful careers as nursing students\nand nurses (2) reason critically (3) develop lifelong\nlearning skills (4) write and speak effectively and (5)\ndevelop a sense of self in society.\nAdditional information on preparation for\nadmission to nursing can be obtained from the\npre-Nursing Health Professions Advisors, LeeAnn\nTibbals and Bryon Gregory, MS, Health Professions\nStudent Center, Washington State University,\n502 Smith Center for Undergraduate Education,\nPullman, WA 99164-4551.\nPre-Nutrition and Exercise\nPhysiology Curriculum\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-Nutrition and Exercise Physiology students are\nassisted with their preparation for application to the\nprogram in Nutrition and Exercise Physiology through\nthe Health Professions Student Center (HPSC). health.\nprofessions@wsu.edu .\nStudents interested in the program in Nutrition\nand Exercise Physiology (NEP) must meet the\nrequirements for admission. The requirements for\nadmission are listed in the WSU Spokane catalog\nunder Nutrition and Exercise Physiology. Pre-NEP\nstudents typically spend their first two years in\nPullman fulfilling their core curriculum and pre-\nNEP requirement courses, and then if accepted, they\nspend their junior and senior years fulfilling their\nNEP program courses on the WSU Spokane campus.\nThe Learning Goals for the pre-NEP curriculum\nare based on the WSU Learning Goals of the\nBaccalaureate and can be identified as (1) acquire\nand assimilate the disciplinary knowledge that is\nessential to successful careers (2) reason critically (3)\ndevelop lifelong learning skills (4) write and speak\neffectively and (5) develop a sense of self in society.\nAdditional information on preparation for\nadmission to NEP can be obtained from Health\nProfessions Advisor, Avis Stein, BSN, RN, Health\nProfessions Student Center, Washington State\nUniversity, 502 Smith Center for Undergraduate\nEducation, Pullman, WA 99164-4551.\nPre-Pharmacy Curriculum\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-pharmacy students are assisted with their\npreparation for application to pharmacy schools through\nthe Health Professions Student Center (HPSC). health.\nprofessions@wsu.edu.\nStudents interested in entering a professional\nDoctor of Pharmacy (PharmD) program at schools\nand colleges across the country must meet the\nPre-Pharmacy\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n368\nrequirements for admission. The requirements for\nadmission to the WSU PharmD program are listed in\nthe WSU Spokane catalog under Pharmacy. While\nmost students attain a bachelor’s degree, one is\nnot required for admission to most colleges of\npharmacy. Pre-pharmacy students at the WSU\nPullman campus typically take 3 years fulfilling\ntheir pre-pharmacy requirements if they do not\nwant a bachelor’s degree. Then, if admitted to the\nhighly competitive WSU PharmD program, the\nstudent will spend 4 years in professional school,\nregardless of prior degrees.\nAdditional information on preparation for\nadmission to pharmacy schools can be obtained\nfrom the pre-Pharmacy Health Professions Advisor,\nByron Gregory, MS, Health Professions Student\nCenter, Washington State University, 502 Smith\nCenter for Undergraduate Education, Pullman, WA\n99164-4551.\nPre-Physical Therapy, Pre-\nPhysician Assistant, Pre-\nOccupational Therapy\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-physical therapy, pre-occupational therapy, or\npre-physician assistant students are assisted with their\npreparation for allied health fields such as physical\ntherapy, occupational therapy, or physician assistant\nprograms through the Health Professions Student Center\n(HPSC). health.professions@wsu.edu.\nStudents interested in allied health fields such\nas physical therapy, occupational therapy, or\nphysician assistant programs must complete\nundergraduate preparative coursework as well\nas graduate studies. No specific major is required\nfor admission. Students can prepare from many\nmajors in the University as long as they meet the\nminimum requirements for admission. Admission\nto physical therapy, occupational therapy, and\nphysician assistant programs is highly competitive\nand a strong academic record is a must. Your Health\nProfessions Specialist is able to suggest a plan of\nstudy and extracurricular activities that fit your\ninterests, strengths, and career goals. The specialist\nwill help you integrate admission prerequisites\nwith your major and help you prepare to apply for\nadmission into professional programs. Be sure and\nmake an appointment during your first semester at\nWashington State University with the pre-PT/OT or\npre-PA specialist in the HPSC.\nAdditional information can be obtained from the\npre-Physical therapy and pre-Occupational therapy\nHealth Professions Specialist, Avis Stein, BSN,\nRN. Additional information on preparation for\nadmission to physician assistant programs can\nbe obtained from the Physician Assistant Health\nProfessions Specialist, Lourdes Giordani, Ph.D.,\nHealth Professions Student Center, Washington State\nUniversity, 502 Smith Center for Undergraduate\nEducation, Pullman, WA 99164-4551.\nPre-Speech and Hearing\nSciences Curriculum\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-Speech and Hearing Sciences students are assisted\nwith their preparation for admission to the program\nin Speech and Hearing Sciences through the Health\nProfessions Student Center (HPSC). health.professions@\nwsu.edu.\nStudents interested in the program in Speech and\nHearing Sciences (SHS) must meet the requirements\nfor admission to the major. The requirements are\nlisted in the WSU Spokane catalog under Speech\nand Hearing Sciences. Pre-SHS students typically\nspend their first two years in Pullman fulfilling their\ncore curriculum and pre-SHS requirement courses,\nand then they spend their junior and senior years\nfulfilling their SHS program courses on the WSU\nSpokane campus.\nAdditional information on admission to Speech\nand Hearing Sciences can be obtained from Health\nProfessions Advisor, LeeAnn Tibbals, Health\nProfessions Student Center, Washington State\nUniversity, 502 Smith Center for Undergraduate\nEducation, Pullman, WA 99164-4551.\nPre-Veterinary Curriculum\nhealthprofessions.wsu.edu\nSmith Center for Undergraduate Education\n(CUE) 502\n509-335-4549\nhealth.professions@wsu.edu\nDirector and Clinical Assistant Professor, Donald\nAllison, PhD, PA-C\nAll pre-veterinary students are assisted with their\npreparation for veterinary school through the Health\nProfessions Student Center (HPSC). health.professions@\nwsu.edu.\nStudents interested in veterinary medicine may\nprepare for admission from any major in the\nUniversity as long as they satisfy the required\nprerequisite courses for admission. The requirements\nfor admission are listed on the Health Professions\nStudent Center webpage and requirements specific\nto the WSU College of Veterinary Medicine can be\nfound in this catalog under Veterinary Medicine.\nAdmission to the veterinary program is highly\ncompetitive. A minimum of three years of college\nor completion of a baccalaureate degree is essential.\nThe Health Professions Specialists in the Health\nProfessions Student Center will assist all students,\nregardless of major, who have an interest in a\nveterinary medicine profession in meeting their\ngoal.\nThe Learning Goals for the pre-veterinary\ncurriculum are based on the WSU Learning Goals\nof the Baccalaureate and can be identified as (1)\nacquire and assimilate the disciplinary knowledge\nthat is essential to successful careers as veterinary\nstudents and veterinarians (2) reason critically (3)\ndevelop lifelong learning skills (4) write and speak\neffectively and (5) develop a sense of self in society.\nAdditional information on preparation for\nadmission to veterinary medicine can be obtained\nfrom the Pre-Veterinary Health Professions\nSpecialist, Becky Jewell, M.A., Health Professions\nStudent Center, Washington State University,\n502 Smith Center for Undergraduate Education,\nPullman, WA 99164-4551.\nDepartment of Psychology\npsychology.wsu.edu\nJohnson Tower 233\n509-335-2631\nProfessor and Department Chair, D. Marcus; Professors,\nC. Barry, T. D. Barry, A. Blume, G. L. Burns, S. Collins,\nR. M. Craft, L. Fournier, M. Gartstein, J. M. Hinson,\nP. Kwon, M. M. Morgan, C. D. Parks, T. M. Probst,\nR. Quock, K. Schmaling, M. Schmitter-Edgecombe,\nW. Scott, P. S. Strand, P. M. Whitney; Associate\nProfessors, S. Bauman, J. Fales, S. Lakatos, R. Magnan,\nS. Tragesser; Assistant Professors, E. Canning, C.\nCuttler, B. Ladd, B. Rangel; Professor (Career-Track), S.\nSwindell; Associate Professors (Career-Track), B. Duell,\nL. Daffin, A. L. Matthews, J. Peters, D. Posey, B. Wright;\nAssistant Professors (Career-Track), M. C. Kirchhoff, A.\nSpradlin; Instructor, K. Baldwin; Professors Emeriti, T.\nA. Brigham, F. K. McSweeney, J. W. Wright.\nPsychology is the scientific study of the human\nmind and behavior. The department offers courses\nof study leading to the Bachelor of Science in\nPsychology and the Doctor of Philosophy. It also\noffers an undergraduate minor in Psychology.\nExcellent facilities are available for instruction\nand research in psychology. There are specially\ndesigned facilities for research in learning, memory,\nperception, animal behavior, neurosciences and\nsocial interaction. Departmental facilities also\ninclude the Psychology Clinic, which is a training\nclinic for doctoral students in clinical psychology.\nIn addition, cooperative arrangements with other\nunits of the university and with outside agencies\nand institutions make it possible for students to gain\nfirst-hand experience in research and professional\nwork. The university maintains a comprehensive\nlibrary of books and journals in psychology and\nrelated fields.\nThe Undergraduate Program\nThe program for majors is designed for those\nwho wish to study psychology as part of a liberal\neducation; for those who plan to use their training\nin related vocations such as the professions,\ngovernmental organizations, business and industry,\nand psychological services; and for those who are\npreparing for graduate work in psychology. Course\nofferings are open to students in other departments\nwho need a background in those aspects of\npsychology that are related to their respective fields.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nStudents graduating with a bachelor of science\ndegree in psychology will be able to: 1) use the major\nconcepts, principles, theories and perspectives of the\nPre-Pharmacy\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n369\ndiscipline to explain psychological phenomena and\naddress real world issues; 2) demonstrate tolerance\nfor ambiguity while using reasoning, skepticism,\nand empirical evidence to recognize, develop,\nand evaluate claims made about psychological\ntopics; 3) effectively design, conduct, and interpret\nethical studies to address psychological questions;\n4) communicate effectively by using professional\nwriting and oral conventions; 5) practice\ninformation literacy by locating and evaluating\nrelevant references from a variety of sources; 6)\nexplain how individual differences interact with\nsocial, economic, and cultural factors to affect\nperceptions, cognitions, and behaviors; and 7)\ndevelop skills and knowledge that enable them to\nbetter understand themselves, behave ethically and\nresponsibly, and pursue their unique personal and\nprofessional goals. For an expanded description\nof these program goals, see http://psychology.wsu.\nedu/documents/2015/02/program-goals-table.pdf\nGraduate Programs\nThe graduate program leads to advanced\ndegrees for qualified students who plan careers as\npsychologists. The course of study for the Doctor\nof Philosophy degree may be directed toward\neither a specialization in clinical or experimental\npsychology. The graduate training program in\nclinical psychology at Washington State University\nis accredited by the American Psychological\nAssociation. For information about the clinical\npsychology program’s accreditation status, you can\ncontact the Commission on Accreditation of the\nAmerican Psychological Association, which can also\nbe reached at: Office of Program Consultation and\nAccreditation, 750 First Street, NE, Washington, DC\n20002-4242; Phone: 202-336-5979; TDD/TTY: 202-\n336-6123; Fax: 202-336-5978; apaaccred@apa.org.\nStudent Learning Outcomes (Clinical\nPsychology)\nThe Clinical Psychology Program is based on the\nscientist-practitioner model of training. The Program\nis designed to integrate theory, research, and clinical\npractice in the training of students. The goals of the\nprogram are to produce graduates who (1) have a\nbroad knowledge of scientific psychology; (2) can\nprovide evidence-based clinical services that are\nconsistent with ethical and professional standards,\nincluding knowledge of and sensitivity to issues\nof diversity; and (3) are capable of contributing to\ncurrent knowledge in clinical psychology.\nStudent Learning Outcomes (Experimental\nPsychology)\nThe doctoral program in Experimental Psychology\nis designed to produce skilled, innovative,\nand productive experimental psychologists.\nDegree recipients are expected to be (1) highly\nknowledgeable about their specialty area (Cognition,\nBiological, Social, Industrial/Organizational, Health,\nor Applied Quantitative Methods), (2) well-versed in\ngeneral experimental psychology, (3) able to identify\nsignificant research problems, (4) conversant with a\nwide variety of strategies for generating and testing\nhypotheses that emerge from these problems, and\n(5) able to effectively communicate scientific results.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nStudents who contemplate work leading to\nadvanced degrees are urged to confer as early\nas possible with a psychology faculty mentor.\nGraduate programs require a solid background in\nmathematics, natural sciences, philosophy, and\nsocial sciences as well as appropriate preparation\nin psychology itself.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nPSYCHOLOGY - BACHELOR OF SCIENCE\n(120 HOURS)\nThe Bachelor of Science in Psychology requires a\nminimum of 35 credits in PSYCH, at least 15 of\nwhich must be in 300-400-level courses. Students\nmust take at least 10 credits of psychology in\nresidence at WSU and must maintain at least a C\naverage in PSYCH courses. Students must have\ntwo years of one foreign language in high school\nor take one year in college of a modern foreign\nlanguage before graduation. Beyond certain\nminimum requirements there is flexibility in the\ndegree program, in accordance with the needs of the\nindividual student. A student may be admitted to\nthe Psychology major after completion of 30 credits,\nPSYCH 311 with a C- or better, and cumulative GPA\nof 2.5 or better.\nFor the BS degree in Psychology, the four learning\ngoals are: (1) Students will understand basic\nresearch design and analysis; (2) Students will be\nable to describe societal influences on individual\nbehavior, and they will display an understanding\nof the cultural relativism inherent in defining what\nis normal and abnormal behavior; (3) Students will\nbe able to critically evaluate scientific studies; (4)\nStudents will demonstrate proficiency in the written\ncommunication of psychological concepts.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 101 [BSCI] and 105, or BIOLOGY 102\n[BSCI], 106 [BSCI], or 107 [BSCI] 4\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3 or 4\nForeign Language or Electives 3 or 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab 4\nPSYCH 210 3\nForeign Language and/or Electives 5\nSecond Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nPSYCH 311 4\nElectives 7\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFocus Area PSYCH Electives\n1 \n9\nPSYCH 312 [M] 4\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nFocus Area PSYCH Electives\n1 \n6\n300-400-level Electives 10\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nFocus Area PSYCH Electives\n1 \n6\nIntegrative Capstone [CAPS] 3\nPSYCH [M] Course 3\n300-400-level Electives 4\nSecond Term Hours\nElectives 15\nComplete Psychology Exit Interview and Survey\n_______\n1 \nFocus Area Electives (21 credits): Students must\ncomplete at least 2 courses from each of the\nfollowing areas: 1) Neuroscience/Cognition:\nPSYCH 265, 372, 384, 473, 490, 491, 492; 2) Social/\nMotivational PSYCH 230, 306, 307, 308, 309, 321,\n328, 350, 403, 466, 470; and 3) Clinical/Counseling:\nPSYCH 110, 320, 324, 333, 342, 361, 363, 440, 442,\n444, 464, 468. Additional approved courses include\nany PSYCH course not used to fulfill other PSYCH\nrequirements. Note that many courses require\nprerequisites and not all courses are offered both Fall\nand Spring semester. Contact advisor for additional\ninformation.\nMinors\nAddiction Studies (Vancouver\nonly)\nA minor in addiction studies requires 19 or 22\ncredits. Track 1 (professional certification, 22\ncredits): comprises coursework primarily in the\nDepartment of Psychology and is aimed at preparing\nstudents for certification as chemical dependency\nprofessionals (CDP) in Washington State. Track\n2 (addictions research, 19 credits): geared toward\nstudents preparing for graduate study in research\ncareers in clinical and health psychology, as well\nas public policy emphasizing the study of addictive\nbehaviors. Credit hours for the minor must include\n9 hours of upper-division work taken in residence at\nWSU or through WSU-approved education abroad\nor educational exchange courses.\nTrack 1: This track comprises coursework based\nprimarily in the Department of Psychology. It aims\nto prepare students for certification as chemical\ndependency professionals (CDP) in Washington\nState. The minor provides theoretical and practical\ntraining in the diagnosis and treatment of addictive\nbehaviors. It is important to note that courses in\nTrack 1, taken by themselves, address only a subset\nof these competencies. To obtain certification\nrequires additional coursework and relevant\npracticum experience.\nTrack 1 requires a minimum of 22 semester credits,\nwhich must include the following:\nRequired Courses (16 credits):\nPsychology\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n370\n• PSYCH 110\n• PSYCH 265\n• PSYCH 333\n• PSYCH 342\n• PSYCH 442\nElective Courses (choose two of the following; six\ncredits):\n• PSYCH 301\n• PSYCH 320\n• PSYCH 440\n• PSYCH 444\n• PSYCH 468\n• CRM J 428\n• SOC 368\nTrack 2: This track prepares students for graduate\ntraining in research careers emphasizing the\nempirical study of addictive behaviors (e.g., clinical\nand health psychology, public health and policy).\nTo ensure completion, students must commit to this\ntrack no later than the beginning of their junior year\n(i.e., with 4 semesters remaining at WSUV). Track\n2 culminates in an independent research project\nunder the supervision of a Psychology faculty\nmember.\nTrack 2 requires a minimum of 19 semester credits,\nwhich must include the following:\nRequired Courses (16 credits)\n• PSYCH 265\n• PSYCH 312\n• PSYCH 333\n• PSYCH 498: Must work in at least one research\nlab for a minimum of 2 semesters.\n• PSYCH 499 (2 credits min.): Student will\nproduce a final independent product (e.g., grant\napplication, review paper, research project) related\nto addiction or related topics. Student must identify\na mentor willing to work with them no later than\nthe end of their junior year.\nElectives (3 credits)\n• PSYCH 301\n• PSYCH 342\n• PSYCH 468\n• CRM J 428\n• SOC 368\nPsychology\nThe minor in psychology may be certified after the\ncompletion of 60 semester hours. It requires 18\ncredit hours in PSYCH, of which at least 9 must\nbe taken at WSU and at least 9 must be in graded\n300-400-level courses. PSYCH 105 is required and\na statistics or research methods course is strongly\nrecommended. A minimum GPA of 2.00 or higher\nis required in all coursework used for the minor.\nDescription of Courses\nPSYCHOLOGY\nPSYCH\n105 [SSCI] Introductory Psychology 3 Survey\nof the basic terms, processes, principles, and\ntheories related to the scientific study of\nhuman behavior.\n110 Introduction to Addiction Studies 3\nAnalysis of cultural, societal, individual,\nand physiological factors underlying drug\naddiction.\n201 Degrees and Careers in Psychology 1\nIntroduction to the major, degree requirements,\nresources for degree planning, graduate\ndegrees, and careers for psychology majors.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n210 Psychology as a Science 3 How psychology\nuses reasoning, skepticism, and the scientific\nmethod to evaluate claims made in everyday\nlife.\n230 Human Sexuality 3 Sexuality in personal\ndevelopment; personal, cultural, biological\ninfluences on sexual identification and\nbehavior; fertility, reproduction, sexual\nfunctioning, sexuality and personality.\n(Crosslisted course offered as PSYCH 230,\nWOMEN ST 230). Recommended preparation:\nPSYCH 105.\n265 Biopsychological Effects of Alcohol and\nOther Drugs 3 Biopsychological effects of the\nmajor classes of abused and psychotherapeutic\ndrugs, including alcohol, stimulants, sedatives\nand hallucinogens. Recommended preparation:\nPSYCH 105; BIOLOGY 102, BIOLOGY 107, or\nBIOLOGY 101 and 105.\n301 Seminar in Psychology V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours.\n306 Industrial Psychology 3 Job analysis\nand evaluation; personnel recruitment\nand selection; design and evaluation of\ntraining systems; performance appraisals.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n307 Human Factors 3 Human limitations and\ncapabilities in architectural and engineering\ndesign; system analysis. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105.\n308 Organizational Psychology 3 Employee\nmotivation satisfaction and commitment;\norganizational communication; leadership;\ng r o u p b e h a v i o r, t e a m s a n d c o n f l i c t ;\norganizational change and development.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n309 Diversity in Organizations 3 Psychology\napplied to cultural diversity in organizations;\ninterpersonal and intergroup relationships;\ndiversity training; EEO legislation and\naffirmative action. Recommended preparation:\nPSYCH 105.\n310 Work, Stress, and Health 3 Workplace\nstressors and their effects on employee\nhealth, well-being, and safety; employee\nburnout, engagement, and stress management\ninterventions. Recommended preparation:\nPSYCH 105.\n311 [QUAN] Statistics in Psychology 4 Course\nPrerequisite: One of the following with a C- or\nbetter: ENGR 107, MATH 103 or higher, MGTOP\n215, STAT 205, STAT 212, or a minimum ALEKS\nmath placement score of 45%. Descriptive\nstatistics, probability, and inference; design\nand interpretation of research. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105.\n312 [M] Research Methods in Psychology 4\n(3-3) Course Prerequisite: PSYCH 210; PSYCH\n311 with a grade of C- or better. Designing,\nconducting, and reporting research in\nselected areas of experimental psychology.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n320 Health Psychology 3 Psychological and\nphysiological aspects of stress; health behavior\nand disease prevention; adjustment to chronic\nillness. Recommended preparation: PSYCH\n105.\n321 Personality 3 Theories, concepts, methods,\ndiscoveries in psychology of personality.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n324 Psychology of Gender 3 Contemporary\noverview of the psychological theory and\nresearch on sex and gender. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as PSYCH 324, WOMEN ST\n324). Recommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n328 [M] Self Control 3 Analysis of self-control\nproblems; application of behavioral principles\nto student-conducted projects. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105.\n333 A b n o r m a l P s y c h o l o g y 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: PSYCH 105. Problems of\nabnormality from traditional and evolving\npoints of view; types, therapies, outcomes,\npreventive techniques.\n342 Assessment and Treatment of Dual\nDiagnosis 3 Course Prerequisite: PSYCH\n333. Development of conceptual frameworks\nto guide the treatment and research of\npatient’s co-occurring chemical dependency\nand psychiatric disorders. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105.\n348 F o r e n s i c a n d L e g a l P s y c h o l o g y\n3 Introduction to the ways in which\npsychological science is used to inform the\nlegal system. Recommended preparation:\nPSYCH 105.\n350 Social Psychology 3 Course Prerequisite:\nSophomore standing. Attitude changes,\nconformity, interpersonal relations, groups\nand social influences explored to give\na coherent view of social psychology.\n(Crosslisted course offered as PSYCH 350, SOC\n350). Recommended preparation: PSYCH 105\nor SOC 101.\n361 Developmental Psychology 3 Introduction\nto biological and psychosocial influences on\ninfant, child and adolescent development.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n363 Psychology of Aging 3 Psychological\nprocesses of aging; changes in sensory, motor,\ncognitive, motivational and personality\ncharacteristics; research methodologies for\nthe study of aging. Recommended preparation:\nPSYCH 105.\n372 [BSCI] Biological Basis of Behavior 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Sophomore standing.\nFunctional relationship between nervous\nsystem and behavior; integrated organ\nsystems, sensory processes, and investigative\nprocedures. Recommended preparation:\nPSYCH 105 or PSYCH 265; BIOLOGY 102,\nBIOLOGY 107, or BIOLOGY 101 and 105.\n384 Sensation and Perception 3 Perception\nof size, depth, form, shape; illusions,\ncontrast; historical and modern theories and\nresearch; applications and demonstrations.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\nPsychology\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n371\n390 [M] Alcohol Use and Abuse 3 Course\nPrerequisite: PSYCH 105. Biopsychosocial\nmodels of alcohol use and abuse; biology,\neffects, risk, and protective factors, assessment\nand diagnosis, and prevention of alcohol\nuse and abuse disorders. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 210, 312.\n401 [CAPS] [M] Historical Development of\nPsychology 3 Course Prerequisite: Admitted\nto the major in Psychology; junior standing.\nConcepts, methods, theories, trends, and\nsystems. Recommended preparation: PSYCH\n105.\n403 M u l t i c u l t u r a l P s y c h o l o g y 3\nMultidisciplinary analyses of the relationship\nbetween social-ecological and political contexts\nand individual and collective psychology.\n405 Instructional Practicum Training 1\nCourse Prerequisite: By permission only.\nTraining of undergraduate students in best\npractices, policies, and responsibilities of being\na teaching assistant. S, F grading.\n412 [CAPS] [M] Psychological Testing and\nAssessment 3 Course Prerequisite: PSYCH\n311; junior standing. Introduction to test and\nsurvey development in clinical, organizational,\nand educational settings; assessment\nof attitudes, personality, and behavior.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n440 [M] Clinical/Community Psychology\n3 Course Prerequisite: PSYCH 333; junior\nstanding. Professional problems; theory,\ntraining, relations with clients, institutions,\npublic. Recommended preparation: PSYCH\n105.\n442 A d v a n c e d A d d i c t i o n Tr e a t m e n t\nTechniques 4 (3-2) Course Prerequisite:\nPSYCH 342. Advanced addiction treatment\napproaches for individuals, couples, families\nand groups within a human services framework;\nintegration of relapse prevention techniques.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 110.\n444 [M] Basic Clinical Skills 3 Course\nPrerequisite: 6 hours PSYCH. Training in\nbasic skills to work with varied types of\nclients; didactic and role play instruction.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n445 Undergraduate Practicum V 1 (0-3) to 3\n(0-9) May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Course Prerequisite: 6 hours\nPSYCH; junior standing. Supervised experience\nin local and county agencies; application\nof psychological principles to a variety of\nprofessional work settings. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105; PSYCH 333; PSYCH\n444. S, F grading.\n464 Behavior Disorders of Children and\nAdolescents 3 Course Prerequisite: PSYCH\n361, H D 101, or H D 340. Theoretical and\nempirical approaches to the description,\netiology, and treatment of behavior disorders\nin children and adolescents. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105; PSYCH 333.\n466 Environmental Psychology 3 Psychological\nconcepts applied to the mixture of positive and\nnegative interactions individuals have with\ntheir physical environment. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105.\n468 Addictive Behavior Among Diverse\nPopulations 3 Course Prerequisite: Junior\nstanding. Overview of social, cultural, and\nhistorical perspectives on dealing with\naddictive behavior. (Crosslisted course\noffered as PSYCH 468, CRM J 468, SOC 468).\nRecommended preparation: SOC 101, PSYCH\n105, or CRM J 101.\n470 Motivation 3 Course Prerequisite: Junior\nstanding. Different motivational systems;\nanalysis of environmental and biological\nfactors influencing motivation, with emphasis\non human motivation. Recommended\npreparation: PSYCH 105; PSYCH 350, PSYCH\n372, PSYCH 490, or PSYCH 491.\n473 [M] Advanced Biological Basis of\nBehavior 3 Course Prerequisite: PSYCH\n372, or NEUROSCI 301. Neurophysiological,\nhormonal, and biochemical bases of regulatory\nbehavior; theoretical and applied issues.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n485 Gerontechnology I 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCPT S 215, 223, or 233; admitted to the major\nor minor in Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, Electrical Engineering, Software\nEngineering, Data Analytics, or major in\nPsychology. Introduction to the field of\ngerontechnology, including aging and senses,\nmobility and exercise, data analysis, and\nresearch methods. (Crosslisted course offered\nas CPT S 485, PSYCH 485).\n486 Gerontechnology II 3 Course Prerequisite:\nCPT S 215, 223, or 233; admitted to the major\nor minor in Computer Science, Computer\nEngineering, Electrical Engineering, Software\nEngineering, Data Analytics, or major\nin Psychology. In-depth exploration of\ngerontechnology, including socialization,\ncaregiver issues, dementia, app design and data\nvisualization. (Crosslisted course offered as CPT\nS 486, PSYCH 486).\n490 C o g n i t i o n a n d M e m o r y 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Human\ninformation processing, memory, and\ncognition. Recommended preparation: PSYCH\n105.\n491 P r i n c i p l e s o f L e a r n i n g 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Principles of\nlearning from a behavioral perspective using\nthe experimental analysis of behavior. Credit\nnot granted for both PSYCH 491 and 591.\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n492 Psychology of Language 3 The cognitive\nand neuropsychological processes involved\nin the acquisition and use of language; cross-\ncultural perspectives on language and thought.\n495 F i e l d E x p e r i e n c e i n P e r s o n n e l\nPsychology V 2 (0-6) to 6 (0-18) May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 6\nhours. Course\nPrerequisite: Ph.D. student in Psychology.\nResearch design, equipment, data collection,\ndata analysis, and report writing. S, F grading.\n504 History of Psychology: Theoretical\nand Scientific Foundations 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Ph.D. student in Psychology.\nRoots of scientific explanation in psychology\ntraced through various philosophical schools\nand psychological movements. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\n505 Teaching Introductory Psychology V\n1-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 5 hours. Course Prerequisite:\nPh.D. student in Psychology. Problems and\ntechniques related to teaching introductory\npsychology. S, F grading.\n506 Current Research in Psychology 1 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Course Prerequisite: Ph.D. student in\nPsychology. Current research being conducted\nby psychology faculty and members of\nassociated departments. S, F grading.\n508 Special Topics in Psychology V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit.\n510 Introduction to Online Instruction\n1 Course Prerequisite: Ph. D student in\nPsychology. Instruction in teaching online\ncourses addressing issues faced by instructors\nand students; students are mentored while\nteaching online. S, F grading.\n511 Experimental Design, T-Tests, and\nAnalysis of Variance 3 Course Prerequisite:\nPh.D. student in Psychology or Business\nAdministration. Parametric, nonparametric,\nrepeated-measures, and multivariate ANOVA;\nplanned comparisons; confidence intervals\nand power analysis; experimental design and\nvariants.\nPsychology\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n372\n512 Non-Experimental Designs, Correlation,\nand Regression 3 Course Prerequisite:\nPh.D. student in Psychology or Business\nAdministration. Simple and multiple\ncorrelation and regression; time-series analysis;\nfactor analysis; field research and quasi-\nexperimental design.\n513 Seminar in Quantitative Methods and\nResearch Design 3 May be repeated for credit.\nCourse Prerequisite: PSYCH 512. Advanced\ntopics in specialized quantitative procedures\nand in design of research in psychology.\n514 Psychometrics 3 Course Prerequisite: PSYCH\n512. Scientific construction of behavioral\nassessment instruments, including validation\nand reliability; types of scales and responses;\nstatistical scaling; test theory issues.\n515 Multilevel and Synthesized Data 3 Course\nPrerequisite: PSYCH 512. Structural equation\nmodeling, hierarchical linear modeling and\nmeta-analysis and the software used to conduct\nthese analyses.\n516 Applied Structural Equation Modeling\nw i t h C u r r e n t S o f t w a r e 3 Course\nPrerequisite: PSYCH 512; PSYCH 514.\nConfirmatory factor analysis, path analysis,\nstructural regression analysis, multilevel\nanalysis and latent growth analysis with\ncurrent software.\n517 Clinical Skills 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 2 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: Ph.D. student in Psychology.\nIntroduction to micro-skills and basic\ntherapeutic interventions necessary for\nentering practicum students. S, F grading.\n518 Lifespan Developmental Psychology\n3 Course Prerequisite: Ph.D. student in\nPsychology. Study of continuity and change\nfrom infancy through senescence, with an\nemphasis on a biopsychosocial perspective and\nan interdisciplinary approach to the principles\nof development.\n519 Industrial/Organizational Psychology\n3 Course Prerequisite: Ph.D. student in\nPsychology. Overview of research, theory, and\napplication of psychological principles in the\nworkplace.\n520 Adult Psychotherapy 3 Course Prerequisite:\nPSYCH 533. An overview of empirically-\nsupported treatments for psychological\ndisorders in adults and the science of\npsychotherapy research.\n521 Empirical Approaches to Psychotherapy\nII 3 Course Prerequisite: PSYCH 520. Research\nmethods in empirically-supported therapies\n(ESTs), and specific ESTs approaches including\ncognitive-behavioral (CBT) for mood disorders,\npersonality disorders, pain and health-related\nproblems.\n523 Health Psychology 3 Course Prerequisite:\nPh.D. student in Psychology. Overview of\nthe field of health psychology from a social-\ncognitive perspective; includes a focus on\nhealth behavior models addressing how beliefs,\nexpectations, affect, and other social influences\nimpact health decisions and behavior.\n524 Motivational Interviewing 3 Advanced\nbackground in Motivational Interviewing\n(MI), a strategy for motivating health behavior\nchange; knowledge on outcome and process\nMI research and introduction to the basic\nclinical techniques and skills of MI.\n529 Occupational Health Psychology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Ph.D. student in Psychology.\nOverview of major occupational health\npsychology content areas and foundational\ntheories; causes and consequences of work-\nrelated stressors, injury, and illness; individual\nand organizational interventions.\n530 Professional, Ethical, and Legal Issues\n3 Course Prerequisite: Ph.D. student in\nPsychology. Application of professional,\nethical, and legal issues in clinical psychology\nto such topics as confidentiality, dual-\nrelationships, research, assessment, and\nintervention.\n533 A d u l t P s y c h o p a t h o l o g y 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Ph.D. student in Psychology.\nTheoretical and empirical approaches to\ndiagnosis, etiology and treatment of mental\ndisorders.\n534 Clinical Psychopharmacology 3 Course\nPrerequisite: PSYCH 533; Ph.D. student\nin Clinical or Counseling Psychology.\nClassification, clinical application, and\nmechanisms of psychotherapeutic drugs used\nin the treatment of mental disorders.\n535 Personality Assessment and Diagnosis\n3 Course Prerequisite: Ph.D. student in\nPsychology. Diagnostic inter viewing,\nconceptualization of clinical problems, case\npresentations, and treatment planning.\n536 Measurement Theory and Personality\nAssessment 3 Course Prerequisite: By\ninterview only. Psychometric theory, theories\nof personality, objective and projective\nmethods of assessing personality, development\nof testing and interpretive skills.\n537 Psychology Clinic Assessment Practicum\n3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Research on developmental\npsychopathology and evidence-based\nassessment of children and adolescents.\n544 Clinical Health and Primary Care\nPsychology 3 Course Prerequisite: Ph.D.\nstudent in Clinical or Counseling Psychology.\nPrinciples and practice of clinical health and\nprimary care psychology.\n545 Psychology Clinic Assessment and\nPsychotherapy Practicum 3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 24\nhours. Neuroanatomical,\nneurochemical, and other biological cases of\nhuman and animal behavior. Cooperative:\nOpen to UI degree-seeking students.\nPsychology\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n373\n584 Sensory Bases of Behavior 3 Sensory and\nphysiological aspects of vision, audition, and\nother senses.\n591 Principles of Learning 3 Principles of\nlearning from a behavioral perspective using\nthe experimental analysis of behavior. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor before enrolling in 600\ncredit, which cannot be used toward the core\ngraded credits required for a graduate degree.\nS, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit.
