Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 800 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nDepartment of Sociology\nsoc.wsu.edu/\nWilson-Short 204\n509-335-4595\nDepartment Chair and Professor, J. Kmec; Professors,\nD. Dillman, C. Horne, M. Johnson, A. MacLean, C.\nMosher, T. Rotolo, J. Schwartz; Associate Professors, J.\nDenney, E. Johnson, J. Sherman; Assistant Professosr,\nM. Amorim, D. Bugden, K. Leupp; A. Zamora-Kapoor;\nClinical Assistant Professors, K. Cutler, J. Kremer S.\nWhitley; Instructors, M. Nesbitt, J. Schmidt.\nSociology is the scientific study of social life. The\nfundamental insight of the discipline is that the\nsocial matters; our lives are affected not only by\nour personal psychology, but by our place in the\nsocial world. Substantively, sociologists look at a\nrange of issues, from inequality to human ecology,\nfrom deviance to social order, from medicine to\npolitics. Few fields offer students (and researchers)\nopportunities of such breadth.\nCourses in sociology are designed to provide\nthe student with an understanding of what makes\nIndividuals and groups behave the way they do.\nSocial inequality, social order, and social change\nare prominent themes. In today’s changing job\nmarket, the skills developed by sociology majors\nare important – skills in analyzing problems,\nunderstanding diverse peoples, and assessing\nhow changes in the broader social structure shape\nindividuals’ daily lives. Sociology also provides\ntraining in social science research methods and\nstatistics, communication, and critical thinking.\nSuccessful sociology majors enter the professional\nworld with skills useful in a wide range of careers\nincluding public relations, community planning,\npositions in government and social agencies, as\nresearchers and data analysts, criminal justice\nsystem professions, health and medical fields,\nand business. Sociology also provides an excellent\nfoundation for professions that may require\ngraduate school training, such as counseling, law,\npublic policy and administration, social work,\npublic health or teaching.\nThe department offers courses of study leading to\nthe degrees of Bachelor of Arts in Sociology, Master\nof Arts in Sociology, and Doctor of Philosophy. It\nalso offers an undergraduate minor in Sociology,\na minor in At-Risk Youth, a minor in Workplace\nDiversity, and, in partnership with the Carson\nCollege of Business, a certificate in Organizational\nLeadership in Sustainability.\nUndergraduate Student Learning\nOutcomes\nAt the completion of the bachelor of arts degree\nin sociology, students will be able to 1) think\ncritically about social problems; 2) understand\nand apply basic statistics to social issues; 3) clearly\ncommunicate sociological concepts, theories,\nand findings; 4) evaluate and conduct empirical\nresearch, and use social science to develop\ninformed judgements about significant social\nissues; 5) analyze the relationships between social,\ntechnological, and natural physical systems; 6)\nanalyze the contributions of social institutions to\nsocial order; 7) analyze the causes and consequences\nof social inequality; and 8) put into practice the\nskills and habits of successful professionals.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nSOCIOLOGY\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Sociology\nprogram upon making their intentions known to\nthe department.\nThis is a prototype of one of many ways to\ncomplete the Bachelor of Arts in Sociology in four\nyears. The program has built-in flexibility.\nA Bachelor of Arts degree in sociology requires\na minimum of 31 credits of sociology coursework\nin which students must maintain a C average. All\nmajors must complete five required core courses:\nIntroduction to Sociology (SOC 101), Development\nof Social Theory (SOC 310), Research Methods in\nSociology (SOC 317 [M]), Quantitative Techniques\nin Sociology (SOC 321), and one of the following\n“capstone experience” integrative capstone courses:\nInternship Capstone (SOC 495 [CAPS][M]), From\nTheory to Practice Capstone (SOC 496 [CAPS][M]),\nor Research Practicum Capstone (SOC 497 [CAPS]\n[M]).\nStudents must also complete 15 credits of\nelective courses in sociology and 12 credits in\na concentration area, half of which must be in\n300-400-level courses. Concentration courses\nenable students to individualize their programs\nof study to best meet their academic and career\ngoals. Students select concentration courses from a\ndepartment-approved list and in consultation with\nan academic advisor.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nQuantitative Reasoning [QUAN] 3\nSOC 101 [SSCI] 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, or Elective 4\nSecond Term Hours\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nForeign Language, if necessary, and/or\nElectives 5\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS], Humanities [HUM], or\nSocial Sciences [SSCI] 3\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nElectives 6\nSecond Term Hours\nPhysical Sciences [PSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nSOC Elective\n2 \n3\nElectives 9\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nSociology\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n374\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nConcentration Elective\n3 \n3\nSOC 310 3\nSOC 317 [M] 3\nElectives 3\nSOC Electives\n2 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nConcentration Elective\n3 \n3\nSOC 321 4\nSOC Electives\n2 \n6\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\n300-400-level Concentration Elective\n3 \n3\nSOC Elective\n2 \n3\nElectives 9\nSecond Term Hours\nSOC 495 [CAPS] [M], 496 [CAPS] [M], or\n497 [CAPS] [M] 3\n300-400-level Concentration Elective\n3 \n3\n300-400-level Electives 9\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nSOC Electives (15 credits): Any SOC course except\nrequired SOC courses and SOC 320. Must include\nsufficient 300-400-level courses to meet University\nRequirement of 40 credits of Upper Division\ncoursework.\n3 \nConcentration Electives (12 credits): At least 6\ncredits must be at the 300-400 level. Students are\nencouraged to select a concentration area that best\nfurthers their career objectives. Concentration areas\ninclude: Work and Family (SOC 251, 340, 351, 384,\n390); Crime, Deviance, and Control (SOC 360, 361,\n362, 364, 368, 461); Sustainable Societies (SOC 332,\n334, 335, 336, 430, 474); and Related Fields (COM\n101, 410, 440, 464, 470, COMSOC 230, 321, 421,\nCOMSTRAT 312, 380, CPT S 401, I BUS 380, MGMT\n301, MIL SCI 201, 202, 301, 302, 401, 402, MKTG\n360, SOE 110, 312, and any AMER ST, ANTH, ASIA,\nCES, CRM J, ECONS, H D, HISTORY, HONORS,\nPHIL, POL S, PSYCH, and WOMEN ST courses).\nStudents may not use the 12-credit concentration\nareas to fulfill the 15 credits of sociology electives\nrequired in the major.\nMinors\nAt-Risk Youth\nA student may be admitted to the minor in At-Risk\nYouth after completion of 60 credits. The minor\nrequires a minimum of 18 credits in sociology,\nincluding SOC 352, 360, 362, and 368, and at least\n6 additional credits of electives (SOC 346, 351,\n361, or CRM J 365/SOC 367). At least 9 credits\nmust be upper-division taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses. A GPA of 2.0 is\nrequired for the minor.\nHealth and Society\nStudents may be admitted to the minor in Health\nand Society after completion of 60 credits. The\nminor requires a minimum of 18 credits in\nSociology or related disciplines, including SOC\n334; SOC 340; and at least 12 additional credits of\nHealth and Society electives from the following:\nANTH 205, 304, 405, PHIL 365, PSYCH 310, SOC\n101 or 102, 251, 330, 336, 351, 356, 368, 384, 493,\nWOMEN ST/SOC 385. At least 9 credits must be\nupper-division work taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange programs. Up to 3 credits of\nSOC 493 may apply to the minor. All minor courses\nmust be completed with a minimum 2.0 GPA.\nSociology\nA student may be admitted to the minor in\nSociology after completion of 60 credits. It requires a\nminimum of 18 credits in sociology, including SOC\n101, 320, and at least 9 additional graded credits\nof 300-400-level courses taken in residence at WSU\nor through WSU-approved education abroad or\neducational exchange courses. Any SOC course may\nbe counted toward the minor (subject to the above\nprovisions). Only 3 credits of SOC 495 may apply\nto the minor. A GPA of 2.0 is required for the minor.\nWorkplace Diversity\nFaculty coordinator: Dr. Sarah Whitley\nWilson 204\nPullman, WA 99164-4020\n509-335-4595\nwhitley@wsu.edu\nThe Minor in Workplace Diversity program\nis designed specifically for students and/or\nprofessionals with the aim of preparing them\nfor increasingly diverse and global workplaces. It\nincreases their intercultural understanding and\nskills, as well as provides evidence of those skills\n(in the form of an academic minor) to prospective\nor current employers. Given the possibility of\nfollowing a number of profession-specific tracks, the\nprogram is useful for individuals across majors or\ndisciplines who are or expect to be in management\npositions, or work with diverse colleagues, clients,\ncustomers, patients, or students.\nThe intent of this minor is to broaden and enhance\nknowledge and/or incorporate additional skills in\nthe student’s academic preparation. The minor’s\nprogram of studies is designed by the student in\ncollaboration with the coordinator and /or the\nadvisor. Students may be admitted after completing\n60 credits and/or admission into a major. A\nminimum of 18 credits is required and must include\n9 credits of upper-division work taken in residence\nat WSU or through WSU-approved education\nabroad or educational exchange courses. All core\ncourses must be taken at WSU. Not counting the\nSOC 341 course, no more than two courses with the\nsame subject (or content, as in cross-listed courses)\nmay be applied towards the minor. A maximum of\n3 internship credits may count towards the minor’s\nelectives, if approved by coordinator. For a selection\nof suggested electives, please consult with the\nminors’ faculty coordinator or the academic advisor\nfor the Department of Sociology.\nProgram of Study\nCore Courses (12 credits): SOC 341; PHIL 360;\nANTH 203, CES 101 or WOMEN ST 101; SOC 340\nor CES 301\nElectives (6 credits) to be selected in collaboration\nwith program director from: ANTH 316; ANTH/POL\nS/SOC 418; CES 244, 301, 440, 446; COMSOC 321,\n421; MGMT 315; PHIL 365 ; POL S 305, 432; PSYCH\n309; SOC 334, 390; WOMEN ST 385, 406.\nLearning Goals\nAfter completing the Workplace Diversity Minor\nProgram, students will be able to:\n• Recognize how behavior and perspective are\nshaped by social structural factors such as economics,\npower, and institutionalized discrimination.\n• Assess how their own and others’ cultural\nidentity, filters and behaviors impact the work\nenvironment.\n• R e s p o n d t o b i a s i n a p r o a c t i v e a n d\ntransformational way.\n• Utilize strategies to value and bridge differences\namong, and work more effectively with, people who\ndiffer from one another according to a wide variety\nof attributes.\n• Demonstrate behaviors that contribute to a\nwelcoming and respectful workplace.\nCertificates\nSustainable Organizational\nLeadership\nThe Certificate in Sustainable Organizational\nLeadership at WSU is open to all majors. This\ninterdisciplinary certificate provides value\nto students by building synergies across two\nstrongly complementary units: the Department\nof Sociology and the Carson College of Business.\nEnvironmental and resource sustainability is an\nimportant social problem and an increasingly\ncommon issue across for-profit, not-for-profit, and\ngovernmental workplaces. Achieving sustainability\nrequires attention to the intersections of three key\ndomains – financial, environmental, and social.\nThis certificate will develop student expertise and\nskills in these three arenas and the intersections\nbetween them, producing leaders who can act to\nachieve sustainability goals across a diversity of\norganizational settings.\nThe Certificate in Sustainable Organizational\nLeadership requires 15 credits including SOC 332,\n340, and MGMT 301, and two electives drawn from:\nHBM 381 or MGMT 401; MGMT 483, 487; SOC 335,\n336, 430, 474.\nDescription of Courses\nSOCIOLOGY\nSOC\n101 [SSCI] Introduction to Sociology 3\nIntroduction to the discipline of sociology:\nConcepts and methods used in the inquiry\ninto the social world.\n102 [SSCI] Social Problems 3 The structure of\nsocial institutions and cultural factors that\nconstitute threats to society (crime, poverty,\ndiscrimination, drugs, family violence).\n103 [ C O M M ] S o c i a l P s y c h o l o g y o f\nC o m m u n i c a t i o n 3 U s e o f s o c i a l\npsychological principles to communicate\neffectively with diverse audiences.\nSociology\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n375\n106 Murder and Mass Mayhem in American\nSociety 3 Similarities and differences in\nmurder and mass mayhem within the US and\nbetween US and other nations.\n245 Sociology of Sport 3 Sociological study of\nsport in America.\n250 Perspectives on Disability 3 Historical,\ninternational, socioeconomic, ethical\nand personal perspectives on disability;\nindividual choices, societal values, and social\nresponsibility.\n251 [ D I V R ] T h e S o c i o l o g y o f S e x ,\nRelationships, and Marriage 3 Social\nand personal factors in mate selection; the\nsociology of sexuality; development of\ngender roles; and intimate relationships and\nmarriage. (Crosslisted course offered as SOC\n251, WOMEN ST 251).\n300 [DIVR] [M] Intersections of Race,\nClass, Gender, and Sexuality 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SOC 101 or WOMEN ST\n101. Intersections between race, class and\ngender through case studies; experiences in\ninterdisciplinary methods. (Crosslisted course\noffered as WOMEN ST 300, ENGLISH 310, SOC\n300).\n302 Contemporary Masculinities 3 Analysis\nof the development of masculinity in its\nbiological and cultural forms. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as WOMEN ST 302, SOC 302).\n305 Degree and Careers 1 Introduction to the\nmajor or minor, degree or minor requirements,\nresources for degree planning, graduate\ndegrees, and careers for sociology majors and\nminors.\n310 Development of Social Theor y 3\nF o u n d a t i o n s o f s o c i o l o g i c a l t h e o r y ;\nintroduction to original works of early social\ntheorists. Recommended preparation: SOC\n101.\n311 V i s u a l P r e s e n t a t i o n a n d D a t a\nManagement in Social Science 3\nInvestigate and communicate with social\nscience data; techniques of visual data display\nusing Excel and other tools.\n317 [M] Research Methods in Sociology 3\nDesigning, conducting, and reporting social\nresearch.\n320 Introduction to Social Research 3 Methods\nof collecting data; surveys, experiments, field\nobservations; organization and interpretation\nof data; reading social research findings.\n321 Quantitative Techniques in Sociology I\n4 Levels of measurement; measures of central\ntendency, dispersion and association; normal\ncurve, statistical inference; logic of quantitative\ncomparison and decision making.\n330 America’s Changing Population:\nChallenges and Strategies 3 Introduction\nto population studies and to measurements\nof fertility, mortality, and migration;\nstudy of impacts of populations changes\non contemporary social issues (e.g., mass\nincarceration, poverty, teen pregnancy,\nenvironment).\n331 Population, Resources, and the Future\n3 Effects of population on resource depletion,\nenvironmental deterioration, social and\neconomic structure; zero population growth\nprospects; limits to growth debate.\n332 [SSCI] Sustainability and Society 3 The\nstudy of human-environment relationships\nand the connections between environmental,\neconomic, and social systems. Recommended\npreparation: SOC 101.\n333 Science, Power and Human Values 3\nRecent developments in the sociological\nstudy of science and scientific knowledge\nthrough cultural, commercial, and political\nperspectives.\n334 Medical Sociology 3 Study of the societal\ndimensions of health and medicine: social\ndeterminants of health.\n335 Shopping and Society 3 Course Prerequisite:\nSOC 101. Consumption and its impacts on the\nenvironment and society.\n336 Sociology of Food 3 Theoretical, historical,\nand empirical issues of food and agriculture\nin the United States including social, political,\nand economic aspects. Recommended\npreparation: SOC 101.\n337 Climate Change in Your Lifetime 3\nReflections on personal experiences with\nclimate change, climate politics and policy,\nscientific uncertainty, and more\n340 [DIVR] Social Inequality 3 Causes\nand consequences of social inequality in\ncontemporary America. Recommended\npreparation: SOC 101.\n343 S o c i o l o g y o f P r o f e s s i o n s a n d\nOccupations 3 Social organization of\nwork in America including historical and\ncontemporary trends, bureaucracy, gender/\nracial inequality, technological affects, work/\nfamily relations. Recommended preparation:\nSOC 101.\n346 Sociology of Education 3 Examination of\nhow educational institutions are influenced\nby other social forces, how school practices\naffect individual outcomes and how race/\nclass/gender shape educational opportunity.\nRecommended preparation: SOC 101.\n347 Sociology of Race, Ethnicity, and\nImmigration 3 Racial and ethnic categories\nand experiences of specific racial, ethnic, and\nimmigrant groups.\n350 Social Psychology 3 Course Prerequisite:\nSophomore standing. Attitude changes,\nconformity, interpersonal relations, groups and\nsocial influences explored to give a coherent\nview of social psychology. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as PSYCH 350, SOC 350).\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105 or\nSOC 101.\n351 [DIVR] The Family 3 Family system and\nits interaction patterns; family formation and\ndissolution; marital and partner relations,\ndivorce, sexuality, parenting, work-family\nbalance. Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n358 Beliefs, Norms, and Values 3 Sources and\nconsequences of beliefs, norms, and values.\n359 Giving 3 Giving that contributes to flourishing\nsocieties; philanthropy, volunteering,\ncooperation, and altruism.\n360 Social Deviance 3 A survey of the sociology\nof deviance. S, U grading.\nDepartment of Speech and\nHearing Sciences\nmedicine.wsu.edu/speech-and-hearing-\nsciences-2/\nHealth Science Bldg, Room 125X; WSU\nSpokane\n509-358-7602\nspeechhearing@wsu.edu\nProfessor and Department Chair, G. D. Chermak;\nProfessor, N. Potter; Associate Professor, M. VanDam;\nAssistant Professors, D. Jenson, G. Lynch, L. Swineford;\nClinical Professor, A. Meredith; Clinical Associate\nProfessors, C. Dechert, K. Simpson; Clinical Assistant\nProfessor, D. Algeo; Teaching Assistant Professor, M.\nRatsch; Instructors, C. Balasz, K. Jones; Professors\nEmeriti, S. Bassett, E. Inglebret, C. L. Madison, R. E.\nPotter, L. Power.\nThe Department of Speech and Hearing Sciences in\nthe Elson S. Floyd College of Medicine offers courses\nof study leading to the degrees of Bachelor of Arts in\nSpeech and Hearing Sciences and Master of Science\nin Speech and Hearing Sciences. Training in speech\nand hearing sciences through the bachelor’s degree\nprepares students for a range of careers in health\nprofessions, education, and social services, among\nothers. State and national clinical and educational\nlicensure and certification require completion\nof the master’s degree. The graduate program in\nspeech-language pathology is accredited nationally\nby the Council on Academic Accreditation of the\nAmerican Speech-Language-Hearing Association\nand recognized at the state level by the Washington\nState Board of Education.\nGraduate students are prepared as speech-language\npathologists to provide evidence-based, direct and\nconsultative services in education and medical\nsettings to meet the diagnostic and treatment needs\nof individuals across the life span evidencing a wide\nvariety of speech, language, swallowing, voice and\nhearing problems. The course of study emphasizes\nthe physiological, neurological, psychological, and\nbehavioral processes of normal development, the\nfundamental communication process, and the\ndisorders of communication.\nThe undergraduate and graduate programs,\nlocated in the Health Sciences Building on the\nWashington State University Health Sciences\nSpokane campus, are cooperative ventures,\ncombining faculty and resources of Washington\nState University and Eastern Washington University\nto form University Programs in Communication\nDisorders (UPCD). WSU students enroll through\nand receive their degrees from Washington State\nUniversity. The Hearing and Speech Clinic is the\nSpokane campus graduate training facility for the\nUniversity Programs in Communication Disorders.\nOpportunities to work with special populations and\nin medical settings are readily available for graduate\nstudents in the Spokane area. A capstone graduate\ninternship program provides intensive practical\nexperience in many clinical and educational\nsettings across the state and the region. Contact:\nspeechhearing@wsu.edu and speech.hear.grad@\nwsu.edu\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nA graduate of the bachelor’s Speech and Hearing\nSciences program will be able to: 1) identify needs\nor issues in clinical service delivery; 2) identify\ncontextual factors to consider in addressing\nclinical service delivery needs/issues; 3) identify\nand consider various perspectives important\nto analysis of the needs/issues and underlying\nassumptions associated with each; 4) identify and\nassess the quality of evidence supporting particular\nservice delivery practices; 5) identify and assess\nconclusions, implications, and consequences\nassociated with examination of the needs/issues;\n6) Provide informed leadership to achieve desired\nsocial outcomes.\nLearning outcomes for students in Speech and\nHearing Sciences master’s program reflect the\nknowledge and skills competencies required\nby the American Speech-Language-Hearing\nAssociation. Students earning a master’s degree\nwill be able to demonstrate: 1) knowledge of the\nbasic human communication and swallowing\nprocesses; 2) knowledge of the nature of speech,\nlanguage, hearing, and communication disorders\nand differences, and swallowing disorders; 3)\nknowledge of the principles and methods of\nprevention, assessment, and intervention for\npeople with communication and swallowing\ndisorders; 4) knowledge of standards of ethical\nconduct; 5) knowledge of the processes used in\nresearch and the integration of research principles\ninto evidence-based clinical practice; 6) knowledge\nof contemporary professional issues; 7) skills in\nscreening, evaluation and prevention procedures; 8)\nskills in developing, implementing, and monitoring\nappropriate intervention plans with measurable and\nachievable goals that meet clients’/patients’ needs.\nPreparation for Graduate Study\nStudents with undergraduate majors in human\ndevelopment, linguistics, education, psychology,\nand other social and behavioral sciences, as well\nas those with undergraduate majors in speech and\nhearing sciences, may be accepted for graduate\nstudy in this department. Those with majors in areas\nother than speech and hearing sciences are required\nto complete undergraduate prerequisite coursework\nprior to applying to the graduate program.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nSPEECH AND HEARING SCIENCES\n(120 HOURS)\nAdmission Requirements:\nGiven the rigorous nature of the coursework\nand the need to prepare students for work in a\nSpeech and Hearing Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n378\npre-professional role or to prepare them for the\ncompetitive demands of applying to graduate\nschool in the discipline, students must meet the\nfollowing minimum requirements for admission to\nthe major in Speech and Hearing Sciences: 1) Have\nearned a minimum of 24 credits of undergraduate\ncredits; 2) Have taken, or currently enrolled in, SHS\n205, Introduction to Speech-Language Pathology\n& Audiology; 3)minimum cumulative GPA of 2.75.\nAt least 45 of the total credits required for the\nbachelor’s degree in this program must be in\n300-400-level courses. Successful completion of\nSHS 473 [M] and 482 [M] fulfills the university\nrequirement of two writing in the major courses.\nThe Speech and Hearing Sciences Department\nprovides preparation for professional (graduate)\ntraining as a speech-language pathologist or\naudiologist. This course sequence is based on fall\nenrollment. UCOREs must be completed prior to\nthe fifth semester.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBIOLOGY 102 [BSCI] or 106 [BSCI] 4\nCommunication [COMM] or Written\nCommunication [WRTG] 3\nDiversity [DIVR] 3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nPSYCH 105 [SSCI] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nPHYSICS 101/111 [PSCI] or CHEM 101 [PSCI] 4\nSHS Elective\n1 \n3\nSTAT 212 [QUAN] 4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nArts [ARTS] 3\nSHS 205 3\nSHS Electives\n1 \n6\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nHumanities [HUM] 3\nSHS Electives\n1 \n6\nElectives 6\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nSHS 371 3\nSHS 372 3\nSHS 375 3\nSHS 377 3\nElectives 3\nSecond Term Hours\nSHS 376 3\nSHS 378 3\nSHS 472 3\nSHS 478 3\nElectives 3\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nSHS 201 4\nSHS 477 3\nSHS 479 3\nSHS 482 [M] 3\nSHS Electives\n1 \n2\nSecond Term Hours\nSHS 202 4\nSHS 451 3\nSHS 461 2\nSHS 473 [M] 3\nSHS 480 [CAPS] 3\n_______\n1 \nSHS electives (17 credits required) include any H D\nor PSYCH course 200-level or above, or as approved\nby advisor.\nDescription of Courses\nSPEECH AND HEARING SCIENCES\nSHS\n201 American Sign Language I 4 Instruction\nand practical training in sign language for\ncommunication with persons who are deaf;\ndeaf culture; beginning conversation skills.\n202 American Sign Language II 4 Course\nPrerequisite: SHS 201 or concurrent enrollment;\ncompletion of SHS 201 recommended.\nSign language systems; vocabulary and skill\ndevelopment in signing and interpreting signs;\nintermediate conversation skills.\n205 Introduction to Speech-Language\nPathology and Audiology 3 Overview of\ndeficits of speech, language, and hearing and\nthe role of speech-language pathologist and the\naudiologist.\n371 Language Development 3 Normal\ndevelopment of the cognitive, linguistic,\nand pragmatic components of language;\nintroduction to language disorders in children.\n372 Hearing and Hearing Disorders 3 Acoustic\nand psychophysiologic aspects of normal\nhearing and speech perception, and the nature\nand consequences of hearing disorders.\n375 Phonetics 3 Description and classification\nof American English speech sounds; practice\nusing the International Phonetic Alphabet\nto transcribe normal and disordered speech\nsounds.\n376 Speech Sound Disorders 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SHS 375. Clinical phonetics and\ntranscription; evaluation and treatment of\natriculatory disorders; delayed phonological\nacquisition; dysarthria; and dyspraxia.\n377 Anatomy and Physiology of the Speech\nProduction 3 Anatomical and physiological\nbasis of speech production and the pathologies\nand aberrations that require the services of a\ncommunication disorders specialist.\n378 Speech and Hearing Sciences 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SHS 377. Basis of acoustics,\nacoustic phonetics, psychoacoustics,\nspeech production, speech perception, and\ninstrumentation for measurement of related\nphenomena.\n450 Special Topics in Speech and Hearing\nSciences V 1-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 9 hours. Study of\nspecialized topics in speech and hearing\nsciences.\n451 Neurogenic Communication Disorders\n3 Course Prerequisite: SHS 479. Introduction\nto the etiology, assessment and intervention\nof communication disorders associated with\nneurological disorders.\n460 Special Topics in Speech and Hearing\nSciences V 1-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 9 hours. Study of\nspecialized topics in speech and hearing\nsciences.\n461 Clinical Methods 2 Course Prerequisite:\nConcurrent enrollment in SHS 480 or SHS\n478. Pre-practicum preparation; observation\nof and assisting in therapy; state laws; clinical\nmethods.\n471 S p e e c h - L a n g u a g e P a t h o l o g y a n d\nAudiology in Schools 2 Therapy methods\nand procedures in speech-language pathology\nand audiology; state/federal laws affecting\npublic school therapy.\n472 Audiometry 3 Course Prerequisite: SHS\n372. Principles and procedures in basic\nidentification and assessment of hearing\nimpairment; introduction to differential\ndiagnosis of auditory pathologies.\n473 [M] Language and Literacy 3 Diagnosis\nand remediation of language and learning\ndisabilities in individuals manifesting disorders\nin understanding or using spoken/written\nlanguage.\n477 Aural Rehabilitation 3 Theories and\nmethods in aural rehabilitation for persons\nwho are hard of hearing; amplification;\neducational audiology; counseling techniques.\n478 L a n g u a g e I m p a i r m e n t 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: SHS 371. Assessment and\nhabilitation for the preschool and elementary-\nage child with language disorders.\n479 Neuroanatomy 3 Neuroanatomical and\nneurophysiological bases of speech production\nand audition; neuropathologies of speech,\nlanguage, and audition.\n480 [ C A P S ] S e n i o r S e m i n a r 3 C o u r s e\nPrerequisite: Senior standing. Synthesis of\ntheory and evidence underlying professional\nprinciples and practices inclusive of\nmulticultural populations in speech-language\npathology and audiology.\n482 [M] Assessment of Speech and Language\n3 Course Prerequisite: SHS 376 or concurrent\nenrollment; and SHS 478. Principles,\ntechniques, and materials involved in\nexploring the nature of speech and language\ndisorders; planning programs of therapy.\n490 Special Topics in Speech and Hearing\nSciences V 1-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 9 hours. S, F grading.\nSpeech and Hearing Sciences\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n379\n501 Research Methods 3 Philosophy of\nresearch, types of literature; experimental and\ndescriptive designs; application of statistics;\nanalysis of statistical results.\n540 Special Topics in Speech and Hearing\nSciences V 1-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 9 hours. Advanced\nstudy of specialized topics in speech and\nhearing sciences. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n542 E a r l y L a n g u a g e D e v e l o p m e n t 2\nDevelopmental progression of communication\nand language in pediatric populations, with an\nemphasis on assessment and intervention for\nvery young children and families. SHS graduate\nstudent; all undergraduate prerequisite courses\ncompleted.\n543 School Age and Adolescent Language\n3 Language development in typically\ndeveloping and language impaired school\nage and adolescent students; disorder types;\nimplications for assessment and intervention.\nSHS graduate student; all undergraduate\nprerequisite courses completed.\n545 Autism Spectrum Disorder 2 Course\nPrerequisite: SHS 542. Overview and discussions\nof the characteristics, causes, assessments, and\ninterventions for autism spectrum disorder.\n550 Special Topics in Speech and Hearing\nSciences V 1-3 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 9 hours.\nStudy of specialized topics in speech and\nhearing sciences. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n552 S p e e c h - L a n g u a g e P a t h o l o g y a n d\nAudiology in Schools 2 Laws, policies, and\nethical issues involved in providing speech-\nlanguage and audiology services in public\nschools.\n555 Bilingual and Cultural Issues 2 Cultural\nand linguistic variables that may impact speech-\nlanguage pathology services of culturally and\nlinguistically diverse populations; assessment\nand treatment considerations.\n556 Problems in Stuttering 2 Historical and\ncurrent literature; problem-solving strategies\napplied to theoretical and clinical problems\nin stuttering. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n557 Cleft Palate and Craniofacial Disorders 2\nSpeech and voice problems associated with clefts\nof the lip and palate. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n560 Special Topics in Speech and Hearing\nSciences V 1-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 9 hours. Advanced\nstudy of specialized topics in speech and\nhearing sciences. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n562 Motor Speech Disorders 3 Underlying\nprocesses of neuromuscular control and\nfeedback; results of damage and disease on\nneuromotor system. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n563 Dysphagia 3 Anatomy and physiology of\nswallowing; evaluation and treatment of\nswallowing disorders. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n565 Augmentative Communication 3\nAugmentative communication theory;\nimplementation, training strategies, ongoing\nadjustments, and evaluating effectiveness.\nSHS graduate student; all undergraduate\nprerequisite courses completed.\n566 Off-Campus Practicum Public School\nSetting V 2 (0-6) to 6 (0-18) May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 15 hours. By\ndepartmental consent only; minimum grade\nof B in SHS 575 or a grade of S in SHS 566\nor SHS 568 in the prior semester or summer\nterm, and a minimum grade of C in all prior\nSHS graduate coursework. Advanced clinical\npractice in a public school setting; evaluation\nand treatment of speech, language, and\nhearing disorders. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\nS, F grading.\n567 Issues in Public School Service Delivery\n3 Clinical operations, policies, procedures,\nincluding legal, ethical, and professional\nconsiderations in the schools. SHS graduate\nstudent; all undergraduate prerequisite courses\ncompleted.\n568 Off-campus Practicum Clinical Setting\nV 2 (0-6) to 6 (0-18) May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 15 hours. By\ndepartmental consent only; minimum grade of\nB in SHS 575 or a grade of S in SHS 566 or SHS\n568 in the prior semester or summer term, and\na minimum grade of C in all prior SHS graduate\ncoursework. Advanced clinical practice in an\noff-campus clinical/medical setting; evaluation\nand treatment of speech, language and hearing\ndisorders. S, F grading.\n570 Advanced Inter nship in Speech-\nLanguage Pathology V 1-18 May be\nrepeated for credit. By departmental consent\nonly; minimum grade of S in SHS 566 or SHS\n568 in the semester or summer term preceding\ninternship, and a minimum grade of C in all\nprior SHS graduate coursework. Advanced\npracticum in diagnosis of and therapy for\ncommunication disorders. SHS graduate\nstudent; all undergraduate prerequisite courses\ncompleted. S, F grading.\n574 Neuropathologies of Language and\nCognition I 2 Study of acquired language and\ncognitive disorders resulting from neurological\ndamage (specific to left and right hemisphere-\nbased disorders). SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n575 Advanced Clinical Practice V 2-6 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 15\nhours. Advanced clinical practice in evaluation\nand treatment of speech, language, and\nhearing disorders. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n576 Voice and Resonance Disorders 2\nFunctional and organic voice disorders\nresulting from various etiologies. SHS graduate\nstudent; all undergraduate prerequisite courses\ncompleted.\n577 Neurogenic Disorders of Language and\nCognition II 2 Course Prerequisite: SHS 574.\nStudy of acquired cognitive-communication\ndisorders resulting from diffuse and/or\nprogressive neurological damage.\n580 Special Topics in Speech and Hearing\nSciences V 1-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 9 hours. Advanced\nstudy of specialized topics in speech and\nhearing sciences. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n587 Speech-Language Pathology in the\nMedical Setting 2 Report writing and\ncharting, collaborating with the medical team,\nestablishing prognosis and assessing efficacy\nof treatment, and third-party reimbursement.\nSHS graduate student; all undergraduate\nprerequisite courses completed.\n588 Advanced Speech and Sound Disorders 2\nCurrent literature in articulatory development\nand deviancy; diagnosis and therapy. Required\npreparation: SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n590 Special Topics in Speech and Hearing\nSciences V 1-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 9 hours. Advanced\nstudy of specialized topics in speech and\nhearing sciences. SHS graduate student; all\nundergraduate prerequisite courses completed.\n600 Special Projects or Independent Study V\n1-18 May be repeated for credit. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. S, F grading.\n700 Master’s Research, Thesis, and/or\nExamination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Independent research and advanced\nstudy for students working on their master’s\nresearch, thesis and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n700 credit. S, U grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 702 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nDepartment of Teaching\nand Learning\neducation.wsu.edu/tl/\nCleveland 321\n509-335-6842\nChair and Associate Professor, T. Akmal; Professors,\nJ. L. Egbert, G. Ernst-Slavit, S. Finley, S. Kruse, A. R.\nMcDuffie, E. J. Johnson, J. Morrison, A. G. Rud, R. D.\nSawyer, D. Slavit; Associate Professors, Y. Ardasheva,\nA. Cavagnetto, D. Day-Wiff, M. Dunn, Y. Hsiao, J.\nE. Kelley, K. Lesseig, J. Lupinacci, D. McMahon,\nS. Newcomer, K. Puzio, T. L. Salsbury, M. Vaughn;\nAssistant Professors, L. Bruno, S. Fick, J. Firestone,\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n380\nA. Gilmore, A. Guerrettaz, S. Johnson, M. Kelton,\nJ. Masterson, M. Poppen, H. Whittenburg; Career\nTrack Faculty, J. Johnson, M. Moscatelli, S. Rakha,\nA. Segadelli, S. E. Skavdahl, T. F. Watson, L. White;\nProfessors Emeriti, J. M. Canty, S. B. Kucer, L. Mabry,\nD. Miller, M. Roe, B. Romanish; Associate Professor\nEmeritus, P. J. Bettis.\nCourses of study (availability differs across\ncampuses) are offered for elementary school\nteaching (Bachelor of Arts in Education, Master in\nTeaching) and secondary school teaching (degree\nfrom major plus certification, Master in Teaching).\nAdditional endorsements are offered in Special\nEducation, English Language Learners/Bilingual\nEducation, Middle Level Math, and Middle Level\nScience. Graduate programs include Master of Arts\nin the following specializations: Curriculum and\nInstruction; Language, Literacy, and Technology;\nand Special Education; Masters of Education,\nMasters in Teaching, and Doctor of Philosophy.\nDoctoral specializations are available in these areas:\nCultural Studies and Social Thought in Education\n(Ph.D.); Language, Literacy, and Technology (Ph.D.);\nMathematics and Science Education (Ph.D.); and\nSpecial Education (Ph.D.).\nDepartment of Teaching and Learning faculty\ncontribute to the theory and practice of the broad\nfield of education, and dedicate themselves to\nunderstanding and respecting learners in diverse\ncultural contexts. They facilitate engaged learning\nand ethical leadership in schools and clinical\nsettings. They seek collaboration with diverse\nconstituencies, recognizing their local and global\nresponsibilities to communities, environments, and\nfuture generations.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\nFaculty seek the following learning outcomes for\nstudents in teacher education: graduates will (1)\nuse content and pedagogical knowledge to inform\ntheir teaching, (2) develop relevant, rigorous, and\ndevelopmentally appropriate curricula, (3) modify\ncurriculum and instruction based on the individual\nneeds of their students, (4) use assessment of their\nstudents’ learning and their own teaching to inform\nfuture planning and teaching, (5) attend to the social\nand civic development of their students, and (6) work\nrespectfully and collaboratively with colleagues\nto ensure quality instructional programs and\nstewardship of public schools. At the master’s level,\ngraduates will (1) locate, analyze, and synthesize\nresearch literature, and apply that synthesis to\nproblems of practice, (2) effectively communicate\nscholarly work through written, oral, and/or alternate\nformats, (3) skillfully inquire into areas of program-\nrelated interest, (4) develop scholarly habits of\ncuriosity, inquiry, skepticism, and data-based decision\nmaking, and (5) demonstrate professional habits\nof respect, accept and use feedback, and consider\nothers’ ideas and perspectives. Doctoral students\nwill achieve master’s level outcomes and also will:\n(1) conduct and disseminate original scholarship\nthat demonstrates acquisition and application of new\nknowledge and theory, (2) become emerging experts\nin their area of study. Visit our website at https://\neducation.wsu.edu/formsanddeadlines/.\nThe Washington State University annual report on\nteacher education, required under Title II, Section\n207(f)(2) of the Higher Education Act, is available\nupon request. Visit our web site at https://education.\nwsu.edu/titleii/\nTEACHER CERTIFICATION\nThe Department of Teaching and Learning\nprepares individuals to teach elementary education,\nand various single subjects at the secondary\neducation level. The teaching certificate, awarded by\nthe State Superintendent of Public Instruction upon\nrecommendation by Washington State University,\ndesignates the subject area in which the certificate\nholder is qualified to teach. Candidates seeking a\nB.A. in Education must also complete 20 hours in\nan endorsable area (e.g., English Language Learning,\nSpecial Education, Middle Level Math, Middle Level\nScience, etc.). Admission to the teacher education\nprograms at all campuses is selective. Teacher\neducation is offered at the Pullman, Spokane, Tri-\nCities, and Vancouver campuses, although not all\nprograms are available at each site.\nThe teaching certificate will be awarded if the\nfollowing provisions are met:\n• The candidate provides evidence of good character\nand personal fitness to teach. Fingerprinting is\nrequired. A background investigation is conducted\nby the Washington State Patrol, the FBI, and Office\nof Professional Practices.\n• T h e d e g r e e i s a w a r d e d a n d t h e\nprofessional education program is satisfactorily\ncompleted following these guidelines:\n• All course work is taken for a letter grade where\noffered. Pass, Fail grading is not accepted except for\nfield experience courses.\n• The candidate has earned no grade lower than\nC (2.0) for professional course work, and course\nwork in the endorsements. The C minimum grade\nalso applies to general education, math, science,\nand social studies requirements in the elementary\nprogram.\n• The cumulative WSU GPA and the GPA computed\nseparately for professional course work and each\nendorsement is not less than 2.5.\n• The student has completed all work within five\nyears of admission to teacher education. Those not\nfinishing within this time limit will be subject to all\nnew program requirements.\n• The candidate has achieved a passing score\nor demonstrated basic skills on the statewide\nexaminations in basic skills (WEST-B, SAT, or ACT),\ncontent (WEST-E or NES).\n• The candidate has met the Professional\nDispositions Assessment standards.\nTransfer students entering an undergraduate\nor post-baccalaureate certificate program must\ncomplete at least fifty percent of the professional\neducation core, and, if preparing to teach at the\nelementary level, fifty percent of the elementary\nendorsement course work, plus student teaching\nat WSU. Transfer students and post-baccalaureate\napplicants should consult with an advisor regarding\nequivalency and transferability of course work.\nOpportunities are provided for teacher certificate\ncandidates to gain meaningful experiences by\nworking directly with and observing children in\nschool settings. It is WSU’s intent to place only\nthose individuals in K-12 classrooms that are able to\ndemonstrate a positive impact on student learning,\nand to insure that they possess those characteristics\ndesirable for working with children and young\npeople. The College of Education therefore reserves\nthe right to refuse placement of any student in a\nfield experience, or to terminate an individual’s\nplacement if in the professional judgment of the\nfaculty, the hosting school, or coordinating field\npersonnel there is cause for concern about the\nfitness of that individual to work with children\nin a classroom setting. The student teaching field\nplacement is arranged by the faculty with school\ndistricts contracted to provide experiences for WSU\nstudents. Students do not make their own student\nteaching placements. Student teaching must be\ncompleted at an approved WSU site in the state of\nWashington or internationally with supervision by\nan approved WSU provider.\nCertificate Renewal, Continuing\nCertificate, Add-On Endorsements\nhttps://education.wsu.edu/certification/\nInformation is available upon request from the\nCertification Coordinator, College of Education,\nPO Box 642114, Pullman, WA 99164-2114 (509)\n335-8146 or sbickel@wsu.edu.\nWSU PULLMAN/SPOKANE TEACHER\nCERTIFICATION\nInquiries and requests for program information\nshould be addressed to Office of Undergraduate\nStudent Services, College of Education, PO Box\n642152, Pullman WA 99164-2152 (509) 335-4855 or\nbeateacher@wsu.edu or visit our website at https://\neducation.wsu.edu/teachered/.\nWSU Pullman seeks to prepare the best possible\nteachers and therefore seeks highly qualified\nindividuals. Admission to, or continued enrollment\nin, the teacher education program may be denied a\ncandidate on the basis of review by the faculty. To\nprepare in elementary education the candidate shall\nsatisfy degree requirements of the Department of\nTeaching and Learning. To prepare in a single subject,\nthe candidate shall complete the baccalaureate\ndegree/teaching option offered through the subject\nmatter department. Single-subject endorsement\npreparation is available in Agriculture, Biology,\nChemistry, Earth and Space Science, English\nLanguage Arts, World Languages (French and\nSpanish), History, Family and Consumer Sciences,\nMathematics, Music, Physics, and Social Studies.\nAdd-on endorsements for pre-service teachers are\noffered in English Language Learners, Middle Level\nMath, Middle Level Science, and Special Education.\nCandidates holding single-subject endorsements\ntypically will be assigned to teach in grades 5-12\nexcept those endorsed in ELL, World Languages,\nMusic, or Special Education who are authorized\nto teach P-12. Specific course requirements for\nendorsements are listed in the subject matter of\nthe catalog. Endorsement requirements are subject\nto change by the Professional Educator Standards\nBoard.\nAdmission to Undergraduate and Post-\nBaccalaureate Teacher Education\nApplicants who meet the minimum requirements\nare eligible for consideration, but not assured\nadmission. Enrollment is limited and admission\ncompetitive. Admission deadlines are September\n30 and February 28 or 29 with admission effective\nthe following term. Candidates must complete\nformal admission procedures and be admitted to\nteacher education prior to taking any professional\neducation course work beyond TCH LRN 301 or 317.\nThe following minimum criteria must be met for\nconsideration for admission:\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n381\nMinimum Criteria\nContact Office of Undergraduate Student Services\nat 509-335-4855 or beateacher@wsu.edu for up-to-\ndate information.\n• Completion, within the last three years, of 80\nhours of supervised work with children 4 years\nof age or older in a supervised setting. Twenty of\nthese hours must be with students from diverse\npopulations or attending cultural events.\n• Basic skills proficiency in reading, writing,\nand mathematics. Students may use SAT, ACT,\nor WEST-B scores to demonstrate proficiency or\nrequest alternative means to meet the basic skills\nrequirement. For information go to: https://\neducation.wsu.edu/basicskillstesting.\n• Completion of at least 45 semester hours of post-\nsecondary course work.\n• Minimum WSU cumulative GPA of 2.50 for\nelementary and secondary applicants (transfer\nstudent GPA is based on WSU course work).\n• TCH LRN 301 and ENGLISH 201 graded C or\nbetter.\n• E l e m e n t a r y M a j o r s : H D 1 0 1 , M AT H\n251, and three of the four required UCORE science\ncourses, all graded C or better.\n• Secondary Majors: Nine hours of course work\nin the endorsement area. Admitted to major\ndepartment. Contact major department for\nadditional requirements.\n• Personal goal statement.\n• Interview.\nField Experiences and Student Teaching\nWashington State University requires background\nclearance for all students admitted into the\nundergraduate teacher education, Master in\nTeaching (MIT), and selected add-on endorsement\nprograms. Secondary single subject majors must\nmake application for student teaching one full\nacademic year prior to the actual student teaching\nsemester. Elementary majors make application for\nadvanced practicum placement one year prior to\nthe advanced practicum semester. Fingerprint and\nbackground clearance is required for enrollment in\nall practicum courses with the exception of TCH\nLRN 317. Application forms are distributed at an\norientation held each semester. An interview is\nrequired to begin student teaching. The following\ncourses are required field experiences:\nElementary majors enroll in TCH LRN 402,\nInstructional Practicum I (1 credit); TCH LRN 405,\nInstructional Practicum II (1 credit); TCH LRN 490,\nAdvanced Practicum (3 credits). Elementary majors\nenroll concurrently in the required practicum for\nthe appropriate block. TCH LRN 402 and 405\ninvolve participation in a school setting to apply\nconcepts learned in blocked courses. Practicum\nplacement and activities are arranged by the course\ninstructors and the Field Experience Office. TCH\nLRN 490 is an extended 5-week, full-time practicum\nin a school setting one semester prior to student\nteaching. Placement is arranged by the Department\nof Teaching and Learning. Secondary majors enroll\nin TCH LRN 317, Initial Practicum Experience\n(2 credits) and TCH LRN 469, Advanced Field\nExperience (2 credits). TCH LRN 317 is a three-week,\nfull-time experience completed in May at the end of\nthe sophomore year or prior to enrollment in Block I\nclasses, in a public or private school in the student’s\nhome community. TCH LRN 469 is an extended\n5-week, full-time practicum in a school setting\none semester prior to student teaching. Placement\nis arranged by the Department of Teaching\nand Learning. All practica involve observation,\nreflection, and practice in classrooms.\nTCH LRN 415, Student Teaching (16 credits), is\na semester of full-time teaching in a public school,\narranged by university personnel. Agricultural\nEducation, Family Consumer Sciences and Music\nmajors enroll concurrently in TCH LRN 415 and the\nappropriate student teaching course in the major.\nPrior to student teaching the certificate candidate\nwill: interview; satisfactorily complete all course\nwork for the degree and teacher certificate; obtain\na passing score on the content exam (NES, WEST-E,\nand/or ACTFL); receive fingerprinting clearance\nfrom the Washington State Patrol, the FBI, and the\nOffice of Professional Practices. Student teaching\nmust be completed at an approved WSU site in\nthe state of Washington or internationally with\nsupervision by university personnel.\nMIT 571 Pre-Internship (2 credits) requires\nsuccessful completion of MIT summer courses,\nenrollment in concurrent fall coursework and\nfinger printing clearance from the Washington\nState Patrol, the FBI and the Office of Professional\nPractices.\nMIT 575 Internship (10 credits) requires successful\ncompletion of MIT 571 and concurrent coursework,\nand a passing score on the NES, WEST-E, and/or\nACTFL content examination.\nThe Pre-Internship and Internship are arranged by\nuniversity personnel and must be completed at an\napproved WSU site in the state of Washington with\nsupervision by university personnel.\nMaster in Teaching (MIT)\nThe Master in Teaching degree program is a full-\ntime, field-based program leading to elementary\nor secondary teacher certification and a master’s\ndegree. Students in this program will complete\ncertification courses during the first 15 months\nof the program. With successful completion of\nthese requirements, students may opt to complete\nadditional research requirements for a master’s\ndegree. Applicants must have a bachelor’s degree\nfrom an accredited institution with a minimum\n3.0 cumulative GPA. Applications for Elementary\nEducation and Secondary Education must be\nsubmitted by November 15 for programs beginning\nthe following summer. All applicants must attempt\nan approved basic skills exam in reading, writing,\nand math to be considered for admission. Students\nmay use SAT, ACT, or WEST-B scores to meet the\nbasic skills requirement. If passing scores are not\nachieved, a bachelor’s degree from an accredited\ninstitution will fulfill the basic skills requirement.\nI n f o r m a t i o n a b o u t m i n i m u m a d m i s s i o n\nrequirements may be obtained from the College\nof Education Office of Graduate Studies 509-335-\n9195 or gradstudies@wsu.edu or https://education.\nwsu.edu/graduate. For additional information\nabout certification issues contact the Certification\nCoordinator at sbickel@wsu.edu or visit them online\nat https://education.wsu.edu/undergradprograms/\nteachered/certification/.\nCourse of Study for Elementary Education: KINES\n536, MIT 501, 502, 505, 507, 508, 511, 530, 531,\n532, 533, 534, 535, 571, 575, SPEC ED 520.\nCourse of Study for Secondary Education: MIT\n501, 502, 505, 506, 507, 508, 511, 550, 551, 552,\n571, 575, SPEC ED 520, TCH LRN 502 and an\nadditional 9 credits of graded course work.\nWSU PULLMAN/SPOKANE MASTERS’\nDEGREES (non-certification)\nMaster of Arts\nWSU Pullman offers Master of Arts degrees (M.A.)\nin the following areas: Curriculum and Instruction;\nLanguage, Literacy, and Technology Education;\nand/or Special Education. Students planning to add\nan endorsement to a Washington teacher certificate\nmust apply to WSU’s add-on endorsement program.\nThis thesis degree focuses on developing research\nand inquiry skills and other professional knowledge\nand skills in education and leadership and may\ninclude a concentration of coursework outside the\nDepartment of Teaching and Learning.\nMaster of Education Degree (Ed.M.)\nWSU Pullman/Spokane also offers a Master of\nEducation degree (Ed.M.) program specialization\nand/or endorsements in Curriculum and\nInstruction, Language, Literacy, and Technology\nEducation, and/or Special Education. Students\nplanning to add an endorsement to a Washington\nteacher certificate must apply to WSU’s add-on\nendorsement program. This non-thesis degree\nfocuses on developing K-12 teachers’ or other\nprofessionals’ knowledge and skills in education\nand leadership and may include a concentration\nof coursework outside the Department of Teaching\nand Learning.\nWSU PULLMAN/SPOKANE DOCTORAL\nPROGRAMS\nDoctor of Philosophy in Education (Ph.D.)\n(Pullman only) Specializations include Cultural\nStudies and Social Thought in Education,\nLanguage, Literacy and Technology, Mathematics\nand Science Education, and Special Education (see\nhttps://education.wsu.edu/graduate/ for program\ndescriptions and application procedures).\nWSU TRI-CITIES TEACHER\nCERTIFICATION\nhttps://education.wsu.edu/certification/\nhttp://tricities.wsu.edu/education\nInquiries and requests for application materials\nshould be addressed to WSU Tri-Cities, Department\nof Teaching and Learning, 2710 University Drive,\nRichland WA 99354-1671, (509) 372-7394.\nWSU Tri-Cities seeks to prepare the best possible\nteachers and therefore seeks highly qualified\nindividuals. Admission to, or continued enrollment\nin, the teacher education program may be denied\non the basis of review by the faculty.\nBachelor of Arts\nApplicants to the bachelor of arts program with\nelementary certification at the Tri-Cities campus\nwho meet the minimum requirements are eligible\nfor consideration, but not assured admission.\nEnrollment is limited and admission is competitive.\nThe admission deadline is March 1 with admission\neffective for Fall semester. Candidates must\ncomplete formal admission procedures and be\nadmitted to teacher education prior to taking any\nprofessional education coursework beyond TCH\nLRN 301. Applicants must meet the admission\ncriteria listed for WSU Pullman. TCH LRN 301 may\nnot be required for program admission by transfer\nstudents who are admitted to the program before\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n382\nthey begin taking classes at WSU. TCH LRN 301\nmust be taken in the first semester of the program\nby these students in order to remain eligible for the\nmajor.\nMaster in Teaching (MIT)\nThe Master in Teaching is a full-time, field-based\nprogram leading to elementary or secondary\ncertification and a master’s degree. Students in this\nprogram will complete certification courses during\nthe first 15 months of the program. With successful\ncompletion of these requirements, students may opt\nto complete additional research requirements for a\nmaster’s degree. Applicants must have a bachelor’s\ndegree from an accredited institution with a\nminimum 3.0 GPA in the last 60 semester hours of\ngraded course work, and submit the MIT application\nportfolio which is available from the WSU Tri-\nCities Education Department. All applicants must\nattempt an approved basic skills exam in reading,\nwriting and mathematics. Passing SAT, ACT, or\nWEST-B scores may be used to meet basic skills.\nIf passing scores are not achieved, a bachelor’s\ndegree from an accredited institution will fulfill\nthe basic skills requirement. Content proficiency\n(NES or WEST-E) is also required to be considered for\nadmission. Applications for Elementary Education\nand Secondary Education must be submitted by\nNovember 15 for programs beginning the following\nsummer.\nCourse of Study for Elementary Education: KINES\n536, MIT 501, 502, 505, 507, 508, 511, 530, 531,\n532, 533, 534, 535, 571, 575, SPEC ED 520.\nCourse of Study for Secondary Education: MIT\n501, 502, 505, 506, 507, 508, 511, 550, 551, 552,\n571, 575, SPEC ED 520, TCH LRN 502 and an\nadditional 9 credits of graded course work.\nMaster of Education (Ed.M.)\nWashington State University Tri-Cities offers\nthe Master of Education (Ed.M.) degree with\nspecializations in Curriculum and Instruction; and\nLanguage, Literacy, and Technology. The Ed.M. is a\nnon-thesis degree designed for educators wishing to\nextend their professional knowledge and enhance\ntheir competence as practitioners. Course credit\nalso may be used to meet continued certification\nrequirements or lead to a Special Education,\nBilingual Education, and/or English Language\nLearner endorsement. Students planning to add\nan endorsement to a Washington teacher certificate\nmust apply to WSU’s add-on endorsement program.\nFor additional information about certification issues\nplease contact the Department of Teaching and\nLearning, WSU Tri-Cities.\nWSU VANCOUVER TEACHER\nCERTIFICATION\nhttp://education.vancouver.wsu.edu/teacher-\ncertification-programs\nInquiries and requests for application materials for\nteacher certification programs should be addressed\nto WSU Vancouver, Education Department, 14024\nNE Salmon Creek Avenue, Vancouver WA 98686,\n(360) 546-9673, or by email at admissions@\nvancouver.wsu.edu.\nWSU Vancouver seeks to prepare the best\npossible teachers and therefore seeks highly\nqualified individuals for admission to the Bachelor\nof Arts in Education and the Master in Teaching\nprograms. Admission to, or continued enrollment\nin, a teacher education program may be denied a\ncandidate on the basis of review by the faculty. Field\nexperiences with accompanying seminars allow the\nintern-cooperating partners to engage in ongoing\ndialogue with university field personnel throughout\nthe year and are coordinated with academic work.\nBachelor of Arts in Education\nThis Teacher Education Program culminates in\na bachelor’s degree with elementary certification.\nThe program is designed for students who have a\ndirect transfer Associate of Arts degree or who have\ncompleted 60 semester hours of study and who have\nalso completed the required program prerequisites.\nStudents can obtain a list of the prerequisites by\ncontacting the Education Department at (360) 546-\n9673. All applicants must attempt an approved\nbasic skills exam in reading, writing, and math to\nbe considered for admission. Passing WEST-B, SAT\nor ACT scores may be used to meet basic skills. If\npassing scores are not achieved, a bachelor’s degree\nfrom an accredited institution will fulfill the basic\nskills requirement. Students must be admitted to\nboth WSU and the Teacher Education Program\nbefore beginning education classes. Students are\nadmitted and begin classes only during the summer\nsession.\nMaster in Teaching (MIT)\nThe Master in Teaching is a full-time, 15-18\nmonth field-based program leading to elementary\nor secondary certification and a master’s degree.\nApplicants must have a bachelor’s degree from an\naccredited institution with a minimum 3.0 GPA in\nthe last 60 semester hours of graded course work,\nand submit the MIT application portfolio which\nis available from the WSU Vancouver Education\nDepartment. All applicants must demonstrate\nproficiency or request alternative means to meet\nbasic skills requirements in reading, writing and\nmathematics (SAT, ACT, or WEST-B) and content\nproficiency (NES, WEST-E, and/or ACTFL) to be\nconsidered for admission. Applications are available\nin the summer and must be submitted by October 1\nfor secondary certification in order to be considered\nfor the program beginning in January; December\n1 is the deadline for application for elementary\ncertification in order to be considered for the\nprogram beginning the following May.\nCourse of Study for Elementary Education: KINES\n536, MIT 503, 504, 505, 506, 507, 509, 512, 530,\n531, 532, 533, 534, 535, 537, 571, 575, 702, SPEC\nED 520, TCH LRN 521.\nCourse of Study for Secondary Education: MIT\n502, 503, 504, 505, 506, 507, 510, 513, 551, 552,\n571, 575, 702, SPEC ED 520.\nWSU VANCOUVER IN SERVICE AND\nMASTERS’ DEGREE PROGRAMS (NON-\nCERTIFICATION)\nInquiries and requests for application materials\nshould be addressed to WSU Vancouver, Education\nDepartment, 14024 NE Salmon Creek Avenue,\nVancouver, WA 98686, (360) 546-9075, or by email\nat admissions@vancouver.wsu.edu.\nEndorsement Program\nWSU Vancouver is proud to offer a number of\nendorsements for certified teachers to add to their\ncredential. Use these endorsements to open new\ndoors of opportunity for you within your school\ndistrict or to help you gain employment for the\nfirst time. Some of our endorsements may be\nobtained in conjunction with a master’s degree.\nOthers are strictly “non-degree” endorsements.\nEndorsements offered as either non-degree or with\na Master of Education (Ed.M.): English Language\nLearners, Middle Level Mathematics, and Special\nEducation. Endorsements offered only as non-\ndegree: Biology, English/Language Arts, History,\nMathematics, and Social Studies.\nMaster of Education Degree (Ed.M.)\nWSU Vancouver also offers a Master of Education\ndegree (Ed.M.) program with course work leading\nto endorsements in Special Education, Middle Level\nMathematics, and/or English Language Learners for\neducators who already have a teaching certificate.\nThis non-thesis degree focuses on K-12 developing\nteachers’ or other professionals’ knowledge and\nskills in education and leadership.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nELEMENTARY EDUCATION TEACHER\nCERTIFICATE\n(128 HOURS)\nCandidates for the undergraduate elementary\neducation teacher certificate program will satisfy\ndegree requirements of the Department of Teaching\nand Learning. The degree will be the Bachelor of\nArts. The student should include the following\ncourse work within UCORE selections to satisfy\nprerequisite, degree, and admission to teacher\npreparation requirements. This course schedule\ndoes not include an add-on endorsement.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nH D 101 [SSCI] 3\nMATH 251 3\nMUS 153 [ARTS] or Arts [ARTS] 3\nScience Requirement\n1 \n4\nSecond Term Hours\nEndorsement Course\n2 \n3\nHISTORY 105 [ROOT] 3\nHISTORY 110 [HUM] or 111 [HUM] 3\nMATH 252 [QUAN] 3\nScience Requirement\n1 \n4\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nEndorsement Course\n2 \n3\nENGLISH 201 [WRTG], 301 [WRTG], or 402\n[WRTG] 3\nPOL S 101, ECONS 101, or ECONS 102 3\nScience Requirement\n1 \n4\nTCH LRN 301 3\nSecond Term Hours\nEndorsement Courses\n2 \n6\nHISTORY 120 [DIVR] 3\nScience Requirement\n1 \n4\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n383\nTCH LRN 307 3\nApply for admission to the major\nComplete Writing Portfolio\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nED PSYCH 401 3\nTCH LRN 320 or 321 3\nTCH LRN 352 3\nTCH LRN 402 1\nTCH LRN 445 2\nTCH LRN 483\n3 \n3\nSecond Term Hours\nEndorsement Course\n2 \n3\nSPEC ED 420 3\nTCH LRN 306 [M] or 322 [M] 3\nTCH LRN 310 [M] 2\nTCH LRN 371 3\nTCH LRN 405 1\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nEndorsement Course \n2 \n3\nTCH LRN 330 3\nTCH LRN 385 3\nTCH LRN 390 3\nTCH LRN 413 3\nTCH LRN 490 [CAPS] 3\nSecond Term Hours\nTCH LRN 415 16\n_______\n1 \nScience Requirement – choose one of two options:\nOption 1) SCIENCE 101 [PSCI] and 102 [BSCI], plus\ntwo from: ASTRONOM 135 [PSCI], BIOLOGY 102\n[BSCI] or 106 [BSCI], CHEM 101 [PSCI], PHYSICS\n101 [PSCI], SOE 101 [PSCI], or SOE 110 [BSCI];\nOption 2) SOE 101 [PSCI], and BIOLOGY 102\n[BSCI] or 106 [BSCI], plus two from: ASTRONOM\n135 [PSCI], CHEM 101 [PSCI], PHYSICS 101 [PSCI],\nSCIENCE 101 [PSCI], SCIENCE 102 [BSCI], or SOE\n110 [BSCI].\n2 \nEndorsement Courses: Students seeking a BA in\nElementary Education must complete at least 20\nsemester credits in an endorsable area. Some required\ncoursework may be applied to the endorsement\narea. See Specific Subject area requirements.\n3 \nTCH LRN 483 must be completed prior to the\nFourth Year.\nSPECIFIC SUBJECT TEACHER CERTIFICATE\nCandidates for specific subject certificates shall\ndeclare a major with the subject-matter department\nand meet the UCORE and degree requirements of\nthat department. Students completing subject-\nspecific endorsements will follow the Secondary\nProfessional Education Core: ED PSYCH 468, TCH\nLRN 301, 317, 464, 465, 466, 467, 469, 470 and 415\nunless admitted to the MIT program.\nIn addition to meeting requirements of the\ndegree-granting department, the student must\nmeet admission requirements and make formal\napplication to the teacher education program prior\nto enrolling in any professional education courses\nbeyond TCH LRN 301 and 317. It is recommended\nthat candidates begin professional education\ncourses in the sophomore or junior year to meet\nsequencing requirements. Students should include\nthe following courses within UCORE selections\nto fulfill prerequisite and admission to teacher\npreparation program requirements: ENGLISH 101\nand one of the following: ENGLISH 201, 301, 302,\nor 402. All courses taken for teacher certification\nmust be completed with a C (2.0) or better.\nSPECIFIC SUBJECT AREA\nREQUIREMENTS\nSchedules of Studies for specific subject\nteaching plans can be found in the subject\narea.\nAgricultural Education: AFS 101, 201, 401;\nANIM SCI 101; CROP SCI 360; CROP SCI/HORT\n102; ECONS 350 or 352; AG ED 407, 440, 450, 471;\nAGTM 201, 402; SOIL SCI 201; plus 9 additional\n300-400-level credits in agriculture system-based\nelectives selected with adviser approval; and 3\ncredits AFS core system elective. one from HISTORY 381,\n382, 483, SOC 430, or HONORS 390; MATH 140 or\n171; MBIOS 303, 304; PHYSICS 101 or 201, 102 or\n202; SCIENCE 430; STAT 212, 412 or PSYCH 311;\nplus an additional 7 credits 300-400-level CHEM\nincluding CHEM 331 or MBIOS 465, and at least 4\ncredits from CHEM 333, 335, 347, 398, 425, 426,\n495 or 499.\nDesignated World Languages French:\nFRENCH 204, 306, 307, 308, or 408; two from\nFRENCH 120, 320, 420; one from FRENCH 310, 350,\n361; FOR LANG 440, 441; approved internship in\nFrench or study abroad in Francophone country at\nthe advanced level.\nDesignated World Languages Spanish:\nSPANISH 204, 306, 307, 308, 407, 408; MATH 140 or 171; PHYSICS 101, 102; CHEM\n101 or 105, 102 or 106; BIOLOGY 106; SOE 311 or\nSOIL SCI 368; BIOLOGY 372 or SOE 300; SOE 312;\nSCIENCE 430; STAT 370 or 412; minimum of 19\ncredits from ASTRONOM 390, 435, 450, SOE 303,\n405, 470, 475, 498.\nEnglish Language Arts: ENGLISH 301 or 302;\none from ENGLISH 368, 371, 372, 470, 472, 480,\n481, 482; one from ENGLISH 332 (with advisor\napproval), 338 (with advisor approval), 366,\n370, 373, 419, 483, 484, 485, 486, 487, 488, 489;\nHUMANITY 303, 304, 335, 338, 350, 410, 450;\nENGLISH 305 or 306; one from ENGLISH 309,\n311 314, 315, 317, 321, 322, 332 (with advisor\napproval), 338 (with advisor approval), 341, 345,\n409; BIOLOGY 140; HBM\n258; H D 201, 202, 203, 204, 302, 310, 320, 350, 406,\n407, 410, 479, 480.\nHistory: ECONS 102; POL S 101; HISTORY 101,\n102, 110, 111, 120, 300, 422, 469, 480; one HISTORY\nfrom two separate categories: 1) 230 or 231, 2) 270\nor 271, 3) 272 or 273, 4) 275; one from HISTORY\n411, 413, 414, 415, 416; one from HISTORY 412,\n417, 418, 419; 6 credits 300-400-level HISTORY\nelectives which must include one European and\none global non-western course.\nMathematics: MATH 171, 172, 216, 220, 273,\n300, 301, 320 or 421, 330, 360, 398, 403, 431, 432;\nPHYSICS 201.\nMusic Education Endorsements General\nRequirements: Each endorsement below requires\nthe passing of a piano proficiency examination, an\nupper-division exam, a solo half-recital, a 2.5 GPA\nand a grade of C or better in all music courses. If the\nrequirements listed below along with the graduation\nrequirements of the College of Arts and Sciences are\nmet, the degree will be Bachelor of Music.\nMusic Education - Choral/Instrumental/\nGeneral Endorsement: MUS 164, 251, 252, 253,\n254, 351, 352, 353, 354, 359, 360, 361, 455, 480,\n482, 483, 487, 488, 489, 490, 491, 493, 494, 497.\nPerformance Studies: 14 credits of which 2 credits\nmust be at the 400-level. Include a minimum of 2\ncredits in choral and 2 credits in performing groups.\nPerformance Groups: 7 credits (minimum of 1 credit\nduring each of seven semesters) to include at least\none semester of MUS 435 for instrumentalists and\nMUS 428 for vocalists.\nMusic Education - Cho r a l / G e n e r a l\nEndorsement: MUS 164, 251, 252, 253, 254, 351,\n352, 353, 354, 359, 360, 361, 455, 480, 482, 483,\n488, 489, 490, 491, 497.
