Performance Studies:\n14 credits of which 2 credits must be at the 400 level.\nPerformance Groups: 7 credits (minimum of 1 credit\nduring each of seven semesters) to include at least 1\ncredit of MUS 435.\nPhysics: ASTRONOM 345; BIOLOGY 106; CHEM\n105, 106; one from HISTORY 381, 382, 483; SOC\n430, or HONORS 390; MATH 171, 172, 220, 273,\n315; PHYSICS 201 or 205, 202 or 206, 303, 304, 410,\n415 or 514; 499 (4 credits hours includes observing\nPHYSICS 101 and 102); SCIENCE 430; one from\nSTAT 212, 412 or PSYCH 311; two from PHYSICS\n320, 330, 341.\nSocial Studies: ECONS 102; HISTORY 101, 102,\n110, 111,120, 422, 480 and 12 credits of upper-\ndivision history electives w/advisor approval that\nmust include a non-western, a European, a U.S.\nHistory, and an elective; POL S 101; SOC 101; one\nfrom ANTH 101, 198, 203, 260; one from ECONS\n404, 428, 430; one HISTORY from two separate\ncategories: 1) 230 or 231, 2) 270 or 271, 3) 272 or\n273, 4) 275; one from HISTORY 319, 495, ANTH\n309; one from HISTORY 469, SOC 320; one from\nPOL S 300, 316, 427, 450, 455, CRM J 320; one from\nANTH 307, 316, 320, 330, 331, 350, PSYCH 310,\n324, 361, 470, SOC 320, 351, 384, 430.\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n384\nADD-ON ENDORSEMENTS\nAnyone wishing to add an endorsement to a valid\nWashington State teacher certificate must make\napplication to the WSU add-on endorsement\nprogram. The application and more information\ncan be found on the College of Education’s website\n(http://education.wsu.edu/studentservices/\nendorsements). The following endorsements are\navailable as add-on endorsements only. Individuals\nmay be recommended for endorsement in bilingual\neducation, English Language Learners, reading,\nmiddle level science, middle level mathematics,\nscience, or special education concurrently with\ncompletion of endorsement requirements in\nelementary education or one of the specific subject\nendorsements listed above, or as an endorsement\nadded to a currently valid teacher certificate.\nBilingual Education: TCH LRN 333, 410, or\n510; 339 or 549; 401 or 501; 409 or 509; 411; 413,\n414, or 514; one from ENGLISH 256, TCH LRN 330,\n404, 504 (highly recommended), 512, 516, 537,\n574, 580. Demonstrated proficiency in a language\nother than English by passing the oral and written\nproficiency tests of the American Council on the\nTeaching of Foreign Language (ACTFL) at the\nadvance mid-level.\nEnglish Language Learners [undergraduate\ncourses]: TCH LRN 333, 339, 401, 413 or 414, and\n409. One from ENGLISH 256, TCH LRN 330, 404,\n504 (highly recommended), 512, 516, 537, 574, 580.\nEnglish Language Learners [graduate\ncourses]: TCH LRN 501, 509, 510, 514, 549;\none from TCH LRN 512, 516, 504, (highly\nrecommended), 537, 574 or 580.\nMiddle Level Math: MATH 106, 252, 303,\n351; TCH LRN 433 or 533, 434 or 534, approved\nprobability and statistics course.\nMiddle Level Science: BIOLOGY 106, 107,\nBIOLOGY/TCH LRN 430, CHEM 101, PHYSICS 150,\nSCIENCE 101, 102, SOE 101.\nReading [graduate courses]: TCH LRN 528,\n537, 544, 546, 551, 553, 558.\nS p e c i a l E d u c a t i o n [ u n d e r g r a d u a t e\ncourses]: SPEC ED 301, 401, 402, 403, 404, 409,\n421, 440, 471, 490 or 499 (4 credits).\nSpecial Education [graduate courses]: SPEC\nED 301, 501, 502, 503, 504, 509, 521, 540, 571, 590\nor 499 (4 credits).\nCertificates\nCertificate in Education\nTechnology\nThe WSU College of Education undergraduate\ncertificate in Education Technology allows students\nto develop skills and obtain documentation that will\nhelp them obtain positions that require knowledge\nof and experience with education technology.\nThe course work comprises 15 credits that address\nInternational Society for Technology in Education\n(ISTE), TESOL, and disciplinary standards, and it\nfocuses on developing knowledge and skills for\nworking with diverse students and communities.\nThe required course work emphasizes research,\ntheoretical, and practical issues concerning effective\nuses and affordances of technologies and the\nimplementation of appropriate classroom teaching\ntechniques.\nTo earn the certificate, students must complete\n12 credits of required course work and one elective\nfor a total of 15 credits. Required courses include:\nTCH LRN 445 or 466; 416, 417, 419; and 1 credit of\nTCH LRN 499. Approved elective courses include\nDTC 201, 206, 354, ENGLISH 342 and SPEC ED 495,\nor as approved by department. The prerequisite for\nTCH LRN 445 and 466 is admission to the teacher\neducation program or an undergraduate program in\nthe College of Education or status as an in-service\nteacher/teacher education program graduate.\nTCH LRN 445 or 466 are prerequisites for all other\nrequired TCH LRN courses.\nEnglish Language Learners\nThe Certificate in English Language Learners\nrequires a minimum of 18 hours. The 15 hour core\nis: TCH_LRN 333, 339, 401, 409, 413/414. 3 hours\nof electives are selected from TCH_LRN 404, 519,\n516, or courses in other programs that are approved\nby the ELL Program Coordinator. A grade of C or\nbetter must be earned in all classes that apply\ntowards this certificate. Few of the courses required\nfor this certificate have prerequisites, but teaching\nexperience or education classes are recommended.\nDescription of Courses\nCULTURAL STUDIES AND SOCIAL\nTHOUGHT IN EDUCATION\nCSSTE\n530 Readings in Cultural Studies and Social\nThought in Education 1 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 3 hours.\nCurrent scholarship in the field of cultural\nstudies in education and practices of schools.\n531 Cultural Studies in Education 3 Historical\nand conceptual background of the field of\ncultural studies.\n532 Gender, Power, and Education 3\nInterdisciplinary focus on the relationships\namong gender, power, and education.\n533 Race, Identity, and Representation in\nEducation 3 Interdisciplinary research in\nrace, identity and representations in education.\n534 Social Theory in Education 3 Social\ntheory and how it applies to intellectual work\nin education. Recommended preparation:\nAdmission to a doctoral program.\n535 Multicultural Education in a Global\nSociety 3 Multicultural and multilingual\neducation from a global perspective;\ndevelopment of multicultural curriculum.\n(Crosslisted course offered as TCH LRN 580,\nCSSTE 535, MIT 552). Credit not granted for\nboth TCH LRN 480 and TCH LRN 580.\n536 Environment, Culture and Education\n3 Role of education in the social, ecological,\nand political conflicts between culture and\nenvironment.\n537 Place-Based Education 3 Theory and\npractice of place-based education with an\nemphasis on community-based action research\nand curriculum planning.\n538 Youth Cultures in Education 3 Analysis of\nhow youth cultures operate in society and how\nthey are practiced in schools.\n539 Curriculum Theory 3 Curriculum theory\nas the interdisciplinary study of educational\nexperience. (Crosslisted course offered as TCH\nLRN 577, CSSTE 539).\n540 Globalization and Identity in Education\n3 Issues relating to the complexities of\nglobalization and identity in education.\n544 Discourse Analysis 3 Course Prerequisite:\nED RES 562; ED RES 564. Examination of and\npreparation for discourse analysis research\napproach.\n545 Critical Ethnography in Education 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ED RES 562; ED RES 564.\nIn-depth focus on issues in qualitative research\nand ethnography and critical ethnography.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted\nto Cultural Studies and Social Thought in\nEducation PhD program. Independent research\nand advanced study for students working on\ntheir doctoral research, dissertation and/or final\nexamination. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nLANGUAGE, LITERACY, AND\nTECHNOLOGY\nLLT\n586 Seminar in Language, Literacy, and\nTechnology 1 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 3 hours. Tools for\nprofessional development in the areas of\nresearch, teaching, and service. Seminar\ncompliments required courses in the LLT\ndoctoral student program.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated\nfor credit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted\nto the Language, Literacy, and Technology\nPhD program. Independent research and\nadvanced study for students working on their\ndoctoral research, dissertation and/or final\nexamination. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nMASTER IN TEACHING\nMIT\n501 Learning and Development in School\nand Community Contexts 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to MIT Program.\nTheories of learning and student development\nwithin school and community contexts.\n502 Assessment for Teaching and Learning\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to MIT\nProgram. Instruction in sound assessment\npractices for preservice and in-service graduate\nstudents.\n503 Theories of Learning and Development\nV 2-3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to\nMIT Program. Theories of learning and\ndevelopment for K-12 teaching.\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n385\n504 Social Foundations of Education\nfor Teachers V 2-3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to MIT Program. The social context\nof American education including historical and\ncontemporary influences; education in the\ncontext of history, politics, and society.\n505 Classroom Management Seminar 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admission to MIT\nProgram. Contemporary issues in management\nof elementary, middle school, and secondary\nclassrooms; issues of abuse.\n506 Integrating Technology into Classroom\nTeaching V 2-3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to MIT Program. Exploration\nof technology use in schools, production\ntechniques, instructional methods, and\nintegration of technology into grade-level\ncurriculum based on current technology\nstandards.\n507 Teacher Inquiry and Praxis V 2-3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to MIT Program.\nExploration and development of teacher\nresearch strategies; concepts for producing\nknowledge and empowerment enabling\nteachers to challenge social norms that\nperpetuate inequality and marginalization.\n508 Curriculum and Instruction Methods\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to MIT\nProgram. Development of curriculum and\ninstructional methods for teaching in diverse\nK-12 classrooms.\n509 I n s t r u c t i o n a n d A s s e s s m e n t f o r\nElementary Teachers 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to MIT Program. Knowledge, skills,\nand dispositions that support continuous\nimprovement in teaching and learning.\n510 Instruction for Secondary Teachers 3\nCourse Prerequisite: Admission to MIT Program.\nMethods of improvement in education, with\nemphasis on teacher collaboration, classroom\ninstruction, and school reform.\n511 Methods for Teaching English Language\nLearners, K-12 2 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to MIT Program. Research-based ESL\nstrategies, methods, and practical knowledge\nthat pre-service teachers can apply in a variety\nof instructional contexts to insure the success\nof minority students from diverse linguistic\nand cultural backgrounds.\n512 ESL Methods for General Educators\n(K-8) 2 Course Prerequisite: Admission to\nMIT Program. Research-based ESL strategies\nand methods for pre-service and experienced\nteachers.\n513 E S L M e t h o d s a n d M a t e r i a l s f o r\nSecondary Teachers 2 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to MIT Program. Research-based\nESL strategies and methods for pre-service and\nsecondary content area teachers.\n530 Elementary School Social Studies\nMethods 3 Course Prerequisite: Admission\nto MIT Program. For candidates admitted to\ngraduate teacher preparation and experienced\nteachers. Elementary structures of various\nsocial sciences; research findings related\nto instruction; classroom applications and\nmaterials.\n531 Literacy Development I 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to MIT Program.\nFor candidates admitted to graduate teacher\npreparation. Review of current research and\napproaches to instruction in the development\nof literacy in elementary and middle grades.\n532 Literacy Development II 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to MIT Program.\nReview of current research and approaches to\ninstruction in the development of literacy in\nelementary and middle grades.\n533 E l e m e n t a r y S c h o o l M a t h e m a t i c s\nMethods 3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to\nMIT Program. Introduction to research, theory,\nand methods of teaching K-8 mathematics;\nemphasis on integrating theory and practice.\n534 Elementary School Science Methods\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to MIT\nProgram. Theoretical base to design and\nimplement appropriate standards-based\nelementary science instruction.\n535 I n t e g r a t i n g F i n e A r t s i n t o K - 8\nCurriculum 2 Course Prerequisite: Admission\nto MIT Program. Integrating Fine Arts (art,\nmusic, dance, drama) into K-8 curriculum;\ncurriculum design and methods.\n537 P r o b l e m S o l v i n g i n E l e m e n t a r y\nMathematics 1 (0-2) Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to MIT Program. Supplemental\npracticum course for MIT 533 that affords pre-\nservice elementary teachers opportunity to\ndiscuss mathematical problem solving in great\ndetail: theoretically, by looking at samples\nof children’s mathematical solutions, and\nengaging in mathematical problem solving.\n550 Seminar in Middle Level Education\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to MIT\nProgram. Research on organizational structures,\ncurriculum, instructional approaches, and\nmaterials for contemporary middle grade\nschools.\n551 Literacy within the Disciplines 3 Explores\nliteracy research and practices that enhance the\nlearning of various disciplines taught in K-12\nsettings. (Crosslisted course offered as TCH\nLRN 528, MIT 551). Credit not allowed for\nstudents who have earned credit for TCH LRN\n428.\n552 Multicultural Education in a Global\nSociety 3 Multicultural and multilingual\neducation from a global perspective;\ndevelopment of multicultural curriculum.\n(Crosslisted course offered as TCH LRN 580,\nCSSTE 535, MIT 552). Credit not granted for\nboth TCH LRN 480 and TCH LRN 580.\n571 Pre-internship and Seminar 2 (1-3) May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n4 hours. Course Prerequisite: Admission to\nMIT Program. Instructional practice in diverse\nclassroom settings and reflection on that\npractice. S, F grading.\n575 Internship and Seminar 10 (1-27) Course\nPrerequisite: MIT 571; admission to MIT\nProgram. Instructional practice in classroom\nsettings, reflection on practice; completion of\nWashington state licensure requirements for\nteacher certification. S, F grading.\n702 Master’s Special Problems, Directed\nStudy, and/or Examination V 1-18 May\nbe repeated for credit. Independent research\nin special problems, directed study, and/or\nexamination credit for students in a non-thesis\nmaster’s degree program. Students must have\ngraduate degree-seeking status and should\ncheck with their major advisor/committee\nchair before enrolling for 702 credit. S, U\ngrading.\nMATHEMATICS / SCIENCE EDUCATION\nED MTHSC\n598 Research Seminar in Mathematics and\nScience Education 1 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 6 hours. Through\ntargeted readings and discussion, students will\ndevelop knowledge base proficiencies related\nto areas of mathematics and science education.\n800 Doctoral Research, Dissertation, and/\nor Examination V 1-18 May be repeated for\ncredit. Course Prerequisite: Admitted to the\nMathematics/Science Education PhD program.\nIndependent research and advanced study for\nstudents working on their doctoral research,\ndissertation and/or final examination.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor/committee chair before enrolling for\n800 credit. S, U grading.\nSPECIAL EDUCATION\nSPEC ED\n301 Education of Exceptional Children 3\nSurvey of characteristics of students with\ndisabilities, and overview of programming,\nlegal aspects, and methods of instruction.\n401 Teaching Students with Disabilities\n3 Course Prerequisite: SPEC ED 301 or\nconcurrent enrollment, or SPEC ED 420 or\nconcurrent enrollment. Intervention and\ninstructional strategies for managing academic,\nsocial, and behavior problems in classroom\nsettings. Credit not granted for both SPEC ED\n401 and SPEC ED 501. Required preparation\nmust include completion of an introductory\nspecial education course, or SPEC ED 520.\n402 Assessment and Curriculum for Students\nwith Disabilities 3 Course Prerequisite: SPEC\nED 301 or concurrent enrollment. Methods of\nindividual and group, formal and informal\nassessment for students with disabilities. Credit\nnot granted for both SPEC ED 402 and SPEC ED\n502. Graduate level required preparation must\ninclude completion of an introductory special\neducation course, or SPEC ED 520; SPEC ED\n504; concurrent enrollment SPEC ED 590 (2\ncredits).\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n386\n403 Secondary Education for Students with\nDisabilities 3 Course Prerequisite: SPEC\nED 301 or concurrent enrollment, or SPEC\nED 420 or concurrent enrollment. Overview\nof instruction and intervention strategies\nfor secondary students with disabilities;\nassessment, and curriculum/program\ndevelopment. Credit not granted for both SPEC\nED 403 and SPEC ED 503. Credit not granted for both TCH\nLRN 434 and 534.\n537 Seminar in Language, Literacy, and\nCulture 3 Interrelationships between schools,\nliteracy, and student cultural background.\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n390\n538 Writing Across the Curriculum 3 Writing\nfor learning at grade levels K-12.\n539 Innovations in Language Arts 3 The\nmost recent developments in language arts\ninstruction for pre-service and in-service\nteachers K-12.\n541 Teacher Professional Certification: Pre-\nAssessment Seminar V 1-3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nCandidates evaluate current teaching against\nstandards to determine steps for professional\ngrowth plans which measure positive impact\non student learning.\n542 Teacher Professional Certification:\nResearching Exemplary Practices V\n1-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. Teachers will apply\nexemplary practices, continue to assess their\nperformance and college evidence of positive\nimpact on student learning.\n543 Teacher Professional Certification:\nCulminating Seminar V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Candidates will complete ProCert\nrequirements to document positive impact on\nstudents’ learning: set new goals; learn about\nNational Board options.\n544 Teaching Children’s and Young Adult\nLiterature 3 Trends, issues, and research in\nchildren’s and young adult literature.\n546 Teaching Writing 3 Enrollment not allowed\nif credit already earned for TCH LRN 446.\nTheory and research relevant to instructional\napproaches and practices for teaching writing\nin K-12 schools. Credit not allowed for students\nwho have earned credit for TCH LRN 446.\n547 Teaching Folk Literature to Children\nand Adolescents 3 Folk literature as a genre\nin child and adolescent literature; curriculum\napplications; reading, language development,\nsocial studies, creative expression.\n548 Teaching Adolescent Literature 3\nEvaluating, selecting, and using literature for\nmiddle school and teenage students.\n549 Communicating in a Multilingual\nSociety 3 Study of language in social and\neducational context and its relation to cultural\nand linguistic diversity. Recommended\npreparation: TCH LRN 510.\n550 Second Language Learning and Literacy\n3 Course Prerequisite: Admission to a graduate\nprogram. Research on second language\nteaching and learning in literacy education\nwith a focus on English language learners in\nUS schools.\n551 Psychology of Reading 3 Enrollment not\nallowed if credit already earned for TCH LRN\n441. Psychological, perceptual, motivational,\ndevelopmental and physiological aspects of\nreading. Credit not allowed for students who\nhave earned credit for TCH LRN 441.\n553 Assessment and Instruction for Reading\n4 (3-3) Enrollment not allowed if credit\nalready earned for TCH LRN 443. Evaluation\ntechniques and instructional practices for\nimpacting the reading achievement of K-12\nstudents. Credit not allowed for students who\nhave earned credit for TCH LRN 443.\n554 Sociolinguistics 3 Interaction between\nlanguage use and sociopolitical and cultural\ncontexts; cultural and linguistic delivery and\neducational opportunity. Recommended\npreparation: TCH LRN 504.\n555 Seminar in Literacy Development 3 May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n6 hours. Current and historical research in\nreading/language arts, infancy through college\nand adult years; papers presented by faculty,\ninvited speakers, and students.\n557 Research in Reading 3 Exploration of\nqualitative and quantitative reading research\ncovering topics of current and historical\nimportance.\n558 Improving Reading Comprehension (K-\n12) 3 Enrollment not allowed if credit already\nearned for TCH LRN 448. Key theoretical\nconcepts and their implications for improved\ncomprehension instruction, for K-12. Credit\nnot allowed for students who have earned\ncredit for TCH LRN 448.\n560 Research in Teaching 3 May be repeated\nfor credit; cumulative maximum 6 hours.\nRecent developments in research on teaching;\nboth quantitative and qualitative research\nmethodologies emphasized.\n561 Elementary School Mathematics 3\nResearch on curriculum and instruction issues\nin elementary school mathematics.\n562 Foundations of Literacy: Theory and\nResearch 3 Interdisciplinary inquiry into the\nvarious foundations of literacy.\n563 Teaching Concepts of Probability and\nStatistics 3 Development of mathematical\nconcepts and related teaching strategies for\nprobability and statistics, with an emphasis\non middle school topics. Credit not granted\nfor both TCH LRN 463 and 563.\n565 Introduction to Scholarly Inquiry 1\nIntroduction to the Ed.M program including\nthe scholarship and research requirements and\nthe role of students and action research.\n566 Democratic Education 3 Rationale and skill\nto assist teachers in making classrooms more\ndemocratic.\n567 Social Foundations of Language and\nLiteracy 3 Social and cultural theories\nof language and literacy. Recommended\npreparation: Admission to a doctoral program.\n568 Psychological Foundations of Language\nand Literacy 3 Psychological foundations\nof language and Literacy. Recommended\npreparation: Admission to a doctoral program.\n569 Critical Analysis of Children’s and\nYoung Adult Literature 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Admission to a graduate program.\nMulticultural analysis of children’s and\nadolescent literature and its pedagogical and\nsociopolitical implications and possibilities.\n570 T h e o r y a n d R e s e a r c h i n D i g i t a l\nLiteracies 3 Ideas of literacy and effects of\ntechnology on literacy and policy, particularly\nthose issues addressing diverse learners.\n571 R e s e a r c h i n S T E M E d u c a t i o n 3\nContemporary issues in STEM education\nresearch and practice.\n573 Theory and Research in Computer-\nAssisted Language Learning 3 Information\nand tools needed to contribute to the CALL\nresearch literature.\n574 Science for All: An Individual and\nMulticultural Perspective 3 Implications\nof cultural and individual diversity for\nunderstanding western scientific and\nmathematical thought; an activity-based,\neducational perspective.\n577 Curriculum Theory 3 Curriculum theory\nas the interdisciplinary study of educational\nexperience. (Crosslisted course offered as TCH\nLRN 577, CSSTE 539).\n578 National Board for Professional\nTeaching Standards (NBPTS) I 3\nDevelopment of evidence aligned with\nNational Board standards and allowance for\nreflection on the impact of teaching and\nstudent learning. Required background must\ninclude: Bachelor’s degree from accredited\ninstitution, valid state teaching/counseling\ncertificate, completion of minimum 3 years\nsuccessful full-time teaching in a U.S. P-12\nschool.\n579 National Board for Professional\nTeaching Standards (NBPTS) II 3\nConstruct/submit portfolio of evidence\nmeeting national standards in classrooms\nfor National Board Certification assessment.\nRequired background must include: Bachelor’s\ndegree from accredited institution, valid state\nteaching/counseling certificate, completion of\nminimum 3 years successful full-time teaching\nin a U.S. P-12 school.\n580 Multicultural Education in a Global\nSociety 3 Multicultural and multilingual\neducation from a global perspective;\ndevelopment of multicultural curriculum.\n(Crosslisted course offered as TCH LRN 580,\nCSSTE 535, MIT 552). Credit not granted for\nboth TCH LRN 480 and TCH LRN 580.\n581 L e a r n i n g a n d D e v e l o p m e n t i n\nMathematics and Science 3 This course\nexplores and illustrates what we know about\nvarious aspects of mathematical learning at\nvarious grade levels.\n582 Scholarly Writing 3 Interdisciplinary;\nsupports students to write publication-quality\nmanuscripts.\n583 Problem Solving in Elementary and\nMiddle Level Education 3 Course\nPrerequisite: For candidates admitted to MIT.\nIntegration of knowledge and skills to address\ncomplex cases in teaching and learning.\n584 Research in Teaching Mathematics and\nScience 3 Development of an understanding\nfor the research literature that is particularly\nrelated to mathematics and science teaching.\n585 Focused Reading and Conference in\nMath/Science Education V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 9\nhours. Designed to foster ongoing scholarship\nfor individuals interested in mathematics and/\nor science educational research.\nTeaching and Learning\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n391\n588 Action Research: Teachers as Research 3\nTheoretical concepts, research, issues, models,\nand strategies for implementation of action\nresearch.\n590 Internship V 2-6 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 12 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: By interview only. Opportunities\nin professional positions. S, F grading.\n591 Research Internship in Math/Science\nEducation V 2-3 May be repeated for credit;\ncumulative maximum 6 hours. Independent\nstudy, special projects, and/or internships.\nStudents must have graduate degree-seeking\nstatus and should check with their major\nadvisor before enrolling in 600 credit, which\ncannot be used toward the core graded credits\nrequired for a graduate degree. Students must have graduate\ndegree-seeking status and should check with\ntheir major advisor/committee chair before\nenrolling for 800 credit. S, U grading.\nCollege of Veterinary\nMedicine\ndvm.vetmed.wsu.edu/\nBustad 110\n509-335-1532\nThe College of Veterinary Medicine offers courses of\nstudy leading to the degrees of Doctor of Veterinary\nMedicine (DVM), Master of Science, and Doctor of\nPhilosophy. Additional information, including\nrequirements for admission, is contained in the\ngeneral information section of this catalog.\nThe professional DVM program offered by the\nCollege of Veterinary Medicine at Washington\nState University is accredited by the Council on\nEducation of the American Veterinary Medical\nAssociation.\nDOCTOR OF VETERINARY MEDICINE\nPROGRAM REQUIREMENTS\nA minimum of seven years is generally necessary\nto obtain the degree of Doctor of Veterinary\nMedicine (DVM). Most successful applicants have\ncompleted three to four years of undergraduate\neducation. Following undergraduate studies, a\nstudent then takes four years of professional study\ndirected by the College of Veterinary Medicine.\nApplicants for admission to the College of\nVeterinary Medicine must present at least 64\nsemester credits of acceptable prerequisite credits\nfrom an accredited college or university. The 64\nsemesters should include: 36 credits of science\nand math prerequisites, including general biology,\ninorganic and organic chemistry, biochemistry,\nphysics, mathematics, genetics, and statistics; and\n27 credits of University Common Requirements\n(UCORE): 21 credits of social science, arts and\nhumanities, history, diversity studies, language,\netc.; and 6 credits of English composition and\ncommunication (written or verbal). Non-\ncognitive criteria for admission include clinical,\nanimal, employment, volunteer, and research\nexperience, honors, awards, and scholarships,\nextracurricular activities, community service, letters\nof recommendation, personal statements, and a\npersonal interview.\nCourses designed to fit the academic requirements\nare offered by Washington State University, and\nthe number of students admitted to undergraduate\ncourses is not limited. Because the number of\napplicants for admission to the DVM program\nexceeds the number that can be admitted, no\nassurance can be given that all applicants who\nsuccessfully complete the undergraduate curriculum\nwill be admitted. WSU does not grant a BS in pre-\nveterinary medicine. Students taking pre-veterinary\ncourse work may declare a major in any subject.\nMany successful applicants major in animal science,\nbiology, chemistry, microbiology, neuroscience,\nwildlife ecology, zoology, or other science-related\nfields.\nA major in veterinary medicine is not declared\nuntil admission to the College of Veterinary\nMedicine has been granted.\nInformation regarding the acceptability of course\ncredits should be obtained from the Office of\nStudent Services, College of Veterinary Medicine.\nADMISSION TO THE DVM PROGRAM\nA student seeking to enter the professional DVM\nprogram should fill out a Veterinary Medical College\nApplication Service (VMCAS) application at http://\nwww.aavmc.org/Students-Applicants-and-Advisors/\nVeterinary-Medical-College-Application-Service.\naspx) designating WSU as a school of choice and\nanswering the supplemental questions. Please see\nhttp://dvm.vetmed.wsu.edu for further application\ninformation. The Admissions Committee selects\nthose students to be admitted to the first year of\nthe professional DVM program. Applicants will be\nnotified of their acceptance on or before April 15th.\nUnsuccessful applicants who wish to be considered\nthe next year must present new applications.\nIn accordance with policies adopted by the\nBoard of Regents, preference for admission to\nthe professional DVM program in the College of\nVeterinary Medicine is as follows:\n• To qualified applicants who are certified and\nfinanced as residents of Washington, Idaho,\nMontana, or Utah.\n• To qualified applicants certified and financed\nby the Western Interstate Commission for Higher\nEducation (WICHE) contract states\n• To all other qualified applicants\nPRE-ADMITTANCE PROGRAMS\nA highly selective program for admission of\nacademically qualified students to the DVM\nprogram at Washington State University College of\nVeterinary Medicine has been established with the\nWSU Honors College. This program conditionally\nadmits successful applicants directly to the program\nupon completion of one year of undergraduate\nwork at WSU. This is a pre-admit program leading\nto the Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree after\nsatisfactory completion of a designed curriculum.\nIt consists of three years of a unique undergraduate\npre-professional education and the four-year\nprofessional DVM program. The first three years of\nthis program are a combination of Honors College\ncourses and regular University classes which fulfill\nthe pre-veterinary requirements plus the completion\nof an honors thesis. The last four years are the\ntraditional Doctor of Veterinary Medicine program.\nInterested students should identify themselves to\nthe Honors College as soon as they decide to enter\nWSU, because the number of positions is limited.\nFor the Combined Program in Animal Sciences\nand Veterinary Medicine - See Department of\nAnimal Sciences.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nDOCTOR OF VETERINARY MEDICINE\n(DVM) CURRICULUM\n(153 HOURS)\nThe professional curriculum for the Doctor of\nVeterinary Medicine degree is outlined below. A total\nof 154 semester hours are required for graduation.\nAll courses required in the professional program are\n500-600-level professional courses.\nFourth Year: The fourth year begins immediately\nafter the end of the spring semester of the third year\nVeterinary Medicine\nWashington State University, 2021\n\n392\n(May) and continues for 12 consecutive months.\nFourth-year professional students are required to\nenroll in course work for a minimum of 44 credits\nin their final year. All students must participate in\nmandatory clinical rotations in the large- and small-\nanimal clinics, including emergency services and\nanesthesia. In addition, each student must select\nelective opportunities in their area of interest. All\nstudents must prepare and present a senior paper\nunder faculty supervision.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nVET MED 510 4\nVET MED 511 5\nVET MED 513 4\nVET MED 568 2\nVET MED 586 1\nSecond Term Hours\nVET MED 512 4\nVET MED 520 5\nVET MED 521 3\nVET MED 534 3\nVET MED 545 3\nVET MED 580 1\nSecond Year\nFirst Term Hours\nVET MED 522 3\nVET MED 535 3\nVET MED 536 4\nVET MED 546 6\nVET MED 589 3\nSecond Term Hours\nVET MED 523 3\nVET MED 537 4\nVET MED 543 2\nVET MED 561 2\nVET MED 576 1\nVET MED 585 2\nVET MED 587 2\nVET MED 588 3\nThird Year\nFirst Term Hours\nVET MED 502 1\nVET MED 524 3\nVET MED 551 5\nVET MED 553 3\nVET MED 554 1\nVET MED 569 4\nVET MED 578 3\nSecond Term Hours\nVET MED 500 1\nVET MED 552 3\nVET MED 570 3\nVET MED 571 3\nVET MED 572 2\nVET MED 575 1\nVET MED 590 1\nVET MED 596 1\nVET MED 598 1\nFourth Year\nFirst Term Hours\nEquine Elective\n1 \n2\nMedicine Elective\n2 \n4\nSupplemental Electives\n3 \n14\nSurgery Elective\n4 \n2\nVET MED 600 1\nVET MED 605 2\nVET MED 606 2\nVET MED 607 2\nSecond Term Hours\nVET MED 650 3\nVET MED 656 2\nVET MED 674 1\nVET MED 675 2\nVET MED 690 2\nVET MED 691 4\nVET MED 699 1\n_______\n1 \nSelect one from VET MED 628 or 629.\n2 \nSelect two from VET MED 609, 620, or 621.\n3 \nCourses to be chosen in consultation with advisor,\nApproved courses include 600-level VET MED\ncourses. Philosophy\nand history of methodological, ethical and\npolitical issues relevant to biomedical research\nusing selected monographs and essays. May\nbe repeated for credit; cumulative maximum\n3 hours. S, M, F grading.\n510 Veterinary Microscopic Anatomy 4 (3-\n3) Course Prerequisite: Veterinary Medicine\nstudent. S, M, F grading.\n511 Veterinary Anatomy I 5 (0-15) Course\nPrerequisite: Veterinary Medicine student.\nDetailed macroscopic functional morphology\nof the dog with comparison to other domestic\nanimals; developmental anatomy of selected\norgan systems. S, M, F grading.\n512 Veterinary Anatomy II 4 (1-9) Course\nPrerequisite: VET MED 511. Detailed\nmacroscopic functional morphology of\ndomestic animals. S, M, F grading.\n513 Veterinar y Physiology I 4 Course\nPrerequisite: Veterinary Medicine student. Cooperative: Open to UI\ndegree-seeking students. Tannler.\nThe PhD and MS programs in Veterinary Clinical\nSciences provide education and training in\nbiomedical science with an emphasis on Veterinary\nMedicine and applications to clinical medicine.\nWashington State University, 2021\nVeterinary Clinical Sciences\n\n396\nThe research environment includes faculty with\nboth clinical and basic research interests and\nprovides a unique environment for application\nof fundamental biomedical principles to solving\nimportant clinical problems. The Clinical Sciences\ngraduate group offers MS and PhD programs\nfocused on training scientists to have broad\nexpertise in appropriate concepts, theories, and\nemerging methods to effectively conduct research\nacross the disciplines represented in Veterinary\nClinical Sciences. To fully understand “health”\nand appropriate interventions at population and\nindividual levels through studies ranging from the\nmolecular (genetics, pharmacogenetics, molecular\nepidemiology, bacterial genome characterization),\ncellular (mechanisms of tumor cell resistances),\nsystems (orthopedics, theriogenology), mechanism\nof disease (oncology, neurology), populations\n(epidemiology, gene flow within populations,\ndisease rates), and evaluation of disease\ninterventions (clinical trials, observational studies).\nThe MS program may also be paired with advanced\nclinical training where the student participates in\npost-DVM clinical training with the goal of specialty\nboard certification enhanced by training in clinical\nresearch methods.\nDescription of Courses\nVETERINARY CLINICAL MEDICINE AND\nSURGERY\nVET CLIN\n361 Agricultural Animal Health 3 Course\nPrerequisite: One ANIM SCI or BIOLOGY\ncourse. Introduction to basic concepts of\ninfectious, noninfectious, and parasitic\ndiseases of animals of agricultural and public\nhealth importance.\n367 Medical and Surgical Problems in the\nHorse 3 Basic health care of horses with\nrespect to good health care and recognizing and\nresponding to disease and injury situations.\n498 Nihon University Seminar 2 (1-3) Course\nPrerequisite: By permission only; fourth or\nfifth year veterinary DVM students from Nihon\nUniversity. Lectures and laboratory sessions\nin small animal, exotic animal, and equine\nveterinary medicine and surgery. S, F grading.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. Course Prerequisite:\nAdmission to Veterinary Science Immunology\nand Infectious Diseases Ph.D. program.\nMicrobiology laboratory for performing and\ninterpreting virologic, serologic, and related\ntests for the diagnosis of animal diseases.\n563 Deconstruction of Research 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Graduate standing in a WSU\nbiomedical based graduate program. Nature\nand development of scientific investigation\nthrough oral and written avenues, and\nmethods of critical analyses applied to\nquestions of biomedical interest. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as NEUROSCI 563, GLANHLTH\n563, MBIOS 563, VET MICR 563, VET PATH\n563, VET PH 563).\n564 Topics in Biomedical Experimentation\nV 1-3 May be repeated for credit; cumulative\nmaximum 6 hours. S, U\ngrading.\nProgram in Women’s,\nGender, and Sexuality\nStudies\nwgss.wsu.edu\nAvery Hall 202\n509-335-2581\nDirector and Associate Professor, P. Thoma (English);\nProfessors, P. Boag (History, Vancouver), D. Campbell\n(English), R. Christopher (English, Vancouver),\nM. Diversi (Human Development, Vancouver), P.\nGlazebrook (Philosophy), M. Johnson (Sociology),\nJ. Kmec (Sociology), P. Kwon (Psychology), D.\nLee (English) L. Mercier (History, Vancouver), S.\nPeabody (History, Vancouver), D. Potts (English), J.\nSherman (Sociology), C. Siegel (English, Vancouver),\nE. Soliday (Human Development, Vancouver);\nAssociate Professors, A. Boyd (English), J. Cassaniti\n(Anthropology), L. Gordillo, (History, Vancouver), L.\nHeidenreich (History), J. Lupinacci (Education), M.-A.\nNeuilly (Criminal Justice and Criminology), E. Schwartz\n(Mathematics and Statistics and School of Biological\nSciences), N. Shahani (English); Assistant Professors,\nT. Burkhard (Human Development, Vancouver), K.\nLeupp (Sociology, Vancouver), A. Salazar (Human\nDevelopment, Vancouver); Clinical Associate Professor,\nB. Duell (Psycology); Scholarly Associate Professors, L.\nRusso (English), K. Robertson (English, Vancouver), M.\nSciachitano (English); Teaching Associate Professor,\nM. Parkhurst (Music); Scholarly Assistant Professor,\nB. Hewlett (Anthropology, Vancouver); Instructor, A.\nSpradlin (Psychology).\nWomen’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies (WGSS) is\nan interdisciplinary field of research and teaching\nthat places gender and sexuality at the center of\ninquiry. In WGSS courses students work together\nto explore the ways that race, ethnicity, sexuality,\nsocial class, nationality, age, and ability intersect\nto shape gendered experience, injustice, and social\nchange. Using an intersectional lens, students\ngain expertise in analyzing gendered social roles\nand the ways in which they affect personal lives,\nartistic expression, work, relationships, institutional\nstructures, the production of knowledge, and\nnational and international political and economic\nrelations. WGSS offers a Bachelor of Arts in Women’s\nStudies, and minors in Women’s Studies and Queer\nStudies. The program is administered through\nthe Department of English. Students interested\nin declaring a major or minor should contact\nthe program director, Pamela Thoma, associate\nprofessor of English.\nStudent Learning Outcomes\n• Recognizes intersections of race, class, gender,\nsexuality, and ability in the social construction and\nperpetuation of structural inequities and injustice.\n• Understands intersectionality as a critical\nframework for analyzing structural inequalities and\nfor recognizing the complexity of social identity.\n• Analyzes social norms and assumptions to\nenvision alternative, socially just relations,\npractices, and policies.\n• Asks critical questions to understand problems\nand formulate viable research plan.\n• Accesses information tools to identify relevant\ncontext, scholarship, and support for developing\narguments and strategies for social justice.\n• Examines the influence of historical context on\nthe formation of local, national, and global cultural\nnarratives and political narratives struggles.\n• Identifies the key texts of feminist and\nqueer studies and applies key concepts of the\ninterdiscipline.\n• Demonstrates critical oral and written\ncommunication skills in the use of scholarly sources\nin women’s, gender, and sexuality studies.\nFor more information, please see degree options\nat https://wgss.wsu.edu/degree-options/.\nSchedules of Studies\nHonors students complete the Honors\nCollege requirements which replace the\nUCORE requirements.\nWOMEN’S STUDIES\n(120 HOURS)\nA student may be admitted to the Women’s Studies\nmajor upon making their intention known to the\nprogram. The major in Women’s Studies requires\na minimum of 36 credits, of which 15 credits\nare required in the major, 12 credits are required\nin Field Electives, and 9 credits are required in\nInterdisciplinary Electives. 15 credits of electives\nmust be at the 300-400 level.\nFirst Year\nFirst Term Hours\nBiological Sciences [BSCI] with lab\n1 \n4\nENGLISH 101 [WRTG] 3\nSocial Sciences \n13\n_______\n1 \nTo meet University and College of Arts and\nSciences requirements, students must take a [BSCI]\ncourse with lab and [PSCI] course with lab.\n2 \nWomen’s Studies Field and Interdisciplinary\nElectives (21 credits): 12 credits of Field Electives\nand 9 credits of Interdisciplinary Electives required.\n15 of the 21 credits must be at the 300-400 level\nWashington State University, 2021\nVeterinary Microbiology and Pathology\n\n399\nand to meet University requirements electives must\ninclude one [M] course. Courses may not be used to\nfulfill more than one requirement.\n3 \nWOMEN ST Field Electives (12 credits): Approved\ncourses include WOMEN ST 101, 120, 220, 301 ,\n321, 338, 340, 406, 410, 460, 477, 485 [M], 499;\nCRM J/WOMEN ST 403; ENGLISH/WOMEN ST\n309, 317; WOMEN ST 332/ANTH 317; WOMEN\nST/ENGLISH 211; WOMEN ST/ENGLISH/SOC 300\n[M];WOMEN ST/HISTORY 336, 369; WOMEN ST/\nSOC 302.\n4 \nElectives: Students are encouraged to pursue an\nadditional major, minor, or certificate. Electives\nshould include sufficient 300-400-level coursework\nto meet the University requirements of 40 upper-\ndivision credits.\n5 \nTwo years of high school foreign language or at\nleast two semesters of college-level foreign language\nare required by the College of Arts and Sciences for\ngraduation.\n6 \nWomen’s Studies Interdisciplinary Electives (9\nCredits): Approved courses include AMDT/WOMEN\nST 422; AMER ST/DTC/ENGLISH 475; AMER ST/\nENGLISH/HISTORY/WOMEN ST 216; ANTH/\nWOMEN ST 316; BIOLOGY 307; CES 435, 454; CES/\nANTH 312; CES/WOMEN ST 411; COM/WOMEN ST\n464; ENGLISH/WOMEN ST 306 [M]; ENGLISH 483/\nWOMEN ST 382; FINE ART/WOMEN ST 308 [M],\n310 [M]; HISTORY/CES 235; HISTORY/WOMEN ST\n398, 399; MUS/WOMEN ST 363; PHIL/WOMEN ST\n425; POL S 305/WOMEN ST 305; PSYCH/WOMEN\nST 230, 324; SOC/WOMEN ST 251, 351, 384, 390;\nWOMEN ST/PHIL 462 [M].\nMinors\nQueer Studies\nCompletion of the minor in Queer Studies requires\na minimum of 16 credits with a 2.0 GPA. At least\n9 credits must be from upper-division courses\nand taken in residence at WSU or through WSU-\napproved education abroad or educational exchange\ncourses.\nRequired core courses (9 credits): WOMEN ST 101\nor 120, 369 or 385, and 485.\nElectives: A minimum of 7 credits from any\nWOMEN ST courses, except those used as required\ncourses.\nWomen’s Studies\nCompletion of the minor in Women’s Studies\nrequires a minimum of 16 credits with a 2.0 GPA.\nAt least 9 credits must be from upper-division\ncourses and taken in residence at WSU or through\nWSU-approved education abroad or educational\nexchange courses.\nRequired core courses (9 credits): WOMEN ST\n101 or 120; WOMEN ST 300, 332, 369, or 385; and\nWOMEN ST 481.\nElectives: A minimum of 7 credits of any WOMEN\nST courses, except those used as required courses.\nDescription of Courses\nWOMEN’S STUDIES\nWOMEN ST\n101 [DIVR] Introduction to Women’s,\nGender, and Sexuality Studies 3 Analysis\nof gender and power in contemporary society\nfrom perspectives of different racial, ethnic and\nsocioeconomic groups.\n120 [DIVR] Sex, Race, and Reproduction\nin Global Health Politics 3 Examination\nof how cultures, institutions, states, and\neconomies influence reproductive health\ninequalities around gender, sexuality, race,\nclass, and national identity.\n211 [HUM] Sex Matters: Introduction\nto Queer Culture and Literature 3\nIntroduction to Lesbian/queer cultural\nproduction focusing on popular culture,\nfiction, and film; work from various queer\ncommunities in its cultural/historical context.\n(Crosslisted course offered as WOMEN ST 211,\nENGLISH 211).\n216 Introduction to American Cultural\nStudies 3 Introduction to the interdisciplinary\nstudy of American cultures and the field of\nAmerican studies. (Crosslisted course offered\nas AMER ST 216, CES 216, ENGLISH 216,\nHISTORY 216, WOMEN ST 216).\n220 [DIVR] Gender, Culture and Science 3\nAnalysis of intersections of gender, sexuality,\nrace, and culture with science and technology.\n230 Human Sexuality 3 Sexuality in personal\ndevelopment; personal, cultural, biological\ninfluences on sexual identification and\nbehavior; fertility, reproduction, sexual\nfunctioning, sexuality and personality.\n(Crosslisted course offered as PSYCH 230,\nWOMEN ST 230). Recommended preparation:\nPSYCH 105.\n251 [ D I V R ] T h e S o c i o l o g y o f S e x ,\nRelationships, and Marriage 3 Social\nand personal factors in mate selection; the\nsociology of sexuality; development of\ngender roles; and intimate relationships and\nmarriage. (Crosslisted course offered as SOC\n251, WOMEN ST 251).\n260 Rhetoric and Gender 3 Historical survey\nof women writers whose contributions\ndistinguish them as rhetoricians of their time.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ENGLISH 260,\nWOMEN ST 260).\n277 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n298 [DIVR] History of Women in American\nSociety 3 Exploration of the many roles\nwomen have played in American society from\nthe Colonial period through the twentieth\ncentury. (Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY\n298, WOMEN ST 298).\n300 [DIVR] [M] Intersections of Race,\nClass, Gender, and Sexuality 3 Course\nPrerequisite: SOC 101 or WOMEN ST\n101. Intersections between race, class and\ngender through case studies; experiences in\ninterdisciplinary methods. (Crosslisted course\noffered as WOMEN ST 300, ENGLISH 310, SOC\n300).\n301 Introduction to Critical Race Feminism\n3 Studies structural inequalities in the US\nthrough historically grounded analysis of\nsocial systems, race, gender, and the law.\n302 Contemporary Masculinities 3 Analysis\nof the development of masculinity in its\nbiological and cultural forms. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as WOMEN ST 302, SOC 302).\n305 Gender and Politics 3 Role of gender\nin political behavior; voting and political\nparticipation; women as subjects and objects\nof political systems. (Crosslisted course offered\nas POL S 305, WOMEN ST 305).\n306 [M] Introduction to Literary Criticism\n3 Introduction to the systematic study of\ncritical and theoretical approaches to literature;\nemphasis on problems of interpretation.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ENGLISH 308,\nWOMEN ST 306).\n307 [DIVR] Biology of Women 3 Course\nPrerequisite: BIOLOGY 102 or 106. Biological\nbasis of sex and its relationship to body\nfunction, women and health care, and the\nimpact of social and cultural perspectives on\nthe experience of being female. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as BIOLOGY 307, WOMEN ST\n307).\n308 [M] Women Artists I 3 Women artists of\nthe Middle Ages through the 18th century.\n(Crosslisted course offered as FINE ART 308,\nWOMEN ST 308).\n309 Women Writers 3 Women’s artistic and\nintellectual contributions to prose, fiction,\ndrama, and poetry. (Crosslisted course offered\nas ENGLISH 309, WOMEN ST 309).\n310 [M] Women Artists II 3 Women artists of\nthe 19th to 20th century. (Crosslisted course\noffered as FINE ART 310, WOMEN ST 310).\n316 [DIVR] Gender in Cross Cultural\nPerspective 3 Cross-cultural examination\nof the status and roles of women and men,\nsexuality and marriage, and folk concepts\nof sexual anatomy in traditional cultures\nin Western science; concepts of nature and\nculture are explored through a variety of\nperspectives. (Crosslisted course offered as\nANTH 316, WOMEN ST 316). Recommended\npreparation: Sophomore standing; ANTH 101,\nPSYCH 105, SOC 101, or WOMEN ST 101 or\n201.\n317 Gay and Lesbian Literature 3 Gay and\nlesbian literature with focus on the history\nof homosexual literature and exploration of\ncurrent authors. (Crosslisted course offered as\nENGLISH 317, WOMEN ST 317).\n321 Topics in Women’s Studies V 1-3 May be\nrepeated for credit; cumulative maximum 9\nhours. Focused study of subjects/issues relating\nto women.\nWashington State University, 2021\nWomen’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies\n\n400\n324 Psychology of Gender 3 Contemporary\noverview of the psychological theory and\nresearch on sex and gender. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as PSYCH 324, WOMEN ST 324).\nRecommended preparation: PSYCH 105.\n332 Global Feminisms 3 Course Prerequisite:\nANTH 101, WOMEN ST 101, or WOMEN\nST 201. An interdisciplinary approach to\nexamining women’s roles and experiences\nthroughout the world and different approaches\nto feminism/feminisms. (Crosslisted course\noffered as WOMEN ST 332, ANTH 317).\n335 [DIVR] Women in Latin American\nHistory 3 Survey of women’s changing roles\nthroughout Latin America from pre colonial to\npresent. (Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY\n335, WOMEN ST 335).\n336 History of Sexualities 3 Historical analysis\nof the social construction of sexualities in\nintersection with race and class within national\nand transnational contexts. (Crosslisted course\noffered as WOMEN ST 336, HISTORY 336).\n338 [HUM] Gender, Race, and Popular\nCulture 3 Feminist study of intersections\nof gender, race, class, sexuality, and ability\nthrough popular film, television, digital media,\nart, literature, and performance.\n340 Third World Women and Film 3 Focus\non the intersections of race, gender, class,\nsexuality, and nation in third world women’s\nfilms.\n350 European Women’s History, 1400-1800\n3 Women’s experiences in Europe from the\nRenaissance to the Enlightenment and the\nideas and roles that shaped their opportunities.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY 350,\nWOMEN ST 350).\n351 [DIVR] The Family 3 Family system and\nits interaction patterns; family formation and\ndissolution; marital and partner relations,\ndivorce, sexuality, parenting, work-family\nbalance. (Crosslisted course offered as SOC\n351, WOMEN ST 351). Recommended\npreparation: SOC 101.\n363 [DIVR] Women in Music 3 Intersections of\ngender, class, race, and culture with popular\nand country music. (Crosslisted course offered\nas MUS 363, WOMEN ST 363).\n369 [ARTS] Queer Identities in Contemporary\nCultures 3 Course Prerequisite: CES 101,\nHISTORY 105, HISTORY 305, WOMEN ST\n101, or WOMEN ST 120. Analysis of roots/\nlegacies of creative resistance writing by\nQueer communities of color; students learn to\nproduce creative resistance work. (Crosslisted\ncourse offered as WOMEN ST 369, HISTORY\n369).\n382 American Literature: 1940-Present 3\nCourse Prerequisite: ENGLISH 302. Advanced\nstudy of major authors and movements from\nthe period including O’Connor, Bellow,\nSalinger, Baldwin, Pynchon, Morrison, Tan,\nand Alexie. (Crosslisted course offered as\nENGLISH 482, WOMEN ST 382).\n384 Sociology of Gender 3 Construction and\nmaintenance of gender and gender inequality\nin American society. (Crosslisted course offered\nas SOC 384, WOMEN ST 384). Recommended\npreparation: SOC 101.\n385 [DIVR] Introduction to Lesbian, Gay,\nBisexual, and Transgender Studies\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing.\nInterdisciplinary exploration of issues related to\ngender and sexuality, explored transhistorically\nand cross-culturally, including race, class and\nage differences. (Crosslisted course offered as\nWOMEN ST 385, SOC 385).\n390 Gender and Work 3 Gender and inequality\nat work including occupational segregation,\nwage inequality and balancing work and\nfamily. (Crosslisted course offered as SOC 390,\nWOMEN ST 390).\n398 [DIVR] History of Women in the\nAmerican West 3 The multicultural history of\nwomen in the west through women’s literature,\narchives, and oral history. (Crosslisted course\noffered as HISTORY 398, WOMEN ST 398).\n399 [DIVR] Lesbian and Gay History: Culture,\nPolitics and Social Change in the US 3\nHistory and theory of same-sex sexuality in\nthe United States including identity formation,\ncommunity development, politics and culture.\n(Crosslisted course offered as HISTORY 399,\nWOMEN ST 399).\n403 [CAPS] Violence Toward Women 3 Course\nPrerequisite: Junior standing. Violence toward\nwomen and its relationship to broader social\nissues such as sexism and social control.\n(Crosslisted course offered as CRM J 403,\nWOMEN ST 403).\n406 Women and Work In Global Contexts\n3 An interdisciplinary approach to women’s\nlabor in global contexts that analyzes\ndifferences among women as well as possible\nshared interests.\n409 Women Writers in the American West\n3 Course Prerequisite: Junior standing.\nDiversity of writings by women in the trans-\nMissouri West from the 1890s to the present.\n(Crosslisted course offered as ENGLISH 409,\nWOMEN ST 409).\n410 Internship V 1-12 May be repeated for\ncredit; cumulative maximum 12 hours. Course\nPrerequisite: WOMEN ST 101 or 201; WOMEN\nST 300 with a B or better, or 481 with a B or\nbetter; by interview only. Supervised experience\nin approved campus or community agencies or\nprojects focusing on women’s issues.\n411 Asian Pacific American Women 3 Course\nPrerequisite: CES or WOMEN ST course; junior\nstanding. Intersection of ethnicity, race, class,\ngender and sexuality in the lives of Asian\nPacific American women. (Crosslisted course\noffered as CES 411, WOMEN ST 411).\n422 [DIVR] Fat Studies 3 Course Prerequisite:\nJunior standing. Examination of weight based\noppression as a social justice issue with other\nsystems of oppression based on gender, race,\nclass, age, sexual orientation, and ability.\n(Crosslisted course offered as AMDT 422,\nWOMEN ST 422).\n425 Philosophy and Feminism 3 Course\nPrerequisite: PHIL 101, WOMEN ST 101, or\nWOMEN ST 120. Feminist philosophy as\ncritique of Western philosophical tradition\nand as alternate framework for thought.\n(Crosslisted course offered as PHIL 425, POL S\n425, WOMEN ST 425).\n460 Gender, Race, and Nature in American\nCulture 3 Course Prerequisite: WOMEN ST\n101, 201, or 300; junior standing. Exploration\nof American culture through examination\nof cultural representations of nature in\nmainstream and environmental politics.\n462 [M] Women and Ethics 3 Course Prerequisite:\nPHIL 101, WOMEN ST 101, or WOMEN ST 201.\nStudy of gender and feminism and their effect\non contemporary ethical theories and issues.\n(Crosslisted course offered as WOMEN ST 462,\nPHIL 462). Cooperative: Open to UI degree-\nseeking students.\n464 Gender and the Media 3 Course Prerequisite:\nAdmitted to any major; sophomore standing.\nHow news and entertainment media shape\nand reinforce societal expectations of gender;\nconsideration of race, age, class, and sexual\norientation. (Crosslisted course offered as COM\n464, WOMEN ST 464).\n477 Special Topics: Study Abroad V 1-15 May\nbe repeated for credit. S, F grading.\n481 [M] Feminist Theory 3 Course Prerequisite:\nWOMEN ST 101, 201, or 300. Introduction to\nthe field of feminist theory, including classic\ninterdisciplinary methods, and applications\nof this scholarship to contemporary women’s\nissues.\n485 [M] Theoretical Issues in Queer Studies\n3 Course Prerequisite: WOMEN ST 484 or\n300-400-level WOMEN ST course. Theoretical\nconstruction and interpretation of sexualities,\ngender, and identity.\n495 [CAPS] Re-Directions in Women’s,\nGender, and Sexuality Studies: Theory\nand Practice 3 Course Prerequisite: WOMEN\nST 385, WOMEN ST 481, and admitted to the\nmajor in Women’s Studies; senior standing; or\nadmitted to the minor in Women’s Studies or\nQueer Studies, and department permission.\nSeminar-style culminating experience\nin synthesizing prior learning and new\nscholarship for application of theory and\npractice; written and oral communication of\noriginal final project research.\n499 Special Problems V 1-4 May be repeated\nfor credit. Independent study conducted\nunder the jurisdiction of an approving faculty\nmember; may include independent research\nstudies in technical or specialized problems;\nselection and analysis of specified readings;\ndevelopment of a creative project; or field\nexperiences. S, F grading.\nWashington State University, 2021\nWomen’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies"
